<L>817<pc>023-b<k1>aj<k2>aj (aja-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet)
{#aj (aja-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet)#}¦ r. 1st cl. par. ({#ajati#}.
The tenses which require ārdhadhātuka affixes, are not
to be formed of this radical, {#vI#} (q. v.) being then con-
sidered as a substitute, of which the formation is to take
place. According to others, however, there may be found.
perf. {#AjiTa-#} fut. {#ajitA-ajizyati-#} aor. {#AjIt-#} cond.
{#Ajizyat#}. Pass. {#ajyate-#} fut. {#ajitA-ajizyate-#} prec. {#aji-#}
{#zIzwa-#} aor. {#Ajizwa#}. Des. {#ajijizati#}.) <sup>1</sup> To go. <sup>2</sup> To throw
or cast, to impel. With <sup>1</sup> {#acCa-#} To impel to. <sup>2</sup> {#apa-#} To
send away. <sup>3</sup> {#aBi-#} To impel to. <sup>4</sup> {#ava-#} To send down.
<sup>5</sup> {#A-#} To direct hither (trans. and intrans.), to fetch, to
scatter. <sup>6</sup> {#A#} pref. {#aBi- (aByA-)#} To direct hither. <sup>7</sup> {#ud-#}
To drive out, to draw out. <sup>8</sup> {#upa-#} To direct near. <sup>9</sup> {#nir-#}
To drive out. <sup>10</sup> {#vi-#} To throw asunder, to scatter. <sup>11</sup> {#sam-#}
To throw or send together.
<LEND>

<L>818<pc>023-b<k1>aja<k2>aja
{#aja#}¦ I. 1. m. ({#-jaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The mover, the instigator. <sup>2</sup> As such,
this word occurs in the Vedas, for the most part in con-
junction with {#ekapAd#} (q. v.), as an epithet or as a syno-
nyme of <sup>a.</sup> Indra, <sup>b.</sup> Rudra, one of the Maruts, <sup>c.</sup> Agni,
<sup>d.</sup> Pūṣan or Sūrya; in the epic and paurāṇik literature as
a synonyme of <sup>a.</sup> Brahmā (see also {#ajana#}), <sup>b.</sup> Viṣṇu, <sup>c.</sup> Śiva,
<sup>d.</sup> Kāma; in philosophical texts, in its feminine form ({#ajA#})
as a synonyme of <sup>a.</sup> Prakṛti or Nature, <sup>b.</sup> Māyā or Illusion,
the unreality of Nature or Universe. <sup>3</sup> A proper name,
viz. <sup>a.</sup> A descendant of Viśvāmitra. <sup>b.</sup> A prince of the solar
race, the son of Raghu and father of Daśaratha, or ac-
cording to others, the grandson of Raghu, the son of Di-
līpa and father of Dīrghabāhu; or the son of Nābhāga and
father of Daśaratha. <sup>4</sup> A he-goat. This animal was con-
sidered as the vehicle of Pūṣan, the sun, (see {#ajASva#})
and also as consecrated to Agni and Soma conjointly. <sup>5</sup> (In
astronomy.) The sign Aries. <sup>6</sup> The name of a mineral sub-
stance. See {#mAkzika#} and {#ajanAmaka#}. <sup>7</sup> A kind of rice, three
or seven years old(?). <sup>8</sup> The moon(?).
<div n="P">2. m. pl. ({#-jAH#}) The name of <sup>a.</sup> a sort of Ṛṣis in
Brahma's heaven; <sup>b.</sup> a people mentioned in the Vedas.
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-jA#}) <sup>1</sup> Prakṛti or Nature. <sup>2</sup> Māyā or Illusion
[Page024-a+ 56]
(see {#aja#} m.). <sup>3</sup> A she-goat. <sup>4</sup> The name of a plant, the
bulbs of which resemble the udder of a she-goat. E. {#aj,#}
kṛt aff. {#ac;#} in the fem. with the aff. {#wAp#}. 1. 4. and 2. 3.
implying ‘the quick animal’.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Unborn. This mean-
ing has been applied to {#aja#} in the sense of Brahmā,
Viṣṇu, Śiva, Kāma, and {#ajA#} in the sense of Prakṛti
and Māyā. But see before. E. {#a#} neg. and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>819<pc>024-a<k1>ajaka<k2>ajaka
{#ajaka#}¦ I. m. ({#-kaH#}) A proper name: <sup>1</sup> A descendant of Purū-
ravas, the son of Sumantu (or according to others of Su-
naha) and grandson of Jahnu. <sup>2</sup> A king of Magadha, of
the line of Pradyota.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-kA#}) <sup>1</sup> A young she-goat. (Also {#ajikA#}.) <sup>2</sup> A
kind of disease of the pupil of the eye. See {#ajakAjAta#}.
E. {#aja,#} taddh. aff. {#ka#}.
<LEND>

<L>820<pc>024-a<k1>ajakarRa<k2>ajakarRa
{#ajakarRa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-rRaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The ear of a goat. <sup>2</sup> A tree (Ter-
minalia alata tomentosa, Rox.); the leaf being compared
to the ear of a goat. See also {#asana#}. E. {#aja#} and {#karRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>821<pc>024-a<k1>ajakarRaka<k2>ajakarRaka
{#ajakarRaka#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) A tree, vulg. Sāl (Shorea robusta, Rox.).
See {#sAla#}. E. taddh. {#kan#} affixed to the preceding, denoting
resemblance.
<LEND>

<L>822<pc>024-a<k1>ajakava<k2>ajakava
{#ajakava#}¦ m. ({#-vaH#}) The bow of Śiva. E. unknown; the follow-
ing is evidently artificial: {#aja#} Viṣṇu, and {#ka#} Brahmā,
taddh. aff. {#va,#} Brahmā being placed in the centre, and
Viṣṇu on the upper part. See also {#ajakAva-ajagava-aja-#}
{#gAva-ajIkava-Ajagava#}.
<LEND>

<L>823<pc>024-a<k1>ajakAjAta<k2>ajakAjAta
{#ajakAjAta#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tam#}) A disease of the transparent cor-
nea of the eye: small tumors like the litter of goats, slightly
red, which protrude through the cornea, from which a bloody
discharge proceeds mixed with pus. E. {#ajakA#} and {#jAta#}.
<LEND>

<L>824<pc>024-a<k1>ajakAva<k2>ajakAva
{#ajakAva#}¦ I. m. n. ({#-vaH-vam#}) The bow of Śiva; see {#ajakava#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-vaH#}) A poisonous little animal.
<div n="P">III. n. ({#-vam#}) A sacrificial vessel consecrated to Mitra
and Varuna. E. doubtful. Perhaps this word is derived
from {#ajakA,#} taddh. aff. {#va,#} III. being explained as a vessel
having a piece of wood in the shape of the throat nipples
of a goat and II. as an animal poisonous or deadly as the
disease {#ajakA#}.
<LEND>

<L>825<pc>024-a<k1>ajakUlA<k2>ajakUlA
{#ajakUlA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-lA#}) The name of a town of the Bodhis.
E. {#aja#} and {#kUla#}.
<LEND>

<L>831<pc>024-a<k1>ajagara<k2>ajagara

<L>832<pc>024-a<k1>ajagallikA<k2>ajagallikA
{#ajagallikA#}¦ f. ({#-kA#}) One of the ‘minor diseases’; it occurs in
children and consists of small tuberculous eruptions of the
form of peas. E. {#ajagalla#} (cheek of a goat), taddh. aff. {#kan#}.

<L>833<pc>024-b<k1>ajagava<k2>ajagava
{#ajagava#}¦ n. ({#-vam#}) <sup>1</sup> The bow of Śiva. See {#ajakAva#}. <sup>2</sup> The
southern portion of the three portions into which the path
of the sun and other planets amongst the lunar asterisms
is divided. See {#jaradgava#}. E. {#ajaga#} (the meaning of this word
is not given), taddh. aff. {#va#}. See the E. of {#ajakAva#}.

<L>841<pc>024-b<k1>ajadaRqI<k2>ajadaRqI

<L>843<pc>024-b<k1>ajana<k2>ajana

<L>848<pc>024-b<k1>ajanya<k2>ajanya
{#ajanya#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-nyaH-nyA-nyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not to be born
or produced. <sup>2</sup> Not fit for or favourable to men.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-nyam#}) A portent, an omen, any natural pheno-
menon as an earthquake &c. so considered. E. {#a#} neg.
and {#janya#}.
<LEND>

<L>849<pc>024-b<k1>ajapa<k2>ajapa
{#ajapa#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) 1. A goat-herd. E. {#aja#} and {#pa#}.
<div n="P">2. A reader of works considered heterodox. E. {#a#} deter.
and {#japa#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. f. ({#-pA#}) The name of a particular mantra or
mystical formula, otherwise bearing the name of Hansa.
E. {#a#} priv. and {#japa;#} so called from its not consisting of a
{#japa#} or a prayer repeated inaudibly, like other mantras,
but of a certain number of inhalations and exhalations.
<LEND>

<L>850<pc>024-b<k1>ajapaTa<k2>ajapaTa
{#ajapaTa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-TaH#}) Probably the same as {#ajavITI#}
q. v. E. {#aja#} and {#paTin,#} samāsānta aff. {#a,#} ‘like a goat's
road’; the taddh. aff. {#kan#} which implies similarity, being
considered as dropped in this word.
<LEND>

<L>875<pc>025-b<k1>ajavITI<k2>ajavITI
{#ajavITI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-TI#}) One of the three divisions of the
southern portion (see {#ajagava#} or {#jaradgava#}), one of the three
portions into which the path of the sun and other planets
amongst the lunar asterisms is divided. It comprises the
three asterisms Mūlā, Pūrvāṣāḍhā and Uttarāṣāḍhā. E.
{#aja#} and {#vITI#} ‘goat's road’. See also {#ajapaTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>876<pc>025-b<k1>ajaSfNgI<k2>ajaSfNgI
{#ajaSfNgI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-NgI#}) A plant; described as a milky and
thorny plant, with a fruit of a crooked figure, like a ram's
horn, and used as a medicine for the eyes; vulg. Mera
Śriṅgī, and Kankara Śriṅgī (Odina Wodier Rox.). See
{#karkkawaSfNgI#}. E. {#aja#} and {#SfNga#}.

<L>878<pc>025-b<k1>ajasra<k2>ajasra
{#ajasra#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-sraH-srA-sram#}) Continual, unin-
terrupted.
<div n="P">II. ind. ({#-sram#}) Eternally, continually, always. E. {#a#}

<L>879<pc>025-b<k1>ajahatsvArTA<k2>ajahatsvArTA
{#ajahatsvArTA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-rTA#}) A figure of speech, the cha-
racteristic of the {#upAdAnalakzaRA#} q. v. It consists in using
a word in an elliptic meaning without depriving it of its
primary sense; in such phrases as {#Sveto DAvati#} or {#kuntAH#}
{#praviSanti,#} are to be supplied {#aSva#} &c. in the former, {#pu-#}
{#ruza#} &c. in the latter, so as to impart the sense of ‘a white
horse gallops’, ‘the men with lances enter’, while {#Sveta#}
and {#kunta#} retain their original sense. See, on the contrary,
{#jahatsvArTA#}.--E. {#a#} neg. and {#jahatsvArTA,#} scil. {#lakzaRA#}.
<LEND>

<L>880<pc>025-b<k1>ajahalliNga<k2>ajahalliNga
{#ajahalliNga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-NgaH#}) (In grammar.) A noun that does
not vary its gender, even when it is used attributively.
E. {#a#} neg. and {#jahalliNga,#} scil. {#Sabda#}.
<LEND>

<L>910<pc>026-a<k1>ajita<k2>ajita
{#ajita#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unconquered. <sup>2</sup> Un-
excelled, unsurpassed.
[Page026-b+ 56]
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-taH#}) <sup>1</sup> The proper name of several gods and per-
sons, viz. <sup>a.</sup> Viṣṇu. <sup>b.</sup> Śiva. <sup>c.</sup> One of the seven Ṛṣis
who preside during the reign of the fourteenth Manu. <sup>d.</sup> A
name of Maitreya or a future Buddha. <sup>e.</sup> The second of
the Arhats or Jaina saints of the present Avasarpiṇī,
a descendant of Ikṣvāku and a son of Jitaśatru by Vijayā.
<sup>f.</sup> The attendant of Suvidhi or the ninth Jaina Arhat of the
present Avasarpiṇī. <sup>2</sup> The name of a powerful antidote.
<sup>3</sup> A kind of poisonous rat.
<div n="P">III. m. pl. ({#-tAH#}) A particular class of gods in the reign
of the first Manu, the same as the {#jayAH#} in a former life.
E. {#a#} neg. and {#jita#}.
<LEND>

<L>911<pc>026-b<k1>ajitabalA<k2>ajitabalA
{#ajitabalA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-lA#}) The name of one of the Śāsana-
devatās, a class of divinities particular to the Jainas, who
are supposed to carry out the commands of the Arhats.
E. {#ajita#} and {#bala#}.
<LEND>

the second. E. {#ajita#} and {#vikrama#} ‘of invincible strength’.

<L>916<pc>026-b<k1>ajina<k2>ajina
{#ajina#}¦ I. n. ({#-nam#}) The hide of a tiger, lion &c., but more
especially of the antilope or the black species of it (see
{#ajinayoni#} and {#kfzRAjina#}) and particularly appropriated
to the religious student as a garment, seat, bed &c.

son of Havirdhāna by Dhiṣaṇā. E. {#aj,#} uṇ. aff. {#inac;#}
but it would seem that I. is derived from {#aja,#} with taddh.
aff. {#inac#}.

<L>971<pc>027-b<k1>aYc<k2>aYc
{#aYc#}¦ I. 1. ({#ancu-BvAdi-udAtta-svaritet#}) r. 1st cl. par. and
ātm. ({#aYcati-te-AnaYca-ce-aYcitA-acyAt-aktvA#} p. p. {#akta#}.
Pass. {#acyate#} and {#aYcyate#}. Desid. {#aYcicizati-te#}.--Caus.
{#aYcayati#}). <sup>1</sup> To go. <sup>2</sup> To ask, to beg. <sup>3</sup> To speak indis-
tinctly.--With {#apa-#} To go away; caus. to send away.
--{#ud-#} To rise; caus. to raise, to draw up.--{#upa-#}
To approach.--{#ni-#} To go down.--{#pari-#} To go round,
to turn round.--{#vi-#} To approach in different ways;
caus. to drive asunder.--{#sam-#} caus. To impel together.
<div n="P">2. r. 1st cl. par. and ātm. ({#aYcati-te-aYcitvA-#} p. p.
[Page028-a+ 56]
{#aYcita#} and {#akna#}) To bend, to curve. With {#A-#} To bend.
--{#ni-#} To bend down.--{#vi-#} To bend asunder.--{#sam-#}
To bend together, to bend intensely.
<div n="P">3. ({#aci-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet#}) r. 1st cl. par. ({#aYca-#}
{#ti-aYcyAt-aYcitvA-#} p. p. {#aYcita#}) To honour, to worship,
to treat with respect.
<div n="P">4. ({#ancu-curAdi-parasmEpadin#}) r. 10th cl. par. ({#aYcaya-#}
{#ti#}) To make clear or distinct. With {#ud-#} The same.
<div n="P">See also {#ac#}.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. n. ({#-N-cI-k#}) Going.
<div n="P">2. m. f. n. ({#-N-YcI-k#}) Honouring, worshipping.
<div n="P">This word occurs only as the latter part of several,
in most instances irregular compounds, the former part of
which is, in the classic dialect, restricted to some prepo-
sitions and indeclinables; see f. i. {#avAYc-udaYc-nyaYc-prAYc-#}
{#samyaYc-vizvaYc-tiryaYc#}. In the Vedas it occurs also in com-
position with pronominal and nominal themes, f. i. in {#vi-#}
{#zvadryaYc-devadryaYc-GftAYc#}. When it has the meaning of ‘go-
ing’, the nasal of the root appears only in the nom.,
voc. and acc. of the sing. and du. masc., in the nom. and
voc. of the plur. masc. and neuter and in the acc. of
the plur. neuter; in all the other cases and in the formation
of the fem. it is dropped. The declension and the fem. for-
mation of {#aYc#} ‘honouring, worshipping’ is regular in re-
taining the nasal of the root. E. {#aYc,#} kṛt aff. {#kvin#}.
<LEND>

<L>972<pc>028-a<k1>aYca<k2>aYca
{#aYca#}¦ m. ({#-YcaH#}) Going. It occurs only as the latter part of
compounds; f. i. in {#romAYca#}. E. {#aYc,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>973<pc>028-a<k1>aYcati<k2>aYcati
{#aYcati#}¦ m. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Air, wind. <sup>2</sup> Fire. E. {#aYc,#} uṇ. aff. {#ati#}.

<L>979<pc>028-a<k1>aYj<k2>aYj
{#aYj#}¦ I. ({#anjU-ruDAdi-udAtta-udAttet#}) r. 7th cl. par. ({#a-#}
{#nakti-#} ved. 1st cl. {#aYjati-te-AnaYja-aYjitA#} or {#aNktA-aYji-#}
{#zyati#} or {#aNkzyati-AYjIt, AYjizuH-aYjitvA#} or {#aNktvA#} or {#aktvA-#}
p. p. {#akta#}. Desid. {#aYjijizati#}. Caus. {#aYjayati-AYjijat#}).
<sup>1</sup> To anoint. <sup>2</sup> To make clear. <sup>3</sup> To glorify, to extol. <sup>4</sup> To
go, to approach. <sup>5</sup> To be beautiful. With {#aBi-#} To anoint,
to embellish.--{#A-#} <sup>1</sup> To anoint. <sup>2</sup> To glorify, to extol.
--{#ni-pra-prati-#} To anoint, to embellish.--{#vi-#} <sup>1</sup> To
anoint. <sup>2</sup> To make clear or manifest. Caus. To cause to be-
come clear, to reveal.--{#aBivi-#} To make manifest.--
{#sam-#} <sup>1</sup> To anoint, to embellish. <sup>2</sup> To extol, to glorify. <sup>3</sup> To
join, to connect.
<div n="P">II. ({#aji-curAdi-parasmEpadin#}) r. 10th cl. ({#aYjayati#}) To
shine. (It seems to occur only in vulgar speech.)
<LEND>

<L>980<pc>028-a<k1>aYjaka<k2>aYjaka
{#aYjaka#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) A proper name: <sup>1</sup> A son of Viprachitti by
Sinhikā. <sup>2</sup> A son of Yadu. See {#aYjika#}. E. {#aYj,#} kṛt aff. {#vun#}.
<LEND>

<L>981<pc>028-a<k1>aYjana<k2>aYjana
{#aYjana#}¦ I. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Anointing, making clear or distinct &c.
See the meanings of {#aYj#}. <sup>2</sup> A collyrium or application to
[Page028-b+ 56]
the eye lashes, to darken and improve them; a universal
article of the eastern toilet. <sup>3</sup> The name of particular kinds
of the former, viz. lamp black, antimony, and one ex-
tracted from the Ammonium zanthorrhiza. <sup>4</sup> Ink. <sup>5</sup> Night.
(See {#aktu#}.) <sup>6</sup> Fire. <sup>7</sup> (In rhetoric.) Suggesting the special
meaning of a word or a sentence. The special meaning of
a word ({#Sabda#}) is suggested, according to Hindu rhetoric,
by its connexion with either the real ({#aBiDA#}) or the el-
liptic sense ({#lakzaRA#}) of other words; and the special mean-
ing of a sentence ({#arTa#}) by circumstances connected with
either the speaker or the addressed, or the occasion, place,
time or the like. More usually called {#vyaYjanA#} q. v.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-naH#}) <sup>1</sup> A species of lizard. <sup>2</sup> The elephant of the
west or, according to others, of the south-west quarter.
<sup>3</sup> The name of a fabulous serpent. <sup>4</sup> The name of a king
of Mithilā, the son of Kuni. <sup>5</sup> The name of a tree. <sup>6</sup> The
name of a mountain. See {#aYjanAgiri#}.
<div n="P">III. f. 1. ({#-nA#}) <sup>1</sup> The mother of the monkey Hanumat.
<sup>2</sup> The daughter of Vajrendra and mother of Pravarasena.
<div n="P">2. ({#-nI#}) <sup>1</sup> A woman who is fit to be perfumed with
sandal &c. <sup>2</sup> The name of a medicinal plant. See {#kawukA,#}
{#kAlAYjanI#} and {#aYjanakI#}.
<div n="P">E. {#aYj,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>982<pc>028-b<k1>aYjanaka<k2>aYjanaka
{#aYjanaka#}¦ I. m. ({#-kaH#}) A portion of the Veda, so called from
its containing the word {#aYjana#}.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-kI#}) The name of a medicinal plant. See {#aYjanI#}.
E. {#aYjana,#} taddh. aff. {#vun,#} having possessive meaning in
this instance.
<LEND>

<L>983<pc>028-b<k1>aYjanakeSI<k2>aYjanakeSI
{#aYjanakeSI#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-SI#}) A vegetable perfume. See {#hawwa-#}
{#vilAsinI#}. E. {#aYjana#} and {#keSa,#} with fem. affix {#NIp;#} the
fibres being like the crystals, perhaps, of antimony.
<LEND>

<L>984<pc>028-b<k1>aYjananAmikA<k2>aYjananAmikA
{#aYjananAmikA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-kA#}) A disease of the eyelids, a swell-
ing of the eyelids which is described as ‘being very hot, pain-
ful and of a copper colour, soft, small and with little pain’.
E. {#aYjananAman#} (Bahuvr.) samāsānta aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

made long.

<L>992<pc>028-b<k1>aYjali<k2>aYjali
{#aYjali#}¦ m. ({#-liH#}) <sup>1</sup> The two hands put together, the palms
being slightly hollowed and in near contact with each
other, when the hands are raised to the forehead as a
reverential act of salutation or adoration: when employed
in making offerings, or giving a benediction, the hands
[Page029-a+ 56]
are left open only touching by the sides of the little fingers.
<sup>2</sup> A measure, a Kuḍava, as much grain as can be held by
the two hands put together. E. {#aYj,#} uṇ. aff. {#alic#}.
<LEND>

<L>1010<pc>029-b<k1>aw<k2>aw

<L>1027<pc>029-b<k1>awwa<k2>awwa

other structures, as the back of an edifice, a fortified place
[Page030-a+ 56]
in front of a building, a room on the top of a temporary

place. (See {#hawwa#}.)

{#awwAla#}¦ m. ({#-laH#}) An upper room or pavilion, on the flat roof

{#likAbanDam#} used as ind., is explained as being derived from

<L>1062<pc>030-b<k1>aRu<k2>aRu
{#aRu#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-RuH-RuH#} or {#RvI-Ru#}) Small, minute, atomic.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-RuH#}) <sup>1</sup> An atom, a minute and elementary par-
ticle of matter. <sup>2</sup> (According to some Purāṇas) A measure
of time, consisting of two Paramāṇus; 54,675,000 aṇus are
said to be equal to one muhūrta. <sup>3</sup> A sort of grain (Pani-
cum miliaceum). See {#DAnya#}. <sup>4</sup> A name of Śiva.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-RvI#}) (ved.) A finger.
<div n="P">IV. n. ({#-Ru#}) (In prosody.) The fourth part of a {#mAtrA#}
q. v. E. {#aR,#} uṇ. aff. {#u#}.
<LEND>
[Page031-a+ 56]

out altering the meaning of {#aRu;#} in 2. with the sense of
comparison, ‘like one who sees minute objects, who is
sharp-sighted’, &c.

called {#gati#} q. v.

priv. and {#tapas,#} samāsānta aff. {#kap#}.

neg. and {#tapta#}.

<L>1113<pc>032-a<k1>atarka<k2>atarka

<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. One who employs groundless arguments, who
reasons illogically. E. {#a#} priv. and {#tarka#}.

<L>1116<pc>032-a<k1>atala<k2>atala

E. {#a#} priv. and {#tala;#} ‘bottomless’.

<L>1120<pc>032-a<k1>atas<k2>atas
{#atas#}¦ ind. <sup>1</sup> Hence, from this place. <sup>2</sup> From that time. <sup>3</sup> There-
fore, from that cause. <sup>4</sup> Used also in the same sense as
the ablative or fifth case of {#etad;#} f. i. {#ata UrDvam#} or {#ataH#}
{#param,#} after that, afterwards, from now; {#ato'nyaTA#} dif-
ferent from that; {#ato'rTAt#} from that reason, therefore.
E. {#aS#} (i. e. {#a#} considered as a substitute of {#etad#}), taddh.
aff. {#tasil#}.
<LEND>

<L>1121<pc>032-a<k1>atasa<k2>atasa
{#atasa#}¦ I. m. ({#-saH#}) <sup>1</sup> Wind, air. <sup>2</sup> The soul. <sup>3</sup> A weapon.
<sup>4</sup> Cloth made from bark. <sup>5</sup> (In the Vedas.) A tree, a
large tree.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-sI#}) <sup>1</sup> Common flax (Linum usitatissimum). <sup>2</sup> Saṇa,
Bengal sun, a kind of flax (Crotolaria juncea). E. {#at,#}
uṇ. aff. {#asac,#} when fem. with {#NIz#} added.
<LEND>

<L>1122<pc>032-a<k1>ati<k2>ati
{#ati#}¦ ind. (see {#nipAta, upasarga, gati, karmapravacanIya#}) <sup>1</sup> Over,
beyond. <sup>2</sup> Exceedingly, very much. This word is used
either as a separable preposition with a word following
in the accusative, or as an inseparable prefix in compo-
sition with verbal and nominal themes. If {#ati,#} in com-
position with a nominal theme, constitutes a Tatpur. com-
pound, it must either express a higher degree (f. i. in
{#atirAjan,#} a superior or excellent king) or the sense of
the word {#krAnta#} must be supplied after it and the latter
part of the compound understood in the sense of the accu-
[Page032-b+ 56]
sative (f. i. in {#atiKawvaH#} which is explained as meaning
{#atikrAntaH KawvAm#}). E. {#at,#} kṛt aff. {#in(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>1123<pc>032-b<k1>atikaTa<k2>atikaTa
{#atikaTa#}¦ Tatpur. I. f. ({#-TA#}) Idle or unmeaning speech.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-TaH-TA-Tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Incredible, unworthy of be-
lief or trust. <sup>2</sup> Erring, deviating from the duties of a pro-
fession or cast. E. {#ati#} and {#kaTA#}. Some works substitute
for this word the reading {#itikaTa#} q. v., which seems to be
the more correct form.
<LEND>

<L>1131<pc>032-b<k1>atikfti<k2>atikfti
{#atikfti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) A class of metres regulated by
number and quantity. See {#aticCandas#}. It comprises two
species (see {#krOYcapadA#} and {#SamBu#}) and consists of a stanza
of four lines, with twenty-five syllables in each line.
Also called {#aBikfti#}. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#kfti#} (an-
other class of metres; in the sense of the accusative).
<LEND>

<L>1135<pc>032-b<k1>atikrama<k2>atikrama

less demand, an imposition. <sup>7</sup> A gallant attack, advance
of an army in front of an enemy. (See {#aBikrama#}.) E. {#kram#}
with {#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.

<div n="P">II. m. ({#-RqaH#}) The Yoga star of the sixth lunar mansion

<L>1153<pc>033-a<k1>atigraha<k2>atigraha
{#atigraha#}¦ m. ({#-haH#}) I. Overtaking, surpassing. E. {#grah#} with
{#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. (In the philosophical terminology of the
Upanishads) that which goes beyond the grahas or the
eight instruments of apprehension i. e. the objects or func-
tions of apprehension themselves: thus with the graha {#prARa#}
(meaning there ‘the nose’) corresponds the atigraha {#apAna#}
(meaning there ‘fragrant substance’), with the graha {#vAc,#}
the atigraha {#nAman#} and likewise, with the other six grahas
{#jihvA, cakzus, Srotra, manas, hasta, tvac,#} the atigrahas {#rasa,#}
{#rUpa, Sabda, kAma, karman#} and {#sparSa#}.--Also called {#atigrAha#}.
E. {#ati#} and {#graha#} (in the sense of the accusative).
<LEND>

<L>1154<pc>033-a<k1>atigrAha<k2>atigrAha
{#atigrAha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) The same as {#atigraha#} in its philo-
sophical meaning. E. {#ati#} and {#grAha#} (in the sense of the accus.).
<LEND>

<L>1155<pc>033-a<k1>atigrAhya<k2>atigrAhya
{#atigrAhya#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-hyaH-hyA-hyam#}) Very acceptable
or agreeable.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-hyaH#}) The name of three particular grahas or
sacrificial vessels (see {#graha#}), with which libations were made
in the Jyotiṣṭoma sacrifice to Agni, Indra and Sūrya.
E. {#ati#} and {#grAhya#}.
<LEND>

<L>1156<pc>033-a<k1>atiGa<k2>atiGa
{#atiGa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-GaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A bludgeon, a weapon. <sup>2</sup> Anger,
wrath. E. {#ati#} and {#Ga#}.
<LEND>
[Page033-b+ 56]

<L>1157<pc>033-b<k1>atiGnI<k2>atiGnI
{#atiGnI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-GnI#}) The state of happiness, the state of
profound sleep. (In the terminology of the Upanishads.)
E. {#ati#} and {#Gna,#} with {#NIp#} aff., ‘destroying thoroughly all
unpleasant feelings’; sc. {#avasTA#}.
<LEND>

<L>1158<pc>033-b<k1>aticara<k2>aticara
{#aticara#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Going very much.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-rA#}) The name of a plant which grows in Bengal
(Hibiscus mutabilis). See also {#padmacAriRI, avyaTA, padmA#}
and {#cArawI#}. E. {#ati#} (very much) and {#cara,#} or {#ati#} (sc.
{#krAnta#}) and {#cara#} (going i. e. a living being, in the sense of
the accusative); the plant being called so, because ‘it grows
in impervious places and, therefore, goes beyond the reach
of living beings’.
<LEND>

<L>1159<pc>033-b<k1>aticAra<k2>aticAra
{#aticAra#}¦ m. ({#-raH#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Going over or beyond. <sup>2</sup> Surpassing,
excelling. E. {#car#} with {#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. <sup>1</sup> Going quickly. <sup>2</sup> The passage of a planet
from one zodiacal sign to another, in a shorter than ordi-
nary period. E. {#ati#} (exceedingly) and {#cAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>1160<pc>033-b<k1>aticArin<k2>aticArin
{#aticArin#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-rI-riRI-ri#}) Transgressing, surpass-
ing. E. {#car#} with {#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#GinuR,#} the affix implying
here habit or nature.
<LEND>

<L>1161<pc>033-b<k1>aticCatra<k2>aticCatra
{#aticCatra#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. ({#-traH#}) A species of mushroom. (See
{#CatrA#} and {#pAlaGna#}.)
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-trA#}) <sup>1</sup> Anise (Anethum pimpinella). <sup>2</sup> Barleria
longifolia. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAnta#}) and {#Catra#} (in the sense of
the accusative), ‘surpassing a parasol’; in the fem. with
{#wAp#} aff.
<LEND>

<L>1162<pc>033-b<k1>aticCatraka<k2>aticCatraka
{#aticCatraka#}¦ I. m. ({#-kaH#}) A mushroom. See the preceding.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-kA#}) The same as {#aticCatrA#}. E. taddh. aff. {#kan#}
added to the last.
<LEND>

<L>1163<pc>033-b<k1>aticCanda<k2>aticCanda
{#aticCanda#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ndaH-ndA-ndam#}) Without desire,
free from worldly desire. Also {#aticCandas#}. E. {#ati#} (sc.
{#krAnta#}) and {#Canda#} (in the sense of the accusative), ‘having
gone beyond desires’.
<LEND>

<L>1164<pc>033-b<k1>aticCandas<k2>aticCandas
{#aticCandas#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-ndAH-ndAH-ndaH#}) The same
as the preceding.
<div n="P">II. f. n. ({#-ndAH-ndaH#}) The name of two classes of metres
regulated by number and quantity, the first of which com-
prises the classes {#atijagatI, SakvarI, atiSakvarI, azwi,#}
{#atyazwi, Dfti, atiDfti#} (qq. vv.) and the second the classes
{#kfti, prakfti, Akfti, vikfti, saNkfti, atikfti#} (or {#aBi-#}
{#kfti#}), {#utkfti#} (qq. vv.).
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-ndAH#}) The name of one of the consecrated bricks
or iṣṭakās. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAnta#}) and {#Candas#} I. desire, II.
metre (in the sense of the accusative) ‘going or having
gone beyond desires’ and ‘going beyond the seven Chhan-
das or metres {#gAyatrI, uzRih, anuzwuB, bfhatI, paNkti, tri-#}
{#zwuB#} and {#jagatI#}’.
<LEND>

<L>1165<pc>033-b<k1>atijagatI<k2>atijagatI
{#atijagatI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tI#}) The name of a class of metres
regulated by number and quantity. See {#aticCandas#}. It
comprises sixteen varieties and consists of a stanza of
four lines, with thirteen syllables in each line. (See
<sup>1</sup> {#praharziRI,#} <sup>2</sup> {#rucirA#} (or {#atirucirA#}), <sup>3</sup> {#mattamayUra#} (or {#mA-#}
{#yA#}), <sup>4</sup> {#gOrI,#} <sup>5</sup> {#maYjuBAziRI#} (or {#praboDitA,#} or {#sunandinI,#}
or {#kanakapraBA#}), <sup>6</sup> {#candrikA#} (or {#kzamA,#} or {#utpalinI,#} or {#kuwi-#}
{#lagati#}), <sup>7</sup> {#kalahaMsa#} (or {#citravatI,#} or {#siMhanAda#}), <sup>8</sup> {#caYcarikA-#}
{#valI,#} <sup>9</sup> {#candraleKA,#} <sup>10</sup> {#vidyut,#} <sup>11</sup> {#mfgendramuKa,#} <sup>12</sup> {#tAraka,#} <sup>12</sup> {#ka-#}
[Page034-a+ 56]
{#lAkanda#} (or {#kanda#}), <sup>14</sup> {#paNkajAvalI#} (or {#paNkAvalI#}), <sup>15</sup> {#caRqI,#}
<sup>16</sup> {#praBAvatI#}.) E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#jagatI#} (in the sense
of the accusative) ‘going beyond the metre {#jagatI#} q. v.’.
<LEND>

<L>1166<pc>034-a<k1>atijana<k2>atijana
{#atijana#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) Solitary, lonely. E.
{#ati#} (in the sense of {#atigata#} or {#atyantavigata#}) and {#jana;#}
or perhaps as a Tatpur. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAnta#}) and {#jana#} (in the
sense of the accusative).
<LEND>

<L>1179<pc>034-a<k1>atityad<k2>atityad
{#atityad#}¦ Tatpur. Beyond that. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAnta#}) and {#tyad#}
(in the sense of the accusative). This word seems to be
only one of grammatical coinage, to show that the declen-
sion of {#tyad#} in compositions like these is like that of other
nouns ending in {#d#} and not that of the pronominal theme
{#tyad;#} i. e. {#atityad, atityadO#} &c. (instead of {#atisyaH,#}
{#atityO#} &c.).
<LEND>

<L>1180<pc>034-a<k1>atitvam<k2>atitvam
{#atitvam#}¦ Tatpur. m. Surpassing thee. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntaH#})
and {#tvam#} (in the sense of {#tvAm#}). This word seems to be,
like the last, only a grammatical one and scarcely in real
use; its declension is equally purely fictitious and vary-
ing, even, according to the different grammatical autho-
rities. See the following and {#atitvAm, atiyUyam,#} also
{#atyaham#}.
<LEND>

<L>1181<pc>034-a<k1>atitvAn<k2>atitvAn
{#atitvAn#}¦ Tatpur. The accus. in the plural of the preceding.
<LEND>

<L>1182<pc>034-a<k1>atitvAm<k2>atitvAm
{#atitvAm#}¦ Tatpur. The accusative in the singular and dual
of {#atitvam#}.
<LEND>
[Page034-b+ 56]

<L>1183<pc>034-b<k1>atiTi<k2>atiTi
{#atiTi#}¦ I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-TiH-TI-Ti#}) One who arrives and,
though entirely unknown, is entitled to the rites of hospi-
tality, a guest. See {#atiTin#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-TiH#}) <sup>1</sup> A proper name of a king of Ayodhyā, the
son of Kuśa and grandson of Rāma. <sup>2</sup> The vaidik name of an
attendant of Soma. (This latter meaning is more likely to
be taken in a figurative sense, Soma being mentioned as
the name of a king and Agni, Atithi, Śyena as those of his
attendants). E. {#at,#} uṇ. aff. {#iTin#}. ({#atiTi#} in the mean-
ing of ‘guest’ is also explained as a Bahuvr. ‘one who has
no kind of {#tiTi#} or holy day, who may arrive any day’
or ‘one who does not sojourn a whole tithi, but only one
single night’, or ‘one who is not steady (when {#tiTi#} is
supposed to be a mutilated form of {#sTiti#})’; all these ex-
planations are artificial.)
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. ({#-TiH#}) Wrath, anger. E. {#a#} priv. and
{#tiTi#} ‘not restricted to a tithi, what may come at any time’.
<LEND>

<L>1195<pc>034-b<k1>atidagDa<k2>atidagDa
{#atidagDa#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-gDaH-gDA-gDam#}) Very much burnt.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-gDam#}) (In med.) One of the four degrees of burns,
described in the following manner: ‘when the flesh hangs
down and the part is separated with the destruction of the
vessels, joints &c., with fever, thirst, faintness, the tumour
growing slowly and, when ripe, being colourless’. E. {#ati#}
and {#dagDa#}.

<L>1212<pc>035-a<k1>atideSa<k2>atideSa
{#atideSa#}¦ m. ({#-SaH#}) A rule providing for something more than
the ordinary or established rules (see {#pradeSa, upadeSa#}) pro-
vide for and not comprehended by them; it may be either
enjoined specially or derived from inference; if such a rule,
in grammar, affects the form, gender &c. of a word,
it is called {#rUpAtideSa, liNgAtideSa#} &c.; in philosophy
atideśas of a general or comprehensive nature are called
{#sAmAnyAtideSa#} and those restricted to a special case {#viSe-#}
{#zAtideSa#}. See also {#SAstrAtideSa, kAryAtideSa, nimittA-#}
{#tideSa, vyapadeSAtideSa#}. E. {#diS#} with {#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

{#atidoza#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-zaH#}) A great fault. E. {#ati#} and {#doza#}.

<L>1215<pc>035-a<k1>atiDfti<k2>atiDfti
{#atiDfti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of a class of metres
which are regulated by number and quantity. See {#ati-#}
{#cCandas#}. It comprises thirteen varieties and consists of
a stanza of four lines with nineteen syllables in each
line. (See <sup>1</sup> {#SArdUla#} or {#SArdUlavikrIqita,#} <sup>2</sup> {#meGavisPurjita#} or
{#vismita,#} <sup>3</sup> {#paYcacAmara,#} <sup>4</sup> {#puzpadAman,#} <sup>5</sup> {#bimbA,#} <sup>6</sup> {#CAyA,#} <sup>7</sup> {#maka-#}
{#randikA,#} <sup>8</sup> {#samudratawA,#} <sup>9</sup> {#surasA,#} <sup>10</sup> {#maRimaYjarI,#} <sup>11</sup> {#candramAlA#}
or {#candra,#} <sup>12</sup> {#DavalANka#} or {#Davala,#} <sup>13</sup> {#samBu#}.) <sup>2</sup> (In arithmetic
sometimes used to denote) the number nineteen. E. {#ati#}
(sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#Dfti#} (in the sense of the accusative) ‘going
beyond the metre {#Dfti#} q. v.’.
<LEND>

<L>1233<pc>035-b<k1>atipAtaka<k2>atipAtaka

<L>1234<pc>035-b<k1>atipAtita<k2>atipAtita
{#atipAtita#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Quite thrown,
quite driven otu.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-tam#}) (In medicine.) A dislocation, complete sepa-
ration of a limb from the body (see {#Bagna#} and {#kARqaBagna#}).
E. {#ati#} and {#pAtita#}.
<LEND>

ceeding. E. {#pat#} with {#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#GiRun#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. Passing very quick, acute (as a disease). E.
{#ati#} and {#pAtin#}.

<L>1236<pc>036-a<k1>atipAdanicft<k2>atipAdanicft
{#atipAdanicft#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-t#}) The name of a vaidik metre
regulated by the number of syllables. It is a species of the
Gāyatrī metre and consists of three Pādas of six, eight
and seven syllables in each. Also read {#atipAdanivft#}. E.
{#ati#} (sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#pAdanicft#} (or {#pAdanivft#}), in the
sense of the accusative.
<LEND>

<L>1301<pc>037-b<k1>atirAtra<k2>atirAtra
{#atirAtra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-traH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of the fifth part or Soma-
sansthā of the Jyotiṣṭoma sacrifice, for the complete per-
formance of which, however, it is not considered nitya, es-
sential or obligatory but kāmya, voluntary, viz. if the sacri-
ficer institutes it for the sake of progeny, and therefore anitya,
not always taking place, supererogatory. (See {#agnizwoma#}.)
<sup>2</sup> The usual beginning and concluding part of those Ahargaṇa
sacrifices which are called Sattra (q. v.) and the beginning or
the concluding part of those which are called Ahīna (q. v.).
There are, however, exceptions to this rule, see f. i. {#paYcadaSa-#}
{#rAtra, kuRqapAyinAmayana#}. <sup>3</sup> The name of the Sāmaveda verse
which closes the ceremonies of the sacrifices mentioned before.
<sup>4</sup> A proper name, the son of Chākṣuṣa or the sixth Manu by
Nadvalā. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntaH#}) and {#rAtri#} (in the sense of
the accusative), samāsānta aff. {#ac;#} properly meaning ‘last-
ing beyond a night’.
<LEND>

<L>1302<pc>037-b<k1>atirAtrasavanIyapaSu<k2>atirAtrasavanIyapaSu
{#atirAtrasavanIyapaSu#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SuH#}) The savanīyapaśu (q. v.)
or sacrificial animal in the Atirātra (q. v.). It is a ewe con-
secrated to Sarasvatī and subject to the regulations which
exist for the {#agnIzomIyapaSu#} (q. v.) E. {#atirAtra#} and {#sava-#}
{#nIyapaSu#}.
<LEND>

<L>1303<pc>037-b<k1>atirikta<k2>atirikta

[Page038-a+ 56]

{#cUqikA#} or {#cUlikA#}. <sup>2</sup> A metre regulated by number and
quantity; a variety of the metre {#atijagatI#} (q. v.) and con-
sisting of a stanza of four lines with the following feet
in each line: ˘¯˘¯ | ˘˘˘˘¯˘¯˘¯. Also called
{#rucirA#}. E. {#ati#} and {#rucira#}.

<L>1340<pc>038-b<k1>ativiza<k2>ativiza
{#ativiza#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-zaH-zA-zam#}) <sup>1</sup> Bahuvr. Very poisonous.
<sup>2</sup> Tatpur. Exceeding or subduing poison.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. (or Bahuvr.) f. ({#-zA#}) The name of a most
poisonous plant growing in Nepal used in medicine as an
antidote and also against disorders produced by bilious fe-
vers, dysentery, sickness, preternatural parturition &c.
Its bark is also employed in dying; it is of three kinds,
white, red and black. The root is employed by the natives
of India and Nepal to poison the barbs of arrows (Aco-
nitum ferox). E. Bahuvr. {#ati#} and {#viza;#} Tatpur. {#ati#} (sc.
{#krAnta#}) and {#viza#} (in the sense of the accusative).
<LEND>

lising by going beyond the mark or too far, drawing an
inference unwarranted by the premises, rules &c.; applying
a rule, definition, notion &c. to a case, object &c. where
it aught not to be applied. E. {#Ap#} with {#vi#} and {#ati,#}
kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.

<L>1357<pc>039-a<k1>atiSakvarI<k2>atiSakvarI
{#atiSakvarI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-rI#}) The name of a class of metres
regulated by number and quantity. See {#aticCandas#}. It
consists in the classic Sanskṛt of a stanza of four lines
with fifteen syllables in each line and comprises eighteen
varieties. (See <sup>1</sup> {#candrAvartA,#} <sup>2</sup> {#mAlA#} or {#sraj,#} <sup>3</sup> {#maRiguRani-#}
{#kara,#} <sup>4</sup> {#mAlinI#} or {#nandImuKI,#} <sup>5</sup> {#candraleKA,#} <sup>6</sup> {#kAmakrIqA#} or
{#lIlAKelA#} or {#saraNgaka,#} <sup>7</sup> {#praBadraka#} or {#suBadraka#} or {#sukesara,#} <sup>8</sup> {#e-#}
{#lA,#} <sup>9</sup> {#upamAlinI,#} <sup>10</sup> {#vipinatilaka,#} <sup>11</sup> {#citrA,#} <sup>12</sup> {#tuRaka#} or
{#cAmara,#} <sup>13</sup> {#BramarAvalI,#} <sup>14</sup> {#manahaMsa,#} <sup>15</sup> {#saraBa#} or {#SaSikalA,#} <sup>16</sup> {#ni-#}
{#SipAla,#} <sup>17</sup> {#utsara,#} <sup>18</sup> {#haMsa#}.) Also written, though not cor-
rectly, {#atiSakkarI#}. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#SakvarI#} (in the
sense of the accusative), another metre.
<LEND>

<L>1358<pc>039-a<k1>atiSaya<k2>atiSaya
{#atiSaya#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Excellent, superior, excessive.
(The femin. is very seldom used.)
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Excellence, superiority, excessiveness.
({#atiSayena#} used adverbially.) <sup>2</sup> Advantage, visible result
of an action (opposed to {#apUrva#} q. v.). <sup>3</sup> A superhuman qua-
lity inherent to a Jaina Arhat; there are thirty-four such
qualities belonging to them, four of which regard their per-
[Page039-b+ 56]
sonal accomplishment, eleven their supernatural powers and
the remaining twenty-nine their celestial attributes.
<div n="P">III. n. ({#-yam#}) used as adverb. Very much, excessive.
E. {#SI#} with {#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>1464<pc>042-a<k1>atyagnizwoma<k2>atyagnizwoma
{#atyagnizwoma#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of the second part
or Somasansthā of the Jyotiṣṭoma sacrifice, for the complete
performance of which, however, it is not considered nitya,
essential or obligatory, as the Agniṣṭoma (q. v.), but kāmya,
voluntary and therefore anitya, supererogatory. <sup>2</sup> The name
of the Sāmaveda verse which closes the ceremonies of this sa-
crifice. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntaH#}) and {#agnizwoma#} (in the sense of
the accus.), ‘going beyond, coming after the Agniṣṭoma’.
<LEND>

<L>1476<pc>042-a<k1>atyantatiraskftavAcyaDvani<k2>atyantatiraskftavAcyaDvani
{#atyantatiraskftavAcyaDvani#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-niH#}) (In rhetoric.)
A metaphorical expression, when the word expressing the fi-
gure or comparison drops its literal sense in order to be-
come appropriate for the comparison; f. i. in the sentence
‘the moon does not shine, like a mirror which has become
blind by breathing upon it’--the word ‘blind’ loses its
literal meaning, to serve as a comparison for ‘the not shin-
ing’ of the moon with which it has no common quality.
E. {#atyanta, tiraskfta, vAcya#} (these three words forming a
Bahuvr.) and {#Dvani#}.
<LEND>

<L>1477<pc>042-a<k1>atyantapIqana<k2>atyantapIqana
{#atyantapIqana#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-nam#}) Causing excessive pain or
agony. E. {#atyanta#} and {#pIqana#}.
<LEND>

[Page042-b+ 56]
tinues to live with his spiritual preceptor and always re-
mains in the condition of a religious student. See {#nEzWika#}.

<L>1495<pc>042-b<k1>atyazwi<k2>atyazwi

{#Sapatrapatita#} or {#vaMSapatra,#} <sup>4</sup> {#hariRI,#} <sup>5</sup> {#mandAkrAntA,#} <sup>6</sup> {#narkuwaka#} or

{#riRI#}.) <sup>2</sup> (In arithmetic sometimes used to denote) the
numeral 17. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#azwi,#} another metre
(in the sense of the accusative).

{#atyuktA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ktA#}) The name of a class of metres, regulated
by number and quantity; it consists of a stanza of four lines
with two syllables in each line and comprises four varieties.
[Page043-b+ 56]
(See <sup>1</sup> {#strI#} or {#kAma,#} <sup>2</sup> {#rati#} or {#mahI,#} <sup>3</sup> {#sAru,#} <sup>4</sup> {#maDu#}.) Also called
{#atyukTA#}. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#uktA,#} another class of
metres (in the sense of the accusative).
<LEND>

<L>1514<pc>043-b<k1>atyukti<k2>atyukti
{#atyukti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ktiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Idle or excessive talk. <sup>2</sup> A figure
of rhetoric, description of any thing surprising or extra-
ordinary, hyperbole. E. {#ati#} and {#ukti#}.
<LEND>

<L>1515<pc>043-b<k1>atyukTA<k2>atyukTA
{#atyukTA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-kTA#}). See {#atyuktA#}. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntA#})
and {#ukTA#} (in the sense of the accusative).
<LEND>

<div n="P">II. n. ({#-gram#}) Asa foetida. E. {#ati#} and {#ugra#}.

<L>1526<pc>043-b<k1>atra<k2>atra
{#atra#}¦ I. ind. <sup>1</sup> In this place, here, herein. <sup>2</sup> In conjunction
with nouns used in the same sense as {#etasmin,#} the locat.
of {#etad;#} f. i. {#atrAhni = etasminnahni,#} ‘on that day’.--In
the Vedas also written {#atrA#} which seems to be the more
original form of this word. E. {#aS#} (i. e. {#a#} which, in
this instance, is considered as a substitute of {#etad#} (and
not of {#idam#}), because {#atra#} points always to what pre-
cedes), taddh. aff. {#tral#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-traH-trA-tram#}) Not protecting. E. {#a#}
neg. and {#tra#}.
<div n="P">III. m. ({#-traH#}) (ved.) A demon, a Rākṣasa. E. {#ad,#} uṇ.
aff. {#tra#} (literally: ‘one who eats or devours’). See {#attra#}.
<div n="P">IV. n. ({#-tram#}) (ved.) Food. E. {#ad,#} uṇ. aff. {#zwran#}. See {#attra#}.
<LEND>

<L>1531<pc>044-a<k1>atrasnu<k2>atrasnu

<L>1533<pc>044-a<k1>atri<k2>atri
{#atri#}¦ m. ({#-triH#}) <sup>1</sup> Eater, devourer (in the Vedas especially as
an epithet of Agni, the divinity of fire). <sup>2</sup> The name of a
Maharshi or a great Saint, who in the Vedas occurs especi-
ally in hymns composed for the praise of Agni, Indra, the
Aśvins and the Viśvadevas; and who in the epic period
is considered as one of the ten Prajāpatis or lords of crea-
tion engendered by Manu for the purpose of creating the
universe; at a later period he appears as a mindborn son
of Brahmā and as one of the seven Ṛṣis who preside
over the reign of Svāyambhuva, the first, or according to
others of Svārochiṣa, the second, or of Vaivaswata, the
seventh Manu; he is married to Anasūyā, the daughter of
Daksha and their son is Durvāsas. Produced by a flash of
light from his eye which was received by Space, the via
lactea personified, or according to a more recent legend,
by his penitence, is Soma or the moon. See {#atrijAta,#}
{#atridfgja, atrinetraja#} &c. As sons of his are also named
the Manes Barhishads and Udamaya; a daughter of his is
Apālā. The name of Atri occurs also as that of the author
of several vaidik hymns, as that of an inspired legislator,
of the author of an astronomical and medical work and,
in astronomy, as one of the seven Ṛṣis in the constel-
lation of the great bear.--An Atri, son of Sāṅkhya, but
probably a different personage, is the author of a hymn in
the Ṛgveda.--Amongst the authors of vaidik hymns we
find as sons or descendants of Atri the following: Archa-
nāna, Avasyu, Bāhuvṛkta, Bhauma, Budha, Dvita, Ga-
viṣṭhira, Gaya, Gopavana, Isha, Paura, Pratibhānu, Pra-
tiprabha, the Prayaswats, Purīṣa, Ratahavya, Sadāpṛṇa,
Saptavadhri, Śaśa, Satyaśravas, Śrutavid, Sutambhara,
Śyāvāśva, Vasuśruta, the Vasūyus, Viśvasāman, Yajata;
and as daughters of Atri, Apālā, Gātu, Viśvavārā. <sup>3</sup> m.
pl. ({#atrayaH#}) The descendants (see {#gotra#}) of Atri collectively.
(The masc. plur. {#atrayaH#} is considered as the plur. of the
patronymic {#Atreya#} (q. v.) with luk of the taddh. aff. {#Qak;#}
the plural of the fem., however, remaining regular, viz.
{#AtreyyaH;#} but there is no necessity to adopt this artificial
etymology which is given to connect the sense of the pa-
tronymic with that of the plur. of the original form.) E.
See {#attri#}.
<LEND>

<L>1534<pc>044-a<k1>atricaturaha<k2>atricaturaha
{#atricaturaha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) The name of a sacrifice, be-
longing to the class of those called {#ahIna#} q. v. E. {#atri#}
and {#caturaha#}.
<LEND>

<L>1535<pc>044-a<k1>atrijAta<k2>atrijAta

first classes. E. <sup>1</sup> {#atri#} and {#jAta#}. See for the meaning under
{#atri#}. <sup>2</sup> {#a#} neg., {#tri#} and {#jAta#} ‘not thrice born, i. e. born
twice’; see {#dvija#}.
<LEND>

<L>1536<pc>044-a<k1>atridfgja<k2>atridfgja

sometimes used to denote) the numeral one. E. {#atri-dfS#}
(eye) and {#ja#}. See for the meaning of this word and of its
synonymes under {#atri#}.
<LEND>

<L>1547<pc>044-b<k1>atvarA<k2>atvarA

<L>1548<pc>044-b<k1>aTa<k2>aTa
{#aTa#}¦ ind. An inceptive and auspicious particle. It serves to
introduce the beginning of a work, a chapter, a sentence
and with respect to the latter may imply doubt or inter-
rogation or may serve as a conjunctive or disjunctive par-
ticle. It may be accompanied by those particles or words
which themselves are used in the same sense, giving them
greater emphasis, especially by {#u, atas, anantaram, kim,#}
{#tu, punar, vA, kimu, api#}. Without or with these particles
{#aTa#} corresponds therefore with: <sup>1</sup> Now (inceptive or pre-
mising); in the same sense but with greater emphasis {#aTo#}
({#aTa#} and {#u#}), {#aTAtas, aTAnantaram#}. <sup>2</sup> Why? what? (in-
terrogatively and doubtingly); (likewise {#aTavA#}.) <sup>3</sup> How
else? certainly; (in the same sense {#aTakim#}.) <sup>4</sup> But, on the
contrary; (in the same sense {#aTa tu, aTa punar#}.) <sup>5</sup> Or, or
rather; (likewise {#aTavA, aTavApi, aTApi vA#} &c.) <sup>6</sup> More-
over, so much the more, therefore, thus; (likewise {#aTaca,#}
{#aTApi, aTo api, aTa kimu#}.) In the Vedas there occurs
also the protracted form {#aTA#} which seems to be the more
original one; (cf. {#taTA#} and {#yaTA#}). E. According to the native
authorities from {#arT,#} kṛt aff. {#qa#} with {#r#} being dropped;
but it is more probably derived from {#a,#} the pron. theme
which is considered as a substitute for {#idam#} (pointing to
what follows), taddh. aff. {#Ta#}.
<LEND>

<L>1549<pc>044-b<k1>aTakim<k2>aTakim
{#aTakim#}¦ ind. A particle of assent, how else, what else, as-
suredly. (Better to be considered as two words. See {#aTa#}.)
E. {#aTa#} and {#kim#}.
<LEND>

<L>1550<pc>044-b<k1>aTakimu<k2>aTakimu
{#aTakimu#}¦ ind. So much the more. (Better to be considered as
two separate words and also written {#aTa kimu#}. See {#aTa#}.)
E. {#aTa#} and {#kimu#}.
<LEND>

<L>1551<pc>044-b<k1>aTaca<k2>aTaca
{#aTaca#}¦ ind. Also, moreover. (Better to be considered as two
words. See {#aTa#}.) E. {#aTa#} and {#ca#}.
<LEND>

<L>1552<pc>044-b<k1>aTatu<k2>aTatu
{#aTatu#}¦ ind. But, on the contrary. (More properly to be con-
sidered as two distinct words and also written {#aTa tu#}. See
{#aTa#}.) E. {#aTa#} and {#tu#}.
<LEND>
[Page045-a+ 56]

<L>1553<pc>045-a<k1>aTarI<k2>aTarI
{#aTarI#}¦ f. (occurs only as a plural in the Vedas; {#-ryaH#}) The
finger. E. This word is given as an irregular derivation
from {#at#} ‘to go constantly’; but it is more probable that
it is derived, with aff. {#ari,#} from an obsolete rad. {#aT#}
which seems to have had the same meaning as {#at#} (cf.
{#aw#} and {#aW#}), but is found only in {#aTarI, aTarvan#} and their
derivatives, implying quickness or agility. The same etymo-
logical connexion between words meaning ‘finger’ and ‘fire’
may be perceived in other derivations from a radical in the
sense of ‘to go’ f. i. in {#aNguli#} or {#aNguri, agrU#} and {#agni, aNgiras,#}
from {#aNg#}. It reappears distinctly in the denom. {#aTary#} and
its derivatives {#aTarya, aTaryu#} qq. vv.
<LEND>

<L>1554<pc>045-a<k1>aTary<k2>aTary
{#aTary#}¦ par. ({#-ryati#}) To go, to move. (Only in the Vedas.)
Probably a denominative from {#aTarI#} or {#aTar#} with aff. {#yak#}.
<LEND>

<L>1555<pc>045-a<k1>aTarya<k2>aTarya
{#aTarya#}¦ m. ({#-ryaH#}) Moving constantly; an epithet of Agni in the
Vedas. See also the following. E. {#aTary,#} kṛt aff. {#ac(?)#}.
A commentary explains, that {#aTarya#} is an epithet of {#dakzi-#}
{#RAgni,#} because the sacred fire ‘goes always’ from the Gār-
hapatya (q. v.) to his proper place; the epithet may be con-
sidered, however, as one of a more general bearing.
<LEND>

<L>1556<pc>045-a<k1>aTaryu<k2>aTaryu
{#aTaryu#}¦ m. ({#-yuH#}) Moving constantly; an epithet of Agni in the
Vedas. See the preceding. E. {#aTary,#} kṛt aff. {#u#}.
<LEND>

<L>1557<pc>045-a<k1>aTarva<k2>aTarva
{#aTarva#}¦ m. ({#-rvaH#}) A proper name of the eldest son of Brahmā,
to whom Brahmā revealed the Brahmavidyā (q. v.) or know-
ledge of God. See {#aTarvan#}. E. See {#aTarvan#} of which it is
an abbreviated form.
<LEND>

<L>1558<pc>045-a<k1>aTarvaRa<k2>aTarvaRa
{#aTarvaRa#}¦ m. ({#-RaH#}) A name of Śiva. E. {#aTarvan,#} taddh. aff. {#a(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>1559<pc>045-a<k1>aTarvaRi<k2>aTarvaRi
{#aTarvaRi#}¦ m. ({#-RiH#}) <sup>1</sup> A Brahman versed in the Atharvaveda.
<sup>2</sup> A family priest. E. See {#ATarvaRi#} which is the better
reading of this word.
<LEND>

<L>1560<pc>045-a<k1>aTarvan<k2>aTarvan
{#aTarvan#}¦ 1. m. ({#-rvA#}) <sup>1</sup> A Brāhmaṇa, a priest (probably one
connected with offerings to fire or the attendance on the
holy fire). <sup>2</sup> The proper name of a priest who is considered
to have obtained the fire from heaven and who in the course
of mythological personification appears as a Prajāpati or
father of all beings, as the inspired author of the fourth
or Atharvaveda, as the eldest son of Brahmā to whom
Brahmā revealed the Brahmavidyā (q. v.) or knowledge of
God (see also {#aTarva#}) and, at a later period, as the same
as Angiras (q. v.). Sons of his are Agni (see also {#aNgiras#}),
Dadhyanch, Bhishaj, Bṛhaddiva, Kabandha. <sup>3</sup> An epithet of
<sup>a.</sup> Vasiṣṭha q. v., <sup>b.</sup> Soma q. v., <sup>c.</sup> {#prARa#} q. v., <sup>d.</sup> Śiva (the god being
supposed to carry into effect the charms of the Atharvaveda).
<div n="P">2. m. n. ({#-rvA-rva#}) The fourth or Atharvaveda q. v. (see
also m. pl. {#aTarvARaH#}).
<div n="P">3. m. pl. ({#-rvARaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The descendants of Atharvan; they
appear sometimes coupled with the descendants of Bhṛgu
and of Angiras (see {#aTarvANgirasaH#}). <sup>2</sup> The hymns of the
fourth or Atharvaveda collectively (considered as the descen-
dants of Atharvan); the Atharvaveda (see also {#aTarvANgi-#}
{#rasaH#}). E. From an obsolete theme {#aTar,#} fire, with taddh.
aff. {#vanip#}. See the E. of {#aTarI#}. The oldest etym. which
derives {#aTarvan#} from {#a#} neg. and {#Tarvan#} (from {#Tarv#} ‘to go’),
is without any probability. A similar etym. is given of
{#aTarvI#} q. v.
<LEND>

<L>1561<pc>045-a<k1>aTarvaBUta<k2>aTarvaBUta
{#aTarvaBUta#}¦ Tatpur. m. pl. ({#-tAH#}) An epithet of the twelve Maharshis:
[Page045-b+ 56]
{#Darma, dakza, marIci, atri, pulastya, pulaha, kratu, vasizWa, gO-#}
{#tama, Bfgu, aNgiras, manu#} and (according to a commentary)
of ‘Rudra, the Lord of the Universe’. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#BUta#}
(according to a commentary from {#BU,#} to obtain, ‘having
obtained i. e. versed in the Atharvaveda, the same as {#a-#}
{#Tarvavid#}’).
<LEND>

<L>1562<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvavat<k2>aTarvavat
{#aTarvavat#}¦ ind. Like Atharvan or the descendants of Atharvan.
E. {#aTarvan,#} taddh. aff. {#vati#}.
<LEND>

<L>1563<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvavid<k2>aTarvavid
{#aTarvavid#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vit#}) One versed in the Atharvaveda.
See {#aTarvaBUta#}. According to the Pariśiṣṭa of this Veda esp.
an epithet of the priest called Brahman q. v. See {#brahmaveda#}.
E. {#aTarvan#} and {#vid#}.
<LEND>

<L>1564<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvaveda<k2>aTarvaveda
{#aTarvaveda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) The fourth or Atharvaveda (see
{#fc, yajus, sAman#}), the Veda revealed by Atharvan or
Angiras and sometimes considered, therefore, personified
as a son of Angiras. See {#aTarvan, aTarvANgiras, pratyaNgiras,#}
{#brahmaveda#}. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#veda#}.
<LEND>

<L>1565<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvaSiKA<k2>aTarvaSiKA
{#aTarvaSiKA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-KA#}) The name of one of the Upani-
shads of the Atharvaveda. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#SiKA#} ‘the crest’
i. e. (according to the comm.) the essence of the Atharvaveda.
<LEND>

<L>1566<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvaSiras<k2>aTarvaSiras
{#aTarvaSiras#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-raH#}) The name of an Upanishad of
the Atharvaveda. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#Siras#} ‘the head’ i. e.
the principal Upanishad of the A. V.
<LEND>

<L>1567<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvahfdaya<k2>aTarvahfdaya
{#aTarvahfdaya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-yam#}) The name of a Pariśiṣṭa of the
Atharvaveda. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#hfdaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>1568<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvANgiras<k2>aTarvANgiras
{#aTarvANgiras#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-rAH#}) The Angiras of the Athar-
vaveda. This use of the word, as a Tatpur. in the sing.,
is of later origin than that of the Dwandwa in the plur.,
and, as it seems, adopted to explain the form {#aTarvANgi-#}
{#rasa#} q. v.
<div n="P">II. Dwandwa. m. pl. ({#-rasaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The descendants of Athar-
van and of Angiras. <sup>2</sup> The Atharvaveda hymns of both
collectively; the Atharvaveda (q. v.), one part (or parvan)
of which is considered to have been revealed by the descen-
dants of Atharvan and another by the descendants of An-
giras. According to another explanation, however, this
name of the Atharvaveda would merely refer to Atharvan
(q. v.) being the inspired author of one part and Angiras
(q. v.) of the other. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#aNgiras#}.
<LEND>

<L>1569<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvANgirasa<k2>aTarvANgirasa
{#aTarvANgirasa#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-saH-sI-sam#}) Referring or belonging
to the {#aTarvANgirasaH#} q. v.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-sam#}) The religious observances ({#karman#}) connected
with the ritual of the Atharvaveda.
<div n="P">III. m. pl. ({#-sAH#}) The mantras or hymns of the Athar-
vaveda. E. {#aTarvANgiras,#} taddh. aff. {#wac#}.
<LEND>

<L>1570<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvARa<k2>aTarvARa
{#aTarvARa#}¦ n. ({#-Ram#}) The religious observances ({#karman#}) connected
with the ritual of the Atharvaveda. E. Irregular derivation
from {#aTarvan,#} taddh. aff. {#aR(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>1571<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvARavid<k2>aTarvARavid
{#aTarvARavid#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-t#}) One versed in the rites of the
Atharvaveda. E. {#aTarvARa#} and {#vid#}.
<LEND>

<L>1572<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvI<k2>aTarvI
{#aTarvI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-vI#}). This word occurs only in the Veda
and is explained ‘not going, unable to move’, from {#a#}
neg. and {#TarvI#} (from {#Tarv,#} to go). It would seem, how-
ever, that it is a Tatpur. composed of the obsolete word
{#aTar,#} fire, and {#vI,#} ‘surrounded by fire’(?). See the E.
of {#aTarvan#} and {#aTarI#}.
<LEND>
[Page046-a+ 56]

<L>1573<pc>046-a<k1>aTavA<k2>aTavA
{#aTavA#}¦ ind. <sup>1</sup> Why? what? <sup>2</sup> Or, or rather. See {#aTa#}. E. {#aTa#}
and {#vA#}.
<LEND>

as two separate words, {#aTavA#} and {#api#}. See {#aTa#}. E. {#aTa-#}
{#vA#} and {#api#}.

{#atas#}.

<L>1579<pc>046-a<k1>ad<k2>ad
{#ad#}¦ I. ({#ada-adAdi-anudAtta-udAttet#}) r. 2d cl. par.
({#atti-#} imperf. {#Adat-#} imper. {#adDi,#} ep. {#adasva-#} perf. {#Ada,#}
2d pers. {#AdiTa-#} fut. 1. {#atsyati,#} 2. {#attA-#} inf. {#attum-#} p. p.
{#adita#} ({#anna#} only used as subst.). Pass. {#adyate#}. Caus. {#Ada-#}
{#yati-te#}.--For the tenses which are not formed of {#ad,#}
see {#Gas#} which is then considered as a substitute of it.)
To eat. (Caus. To feed.)--With {#ava(?)-A-pra-sam#}
to eat, to devour; {#vi-#} to gnaw, to nibble.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#at#}) Eating. This word occurs only as the
latter part of a Tatpur., the former part of which may be
any word but {#anna#} (which forms {#annAda#} and not {#annAd#}).
See f. i. {#ahutAd, AmAd, kravyAd#}. E. {#ad,#} kṛt aff. {#viw#}.
<LEND>

<L>1580<pc>046-a<k1>ada<k2>ada
{#ada#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-daH-dI-dam#}) Eating; (occurs only as the latter
part of Tatpur. compounds). See f. i. {#ajAda, atfRAda, a-#}
{#nnAda#}. E. {#ad,#} kṛt aff. {#aR#}.
<LEND>

<L>1581<pc>046-a<k1>adakza<k2>adakza
{#adakza#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kzaH-kzA-kzam#}) Awkward, unskilful.
E. {#a#} neg. and {#dakza#}.
<LEND>

<L>1582<pc>046-a<k1>adakziRa<k2>adakziRa
{#adakziRa#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-RaH-RA-Ram#}) I. Tatpur. <sup>1</sup> Not right, left.
<sup>2</sup> Not clever, unskilful. E. {#a#} neg. and {#dakziRa#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. Being or being performed without the presents
usually given to Brahmans (see {#dakziRA#}), as a sacrifice &c.
The celebration of a sacrifice without the Dakṣiṇā oc-
curs for instance under the following circumstances: at
the Prātaḥsavana of the Jyotiṣṭoma, when about to sing
the Vahiṣpavamāna stotra, the priests step out from the
house where the sacred fire is kept, one going after the
other and holding the one who precedes by the hem of his
garment: if it so happens, at this procession, that the
Udgātṛ inadvertently drops the hem, the sacrifice goes on
without the Dakṣiṇā; once accomplished, however, it is
to be repeated and then the Udgātṛ has to pay the Dakṣiṇā
which should have been given at the first performance; if
the Pratihartṛ meets with a similar accident, he has to pay
his whole property at the renewal of the ceremony, which
then is called {#sarvasvadakziRa#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#dakziRA#}.
<LEND>

<L>1583<pc>046-a<k1>adakziRatva<k2>adakziRatva
{#adakziRatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> Leftness, unskilfulness &c. <sup>2</sup> The state
of a sacrifice performed without the Dakṣiṇā. See the pre-
ceding. E. {#adakziRa,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>1593<pc>046-b<k1>adadryaYc<k2>adadryaYc
{#adadryaYc#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dryaN-drIcI-dryak#}) Going to that.
(This word is probably one of a mere grammatical coinage,
to illustrate a rule concerning the pronom. theme {#adas#}.
According to some it would have the same meaning as {#a-#}
{#damuyaYc, amudryaYc#} and {#amumuyaYc#} to which others add {#ada-#}
{#mudryaYc, amumUyaYc, adamUyaYc#} qq. vv., but it might also be
that {#adadryaYc#} (as well as {#adamuyaYc, adamudryaYc, adamUyaYc#})
is formed to show that its first part represents not the
whole theme, but merely the neuter of {#adas,#} while the
first part of {#amudryaYc, amumuyaYc#} and {#amumUyaYc#} refer to its
masc. and femin. For the declension of this word, see
{#aYc#} II. E. {#adas#} and {#aYc#} (II. 1.), with {#adri#} instead of
the final {#as#} of {#adas#}.
<LEND>

<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ntaH#}) A leech. E. {#a#} priv. and {#danta#}.

{#adala#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-laH-lA-lam#}) Leafless.

<L>1615<pc>047-a<k1>adas<k2>adas
{#adas#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#asO-asO-adas#}). The pronoun (see {#sarva-#}
{#nAman#}) which generally points to what is absent, remote
or uncertain (differently from {#idam#} q. v.) and which cor-
responds with <sup>1</sup> That. <sup>2</sup> A certain (so and so). In correlative
phrases it stands therefore usually in the prior sentence,
imparting greater emphasis. Its declension is defective in
as far as most of its cases are supplied by the themes {#asu#}
or {#asa, amu (amU)#} and {#ami (amI)#}. The theme which ap-
[Page047-b+ 56]
pears in composition is {#adas#} (except in the forms {#ada-#}
{#dryaYc#} &c. q. v. See also {#adDA#}). In some derivations of rare
occurrence we meet also with the themes {#asu, asa#} and {#amu;#}
see {#asuka, asaka, amuka#}.
<div n="P">II. ind. (esp. in composition with radicals (see {#gati#}),
when employed reflectively). So, in such a manner, f. i.
{#adaHkftya#} having done so &c.--In conjunction with a re-
lative pronoun or particle it has the effect of giving em-
phasis or of generalising, e. g. {#yadadas#} whatever, {#yatrAdas#}
wherever, {#yaTAdas#} howsoever. E. unknown; but it is pro-
bably derived from the theme {#ad#} which occurs in {#ada-#}
{#dryaYc#} and {#adDA#}.
<LEND>

<L>1616<pc>047-b<k1>adasy<k2>adasy
{#adasy#}¦ denom. par. ({#-syati#}) To become that. E. {#adas,#} de-
nom. aff. {#yak#}.
<LEND>

<L>1617<pc>047-b<k1>adAtf<k2>adAtf
{#adAtf#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-tA-trI-tf#}) <sup>1</sup> Not giving. <sup>2</sup> Not liberal,
miserly. <sup>3</sup> Not paying (a debt &c.). <sup>4</sup> Not giving in mar-
riage (a daughter, as a father). E. {#a#} neg. and {#dAtf#}.

<L>1623<pc>047-b<k1>adAyika<k2>adAyika

<L>1630<pc>047-b<k1>adikka<k2>adikka

<L>1631<pc>047-b<k1>aditi<k2>aditi
{#aditi#}¦ I. Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Entireness, the being unbroken
or unhurt. <sup>2</sup> Exemption from defect or misery. <sup>3</sup> The full
or unbroken creative power of the Prajāpati. E. {#a#} neg.
and {#diti#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. I. m. f. ({#-tiH-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Unbroken, unhurt.
<sup>2</sup> Free from misery, happy. <sup>3</sup> Pious, holy. As Bahuvr.
<LEND>
[Page048-a+ 56]

<L>1632<pc>048-a<k1>aditi<k2>aditi
{#aditi#}¦ is in the Vedas often used as an epithet of Indra,
the Maruts and Agni, but it becomes personified especially in
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-tiH#}) which in the Vedas means <sup>1</sup> the earth, <sup>2</sup> a
cow, <sup>3</sup> speech; but especially <sup>4</sup> Aditi, the first goddess of
the intermediate space or air, the mother of the Gods, who
at a later period was considered as the daughter of Daksha
and wife of Kaśyapa, as the sister of Agastya and as the
mother of the twelve Ādityas, of the eight Vasus, eleven
Rudras and two Aśvins, besides of the thirty-six Tushitas.
--Aditi is in a still later time also an appellative of Durgā.
<div n="P">3. f. du. ({#-tI#}) (In the Vedas.) Heaven and earth.
E. {#a#} priv. and {#diti#}.
<div n="P">III. m. ({#-tiH#}) A name of Mṛtyu, the god of Death;
literally: the eater or devourer. (This meaning of the word
occurs only in a commentary of an Upanishad and is rather
doubtful.) E. {#ad#} (uṇ. aff. {#ti?#}).
<LEND>

<L>1633<pc>048-a<k1>aditija<k2>aditija
{#aditija#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) A son of Aditi, a deity, a god.
See {#aditinandana#}. E. {#aditi#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>1634<pc>048-a<k1>adititva<k2>adititva
{#adititva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unbrokenness, entireness, fullness of
power. <sup>2</sup> The being Aditi (in the sense of Mṛtyu; see
{#aditi#} III). E. {#aditi,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

{#aditi#} and {#nandana#}.
<LEND>

<L>1660<pc>048-b<k1>adfzwa<k2>adfzwa
{#adfzwa#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unseen, unfore-

flagration, inundation &c.). <sup>2</sup> Fortune, destiny, fate. <sup>3</sup> (In
philosophy.) <sup>a.</sup> Virtue or vice ({#Darma#} or {#aDarma#}), as the even-
tual cause of pleasure or pain. <sup>b.</sup> The remote or unforeseen
consequence of an act, e. g. heaven as that of religious
rites &c. See {#apUrva#}.

the Vedas). E. {#a#} neg. and {#dfzwa#}.

<L>1668<pc>048-b<k1>adeya<k2>adeya
{#adeya#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Improper or unfit to
[Page049-a+ 56]
be given. II. n. ({#-yam#}) (In law.) An object not fit to be

posed of. See {#adatta, datta, deya#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#deya#}.

<L>1688<pc>049-a<k1>adButa<k2>adButa
{#adButa#}¦ Tatpur.(?) I. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Surprising, wonderful (ac-
cording to a vaidik interpretation: not having existed before).
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-taH#}) <sup>1</sup> Surprise, astonishment. See {#adButarasa#}. <sup>2</sup> The
name of the Indra or chief of the ninth Manwantara.
<div n="P">III. n. ({#-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> A prodigy, a wonder, any portentous
[Page049-b+ 56]
or marvellous phenomenon. <sup>2</sup> (In architecture.) A kind of
temple or vimāna, the breadth of which is divided into
four parts, seven such parts being given to its height. E.
(doubtful) {#ad#} ind. and {#BU,#} uṇ. aff. {#qutac#}. Compare {#ana-#}
{#tidButa#}.
<LEND>

<L>1689<pc>049-b<k1>adButaganDa<k2>adButaganDa

<L>1691<pc>049-b<k1>adButabrAhmaRa<k2>adButabrAhmaRa

belonging to the Sāmaveda; more properly the last portion

{#brAhmaRa#}.

<L>1692<pc>049-b<k1>adButarasa<k2>adButarasa
{#adButarasa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-saH#}) (In rhetoric.) The marvellous, as
a prevailing sentiment in poetical composition, one of the
nine rasas or characteristic sentiments of poetical compo-
sition as described in Hindu works on rhetoric or poetry.
See {#rasa#}. E. {#adButa#} and {#rasa#}.
<LEND>

ascribed to Vālmīki. E. {#adButa#} and {#rAmAyaRa#}.

<L>1696<pc>049-b<k1>adButasvana<k2>adButasvana

a wonderful sound’.
<LEND>

<L>1700<pc>049-b<k1>admasad<k2>admasad
{#admasad#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-d#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> A cook. <sup>2</sup> A mother. E. {#adman#}
and {#sad;#} according to the comm. ‘sitting by the food, to
cook it; or sitting in the house; or spending food’.
<LEND>

<L>1701<pc>049-b<k1>admasadya<k2>admasadya
{#admasadya#}¦ n. ({#-dyam#}) (ved.) Being a cook, the condition of a
cook. See the preceding. E. {#admasad,#} taddh. aff. {#ya#}.
<LEND>

<L>1702<pc>049-b<k1>adya<k2>adya
{#adya#}¦ I. ind. <sup>1</sup> To-day. <sup>2</sup> Now, at present. In the Vedas also
written {#adyA#} which seems to be the more original form of
this word. {#adyApi#} Even now, still. {#adyapUrvam#} before to-
day, before now. E. {#aS,#} considered as a substitute of
{#idam,#} taddh. aff. {#dya;#} but more probably a Karmadh. com-
pound of {#a#} (the pronom. theme in {#idam#}) and {#dya#} or {#dyA#}
(from {#dyu#} or {#div#}) = {#asmindyavi#}.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. n. ({#-dyaH-dyA-dyam#}) Fit to be eaten, eatable.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-dyam#}) Food in general. E. {#ad,#} kṛtya aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>1703<pc>049-b<k1>adyatana<k2>adyatana
{#adyatana#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nI-nam#}) Of or belonging to the
current day, of to-day.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-naH#}) The period of a current day, from mid-
night to midnight in the usual acceptation, but sometimes
considered to begin and to end with sun-set or to begin
with the proper time of rising and to end with the proper
time of going to rest.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-nI#}) (In grammar.) The aorist (or {#luN#}), as the
tense employed in relating what has happened during the
current day. E. {#adya,#} taddh. aff. {#wyul#} and āgama {#tuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>1704<pc>049-b<k1>adyatanIya<k2>adyatanIya
{#adyatanIya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Of to-day, belonging to
the current day. E. {#adyatana,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#}.
<LEND>
[Page050-a+ 56]

<L>1705<pc>050-a<k1>adyapraBfti<k2>adyapraBfti
{#adyapraBfti#}¦ Bahuvr. ind. From to-day. E. {#adya#} and {#praBfti#}.
<LEND>

<L>1706<pc>050-a<k1>adyaSvIna<k2>adyaSvIna
{#adyaSvIna#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) What may happen to-day
or to-morrow, near to any event, at the point of death &c.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-nA#}) A woman or any female animal near the time
of delivery. E. {#adya#} and {#Svas,#} taddh. aff. {#Ka#}.
<LEND>

<L>1707<pc>050-a<k1>adyAvaDi<k2>adyAvaDi
{#adyAvaDi#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-DiH-DiH-Di#}) Beginning or end-
ing with the current day; from or till to-day. E. {#adya#} and
{#avaDi#}.
<LEND>

<L>1708<pc>050-a<k1>adyUtya<k2>adyUtya
{#adyUtya#}¦ (ved.) Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-tyaH-tyA-tyam#}) Not gained by
playing, not gained improperly, obtained honestly. E. {#a#}
neg. and {#dyUtya#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. n. ({#-tyam#}) The last watch of the night, that
preceding the dawn, at which time the Aśvins are espe-
cially to be worshipped. E. {#a#} and {#dyUtya#} (from {#dyut,#} kṛt
aff. {#Ryat#} and {#U#} instead of {#u#}) ‘without light’. Both ex-
planations of this word belong to different commentaries
but refer to the same passage in which it occurs.
<LEND>

<L>1709<pc>050-a<k1>adrava<k2>adrava
{#adrava#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-vaH-vA-vam#}) Not liquid, solid. E.
{#a#} neg. and {#drava#}.

<L>1710<pc>050-a<k1>adravya<k2>adravya
{#adravya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-vyam#}) A worthless or good-for-nothing
object. E. {#a#} deter. and {#dravya#}.
<LEND>

<L>1711<pc>050-a<k1>adri<k2>adri
{#adri#}¦ m. ({#-driH#}) <sup>1</sup> A stone. <sup>2</sup> The thunderbolt. <sup>3</sup> A mountain.
<sup>4</sup> A cloud. <sup>5</sup> A tree. <sup>6</sup> The sun. <sup>7</sup> The name of a measure.
<sup>8</sup> A proper name of the son of Viśvagaśva and father of
Yuvanāśva. <sup>9</sup> (In arithmetic sometimes used to denote) the
numeral 7. E. {#ad,#} uṇ. aff. {#krin;#} but more probably, a
Tatpur. composed of {#a#} and {#dri#} (from {#dF#} or {#drA?#}). Compare
{#aga#}. The meanings 1. 2. 4. belong exclusively to the Vedas.
<LEND>

<L>1712<pc>050-a<k1>adrikarRI<k2>adrikarRI

ternatea). See {#aparAjitA#} or {#girikarRI#}. E. {#adri#} and {#karRa,#}
fem. aff. {#NIz#}.
<LEND>

<L>1716<pc>050-a<k1>adrija<k2>adrija
{#adrija#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Produced or found
in the hills.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-jA#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Pārvatī or Durgā, the daughter
of Himālaya, the ruler of the Himālaya mountain, and
hence this her appellation, mountain-born. <sup>2</sup> The name of
a plant. See {#sEMhalI#}.

and {#jA#}.

<L>1718<pc>050-a<k1>adrijUta<k2>adrijUta

<L>1719<pc>050-a<k1>adritanayA<k2>adritanayA

and quantity; a variety of the class called {#vikfti#} q. v. It con-
sists of four lines, with the following twenty-three syllables
to each: ˘˘˘˘¯˘¯˘˘˘¯ । ˘¯˘˘˘¯˘¯˘˘˘¯.

<L>1744<pc>050-b<k1>advaya<k2>advaya
{#advaya#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not duality, unity. <sup>2</sup> The
[Page051-a+ 56]
identity of Brahman (n.) and the Universe or of the divine
essence and the human soul; the real truth. E. {#a#} neg.
and {#dvaya#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Without a second,
only, alone; esp. in the neuter as an epithet of Brahman (n.)
which is not distinct from the Universe.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-yaH#}) A name of Buddha (acc. to a commentary,
because wisdom and object of wisdom are identical with
him). E. {#a#} priv. and {#dvaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>1745<pc>051-a<k1>advayat<k2>advayat
{#advayat#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yan#}) (ved.) Free from duplicity, one
whose acts are not different from his words and thoughts,
upright, honest. E. {#a#} neg. and {#dvayat#}.
<LEND>

<L>1746<pc>051-a<k1>advayavAdin<k2>advayavAdin
{#advayavAdin#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-dI#}) A Jina or Buddha. E. {#advaya#}
and {#vAdin:#} one who acknowledges but one principle;
or who teaches the real truth. See {#advEtavAdin#}.
<LEND>

<L>1747<pc>051-a<k1>advayas<k2>advayas
{#advayas#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yAH#}) (ved.) The same as {#advayat#}. E.
{#a#} neg. and {#dvayas#}.
<LEND>

{#advaya#} and {#Ananda#}.

or hateful, agreeable, desired. E. {#a#} neg. and {#dvizeRya#}.

<L>1754<pc>051-a<k1>adveza<k2>adveza

<L>1755<pc>051-a<k1>advezin<k2>advezin
{#advezin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-zI-ziRI-zi#}) Harmless, inoffen-
sive. E. {#a#} neg. and {#dvezin#}.
<LEND>

<L>1756<pc>051-a<k1>advEta<k2>advEta
{#advEta#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unity, not duality. <sup>2</sup> The iden-
tity of Brahman (n.) and the Universe or of the divine es-
sence and the human soul; the real truth. <sup>3</sup> The name of
an Upanishad of the Atharvaveda. E. {#a#} neg. and {#dvEta#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Without a second,
only, alone; esp. as an epithet of {#Atman#} and {#brahman#} (n.)
or {#brahmaloka#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#dvEta#}.
<LEND>

<L>1757<pc>051-a<k1>advEtavAdin<k2>advEtavAdin
{#advEtavAdin#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-dI#}) A unitarian, one who main-
tains the existence of but one principle in the Universe.
E. {#advEta#} and {#vAdin#}. See {#advayavAdin#}.
<LEND>

<L>1758<pc>051-a<k1>advEtAnanda<k2>advEtAnanda
{#advEtAnanda#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-ndaH#}) The proper name of one of the
founders of the Vaiṣṇava sect in Bengal; he lived about
the end of the 15th century. Also {#advayAnanda#}. E. {#advEta#} and
{#Ananda#}.
<LEND>

<L>1759<pc>051-a<k1>aDa<k2>aDa
{#aDa#}¦ ind. ({#nipAta#}) An inceptive particle which occurs only
in the Vedas. It is used very much in the same manner as
{#aTa#} of which it is apparently a variety and corresponds
chiefly with <sup>1</sup> Now, hereafter. <sup>2</sup> Moreover, so much the
more. <sup>3</sup> Therefore. It occurs frequently in its protracted
form {#aDA#} which seems to be the more original one. E.
See {#aTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>1760<pc>051-a<k1>aDaHkara<k2>aDaHkara
{#aDaHkara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) The lower part of the hand, the
[Page051-b+ 56]
metacarpus or the hand from the wrist to the root of the
fingers. E. {#aDas#} and {#kara#}.
<LEND>

<L>1761<pc>051-b<k1>aDaHkAya<k2>aDaHkAya
{#aDaHkAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) The lower part of the body, the

<L>1776<pc>051-b<k1>aDama<k2>aDama
{#aDama#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) <sup>1</sup> Very low or inferior in
place or degree. <sup>2</sup> Vile, despicable. (In the vituperative
sense it stands often as the latter part of a Tatpur. com-
pound; f. i. {#pApADama, narADama#}.)
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-maH#}) (In rhetoric, according to some.) A para-
mour of a low description, one without fear, pity or shame &c.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-mA#}) (In rhetoric, according to some.) A mistress
of a low description, one ungrateful, whimsical, acting
unkindly towards her lover &c. E. {#av,#} uṇ. aff. {#ama,#} with
{#v#} changed to {#Da;#} or according to others a Tatpur. com-
posed of {#a#} neg. and {#Dama#} (from {#DmA#}); but a preferable
etym. is that from {#aDas,#} taddh. aff. {#ma,#} with elision of
{#s;#} or better from {#aD#} (the thematic form common to {#aDama,#}
{#aDara, aDas, aDastAt#}), aff. {#ama#}.
<LEND>

<L>1785<pc>052-a<k1>aDara<k2>aDara
{#aDara#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Lower, inferior, in place.
(In this sense the word is declined like the sarvanāman {#yat#}
&c. (q. v.), but in the abl. and loc. sing. of the masc. and
neuter and in the nom. plur. of the masc. it forms optionally
{#aDarasmAt#} or {#aDarAt, aDarasmin#} or {#aDare, aDare#} or {#a-#}
{#DarAH;#} it may form Tatpur. compositions with nouns having
the sense of the singular and considered then as depending
upon {#aDara,#} which is the former part of the compound, in
the genitive; for instance {#aDarakAyaH#} is explained, {#aDaraM#}
{#kAyasya#}.) Adverbially used are {#aDarAt, aDarasmAt, aDareRa;#}
qq. vv. <sup>2</sup> Low, vile. <sup>3</sup> Speechless, refuted, overcome in abuse
or controversy. <sup>4</sup> Prior, preceding in time. See {#aDaredyus#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-raH#}) The lower lip, the lip.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-rA#}) <sup>1</sup> The lower region. <sup>2</sup> The nadir (?).
<div n="P">IV. m. n. ({#-raH-ram#}) Pudendum muliebre. E. Probably
from {#aD#} (see E. of {#aDama#}), aff. {#ara;#} the derivation given
by the native authorities, from {#a#} neg. and {#Dara#} is not correct.
<LEND>

<L>1786<pc>052-a<k1>aDarakaRWa<k2>aDarakaRWa
{#aDarakaRWa#}¦ Tatpur. m. n. ({#-RWaH-RWam?#}) The lower part of the
throat. E. {#aDara#} and {#kaRWa#}. See under {#aDara#}.
<LEND>

{#aDara#}.

that the distance must not be far; or governing in the first

Cf. {#aDarAk#}. E. {#aDara,#} taddh. aff. {#atasuc#}.

<L>1806<pc>052-b<k1>aDarma<k2>aDarma
{#aDarma#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-rmaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Unrighteousness, injustice, all
behaviour contrary to the Śruti and Smṛti, or religious
and legal institutions. <sup>2</sup> (In philosophy.) According to the
Nyāya and Vaiśeṣika: moral demerit, the result of doing
what is forbidden, the peculiar cause of pain, one of the
twenty-four qualities united with substance.--According
to the Sāṅkhya, one of the changeable ({#vEkftika#}) dispo-
sitions ({#BAva#}) of the mind, which being the efficient cause,
makes the soul migrate into an animal, a deer, a bird, a
reptile, a vegetable, a mineral.--According to the Bud-
dhistic doctrine it is the consequence of upādāna or exertion
of body or speech.--According to the Jainas it is that
which causes the soul in general to continue embarrassed
with body notwithstanding its capacity for ascent and na-
tural tendency to soar. <sup>3</sup> As a personification Adharma oc-
curs in the Purāṇas as one of the Prajāpatis or mind-born
sons of Brahmā; his wife is Hinsā (mischief) on whom he
begot Anṛta (falsehood) and Nikṛti (immorality) or ac-
cording to others, Mṛṣā (falsehood) and his children Dam-
bha (hypocrisy) and Māyā (deceit) who were adopted by
Nirṛti (misfortune).--Adharma is also mentioned as one
of the eighteen servants of the sun.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-rmA#}) According to the Śāktas a kalā or part of
the original or Mūla-prakṛti and personified as the bride
of Mṛtyu or Death. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Darma#}.
<LEND>

<L>1807<pc>052-b<k1>aDarmacArin<k2>aDarmacArin
{#aDarmacArin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rI-riRI-ri#}) Unrighteous,
wicked. E. {#aDarma#} and {#cArin#}.
<LEND>
[Page053-a+ 56]

<L>1818<pc>053-a<k1>aDas<k2>aDas
{#aDas#}¦ ind. <sup>1</sup> Underneath, downwards or from below. <sup>2</sup> The lower
regions, the nadir, or: from or in the lower regions, the nadir.
(In these meanings it is used in the sense of a nominative,
ablative or locative; or governs in the first meaning a noun in
the genitive, more seldom in the ablative; the reiterated {#aDo#}
{#'Das#} implies proximity and is followed by the noun in the
accusative, f. i. {#aDo'Do grAmam#} below the village, but in its
neighbourhood; it may occur as the former and as the latter
part of Tatpur. compounds.) <sup>3</sup> Pudendum muliebre. <sup>4</sup> Away,
out(?). See {#aDastAt;#} cf. {#aDarAk#}. E. {#aD#} (considered as a
substitute of {#aDara,#} but more probably the thematic form
common to {#aDama, aDara, aDas#} and {#aDastAt#}), taddh. aff. {#asi#}.
<LEND>

<L>1819<pc>053-a<k1>aDastana<k2>aDastana
{#aDastana#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-naH-nI-nam#}) Below, underneath. E. {#aDas,#}
taddh. aff. {#wyul#} and āgama {#tuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>1820<pc>053-a<k1>aDastarAm<k2>aDastarAm
{#aDastarAm#}¦ ind. Lower, very low. E. {#aDas,#} taddh. aff. {#tarap#}
and {#Amu#} (or better the acc. fem. in the comparative of
{#aDas#} used as an adverb).
<LEND>

<L>1821<pc>053-a<k1>aDastAt<k2>aDastAt
{#aDastAt#}¦ ind. The same as {#aDas#} in the three first meanings.
It is used, like this word, in its two first meanings in the
sense of a nominative, ablative and locative and may in its
first meaning govern a noun in the genitive, more seldom in
the ablative. See {#aDas#}. E. {#aD#} (considered as a substitute
of {#aDara,#} but more probably the thematic form common to
{#aDama, aDara, aDas#} and {#aDastAt#}), taddh. aff. {#astAti#}.
<LEND>

<L>1822<pc>053-a<k1>aDastAddiS<k2>aDastAddiS
{#aDastAddiS#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-k#}) The lower region, the nadir. E.
{#aDastAt#} and {#diS#}.
<LEND>

<L>1823<pc>053-a<k1>aDaspada<k2>aDaspada
{#aDaspada#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-dam#}) The place under the feet. E. {#a-#}
{#Das#} and {#pada#}.
<LEND>

<L>1824<pc>053-a<k1>aDA<k2>aDA
{#aDA#}¦ ind. See {#aDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>1827<pc>053-b<k1>aDArmika<k2>aDArmika
{#aDArmika#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kI-kam#}) Unjust, unrighteous,
