<LEND>

<L>1828<pc>053-b<k1>aDi<k2>aDi
{#aDi#}¦ ind. (see {#nipAta, upasarga, gati, karmapravacanIya#}) A par-
ticle implying superiority in place, power, rank, quality
and quantity and generally used as a separable prepo-
sition or as a prefix to verbs, but in the Vedas also as
an adverb. With nouns it may form Tatpur., Bahuvr.
and Avyayībhāva compounds. It means.
<div n="P">1. (as adverb, in the Vedas) very much, excessively.
<div n="P">2. (as a separable preposition) <sup>1</sup> with a noun following
or preceding in the locative, <sup>a.</sup> above (in place), <sup>b.</sup> over (in
the sense of mastership, power &c.), <sup>c.</sup> under (see {#aDIna#}
and {#aDika#} 4, cf. {#aDas#}); <sup>2</sup> with a noun following or pre-
ceding in the accusative, <sup>a.</sup> on, above (in place), <sup>b.</sup> concerning,
with respect to, <sup>c.</sup> repeated it implies also proximity; f. i.
{#aDyaDi grAmam#} above the village but in its neighbourhood;
<sup>3</sup> with a noun following or preceding in the ablative (in the
Vedas), <sup>a.</sup> on, above, <sup>b.</sup> from above, <sup>c.</sup> from (in this meaning
it occurs also in the classical language, when it is supposed
to be merely an expletive, the preceding ablative implying
already the notion ‘from’), <sup>d.</sup> in consequence of, on behalf of,
<sup>e.</sup> in presence of, before, in front of; <sup>4</sup> with a noun following
or preceding in the genitive (in the Vedas), amidst, amongst.
<div n="P">3. (as a prefix to verbs) Over, esp. in the sense of
taking possession of, mastering &c. literally or metapho-
rically; but used also as an expletive esp. when followed by
another preposition: f. i. with {#kf#} to superintend, with {#i#} to
obtain, to study &c.; but it does not alter the meaning of
{#Agam,#} when forming with the latter {#aDyAgam#}.
<div n="P">4. (in composition) <sup>1</sup> (with Tatpur. or Bahuvr.) it implies
superiority in place, rank, quantity &c., <sup>2</sup> (with Avyayībh.)
<sup>a.</sup> concerning, with respect to, <sup>b.</sup> over. E. unknown.
<LEND>

<L>1829<pc>053-b<k1>aDi<k2>aDi
{#aDi#}¦ 1. m. ({#-DiH#}) Anxiety, mental pain; more usually {#ADi#}
q. v. of which it seems to be an incorrect reading. E. see {#ADi#}.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-DiH#}) A woman in her courses. See also {#avi#}.
E. {#ad,#} kṛt aff. {#i#} and {#D#} substituted for {#d#} or a Tatpur.
{#a#} neg. and {#Di#} (from {#DA#}). (The first etym. doubtful.)
<LEND>

<L>1830<pc>053-b<k1>aDika<k2>aDika
{#aDika#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Exceeding, in addition to
(the reverse of {#nyUna;#} between both {#sADAraRa#}). <sup>2</sup> More, more
than, superior (in place, power, rank, quality or quantity).
<sup>3</sup> Very much, excessive, excellent. <sup>4</sup> Less, smaller, inferior (cf.
{#aDi#} 2. 1. c.). {#aDikam#} used as adverb. (If {#aDika#} has the first of
these meanings, that by which the excess is caused, stands in
the instrumental or (but seldom) in the locative or forms the
first part of a Tatpur. compound of which {#aDika#} is the latter;
if it has the second meaning, the object compared with, stands
in the instrumental, the ablative or in the genitive; if it has
the last meaning, the object compared with stands in the abla-
tive. Cf. {#aDyArUQa#}. With numerals {#aDika#} may form Bahuvr.
compounds, usually in the plural, if it is the former part of
the compound; for instance {#aDikacatvAriMSAH#} (sc. {#saMKyAH#}) i. e.
more than forty. It is considered as dropped in Dwandwa
compounds of numerals f. i. in {#paYcaviMSati,#} equal to {#paYcADi-#}
{#kaviMSati#}.) <sup>5</sup> Embolismic, intercalary (only in composition
with and prefixed to the name or numeral of a luni-solar
year, to the name of a month and to the name of a day;
[Page054-a+ 56]
f. i. {#aDikASvina#}. See also {#aDikatiTi, aDikadina, aDi-#}
{#kamAsa, aDikasaMvatsara,#} and compare {#kzaya#}). <sup>5</sup> Subsequent,
following (as a day, a chapter or a passage in a book &c.;
used very much in the same manner as {#UrDva#}).
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-kam#}) <sup>1</sup> The surplus, that which is exceeding.
<sup>2</sup> (In Nyāya.) Superfluity in reasons or instances, giving
more reasons or instances than are required or relevant in
a syllogism. <sup>3</sup> (In rhetoric.) Hyperbole (of which two
kinds are enumerated: hyperbole concerning the recipient
(substance, subject &c.) and hyperbole concerning that
which is to be received (accidents, predicate &c.). E. {#aDi,#}
taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

E. {#aDika,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>1833<pc>054-a<k1>aDikatiTi<k2>aDikatiTi
{#aDikatiTi#}¦ Karmadh. m. f. ({#-TiH-TiH#}) An intercalary lunar
day. When no tithi (q. v.) begins or ends in a solar day,
the numeral of the preceding is repeated in the calendar,
the first tithi being accounted the intercalated and the second
the proper one. Compare {#kzayatiTi#}. E. {#aDika#} and {#tiTi#}.
<LEND>

other. See {#aDidanta#} and {#varDana#}. E. {#aDika#} and {#danta#}.

<L>1838<pc>054-a<k1>aDikaraRa<k2>aDikaraRa
{#aDikaraRa#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Superiority, supremacy, govern-
ment. <sup>2</sup> Title, right. <sup>3</sup> Town meeting, court of justice. <sup>4</sup> Sup-
port, receptacle. <sup>5</sup> Substance ({#dravya,#} as the recipient of quali-
ties &c.). <sup>6</sup> (In grammar.) Comprehension, location, gener-
ally the sense of the seventh or locative case, but occa-
sionally also that of the third or instrumental and of the
sixth or genitive case. <sup>7</sup> (In grammar.) Government, re-
gimen; see {#ekADikaraRa, yugapadaDikaraRa, samAnADikaraRa#}.
<sup>8</sup> (In philosophy.) A case or topic; esp. in the Mīmānsā
and Vedānta; in the former it comprehends usually five
parts or members, the subject ({#vizaya#}), the doubt ({#saMSaya#}),
the first side (or objectionable) argument ({#pUrvapakza#}), the fol-
lowing (or right) argument ({#uttarapakza#}) and the conclusion
({#sidDAnta#} or {#rAdDAnta#}). Sometimes, however, the second
part is inherent in the third and the fifth in the fourth.
In both philosophies an adhikaraṇa is a subdivision of a
pāda, which is the division of an adhyāya. E. {#kf#} with {#aDi,#}
kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. ({#-RaH-RI#}). See {#aDikAra#} II. E. {#aDi#} and
{#karaRa;#} in the fem. with aff. {#NIp#}.
<LEND>

<L>1839<pc>054-a<k1>aDikaraRamaRqapa<k2>aDikaraRamaRqapa
{#aDikaraRamaRqapa#}¦ Tatpur. m. n. ({#-paH-pam#}) A hall of the town
council, a hall of justice(?). E. {#aDikaraRa#} and {#maRqapa#}.
<LEND>

<L>1840<pc>054-a<k1>aDikaraRasidDAnta<k2>aDikaraRasidDAnta
{#aDikaraRasidDAnta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ntaH#}) (In the Nyāya philoso-
phy.) A truth or conclusion which implies another truth or
conclusion; one of the four kinds of {#sidDAnta#}. See also {#sarva-#}
{#tantrasidDAnta, pratitantrasidDAnta#} and {#aByupagamasidDAnta#}. E. {#a-#}
{#DikaraRa#} and {#sidDAnta,#} a paramount truth.
<LEND>

<L>1855<pc>054-b<k1>aDikAra<k2>aDikAra
{#aDikAra#}¦ I. Tatp. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Superintendence, supremacy, autho-
rity. <sup>2</sup> Rule, government. <sup>3</sup> Duty, office. <sup>4</sup> Right, title, owner-
ship. <sup>5</sup> The use of royal insignia. <sup>6</sup> (In the Mīmānsā philo-
sophy.) The right of action, i. e. the right to institute a
sacrifice and to claim the results which are derived from
it; it is subject to different regulations and restrictions and
forms the subject of the sixth adhyāya of the Mīmānsā.
See also {#karmADikAra#}. <sup>7</sup> A topic in a book; especially
in grammatical works where it means a precept, rule or
word, heading and applying to a number of particular rules
which follow. Also written {#aDIkAra#}. E. {#kf#} with {#aDi,#}
kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. ({#-raH-rI#}) One who has many duties to per-
form, very busy. E. {#aDi#} and {#kAra;#} in the fem. with aff. {#NIz#}.

<L>1876<pc>055-a<k1>aDija<k2>aDija

<sup>2</sup> Born from, produced on(?). E. {#jan#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#qa#}.
<LEND>

<L>1877<pc>055-a<k1>aDijanana<k2>aDijanana
{#aDijanana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Birth. E. {#jan#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>1878<pc>055-a<k1>aDijihva<k2>aDijihva
{#aDijihva#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-hvaH#}) One of the diseases of the throat,
described as ‘a swelling at the root of the tongue like a second
tongue’ (probably a swelling of the epiglottis)--therefore
[Page055-b+ 56]
called also {#dvijihva#}--and produced by the phlegm and blood;
when it suppurates, considered as incurable. Also {#aDi-#}
{#jihvikA#}. E. {#aDi#} and {#jihvA#}.
<LEND>

<L>1879<pc>055-b<k1>aDijihvikA<k2>aDijihvikA
{#aDijihvikA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-kA#}) The same as the preceding.
E. {#aDijihva,#} samāsānta aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>1880<pc>055-b<k1>aDijya<k2>aDijya
{#aDijya#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-jyaH-jyA-jyam#}) Strung (as a bow).
E. {#aDi#} and {#jyA#}.
<LEND>

{#aDijyotizam#}¦ Avyayībh. Concerning or relating to the lu-
minous part of creation; a chapter in the Upanishads treat-
ing thereon, comprises the following subjects: fire, sun,
water and the substance of lightning. E. {#aDi#} and {#jyotiza#}.

<L>1890<pc>055-b<k1>aDidEvata<k2>aDidEvata
{#aDidEvata#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> The supreme or tutelary
deity. <sup>2</sup> The active principle in creation, the regulating
power which resides in water, fire, sky, air, the regions
&c. See also {#aDiBUta, aDyAtma#}.
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-tam#}) Concerning <sup>1</sup> the deity or <sup>2</sup> the active
principle in creation. E. {#aDi#} and {#dEvata#}.

<L>1891<pc>055-b<k1>aDipa<k2>aDipa

<L>1892<pc>055-b<k1>aDipati<k2>aDipati
{#aDipati#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> A master, an owner, a ruler. <sup>2</sup> A

dicine.) ‘That part of the trunk which is inside of the
upper part of the head, at the passage of the vessel along
the lateral sinus; wounds inflicted there produce instan-
taneous death’. E. {#pA#} with {#aDi,#} uṇ. aff. {#qati#}.

word, to the vaidik meaning of it.

<L>1901<pc>056-a<k1>aDiprazwiyuga<k2>aDiprazwiyuga
{#aDiprazwiyuga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) (ved.) The yoke over the
Praṣṭi horse, to which a fourth horse was put (in a cere-
mony connected with the Vājapeya sacrifice; two horses
being put before a cart and a third in front of the two,
so as to form with them a kind of triangle or tripod
({#prazwi#} q. v.), wherefore the third horse was called meta-
phorically the Praṣṭi). E. {#aDiprazwi#} and {#yuga#}.
<LEND>

<L>1902<pc>056-a<k1>aDiBU<k2>aDiBU

aff. {#kvip#}.
<LEND>

<L>1903<pc>056-a<k1>aDiBUta<k2>aDiBUta
{#aDiBUta#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-tam#}) A subtile or invisible element,
one which is the cause of the gross or visible elements
(also as an attribute of the supreme soul that pervades and
regulates all elements or existence).
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-tam#}) Concerning or relating to the bhūta
or elements; a chapter in the Upanishads includes under
this topic, earth, atmosphere, material heaven, regions,
intermediate regions, fire, air, sun, moon, lunar mansions,
water, annual plants, trees, ether, soul. (In derivatives
with a taddh. aff. which has an anubandha {#Y, R#} or {#k,#}
both parts of this word assume vṛddhi, f. i. {#ADiBOtika#}.)
E. {#aDi#} and {#BUta#}.
<LEND>

<L>1904<pc>056-a<k1>aDimanTa<k2>aDimanTa
{#aDimanTa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-nTaH#}) (In medicine.) Severe ophthal-
mia which is described as having the following symptoms:
‘acute pains as if the eyes were torn; throbbing which ex-
tends to half of the head’; it consists of four varieties ac-
cording to its being produced by derangement of the air,
bile, phlegm or blood. Also {#aDImanTa#}. E. {#aDi#} and {#manTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>1905<pc>056-a<k1>aDimanTana<k2>aDimanTana
{#aDimanTana#}¦ Tatpur. m. n. ({#-naH-nam#}) (ved.) A piece of wood from
the paring of the sacrificial post, placed over the araṇi
(q. v.) to kindle a fire by attrition. E. {#manT#} with {#aDi,#}
kṛt aff. {#lyuw;#} scil. {#Sakala#}.
<LEND>

<L>1906<pc>056-a<k1>aDimanTita<k2>aDimanTita
{#aDimanTita#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Affected with the disease
called {#aDimanTa#} q. v. E. {#aDimanTay#} ({#aDimanTa,#} denom. aff.
{#Ric#}), kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>1907<pc>056-a<k1>aDimAMsa<k2>aDimAMsa
{#aDimAMsa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-saH#}) (In medicine.) A disease of the
gums, described as ‘a great and painful swelling round the
wisdom-tooth with the discharge of saliva; produced by
diseased phlegm’. Also {#aDimAMsaka#}. E. {#aDi#} and {#mAMsa#}.

{#aDimAMsArman#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-rma#}) (In medicine.) A disease of the
white part on the conjunctiva of the eye; it is described as ‘a
large, soft (fleshy growth), either liver-coloured or brown’.
Also {#aDikamAMsArman#}. E. {#aDimAMsa#} (scil. {#ja#}) and {#arman;#}
‘the disease {#arman#} produced by the fleshy excrescence’.
<LEND>

<L>1910<pc>056-b<k1>aDimAtra<k2>aDimAtra

the doctrine of the Upanishads the mysterious syllable {#om#}
is said to be exempt from the general rules of prosody.

<L>1939<pc>057-a<k1>aDivAsa<k2>aDivAsa
{#aDivAsa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-saH#}) I. <sup>1</sup> One who dwells above others.
<sup>2</sup> One who dwells near others, a neighbour. <sup>3</sup> An in-
habitant. <sup>4</sup> An abode, a place or situation. E. {#vas#} (to
dwell &c.) with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">II. A cover, an upper garment. Also {#aDIvAsa#}. E. {#vas#}
(to cover with dress) with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">III. Continuance, perseverance, esp. fig.: fixing one's
self at a person's door in order to enforce compliance with
some demand. E. {#vas (vasu)#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">IV. <sup>1</sup> Perfuming or dressing the person &c.; (as materials and
objects of toilet by which this is done, are enumerated the fol-
lowing: {#mfttikA, ganDaH, SilA, DAnyam, dUrvA, puzpam, Palam,#}
{#daDi, Gftam, svastikam, sindUram, SaNKaH, kajjalam, rocanA, Sve-#}

{#stapAtram#}). <sup>2</sup> See {#aDivAsana#}. E. {#vAs#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.

<L>1940<pc>057-a<k1>aDivAsana<k2>aDivAsana
{#aDivAsana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Perfuming or dressing the per-
son &c. (see {#aDivAsa#} IV. 1.). <sup>2</sup> A religious ceremony, pre-
liminary to any great Hindu festival: touching a vessel
containing perfumes, flowers and other things previously
presented to an idol, or offering perfumes &c. to it. E. {#vAs#}
with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<div n="P">II. <sup>1</sup> A summoning and fixing of the presence of a divinity upon
an image &c., when he is wanted for any solemnity. <sup>2</sup> The
placing of a new image in water &c. the day before the divinity
is to be summoned to inhabit it. <sup>3</sup> The same as {#aDivAsa#} III.
E. {#vas (vasu)#} with {#aDi,#} in the caus., kṛt aff. {#yuc(?)#}.
<LEND>
[Page057-b+ 56]

<L>1941<pc>057-b<k1>aDivAsaBUmi<k2>aDivAsaBUmi
{#aDivAsaBUmi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-miH#}) A dwelling place. E. {#aDivAsa#}
and {#BUmi#}.
<LEND>

{#aDivAsita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) I. Invested with. E.
{#vas#} (to cover with dress) with {#aDi,#} in the caus., kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<div n="P">II. Perfumed, scented. E. {#vAs#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>1946<pc>057-b<k1>aDividyam<k2>aDividyam

chapter in the Upanishads treating thereon comprises the sub-

<L>1947<pc>057-b<k1>aDivinnA<k2>aDivinnA
{#aDivinnA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-nnA#}) (In law.) A wife whose husband has
subsequently married others; a superseded wife. E. {#vid (vidx)#}
with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta,#} or according to another etym. a Bahuvr.
of {#aDi#} and {#vinna,#} taken either in the sense of {#vinnA#} or {#vinnam#}.
<LEND>

or {#aDivedanIyA#}. E. {#vid (vidx)#} with {#aDi,#} kṛtya aff. {#tavya#}.

<L>1958<pc>057-b<k1>aDizavaRa<k2>aDizavaRa

<L>1959<pc>057-b<k1>aDizWAtf<k2>aDizWAtf

<sup>2</sup> (According to the doctrine of the Pāśupatas) Īśvara,
the superintending or ruling providence. (In the feminine
esp. in conjunction with {#devatA,#} a ruling or tutelary divinity.)

<LEND>

<L>1972<pc>058-a<k1>aDIna<k2>aDIna
{#aDIna#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Dependant. <sup>2</sup> Docile. E.
{#aDi#} and {#ina#} ‘having a master over one's self’. This word
and the etymology as mentioned, are given by the native
lexicographers; but according to the best grammatical autho-
rities {#aDIna#} would not exist as a real word. Words as {#rA-#}
{#jADIna, brAhmaRADIna#} and the like, are explained by them as
coming from {#rAjADi#} ({#rAjan#} and {#aDi#}), {#brAhmaRADi#} ({#brAhmaRa#}
and {#aDi#}) with taddh. aff. {#Ka,#} or by others as derived from {#rA-#}
{#jan, brAhmaRa#} with taddh. aff. {#saDInan;#} it would seem therefore
that the use of {#aDIna#} as an independant word is grammatically
not correct. But see {#aDyaDIna#} and {#anaDInaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>1973<pc>058-a<k1>aDInatA<k2>aDInatA
{#aDInatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) Subjection, dependance, slavery: so {#aDI-#}
{#natva#} n. ({#-tvam#}). E. {#aDIna,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}. The gram-
matical correctness of this word is questionable; see the E.
of the preceding.
<LEND>

vowel in {#aDi#} being lengthened.

<L>1977<pc>058-b<k1>aDIra<k2>aDIra
{#aDIra#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Unsteady, unstable
(lit. or met.). <sup>2</sup> Perplexed, confused, not possessed of self-
command. <sup>3</sup> Unwise.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-rA#}) <sup>1</sup> Lightning. <sup>2</sup> (In rhetoric.) A cross or ca-
pricious mistress, one not possessed of self-command; with
two varieties, the {#maDyA#} or adolescent dame who will ‘as-
sail her lover with harsh speeches’ and the {#pragalBA#} or
{#prOQA#} or mature dame who will ‘scold and beat him’.
See also {#DIrA#} and {#DIrADIrA#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#DIra#}.
<LEND>

<L>1995<pc>058-b<k1>aDokzaja<k2>aDo'kzaja
{#aDo'kzaja#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Kṛṣṇa. <sup>2</sup> The sign
Śravaṇā. Also written {#aDokzaja#}. E. {#aDas-akza#} and {#ja;#}
‘Kṛṣṇa, as a child, killed, when lying under a car, Pūtanā,
[Page059-a+ 56]
a female fiend who was hovering over it in the shape of a
bird, and thus, as it were, was born again (under the car)’;
or according to others, from {#aDokza,#} the name of a Ṛṣi,
and {#ja,#} ‘a son of Adhoksha’; or, ‘because he is produced by
or to such as have subdued or cast down their passions,
i. e. because he becomes visible to them’; or a Bahuvr. from
{#aDas#} and {#akzaja#} (n. knowledge derived from the senses;
m. pl. living beings), ‘because he has subdued all untrue
knowledge or because he is superior to all living beings’.
<LEND>

<L>2001<pc>059-a<k1>aDojAnu<k2>aDojAnu

<L>2009<pc>059-a<k1>aDopahAsa<k2>aDopahAsa
{#aDopahAsa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-saH#}) Copulation, coition. E. This
word occurs only in the Upan. and seems to be an irre-
gular compound formed of the phrase {#aDa upa ha Asa,#}
‘she was or lay under (him)’.
<LEND>

<L>2010<pc>059-a<k1>aDobanDana<k2>aDobanDana

<L>2011<pc>059-a<k1>aDoBakta<k2>aDoBakta
{#aDoBakta#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ktam#}) (In medicine.) A medicament
which is to be taken after eating; one of the ten kinds of
medicaments classified according to the time of their appli-
cation; see besides {#nirBakta, prAgBakta, maDyeBakta, antarABakta,#}
{#saBakta, sAmudga, muhurmuhurgrAsa#} (which is twofold) and {#grA-#}
{#sAntara#}. E. {#aDas#} and {#Bakta,#} scil. {#OzaDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>2012<pc>059-a<k1>aDoBava<k2>aDoBava

E. {#aDas#} and {#Bava#}.

<L>2018<pc>059-b<k1>aDomuKa<k2>aDomuKa
{#aDomuKa#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-KaH-KA#} or {#KI-Kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Downlooked,
looking downwards. <sup>2</sup> Inverted, turned upside down, headlong.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-KaH#}) A name of Viṣṇu.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-KA#}) A plant (Premna esculenta). See {#gojihvA#}.
<div n="P">IV. n. ({#-Kam#}) A division of Naraka or hell. See {#aDaHSiras#}.
E. {#aDas#} and {#muKa;#} in the fem. with aff. {#wAp#} or {#NIz#}.
<LEND>

epithet of the goat, one of the twelve {#EkAdaSina#} (q. v.)
animals in the Aśvamedha sacrifice. E. {#aDas#} and {#rAma#}.

<L>2027<pc>059-b<k1>aDosrapitta<k2>aDo'srapitta
{#aDo'srapitta#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ttam#}) (In medicine.) A kind of ple-
thora, ‘when blood is discharged from the anus and urethra’.
Also written {#aDosrapitta#}. E. {#aDas#} and {#asrapitta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2028<pc>059-b<k1>aDyakza<k2>aDyakza
{#aDyakza#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-kzaH-kzA-kzam#}) <sup>1</sup> Perceptible, present
to the senses. <sup>2</sup> Superintending, presiding over.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-kzaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A superintendent in general, one of receipts
and disbursements. <sup>2</sup> A plant (a species of Mimusops). See
{#kzIrikA#} and {#PalADyakza#}. E. {#aDi#} and {#akza,#} or more correctly, as
also mentioned in the native etym., {#akz#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.

<L>2029<pc>059-b<k1>aDyakzaram<k2>aDyakzaram
{#aDyakzaram#}¦ Avyayībh. Above all other letters (in importance
or in place; being often put at the head of various writings,
as the mysterious syllable {#om#}). E. {#aDi#} and {#akzara#}.
<LEND>

<L>2030<pc>059-b<k1>aDyagni<k2>aDyagni
{#aDyagni#}¦ Avyayībh. (In law.) Property given to the wife at
the time of her marriage, one of the six items of woman's
peculiar property. See {#strIDana#}. E. {#aDi#} and {#agni;#} lit.
(presented) over the (nuptial) fire.
<LEND>

<L>2041<pc>060-a<k1>aDyarDa<k2>aDyarDa
{#aDyarDa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rDaH-rDA-rDam#}) One and a half, having
an extra half. See also {#sArDa#}. (In derivatives of compounds
the first part of which is {#aDyarDa#} and which have the meaning of
‘measuring or weighing, worth, containing, bought for, pro-
duced from, consisting of &c.’, the affix which would be re-
quired, is dropped in many instances; see f. i. {#aDyarDakaMsa,#}
{#aDyarDaSUrpa#} &c.) E. {#aDi#} and {#arDa#}.

containing, produced from &c. one and a half. E. {#aDyarDa,#}
taddh. aff. {#kan#}.

{#aDyarDasAhasra#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-sraH-srI-sram#}) Measuring, consisting of, worth,
bought for &c. thousand five hundred. E. {#aDyarDasahasra#} (I.),
taddh. aff. {#aR#} with Vṛddhi in the latter part of the compound.
<LEND>

<L>2062<pc>060-b<k1>aDyarDasuvarRa<k2>aDyarDasuvarRa
{#aDyarDasuvarRa#}¦ (accord. to some) Dwigu I. m. n. ({#-rRaH-rRam#})
One Suvarṇa (q. v.) and a half.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-rRaH-rRI-rRam#}) Weighing, consisting of, worth,
[Page061-a+ 56]
bought for &c. one Suvarṇa (q. v.) and a half. E. {#aDyarDa#}
and {#suvarRa;#} in the meaning II. the taddh. aff. {#Wak#} is con-
sidered as dropped. See also the following.
<LEND>

<L>2063<pc>061-a<k1>aDyarDasOvarRika<k2>aDyarDasOvarRika
{#aDyarDasOvarRika#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kI-kam#}) Weighing, produced
from, worth, bought for &c. one Suvarṇa (q. v.) and a
half. See also the preceding. E. {#aDyarDasuvarRa#} (I.), taddh. aff.
{#Wak,#} with Vṛddhi in the latter part of the compound.
<LEND>

<L>2064<pc>061-a<k1>aDyarbuda<k2>aDyarbuda
{#aDyarbuda#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-dam#}) An indolent swelling, the growth
of which begins in the embryo and which is considered in-
curable. According to the native commentaries it is a he-
reditary disease and in so far always also {#dvirarbuda#} (q. v.),
though the latter is distinct from it in some respects. E.
{#aDi#} and {#arbuda;#} ‘an Arbuda or indolent swelling which
reaches beyond (scil.) birth’, i. e. which takes place prior
to birth.
<LEND>

<L>2065<pc>061-a<k1>aDyavasAna<k2>aDyavasAna
{#aDyavasAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Determining, ascertaining. <sup>2</sup> Effort,
energy. <sup>3</sup> (In rhetoric.) The simple enunciation of elliptic
or figurative speech without qualifying it by epithets &c.,
as it were, leaving it on its own effort; such sentences as
{#Sveto DAvati#} ‘the white (horse) gallops’, {#kuntAH praviSanti#}
‘(men with) lances enter’ (see also under {#ajahatsvArTA#}), or
{#kaliNgaH sAhasikaH#} ‘the (inhabitant of) Kalinga is impetuous’
(see also under {#jahatsvArTA#}) would be lakṣaṇās or elliptic
expressions by {#aDyavasAna,#} while {#aSvaH Sveto DAvati#} the
white horse gallops, {#ete kuntAH praviSanti#} these (men with)
lances enter, {#kaliNgaH puruzo yuDyate#} the man (inhabitant of)
Kalinga fights would be qualified or lakṣaṇās by {#Aropa#}
q. v. (See also under {#lakzaRA#}.) Or {#muKaM dvitIyaScandraH,#} (her)
face is another moon, would be an {#atiSayokti#} (q. v.) or
hyperbole in virtue of {#aDyavasAna,#} the comparison as it
were resting on its own merit. E. {#so#} with {#ava#} and {#aDi,#}
kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>2066<pc>061-a<k1>aDyavasAya<k2>aDyavasAya
{#aDyavasAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Ascertainment, determining. <sup>2</sup> As-
siduous application, effort, energy. <sup>3</sup> (In philosophy.) The
specific function of {#budDi#} or intellect (q. v.), apprehension
by intellect, its taking hold of an object either by ascertain-
ment or volition. <sup>4</sup> (In rhetoric.) The same as {#aDyavasAna#}.
E. {#so#} with {#ava#} and {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#Ra#} and āgama {#yuk#}.
<LEND>

<L>2067<pc>061-a<k1>aDyavasAyita<k2>aDyavasAyita

tempted as a difficult task. E. {#so#} with {#ava#} and {#aDi,#} in
the caus., kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2069<pc>061-a<k1>aDyavasita<k2>aDyavasita

<L>2071<pc>061-a<k1>aDyasta<k2>aDyasta

stituted, supposed erroneously, misconceived: as a snake
when that so perceived is actually a piece of rope. E. {#as#}

<LEND>

<L>2073<pc>061-a<k1>aDyAtma<k2>aDyAtma
{#aDyAtma#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-tmam#}) The supreme soul or {#Atman#}
[Page061-b+ 56]
(q. v.), sometimes considered as identical with {#prARa#} (q. v.)
and, in the sectarian doctrine, especially with Nārāyaṇa
or Viṣṇu.
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-tmam#}) Concerning or relating to soul, life
&c.; see {#Atman#}. A chapter in the Upan. treating thereon con-
tains the following subjects: the lower jaw, the upper jaw,
speech and tongue; another passage comprises under this
topic <sup>1</sup> the vital airs: prāṇa, apāna, vyāna, udāna, samāna,
<sup>2</sup> the organs of sensation: eyes, ears, manas, speech, skin
(tvach) and <sup>3</sup> the elementary parts of the body: skin (char-
man), flesh, tendons, bones, marrow. E. {#aDi#} and {#Atman,#}
samāsānta aff. {#wac#}.
<LEND>

<L>2074<pc>061-b<k1>aDyAtmajYAna<k2>aDyAtmajYAna
{#aDyAtmajYAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The knowledge of the supreme
spirit or of the nature of ātman or soul. E. {#aDyAtma#} (I. or
II.) and {#jYAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>2075<pc>061-b<k1>aDyAtmadfS<k2>aDyAtmadfS

the nature of or what concerns ātman or the soul. E.
{#aDyAtma#} (II.) and {#dfS#}.
<LEND>

ātman or the soul. E. {#aDyAtma#} (II.) and {#rati#}.

<L>2080<pc>061-b<k1>aDyApaka<k2>aDyApaka
{#aDyApaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A teacher, esp. one who instructs
in the sacred books. <sup>2</sup> (According to a legend in the Calcutta
edition of the Harivanśa.) One of the sixteen Ṛtvijs (q. v.)
or priests, who was produced together with the Neṣṭṛ from
the thighs of Purushottama. The reading of the commen-
tary, however, is {#acCAvAka#} (q. v.) and the list of priests
mentioned there is differently given in the manuscripts; {#a-#}
{#DyApaka#} does not usually occur as the name of a Ṛtvij. (In
the first meaning {#aDyApaka#} may be the latter part of Tatpur.
compounds, the former of which stands in the sense of the
genitive (f. i. {#brAhmaRADyApaka#} one who instructs a Brāhmana)
and as the latter part of several Karmadh. compounds; see
f. i. {#kumArADyApaka, kaWADyApaka#}.) E. {#i (iN)#} with {#aDi,#} in
the caus., kṛt aff. {#Rvul#}.
<LEND>

of as a teacher. E. {#aDyApaka#} and {#udita#}.
<LEND>

{#aDi;#} in the caus., kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>2106<pc>062-b<k1>aDyuzwa<k2>aDyuzwa

<L>2107<pc>062-b<k1>aDyuzwavalaya<k2>aDyuzwavalaya
{#aDyuzwavalaya#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-yaH#}) Having the ringlets coiled,
wound into rings. This word occurs in the poem Ānanda-
laharī as the epithet of a serpent, to indicate that it is in
profound sleep, forming, then, three ringlets and a half;
the god Śiva is likened to a serpent coiled up in this man-
ner, its half ringlet being compared to his Śakti or female
energy and the three others to the god as representing the
Trimūrti. E. {#aDyuzwa#} and {#valaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2108<pc>062-b<k1>aDyuzwra<k2>aDyuzwra
{#aDyuzwra#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-zwraH#}) A litter drawn or carried by a camel.
E. {#aDi#} and {#uzwra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2109<pc>062-b<k1>aDyUQa<k2>aDyUQa
{#aDyUQa#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-QaH-QA-Qam#}) <sup>1</sup> Borne or placed over,
elevated. <sup>2</sup> Very prosperous, thriving. <sup>3</sup> Much, excessive.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-QaH#}) A name of Śiva.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-QA#}) A superseded wife, one whose husband has
married others. E. {#vah#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}. The com-
mentaries explain I. 2. as derived from {#aDi,#} in the sense
of {#aDika#} and {#UQa;#} II. as the god by whom the world has
been upheld ‘first’ and III. also as derived from {#aDi,#} in
the sense of ‘first’ and {#UQA#} married.
<LEND>

<L>2110<pc>062-b<k1>aDyUDnI<k2>aDyUDnI
{#aDyUDnI#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-DnI#}) The penis (or according to another
interpretation perhaps, the urethra). This word occurs esp.
in the ritual works, in passages treating on the Agnisho-
mīyapaśu (q. v.) and the ceremonies connected with it. E.
{#aDi#} and {#UDas,#} samāsānta ādeśa {#anaN#} and fem. aff. {#NIz,#}
scil. {#iqA;#} literally: the tubular vessel above the scrotum.
<LEND>

<L>2111<pc>062-b<k1>aDyUzitASva<k2>aDyUzitASva
{#aDyUzitASva#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-SvaH#}) The name of a prince, a
descendant of Daśaratha. According to others his name
would be {#aByutTitASva#} or {#dUzitASva#} or {#viDfti#}. E. {#aDyU-#}
{#zita#} (very diseased, from {#aDi#} and {#Uzita#}) and {#aSva#}.

<L>2114<pc>062-b<k1>aDyetavya<k2>aDyetavya
{#aDyetavya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-vyaH-vyA-vyam#}). The same as {#a-#}
{#DyayanIya#}. E. {#i (iN)#} with {#aDi,#} kṛtya aff. {#tavya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2119<pc>063-a<k1>aDri<k2>aDri

<L>2120<pc>063-a<k1>aDrigu<k2>aDrigu
{#aDrigu#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-guH#}--n. pl. {#-gAvaH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Of un-
restrained or irresistible course; esp. as an epithet of Indra,
Agni, Soma, the Rudras and the Aśvins. <sup>2</sup> The name of
a heavenly śamitṛ (q. v.) or killer of the sacrificial animal.
<sup>3</sup> The name of a Praishamantra (q. v.) used in the cere-
mony of the killing of the Agnīṣomīyapaśu (q. v.), and
beginning with the words {#dEvyAH SamitAra AraBaDvamuta ma-#}
{#nuzyA upanayata meDyAH#} &c. E. {#aDri#} and {#go#}.
<LEND>

doubtful; perhaps {#a#} neg. and {#Drija#} (from {#Drij#}).
<LEND>

red colour, produced by (diseased) blood and accompanied
with pain and fever’. E. unknown.

<L>2135<pc>063-a<k1>aDvan<k2>aDvan
{#aDvan#}¦ m. ({#-DvA#}) <sup>1</sup> Sky, atmosphere (only in the Vedas).
<sup>2</sup> A road. <sup>3</sup> Time. <sup>4</sup> A place (perhaps, a place where four
roads meet). <sup>5</sup> A branch or school of the Vedas or sacred
literature.--In some Tatpurusha compounds the former
part of which is an {#upasarga#} (q. v.), this word occurs in the
form of {#aDva;#} i. e. the compound assumes the samāsānta
aff. {#ac;#} e. g. {#prADva, niraDva, pratyaDva#}.--(The two last
meanings of this word are rather unsettled through the
variety of readings in the native dictionaries from which
they are taken; some read {#aDvA…saMsTAne syAdavaskanDe,#}
[Page063-b+ 56]
others {#saMsTAne sASravaskanDe;#} the best reading, however, that
which has been adopted in the present translation, seems
to be this: {#saMsTAne SAstravatskanDe#}.) E. doubtful; according
to some, {#ad,#} uṇ. aff. {#kvanip,#} with {#D#} substituted for {#d#}
‘because it eats up the strength of the traveller’; or ac-
cording to others, {#at,#} uṇ. aff. {#kvanip,#} with {#D#} instead of {#t#}.
<LEND>

<L>2136<pc>063-b<k1>aDvanIna<k2>aDvanIna
{#aDvanIna#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Marching fast or fleet. <sup>2</sup> (m.) A
traveller. E. {#aDvan,#} taddh. aff. {#Ka#}. According to some used
in all the three genders.
<LEND>

<L>2137<pc>063-b<k1>aDvanya<k2>aDvanya
{#aDvanya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-nyaH-nyA-nyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Marching fast or fleet. <sup>2</sup> (m.) A
traveller. E. {#aDvan,#} taddh. aff. {#yat#}. According to some
used in all the three genders.
<LEND>

<L>2138<pc>063-b<k1>aDvapati<k2>aDvapati
{#aDvapati#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-tiH#}) An epithet of the sun, in the
Vedas. Literally: ‘the lord of the roads’ or perhaps better
‘the lord of the atmosphere’. E. {#aDvan#} and {#pati#}.
<LEND>

<L>2139<pc>063-b<k1>aDvara<k2>aDvara
{#aDvara#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Not crooked,
honest proper (ved.) <sup>2</sup> Not perishable, lasting (in its con-
sequences, as a sacrifice; ved.). <sup>3</sup> Intent, attentive. (It is
doubtful whether this word in the two meanings ‘not crook-
ed’ and ‘not perishable’, occurs in the femin. gender, as
it is used in the Vedas either absolutely as a neuter or as
epithet of {#yajYa#} in the mascul. Nor is the latter meaning
‘intent, attentive’, a usual one, though it is given in
several of the native dictionaries.)
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Sacrifice in general, but in the ritual works
mostly used as the denomination of the greater sacrifices
or those performed with the juice of the Soma plant; see
also {#sOmyADvara#} and {#aDvarakARqa#}. <sup>2</sup> The name of a Vasu
(q. v.). <sup>3</sup> The proper name of the chief of a renowned fa-
mily. See {#ADvarAyaRa#}.
<div n="P">III. n. ({#-ram#}) Sky, atmosphere (ved.). E. {#a#} priv. and
{#Dvara#} ‘having no crookedness, dishonesty &c.’ or according
to others ‘preventing, not allowing of injury’; another
etym. makes this word, but erroneously, a Tatpur. from
{#aDvan#} and {#ra#} ‘giving or affording the road (scil. to heaven)’.
<LEND>

<L>2140<pc>063-b<k1>aDvarakarman<k2>aDvarakarman
{#aDvarakarman#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-rmaH#}) The proceedings with an
Adhwara-sacrifice (ved.). See the preceding. E. {#aDvara#}
and {#karman#}.
<LEND>

<L>2141<pc>063-b<k1>aDvarakalpA<k2>aDvarakalpA
{#aDvarakalpA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-lpA#}) One of the Kāmyeṣṭis (q. v.)
or voluntary iṣṭis with three yāgas (q. v.) in the morning,
in the middle of the day and in the evening, which may
be instituted by a man of either of the three first classes.
E. {#aDvara#} and {#kalpa#}.
<LEND>

<L>2142<pc>063-b<k1>aDvarakARqa<k2>aDvarakARqa

(q. v.) which treats on the Adhwaras or the greater sa-
crifices performed especially with the juice of the Soma
plant, the Agniṣṭoma &c. E. {#aDvara#} and {#kARqa#}.
<LEND>

and {#kft#}.

<L>2154<pc>064-a<k1>aDvary<k2>aDvary

<LEND>

<L>2155<pc>064-a<k1>aDvaryu<k2>aDvaryu
{#aDvaryu#}¦ m. ({#-ryuH#}) <sup>1</sup> One desirous of having a sacrifice insti-
tuted for one's self (used in this sense in the Rigveda). <sup>2</sup> A
priest in general (ved.) <sup>3</sup> (In the ritual and the epic litera-
ture.) A special priest, one conversant with and performing
the ritual observances connected with the Yajurveda; he is
one of the sixteen Ṛtvijs required for the performing of the
great Soma sacrifices (see {#ftvij#}) and, amongst them,
one of the four leading priests (see besides {#brahman, udgAtf#}
and {#hotf#}) who receive the whole dakṣiṇā (q. v.); his pu-
rushas or assistant priests are the {#pratiprasTAtf, nezwwa#} and
{#unnetf#} who are called, like himself, the {#dIkzayitf#} (q. v.) because
they initiate, viz. the {#aDvaryu#} the three other leading priests,
the {#pratiprasTAtf#} the {#arDin-#} (q. v.), the {#nezwf#} the {#tftIyin-#}
(q. v.) and the {#unnetf#} the {#pAdin-#} (q. v.) priests. The Mi-
mānsā decides in doubtful cases, viz. whenever a sacrifice
mentioned in and making part of the ritual of the Yajur-
veda, is mentioned also and forms part of another Veda,
whether the Adhwaryu has another priest to share in
his functions or whether he has to abstain from the pro-
ceedings altogether. The ten {#camasADvaryu#} (q. v.), who,
are also assistants or purushas of the Adhwaryu, are dis-
tinct from and do not bear the name of Ṛtvij.--According
to a legend in the Harivanśa, Nārāyaṇa created the first
Adhwaryu from his arms. The dual {#aDvaryu#} is the collective
denomination of the {#aDvaryu#} and {#pratiprasTAtf,#} his principal
assistant; the plur. {#aDvaryavaH#} of the {#aDvaryu#} and his three
assistants, and in general of those devoted to the study or
the practice of the Yajurveda. <sup>4</sup> The Yajurveda (also in the
plur. {#aDvaryavaH#}). E. {#aDvary,#} kṛt aff. {#u#}.
<LEND>

<L>2156<pc>064-a<k1>aDvaryukARqa<k2>aDvaryukARqa
{#aDvaryukARqa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Rqam#}) A collection of mantras or
prayers for the special use of the Adhwaryu (q. v.). Also
called {#ADvaryavakARqa#}. E. {#aDvaryu#} and {#kARqa#}.
<LEND>
[Page064-b+ 56]

<L>2157<pc>064-b<k1>aDvaryukratu<k2>aDvaryukratu

fices contained in the Yajurveda or to be performed by
the Adhwaryu. E. {#aDvaryu#} (in the meanings of 3. or 2.)
and {#kratu#}.

<L>2159<pc>064-b<k1>aDvaSalya<k2>aDvaSalya

{#apAmArga#}. E. {#aDvan#} and {#Salya#}.

<L>2160<pc>064-b<k1>aDvasman<k2>aDvasman

not falling, everlasting. <sup>2</sup> Not causing to perish or to fall.

<L>2161<pc>064-b<k1>aDvAnta<k2>aDvAnta
{#aDvAnta#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ntam#}) Gloom, twilight. E. {#a#} neg. and

<L>2162<pc>064-b<k1>aDvAntaSAtrava<k2>aDvAntaSAtrava

<L>2163<pc>064-b<k1>an<k2>an<h>1
I. {#an#}.¦ See {#a#} III.
<LEND>

<L>2164<pc>064-b<k1>an<k2>an<h>2
II. {#an#}.¦ Considered as a substitute of {#id#} in {#idam#} in some
cases, viz. {#anena, anayA#} and {#anayoH#}. See {#idam#} and {#ana#}.
<LEND>

<L>2165<pc>064-b<k1>an<k2>an<h>3
III. {#an#}¦ I. ({#ana-adAdi-rudAdi-udAtta-parasmEpadin#}) r. 2d cl.
par. ({#aniti-#} imp. {#AnIt#} or {#Anat-Ana-anitA-anizyati-#}
{#AnIt#}.--Desid. {#aninizati#}.--Caus. {#Anayati#}) and
<div n="P">II. ({#ana-divAdi-udAtta-anudAttet#}) r. 4th cl. ātm. ({#a-#}
{#nyate#} &c.) Also read {#aR#} q. v. <sup>1</sup> To breathe, to live. <sup>2</sup> (ved.)
To go. (In composition with {#parA#} and {#pra,#} the {#n#} of the
radical is changed to {#R#}.) With {#apa-#} To breathe away (in
farting), to produce the action of the vital air {#apAna#} (q. v.);
{#aByapa-#} The same ({#aBi#} implying moreover the direction
towards); {#ava-#} To breathe out, to breathe forth; {#ud-#}
To breathe up, to produce the action of the vital air {#udAna#}
(q. v.); {#aByud-#} The same ({#aBi#} implying also the direction
towards); {#parA-(parARiti-parARiRat-parARiRizati)(?);#}
{#pari-(paryaniti)(?); pra-#} ({#prARiti#}. Des. {#prARiRizati#}.) <sup>1</sup> To
breathe, to respire, to produce the action of the vital air
{#prARa#} q. v. <sup>2</sup> To live. <sup>3</sup> (In the Upanishads, but doubtful.)
To smell (see also {#prARa#} and {#atigraha#}). Caus. ({#prARayati-#}
{#prARiRat#}) To revive; {#anupra-#} To breathe or to live in con-
formity with (a following noun depends upon it in the ac-
cusative); {#aBipra-#} To breathe into, to make one's breath
enter into (the mouth of another); {#vi-#} To breathe, to pro-
duce the action of the vital air {#vyAna#} (q. v.); {#aBivi-#} The
same with the meaning of ‘towards’; {#sam-#} <sup>1</sup> To breathe,
to live. <sup>2</sup> To produce the action of the vital air {#samAna#} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>2166<pc>064-b<k1>ana<k2>ana<h>1
I. {#ana#}¦ ind. Not. E. g. {#anopamA te budDiH,#} explained by a
commentator: ‘thy intellect is unequalled’. See also {#anA,#}
and comp. {#anAnukftya, anAnuda#} &c.
<LEND>

<L>2167<pc>064-b<k1>ana<k2>ana<h>2
II. {#ana#}.¦ Considered by some as a substitute of {#idam#} in some
cases; viz. {#anena, anayA#} and {#anayoH#}. See {#idam#} and {#an#}.
<LEND>

<L>2168<pc>064-b<k1>ana<k2>ana<h>3
III. {#ana#}¦ m. ({#-naH#}) Spiration; it is explained as the action
which is common to the five vital airs {#prARa, apAna, udAna,#}
{#vyAna#} and {#samAna#} (qq. vv.). Compare {#anila#}. E. {#an,#} kṛt
aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>2169<pc>064-b<k1>anaMSa<k2>anaMSa
{#anaMSa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-SaH-SA-Sam#}) <sup>1</sup> Portionless, not en-
titled to a share or portion. <sup>2</sup> (In law.) One excluded from
participation in an inheritance viz. a eunuch, a degraded
man, a blind or deaf person, a fool, an idiot, a dumb
[Page065-a+ 56]
person or one deprived of one of his limbs or senses, a
cripple &c. See also {#anaMSin#} and {#niraMSaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>2170<pc>065-a<k1>anaMSatva<k2>anaMSatva
{#anaMSatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) (In law.) The not being entitled to a
share &c. See the preceding. Also {#anaMSatA#} f. ({#-tA#}). E.
{#anaMSa,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#} or {#tal#}.
<LEND>

{#naMSa#} q. v. E. {#a#} neg. and {#aMSin#}.

<L>2174<pc>065-a<k1>anaka<k2>anaka

{#ac#}) and the taddh. aff. of depreciation {#kan#}.

<L>2175<pc>065-a<k1>anakadunduBa<k2>anakadunduBa

perhaps formed only by the commentaries, to explain the
patronymic {#AnakadunduBi#} q. v. See also the following.)

<L>2176<pc>065-a<k1>anakadunduBi<k2>anakadunduBi
{#anakadunduBi#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-BiH#}) A name of Vasudeva, the
father of Kṛṣṇa. More usually written {#AnakadunduBi,#}
but given also with the short initial by some commentators
of the Amarakosha. E. {#anaka#} (instead of {#Anaka#}) and {#dundu-#}
{#Bi#} ‘because the gods beat the Anaka-drums in his house
when Kṛṣṇa was born’.
<LEND>

<L>2186<pc>065-a<k1>anagni<k2>anagni
{#anagni#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-gniH#}) Any thing not or different from
fire. E. {#a#} neg. and {#agni#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-gniH-gniH-gni#}) <sup>1</sup> Having no sacrificial
fire or being deprived of the arrangement of a sacrificial
fire place (see {#agnicayana#}), as a sacrifice. <sup>2</sup> Impious, irre-
ligious (as one not performing the observances which require
a sacrificial fire; also an epithet of the Manes {#agnizvAtta#}
q. v.). <sup>3</sup> Unmarried(?). <sup>4</sup> Having no domestic fire, no fire
[Page065-b+ 56]
for worldly purposes (as an anchorite who has given up
his house and retired to the wood). <sup>5</sup> Having a bad di-
gestion. E. {#a#} priv. or (in 5.) deterior. and {#agni#}.
<LEND>

<L>2187<pc>065-b<k1>anagnitra<k2>anagnitra
{#anagnitra#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-traH-trA#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Not having Agni
or the divinity of fire as protector, unprotected by Agni.
Or according to another interpretation, <sup>2</sup> not maintain-
ing a sacrificial fire, impious, wicked. E. {#a#} neg. and
{#agni-tra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2188<pc>065-b<k1>anagnidagDa<k2>anagnidagDa
{#anagnidagDa#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-gDaH-gDA-gDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not burnt
in or with fire. <sup>2</sup> Not burnt on the funeral pyre, not hav-
ing received the obsequies in conformity with the religious
rites.
<div n="P">II. m. pl. ({#-gDAH#}) The name of a particular class of Pi-
tṛs or Manes, of those apparently who when alive did
not observe religious rites. See {#agnidagDa#} and the following.
E. {#a#} neg. and {#agnidagDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>2189<pc>065-b<k1>anagnizvAtta<k2>anagnizvAtta
{#anagnizvAtta#}¦ Tatpur. m. pl. ({#-ttAH#}) The name of a particular
class of Pitṛs or Manes. This word is explained by a
commentator of the Yajurveda: ‘not tasted by ({#svAtta#}) i. e.
not burnt by fire, not having received the obsequies in con-
formity with the religious rites’ and it appears therefore as
a synonyme of {#anagnidagDa,#} as well as the converse of {#agni-#}
{#zvAtta#} which, according to the same commentator, would
be a synonyme of {#agnidagDa#}. Anagniṣvātta does not occur
in the list of the Pitṛs which are given in the law books
and in the Purāṇas, while {#agnidagDa#} and {#agnizvAtta#} (qq. vv.)
are named there as distinct classes and explained in a
different manner. The etymology given, which identifies
{#svAtta#} and {#svAdita,#} seems moreover objectionable. E. {#a#}
and {#agnizvAtta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2190<pc>065-b<k1>anaGa<k2>anaGa
{#anaGa#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-GaH-GA-Gam#}) <sup>1</sup> Sinless, pure.
<sup>2</sup> Clean, clear. <sup>3</sup> Handsome, pleasing.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-GaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Śiva. <sup>2</sup> The name of a Gan-
dharva. <sup>3</sup> The name of a Sādhya. <sup>4</sup> The name of a prince,
son of Surodha and Upadānavī. <sup>5</sup> The name of a son of
Vasiṣṭha and Ūrjā. <sup>6</sup> White mustard; see {#gOrasarzapa#}. A
less correct reading of this word in the latter sense is {#a-#}
{#nadya#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#aGa#}.
<LEND>

<L>2192<pc>065-b<k1>anaNga<k2>anaNga
{#anaNga#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-Ngam#}) What is different from or other

<div n="P">2. m. ({#-NgaH#}) A name of Kāma, the god of Love; so

him enamoured of Pārvatī’.
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-Ngam#}) <sup>1</sup> Sky, æther. <sup>2</sup> The same as {#manas#} q. v.

<L>2210<pc>066-a<k1>anaquh<k2>anaquh
{#anaquh#}¦ Tatpur. m. (sing. {#-qvAn, -qvan, -qvAham, -quhA, -quhe,#}
{#-quhaH, -quhi;#} du. {#-qvAhO, -qudByAm, -quhoH;#} plur. {#-qvAhaH,#}
{#-quhaH, -qudBiH, -qudByaH, -qutsu#}) f. ({#-quhI#} or {#-qvAhI#}) <sup>1</sup> A bull
or ox, especially one fit to draw a cart or to bear a weight.
<sup>2</sup> The sign of the zodiac, Taurus. <sup>3</sup> (According to a vaidik
commentator also used in the adjective sense:) fit or able
to draw a cart, as an epithet of a goat; but this expla-
nation seems doubtful.--(The use of the femin. {#anaqvAhI#}
would be restricted, according to one authority, to the
Vedas, while others do not make any distinction between
this form and {#anaquhI#}. In Avyayībh. compounds, the com-
pound terminating with {#anaquh#} assumes the samāsānta aff.
{#wac#} (see {#anaquha#}) and in Bahuvr. compounds, the samā-
sānta aff. {#kap#} (see {#anaqutka#}); in the latter, however, it
[Page066-b+ 56]
may also retain its original form, with the following de-
clension in the neuter: sing. {#anaqut,#} du. {#anaquhI#} and plur.
{#anaqvAMhi#}.) E. {#anas,#} with {#s#} changed to {#q,#} and {#vah#} (from
{#vah,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}) with samprasāraṇa of {#v;#} in the fem.
with aff. {#NIz#}.
<LEND>

<div n="P">II. Seemingly the latter part of the thematic form of an
Avyayībh. compound concluding with {#anaquh,#} f. i. {#pratyanaquham;#}
such a compound assuming the samāsānta aff. {#wac#}.

<L>2226<pc>066-b<k1>anatyantagati<k2>anatyantagati
{#anatyantagati#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) (In grammar.) The sense of
‘not completely’, ‘not very much’, the sense of diminu-
tiveness. E. {#a#} neg. {#atyanta#} and {#gati#}. See {#atyantagati#}.
<LEND>
[Page067-a+ 56]

end &c., eternal, continual. See the meanings of {#atyaya#}.

pears, a transposition of {#atyanudya,#} similar to that which
has probably taken place in {#anatidfSya#} (q. v.).

<div n="P">II. m. ({#-dyaH#}) White mustard. See {#anaGa#} which is the more
correct reading of this word. E. {#a#} neg. and {#adya#}.

<L>2233<pc>067-a<k1>anadyatana<k2>anadyatana
{#anadyatana#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-naH#}) (In grammar.) The time which
does not belong to the current day. See {#adyatana#}. It is either
{#BUtAnadyatanaH#} the past or {#BavizyadanadyatanaH#} the future time, if
such a period does not include the current day. E. {#a#} priv.
and {#adyatana,#} sc. {#kAla#}.
<LEND>

<L>2244<pc>067-a<k1>anana<k2>anana
{#anana#}¦ n. ({#-nam#}) Breathing, living. E. {#an,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>2245<pc>067-a<k1>ananaNgamejaya<k2>ananaNgamejaya
{#ananaNgamejaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Not allowing the body

<LEND>

<L>2246<pc>067-a<k1>ananuBAzaRa<k2>ananuBAzaRa
{#ananuBAzaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
Not repeating the argument for discussion, i. e. a tacit
agreement with it or assent to the assertion of the person
[Page067-b+ 56]
who has proposed it; viz. if, after the argument for dis-
cussion has been announced, it has not been repeated by
any one--the sign of taking it up--the proposer has to
proclaim it three times; if then it does not meet with the
anubhāṣana, it is considered as proved or as accepted as
such. E. {#a#} neg. and {#anuBAzaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>2247<pc>067-b<k1>ananuzaNgin<k2>ananuzaNgin
{#ananuzaNgin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-NgI-NgiRI-Ngi#}) Not attached
to, indifferent (as to pleasure &c.). E. {#a#} neg. and {#anu-#}
{#zaNgin#}.
<LEND>

<L>2248<pc>067-b<k1>ananuzWAna<k2>ananuzWAna
{#ananuzWAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Non-observance (of duties &c.),
neglect, want of propriety. See the meanings of {#anuzWAna#}.
E. {#a#} neg. and {#anuzWAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>2249<pc>067-b<k1>ananUkta<k2>ananUkta
{#ananUkta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not spoken-after
or accordingly. <sup>2</sup> Not read or studied (as the Veda). E.
{#a#} neg. and {#anUkta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2250<pc>067-b<k1>ananta<k2>ananta
{#ananta#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-ntaH-ntA-ntam#}) Endless in time
and space: eternal, unbounded, innumerable &c.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-ntaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Viṣṇu or Kṛṣṇa. <sup>2</sup> A name
of Baladeva, the elder brother of Kṛṣṇa. <sup>3</sup> A name of
Śiva. <sup>4</sup> A name of Rudra, in an Upanishad of the Athar-
vaveda. <sup>5</sup> A name of Śeṣa, the chief of the Nāgas or ser-
pent race that inhabit the infernal regions: the couch and
constant attendant of Viṣṇu. <sup>6</sup> A name of Vāsuki, another
king of the serpents, the brother of the former. <sup>7</sup> A name
of one of the Viśvadevas. <sup>8</sup> The name of the fourteenth of
the twenty-four Arhats or Jaina deified saints of the present
Avasarpiṇī; see also {#anantajit#}. <sup>9</sup> The name of a king of
Kashmir; see also {#anantadeva#}. <sup>10</sup> A proper name common to
several authors &c. <sup>11</sup> The name of a plant, Vitex trifolia
(Lin.); see {#sindavAra#}. <sup>12</sup> Talc (see {#aBraka;#} in this sense the
word is given by some as a neuter). <sup>13</sup> (In arithmetic.)
Infinite quantity: a fraction having a cypher for its deno-
minator; see also {#anantarASi#} and {#Kahara#}. <sup>14</sup> The name of
the twenty-third of the lunar asterisms; see {#SravaRa#}. <sup>15</sup> A
silken cord with fourteen knots which the Hindus tie round
the right arm at the festival of Anantachaturdaśī.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-ntA#}) <sup>1</sup> The earth. <sup>2</sup> (In arithmetic sometimes
used to denominate) the numeral one. <sup>3</sup> A name of Pār-
vatī, the wife of Śiva. <sup>4</sup> A name of Tārā, a Buddhist
deity. <sup>5</sup> The proper name of the wife of Janamejaya. <sup>6</sup> The
name of the following plants: <sup>a.</sup> Hedysarum alhagi; see
{#yavAsa#} or {#rodanI#}. <sup>b.</sup> Echytes frutescens; see {#SyAmA#} or {#go-#}
{#pI#}. <sup>c.</sup> A sort of potherb; see {#viSalyA#} or {#SakrapuzpI#}. <sup>d.</sup> Agrostis
linearis (Koen.) or Panicum dactylon; see {#dUrvA#} or {#BArgavI,#}
{#SvetadUrvA#} and {#nIladUrvA#}. <sup>e.</sup> Phyllanthus emblica (emblic my-
robolan); see {#AmalakI#}. <sup>f.</sup> Menispermum glabrum or cordi-
folium; see {#guqUcI#}. <sup>g.</sup> Gloriosa superba; see {#lANgalI#}. <sup>h.</sup> See
{#hemamAnI#}. <sup>i.</sup> Premna spinosa; see {#asimanTa#}. <sup>k.</sup> Piper longum
(Long pepper); see {#pippalI#} or {#kaRA#}. <sup>l.</sup> Terminalia chebula
(yellow myrobolan); see {#harItakI#}. <sup>m.</sup> Asclepias pseudosar-
sa; see {#SArivA#}. <sup>n.</sup> Justicia adhatoda(?). <sup>o.</sup> Bromelia Ana-
nas(?). <sup>p.</sup> Echytes dichotoma(?). <sup>q.</sup> According to some
also the same as {#anantamUla#} q. v.
<div n="P">IV. n. ({#-ntam#}) <sup>1</sup> Sky, atmosphere, æther. <sup>2</sup> Talc; (also
given in the latter sense as a masculine). E. {#a#} priv. and
{#anta#}.
<LEND>
[Page068-a+ 56]

<L>2251<pc>068-a<k1>anantaka<k2>anantaka
{#anantaka#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) Endless, eternal, unlimited.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-kam#}) (In the Jaina doctrine.) The collective ex-
pression for what is eternal viz. matter and soul; but in-
cluding also, according to a commentary, planets or accord-
ing to another, æther, regions &c. E. {#ananta,#} taddh. aff.
{#kan,#} or rather a Bahuvr. composed of {#a#} neg. and {#anta,#}
samāsānta aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>2252<pc>068-a<k1>anantakara<k2>anantakara
{#anantakara#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rI-ram#}) Making endless or
unlimited. E. {#ananta#} and {#kara#}.
<LEND>

<L>2253<pc>068-a<k1>anantaga<k2>anantaga
{#anantaga#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-gaH-gA-gam#}) Going continually,
moving perpetually. E. {#ananta#} and {#ga#}.
<LEND>

<L>2254<pc>068-a<k1>anantacaturdaSI<k2>anantacaturdaSI
{#anantacaturdaSI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-SI#}) The fourteenth lunation of

Bhādra (August-September), when Viṣṇu under the
form of the serpent Ananta is worshipped. E. {#ananta#} and
{#caturdaSI#}.
<LEND>

present Avasarpiṇī; also called {#ananta#}. E. {#ananta#} and {#jit#}
‘who conquers, who gains eternity’.

<L>2263<pc>068-a<k1>anantamUla<k2>anantamUla

<L>2264<pc>068-a<k1>anantara<k2>anantara
{#anantara#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Having nothing in-
termediate, having no interval or defect, uninterrupted,
entire; in the Upanishads also as an epithet of Brahman (n.)
or the supreme soul, of which it is said that it has nothing
before it nor after it, nor between ‘before’ and ‘after’
it nor besides it, or that it exists without interruption
or defect, entire. <sup>2</sup> Next, immediately following or pre-
ceding. <sup>3</sup> Next of kin, in succession, in caste. <sup>4</sup> Close,
compact.--{#anantaram#} immediately, afterwards; it is fol-
lowed or preceded sometimes by a noun depending upon
it in the ablative or genitive. E. {#a#} priv. and {#anantara#}.
<LEND>

<L>2265<pc>068-a<k1>anantaraja<k2>anantaraja
{#anantaraja#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) The son of a man of the three
first castes, married to a woman of a caste inferior in order
[Page068-b+ 56]
to his own, but not to a Sūdra woman viz. of a Brāhmaṇa
by a Kṣatriyā or Vaiśyā and of a Kṣatriyā by a Vaiśyā.
The three kinds of sons got by parents of the same caste
are called {#sajAtija#} and both, comprising six kinds, have
the privileges of a Dvija or twice-born man. (This is
the explanation given by a commentator of Manu and,
according to him, {#anantaraja#} would have a different mean-
ing than {#anantarajAta,#} though both words appear to be
synonymes.) E. {#anantara#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>2266<pc>068-b<k1>anantarajAta<k2>anantarajAta
{#anantarajAta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-taH#}) The son of a father married to
a woman of a caste next in order to his own, viz. of a
Brāhmaṇa by a Kṣatriyā, of a Kshatriya by a Vaiśyā,
of a Vaiśya by a Sūdrā. E. {#anantara#} and {#jAta#}.
<LEND>

{#anantarAyam#}¦ Bahuvr. ind. Without interruption. E. {#a#} priv.
and {#antarAya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2272<pc>068-b<k1>anantarhita<k2>anantarhita

<LEND>

<L>2273<pc>068-b<k1>anantavat<k2>anantavat
{#anantavat#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) Endowed with infinity,
eternal.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-vAn#}) A name or epithet of one of the four pā-
das or feet of Brahman (in the symbolical language of the
Upanishads), consisting of four Kalās or parts, viz. earth,
intermediate space, heaven and ocean. The other three
feet are called {#prakASavat, jyotizmat#} and {#Ayatanavat#}
(qq. vv.).
<LEND>

<L>2274<pc>068-b<k1>anantavarman<k2>anantavarman
{#anantavarman#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-rmA#}) The proper name of a king.
E. {#ananta#} and {#varman#}.
<LEND>

<L>2275<pc>068-b<k1>anantavAta<k2>anantavAta
{#anantavAta#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-taH#}) (In medicine.) One of the
diseases of the head (see {#Siroroga#}). It is described in the
following manner: ‘when the three humours (air, bile and
phlegm) are deranged in the vessels of the back of the
neck they make it very feverish and painful and it sup-
presses the humours particularly in the region of the eyes,
eyebrows and temples; it then produces shaking in the
sides of the cheeks, cramp of the jaws and morbid affec-
tions of the eyes’. E. {#ananta#} and {#vAta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2276<pc>068-b<k1>anantavikramin<k2>anantavikramin
{#anantavikramin#}¦ m. ({#-mI#}) The proper name of a Bodhisattva
or Bauddha saint. E. {#ananta-vikrama,#} taddh. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

<L>2277<pc>068-b<k1>anantavijaya<k2>anantavijaya
{#anantavijaya#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-yaH#}) The name of the shell of Yu-
dhiṣṭhira. E. {#ananta#} and {#vijaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2278<pc>068-b<k1>anantavIrya<k2>anantavIrya
{#anantavIrya#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-ryaH#}) The proper name of the twenty-
third Jaina Arhat or deified saint of a future age or Utsar-
piṇī. E. {#ananta#} and {#vIrya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2279<pc>068-b<k1>anantavrata<k2>anantavrata

served on the day of the full moon in Bhādra (August-
[Page069-a+ 56]

serpent Ananta (q. v.). See {#anantacaturdaSI#}. E. {#ananta#}

<L>2282<pc>069-a<k1>anantaSIrzA<k2>anantaSIrzA

<L>2283<pc>069-a<k1>anantaSuzma<k2>anantaSuzma

<LEND>

<L>2284<pc>069-a<k1>anantya<k2>anantya
{#anantya#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-ntyaH-ntyA-ntyam#}) Infinite, eternal,
unbounded.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-ntyam#}) Infinity, eternity, immortality. cf. {#Anantya#}.
E. {#a#} priv. and {#antya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2285<pc>069-a<k1>ananda<k2>ananda
{#ananda#}¦ Bahuvr. m. pl. ({#-ndAH#}) (In the Upanishads) the name
of a world where those are doomed to reside after their
death, who have not acquired spiritual knowledge or who
have made to a priest a sacrificial gift of an old or de-
fective cow &c. E. {#a#} priv. and {#nanda;#} literally: ‘having or
giving no pleasure or joy’.
<LEND>

<L>2286<pc>069-a<k1>ananna<k2>ananna
{#ananna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nnam#}) No-food, no-corn, bad food, bad
corn &c. See the meanings of {#anna#}. E. {#a#} deter. and {#anna#}.
<LEND>

<L>2287<pc>069-a<k1>ananya<k2>ananya
{#ananya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-nyaH-nyA-nyam#}) I. Tatpur. Not different, same,
identical. E. {#a#} neg. and {#anya#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. <sup>1</sup> Without another, one, sole. <sup>2</sup> Fixed on
one object, having no other object or occupation. E. {#a#}
priv. and {#anya#}.
<LEND>

<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-tiH-tiH-ti#}) Having but one refuge,

<L>2306<pc>069-b<k1>ananvaya<k2>ananvaya
{#ananvaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) (In rhetoric.) One of the Ālaṅkā-
ras or figures of speech: comparing an object to itself, with
respect to its being the only one of its class as to the qua-
lities expressed and therefore not liable to comparison with
any thing else; e. g. the moon shines like a moon i. e. like
a very moon, a moon indeed. E. {#a#} neg. and {#anvaya,#} literally:
‘want of connexion sc. with other objects’.
<LEND>

<L>2307<pc>069-b<k1>ananvita<k2>ananvita
{#ananvita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unconnected with,
inconsistent, incoherent. <sup>2</sup> Devoid of, not possessing. E.
{#a#} neg. and {#anvita#}.
<LEND>

<L>2377<pc>071-b<k1>anamitra<k2>anamitra
{#anamitra#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-traH-trA-tram#}) Free from enemies,

<div n="P">II. n. ({#-tram#}) The being free from or without enemies.
<div n="P">III. m. ({#-traH#}) A proper name of <sup>1</sup> A prince of the solar
race, a descendant of Sagara, son of Nighna and brother
of Raghu, the fifty-second king of Ayodhyā. <sup>2</sup> A son of
the king Kroṣṭu or Kroṣtṛ by Gāndhāri and father of

of Sumitra by Mādrī and brother to Śini; or, again, a
grandson of Dhṛṣṭa, son of Sumitra &c. E. {#a#} priv. and
{#amitra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2382<pc>071-b<k1>anaraRya<k2>anaraRya
{#anaraRya#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-RyaH#}) The proper name of a king of
Ayodhyā, of the solar race; according to one authority, a
son of Vāna and father of Pṛthu, according to others,
a son of Sambhūta and father of Pṛṣadaśva or, again, a
son of Sarwakarman and father of Nighna. Those who
make him a son of Sambhūta, relate that he was slain by
Rāvaṇa.
<LEND>

<L>2400<pc>072-a<k1>anala<k2>anala
{#anala#}¦ m. ({#-laH#}) <sup>1</sup> Fire. <sup>2</sup> A name of Agni or the god of fire.

deva. <sup>5</sup> The proper name of a Muni. <sup>6</sup> The proper name
of a monkey (in the Rāmāyaṇa). <sup>7</sup> The fire of the stomach,
digestive faculty. <sup>8</sup> Bile. <sup>9</sup> The name of several plants,
viz. <sup>a.</sup> Plumbago zeylanica (see {#citraka#}), <sup>b.</sup> Plumbago rosea
(see {#raktacitraka#}), <sup>c.</sup> Semicarpus anacardium (see {#BallAtaka#}).
<sup>10</sup> Wind. <sup>11</sup> (In astronomy.) The name of the fiftieth year
[Page072-b+ 56]
of Bṛhaspati's cycle of sixty years. <sup>12</sup> (In astronomy.)
The name of the third lunar mansion or Kṛttikā(?). <sup>13</sup> (In
arithmetic sometimes used to denote) the numeral three; see
{#agni#}(9.). E. {#an,#} in the causative, uṇ. aff. {#kalac;#} ({#anala#}
belongs to the {#vfzAdi#}).

<L>2494<pc>075-a<k1>anA<k2>anA
{#anA#}¦ ind. (ved.) Certainly, indeed. (A commentator of the
Amarakosha considers this particle as a synonyme of the
negative {#na;#} his opinion rests, however, only on an arti-
ficial interpretation of the word {#anAvfzwi#} (q. v.) and is
refuted by others who explain it as derived, not from {#anA#}
and {#vfzwi,#} but from {#a#} neg. and {#Avfzwi#}.) E. unknown;
probably an obsolete third case of the pronominal theme
{#a#} (q. v.).
<LEND>

{#anAgAmin#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-mI-minI-mi#}) <sup>1</sup> Not arriv-

dhists, generally termed Āryās; (see besides {#SrotaApanna,#}
{#sakfdAgAmin#} and {#arhat#}): literally, one who does not return,
but it means one who has only to pass through forty
thousand kalpas and then is freed from transmigration. E.

eternal. E. {#a#} priv. and {#Adya#}.

<L>2600<pc>077-b<k1>anAraByavAda<k2>anAraByavAda
{#anAraByavAda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) An injunction (concerning sa-
crifices or vaidik rites) not connected with the books or

regular order. See {#AraByavAda#} and the following. E. {#a#}
neg. and {#AraByavAda#}.
<LEND>

<L>2601<pc>077-b<k1>anAraByADIta<k2>anAraByADIta
{#anAraByADIta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Not read in con-
nexion with chapters or books treating authoritatively on
vaidik rites or sacrifices; said of passages, esp. in the
Brāhmaṇas, which treat on rites, sacrifices &c. not to be
connected with other passages with which they may happen
[Page078-a+ 56]
to be found together, the injunctions of the latter not be-
ing applicable to those of the former. A ceremonial, for
instance, taught in an anārabhyādhīta, would not be con-
sidered as the essential part of another ceremonial, treated
in passages, called ārabhyādhīta, which may precede or
follow it, nor share in the general rules concerning these;
and it is, therefore, always the object of special rules which
define its position amongst the other parts of the ritual and
its applicability. E. {#a#} neg. and {#AraByADIta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2668<pc>079-b<k1>anitya<k2>anitya
{#anitya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-tyaH-tyA-tyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Transient, not ever-
lasting (as the body, or in the Sāṅkhya philosophy the
discrete principles mahat, ahaṅkāra &c. or in the Nyāya
the sound &c. <sup>2</sup> Occasional, not peremptory, not obligatory
as a rule &c. (see also {#kAmya;#} as in the Jyotiṣṭoma the six
samsthās: {#atyagnizwoma, ukTya, zoqaSin, atirAtra, aptoryAma#}
and {#vAjapeya#} &c.). <sup>3</sup> Not necessary, not immutable. See
{#anityasamAsa#}. <sup>4</sup> Unstable, inconstant. <sup>5</sup> Unusual, irregular.
({#anityam#} not always.) E. {#a#} neg. and {#nitya#}.
<LEND>

{#karman#}. E. {#anitya#} and {#karman#}.

<L>2672<pc>079-b<k1>anityadatta<k2>anityadatta

a son is performed without the homas or burnt offerings re-
quired at the adoption of a nityadatta (q. v.). Also {#anityadattaka#}
and {#anityadatrima#}. E. {#anitya#} and {#datta,#} temporarily given, scil. {#putra#}.

<L>2675<pc>080-a<k1>anityapratyavekzA<k2>anityapratyavekzA

<L>2676<pc>080-a<k1>anityaBAva<k2>anityaBAva
{#anityaBAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) The state or condition of what
is transient or perishable, perishableness. E. {#anitya#} (in
the sense of the genitive) and {#BAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>2677<pc>080-a<k1>anityasama<k2>anityasama
{#anityasama#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-maH-mA#}) (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
Wrongly generalizing the predicament of perishableness i. e.
a sophism on perishableness; viz. arguing perishableness
from the reason that every thing is perishable because it
shares in some qualities with other things which are pe-
rishable. E. {#anitya#} and {#sama#} (in the sense of {#jAti,#} sophism);
the masc. form of this word is explained according to some,
by the ellipsis of {#pratizeDa#} or contradiction, as a Sūtra in
the Nyāya treating on a sophism is always followed by
another containing the refutation; or, according to others,
by the ellipsis of {#vikalpa#} (in the sense of {#viviDaH kalpaH#}
i. e. {#prakAraH#} or variousness), there being various sophisms,
viz. twenty-four; or according to others, by the ellipsis of
{#prayoga#} i. e. a (logical) proceeding which likens or produces
the plausibility of perishableness; or the word is taken as
a Bahuvr. with the ellipsis of {#prayoga#} i. e. a logical proceeding
in which perishableness is likened (viz. made plausible).--
As a feminine, {#°samA#} is taken in the sense of {#jAti,#} sophism.
<LEND>

<L>2678<pc>080-a<k1>anityasamaprakaraRa<k2>anityasamaprakaraRa
{#anityasamaprakaraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) The chapter in the Nyāya
philosophy which treats on the sophism {#anityasama#} q. v. E.
{#anityasama#} and {#prakaraRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>2679<pc>080-a<k1>anityasamAsa<k2>anityasamAsa
{#anityasamAsa#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-saH#}) (In grammar.) A compound
which may be dissolved into its constituent parts without under-
going a material change of sense; e. g. {#rAjapuruzaH,#} which may
be dissolved into {#rAjYaH puruzaH#}. The converse of {#nityasamAsa#} q. v.
<LEND>

<L>2704<pc>080-b<k1>animittaliNganASa<k2>animittaliNganASa
{#animittaliNganASa#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-SaH#}) (In medicine.) A dis-

lens is affected; it is described as being produced ‘by the
sight of the divine Ṛṣis, the Gandharvas, the great Ser-
pents and luminous bodies’ and causing the entire loss of
vision. See also {#liNganASa#} and {#sanimittaliNganASa#}. E. {#ani-#}
{#mitta#} and {#liNganASa#}.
<LEND>

<H>CORRECTIONS AND ADDITIONS.
<P>P. = page; 1. = line; r. = read; a. = add; d. = take off; p. = instead of; {%a%} = first column; {%b%} = second column.
<P>P. 5{%a,%} 1. 10, r. E. {#a#} and {#kfzwapacya;#} 1. 29, r. E. an abbrev. form of {#naktA#}.--P. 6{%a,%} 1. 20, d. ‘and {#rI#}’; 1. 35, r. ‘Loosing (the game of
{#paYcikA#}) through not succeeding with one die’.--P. 6{%b,%} 1. 10, r. ‘{%Tuesday%}’ (p. {%Wednesday%}).--P. 7{%a,%} 1. 29, r. ‘{#rAjan,#} sam. aff. {#wac#}.--
P. 7{%b,%} 1. 25, a. ‘which is {#nit#}’.--P. 8{%b,%} d. 1. 23 and 24; 1. 53, a. ‘Bahuvr.’ and r. ‘E. {#agati#} (Bahuvr.), sam. aff. {#kap#}’.--P. 9{%b,%} d. 1. 1-4.
--P. 12{%a,%} 1. 52, r. ‘{#-rDikA#}’ (p. {#kA#} or {#kI#}).--P. 15{%a,%} 1. 13, {%b.%} 1. 1, 16{%a,%} 1. 14, d. ‘{#-rA#} or’.--P. 16{%a,%} 1. 38, r. {#-SikA#}.--P. 17{%a,%} 1. 2, r. E.
{#aNka,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.--P. 18{%a,%} 1. 5, a. ‘or {#am,#} uṇ. aff. {#gan; aNga#} (II. 1. 2.), in Bahuvr. comp. fem. aff. {#wAp#} or {#NIz#}.’--P. 21{%a,%} 1. 40, r. {#Ca#}
(p. {#ya#}).--P. 21{%b,%} 1. 29, r. {#NIz;#} 1. 35, d. ‘the ancle’ and ‘also’.--P. 23{%a,%} 1. 38, r. {#-kI#}.--P. 24{%a,%} 1. 47, r. E. {#ajaganDi#}.--P. 25{%b,%} 1. 44, r.
‘{%sword%}’ (p. {%shears%}) and E. {#kfpARa#}.--P. 28{%a,%} 1. 25, a. ‘fem. {#NIp#}’.--P. 28{%b,%} 1. 49 and 31{%a,%} 1. 16, r. {#Wan#} (p. {#zWan#}).--P. 28{%b,%} 1. 30, r. {#-NIz#}.
--P. 30{%b,%} 1. 56, a. ‘fem. I. {#NIz,#} III. {#NIn#}’.--P. 32{%a,%} 1. 32, d. ‘f. n. {#-vyasI-vyaH#}’.--P. 35{%a,%} 1. 24, d. ‘or {#-rI#}’.--P. 37{%b,%} 1. 50, a. ‘or {#-NgI#}’.
--P. 38{%a,%} 1. 33, a. ‘{%Tatpur%}’.--P. 39{%b,%} 1. 23, r. {#-strI;#} 1. 26, r. {#-rI#}.--P. 40{%a,%} 1. 2, r. ‘{#aN#}’ (p. {#qa#}).--P. 41{%b,%} 1. 46, r. ‘{#trinic;#} d. 1. 51.--
P. 42{%b,%} 1. 36, r. {#ac#} (p. {#aR#}).--P. 43{%a,%} 1. 16, d. ‘{#-hnA-hnam#}’.--P. 45{%a,%} 1. 51, r. ‘E. {%Probably%} &c.’--P. 46{%b,%} 1. 14, r. {#-datI;#} 1. 50, a. in
both meanings ‘or not being in the teeth’.--P. 51{%b,%} 1. 55, r. ‘Tatpur.’--P. 55{%a,%} 1. 54, r. Tatpur.--P. 55{%b,%} 1. 4, d. Bahuvr. and r.
E. taddh. aff. {#kan#}.--P. 65{%a,%} 1. 32, r. {#-kzA#} (p. {#-kzI#}).--P. 69{%b,%} 1. 8, r. {#-sA#} (p. {#-sI#}).
<P>The Articles {#akta, agnizvAtta, agnisAt, aYjalika, at, ati, atidurlamBa, ada, adas#} and {#aDarozWa#} will be completed or amended
in the Supplement {%which will contain also the additional words and meanings.%}--It was originally intended to omit the name ‘{%Tatpur.%}’
when the {%Upapada-%}compounds had for their first part a {%gati,%} in order to distinguish them from common Tatpurushas. As the dif-
ference, however, appeared sufficiently marked by the method in which their Etym. is given and which, not being that of the native
grammarians, will have to be explained in the grammatical Appendix, the name ‘{%Tatpur.%}’ has been added already to all similar
compounds beginning with {#aDi;#} and the same may be done, for the sake of conformity, with the {%Upapada-%}compounds beginning
with {#ati#}.
[Page081-a+ 56]

<L>2712<pc>081-a<k1>animeza<k2>animeza
{#animeza#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-zaH#}) The not-twinkling. E. {#a#} neg.
and {#nimeza#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-zaH-zA-zam#}) Not twinkling.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A god. <sup>2</sup> A fish. E. {#a#} priv. and {#nimeza#}.

<L>2713<pc>081-a<k1>animezam<k2>animezam
{#animezam#}¦ Tatpur. ind. (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Without twinkling. <sup>2</sup> Atten-
tively, watchfully, without interruption. See also {#animizam#}.
E. {#a#} and {#nimezam#} (from {#miz#} with {#ni,#} kṛt aff. {#Ramul#}).
<LEND>

<L>2714<pc>081-a<k1>aniyata<k2>aniyata
{#aniyata#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not restrained, not
fastened. <sup>2</sup> Not necessarily connected. <sup>3</sup> Not inevitable,
not certain, not always occurring. <sup>4</sup> Not positive, not de-
finite, undefined, undetermined. (The {#aniyatA DarmAH#} or
‘undetermined rules’ of the Buddhists, are the topic of
one of the chapters of their Phātimokkha, and treat on
transgressions that involve exclusion, suspension and pe-
nance, but not permanent exclusion, of a Bauddha priest.)
E. {#a#} neg. and {#niyata#}.
<LEND>

<L>2715<pc>081-a<k1>aniyatapuMskA<k2>aniyatapuMskA
{#aniyatapuMskA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-skA#}) An unsteady or unchaste woman.
E. {#a#} neg. and {#niyata-pum#} (Bahuvr. samāsānta aff. {#kap#}).
<LEND>

no fixed profession or livelihood. E. {#a#} neg. and {#niyata-vftti#}.

<L>2719<pc>081-a<k1>aniyama<k2>aniyama
{#aniyama#}¦ 1. Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) <sup>1</sup> Absence of a restriction or
fixed rule. <sup>2</sup> Absence of moral or religious obligation. <sup>3</sup> In-
decorous or improper conduct. E. {#a#} neg. and {#niyama#}.
<div n="P">2. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) Without restriction,
undertermined, undefined, unprovided for, by any rule or
law. E. {#a#} priv. and {#niyama#}.
<LEND>

<L>2720<pc>081-a<k1>aniyukta<k2>aniyukta
{#aniyukta#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) Not authorised,
not called, not appointed &c. See {#niyukta#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ktaH#}) (In Law.) A Brāhmaṇa who attends a court
without having been appointed a member of it, whose vote
is therefore not binding, and who is at liberty to attend
the court meetings and to debate in them, or not. (See,
on the contrary, {#saBAsad#}.)
<LEND>

<L>2724<pc>081-a<k1>anirukta<k2>anirukta
{#anirukta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not spoken out,
not declared. <sup>2</sup> Not explained, not defined (e. g. the di-
vinity, if spoken of in general terms, or Brahma (n.) that
is without qualities, or an invocation, not containing the
special name of the god addressed, one addressed to the
gods in general &c.). <sup>3</sup> Obscure, incomprehensible, literally
and metaphorically; e. g. Prajāpati, Brahman (n.) or a
hymn uttered inaudibly, so as not being comprehensible to
the by-standers. E. {#a#} neg. and {#nirukta#}.
<LEND>
[Page081-b+ 56]

<L>2725<pc>081-b<k1>aniruktagAna<k2>aniruktagAna
{#aniruktagAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) One of the modes of chanting
the hymns of the Sāmaveda. See {#gAna#}. E. {#anirukta#} and {#gAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>2726<pc>081-b<k1>anirudDa<k2>anirudDa
{#anirudDa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unobstructed,
unrestrained. <sup>2</sup> Self-willed, ungovernable, headstrong. <sup>3</sup> Move-
able, unsteady(?).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-dDaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of the son of Pradyumna or
Kāmadeva by Śubhāṅgī or, according to others, Kaku-
dvatī, the daughter of Rukmin; his wife is Uṣā, the
daughter of Vāna, or, according to others, Subhadrā, the
granddaughter of Rukmin, and his son Vajra.--The
Vaiṣṇava sect, called Pāñcharātra or Bhāgavatas, con-
sider him as an incarnation or part of Viṣṇu and identify
him with Ahaṅkāra, self-consciousness.--<sup>2</sup> A name of
Śiva. <sup>3</sup> The name of a celebrated Bauddha Arhat and con-
temporary of Śākyamuni. <sup>4</sup> The name of a member of the
Vṛṣṇi tribe, the descendants of Vṛṣṇi. See also {#AnirudDa#}
and {#AnirudDAyani#}. <sup>5</sup> A spy(?).
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-dDam#}) A rope for fastening cattle. E. {#a#} neg.
and {#nirudDa#}. (It is doubtful whether the meaning 1. 3. (move-
able) or the meaning 2. 4. (spy) is the correct one, the
translation being founded on the word {#cara,#} given as one
of the meanings of {#anirudDa,#} but without any further in-
dication as to the gender. From the place, however, {#cara#}
occupies in the explanation of some of the native dictio-
naries, the meaning ‘spy’ is likely to be preferable to the
meaning ‘moveable’.)
<LEND>

<L>2727<pc>081-b<k1>anirudDapaTa<k2>anirudDapaTa
{#anirudDapaTa#}¦ Bahuvr. n. ({#-Tam#}) Atmosphere, æther. E. {#anirudDa#}
and {#paTin,#} samāsānta aff. {#a;#} lit. having an unobstructed path.
<LEND>

<L>2738<pc>081-b<k1>anirmAlyA<k2>anirmAlyA
{#anirmAlyA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-lyA#}) A plant (Trigonella corniculata
or Medicago esculenta, Rox.). Also {#nirmAlyA, laNka, pikA,#}
{#pfkkA, piSunA,#} and ranging amongst the {#mahOzaDa#}. E. {#a#}
neg. and {#nirmAlya,#} according to a commentary ‘because no
garland can be made of it’.
<LEND>
[Page082-a+ 56]

<L>2739<pc>082-a<k1>anirlocita<k2>anirlocita
{#anirlocita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Not considered,
not reflected. E. {#a#} neg. and {#nirlocita#}.
<LEND>

<L>2740<pc>082-a<k1>anirvacanIya<k2>anirvacanIya

indescribable. E. {#a#} neg. and {#nirvacanIya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2741<pc>082-a<k1>anirvAcya<k2>anirvAcya
{#anirvAcya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-cyaH-cyA-cyam#}) Not explainable,

<LEND>

<L>2742<pc>082-a<k1>anirvAha<k2>anirvAha
{#anirvAha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) <sup>1</sup> Want of completion. <sup>2</sup> Want of
logical connexion (in a sentence &c.). <sup>3</sup> Want of means of
subsistence. E. {#a#} neg. and {#nirvAha#}.
<LEND>

<L>2743<pc>082-a<k1>anirvfta<k2>anirvfta

and {#nirvfta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2744<pc>082-a<k1>anirvfti<k2>anirvfti
{#anirvfti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Incompleteness, want of com-
pletion. <sup>2</sup> Discontent, unhappiness. <sup>3</sup> Poverty. E. {#a#} neg.
and {#nirvfti#}.
<LEND>

<L>2745<pc>082-a<k1>anirveda<k2>anirveda
{#anirveda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) Undauntedness, hopefulness, self-
confidence. E. {#a#} neg. and {#nirveda#}.
<LEND>

<L>2746<pc>082-a<k1>anila<k2>anila
{#anila#}¦ m. ({#-laH#}) <sup>1</sup> Wind, viz. <sup>a.</sup> (in its usual acceptation) the
motion of air; <sup>b.</sup> the deity of wind; <sup>c.</sup> one of the eight
Maruts, and in this sense distinct from {#mAruta, vAyu#} &c.
(see {#marut#}); <sup>d.</sup> one of the eight Vasus (see {#vasu#}); <sup>e.</sup> (in the
plural {#anilAH#}) a class of the Gaṇadevatās, comprising
forty-nine Anilas; <sup>f.</sup> (in medicine) one of the three Rasas
or temperamental elements of the body (see {#rasa#}), subdi-
vided into {#prARa, udAna, samAna, vyAna#} and {#apAna;#} in this
sense used synonymously with {#mAruta, vAta, vAyu, samIraRa#}
and other words meaning wind; <sup>g.</sup> (in the terminology of
the Upanishads) the exterior wind or the surrounding air,
in distinction from {#vAyu#} or {#prARa,#} the vital air of the body.
<sup>2</sup> A proper name of <sup>a.</sup> a son of Tansu and father of Du-
shwanta; <sup>b.</sup> a Rākṣasa; <sup>c.</sup> a Ṛṣi, author of a vaidik
hymn; <sup>d.</sup> (in the mythology of the Jainas) the seventeenth
Arhat of the past Utsarpiṇī. <sup>3</sup> (In arithmetic, sometimes
used to denote) the numeral 49 (there being forty-nine
Anilas). <sup>4</sup> A mystic denomination of the letter {#ya#}. E. {#an,#}
uṇ. aff. {#ilac#}.
<LEND>

<L>2747<pc>082-a<k1>anilakumAra<k2>anilakumAra
{#anilakumAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. pl. ({#-rAH#}) (In the mythology of the
Jainas.) One of the ten kinds of Bhavanapatis (q. v.) or
Bhavanādhīśas (q. v.), the first of the four classes of Jaina
divinities. E. {#anila#} and {#kumAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2748<pc>082-a<k1>anilaGna<k2>anilaGna
{#anilaGna#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-GnaH-GnI-Gnam#}) Removing disorders
from wind (see {#anila#} 1. f.), as a medicine &c. Also {#vAtaGna,#}
{#vAyuGna#} &c. E. {#anila#} and {#Gna#}.
<LEND>

<L>2749<pc>082-a<k1>anilaGnaka<k2>anilaGnaka
{#anilaGnaka#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) A large tree (Terminalia belerica). See
also {#viBItaka#}. E. {#anilaGna,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>2750<pc>082-a<k1>anilaparyAya<k2>anilaparyAya
{#anilaparyAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) (In Medicine.) An inflammation
affecting the whole eye, described as produced from the
vitiated Rasa wind (see {#anila#} 1. f.) ‘which pervades the eye-
lids, eye and eyebrows and makes them diseased one after the
other’. The less correct reading of this word is {#anilapayaya#}.
See also {#mArutaparyAya#} and {#vAtaparyAya#}. E. {#anila#} and {#paryAya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2751<pc>082-a<k1>anilaprakfti<k2>anilaprakfti
{#anilaprakfti#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-tiH-tiH-ti#}) Of airy or windy
nature; an epithet of the planet Saturn. E. {#anila#} and {#prakfti#}.
<LEND>

<L>2752<pc>082-a<k1>anilamBasamADi<k2>anilamBasamADi
{#anilamBasamADi#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-DiH#}) A fanciful name of a
Buddhistic samādhi or profound meditation. E. {#anilamBa#}
and {#samADi,#} meaning perhaps ‘a meditation that sur-
[Page082-b+ 56]
passes all impediments or limits, one which nothing can
resist’.
<LEND>

<L>2753<pc>082-b<k1>anilayana<k2>anilayana
{#anilayana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) No-resting place, no-support
(an epithet of the neuter Brahman, in an Upanishad, be-
cause it is devoid of qualities, impersonal &c.). E. {#a#} neg.
and {#nilayana#}.
<LEND>

<L>2754<pc>082-b<k1>anilavyADi<k2>anilavyADi
{#anilavyADi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-DiH#}) (In Medicine.) Derangement
of the Rasa wind (see {#anila#} 1. f.), produced, according to
the native theory, by the continued use of dry, cold or light
articles of food, taken in unusually small quantities &c.
and causing, according to some authorities, eighty varieties
of nervous diseases. See also {#anilAmaya#} and {#vAtavyADi#}.
E. {#anila#} and {#vyADi#}.
<LEND>

<L>2755<pc>082-b<k1>anilasaKa<k2>anilasaKa
{#anilasaKa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-KaH#}) A name of Fire. Cf. {#agnisaKa#}.
E. {#anila#} and {#saKi,#} samāsānta aff. {#wac,#} ‘the friend of Wind’.
<LEND>

<L>2773<pc>083-a<k1>aniSita<k2>aniSita
{#aniSita#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) (ved.) Restless, incessant(?).
E. {#aniSi#} (a denom. from {#aniSa#}), kṛt aff. {#kta(?)#}. (Mean-
ing and etymology of this word are doubtful. According
to the native commentaries it would be a Tatpur. compounded
of {#a#} neg. and {#niSita,#} sharpened, sharp, and would mean
either: <sup>1</sup> not sharp, not injurious, or: <sup>2</sup> not difficult, easy,
or <sup>3</sup> not slender, not little; but these explanations, when
applied to the passages to which they refer, seem artificial.
<LEND>

<L>2774<pc>083-a<k1>aniSitasarga<k2>aniSitasarga
{#aniSitasarga#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rgaH-rgA-rgam#}) (ved.) Of con-
tinual effusion, continually flowing (an epithet of the wa-
ters)(?). (This meaning is doubtful; according to the comm.
it would be: of strong or abundant effusion. See the pre-
ceding.) E. {#aniSita#} and {#sarga#}.
<LEND>

artificial.) E. {#a#} priv. and {#nizaNga#}.

<L>2780<pc>083-a<k1>anizwa<k2>anizwa

<L>2782<pc>083-a<k1>anizwaprasaNga<k2>anizwaprasaNga
{#anizwaprasaNga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-NgaH#}) Connexion or association with
what is undesirable, incongruous or wrong connexion, as
that of a Yogin with worldly objects; or (in Nyāya) that
of an inference with wrong premises, the former tending to
prove the absurdity of the argument advanced; or (in gram-
matical literature) connecting one rule with an other rule
which has no relation to it. E. {#anizwa#} and {#prasaNga#}.
<LEND>

<L>2801<pc>083-b<k1>anIka<k2>anIka
