one direction. E. {#anyatas#} and {#GAtin#}.
<LEND>

<L>4217<pc>141-a<k1>anyatomuKa<k2>anyatomuKa
{#anyatomuKa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-KaH#}) (ved.) Having the face only
in one place; opposed to {#sarvatomuKa#} or (the sacrificer) who
by shaving off his hairs, makes his scull, through its bald-
ness, resemble the face and thus becomes as it were ‘face
all over’ (according to the comm. of Sāyaṇa on Śatapa-
thabr. II. 6. 3. 16, which unmutilated runs thus: {#ayaMSabda-#}
{#stvarTe . ayaM tu puruzo yajamAno'nyatomuKaH . anyaSabda ekaSa-#}
{#bdaparyAyaH . anyata ekatra sTitameva muKaM yasya sa taToktaH . tasya#}
{#sarvatomuKatvasaMpattimAha . sa etaditi . yadyasmAtparitaH Siro#}
{#vartayate keSAnvApayati . etat . etena . alomakatvasAmyAcCi-#}
{#rasaH prAntadeSA api muKamiva BavantIti sa yajamAnaH sarvato-#}
{#muKo Bavati ..#}). E. {#anyatas#} and {#muKa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4218<pc>141-a<k1>anyatoraRya<k2>anyato'raRya
{#anyato'raRya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ryam#}) (ved.) A place which is forest
only on one spot; (this is probably the meaning of this
word in the vaidik passage {#vanAya vanapamanyato'raRyAya dA-#}
{#vapam#} where it is opposed to {#vana#}). E. {#anyatas#} and {#araRya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4219<pc>141-a<k1>anyatovAta<k2>anyatovAta
{#anyatovAta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-taH#}) (In Medicine.) A disease of the
whole eye ({#sarvAkziroga#}); symptoms and etymology are con-
veyed by the following verse: {#yasyAvawUkarRaSirohanusTo ma-#}
{#nyAgato vApyanilo'nyato vA . kuryAdrujo'ti Bruvi locane vA#}
{#tamanyatovAtamudAharanti#} ‘when the {%air%} of the back of the
neck, of ears, head, jaw, the tendons which form the nape
of the neck or {%elsewhere%} produces excessive pain in the eye-
brow and eye, they call this (disease of the eye) {#anyato-#}
{#vAta#}’. The word occurs also in its uncompounded state,
e. g. {#hatADimanTo'nilaparyAyaSca SuzkAkzipAko'nyata eva#}
{#vAtaH#}. E. {#anyatas#} and {#vAta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4220<pc>141-a<k1>anyatkAma<k2>anyatkAma
{#anyatkAma#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) Having desire for
something else; comp. {#anyakAma#}. (The correctness of this
word is doubtful, as it is not mentioned by Pāṇini amongst
those compounds in which {#anya#} retains the {#d#} of its neuter;
see s. v. {#anya#}.) E. {#anya,#} āgama {#duk#} and {#kAma#}.
<LEND>

<L>4221<pc>141-a<k1>anyatkAraka<k2>anyatkAraka
{#anyatkAraka#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-rakaH-rikA-rakam#}) I. Karmadh. Another
agent (Kāsikā = {#anyaH kArakaH#}).
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. Agent of another (Patanjali and Kāśikā = {#a-#}
{#nyasya kArakaH#}). (With regard to the first part of the com-
pound see s. v. {#anya#}.) E. {#anya,#} āgama {#duk#} and {#kAraka#}.
<LEND>

<L>4222<pc>141-a<k1>anyatra<k2>anyatra
{#anyatra#}¦ (ved. also {#anyatrA#}) ind. Used in the same sense as the
locat. of {#anya,#} absolutely or with the ellipsis of a word im-
plying ‘place’, ‘manner’ &c.; comp. {#anyatas;#} viz. <sup>1</sup> In
another or others, on another or others, e. g. {#anyatra jAtO#}
(see the instance s. v. {#anyatas#}); {#anyatrArTe; sarvABedAdanyatreme#}
(which Vedānta Sūtra is explained: {#sarvaSAKAsu prARopA-#}
{#sanasyABedAdanyatra SAKAntare ime vasizWatvAdiguRAH samAhA-#}
[Page141-b+ 56]
{#ryAH#}); or {#sAhasasteyapAruzyago'BiSApAtyaye striyAm . vivA-#}
{#dayetsadya eva kAlo'nyatrecCayA smftaH#} (comm. {#anyatra = vi-#}
{#vAdAntarezu#}); also with a noun depending on it in the ablat.
‘in another than’, e. g. in the Sūtra of Pāṇ. {#tAByAmanyatro-#}
{#RAdayaH#} (Kāśikā: {#uRRAdayaH pratyayAstAByAM saMpradAnApAdAnA-#}
{#ByAmanyatra kArake Bavanti#}); or {#DAtvarTAnAM saMbanDe yatra kAle pra-#}
{#tyayA uktAstato'nyatrApi Bavanti#}. <sup>2</sup> Elsewhere; in space or
time, e. g. {#yadA CalaM vinEva kAryAtiSayAdanyatra gataH#} &c.;
or {#etezAM#} (scil. {#rUparasaganDasparSAnAM#}) {#pAkajatvaM tu kzitO nA-#}
{#nyatra kutracit;#} also with a noun in the ablat., e. g. (Kā-
śikā on Pāṇini VIII. 1. 12. v. 10.) {#strInigadaBAvAdanyatrApi#}
{#dfSyate#}. <sup>3</sup> In another manner, differently from; with a noun
in the ablative, e. g. {#apatyADikArAdanyatra lOkikamapatyamAtraM#}
{#gotram,#} i. e. {#gotra#} in Pāṇini's rule IV. 2. 39 is to be taken
in the sense of a son only, differently from the chapter on
{#apatya#} (IV. 1. 162) where it means the descendants beginning
with the grandson ({#apatyamAtraM na tu pOtrapraBftyeva#} Kāś.). <sup>4</sup> In
another or different sense; e. g. {#kAraskaro vfkzaH . anyatra kA-#}
{#rakaraH;#} or {#ekatra rajo DUliranyatra guRaH#}. <sup>5</sup> Except, with a
noun in the ablative, e. g. {#SabdArTayoH punarvacanaM punaruktamanya-#}
{#trAnuvAdAt#} ‘repetition of word or sense is called {#punarukta,#}
unless it be an {#anuvAda#} q. v.’; or {#ta indriyARi tadvyapadeSA-#}
{#danyatra SrezWAt#} ‘these (eleven prāṇas) are the senses except
the principal one, because exception of it is taken (in a
vaidik passage)’; {#anyatra nityadravyeBya ASritatvamihocyate#}
‘dependence is said (to be the attribute of every thing) ex-
cept (of) eternal substances. [More frequently used so in
the Buddhistic than in the Brāhmanic writings, according
to Burnouf, {%Lotus de la bonne loi,%} II. p. 653.] <sup>6</sup> Without;
with a noun in the ablative; e. g. {#DenvEva hyupayuktaM tfRAdi#}
{#kzIrIBavati na prahInamanaquhAdyupayuktaM vA . yadi hi nirnimi-#}
{#ttametatsyAt . DenuSarIrasaMbanDAdanyatrApi tfRAdi kzIrIBavet#}.
<sup>7</sup> In the contrary case, otherwise; comp. {#anyaTA#} and {#itaratra;#}
e. g. {#devikAdizu tadAdigrahaRam . anyatra hi tadgrahaRAttadanta-#}
{#grahaRAdvA#}. E. {#anya,#} vibhakti-taddh. aff. {#tral#}.
<LEND>

<L>4223<pc>141-b<k1>anyatradattAkza<k2>anyatradattAkza
{#anyatradattAkza#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-kzaH-kzI-kzam#}) Turning the
eyes elsewhere, e. g. {#anyEH pravartitAM SaSvatsAvaDAnA ca tatka-#}
{#TAm . SfRotyanyatradattAkzI priye bAlAnurAgiRI#}. E. {#anyatra-#}
{#datta#} and {#akzi,#} samās. aff. {#zac#}.
<LEND>

<L>4224<pc>141-b<k1>anyatramanas<k2>anyatramanas
{#anyatramanas#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-nAH-nAH-naH#}) Having the mind
directed on another object, absent (mentally). [The passage
of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upan. {#anyatramanA aBUvaM nASrOzam#}
&c. is given as a proof by the Sāṅkhya Pravachana Bh. for
the orthodoxy of the Sāṅkhya tenet that {#manas#} is capable
of becoming multifarious.] E. {#anyatra#} and {#manas#}.
<LEND>

<L>4225<pc>141-b<k1>anyatva<k2>anyatva
{#anyatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The being other, otherness, difference
(the same as {#anyatA,#} but more frequently used as this
word); e. g. {#anyatve'pyaByAsasyopacArAt#} ‘even if there
were different (sounds, sound must be permanent) because
it is possible to repeat it (in teaching)’; also with a noun
in the ablative, e. g. {#vacanAttu tato'nyatvam#} ‘(if it is main-
tained that {#itikartavyatA#} refers to profane things, the answer
is:) but on account of a (distinct vaidik) passage its dif-
ference from that (is established), i. e. it refers only to sacred
or vaidik objects’; or {#tayoranyatve tucCatvam#} (comm. {#akA-#}
{#ryasya prakftipuruzaBinnatve tucCatvam#} &c.).--The word occurs
[Page142-a+ 56]
for the most part, however, as the latter part of a com-
pound--e. g. {#sPawikAnyatvABimAnavattadanyatvABimAnaH#}--
and especially in scientific writings, e. g. in the Vārttikas
of Pāṇini in compounds as {#aNgAnyatva, kartranyatva, kArakAnyatva,#}
{#kAlAnyatva,#} in the Vedānta Sūtras as in {#tadananyatva,#} in the
Mīmānsā S. as in {#prayojanAnyatva, vedAnyatva, rUpAnyatva#} &c.,
in the Nyāya S. as in {#sTAnAnyatva, karmAnyatva,#} in the Sāṅkhya
S. {#uBayAnyatva,#} in the Yoga S. as in {#kramAnyatva#} &c. &c. E.
{#anya,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4226<pc>142-a<k1>anyatvakara<k2>anyatvakara
{#anyatvakara#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rI-ram#}) Producing other-
ness or difference; as species, characteristic properties,
space. E. {#anyatva#} and {#kara#} ({#kf,#} kṛt aff. {#wa#}).
<LEND>

<L>4227<pc>142-a<k1>anyaTA<k2>anyaTA
{#anyaTA#}¦ ind. <sup>1</sup> In another manner, differently; e. g. {#kurvanneveha#}
{#karmARi jijIvizecCataM samAH . evaM tvayi nAnyaTeto'sti na#}
{#karma lipyate nare;#} or {#vipakzacittonmaTanA naKavraRAstirohitA#}
{#viBramamaRqanena ye . hftasya SezAniva kuNkumasya tAnvikatTanIyA-#}
{#ndaDuranyaTA striyaH#} ‘…the women made these wounds
different, i. e. not concealed; they laid them open (comm.:
{#prakASaM daDurityarTaH#}); or {#tarkApratizWAnAdapyanyaTAnumeyamiti cet#}
&c.; comp. {#anyaTAnumiti; anyaTA--anyaTA#} ‘in one way
--in another way’, e. g. {#anyaTA hi prakramante vAjasaneyinaH .#}
{#anyaTA CandogAH;#} also with a noun depending in the abl.,
for the most part with {#atas (= asmAt),#} e. g. {#apfzwo'pi#}
{#hitaM brUyAdyasya necCetparABavam . eza eva satAM Darmo viparI-#}
{#tamato'nyaTA#}. <sup>2</sup> Otherwise, or else; e. g. {#gaterarTavattvamuBa-#}
{#yaTAnyaTA hi viroDaH#} ‘the result of the (divine) way is
doubtful, otherwise there would be contradiction (with a
vaidik passage)’; or…{#drazwumaByAgato hyeza Barato nAnya-#}
{#TAgataH#} ‘…or else he would not have come’; {#gurvagniho-#}
{#trArTakfte prasTitaSca sutastava . na nivAryo nivAryaH syAdanyaTA#}
{#prasTito vanam#} ‘…he was not to be prevented or else he
ought to have been prevented: (but now) he is gone to the
forest’. Comp. {#anyatra#}. <sup>3</sup> On the other hand, on the contrary;
e. g. {#asati#} (scil. {#hetO#}) {#pratijYoparoDo yOgapadyamanyaTA#} (comm.:
{#anyaTA = hetO sati#}). <sup>4</sup> Untruly; e. g. {#yasyocuH sAkziRaH satyAM#}
{#pratijYAM sa jayI Bavet . anyaTA vAdino yasya Druvastasya parA-#}
{#jayaH . ukte'pi sAkziBiH sAkzye yadyanye guRavattamAH . dviguRA#}
{#vAnyaTA brUyuH kUwAH syuH pUrvasAkziRaH#} (comm.: {#anyaTA = vE-#}
{#parItyena miTyA#}). Comp. also {#anyaTAstotra#}. <sup>5</sup> Badly, wrongly,
erroneously; comp. {#anyaTAsidDa#} and {#anyaTAsidDi#}. E. {#anya,#}
vibhakti-taddh. aff. {#TAl#}. Comp. {#itaraTA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4228<pc>142-a<k1>anyaTAkaraRa<k2>anyaTAkaraRa
{#anyaTAkaraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Acting to the contrary, doing
otherwise. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#karaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4229<pc>142-a<k1>anyaTAkAra<k2>anyaTAkAra
{#anyaTAkAra#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. ({#-raH#}) Altering, changing, e. g. the
sense of an expression, by punning on it; {#vakroktO parokte-#}
{#ranyaTAkAraH#}. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#kAra#}.
<div n="P">II. ind. ({#-ram#}) In another manner, differently; e. g.
{#anyaTAkAraM BuNkte#} he eats in another manner. [According
to the Kāśikā on Pāṇini III. 4. 27. {#kAram#} would in this
case be a kind of expletive or superfluous, the word of the
Sūtra {#sidDAprayogaH#} being thus commented by it: {#kaTaM puna-#}
{#rasO sidDAprayogaH . nirarTakatvAnna prayogamarhati . evameva prayu-#}
{#jyate;#} and similarly the Siddh. K.: {#kfYvyarTatvAtprayogAnarha#}
{#ityarTaH;#} but Bhaṭṭoji in the Prauḍhaman. is probably more
correct when he refers to the bearing of the word ({#SAbda-#}
{#boDa#}) and says, that {#kAram#} effectuates a stronger connexion
[Page142-b+ 56]
between the verb and the adverb than would be expressed
without it, when {#sidDAprayoga#} in the Sūtra of Pāṇini would not
convey the notion of ‘absolute superfluity’ but rather that
of ‘not excessive necessity’: {#SAbdaboDe tu vElakzaRyamastyeva .#}
{#taTA hi . kriyAsAmAnyavacanaH karotiH . tadIyaSca prakAro#}
{#'nyaTAdiSabdacatuzwvenocyate . evaM ca . anyaTAkAramityAdiBi-#}
{#ScaturBiH prakAraviSezaviSizwakriyA boDyate . sA ca BuNktePala-#}
{#viSizwakriyAM prati viSezaRatayA saMbaDyate . ekasyA api kri-#}
{#yAyA viSezaRoparAgeRa BinnAyA viSezaRaviSezyaBAvasaMBavAt .#}
{#kaTaM tarhi sidDAprayogaScedityuktamiti cet . anatiprayojanatvA-#}
{#diti gfhARa ..#} &c. Patanjali and his comm. give no gloss
on this Sūtra.] E. {#anyaTA#} and {#kAram#} ({#kf,#} kṛt aff. {#Ramul#}).
<LEND>

<L>4231<pc>142-b<k1>anyaTAKyAti<k2>anyaTAKyAti

{#svavacovyAGAtAt’,#} comm.: {#anyadvastvanyarUpeRa BAsata ityapi#}
{#na yuktaM svavacovyAGAtAt ..#}. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#KyAti#}.
<LEND>

<L>4233<pc>142-b<k1>anyaTAtva<k2>anyaTAtva

teration; e. g. {#budDeranyaTAtvam (= budDiviplavaH);#} or in a Mīm.

{#Bavet#}. Comp. {#anyaTABAva#}. E. {#anyaTA,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4241<pc>142-b<k1>anyaTAsidDa<k2>anyaTAsidDa
{#anyaTAsidDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) I. (In the Vaiśeṣika
philosophy.) Wrongly established, referred to a cause which
is not the true cause (as an effect). See {#anyaTAsidDi#} I. E.
{#anyaTA#} and {#sidDa#}.
<div n="P">II. Not established otherwise, not proved otherwise. See
{#anyaTAsidDi#} II. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#asidDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4242<pc>142-b<k1>anyaTAsidDatva<k2>anyaTAsidDatva
{#anyaTAsidDatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The same as the following. E. {#anya-#}
{#TAsidDa,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>
[Page143-a+ 56]

<L>4243<pc>143-a<k1>anyaTAsidDi<k2>anyaTAsidDi
{#anyaTAsidDi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-dDiH#}) I. (In the Vaiśeṣika philosophy.)
The being wrongly established or the establishing wrongly,
i. e. the being referred of an effect, or the referring an effect,
to a cause which is not the true cause. This may happen
in five ways, viz. <sup>a.</sup> by taking for cause what is prior to
the effect but only accidental to the real cause ({#‘saha tena’#}),
as by taking a potter's stick for the cause of a jar; or
<sup>b.</sup> by taking for cause something inherent to what is ac-
cidental to the real cause ({#‘yasya’#}), as by taking the shape
of a potter's stick for the cause of a jar; or <sup>c.</sup> by taking
for cause what is prior but is known to be the cause of
another effect ({#‘anyaM prati’#}), as by taking æther for the cause
of a jar, æther being the known cause of sound; or <sup>d.</sup> by
taking for cause what is prior but prior in so far only as
the real cause is produced by it ({#‘janakaM prati’#}), as by tak-
ing the potter's father for the cause of a jar; or <sup>e.</sup> by taking
for cause any thing foreign to the effect ({#‘atiriktam’#}), as
by taking the donkey carrying the earth of which the jar is
made, for the cause of the jar. The last error comprises,
indeed, in its generality all the preceding and is therefore
called {#‘AvaSyaka’,#} the absolute error. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#sidDi#}.
<div n="P">II. Not being established or proved otherwise; in the Sān-
khya Sūtra: {#uBayatrApyanyaTAsidDerna pratyakzamanumAnaM vA#} (comm.
{#uBayatrApi vESizwyapratyakze tadanumAne ca svarUpeREvAnyaTAsidDerna#}
{#taduBayaM samavAye pramARamityarTaH . ayaM BAvaH . yaTA samavAyavE-#}
{#SizwyabudDirapi guRAdisvarUpeREvezyatAm . atastatrApi pratyakzA-#}
{#numAne'nyaTAsidDe#} &c.). E. {#anyaTA#} and {#asidDi#}.
<LEND>

<L>4244<pc>143-a<k1>anyaTAstotra<k2>anyaTAstotra
{#anyaTAstotra#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tram#}) Untrue or ironical praise, a
sneer; as saying to a deformed man ‘thou art a handsome
one’ (comm.: {#yatra vikftAkftireva darSanIyastvamasItyucyate .#}
{#tadanyaTAstotram#}). E. {#anyaTA#} and {#stotra#}.
<LEND>

{#yitvA kaTaMcana . yadi SlezeRAnyaTA vA'nyaTayetsApyapahnutiH#}. E.
{#anyaTA,#} denom. aff. {#Ric#}.

<L>4248<pc>143-a<k1>anyadarTa<k2>anyadarTa

<L>4249<pc>143-a<k1>anyadA<k2>anyadA
{#anyadA#}¦ I. ind. At another time; e. g. {#anyadA BUzaRaM puMsaH kzamA#}
{#lajjeva yozitaH . parAkramaH pariBave vEyAtyaM suratezviva#} (where
{#anyadA#} is opposed first to {#pariBave#} and then to {#suratezu#} and
therefore must not be taken in a general sense ‘sometimes’
--which it has not--but in the sense ‘at another time
than that of defeat’, ‘at another time than that of amorous
sport’; comm.: {#anyadA suratavyatirikte kAle yozito lajjeva#}
{#puMso'nyadA apariBave Samo BUzaRaM pariBave tu yozitaH suratezu#}
{#vEyAtyaM DArzwyamiva#}); or {#BartA tu yadA durBikze strIDanaM vinA#}
{#vartanAkzamastadApi grahItumarhati nAnyadA#} ‘when the husband at
a time of dearth cannot support himself without the property
[Page143-b+ 56]
of his wife, he may take it, not {%at another time%}’. <sup>2</sup> At one
time, once. Compare {#anyadina#}. E. {#anya,#} vibhakti-taddh.
aff. {#dA#}. See the Preface.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. f. ({#-dA#}) A virtuous wife. [According to a
comm. of the Bhaṭṭikāvya: {#anyezAM patiSvaSurAdInAM dA Su-#}
{#dDiryAByastAH#} (acc. plur. in the passage referred to) {#anyadAH#}
{#sADvIrityarTaH#}.] Comp. {#anyadIya#}. E. {#anya#} and {#dA#} (from {#dE,#}
kṛt aff. {#kvip#}).
<LEND>

<L>4255<pc>143-b<k1>anyadIya<k2>anyadIya
{#anyadIya#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Being in another (Kāśikā
= {#anyasminBava#}). <sup>2</sup> Belonging to another (Kāśikā = {#anyasye-#}
{#dam#}); e. g. {#anyadIyasyAdattasya grahItA na syAt#} (scil. {#dvijaH#});
also used in the same sense as the genitive of {#anya#} ‘of an-
other’; e. g. {#anyadIyapAWamAkarRya svayaM vA SAstramAkalpya ya-#}
{#jjYAnaM jAyate taditi;#} or {#parasvAnyArjayannArIranyadIyAH parA-#}
{#mfSan#}. E. {#anya,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#} and āgama {#duk;#} see s. v. {#anya#}.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-yA#}) A virtuous wife. [This interpretation of the
word is given, besides the usual one ‘wife of another’ (see
meaning I.), by a comm. of the Bhaṭṭikāvya who after
having explained the meaning and etym. of {#anyadA#} II. q. v.
adds: {#tataH#} (i. e. from {#anyadA,#} a virtuous wife) {#svArTe IyaH#}.]
E. {#anyadA#} II., taddh. aff. {#Ca#}.
<LEND>

<L>4265<pc>144-a<k1>anyaDarma<k2>anyaDarma

ferent qualities or characteristics. See the following. E.

<L>4266<pc>144-a<k1>anyaDarmatva<k2>anyaDarmatva
{#anyaDarmatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> The being the quality or characteristic
of another or something else; e. g. {#vicitraBogAnupapattira-#}
{#nyaDarmatve;#} comm.: {#duHKayogarUpabanDasya cittamAtraDarmatve vici-#}
{#traBogAnupapattiH#}. <sup>2</sup> The having different qualities or charac-
teristics; e. g. {#atiprasaktiranyaDarmatve;#} comm.: {#banDatatkAraRa-#}
{#yorBinnaDarmatve'tiprasaktimuktasyApi banDApattirityarTaH#}. <sup>3</sup> The
being another quality or characteristic. E. {#anyaDarma,#} taddh.
aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4267<pc>144-a<k1>anyanABi<k2>anyanABi
{#anyanABi#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-BiH-BiH-Bi#}) One who is not of
the same family; the reverse of {#sanABi;#} comp. also {#nABi-#}
{#sambanDa#} and {#sodara#}. E. {#anya#} and {#nABi#}.
<LEND>

<L>4270<pc>144-a<k1>anyanindaka<k2>anyanindaka

<L>4271<pc>144-a<k1>anyapadArTa<k2>anyapadArTa
{#anyapadArTa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rTaH#}) (In Grammar.) The sense of
another word; this term is used by Pāṇini and his com-
mentators to qualify the nature of a {%Bahuvrihi%} compound
which always depends on, or refers to, the meaning of an-
other word, the word {#anyapadArTa#} being thus used in contra-
distinction of {#svapadArTa;#} e. g. Patanjali: {#aTAnyagrahaRaM kima-#}
{#rTam . anekaM padArTe . itIyatyucyamAne svapadArTe'pi bahuvrIhiH#}
{#syAt . rAjapuruzaH . takzapuruza iti nEtadasti prayojanam . tatpu-#}
{#ruzaH svapadArTe bADako Bavizyati . ;#} Kaiyyaṭa: {#aTAnyagrahaRa-#}
{#miti . antaraNgatvAtsvapadArTe samAse sidDe padArTagrahaRasAmarTyA-#}
{#danyapadArTo lapsyata iti praSnaH . svapadArTe'pIti . apiSabdA-#}
{#danyapadArTe'pItyarTaH . padArTagrahaRaM vyAptisamASrayaRArTaM syA-#}
{#diti svapadArTAnyapadArTayoH samAsaH syAt . tatpuruza iti .#}
{#bahuvrIhestvanyapadArTo'vakASaH#}. [This word occurs only as
a Tatpurusha. The quotation {#anyapadArTo bahuvrIhiH#} which
is printed somewhere, is a misreading for {#anyapadArTapraDA-#}
{#no#} &c. See the following.] E. {#anya-pada#} and {#arTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4272<pc>144-a<k1>anyapadArTapraDAna<k2>anyapadArTapraDAna
{#anyapadArTapraDAna#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-naH#}) (In Grammar.) Essentially
qualified by, or essentially resting on the sense of another
word, viz. a {%Bahuvrīhi%} (see the preceding); in contradis-
tinction from {#pUrvapadArTapraDAna,#} the quality of an {%Avyayībhāva,%}
{#uttarapadArTapraDAna,#} the quality of a {%Tatpurusha,%} and {#uBaya-#}
{#padArTapraDAna,#} the quality of a {%Dwandwa%} (Patanjali: {#iha ka-#}
{#ScitsamAsaH pUrvapadArTapraDAnaH . kaSciduttarapadArTapraDAnaH . ka-#}
[Page144-b+ 56]
{#ScidanyapadArTapraDAnaH . kaSciduBayapadArTapraDAnaH . pUrvapadArTapra-#}
{#DAno'vyayIBAvaH . uttarapadArTapraDAnastatpuruzaH . anyapadArTa-#}
{#praDAno bahuvrIhiH . uBayapadArTapraDAno dvandvaH ..#}). E. {#anya-#}
{#padArTa#} and {#praDAna;#} scil. {#samAsa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4273<pc>144-b<k1>anyapadArTapraDAnatA<k2>anyapadArTapraDAnatA
{#anyapadArTapraDAnatA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tA#}) (In Grammar.) The pre-
ponderance of the sense of another word, viz. in a Bahuvr.;
see the preceding; e. g. {#unmattagaNgamityAdAvanyapadArTapraDAnatA#}
(Kaiyyaṭa). Comp. the following. E. {#anyapadArTa#} and {#praDAnatA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4274<pc>144-b<k1>anyapadArTaprADAnya<k2>anyapadArTaprADAnya
{#anyapadArTaprADAnya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nyam#}) (In Grammar.) The same
as {#anyapadArTapraDAnatA;#} e. g. {#sa ca yadi samAharaRaM samAhAra#}
{#iti BAvarUpastadAnyapadArTaprADAnyam#} (Kaiyyaṭa). E. {#anyapa-#}

<LEND>

<L>4275<pc>144-b<k1>anyapara<k2>anyapara
{#anyapara#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Having some one or
something else for one's object (e. g. of worship). (Comp. the
following.) <sup>2</sup> Expressing something else, having another
sense, e. g. figurative speech; e. g. {#BedO Dvanerapi dvAvudIritO#}
{#lakzaRABiDAmUlA . avivakzitavAcyo'nyo vivakzitAnyaparavA-#}
{#cyaSca .#} (comm. on the latter word: {#vAcyaM vivakzitam . anya-#}
{#paraM vyaNgyanizWam . atra hi vAcyo'rTaH svarUpaM prakASayanneva vya-#}
{#NgyArTasya prakASakaH#}). E. {#anya#} and {#para#}.
<LEND>

<L>4276<pc>144-b<k1>anyaparatva<k2>anyaparatva
{#anyaparatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> The having some one or something else
for one's object; e. g. {#anyaparatvamavivekAnAM tatra#}. <sup>2</sup> The ex-
pressing something else; e. g. in a Mīm. Vārtt. of Kumārila:
{#adarSanAdviroDasyArTavAdAnAM cAnyaparatvena guRavAdaprAyatvAt#}.
E. {#anyapara,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4277<pc>144-b<k1>anyapuzwa<k2>anyapuzwa
{#anyapuzwa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-zwaH-zwA#}) The Kokila or Indian cuckoo
(supposed to be reared by a crow). Comp. {#kAkapuzwa, anya-#}
{#Bfta, anyavApa;#} e. g. {#uditEranyapuzwAnAmArutErme hftaM manaH . u-#}
{#ditErapi te dUti mArutErapi dakziREH ..#}. E. {#anya#} and {#puzwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4278<pc>144-b<k1>anyapUrvA<k2>anyapUrvA
{#anyapUrvA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-vA#}) A woman who has been given to,
or has had intercourse with, another man than the one to
whom she is married; this may be the case if she is either
a {#punarBU#} or a {#svEriRI;#} as a {#punarBU#} (q. v.) again, she had either
ceased to be a virgin before the nuptial ceremonies, or she
had remained a virgin and become blemished through the
repeated celebration of the marriage ceremonies; she is
{#svEriRI#} or licentious, if she leaves her husband and goes,
out of lust, to a man of the same caste. A woman, how-
ever, is not considered to be a {#punarBU,#} if she is left without
a son and, by order of her Guru, is approached, for the
sake of getting a son, by her brother-in-law, or a relative
of the class of the Sapiṇḍas or a man of the same Gotra,
either of them having been previously anointed with clari-
fied butter. (According to the Mitākṣara as founded on
Yājnavalkya; Manu applies the term {#parapUrvA,#} the same as
{#anyapUrvA,#} only to the licentious woman who leaves her hus-
band for another man; Nārada uses the synonymous term
{#parapUrvA#} in a similar manner as the Mitākṣara {#anyapUrvA,#} but
divides the {#punarBU#} into three and the {#svEriRI#} into four cate-
gories; for according to him a {#punarBU#} may be either a virgin-
woman who is blemished by having gone through the mar-
riage ceremonies for a second time, or a woman who first
has been given to one and then on account of her love, to
another, or a woman who, in want of a brother-in-law,
is given by her relations to a Sapiṇḍa-relative of the same
caste; a {#svEriRI#} a woman, whether having had children or
[Page145-a+ 56]
not, who, while her husband is alive, goes to another from
lust, or a woman who leaves her infant husband for another
man and later returns to the house of her husband; or a
woman who after the death of her husband slights her brother-
in-law and the other relations (she may approach) and goes
from lust to another man, or lastly, a woman who has come
from the country and, purchased with money, under the
pressure of hunger and thirst gives herself up to another
man. E. {#anya#} and {#pUrva;#} scil. {#strI#}.
<LEND>

<L>4279<pc>145-a<k1>anyaBAva<k2>anyaBAva
{#anyaBAva#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) The condition &c. of another; e. g.
{#anyaBAvavyAvftteSca#} (comm.: {#anyasya BAvo'nyaBAvaH . anyaBA-#}
{#vAdvyAvfttiH#} &c.).
<div n="P">II. Karmadh. m. ({#-vaH#}) Another condition &c. (see the
meanings of {#BAva#}).
<div n="P">III. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-vaH-vA-vam#}) <sup>1</sup> Having another con-
dition. See {#AnyaBAvya#}. <sup>2</sup> Having affection or love for another;
e. g. {#ananyaBAve nijaDarmaBAvite manasyavasTApya Bajasva pUruzam#}
(comm. {#nAnyasminBAvo yasya tasmin#}). E. {#anya#} and {#BAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4280<pc>145-a<k1>anyaBft<k2>anyaBft

the cuckoo. Comp. {#anyapuzwa, anyaBfta, anyavApa#}. The gender
of this word is not defined in Hemachandra where it occurs;
but it can scarcely be the masc.). E. {#anya#} and {#Bft#}.
<LEND>

<L>4293<pc>145-a<k1>anyalakzaRopapatti<k2>anyalakzaRopapatti
{#anyalakzaRopapatti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ttiH#}) The taking place (of some-
[Page145-b+ 56]
thing) in consequence of the symptom i. e. the existence (of
something else) being found somewhere else; in a Nyāya
Sūtra, where the possibility of non-existence is argued from
the circumstance that the existence of the counter-entity
might be elsewhere: {#asatyarTe nABAva iti cennAnyalakzaRopapatteH#}
‘if (you say that there is) no non-existence since the thing
is not, it is not so, for (non-existence) might be, since (the
counter-entity) might exist elsewhere’. E. {#anya#} (in the sense
of a locative) {#-lakzaRa#} (of an instrum.) and {#upapatti#}.
<LEND>

<L>4302<pc>145-b<k1>anyavikrIta<k2>anyavikrIta

<L>4303<pc>145-b<k1>anyavIjaja<k2>anyavIjaja
{#anyavIjaja#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) Liter. born from another's seed, i. e.
a boy who may be adopted as a son in want of a legitimate
son (see {#Orasa#}) and become heir to the property, but who
remains nevertheless the son of his real father; such sub-
stituted sons are the following eleven, each succeeding being
inferior in degree to each preceding (according to the order
assigned to them by Manu): the {#kzetraja, datrima#} (or {#dattaka#}), {#kf-#}
{#trima, gUQotpanna#} (or {#gUQaja#}), {#apavidDa, kAnIna, sahoQa#} (or {#sahoQaja#}),
{#krItaka#} (or {#krIta#}), {#pOnarBava, svayaMdatta#} and {#pAraSava#} qq. vv. See
also {#anyavIjotpanna, anyavIjasamudBava, anyaSAKodBava, dvyAmu-#}
{#zyAyaRa#} and {#putrapraticCandaka, putrapratiniDi#}. E. {#anya-vIja#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>
[Page146-a+ 56]

<L>4304<pc>146-a<k1>anyavIjasamudBava<k2>anyavIjasamudBava

<L>4305<pc>146-a<k1>anyavIjotpanna<k2>anyavIjotpanna

<LEND>

<L>4306<pc>146-a<k1>anyavrata<k2>anyavrata
{#anyavrata#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-taH#}) One who has other vows or fol-
lows other practices. The vaidik commentators explain
the word according to where it occurs either ‘one whose
practices are different from those enjoined by the sacred
books i. e. impious, a demon’ or ‘one whose practices are
different from human practices i. e. the Supreme Spirit’.
E. {#anya#} and {#vrata#}.
<LEND>

<L>4307<pc>146-a<k1>anyaSAKaka<k2>anyaSAKaka
{#anyaSAKaka#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-kaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A Brāhmaṇa who has been
abandoned by his school (comm. = {#svakIyaSAKArahitaH#}).
<sup>2</sup> One who has been given up by his own family (comm.
{#atra SAKASabdaH pakzAntare saMtativiSezArTaH#}); comp. the follow-
ing. E. {#anya#} and {#SAKA,#} samās. aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>4308<pc>146-a<k1>anyaSAKodBava<k2>anyaSAKodBava

family, the same as {#anyavIjaja;#} e. g. {#anyaSAKodBavo dattaH#}
{#putraScEvopanAyitaH . svagotreRa svaSAKoktaviDinA svasvaSAKa-#}
{#BAk .#} (where in the two latter words {#SAKA#} means the
vaidik school). E. {#anya-SAKA#} and {#udBava#}.
<LEND>

<L>4309<pc>146-a<k1>anyasaNgama<k2>anyasaNgama
{#anyasaNgama#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) <sup>1</sup> Meeting another man. <sup>2</sup> Inter-
course with another wife than one's own (in the latter
meaning the word deserves notice for the shortening of
{#anyA#} to {#anya#}); e. g. {#nirAsa BfNgaM kupiteva pahminI na mAni-#}

Vopad. 6. 4.--{#puMvat#}). E. {#anya#} and {#saNgama#}.

<L>4310<pc>146-a<k1>anyasADAraRa<k2>anyasADAraRa

others, common. E. {#anya#} and {#sADAraRa#}.

<L>4311<pc>146-a<k1>anyasAmAnya<k2>anyasAmAnya
{#anyasAmAnya#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-nyaH-nyA-nyam#}) Having the
same qualities as others, common; e. g. {#sA kftasAmAnyena#}
{#SrAvitAvatatyamumananyasAmAnyena . svaM rahasA mAnyena svayaMvaraM#}
{#smarati nAYjasA mAnyenaH ..#}. E. {#anya#} and {#sAmAnya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4312<pc>146-a<k1>anyasfzwi<k2>anyasfzwi
{#anyasfzwi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-zwiH#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) The
evolution (of Pradhāna or Matter) for the sake of another
(i. e. Purusha or Soul) viz., after one Purusha has been liber-
ated: {#anyasfzwyuparAge'pi na virajyate prabudDarajjutattvasyevoragaH#}.
E. {#anya#} and {#sfzwi#}.
<LEND>

<L>4313<pc>146-a<k1>anyastrI<k2>anyastrI
{#anyastrI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-strI#}) A woman not one's own. [In
Rhetoric she is one of the three categories of the principal
female character in a poetical composition (the two other
being {#svastrI#} or {#svIyA#} and {#sADAraRastrI#} or {#sAmAnyanAyikA#}
qq. vv.; the {#anyastrI#} or {#parakIyA#} is either ‘another's wife’
or a ‘damsel’; as ‘another's wife’ ‘she is fond of festivals
and the like opportunities, is a disgrace to her family, bare
of modesty’; the ‘damsel’ is ‘one not yet married, bashful
and arrived at the period of youth’. Each of these two
has again eight subdivisions; ‘she may be one who has an
obsequious lover, or one who is ill-treated, or one who
goes after her lover, or one who is separated from him by a
quarrel, or one who is neglected, or one whose lover is abroad,
or one who is prepared in her house to receive him, or one
who is longing in absence of her lover’). E. {#anya#} and {#strI#}.
<LEND>

<L>4314<pc>146-a<k1>anyastrIga<k2>anyastrIga
{#anyastrIga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) An adulterer. E. {#anyastrI#} and {#ga#}.
<LEND>

<L>4315<pc>146-a<k1>anyastrIputrotpAdaka<k2>anyastrIputrotpAdaka
{#anyastrIputrotpAdaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) The father of a child
by another man's wife. E. {#anyastrI#} and {#putra-utpAdaka#}.
<LEND>
[Page146-b+ 56]

<L>4316<pc>146-b<k1>anyA<k2>anyA
{#anyA#}.¦ The feminine of {#anya#} ‘other, different’ &c. q. v. This
word deserves notice only from the circumstance that it oc-
curs in some vaidik passages with the udātta accent on the
first syllable, instead of having this accent on the last syllable.
[Sāyaṇa is not the author of the meaning ‘never drying-up’
and of an etym. ‘{#a#} and {#nyA,#} contracted of {#ni-yA#}’ which have
been lent to this word by a new kind of vaidik exegesis.]
<LEND>

<L>4317<pc>146-b<k1>anyAda<k2>anyAda
{#anyAda#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dA-dam#}) Without food, food-
less; e. g. {#AdareRa gamaM cakrurvizamezvapyasaMGasAH . vyApnuvanto#}
{#diSo'nyAdAnkurvantaH savyaDAnharIn#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#nyAda#}.
<LEND>

<L>4318<pc>146-b<k1>anyAdfkza<k2>anyAdfkza
{#anyAdfkza#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kzaH-kzA-kzam#}) The same as {#anyA-#}
{#dfS#}. [This word is given on the authority of the Siddhānta
Kaum. fol. 181 a. 1. 14. ed. Calc. and on that of Durgādāsa's
comm. on Vopadeva 26. 83. 85; it is not mentioned, however,
in the commentaries of the Dhātupāṭhas, nor by the author
of the Kāśikā who in his gloss on a Vārttika to Pāṇ. III.
2. 60. gives only the words: {#tAdfkza, yAdfkza, Idfkza#} and {#kIdfkza;#}
Patanjali and his commentators do not even speak of the
Vārttika on which the Kāś. has founded {#tAdfkza#} &c., the
only word of a similar formation, viz. {#sadfkza,#} being men-
tioned by Patanjali in his gloss on a Vārtt. to Pāṇ. VI.
3. 89. It will appear therefore, that {#anyAdfkza#} does not belong
to the older period of the classical Sanskṛt.] E. {#anya#} and {#dfkza#}
({#dfS,#} kṛt aff. {#ksa#}) with the prolongation of the middle vowel.
<LEND>

<L>4324<pc>146-b<k1>anyAya<k2>anyAya
{#anyAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> No-rule, no authority, a word,
a sentence &c. which is not binding; used in this sense
especially in philosophical Sūtras; e. g. in the Mīmānsā Sū-
tras, {#anyAyaScAnekaSabdatvam;#} or {#anyAyaSca kfte'ByAsaH;#} or
{#anyAyo vAnAraByaviDAnAt#} &c. &c. <sup>2</sup> Unlawfulness, in-
justice, an unlawful act; e. g. {#nyAyApetaM yadanyena rAjYA jYAna-#}
{#kftaM Bavet . tadapyanyAyavihitaM punarnyAye niveSayet;#} or {#anyA-#}
{#yena hftA BUmiranyAyena tu hAritA . harato hArakasyApi daha-#}
{#tyAsaptamaM kulam#}. <sup>3</sup> Impropriety, improper conduct; e. g. {#iti#}
{#matimAnASvasyAnyAyamanASaNkya vikftimAnASvasyAm#} (comm.
{#asyAM damayantyAmanyAyaM parastryaBilAzalakzaRamanASaNkya#} &c.); or
[Page147-a+ 56]
{#narakasyAvatAro'yaM pratyakzo'smAkamAgataH . acezwA yadi hA-#}
{#nyAyAdanenAtsyAmahe vayam#} (comm. {#anyAyAdanOcityAt#}). E.
{#a#} neg. or deter. and {#nyAya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4357<pc>148-a<k1>anyonya<k2>anyo'nya
{#anyo'nya#}¦ (usually written {#anyonya#}) Tatpur. (see {#sarvanAman#})
1. m. f. n. ({#-nyaH-nyA-nyam,#} not. {#anyonyad;#} in the other cases
it follows the declension of {#anya#} q. v.) One-another, mutual.--
<sup>a.</sup> The verb in connexion with {#anyonya#} stands (acc. to Pāṇ.) in
the Parasmaipada, not in the Ātmanepada; e. g. {#anyonyasya#}
{#vyatipunanti, anyonyasya vyatilunanti#}.--<sup>b.</sup> If {#anyonya#} refers
to the subject of the sentence and the subject is a mascu-
line, it is possible to consider it as consisting of two dis-
tinct not compound words {#anya,#} the former being a nomi-
native as attribute to the subject, while the latter assumes
the case required by the sentence (see the Etym.); e. g.
{#anyo'nyamAhvayantO tu mattAviva mahAgajO;#} or {#te'nyonyamaBi-#}
{#saMsftya kzipanto nAmaBirmiTaH;#} or {#…kapirAkzasAH . anyo'nyenA-#}
{#ByasUyanta vimardamasahanta ca;#} or in sentences in which the gerond
is used elliptically; e. g. {#tAByAmanyo'nyamAsAdya samavApyata saM-#}
{#SamaH#}.--<sup>c.</sup> There are however many instances in which
{#anyonya#} does not refer to the subject, or in which it is the
attribute of a subject which is not a masculine and there-
fore cannot be looked upon otherwise than as a compound;
e. g. {#anyonyena kftam;#} or {#anyonyasmE dattam;#} or {#anyonyezAM pu-#}
{#zkarErAmfSanto dAnodBedAduccakErBugnavAlAH;#} or as an attribute
of a neuter {#prItyaprItivizAdAdyErguRAnAmanyonyaM vEDarmyam;#} and
the same must be observed of all the words in which {#anyonya#}
is the first part of a compound; comp. e. g. the following
articles and {#anyonyatas#}. <sup>d.</sup> {#anyonyam#} is frequently used ad-
verbially, e. g. {#yadyapyAtmanAmanyonyaM BedavAkyavadaBedavAkyAnyapi#}
{#santi taTApi nAdvEtaM nAtyantamaBedaH.--anyonyam#} or {#anyonyAm#}
are used optionally in the sense of an accusative, if the
subject to which they refer is either a feminine or a neuter;
e. g. {#anyonyamime brAhmaRyO BojayataH#} or--{#anyonyAM BojayataH;#}
{#anyonyamime brAhmaRakule BojayataH#} or--{#anyonyAM BojayataH;#}
these are the instances given by Patanjali on the Vārttika
12 to Pāṇ. VIII. 1. 12, and because they show either word
as representing in meaning the accus. of {#anyonya,#} some
grammarians (‘of the East’, according to the Prauḍhama-
noramā on the same rule) contend that the option is re-
stricted to the meaning of this case, but that {#anyonyam#} alone
is admissible when expressing adverbially the sense of the
other cases. Others, on the contrary, maintain that the quoted
words are intended by Patanjali merely as an instance and
that the option extends also to sentences in which {#anyonyam#}
would imply the sense of an instrumental &c. Bhaṭṭoji, re-
ferring in the Siddh. Kaum. on the quoted rule to Patanjali's
gloss on the 5th Bhāṣyakārikā to Pāṇ. IV. 1. 3, sides with
the former opinion. (Prauḍham. {#yadapi tftIyAdizu puMvaditi#}
{#prAco granTaM vyAcakzARA AhuH . tftIyAdizu puMvadBAvaviSezaH .#}
{#tena wAp na . atra tftIyAdizvavivakzitam . dvitIyAyAmapi puM-#}
[Page148-b+ 56]
{#vattvasyezwatvAditi . taccintyam . puMvattvaM viSeza iti viSezABiDA-#}
{#namavivakzitamiti ca svokteH . parasparavyADAt . mUlakftA puMva-#}
{#dBAvasyAspfzwatvAt . tadgranTasyAYjasyenEva vyAKyAtatvAcceti dik ..#});
Jayamangala, however (in the printed ed. of the Bhaṭṭikāvya)
differs materially from either of the quoted authorities; for in
his comment on Bhaṭṭik. 8. 6. he not merely quotes apparently
a Vārttika which varies in important points from that of Pa-
tanjali, but justifies {#anyonyam#} of the text by adding: {#strInapuM-#}
{#sakayorAmaBAva iti vaktavyam#} ‘if the subject is a feminine or a
neuter, the form {#anyonyAm#} is not admissible’ (the subject of
the commented sentence being {#udanvAn#} and the femin. {#rA-#}
{#kzasI#}); yet the correctness of the printed text alluded to is
very doubtful; for the E. I. H. Ms. 544 reads this comm. thus:
{#anyonyamityAdi . anyonyamityasyetyarTaH . karmavyatIhAre sarvanA-#}
{#mnI dvirBavataH . samAsavacca bahulam . yadA samAsavattadA pUrvapa-#}
{#dasya praTamEkavacanam . uttarapadasyAmBAva iti vAcyam . anyo-#}
{#nyasaMbanDiBiH SabdEH#} &c. &c. (Comp. also the comm. on Bhaṭṭ.
1. 21.)--As regards the classical literature there can be no
doubt that the adverbial use of {#anyonyam#} prevails almost ex-
clusively over that of {#anyonyAm#}. <sup>e.</sup> The Gaṇaratnamaho-
dadhi (which mentions {#anyonya#} among the {#sarvanAman#} q. v.) gives
{#anyonyasya#} in the Gaṇa {#cAdi,#} imparting to the genitive the
value of an adverb or that of {#anyonyam;#} but the instance,
Vardhamāna gives in his comm. on this work, {#‘anyonyasya#}
{#smaranti’#} is not happy, as the genitive could be the legitimate
government of {#smaranti; ‘anyonyasya Bojayanti’,#} the instance
of the Kāśikā to Pāṇ. VIII. 1. 12. Vārtt. 11; {#‘anyonyasya vya-#}
{#tipunanti’#} of Patanjali to Pāṇ. III. 1. 16. and {#‘anyonyasya#}
{#vyatilunanti’#} of the Kāś. to the same rule, seem more to the
purpose; but the occurence of the genitive in the sense of
other cases is, in general, rare.--Comp. {#itaretara#} and {#paraspara#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-nyam#}) (In Rhetoric.) An {#alaMkAra#} q. v. or mode
of elegant expression; viz. conveying the mutual relation
or intimacy of two objects by representing them as the
mutual cause of the same action ({#‘arTayorekakriyAmuKena#}
{#parasparaM kAraRatve satyanyonyaM nAmAlaMkAraH’#}), e. g. ‘she shineth
through thee and thou shinest through her, like as the
moon shineth through the night and the night shineth through
the moon’. E. {#anyas#} and {#anya#}. [The oldest grammatical
authorities do not consider {#anyonya#} as a compound, but
take {#anyonyena#} and other cases as consisting of the two dis-
tinct words: the nomin. of {#anya#} and the instrum. of {#anya#}
&c.; see Vārtt. 11 to Pāṇ. VIII. 1. 12. and the remark of
Kaiyyaṭa: {#tatra bahulagrahaRAdanyonyaSabde samAsavadBAvABAvA-#}
{#tsubluNga Bavati . nApi samAsAntodAttatvamityAmreqitAnudA-#}
{#ttatvaM Bavati#} (comp. Pāṇ. VIII. 1. 3); but it results from the
foregoing statement that this etym. cannot be entertained.
Jayamangala on the Bhaṭṭikāvya 17. 8. appears to consider
{#anyonya#} not as a Tatpur., but as Karmadh. (in explaining
{#anyonyam#} by {#‘anyasya anyasya’#}), probably in thinking of Pāṇ.
VIII. 1. 11. which applies to VIII. 1. 12; but the possibility
of this application is removed by the quoted words of
Kaiyyaṭa and by the general remark he appends to the
Vārttikas of VIII. 1. 12, viz. {#vArtikezu karmaDArayavaditi na#}
{#saMbaDyata iti sublopAdi na Bavati#}. A modern theory takes
{#anyonya#} for a compound (it does not say which), but calls
[Page149-a+ 56]
the former part of this word a ‘benumbed’ nominative. It
seems, however, that the sense and accent of the word (it is
udātta on the second syllable) decide in the first place for
its being a Tatpur., and secondly its form, that it belongs
to that class of compounds in which the former part has
received a further developement by means of an affix {#s,#}
the function of which {#s#} apparently consists in producing a
stronger relation between the two parts of the compound and
consequently a more intense unity of notion, than would be
expressed without this {#s;#} comp. e. g. the derivatives of
{#sam-kf#} and {#saMs-kf, pari-kf#} and {#pariz-kf, apa-kF#} and {#apas-#}
{#kF; A-carya#} and {#AS-carya, apa-kara#} and {#apas-kara#} &c. and
such words as {#hariS-candra, ajas-tunda, bfhas-pati, prAyaS-#}
{#citti#} &c. &c. (comp. Pāṇ. VI. 1. 135-157.) which resemble closely
in formation {#anyo'nya#} (and the synon. {#paraspara#}); the accent of
this word would then fall under the category of Pāṇ. VI. 2. 2.]
<LEND>

<L>4359<pc>149-a<k1>anyonyajanana<k2>anyonyajanana
{#anyonyajanana#}¦ Tatpur. (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) 1. n. ({#-nam#})
The producing each other; see the following.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-naH#}) Producing each other; a condition of the
three {#guRa#} or qualities {#sattva, rajas#} and {#tamas#} qq. vv. ‘as a
lump of clay produces a jar’; comp. also {#anyonyamiTuna, a-#}
{#nyonyABiBava, anyonyASraya, anyonyavftti#}. [In the Sāṅkhya-
kārikā v. 12, where these terms occur {#‘anyonyABiBavASraya-#}
{#jananamiTunavfttayaSca guRAH’#} Vāchaspati combines {#vftti#} with
each of the former and analyses therefore {#anyonyABiBavavftti#}
&c., while Gauḍapāda takes {#anyonyavftti#} for a separate con-
dition.] E. {#anyonya#} and {#janana#}.

<L>4368<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyaviBAga<k2>anyonyaviBAga

<L>4369<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyavftti<k2>anyonyavftti
{#anyonyavftti#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-ttiH#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.)
One calling the other into action, reciprocally causing each
other to act; a condition of the three {#guRa#} or qualities {#sattva,#}
{#rajas#} and {#tamas#} qq. vv.; i. e. ‘one being or acting in the
other; as a handsome and well behaved woman is at the
same time a source of delight to every one else and one of
misery to the other wives of her husband, as well as one
of bewilderment to enamoured damsels, in the same manner
{%sattwa%} calls into existence {%rajas%} and {%tamas%} &c.’, other similes
being used to illustrate that {%rajas%} causes the action of {%sattwa%}
and {%tamas,%} and {%tamas%} that of {%sattwa%} and {%rajas.%} (Vāchaspati
does not recognise this condition of the three qualities;
see {#anyonyajanana#}.) E. {#anyonya#} and {#vftti#}.
<LEND>

<L>4376<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyasApekza<k2>anyonyasApekza

<L>4377<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyahastakalita<k2>anyonyahastakalita
{#anyonyahastakalita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Held reci-
procally in (his several) hands. This word occurs in an
example of permutation, given in the Līlavatī, where the
[Page150-a+ 56]
question is put, ‘how many are the variations of form of
the god Śiva by the exchange of his ten attributes held reci-
procally in his hands viz. the rope, the elephant's hook &c.,
as those of Viṣṇu by the exchange of the mace &c.?’ (the
practical purpose apparently being to know the number of
variations that may be effected in the representation of the
idol): {#pASANkuSAhiqamarUkakapAlaSUlEH . KawvANgaSaktiSaracA-#}
{#payutErBavanti . anyonyahastakalitEH kati mUrtiBedAH SamBorhareriva#}
{#gadArisarojaSaNKEH#} (The answer is in the case of Śiva:
3628800; in that of Viṣṇu: 24; and Colebrooke adds (Alg.
p. 124 note): ‘the 24 different representations of Viṣṇu,
arising from his diversity in the manner of placing the
weapons or attributes in his four hands, are distinguished
by as many discriminative titles of the god allotted to those
figures in the theogonies of the Purāṇas. It does not ap-
pear that distinct titles have been in like manner assigned
to any part of the more than three millions of varied re-
presentations of Śiva’.) E. {#anyonya-hasta#} and {#kalita#}.
<LEND>

<L>4378<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyahArABihata<k2>anyonyahArABihata

cally multiplied by the denominators; e. g. {#anyonyahArABi-#}
{#hatO harAMSO rASyoH samacCedaviDAnamevam#} ‘the denominator
and numerator of two quantities being multiplied recipro-
cally by their denominators, (the quantities) are thus re-
duced to the same denominator’. E. {#anyonya-hAra#} and
{#aBihata#}.
<LEND>

<L>4380<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyABAva<k2>anyonyABAva
{#anyonyABAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) (In the Vaiśeṣika philosophy.)
Mutual negation, one of the four divisions of {#aBAva#} q. v.;
viz. that kind of negation or mutual exclusion which is held
to exist between notions that have no property in common;
indifference considered as a negation of heterogeneous notions;
as if one says: ‘shape’ is not ‘jar’ ({#‘anyonyABAvatvaM tAdAtmyasaM-#}
{#banDAvacCinnapratiyogitAkABAvatvam’#}). This notion is different
therefore from that of {#pfTaktva#} q. v. E. {#anyonya#} and {#aBAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4381<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyABAvatva<k2>anyonyABAvatva

<LEND>

<L>4382<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyABiBava<k2>anyonyABiBava

{#tamas#} qq. vv.; viz. when {%sattwa%} prevails, it overpowers

<L>4384<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyArTa<k2>anyonyArTa

<L>4385<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyASraya<k2>anyonyASraya
{#anyonyASraya#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Mutual relation; e. g.
{#BAvEH pratyayasargErvinA liNgaM na…liNgena tanmAtrasargeRa ca#}
{#vinA BAvanirvfttirna…vIjANkurAvanyonyASrayaH#}. <sup>2</sup> The
[Page150-b+ 56]
resting on one another, reciprocal support; see {#anyonyASra-#}
{#yavftti#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
Founded on the mutual relation (between two objects),
one of the five modes of a {#tarka#} (q. v.), viz. an {%argumen-%}
{%tatio ad absurdum,%} which consists in founding a premise
on the imaginary relation between two objects and in
drawing a conclusion from it which is inadmissible.
This kind of argumentation may again ‘be threefold ac-
cording to whether the argument of the premise is taken
from the notion of origin or from that of actuality or from
that of comprehension’ ({#‘sa cotpattisTitijYaptidvArA treDA#}
{#…. tadapekzApekzitvanibanDano'nizwaprasaNgaH ..’#}). For
the other four modes of a {#tarka#} see: {#AtmASraya, cakraka, ana-#}
{#vasTA#} and {#tadanyabADitArTaprasaNga#}. [A commentator of the
Sāṅkhya-Pravachana applies three of these terms to the ex-
planation of the Sūtra: {#‘tadyoge tatsidDAvanyonyASrayatvam’#} in
this manner: {#‘avidyAyogAdavidyAsidDO cAnyonyASrayatvamA-#}
{#tmASrayatvamanavasTA veti SezaH ..’#}.] <sup>2</sup> (In the Sāṅkhya philos.)
Resting on one another, supporting one another; a property
of the three {#guRa#} or qualities {#sattva, rajas#} and {#tamas,#} ‘these
qualities resting on each other like binary atoms’; see {#anyo-#}
{#nyajanana#} and {#anyonyASrayavftti#}. E. {#anyonya#} and {#ASraya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4386<pc>150-b<k1>anyonyASrayatva<k2>anyonyASrayatva
{#anyonyASrayatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) Argumentatio ad absurdum; see the
preceding. E. {#anyonyASraya,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4387<pc>150-b<k1>anyonyASrayavftti<k2>anyonyASrayavftti

sophy.) Having the nature of resting on one another, of
supporting one another; see {#anyonyajanana#} and {#anyonyASraya#}.
E. {#anyonyASraya#} and {#vftti#}.

<L>4390<pc>150-b<k1>anvak<k2>anvak
{#anvak#}¦ ind. <sup>1</sup> Following, after. <sup>2</sup> Favourably, friendly dis-
posed; e. g. {#anvagBUyAste#} or {#anvagBUtvAste;#} comp. {#anvagBA-#}
{#vam#}. E. The neuter of {#anvac#} q. v.
<LEND>

<L>4391<pc>150-b<k1>anvakzam<k2>anvakzam
{#anvakzam#}¦ Avyayībh. <sup>1</sup> After, afterwards. <sup>2</sup> Immediately, in-
stantaneously. E. {#anu#} and {#akzi,#} samās. aff. {#wac#} (accord-
ing to a Gaṇa to Pāṇini; the comm. on the Amarak. and
Vijnānesvara in the Mitākṣara derive it from {#anu#} and {#akza#}
{#(= indriya): ‘anugatamakzam’;#} equally so Vallabhagaṇi on
Hemachandra {#‘akzasya paScAdanvakzam’#}. The second meaning
would arise according to Vijnān. from rendering the word
‘{#yAvaddarSanam,#} as far as a glance’. But it is more probable
to consider {#anvakza#} as a deriv. from {#ac#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#ksa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4392<pc>150-b<k1>anvakzarasanDi<k2>anvakzarasanDi
{#anvakzarasanDi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-nDiH#}) (In vaidik Grammar.) A
technical name for certain Sandhi or meeting of letters at
the end and beginning of words; viz. <sup>a.</sup> when a final vowel
or {#ezaH, syaH#} or {#saH#} are followed by a consonant (the Vi-
sarga of these three words then being dropped); see {#anu-#}
{#loma;#} <sup>b.</sup> when a final consonant is followed by an initial
vowel; see {#pratiloma;#} <sup>c.</sup> when a final Visarga is followed
by a consonant called {#Uzman#} q. v. which itself is followed
by a surd or hard consonant (the preceding Visarga then
being dropped, e. g. {#samudrA sTaH,#} instead of {#samudrAH sTaH#});
see {#vaktra;#} <sup>d.</sup> when the particle {#Im#} is followed by the words
[Page151-a+ 56]
{#garBam, gAvaH, vatsam, mfjanti, pfcyate, saKAyaH, vivyAca,#}
{#punar, riRanti#} and {#raTam#} (the final {#m#} of {#Im#} then being
dropped). E. {#anu-akzara#} and {#sanDi#}.
<LEND>

<L>4393<pc>151-a<k1>anvagBAvam<k2>anvagBAvam
{#anvagBAvam#}¦ Tatpur. ind. Favourably or friendly disposed;
e. g. {#nAmagrAhaM kapiBiraSanEH stUyamAnaH samantAdanvagBAvaM ra-#}
{#GuvfzaBayorvAnarendro virAjan…kizkinDyAdriM nyaviSata#}.
(The same meaning may be expressed also by {#anvagBUya#} or
{#anvagBUtvA;#} but in neither case these words mean ‘after’.)
E. {#anvak#} and {#BAvam#} ({#BU,#} kṛt aff. {#Ramul#}).
<LEND>

<L>4394<pc>151-a<k1>anvac<k2>anvac
{#anvac#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-nvaN-nUcI-nvak; nvaYcam-nUcIm-nvak;#}
{#nUcA-nUcyA-nUcA#} &c.; du. {#nvaYcO-nUcyO-nUcI;#} plur. {#-nvaYcaH-nUcyaH#}
{#-nvaYci; nUcaH-nUcIH-nvaYci#} &c.) <sup>1</sup> Following; {#anUci#} (loc. sing.),
behind, from behind; e. g. {#AgacCato'nUci gajasya GaRwayoH#}
{#svanaM samAkarRya samAkulANganAH#} &c. (comm. {#anUci pfzWadeSe#}).
<sup>2</sup> (ved.) Going along or lengthwise; as opposed to {#udac#} and
{#tiryac#} qq. vv.--The neuter {#anvak#} is used as adv. and as-
sumes in conjunction with {#BUtvA#} or in composition with {#BUya#}
and {#BAvam#} (see {#anvagBAvam#}) the meaning of ‘friendly or
favourably disposed’. [Pāṇini, in the rule III. 4. 64. makes
uses of the form {#anvaci#} which has the value there of a
locat. of {#anvac;#} Patanjali blames him for this liberty: {#a-#}
{#yukto'yaM nirdeSaH . anUcIti Bavitavyam . sOtro'yaM nirdeSaH .#}.
But as Pāṇini expresses himself in a similar manner when
speaking of {#tiryac#} III. 4. 60. {#‘tiryacyapavarge’#}--when he in-
curs a like remark from Patanjali--, it is perhaps more
just to say that he did not intend to speak in these rules
of the declinable {#anvac#} and {#tiryac,#} but of their neuters
become indeclinable; and that, his method requiring in these
rules the locative of the mentioned words, {#anvaci#} and {#ti-#}
{#ryaci#} were less objectionable than {#anvaki#} and {#tiryaki,#} while
{#anUci#} and {#tiraSci,#} as suggested by Patanjali, would not
have necessarily conveyed the notion of indeclinable words.]
E. {#ac#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#kvin#}.
<LEND>

<L>4395<pc>151-a<k1>anvaDyAyam<k2>anvaDyAyam
{#anvaDyAyam#}¦ Avyayībh. <sup>1</sup> Chapter for chapter. <sup>2</sup> According to,
or conformably to, the chapters (esp. of the vaidik writings),
e. g. (in Lāṭyāyana's Kalpasūtras) {#anvaDyAyamapavAdaniSA-#}
{#manam#} (comm. {#aDyAyamanu anvaDyAyam . anvaDyAyamapavAdo#}
{#niSAmayitavyaH . anvaDyAyaM nyAyyAnAM CandodEvatasAmAntAnA-#}
{#mapavAdaH#}). <sup>3</sup> In the vaidik language; used in this sense by
Yāska in contradistinction from {#BAzAyAm#} ‘in the classical
idiom’. E. {#anu#} and {#aDyAya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4396<pc>151-a<k1>anvaya<k2>anvaya
{#anvaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Connexion, association; e. g. {#di-#}
{#gvyApinIrlocanaloBanIyA mfjAnvayAH snehamiva sravantIH . f-#}
{#jvAyatAH SasyAviSezapaNktIstutoza paSyanvitfRAntarAlAH#} (comm.
{#mfjA SudDiH…tayA anvayo'nugamo yAsAM SudDyanugatA#}
{#ityarTaH#}). <sup>2</sup> Retinue, attendance; e. g. {#kA tvamekAkinI BIru#}
{#niranvayajane vane#} (comm. {#niranvayA niranugamA janA yasmi-#}
{#nvane#}). <sup>3</sup> Family, race, lineage (in general); e. g. {#anvayA-#}
{#diviBinnAnAM yaTA saKyamanIpsitam#} &c. Comp. {#anvavAya#}.
<sup>4</sup> The male descendants (in contradistinction from the fe-
male succession); e. g. {#mAturduhitaraH SezamfRAttABya fte'nvayaH#}
(scil. {#viBajerannfkTam;#} comm. {#anvayaH putrAdiH,#} or accord. to
another comm. {#anvayapadena putrARAmaDikAraH#}). <sup>5a.</sup> {%Logical%}
connexion (esp. of words); e. g. {#arpaRaM svasya vAkyArTe para-#}
{#syAnvayasidDaye . upalakzaRahetutvAdezA lakzaRalakzaRA;#} also with
a noun in the instrum.; e. g. {#SaNkAM mA kfTA iti pUrveRAnvayaH#}
[Page151-b+ 56]
(the words of the verse Bhaṭṭik. 1. 22. being logically con-
nected with {#SaNkAM#} &c. of the preceding verse); more seldom
with a word in the locative, e. g. in a comm. on the Ve-
dānta Sūtra {#‘vAkyAnvayAt’#} which is explained: {#etAvadare Ka-#}
{#lvamftatvam . ityupasaMhAreRAsya vAkyasya brahmaRyanvayAt#}. <sup>b.</sup> {%Gram-%}
{%matical%} connexion of the words in a sentence, grammatical
construction of a sentence; in this sense very frequently
used in the commentaries, in the same manner as {#saMbanDa#}.
Sometimes the two latter meanings will coincide, e. g. (in
a Mīmānsā-discussion on the question: whether the bearing
of a passage is conveyed by the words of a sentence or not,
when the wrong thesis, that it is not, is thus refuted:) {#mE-#}
{#vam . anvaye SezaSeziBAvasyAntarBAvAt . na hi guRapraDAnaBA-#}
{#vamantareRAnvayaH saMBavati . dvayorguRayoH parasparAkANkzArahita-#}
{#tvenAnvayayogyatvABAvAt . evaM dvayoH praDAnayorapi . ato#}
{#vyutpattisaMBavAtkriyAkArakatadanvayo yaTA SAbdaH . taTA tada-#}
{#nvayAntargataH SezaSeziBAvo'pi SAbdaH .#}. <sup>6</sup> (In Philosophy,
esp. in the Nyāya and Vaiśeṣika, and in scientific language
in general.) <sup>a.</sup> Logical consequence; e. g. in a comm. on a
Yoga Sūtra {#na hi kvacidapi kleSAnAM viparyayAnvayanirapekzarU-#}
{#pARAM svarUpamupalaByate;#} or in the Yoga Sūtra: {#sTUlasvarUpasU-#}
{#kzmAnvayArTavattvasaMyamAdBUtajayaH,#} where the word {#anvaya#} is ex-
plained: {#KyAtikriyAsTitiSIlAguRAH kAryasvaBAvAnupAtino#}
{#anvayaSabdenoktAH;#} or in another Yoga Sūtra: {#grahaRasvarUpA-#}
{#smitAnvayArTavattvasaMyamAdindriyajayaH,#} where it has the same
meaning. <sup>b.</sup> Logical continuance; in this sense the word is
opposed to {#vyatireka#} ‘logical discontinuance’ and occurs, for
the most part, either combined with the latter to a Dwandwa
(see also {#anvayavyatireka#}), or in reference to it. Again the
general notion of {%‘logical continuance%} and {%discontinuance’%} be-
comes modified <sup>aa.</sup> when applied to the notion of genus, into
to the notion of {%species%} and {%variety;%} e. g. in a Mīmānsā dis-
cussion: {#nanvAnantyavyaBicArAByAM na vyaktO vyutpattiH saMBavati .#}
{#anantA hi govyaktayaH… . SuklavyaktO vyutpanno goSabdaH kf-#}
{#zRavyaktO prayujyamAnaH svArTaM vyaBicaret…iti prApte brUmaH .#}
{#anvayavyatirekAByAmAkfteH SaktigrahaRanimittatvAcCabdArTatvaM ta-#}
{#syA evocitam .;#} or: {#anvayavyatirekAByAM jAtivAcitvAt;#}
<sup>bb.</sup> when applied to the notion of subject and predicate or to
syllogizing in general, this term expresses {%congruity%} and {%dis-%}
{%parity, consecutiveness%} and {%exception%} (deviation), or {%affirmation%}
and {%negation;%} e. g. {#kAvyasvarUpatvenABimatayoH SabdArTayoH raso#}
{#'sti na vA . nAsti cet . guRavattvamapi nAsti . guRAnAM tada-#}
{#nvayavyatirekAnuviDAyitvAt .#} (also in this sense in a verse
of the Rājataraṅgiṇī: {#svadeSo'yaM videSo'yamiti budDeH#}
{#pravartakaH anvayavyatirekAByAM sTityaByAsaH SarIriRAm;#} or of
the Bhāgav. Purāṇa: {#etAvadeva jijYAsyaM tattvajijYAsunAtmanaH .#}
{#anvayavyatirekAByAM yatsyAtsarvatra sarvadA#}); and comp. {#kevalAnva-#}
{#yin, kevalavyatirekin, anvayavyatirekin, anvayavyApti, vya-#}
{#tirekavyApti#}. <sup>cc.</sup> when applied to the notion of law, it ex-
presses {%rule%} and {%exception,%} or {%positive%} and {%negative clause;%}
e. g. {#anyodaryaH…saMsfzwI DanaM harenna punaranyodaryo DanaM hare-#}
{#dasaMsfzwI . anenAnvayavyatirekAByAmanyodaryasya saMsfzwitvaM Danagra-#}
{#haRe kAraRamuktam#}.--E. {#i (iR)#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>4399<pc>152-a<k1>anvayavyatireka<k2>anvayavyatireka

tras: {#atrApi pratiniyamo'nvayavyatirekAt;#} or {#viSizwasya jI-#}

<L>4400<pc>152-a<k1>anvayavyatirekin<k2>anvayavyatirekin

śeṣika philosophy.) Congruous and disparate, positive and ne-
gative; one of the three kinds of inference; see {#anumAna#} and
the explanation given there. Compare also {#anvayavyatireka#}.
E. {#anvayavyatireka,#} taddh. aff. {#ini#}.

<L>4401<pc>152-a<k1>anvayavyApti<k2>anvayavyApti

or affirmative kind, a positive proposition; one of the two
kinds of a {#vyApti;#} see besides {#vyatirekavyApti#} and compare
{#anumAna#} and {#anvaya#}. E. {#anvaya#} and {#vyApti#}.

<L>4403<pc>152-a<k1>anvayin<k2>anvayin

<L>4405<pc>152-a<k1>anvarTa<k2>anvarTa
{#anvarTa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rTaH-rTA-rTam#}) Having an obvious
sense, having a sense easily to be understood from the
etymon, as simple words like {#vftti, kazAyavat,#} or com-
pounds, when analyzed into their constituent parts, such
as {#nibanDa, dIrGapattra#} &c. The same as {#anugatArTa;#} comp. the
following words. (The word is taken as a Bahuvr. by Val-
labhagaṇi on Hemach. 257. = 2. 171: {#anugato milito'rTo#}
{#'nayoranvarTe;#} but it may be also a Tatpur.)
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-rTam#}) According to the literal sense (arising
from the etymon); literally; e. g. {#kriyAyAH pratizeDena tatPalasya#}
{#viBAvanAt . jYeyA viBAvanEvAsO sAnvarTaM kaTyate yaTA .#}.
Comp. the following. E. {#anu#} and {#arTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4406<pc>152-a<k1>anvarTagrahaRa<k2>anvarTagrahaRa
{#anvarTagrahaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Taking or understanding a
word in its literal or etymological (not in its conventional
or technical) sense; e. g. the word {#bahuvacane#} in Pāṇini VIII.
2. 81, where it is not be taken in the technical sense ‘plural’,
but in the sense {#bahUnAmarTAnAM vacane,#} as otherwise the form
{#amI#} would not result from the rule. E. {#anvarTa#} (Avyayībh.)
and {#grahaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4407<pc>152-a<k1>anvarTatA<k2>anvarTatA
{#anvarTatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) The having an obvious sense or one to
be inferred from the etymon; e. g. {#yatrAnvarTatA nAstyupamA-#}
{#yAH . tadupamAyuktameva rUpakaM drazwavyam#}. E. {#anvarTa,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#}.
<LEND>
[Page152-b+ 56]

<L>4408<pc>152-b<k1>anvarTasaYjYa<k2>anvarTasaYjYa
{#anvarTasaYjYa#}¦ I. Tatpur. f. ({#-YjYA#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Grammar.) A technical
name (see {#saMjYA#}) which conveys its own meaning (when
etymologically analyzed) and therefore distinct from techni-
cal names such as {#Gu, liw#} &c., which are purely technical;
such {#saMjYAH#} as {#sarvanAman, karmapravacanIya, anunAsika, svara-#}
{#Bakti#} &c. &c. are {#anva°;#} thus Patanj. observes on the word
{#‘karmapravacanIyAH’: kimarTaM mahatI saMjYA kriyate . anvarTa-#}
{#saMjYA yaTA vijYAyeta,#} and Kaiyyaṭa on the latter: {#anvarTasaM-#}
{#jYeti . arTamanu gatArTena vAnugatANgIkftapravfttinimittA yA sA#}
{#saMjYA anvarTasaMjYA#}. <sup>2</sup> A proper name in general which has
preserved its etymological sense; e. g. {#dIrGabAhu#} the name
of a Rākṣasa.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-YjYaH-YjYA-YjYam#}) Bearing a name
which conveys its etymological meaning, properly called (so
and not otherwise); e. g. {#anvarTasaMjYEva paraM trimArgagA#} (i. e.
{#gaNgA#}). E. {#anvarTa#} and {#saYjYA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4409<pc>152-b<k1>anvarTopamA<k2>anvarTopamA
{#anvarTopamA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-mA#}) (In Rhetoric.) A simile con-
veyed by a word which is {#anugatArTa#} (q. v.) or {#anvarTa#} q. v.;
e. g. in the words {#vAnarArkaH…udayagirimivAdriM saMpra-#}
{#mucyAByagAtKam .#} (comm. {#vAnarArkaH vAnaro'rka iva vAna-#}

and {#lalAma#}. E. {#anvarTa#} and {#upamA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4412<pc>152-b<k1>anvavasarga<k2>anvavasarga

<L>4414<pc>152-b<k1>anvavAya<k2>anvavAya

<L>4415<pc>152-b<k1>anvavAyana<k2>anvavAyana

<L>4417<pc>152-b<k1>anvazwakA<k2>anvazwakA
{#anvazwakA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-kA#}) The ninth day of the latter half
of the months Pausha, Māgha and Phālguṇa, according to
Kullūka; according to the gloss of the Mitākṣara on a
quotation from the Gṛhyasūtras: the ninth day of the latter
half of the months Āgrahāyaṇa, Pausha, Māgha and Phālguṇa.
See the following and {#azwakA#}. E. {#anu#} and {#azwakA;#} scil. {#tiTi#}.

<L>4418<pc>152-b<k1>anvazwakya<k2>anvazwakya

called {#anvazwakya#}.--Mitākṣara: {#hemantaSiSirayoScaturRAmapa-#}

{#yate tadanvazwakyam .#}. E. {#anvazwakA,#} taddh. aff. {#yat;#} scil. {#karman#}.

<L>4420<pc>153-a<k1>anvAKyAna<k2>anvAKyAna
{#anvAKyAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) An explanation referring to a
subject mentioned before; e. g. Kumārilabhaṭṭa in a Mīmānsā
Vārttika: {#vyAkaraRenApi prasidDArTAnAmevAvinazwasvarUpAnvA-#}
{#KyAnamAtraM kriyate…yaTA mahABAratanirvacanAnvAKyAne#}
{#dvEpAyanenoktam . mahatvAdBAratatvAcca mahABAratamucyate . niru-#}
{#ktamasya yo veda sarvapApEH pramucyata iti;#} Sāyaṇa = {#anukramaka-#}
{#Tanam;#} also the name of certain passages in the Brāhmaṇas
which explain other passages occurring there. Comp. {#anu-#}
{#vyAKyAna#}. E. {#anu#} and {#AKyAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>4421<pc>153-a<k1>anvAcaya<k2>anvAcaya
{#anvAcaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) Adding an object of secondary
import, or such an object itself; used only in reference to
{#praDAna, muKya#} or {#prADAnya,#} the subject of primary import:
{#‘yatrEkasya prADAnyenAparasya gORyenAKyAnaM so'nvAcayaH’;#} thus
a comm. of the Amarak. in explaining the various appli-
cations of the particle {#ca,#} one of which is {#‘anvAcaye’#} in-
stances (comp. the Siddhāntakaum. on Pāṇini II. 2. 29.):
{#Bo Bikzo BikzAmawa gAM cAnaya,#} when the going out for alms
is enjoined to the beggar as his principal object and his
bringing a cow, when he can see one, as the matter of
secondary import; or of the three Sūtras of Pāṇini VII. 3.
117. 118. 119., the two former contain the {#praDAna#} and the latter
the {#anvAcaya#}. See the following. E. {#anu#} and {#Acaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4422<pc>153-a<k1>anvAcayaSizwa<k2>anvAcayaSizwa
{#anvAcayaSizwa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) Taught or laid
down as a matter of secondary import, being the object of
a secondary rule or observation; used in reference to {#praDA-#}
{#naSizwa,#} what is taught or laid down as a matter of primary
import; e. g. Patanjali observes on Pāṇ. VII. 3. 117-119. (comp.
VII. 3. 118. Vārtt. 3): {#praDAnaSizwamOtvam . anvAcayaSizwama-#}
{#tvam . yaTA kyaNi salopaH . tadyaTA praDAnaSizwaH kyaN prAti-#}
{#padikamAtrAdBavati yatra ca sakArastatra lopaH . ;#} or the Kāśikā
on the same rules: {#Odacca Geriti yezAmekamevedaM sUtraM tena pra-#}
{#DAnaSizwamidudByAmOtvaM ca varRayanti . anvAcayaSizwaM GerakAra-#}
{#miti ..#}. In a similar manner Mallinātha explains in the
Kirātārjunīya the words {#nanu lakzmIH PalamAnuzaNgikam#} thus:
{#lakzmIH sampat . anuzaNgAdAgatamAnuzaNgikamanvAcayaSizwaM PalaM#}
{#nanu . mAnatrARaM jaya sa eva muKyaM Palam . aByuccayastu lakzmIri-#}
{#ti mAninAM mAna eva SlAGya ityarTaH ..#}. Comp. the preceding.
E. {#anvAcaya#} and {#Sizwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4424<pc>153-a<k1>anvAje<k2>anvAje

<L>4426<pc>153-a<k1>anvAdeSa<k2>anvAdeSa
{#anvAdeSa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SaH#}) A reference made to a previous
statement ({#anvAdeSaSca kaTitAnukaTanamAtram#}); sentences con-
[Page153-b+ 56]
taining such a reference are introduced by the particles {#aTa#}
or {#aTo,#} e. g. {#asmE CAtrAya kambalaM dehi . aTo asmE SAka-#}
{#wamapi dehi;#} or {#asya cCAtrasya SoBanaM SIlam . aTo asya#}
{#praBUtamapi svam#}. (For the use which is made in such sen-
tences of the pronominal bases {#a#} and {#ena#} see s. vv. {#idam#}
and {#etad,#} and of {#mA, me, nO, nas, tvA, te, vAm, vas#}
see s. vv. {#asmad#} and {#yuzmad#}.) E. {#anu#} and {#AdeSa#}.

<L>4427<pc>153-b<k1>anvADAna<k2>anvADAna

<L>4428<pc>153-b<k1>anvADi<k2>anvADi
{#anvADi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-DiH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Law.) Property which is
handed over by the person who has received it as a loan,
to another, for the purpose of returning it to its lawful owner.
The same as {#anvAhita#} q. v. <sup>2</sup> A second deposit or pledge.
<sup>3</sup> Mental anxiety subsequent to (an act). E. {#anu#} and {#ADi#}.
<LEND>

<L>4429<pc>153-b<k1>anvADeya<k2>anvADeya
{#anvADeya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-yam#}) (In Law.) An item of a married
woman's property; see {#strIDana#}. It is defined by {%Kātyāyana%}
as property ‘which is received by a woman, after marriage,
from the family of her husband or from her own relatives’
(i. e. from her maternal uncle &c., according to Viṣṇu,
or from the relatives of her parents, as the author of
the Dāyabhāga interprets the latter word). [{#kAtyAyanaH .#}
{#vivAhAtparato yattu labDaM BartfkulAtstriyA . anvADeyaM taduktaM#}
{#tu labDaM banDukulAttaTA .. ‘vizRuvacane ca banDupadaM mAtulAdyaBi-#}
{#prAyam’#} or {#‘BartfkulAt . SvaSurakulAdeH . banDukulAt . pitfmA-#}
{#tfkulAt#}.--The reading in the printed edd. of the second
portion of the Mitākṣara {#‘labDaM pitfkulAttaTA’#} would there-
fore require {#pitf#} to be taken in the sense of {#‘pitaraH#} parents’
not in that of ‘father’; but the given reading seems pre-
ferable as it occurs in several Mss. (E. I. H.) of this work,
in Kullūka on Manu 9. 195 (with the v. 1. {#banDukule taTA#}), in two
passages of the Dāyabhāga (pp. 116 and 149) with the com-
ment quoted, and in the Dāyakramas. p. 17, where the comm.
is: {#banDukulAdityatra banDupadena mAtApitrorupalakzaRam#}. In the
Vivādachintāmaṇi p. 139 the latter half of the verse reads
thus: {#anvADeyaM tu tatproktaM yallabDaM svakulAttaTA#}.] {%Bhṛgu%} defines
this property as ‘whatever is received with pleasure by a
woman, after the marriage ceremony, from her husband and
her parents’ [{#UrDvaM labDaM tu yatkiMcitsaMskArAtprItitaH striyA .#}
{#BartuH pitroH sakASAdvA#} (or {#BartuH sakASAtpitrorvA#}) {#anvADeyaM#}
{#tu tadBfguH#}]; when the Dāyabhāga and Dāyakramas. in quoting
this passage supply after ‘her husband’: ‘and from those re-
lated to her through her husband, i. e. father-in-law &c.’ and
after ‘her parents’: ‘and from those related to her through
her parents, i. e. grandparents &c.’, so as to effectuate a con-
cordance between Kātyāyana and Bhṛgu. [Dāyabh. {#mAtA-#}
{#pitfdvAreRa saMbanDinAM pitroSca sakASAdyattu vivAhAtparato la-#}
{#bDam . taTA BartuH sakASAdBartfkulAcca SvaSurAdito yallabDaM DanaM#}
{#tadanvADeyam;#} Dāyakr. {#BartfdvAreRa saMbanDinAM SvaSurAdInAM mA-#}
{#tApitfdvAreRa saMbanDinAM mAtAmahapitAmahAdInAM ca sakASAt#}
&c.] E. {#anu#} (after, scil. marriage) and {#ADeya;#} scil. {#strIDana#} q. v.
<LEND>

<L>4442<pc>154-a<k1>anvAsana<k2>anvAsana

<div n="P">II. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Taking a seat after another (has sat down);
{#mahokzaM vA mahAjaM vA SrotriyAyopakalpayet . satkriyAnvAsanaM#}
{#svAduBojanaM sUnftaM vacaH#} [in which passage--Yājnav. 1. 109
--the reading {#satkriyAnvAsanaM#} seems preferable to the read-
ing {#satkriyAM cAsanaM,#} since the Mitākṣara explains: {#tasmi-#}
{#nnupavizwe paScAdupaveSanamanvAsanam,#} considering in the latter
half of the Śloka the words as nominatives (with an ellipsis
{#kartavyA#} &c.) {#satkiyA . anvAsanaM#} &c.]. <sup>2</sup> A manufactory, a
place where artisans work ({#‘karmaSAlA ca kArURAmanvAsana-#}
{#mudAhftam#} Halāyudha; liter. ‘a by-shop’). E. {#anu#} and {#Asana#}.

{#anuvAsana#} q. v.

<L>4443<pc>154-b<k1>anvAsyamAna<k2>anvAsyamAna

<L>4444<pc>154-b<k1>anvAhArya<k2>anvAhArya
{#anvAhArya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-ryaH#}) Rice which is given as a
present to the priests upon certain sacrificial occasions, as
at the performance of the Darśapūrṇamāsa; (presents there-
fore of a garment or of a calf are not an {#anvAhArya;#}) the
sacrificial acts must be, moreover, such as are connected
with the ritual of the Yajurveda ({#‘anvAhAryadakziRADvaryu-#}
{#vede’#}). Comp. {#anvAhAryapacana#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-ryam#}) The monthly Śrāddha or funeral repast in
honour of the Manes, held on the day of the new moon;
it should consist of meat of an excellent quality and is so
called, because it is partaken after the presentation of a
piṇḍa to the Manes (comp. {#piRqAnvAhAryaka#}); according to
this definition of Manu, it would be the same as the {#pArvaRa#}
q. v.--others, as quoted by Bharatamalla on the Amarak.
s. v., define it as the monthly Śrāddha at the end of the
year, when the presentation of the piṇḍa has not taken
place ({#‘akftasapiRqIkaraRasya vatsarAnte pratimAsaM yacCrAdDaM#}
{#tatrAnvAhAryamiti kecit’#}). According to the Gṛhyasūtra
of Gobhila (as quoted by Rādhākāntadeva) it would be
<sup>a.</sup> the Śrāddha which is the preparatory act to any religious
ceremony, <sup>b.</sup> the second Śrāddha performed on the day of
the new moon, and <sup>c.</sup> the same as {#anvAhArya#} {%m.,%} but in the
more general sense of a present given at the end of any
sacrificial act: {#‘yacCrAdDaM karmaRAmAdO yA cAnte dakziRA Ba-#}
{#vet . amAvAsyaM dvitIyaM yadanvAhAryaM vidurbuDAH . iti go-#}
{#Bilagfhyam’#}.--See also {#anuhArya#} and the following. E. {#anu#}
and {#AhArya,#} 1. scil. {#odana,#} 2. scil. {#SrAdDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4445<pc>154-b<k1>anvAhAryaka<k2>anvAhAryaka
{#anvAhAryaka#}¦ n. ({#-kam#}) The same as the preceding. E. {#anvA-#}
{#hArya,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>4446<pc>154-b<k1>anvAhAryadakziRA<k2>anvAhAryadakziRA
{#anvAhAryadakziRA#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-RA#}) The present called {#a-#}
{#nvAhArya#} q. v. E. {#anvAhArya#} and {#dakziRA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4447<pc>154-b<k1>anvAhAryapacana<k2>anvAhAryapacana
{#anvAhAryapacana#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) The sacrificial fire in the
southern part of the Vedi, which serves for cooking the
present of rice called {#anvAhArya#} q. v. ({#‘anvAhArya odanaH .#}
{#tasya pAkaheturBavizyati’;#} Sāyaṇa)--hence its name--and
which is collected daily, as the destruction of enemies is
supposed to be the result of the frequent repetition of this
act. E. {#anvAhArya#} and {#pacana;#} scil. {#agni#}.
<LEND>

<L>4448<pc>154-b<k1>anvAhita<k2>anvAhita
{#anvAhita#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tam#}) (In Law.) The same as {#anvADi#} 1.;
e. g. {#yAcitAnvAhitanyAsanikzepAdizvayaM viDiH#} (where the
word {#anvAhita#} is thus explained by the Mitākṣara: {#yade-#}
{#kasya haste nihitaM dravyaM tenApyanu paScAdanyasya haste svAmine de-#}
{#hIti nihitaM tadanvAhitam#}). E. {#anu#} and {#Ahita#}.
<LEND>

<L>4449<pc>154-b<k1>anvita<k2>anvita
{#anvita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Following, pursuing.
<sup>2</sup> Followed by, connected, possessed of, endowed with. <sup>3</sup> Logi-
cally connected, as in construction or sense. <sup>4</sup> Acquired
(mentally), understood, become clear; e. g. {#yadyatsADu na#}
{#citre syAtkriyate tattadanyaTA . taTApi tasyA lAvaRyaM reKayA#}
{#kiMcidanvitam#} (where--Śākuntala VI. v. 146--{#anvita#} does
neither mean ‘imitated, rendered’ nor ‘possessed’). Also
{#anvIta;#} comp. {#anugata#}. E. {#i#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4450<pc>154-b<k1>anvitArTa<k2>anvitArTa
{#anvitArTa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rTaH-rTA-rTam#}) <sup>1</sup> Having a sense
or bearing which results from the context; e. g. in Pāṇini
[Page155-a+ 56]
III. 1. 40. the word {#saMpad#} is not to be supplied like {#kf, as#} and
{#BU#} because the rule has not such a bearing: {#saMpadistu na gf-#}
{#hyate . ananvitArTatvAt#}. <sup>2</sup> Having an obvious or clear sense;
e. g. {#astavyastapadavyApi nigUQArTaM taTAkulam . vyAKyAgamyama-#}
{#sAraM ca nottaraM Sasyate buDEH#} ‘a reply (in court) which is con-
fused &c. is not considered as a reply’; comm. {#astavyastapa-#}
{#davyApi ananvitArTapadavyAptamiti#}. E. {#anvita#} and {#arTa#}.
<LEND>
