<L>4797<pc>172-a<k1>aparigraha<k2>aparigraha
{#aparigraha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) <sup>1</sup> Non-encompassing, non-com-
prehension; e. g. in the {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#aparigrahAccAtyanta-#}
{#manapekzA#}. <sup>2</sup> Non-acceptance. In the latter sense this word
has assumed a special bearing in the {%Yoga%} philosophy and
in such passages of the {%Upan.%} and other writings (compare
e. g. {%Wilson's Viṣṇup.%} p. 288. n. 2), as refer to the doctrine
of this philosophy; it means there: {%renouncing every thing%}
{%that can afford enjoyment,%} as a commentator observes,
from the perception of the defects that inhere in mundane
objects, as they must be acquired, preserved, as they pe-
rish, produce affection and cause the infliction of injury
({%Bhojadeva:%} {#aparigraho BogasADanAnAmasvIkaraRam;#} another:
{#vizayARAmarjanarakzaRakzayasaNgahiMsAdozadarSanAdasvIkaraRamapari-#}
{#grahaH#}); it is in the Yoga phil. the last of the five categories of
the term {#yama#} q. v., the latter being one of the eight Angas
or constituent parts of the Yoga (see {#yogANga#}). Renun-
ciation however must be understood there in its widest sense,
also as indifference to one's own body, since the soul's as-
suming a body is also {#parigraha#} or covetousness, for body
is the instrument of enjoyment and passion is connected
with it; and only the Yogin who is firm in the renun-
ciation in this widest sense, obtains a knowledge of the
condition of former and subsequent existences: {#aparigra-#}
{#hasTErye janmakaTantAsaMboDaH#} ({%Bhojadeva:%} {#…na kevalaM Boga-#}
{#sADanaparigraha eva parigrahaH . kiMtu yAvadAtmanaH SarIragrahI#}
{#'pi parigrahaH . BogasADanatvAcCarIrasya tasminsati rAgAnu-#}
{#banDAt . vahirmuKAyAmeva pravfttO na tAttvikajYAnaprAdurBAvaH .#}
{#yadA punaH SarIrAdiparigrahanErapekzyeRa mADyasTyamAlambate tadA#}
{#maDyasTasya rAgAdityAgAtsamyagjYAnaheturBavatyeva pUrvAparajanmasaM-#}
{#boDaH#}). ({%Jayamangala%} in his comm. on {%Bhaṭṭik.%} 1. 15. calls the
fifth {#yama,#} contrary to the {%Yoga S.,%} {#akalmaza,#} equally so {%Hari-%}
{%hara;%} but {%Vidyāvinodāchārya%} names it correctly in his comm.
{#aparigraha#}.)--The comm. on the {%Sāṅkhya%} phil., while re-
taining the definition of {#yama#} as given by Patanjali, have
made {#yama#} one of the four categories of {#Darma#} (q. v.), righte-
ousness, {#Darma#} being in the Sāṅkhya one of the four categories
of {#budDi#} (q. v.), intellect, when it is {#sAtvika#} or under the in-
fluence of the quality of goodness. E. {#a#} neg. and {#parigraha#}.
<LEND>

<L>4814<pc>172-b<k1>aparipanTin<k2>aparipanTin
{#aparipanTin#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-nTI-nTinI-nTi#}) I. Tatpur. Not anta-

<L>4816<pc>172-b<k1>aparipARi<k2>aparipARi

{#Ri#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#paripARi#} ({#pA#} with {#pari,#} kṛt aff. {#ani#}).

<L>4835<pc>173-a<k1>aparIkzita<k2>aparIkzita
{#aparIkzita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not deliberated, incon-

<sup>2</sup> Untried; e. g. {#avahAsyA Bavizyanti brAhmaRAH sarvarAjasu .#}
{#karmaRyasminnasaMsidDe cApalAdaparIkzite#} (viz. when Arjuna pro-
posed to string the bow at Draupadi's self-choice of a hus-
band and was persuaded not to attempt the trial). <sup>3</sup> Not
sufficiently or not clearly established; e. g. {#aparIkzitAByupa-#}
{#gamAttadviSezaparIkzaRamaByupagamasidDAntaH#} (comm. {#aparIkzitasya#}
{#sAkzAdasUtritasya#} &c.). See {#aByupagamasidDAnta#}. E. {#a#} neg. and
{#parIkzita#}.

which characterize a great man, according to the Buddhists).
E. {#aparuza#} and {#keSa#}.

<L>4842<pc>173-b<k1>apareRa<k2>apareRa

{#vasati;#} also with a noun in the accus. or genitive, e. g.
{#apareRa grAmam#} or {#grAmasya#}. E. See {#apara#} of which it is the
instrum. (but according to Pāṇ. {#apara,#} taddh. aff. {#enap#}).

<L>4847<pc>173-b<k1>aparokza<k2>aparokza
{#aparokza#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kzaH-kzA-kzam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not distant, not
remote; e. g. in the {%Sūtra%} of {%Pāṇini%} III. 2. 119. and the
{%Kār.%} 2. to III. 2. 118., where the past which is not remote is
opposed to the past which is remote (as treated III. 2. 115 ff.).
<sup>2</sup> Perceptible, clear; e. g. in the {%Sāṅkhya Sūtras:%} {#yuktito#}
{#'pi na bADyate diNgUQavadaparokzAdfte#} (scil. {#banDaH#} or the bon-
dage of the soul; comm. = {#sAkzAtkAraM vinA#}); or {#nAnume-#}
{#yatvameva kriyAyA nedizWasya tattadvatorevAparokzapratIteH#} (comm.
{#pratyakzeRApi pratItirasti#} &c.); {#aparokzam#} also used adver-
bially. <sup>3</sup> Absolute, not qualified; as epithet of Brahman
(neuter) in the {%Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upan.,%} where the ablative
{#aparokzAt#} is used absolutely in the sense of the nomin.
{#aparokzam#} viz. {#yatsAkzAdaparokzAdbrahma#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#yadbrAhma sAkzA-#}
{#davyavahitaM kenacit . drazwuraparokzAdagORaM na SrotrabrahmAdivat .;#}
{%Anandajnāna:%} {#muKyameva drazwuravyavahitasvarUpaM brahma . taTA ca#}
{#drazwraDInasidDatvABAvAtsvato'parokzamityarTaH . SrotraM brahma mano#}
[Page174-a+ 56]
{#brahmetyAdi yaTA gORaM na taTA gORam .#}). E. {#a#} neg. and
{#parokza#}.
<LEND>

<L>4853<pc>174-a<k1>aparRa<k2>aparRa
{#aparRa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-rRaH-rRA-rRam#}) Leafless.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-rRA#}) A name of Umā, as a daughter of Himavat
and Menā, so called because she did not even eat a leaf
during her performance of religious austerities, while her
sisters {#ekaparRA#} and {#ekapAwalA#} partook at least, the one of
one leaf and the other of one Pāṭalā flower. E. {#a#} priv.
and {#parRa#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rRaH-rRA-rRam#}) Free from debt or
obligation; e. g. {#tatrAparRAya tatasvanayAdBEmI tapasyaparRAyatata .#}
{#tulitasuparRAya tatastasyAgamanAya sartuparRAya tataH .#}. E. {#apa#}
and {#fRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4854<pc>174-a<k1>apartu<k2>apartu
{#apartu#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rtuH-rtuH-rtu#}) Out of season, unseason-
able. E. {#apa#} and {#ftu#}.

<L>4855<pc>174-a<k1>aparparIka<k2>aparparIka

{%dhākāntadeva,%} on the same authority, s. v. {#agni#} seems to be
less correct.) E. {#a#} compar. and {#parparIka;#} lit. ‘like a sun’.

<L>4860<pc>174-a<k1>aparyAyaviDAna<k2>aparyAyaviDAna

<L>4861<pc>174-a<k1>aparyAvartita<k2>aparyAvartita

and {#paryAvartita#}.

<L>4862<pc>174-b<k1>aparyAsita<k2>aparyAsita
{#aparyAsita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) The same as the
preceding; e. g. {#parEraparyAsitavIryasaMpadAM parABavo'pyutsava#}
{#eva mAninAm#} (comm. {#parEH SatruBiraparyAsitAparyAvartitA vI-#}
{#ryasaMpadyezAM tezAM#} &c.). E. {#a#} neg. and {#paryAsita#}.

<L>4865<pc>174-b<k1>aparvan<k2>aparvan

day of the full and change of the moon, not the 8th and

{#aparvaka#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#parva#}.

<L>4872<pc>174-b<k1>apalApa<k2>apalApa
{#apalApa#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> Denial, abnegation; e. g. {#SrutyA#}
{#sidDasya nApalApastatpratyakzabADAt;#} or {#na DarmApalApaH prakfti-#}
{#kAryavEcitryAt#}. <sup>2</sup> Concealing. <sup>3</sup> Love, affection; (this mean-
ing, given in some Koshas, arises perhaps from: self-denial,
self-abnegation, scil. in favour of another). E. {#lap#} with
{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-paH#}) (In Medicine.) ‘The upper part of the sides
under the shoulder’ ({%Suśruta:%} {#aMsakUwayoraDastAtpArSvopari-#}
{#BAgayorapalApO nAma#}), of half a finger's dimension ({%Bhāva-%}
{%prakāśa:%} {#arDANgulO#}), considered as one of the vital parts
of the trunk, the wounding of which ‘causes death after
the blood has passed into the state of pus’. E. unknown;
perhaps related in etym., although not in meaning, to
{#palApa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4873<pc>174-b<k1>apalApadaRqa<k2>apalApadaRqa
{#apalApadaRqa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-RqaH#}) (In Law.) The fine inflicted
on a defendant for denying a charge on which he gets con-
victed; it consists in payment of the whole value of the
object of litigation to the king, after the claimant has re-
ceived his due. ({%Mitākṣara:%} {#…pratyarTI tadA dadyAdDanaM#}
[Page175-a+ 56]
{#prakftamarTine rAjYe ca tatsamamapalApadaRqam#}). E. {#apalApa#} and
{#daRqa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4875<pc>175-a<k1>apalApin<k2>apalApin

{%blic property’;%} but the meaning {#‘vaYcaka’#} of the comm. does not
permit the word to be derived {%in this sense%} from {#apalap-#}--

p. 99: {#anyasADAraRaDanamasADAraRIkftya gfhlan,#} connecting
them logically with the offence named 2. 237., the latter part
of which verse the {%Vivādach.%} quotes: {#‘ezAmapatitAnAM ca#}

by this reading). E. {#lI,#} in the caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.

<L>4884<pc>175-a<k1>apalyUlanakfta<k2>apalyUlanakfta

of {#apalpUlanakfta,#} but although it may be difficult sometimes

{#apalyU°#} is doubtless the correct one, since the reading of the
radical {#palyUl#} (wherefrom {#palyUlanaM = SoDanadravyam#} Mādhava)
is safe through its occurring also in Beṅgāli writing.--

<L>4893<pc>175-b<k1>apavarga<k2>apavarga
{#apavarga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rgaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Completion, complete performance
of an act (comp. {#apavfkti#}); e. g. {#kriyApavargezvanujIvisAtkf-#}
{#tAH kftajYatAmasya#} (scil. {#rAjYaH#}) {#vadanti saMpadaH;#} in this sense
the word is used in the {%Mīmānsā Sūtras,%} e. g. {#kriyARAmarTa-#}
{#SezatvAtpratyakzatastannirvfttyApavargaH syAt . DarmamAtre tvadarSanAcCa-#}
{#bdArTenApavargaH syAt;#} and in {%Pāṇini'%}s {%Sūtr.%} e. g. {#apavarge tf-#}
{#tIyA;#} or in the {%Vārtt.%} to III. 2. 123: {#nyAyyA tvAramBAnapa-#}
{#vargAt#} (see {#apavfkta#}). Comp. also {#kriyApavarga#} in distinction
from {#sADanApavarga#}. <sup>2</sup> Complete delivery, i. e. the delivery
of the soul from the body and consequent exemption from
the sufferings connected with transmigration; final beatitude
(Snonymous terms are {#mukti, mokza, niHSreyasa;#} but while
{#apavarga#} is used in the sense ‘final beatitude’ especially in the
{%Sāṅkhya-, Yoga-%} and {%Nyāya Sūtras,%} the former terms (qq. vv.)
have been generally preferred, to express the same notion,
by the authors of the {%Vedānta%} and {%Vaiśeṣika S.;%} for the latter
and the {%Mīmānsā S.%} compare also the preceding and the
following meaning.); e. g. {%Nyāya Sūtr.:%} {#tadatyantavimokzo#}
{#'pavargaH#} ‘final beatitude is the complete deliverance from it
(i. e. from pain)’; {%Sāṅkhya Sūtr.:%} {#dvayorekatarasya vOdAsInyama-#}
{#pavargaH#} ‘final beatitude is the indifference of both or of either
of them (viz. of Matter and Soul, i. e. their separation);
[Page176-a+ 56]
{%Yoga Sūtr.:%} {#prakASakriyAsTitiSIlaM BUtendriyAtmakaM BogApa-#}
{#vargArTaM dfSyam#} ({%Bhojadeva:%} {#apavargo vivekaKyAtipUrvikA saMsA-#}
{#ranivfttiH#} ‘{%apavarga%} is freedom from transmigration as the re-
sult of clear discrimination’). Final beatitude being promised
by each philosophy as the reward of a correct knowledge
of its principles, the mode of attaining it differs, of course,
with the doctrine; e. g. {%Nyāya Sūtr.:%} {#duHKajanmapravfttidoza-#}
{#miTyAjYAnAnAmuttarottarApAye tadanantarApAyAdapavargaH#} ‘final
beatitude takes place after the consecutive annihilation of
wrong knowledge which is conducive to the annihilation of
defects (i. e. passions, love, hatred &c.) and so on succes-
sively to that of exertion (rightful or wrong), of re-birth
and of pain; the topics of knowledge being in the {%Nyāya%}
‘Soul, body, organs of sensation, objects of sense, intel-
lect, imagination, exertion, defects as passions &c., the
state of the soul after death or re-birth, retribution, pain
and final beatitude’ ({#AtmaSarIrendriyArTabudDimanaHpravfttido-#}
{#zapretyaBAvaPaladuHKApavargAstu prameyam#}); for the topics of the
{%Vaiśeṣika%} comp. {#padArTa;#} {%Sāṅkhya Kār.:%} {#jYAnena cApavargaH#}
‘through knowledge i. e. of the twenty-five Sāṅkhya prin-
ciples comes final beatitude (comp. {#tattva#}); a comm. on the
{%Yoga:%} {#BoktuH svarUpAvaDAraRamapavargaH#} ‘final beatitude is com-
prehending the real nature of him who enjoys, i. e. of
Purusha or Spirit’. <sup>3</sup> (In the Vaiśeṣika philosophy.)
Speedy destruction, speedy cessation; in the {%Kaṇāda Sūtra:%}
{#‘guRasya sato'pavargaH karmaBiH sADarmyam’#} which according to
the {%Upaskāra%} of {%Śaṅkara%} means: ‘the speedy cessation of
a quality of what exists (does not come under the category
of action, but) has (only) properties similar to those of
actions’ ({%Śaṅk.%} {#apavarga ASunASaH . sa ca guRatve'pi dvitvA-#}
{#divadASuBAvinASakasaMnipAtADIna iti karmaBiH sADarmyamA-#}
{#tramasya na tu karmatvameva .#}). <sup>4</sup> The place or region where the
final deliverance is obtained; e. g. in the verse of the {%Bhāgav.%}
{%Purāṇa:%} {#sUryeRa hi viBajyante diSaH KaM dyOrmahI BidA . svargA-#}
{#pavargO narakA rasOkAMsi ca sarvaSaH#} (comm. {#svargApavargO Boga-#}
{#mokzadeSO#}). <sup>5</sup> A gift, a donation; e. g. {#na te'pavargaH sukftA-#}
{#dvinAkftastaTA yaTAnyezu varezu mAnada . varaM vfRe…#} <sup>6</sup> Re-
striction of a general rule (according to {%Suśruta's%} definition:
{#aBivyApyApakarzaRamapavargaH#}). E. {#vfj#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}
lit. ‘leaving, abandoning’; comp. {#apavarjana#}.
<LEND>

<L>4894<pc>176-a<k1>apavargada<k2>apavargada
{#apavargada#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dA-dam#}) Conferring final be-
atitude. E. {#apavarga#} and {#da#}.
<LEND>

<L>4895<pc>176-a<k1>apavarjana<k2>apavarjana

a donation. <sup>3</sup> Final beatitude. See {#apavarga#} and comp. {#apa-#}
{#sarjana#}. E. {#vfj#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4898<pc>176-a<k1>apavarjya<k2>apavarjya

[Page176-b+ 56]

<L>4899<pc>176-b<k1>apavarta<k2>apavarta
{#apavarta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rtaH#}) (In Algebra.) The common measure,
the divisor which is assumed for both or either of the quan-
tities, without leaving a remainder ({%Colebr. Brahmagupta%}
p. 363); e. g. {#utpatsyamAnayEvaM mUlakaraRyAlpayA caturguRayA .#}
{#yAsAmapavartaH syAdrUpakftestA viSoDyAH syuH . apavartAdapi#}
{#labDA mUlakaraRyo Bavanti tAScApi .#} ‘those terms are to be
subtracted from the square of the rational number, which
are exactly measured by four times the smaller radical surd
thence to be deduced; the quotients found by that common
measure are surds in the root’. (In this passage from the
{%Vījagaṇita%} p. 18 Colebrooke (Alg. p. 153) has had however
instead of the first {#apavarta,#} the reading {#apavartana#} q. v.) E.
{#vft,#} in the caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>4900<pc>176-b<k1>apavartana<k2>apavartana
{#apavartana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Transferring, removing from one
place to another; e. g. {#sTAnApavartana#}. <sup>2</sup> Taking away, de-
priving one of; e. g. {#dAyApavartana#}. <sup>3</sup> (In Algebra.) Division
without remainder by a common measure, reduction, abridg-
ing; e. g. {#BAjyakzepApavartanena#} ‘through reducing the dividend
and additive by the common measure’; or {#hArakzepApavartanena#}
‘through reducing the divisor and additive by the common
measure’. E. {#vft,#} in the caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4901<pc>176-b<k1>apavartita<k2>apavartita
{#apavartita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Turned away, re-
moved. <sup>2</sup> (In Algebra.) Divided without a remainder by a
common measure; e. g. {#BAjyakzepO daSaBirapavartitO#} ‘dividend
and additive reduced by the common measure 10’; or {#hA-#}
{#rakzepO . 63 . 90 . navaBirapavartitO jAtO hArakzepO . 7 . 10 .#}
‘divisor (63) and additive (90) reduced by the common
measure 9 become divisor (7) and additive (10). E. {#vft,#} in
the caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4902<pc>176-b<k1>apavAcana<k2>apavAcana
{#apavAcana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) (Probably) Removing, defeating
(ved.); {#ArtiranapavAcanA#} ‘sickness which cannot be re-
moved’; (comp. the meaning of {#apavaktf#}). E. {#vac,#} in the
caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4903<pc>176-b<k1>apavAda<k2>apavAda
{#apavAda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Refutation, as of an erroneous
imputation; e. g. {#…evamaDyAropaH . apavAdo nAma rajju-#}
{#vivartasya sarpasya rajjumAtratvavat#} &c. ‘so much for the erro-
neous imputation--to the soul of properties that do not
belong to it--; now the refutation is: like as the rope
alone becomes manifest, instead of the serpent (taken for
a rope) which obscured (the reality) of the rope &c. <sup>2</sup> Re-
striction of a previous rule, decree, definition &c.; e. g.
{%Manu%} 8. 341. is a {#cOryApavAda#} or a case which does not fall
under the category of theft; {%Yājnav.%} 2. 83. is an {#apavAda#} to
the rule that a witness must speak the truth.--In {%Gram-%}
{%mar%} it means an exception to a rule and comprises as well
those rules which supersede as those which restrict a general
rule (compare {#viBAzA#}); the terms opposed to it are
{#utsarga,#} e. g. {#prakalpya vApavAdavizayaM tata utsargo'Bini-#}
{#viSate; kvacidapavAdavizaye'pyutsargo'pi pravartate;#} or {#viDi,#}
e. g. {#purastAdapavAdA anantaraviDInbADante na parAn . maDye'pa-#}
{#vAdAH pUrvAnviDInbADante na parAn;#} sometimes both com-
bined, e. g. {#aByAsavikArezvapavAdA utsargAnviDInna bADante#}.
--The term {#bADApavAda#} means ‘exception to an exception’
i. e. the reestablishing of the previous rule, precept &c.
<sup>3</sup> Censure, blame, evil report; e. g. {#AyurviprApavAdena#} (scil.
{#kzarati#}); or {#lokApavAdAdapi na BIto'si#}. <sup>5</sup> An order, a
[Page177-a+ 56]
command; (in this sense the more correct reading of the
word is probably {#avavAda#}). E. {#vad#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">II. A wrong assertion, a wrong tenet; e. g. {#apavAdamA-#}
{#tramabudDAnAm#} ‘--(to say that the void is the true reality)
--is a wrong assertion of people who are not wise (comm.
{#mUQAnAmapavAdamAtraM miTyAvAda eva#})’. E. {#apa#} and {#vAda#}.
<LEND>

<sup>2</sup> Excepting, excluding. <sup>3</sup> Censuring, blaming. E. {#vad#} with
{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul#}.
<LEND>

<L>4906<pc>177-a<k1>apavAdasaNgati<k2>apavAdasaNgati

{#yADikaraRe sarvavezwanasmfteH pUrvavatprAptaM prAmARyamapodyate . seyama-#}
{#pavAdasaMgatiH#}. Comp. also the terms {#SAstrasaMgati, aDyAyasaM-#}
{#gati, pAdasaMgati, AkzepasaMgati, dfzwAntasaMgati, pratyudAharaRasaM-#}
{#gati, prAsaNgikasaMgati, upodGAtasaMgati#}. E. {#apavAda#} and {#saNgati#}.

<L>4914<pc>177-a<k1>apavAha<k2>apavAha
{#apavAha#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-haH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Arithmetic.) Deduction,
lessening, subtraction; esp. of fractions; see {#BAgApavAha,#}
{#lavApavAha;#} e. g. {#svAMSADikonaH Kalu yatra tatra BAgAnubanDe ca#}
{#lavApavAhe . talasTahAreRa haraM nihanyAtsvAMSADikonena tu tena#}
{#BAgAn,#} ‘but, if indeed the quantity be increased or di-
minished by a part of itself, then in the addition and sub-
traction of fractions, multiply the denominator by the de-
nominator standing underneath and the numerator by the
same augmented or lessened by its own numerator (comp.
Colebr. Alg. p. 15 and the following). <sup>2</sup> The name of
a metre regulated by number and quantity, a variety of
Utkṛti; it consists of a stanza of four lines with the fol-
[Page177-b+ 56]
lowing twenty six syllables in each line:
¯¯¯˘˘˘˘˘˘ । ˘˘˘˘˘˘ । ˘˘˘˘˘˘ । ˘˘¯¯¯.
<div n="P">2. m. pl. ({#-hAH#}) The name of a country or people;
also read {#upavAha#} or {#pravAha#}. E. {#vah#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>4915<pc>177-b<k1>apavAhana<k2>apavAhana
{#apavAhana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) (In Arithm.) The same as {#apavAha#} 1.;
e. g. {#jAnAsyaMSAnubanDaM cettaTA BAgApavAhanam#} ‘if thou knowest
the addition and subtraction of fractions’. [In the passage of the
{%Hitopad.%} ed. {%Schlegel%} and {%Lassen:%} {#svarAzwraM vAsayedrAjA parade-#}
{#SApavAhanAt,#} the ed. of {%Johnson%} reads the latter word {#parade-#}
{#SApahAraRAt#}.] E. {#vah#} in the caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4919<pc>177-b<k1>apavidDa<k2>apavidDa
{#apavidDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Rejected, discarded,
disowned; {#apavidDaH putraH#} is, in law, a son who having
been disowned by his natural parents or, in the case of the
death of either of them, having been disowned by the sur-
viving parent, is adopted by another; one of the twelve
kinds of adopted sons, comp. s. v. {#anyavIjaja;#} also said of
a girl, e. g. in the {%Bhāgav. Pur.%} {#kaRqoH pramlocayA labDA kanyA#}
{#kamalalocanA . tAM cApavidDAM jagfhurBUruhA nfpanandanAH#} (comm.
{#apavidDAM tyaktAm#}). <sup>2</sup> Abject, contemptible, e. g. (Rudra speaks
to Viṣṇu in the {%Bhāgav. Pur.%}) {#yadi racitaDiyaM mAvidyaloko#}
{#'pavidDaM japati na gaRaye tattvatparAnugraheRa#} (comm. {#apavidDamA-#}
{#cAraBrazwam#}), ‘if the ignorant world declares me whose mind
is properly framed, to be abject, I do not mind it on ac-
count of thy paramount grace’; {%Burnouf%} renders this pas-
sage: ‘si pendant ce temps le monde ignorant m'appelle
avec mépris contempteur des lois &c.’. <sup>3</sup> Disabled, broken
(lit. or fig.), e. g. {#gargARAM vAhanamapavidDam;#} ({%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#apa-#}
{#vidDamiti vahanaSaktivikalaM pranazwamityarTaH#}); or in the {%Mālatīm.%}
{#hfdayamaSaraRaM me pakzmalAkzyAH kawAkzErapahftamapavidDaM pItamunmUlitaM#}
{#ca#}. <sup>4</sup> Neglected; (in this sense also in the Buddh. {%Dhamma-%}
{%pada%} ed. {%Fausböll%} v. 292). E. {#vyaD,#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}
and samprasāraṇa of the radical.
<LEND>

<L>4929<pc>178-a<k1>apavfti<k2>apavfti

the following. E. {#vft#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>4937<pc>178-b<k1>apavrata<k2>apavrata

<LEND>

<L>4940<pc>178-b<k1>apaSada<k2>apaSada
{#apaSada#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) The same as {#apasada;#} the latter form
being apparently the more correct one. E. See {#apasada#}.
<LEND>

<L>4941<pc>178-b<k1>apaSabda<k2>apaSabda
{#apaSabda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-bdaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The same as {#apaBraMSa#} 2. q. v.; ({%Rā-%}
{%yamukūta%} on {%Amar.%} {#SabdAnuSAsane'saMskftaSabdo'paSabdaH .#}
{#nipAtasyAnekArTatvAdapaSabdo'saMskftArTaH#}); e. g. in the follow-
ing {%Kārikā:%} {#astu vApi tarastasmAnnApaSabdo Bavizyati . vAca-#}
{#kaScetprayoktavyo vAcakaScetprayujyatAm#} ({%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#nApaSabda iti .#}
{#gatArTatvAt . lugBAvAt . vAcakaScetprayoktavya iti tvaM manyase ta-#}
{#dA Suklatarataramiti . yadi vAcakastataH prayujyatAm . na tu vA-#}
{#cakaH . tasmAnna prayoktavya ityarTaH#}). <sup>2</sup> The word {#apa;#} e. g. {#apa-#}
{#Sabdo maDyavAcI#} ‘the word {#apa#} means in the middle of’.
(Comp. the remark s. v. {#apadiSam#}.) E. {#apa#} and {#Sabda#}.

<L>4945<pc>178-b<k1>apaSu<k2>apaSu
{#apaSu#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-SuH#}) <sup>1</sup> Any thing which is not cattle,
as a jar &c. <sup>2</sup> Small cattle, cattle except oxen and horses.
(Both meanings are discussed in the {%Mīmānsā%} in reference
to the vaidic passage: {#apaSavo vA anye goaSveByaH paSavo#}
{#goaSvAH;#} comp. also the instance to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 122.) E. {#a#}
<sup>1</sup> neg., <sup>2</sup> deter. and {#paSu#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-SuH-SuH-Su#}) Without cattle, poor.
E. {#a#} priv. and {#paSu#}.
<LEND>

<L>4946<pc>178-b<k1>apaSugGna<k2>apaSugGna

conferring final beatitude; in the following verse of the {%Bhā-%}
{%gavata Purāṇa:%} {#nivfttatarzErupagIyamAnAdBavOzaDAcCrotramano-#}
{#'BirAmAt . ka uttamaSlokaguRAnuvAdAtpumAnvirajyeta vinA-#}
{#paSugGnAt#} (where the two latter words however, apparently
in the {%same sense,%} may also be analyzed into {#vinA paSu-#}
{#gGnAt,#} accord. to {%Śrīdharasvāmin:%} {#atra loke triviDA janAH .#}
{#muktA mumukzavo vizayiRaSca . tezAM maDye'tra na kasyApyalaMpratyaya#}
{#ityAha . nivfttatarzEriti gatatfzRErmuktErityarTaH . mumukzURAmayame-#}
{#vopAya ityAha . BavOzaDAditi . vizayiRAM paramo vizayo#}
{#'yamevetyAha . Srotramano'BirAmAditi . apagatA SugyasmAtta-#}
{#mAtmAnaM hantItyapaSugGnastasmAt . paSuGAtina iti vA#}). E. {#apa-#}
{#Suc#} and {#Gna#}.

<L>4962<pc>179-a<k1>apazWa<k2>apazWa

<L>4963<pc>179-a<k1>apazWu<k2>apazWu
{#apazWu#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-zWuH-zWuH-zWu#}) <sup>1</sup> Contrary, opposite,
adverse. <sup>2</sup> Handsome, beautiful. <sup>3</sup> Ignorant, infantine.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zWuH#}) Time.
<div n="P">3. adv. ({#-zWu#}) <sup>1</sup> Contrary, adversely. <sup>2</sup> Faultlessly, bla-
melessly. <sup>3</sup> Handsomely. [The {%Medinī%} has the meaning {#vAma;#}
the latter word however, compared to {#cAru#} of the {%Bhūri-%}
{%prayoga%} and to the meanings {#cAru#} and {#SoBana,#} for the ad-
verb., of {%Hemach.%} and the {%Med.,%} can scarcely be taken in
another sense than in that of ‘beautiful’; the meaning
‘ignorant, infantine’ rests on the authority of the {%Bhūripr.%}
and the {%Uṇṇādikoṣa%} which have the meaning {#bAla,#} the
[Page179-b+ 56]
former together with, the latter without, {#kAla#}.--The form
of the adv. {#‘apazWum’#} in the present ed. of the {%Śiśupālab.%}
15. 17. has been expressly mentioned, as if it were something
remarkable, but the mere scanning of the verse--without
any reference to Mss.--might have shown that it is a mis-
print, instead of {#apazWu#}.] E. {#sTA#} with {#apa,#} uṇ. aff. {#ku#}.
<LEND>

<L>4964<pc>179-b<k1>apazWura<k2>apazWura

adverse. Comp. {#apazWu#} and {#apazWula#}. E. {#sTA#} with {#apa,#} uṇ.
aff. {#urac#} or {#uran#} (?).

<L>4965<pc>179-b<k1>apazWula<k2>apazWula

<L>4966<pc>179-b<k1>apas<k2>apas
{#apas#}¦ I. 1. n. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> Action, act, esp. a religious or sacri-
ficial act. (ved.) <sup>2</sup> Water. [It is very doubtful whether
the word is correct in the latter sense, as a {%neuter sing.;%}
comp. I. 2., it occurs as such in the following Sūtra of
{%Kaṇāda%} (E. I. H. Ms. 232) where the reading {#apas#} however
may be a mistake for {#Apas,#} viz. {#pfTivyapastejo vAyurA-#}
{#kASaM kAlo digAtmA mana iti dravyARi ..#}.] Compare also
{#Apas#}. E. {#Ap,#} uṇ. aff. {#asun,#} the vowel of the radical
being shortened; but more probably of {#ap,#} comp. the E.
of {#apta#} and see the Preface.
<div n="P">2. f. plur. ({#-saH#}) (ved.) Water (comp. {#ap#}); e. g. {#bahvI-#}
{#nAM garBo'pasAm#} ‘(Agni) is the child of abundant waters’;
(according to {%Sāyaṇa,%} because he comes as lightning from the
waters collected in the clouds; comp. {#apAM garBaH#} s. v. {#ap#}).
E. {#Ap,#} uṇ. {#asi;#} and as before but see the Preface.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. plur. ({#-saH-saH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Active, engaged in pursuits
in general, more esp. in the performance of religious or
sacrificial acts; in the femin. also as an epithet of the fingers.
<sup>2</sup> Fulfilling an act or business; as an epithet of {#triDAtavaH#}
or ‘the three worlds upheld by the three divinities Fire,
Wind and Sun’, ‘cold, heat, wind, rain &c.’ being, as
{%Mahīdhara%} explains, ‘the doings of the world’. <sup>3</sup> Possessing
activity (or perhaps, referring to religious acts) as an epi-
thet of {#triDAtavaH,#} when, according to {%Mahīdhara,%} in the
sense of {#paSu#} or sacrificial animal. <sup>4</sup> Rapid, swift; as a
river; comp. {#apastama#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-pAH#}) The name of one of the seven Prajāpatis
in the second or the Manwantara of Svārochiṣa, according
to the Mātsya Purāṇa. E. {#apas,#} with luk of the taddh.
aff. {#vini#}.
<div n="P">III. ind. A further developement of the prefix {#apa#} in com-
bination with the inflected forms, and in composition with
some derivatives, of {#kF#} q. v.; comp. {#apaskara#}. The native
theory considers however {#apaskirate#} &c. as {#apa#} and {#kirate#}
&c. with āgama {#suw;#} see the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>4967<pc>179-b<k1>apasada<k2>apasada
{#apasada#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) <sup>1</sup> An offspring of either of six de-
grading connexions, when the father is superior in caste to
that of the mother, viz. of a Brāhmana with the women of
the three lower castes; of a Kshatriya with women of the
Vaiśya and Sūdra--, and of a Vaiśya with a woman of
the Śūdra caste. Men of this kind must follow occu-
pations which are held in disrespect by the three first
castes. Compare also {#apaDvaMsaja#}. <sup>2</sup> A low or contemptible
man in general; in this sense the word may form Karmadh.
[Page180-a+ 56]
compounds of which it is the latter part; e. g. {#Srutiviro-#}
{#DAnna kutarkApasadasyAtmalABaH#}. Also read, but less correctly
{#apaSada#}. E. {#sad#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>4968<pc>180-a<k1>apasamam<k2>apasamam
{#apasamam#}¦ Bahuvr. and Avyayībh. (Probably.) In the past
year, last year. Comp. {#aparasamam#}. E. {#apa#} and {#samA#}.
<LEND>

{#apasara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) A valid reason (liter. a way-out).
Comp. {#anapasara#}. E. {#sf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>

<L>4975<pc>180-a<k1>apasalavi<k2>apasalavi
{#apasalavi#}¦ Bahuvr. and Avyayībh. (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Not from the
right to the left, i. e. from the left to the right; the re-
verse of {#prasalavi#} and {#pradakziRa;#} and the same as {#apasavyam#} II.
<sup>2</sup> The space between the thumb and the forefinger, the
space considered as sacred to the Manes and wherefrom
the oblations to the latter are made. Comp. {#pitftIrTa#} and
the following; {%Raghunandana%} in the {%Śrāddhatattva:%} {#taTA#}
{#ca goBilagfhyam .…iti savyenEva pARinA sUtratantuM gfhItvA .#}
{#apasalavi pUrvasyAM karzvAM piRqe nidaDyAt . piturnAma gfhItvA .#}
{#asAvetatte vAso ye cAtra tvAmanu yAMSca tvamanu tasmE te svaDeti .#}
{#apa upaspfSya . evamevetarayoH savyenEva pARinA udakapAtraM gfhI-#}
{#tvA . apasalavi piRqAnAmupari siYcet .…ezAmarTaH…#}
{#‘sapuzpaM jalamAdAya tezAM pfzWe pfTakpfTak . apradakziRaM nenijyA-#}
{#dgotre nAmAnumantritam’ . iti brahmapurARavacanAt . apasalavi#}
{#pitftIrTena pradeSinyaNguzWayorantarA apasalavi apasavyaM vA tena#}
{#pitfByo nidaDAtIti BawwaBAzyaDftagfhyAntarAdapasavyaSabdena pi-#}
{#tftIrTamucyate . asmAdeva vacanAt . taTA ca manuH . prAcInAvIti-#}
{#nA samyagapasavyamatandriRA ityAdi#} ({%Manu%} 3. 279.) &c. E. {#apa#} and
{#salavi#}. For the meaning of {#apa#} in this word comp. {#apadiSam#}.
<LEND>

<L>4976<pc>180-a<k1>apasavya<k2>apasavya
{#apasavya#}¦ I. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-vyaH-vyA-vyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not left,
right; the same as {#dakziRa.--apasavyaM kf,#} to keep the right
side towards one, (comp. {#pradakziRaM kf#}), or to put on the right
shoulder (scil. the sacrificial thread). <sup>2</sup> Contrary, adverse.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-vyam#}) <sup>1</sup> The sacrificial thread worn over the right
shoulder and passed under the left, at Śrāddhas; comp.
{#prAcInAvIta#}. <sup>2</sup> (In Astronomy) defined thus: {#tArAgrahARAM#}
{#caturDAsaMgarAntargatAparaM yudDam;#} e. g. in the {%Vasiṣṭha-Sid-%}
{%dhānta:%} {#aMSAdUne'pasavAKyaM yudDameko'tra cedaRu#}.
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-vyam#}) The same as {#apasalavi#} in both
meanings; comp. also the quotation under this word. E.
{#apa#} and {#savya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4977<pc>180-a<k1>apasavyaka<k2>apasavyaka
{#apasavyaka#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-vyakaH-vyikA-vyakam#}) The same as {#apasavya#} I.
E. {#apasavya,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>4978<pc>180-a<k1>apasavyavat<k2>apasavyavat

worn over the right shoulder (see {#apasavya#} I. 2.); as a Śrād-
dha at the performance of which it is worn. E. {#apasavya,#}
taddh. aff. {#matup#}.
<LEND>

<LEND>

<L>4982<pc>180-b<k1>apasArvaseni<k2>apasArvaseni
{#apasArvaseni#}¦ Avyayībh. Except Sārvasenī. E. {#apa#} and {#sArva-#}
{#senI#}.
<LEND>

<L>4983<pc>180-b<k1>apasidDAnta<k2>apasidDAnta
{#apasidDAnta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ntaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A false conclusion; e. g. {#mUrta-#}
{#tvAdGawAdivatsamAnaDarmApattAvapasidDAntaH#} ‘(to say that the
Soul is limited) is a false conclusion, for this would lead
to assert that, from its having shape, it shares in the
properties of material substances (as in those of perishable-
ness &c.)’; or {#AnandABivyaktirmuKyamokza iti navInavedAnti-#}
{#nAmapasidDAnta eveti Dik#} ‘to maintain that manifestation of
happiness is real liberation is a wrong conclusion of the
modern Vedāntists: shame (on such twaddle)’. <sup>2</sup> (In the
Nyāya philosophy.) Logical inconsistency in argumentation,
viz. arguing so as to come in contradiction with the tenets
of one's own school; one of the twenty two {#nigrahasTAna#}
or failures in discussion which lead to the defeat of the
disputant; more especially it is thus defined: {#sidDAntamaByu-#}
{#petyAniyamAtkaTAprasaNgo'pasidDAntaH#} ‘{%apasiddhānta%} is ar-
gumentation without regard to the definitions contained in
the tenets of a school which one has adopted as his own’.--
The commentator adds however that there is no {#apasidDAnta#}
or inconsistency of this kind, if one differs merely in a
special topic from the authority of his school: {#yastvekade-#}
{#Simatena kaTAmAraBate tasya SAstrakArAByupagamaviroDe nApasi-#}
{#dDAntaH;#} ‘the Saugatas’, he says, ‘do not consider logical
inconsistency as a defect, but that is another question’ ({#sO-#}
{#gatAstvapasidDAntaM dUzaRaM na manyanta ityanyadetat#}). E. {#apa#} and
{#sidDAnta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4984<pc>180-b<k1>apasIra<k2>apasIra
{#apasIra#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}); II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#});
and III. Avyayībh. ({#-ram#}); it has the same meanings as
{#apalANgala#} and is also udātta on the last syllable. Comp.
the remark s. v. {#apakukzi#}. E. {#apa#} and {#sIra#}.
<LEND>

<L>4985<pc>180-b<k1>apasfpti<k2>apasfpti
{#apasfpti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ptiH#}) Going away from, quitting;
e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} in his comm. on a {%Ved. Sūtra:%} {#jIvasya…#}
{#SarIrAdapasfptiH#}. E. {#sfp#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>4986<pc>180-b<k1>apasOvIram<k2>apasOvIram

<LEND>

<L>4987<pc>180-b<k1>apaskara<k2>apaskara
{#apaskara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Any part of a carriage, except
the wheel. [Some comm. on the {%Amarak.%} II. 8. 2. 23. include
the wheel, e. g. {%Rāyamukuṭa:%} {#akzayugacakrAdikam;#} but {%Bhā-%}
{%nudīkṣita%} is apparently more in harmony with the context
of the Amarak. {#‘raTANgamapaskaraH . cakraM raTANgam’,#} when he
excepts the wheel: {#dve cakraBinnasya raTAramBakasya;#} and {%Valla-%}
{%bhagaṇi%} on Hemach. 3. 422. (or verse 758) also comments:
{#cakrAdanyAni raTasyANgAni AramBakARi raTANgAni apaskarA#}
{#ityanvayaH#}.] <sup>2</sup> The organs of generation and the anus (i. e.
the parts of the body whence dirt proceeds). <sup>2</sup> Fæces, ex-
[Page181-a+ 56]
crements. [The two latter meanings according to {%Dharaṇi%}
who gives the word in the first meaning as a {%neuter:%} {#apa-#}
{#skarO guhyavizWe apaskaraM raTANgakam#}.] E. {#kF#} with {#apa,#} kṛt
aff. {#ap#} and āgama {#suw;#} but comp. the remark s. v. {#apas#}
III.; in the first meaning explained: ‘because it is thrown,
i. e. shaken, in its place: {#apakIryate svasvasTAne kzipyate#}’.
<LEND>

<L>4988<pc>181-a<k1>apaskAra<k2>apaskAra
{#apaskAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) The root of the leg or, according
to others, the root of the knee. [In the verse of the {%Śiśu-%}
{%pālabadha%} 18. 46. {%Mallinātha%} explains the words {#ApaskArAt#}
by {#gAtramUlamApaskAram . ApaskArAdA mUlAt,#} when the
word would not be {#apaskAra#} m., but {#ApaskAra#} n. {%Valla-%}
{%bhachakravartin,%} however, explains {#apaskAro jAnumUlam,#}
and in the same manner {%Vallabhabharatasena%} and {%Chandra-%}
{%śekhara%} (the reading of the E. I. H. Ms. No. 79 {#ayaskAro#}
or {#apaskaro#} in the commentary of the two latter being re-
futed partly by the reading of the verse in other Mss., partly
by the metre itself); and {%Vallabhagaṇi%} in his comment on
the word {#gAtra#} in {%Hemach.'s Abhidh.%} 4. 294. (= v. 1228),
after having quoted the verse in question continues: {#lUna-#}
{#gAtrasya cCinnapUrvakAyasya . ApaskArAt . A jaNGAmUlAt . a-#}
{#paskAraM yAvacCinnasyetyarTaH#}.] E. {#kF#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}
and āgama {#suw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4989<pc>181-a<k1>apasKala<k2>apasKala
{#apasKala#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-laH#}) (ved.) A place which is not a
threshing floor or outside of a threshing floor; a place which
is useless for the purpose of threshing or unchaffing rice
&c.; the word is used in the {%Śatapathabr.%} I. 7. 3. 26. as a
comparison to the Gārhapatya fire on which the clarified
butter is not to be fried, this fire being unfit for such a
purpose; for ‘like as grain heaped up outside of a threshing
floor is to no purpose, in the same manner clarified butter
fried in the Gārhapatya can produce no result’. E. {#apa#} and
{#sKala#}.
<LEND>

<L>4990<pc>181-a<k1>apastama<k2>apastama
{#apastama#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) (ved.) Most rapid, most swift;
as a stream, e. g. {#(sarasvatI) apasAmapastamA#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#vegavatI-#}
{#nAM nadInAM maDye'pastamA vegavattamA#}). E. {#apas#} II. 4., taddh.
aff. {#tamap#}.
<LEND>

<L>4992<pc>181-a<k1>apastamBa<k2>apastamBa
{#apastamBa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-mBaH#}) (In Medicine.) One of the vital
parts between the belly and chest; the name of two vessels
which convey air to the chest and if wounded will, through
cough and asthma, produce death. (According to the {%Bhā-%}
{%vaprakāśa:%} half a finger long.) E. {#stamB#} with {#apa,#} kṛt
aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>4993<pc>181-a<k1>apastamBinI<k2>apastamBinI

{#apastamBa,#} taddh. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

after mourning, or upon the death of a connexion. <sup>2</sup> Bathed
after death (the corpse) preparatory to other ceremonies.
E. {#apa#} and {#snAta#}.

<L>4995<pc>181-a<k1>apasnAna<k2>apasnAna

bathing in water with which a person has previously washed.

according to the Matsya, Brāhma and Vāyu Pur. E. {#apas#}

<L>4998<pc>181-b<k1>apaspfc<k2>apaspfc
{#apaspfc#}¦ (?) Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-k-k-k#}) (ved.) (Perhaps.) Yield-
ing, giving; in the {%Ātharvav.%} 13. 1. 27: {#vi mimIzvava payasva-#}
{#tIM GftAcIM devAnAM DenuranapaspfgezA#} ‘make her to have milk
and to become possessed of butter for the gods: this cow
does not yield any’. E. {#spfc (= pfc)#} with {#apa,#} or {#pfc#}
with {#apa,#} āgāma {#suw,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}. [This interpretation
is hypothetical, in want of a comm. to the Atharv. The
same meaning might result in deriving {#apaspfk#} from {#apaspfS#}
‘sprinkling, shedding’, the radicals {#pfc#} and {#spfS#} being
connected in origin; but the former seems more natural.]
<LEND>

<L>5000<pc>181-b<k1>apasPur<k2>apasPur
{#apasPur#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-sPUH-sPUH-sPUH#}) (ved.) Very large,
increased, excessive; an epithet of Soma (according to
{%Sāyaṇa,%} viz. = {#atyantapravfdDa#}); {#anapasPur#} ‘not large’, an
epithet of a cow ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#apravfdDa#}). But comp. {#apasPurat#}.

<L>5001<pc>181-b<k1>apasPura<k2>apasPura
{#apasPura#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) (ved.) Injured, hurt;
{#anapasPura#} ‘uninjured, inviolable’, an epithet of a cow (ac-

<L>5002<pc>181-b<k1>apasPurat<k2>apasPurat
{#apasPurat#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-n-ntI-t#}) The same as {#apasPura;#}
{#anapasPurat#} ‘not injured, unhurt’; also as an epithet of a
cow (according to {%Sāyaṇa%} on {%Ṛgv.%} 4. 42. 10., viz. {#anavahiM-#}
{#sita#}). {%Mahidhara,%} however, explains the word {#apasPurat#}
in the corresponding verse of the {%Vājas.%} 7. 10. ‘going to
another’ i. e. running away, and {#anapasPurat#} ‘not going to
another’ i. e. not running away. This latter sense being more
congenial with the context, it is probably not unsafe to
infer that the words {#apasPur#} and {#apasPura#} will also have to
be taken in Mahīdhara's meaning of {#apasPurat,#} and {#anapa-#}
{#sPur, anapasPura#} qq. vv. in Mahīdhara's meaning of {#anapa-#}
{#sPurat#}.--E. {#sPur#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<LEND>

<L>5003<pc>181-b<k1>apasmAra<k2>apasmAra
{#apasmAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) (In Medicine.) Epilepsy, falling
sickness; according to {%Suśruta,%} of four kinds, the three
first produced by the derangement of air, bile and phlegm,
the fourth by the combination of the three. (A definition
of {%Ātreya%} is: {#pittaM raktaM marucCezmA udAnaH kupito BfSam .#}
{#prARaH Sirasi saMkupya kurute nazwacezwatAm#}.) In Rhetoric it is
mentioned as a {#vyaBicAriBAva#} or an accessory condition of
the Erotic ({#SfNgAra#}), Pathetic ({#karuRa#}), the Fearful ({#BayAnaka#})
and the Disgustful ({#bIBatma#}), and is defined--but happily
this definition has not guided the Hindu poets in the re-
presentation of their characters--as ‘dementation caused
by the planets or similar evil influences and causing falls,
trembling, perspiration, foaming at the mouth, slavering
&c.’. E. {#smf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>5004<pc>181-b<k1>apasmArin<k2>apasmArin
{#apasmArin#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-rI-riRI-ri#}) Afflicted with epilepsy.
({%Manu%} enjoins not to marry a girl of a family where there
[Page182-a+ 56]
are persons afflicted with epilepsy, the disease being con-
tagious, according to {%Kullūka.%}) E. {#apasmAra,#} tadd. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

to be busy. E. {#apas#} I., denom. aff. {#kyac#}.

<L>5006<pc>182-a<k1>apasya<k2>apasya
{#apasya#}¦ I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-syaH-syA-syam#}) Fit for a (sacrificial) act.
[{%Mahīdhara%} explains in {%Vājas.%} 10. 7. {#apasyo vasAnAH#} as epi-
thets to the preceding word {#ApaH#} ‘waters’ and renders {#apasyaH#}
in the stated sense; but the commentators on a {%Vārttika%}
to {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 30. {#‘vasuapas°°’#} (misprinted in the present
edition and therefore in the reprint of that edition {#‘vasua-#}
{#yas°°’#}) explain {#apasyAH#} as meaning ‘water’; and while {%Ma-%}
{%hīdhara%} takes {#apasyaH#} as an irregular nom. plur. instead of
{#apasyAH,#} {%Patanjali%} and, after him, the {%Kāśikā%} consider it as
an irregular accus. (= {#apaH#}); {%Patanjali:%} {#apasyo vasAnAH .#}
{#apo vasAnAH ..#}. {%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#apSabdAddvitIyAbahuvacanAntA-#}
{#dyatpratyayo viBakteScAluk#}. {%Kāśikā:%} {#dvitIyAbahuvacanasyAluk .#}
{#apo vasAnA ityarTaH#}.]
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-syA#}) <sup>1</sup> Water (see the preceding explanation).
<sup>2</sup> The name of the first fifteen bricks amongst the twenty
bricks which are placed five in each quarter on a sacrificial
ground; the last five being called {#CandasyA#}. E. {#apas,#} taddh.
aff. {#yat#} (or in {%Vājas.%} 10. 7. according to the quoted {%Vārttika,%}
{#ap#} in the accus. plur., taddh. aff. {#yat#}).
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-syA#}) <sup>1</sup> Activity, action. <sup>2</sup> Desire to act. E. {#apasy,#}
kṛt aff. {#a#}.
<LEND>

<L>5015<pc>182-a<k1>apaharaRa<k2>apaharaRa
{#apaharaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Taking away, carrying off, re-
moving. <sup>2</sup> (In Law.) The same as {#steya,#} stealing or rob-
bing, viz. ‘taking a thing either with, or without, the know-
ledge of the owner, by force or by stealth, or without a
valid title’; compare the following definition of the {%Mitā-%}
{%kshara:%} {#apaharaRaSabdena samakzaM parokzaM vA balAccOryeRa vA#}
{#krayAdisvatvahetuM vinA grahaRamucyate#} (and the following of {#steya#}
[Page182-b+ 56]
by {%Kātyāyana:%} {#pracCannaM vA prakASaM vA niSAyAmaTavA divA .#}
{#yatparadravyaharaRaM steyaM tatparikIrtitam;#} the term {#steya#} being
also applied, in law, to the appropriation of goods with-
out a valid title; compare e. g. the {%Dāyabhāga%} for the
definition of {#stena, ‘ya eva hi parasyedamiti viSezeRa jAnAnaH#}
{#parasve svatvahetumantareREva svatvamAropayati sa stena iti loka-#}
{#prasidDo'rTaH’#}). See also {#apahAra#}. E. {#hf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>5016<pc>182-b<k1>apaharat<k2>apaharat

comp. the preceding. E. {#hf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.

<L>5017<pc>182-b<k1>apaharaRIya<k2>apaharaRIya

<L>5018<pc>182-b<k1>apahartavya<k2>apahartavya
{#apahartavya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-vyaH-vyA-vyam#}) The same as {#apa-#}

<LEND>

<L>5019<pc>182-b<k1>apahartf<k2>apahartf
{#apahartf#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-rtA-rtrI-rtf#}) <sup>1</sup> One who takes
away, carries off, removes. <sup>2</sup> One who steals. <sup>3</sup> One who
conceals or secretes; e. g. {#nikzepasyApahartAram#} (comm. = {#ni-#}
{#kzepasyApahnotAram#}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-rtA#}) The name of a brother of the serpent Śeṣa
(according to the {%Harivanśa%} in the translation of {%Langlois%}
vol. II. p. 481). E. {#hf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#tfc#} or {#tfn#}. [N. B.
When derived with the kṛt {#tfc,#} the word merely expresses
the notion of the {%agens in general,%} as is the case with all
other derivatives of radicals by means of {#tfc;#} a noun de-
pending on it then stands in the genitive, e. g. {#nikzepasyApa-#}
{#hartA#} ‘a man who secretes a deposit’. But when derived
by means of the affix {#tfn#} it implies moreover {%habit%} and, a
noun depending on it in this sense stands in the accus., e. g.
{#annamapahartAra AhvarakA Bavanti SrAdDe sidDe sati#} ‘the in-
habitants of Ahwara are in the {%habit of carrying off%} the food
after the funeral oblation is performed’; it might seem doubt-
ful, therefore, whether e. g. the passage of the {%Dāyabhāga%}
p. 351, line 18: {#asuvarRaM suvarRabudDyApaharturna suvarRApahAraH#} is
correct and ought not to be {#asuvarRasya#} &c., the word {#apahartf#}
expressing there simply the agens without an additional
notion, as results from the comparison of these words with
p. 350. 1. 16. The word when derived by kṛt {#tfc#} is udātta
on the last syllable; but when derived by {#tfn#} udātta on the
first syllable.]
<LEND>

<L>5020<pc>182-b<k1>apahala<k2>apahala
{#apahala#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-lam#}); II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-laH-lA-lam#});
III. Avyayībh. ({#-lam#}). The same as {#apalANgala#} and like
this word, udātta on the last syllable. Comp. the remark
s. v. {#apakukzi#}. E. {#apa#} and {#hala#}.
<LEND>

<L>5021<pc>182-b<k1>apahasita<k2>apahasita
{#apahasita#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tam#}) An uneducated mode of laughing,
a manner in which low people would laugh, as ‘with tears
coming into the eyes’ ({#‘nIcAnAmapahasitam…apahasitaM#}
{#sAsrAkzam’#}); mentioned in Rhetoric as one of the {#vyaBicA-#}
{#riBAvAH#} or accessory conditions of the Comic (or {#hAsyarasa#}).
Comp. {#apahAsa#}. E. {#apa#} and {#hasita#}.
<LEND>

<L>5022<pc>182-b<k1>apahasti<k2>apahasti
{#apahasti#}¦ denom. par. ({#-stayati#}) To throw off, to lose. See
the following. E. {#apa#} and {#hasta,#} denom. aff. {#Ric#}.
<LEND>

{#hasamasya tfzRayA . tadihAnaparADini priye saKi ko'yaM karu-#}
{#RoJitakramaH ..#}. E. {#apahasti,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>5024<pc>183-a<k1>apahAna<k2>apahAna
{#apahAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) Leaving, abandoning.
For the irregular femin. in {#A,#} instead of in {#I,#} compare
{#pUrvApahARA, parApahARA#} and {#aparApahARA;#} the word itself
occurring probably only in these compounds. Comp. {#apa-#}
{#hAyana#}. E. {#hA#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

ception, exclusion. E. {#hA#} with {#apa,#} uṇ. aff. {#ni#} which is {#nit#}.

<L>5026<pc>183-a<k1>apahAyana<k2>apahAyana
{#apahAyana#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) A various reading
of the {%Kāśikā%} and of {%Bhoja%} instead of {#apahAna#} in the words
{#aparApahAyaRA#} and {#pUrvApahAyaRA#} (read in the {%Gaṇaratnam.%}
{#pUrvopahAyaRA#}); accord. to the {%Gaṇaratnam.%} it occurs also
with {%Bhoja%} in {#saMprahAyaRA#}. E. {#hA#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}
and (irregular) āgama {#yuk#}.
<LEND>

<L>5027<pc>183-a<k1>apahAra<k2>apahAra
{#apahAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Taking away, carrying off, re-
moving; also figuratively; comp. {#AtmApahAra#}. <sup>2</sup> (In Law.)
<sup>a.</sup> Stealing, robbing; see {#apaharaRa#} and the definition given
of the latter word. <sup>b.</sup> Concealing, secreting; according to
{%Jīmūtavāhana%} in the passage of the {%Dāyabhāga:%} {#na sADAraRa-#}
{#DanApahAre steyanizpattiH#} ‘the notion of theft is not completed
in a case of concealment of property common (to two or
more)’, when the word {#apahAra#} is thus explained: {#apahA-#}
{#rapadaM tu saMgopanABiprAyam . na ca saMgopanaM steyamuktam . asaM-#}
{#guptaharaRe'pi steyapadapradarSanAt#}. <sup>c.</sup> Withholding property
from its lawful owner; in the passage of the {%Dāyabhāga%}
and the {%Dāyakramasaṅgraha:%} {#strIRAM svapatidAyastu upaBo-#}
{#gaPalaH smftaH . nApahAraM striyaH kuryuH patidAyAtkaTaMcana;#} where
{%Jīmūtavāhana%} explains {#apahAra#} in this manner: {#apahAraSca#}
{#DanasvAmyanupayoge Bavati#}. (The quotation from the {%Dāyabhāga%}
by {%Rādhākāntadeva%} s. v. {#apahAra,#} viz. {#‘DanasvAmyanupayogi-#}
{#vyayaH’#}--as well as the translations which have been founded
on it--seem to arise from a mistake, the more so as the
law point in question does not concern the ‘spending’ but
‘the non-delivery to a wife of her lawful property’.) <sup>3</sup> Loss.
<sup>4</sup> (In Astronomy.) The configuration of the minor planets
considered as influencing the fortune of man; comp. {#anta-#}
{#rdaSA#} and {#apahAreSvara#}. E. {#hf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>5028<pc>183-a<k1>apahAraka<k2>apahAraka
{#apahAraka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rakaH-rikA-rakam#}) <sup>1</sup> Taking away,
carrying off, removing; also figurat., comp. {#vAgapahAraka, A-#}
{#tmApahAraka#}. <sup>2</sup> Stealing, robbing. E. {#hf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul#}.

<L>5029<pc>183-a<k1>apahAraRa<k2>apahAraRa
{#apahAraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Causing or ordering to take
away, to remove, to rob; e. g. {#svarAzwraM vAsayedrAjA parade-#}
{#SApahAraRAt . aTavA dAnamAnAByAM vAsitaM DanadaM hi tat#} ‘a
king will make his kingdom inhabitable either by the an-
nexation of other countries, or by conferring gifts or honours,
for inhabitable is a country which yields wealth’. (Various
readings in this verse of the {%Hitop.%} are {#paradeSAvagAhanAt#}
and {#paradeSApavAhanAt#}.) E. {#hf#} in the caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt
aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>5038<pc>183-b<k1>apahInakleSa<k2>apahInakleSa

from passions (affection &c.) is no obstacle (to his final
emancipation)’. E. {#apahIna#} and {#kleSa#}.

<L>5041<pc>183-b<k1>apahnava<k2>apahnava
{#apahnava#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Denial, concealment of knowledge;

<L>5042<pc>183-b<k1>apahnavavAdin<k2>apahnavavAdin
{#apahnavavAdin#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-dI#}) (In Law.) A plaintiff who
denies or conceals facts; (if the latter are proved by the
defendant, the plaintiff must pay to the king a fine equal
in amount to that of the object in litigation). E. {#apahnava#}
and {#vAdin#}.

<L>5043<pc>183-b<k1>apahnuta<k2>apahnuta

<L>5044<pc>183-b<k1>apahnuti<k2>apahnuti
{#apahnuti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Denial, concealment of knowledge.
<sup>2</sup> (In Rhetoric.) A figure of speech, one of the alamkāras
or modes of elegant expression, viz. with two varieties,
each comprising again two subdivisions: <sup>a.</sup> a hidden com-
parison, the simile being expressed by way of negation or
denial, and that part of the sentence which contains the ne-
gation or the denial either preceding or following the object
of comparison, e. g. (preceding) {#nedaM naBomaRqalamamburASirnE-#}
{#tASca tArA navaPenaBaNgAH#} &c.; or (following) {#etadviBAti cara-#}
{#mAcalacUqacumbihiRqIrapiRqaruciSItamarIcibimbam . ujjvA-#}
{#litasya rajanIM madanAnalasya DUmaM daDatprakawalAYCanakEtavena;#}
comp. also {#antargatopamA;#} <sup>b</sup> a covert expression, the in-
tended sense being conveyed either by way of a pun or by some
other artful mode of language; e. g. (by way of a pun) {#kAle#}
{#vAriDarARAmapatitayA nEva Sakyate sTAtum . utkaRwitAsi#}
{#tarale na hi na hi saKi vicCilaH panTAH#} (where the intended
[Page184-a+ 56]
sense is conveyed by the double etymology of {#apatitA#}
({#apati,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#a-patitA#} (from {#pat,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#});
or (by allusion) {#iha puro'nilakampitavigrahA milati kA na#}
{#vanaspatinA latA . smarasi kiM saKi kAntaratotsavaM na hi GanA-#}
{#gamarItirudAhftA ..#}. Comp. also {#vakrokti#}. E. {#hnu#} with {#apa,#}
kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

not ripe, said also of ulcers. <sup>2</sup> Undigested. <sup>3</sup> (ved.) Than

<L>5055<pc>184-a<k1>apAkartos<k2>apAkartos
{#apAkartos#}¦ Tatpur. (ved.) The same as {#apAkartum#} of the
classical dialect, i. e. to drive away, to remove. E. The
genitive of an obsolete noun {#apAkartu,#} the accus. of which
is alone used, as in all similar cases, in the sense of our
infinitive in the classical dialect; the native etym. expresses
this thus: {#kf#} with {#A#} and {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#tosun,#} to indicate
that the udātta accent is on {#apa#} i. e. on the first syllable.

<L>5065<pc>184-b<k1>apANktya<k2>apANktya

<LEND>

<L>5066<pc>184-b<k1>apANktyopahata<k2>apANktyopahata

ciety. E. {#apANktya#} and {#upahata#}.

<L>5067<pc>184-b<k1>apANga<k2>apANga
{#apANga#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-NgaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The outer corner of the eye.
(In Medicine mentioned amongst the {#marman#} or vital parts
above the clavicle.) <sup>2</sup> A sectarian mark on the forehead,
made with coloured and fragrant pigments, as with saffron,
Sandal &c.; comp. {#patrAvalI#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-NgaH-NgA#} or {#NgI-Ngam#}) Maimed,
crippled. E. {#apa#} and {#aNga;#} the Tatpur. being explained:
{#apagato'NgAt#}. The femin. of the Bahuvr. is either {#wAp#}
or {#NIz#} according to {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 1. 54. v. 1.; and the same
remark applies to {#apANga#} when it is a latter part of a
Bahuvr. compound; the rule IV. 1. 56. not being to the con-
trary, since it merely concerns uncompounded words of
several syllables, in the sense of {#svANga#} q. v.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-NgaH#}) A name of Kāma. E. {#apa#} and {#aNga#}.
<LEND>

taddh. aff. {#kan#}. (In the latter derivation it may also ex-
press the same as {#apANga#} I.; and as a Bahuvr. {#apa-aNga,#}
samās. aff. {#kap#} (fem. {#apANgikA#}), the same as {#apANga#} II.)

<L>5073<pc>185-a<k1>apAc<k2>apAc

{#udac, pratIc’#} are a complete enumeration of the four re-

<L>5088<pc>185-b<k1>apAdAna<k2>apAdAna
{#apAdAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Taking away. <sup>2</sup> (In Gram-
mar.) The sense expressed by the fifth case or ablative;
viz. ‘the point of departure in connexion with the notion of
separation; the cause of fear in connexion with the notion
of fear, protecting from; the object not bearable in con-
nexion with the notion of being overpowered by; the object
protected in connexion with that of withholding from; the
object shunned or abandoned in connexion with that of hid-
ing one's self from, being disgusted with, desisting from; the
object deviated from in connexion with that of deviating from;
the source of knowlege (teacher &c.) in connexion with that of
learning from; birth, origin in connexion with the notion of
descent, coming from’. E. {#dA#} with {#A#} and {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<div n="P">II. Cutting off; in the following passage of the {%Jaiminīya-%}
{%nyāyamālāvistara%} where the word is used in the same sense
as {#avadAna,#} apparently only for the sake of distinguishing the
second cutting off ({#pUrvArDAdavadyati#}) from the first {#(maDyAdava-#}
{#dyati): darSapUrRamAsayoH puroqASAvadAne SrUyate . maDyAdavadyati .#}
{#pUrvArDAdavadyatIti . tadyadyavattaM naSyeta . tadAnImavaSizwAtpu-#}
{#roqASAtpunarapyavadAtavyam . kutaH . avadAnApAdAnayormaDya-#}
{#pUrvArDayoH Sizwe'pi saMBavAditi cet .. mEvam . kftsnapuroqA-#}
{#Sagate maDyapUrvArDe apAdAnatvena SrUyete . na tvavaSizwaBAgagate#}
{#maDyapUrvArDe .#} &c. E. {#do#} with {#A#} and {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>5091<pc>185-b<k1>apADvan<k2>apADvan
{#apADvan#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-DvA#}) A bad road; (the word is udātta

<L>5092<pc>185-b<k1>apAna<k2>apAna
{#apAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) <sup>1</sup> The air which goes downwards; in
the Vedas, in the doctrine of the Upanishads as well as in
the philosophical and medical systems, the air (comp. {#vAta,#}
{#vAyu#}) which is {%inhaled%} and {%descends%} the body, one of the
[Page186-a+ 56]
five vital airs which are supposed to pervade the latter; (op-
posed to {#prARa,#} the air which is {%exhaled%} or {%proceeds%} from the
body; comp. besides {#udAna, samAna, vyAna#} and see {#ana#}); in
the legend of the {%Aitareya Upan.%} it is therefore this vital air
which is able to seize food, (for it introduces it into the body),
and to give support to life; comp. {#annAyu#}. In the {%Śatapath.%}
and {%Bṛhadār. Upan.%} it is called, from the same reason, the
function of {%smelling%} (and the odour {%inhaled%}): {#prARo vE grahaH#}
{#so'pAnenAtigrAheRa gfhIto'pAnena hi ganDaM jiGrati#}. In the
{%Vedānta-Sāra%} it is defined: {#apAno nAmAvAggamanavAnpAyvA-#}
{#disTAnavartI#} (comm. {#aDo nABeraDastAdgamanavAnmalAdyAnayana-#}
{#vyApAreRa . pAyurgudam . tatsTAnavartItyarTaH . AdiSabdAdupasTagra-#}
{#haH . tatrApi mUtraretovisargasyApAnakarmatvAt#}); in the {%Sāṅkhya%} it
is like the other four vital airs the function which is common
to {#budDi, ahaNkAra#} and {#manas#} qq. vv. ({%Sāṅkhya prav.%} {#sAmAnyaka-#}
{#raRavfttiH prARAdyA vAyavaH paYca#}) and explained by the comm.
{#apanayanAdapAnastatra yatsyandanaM tadapi sAmAnyavfttirindriyasya#}.
In the {%Kaṇāda-Sūtra%} {#prARApAnanimezonmeza°°#} it is explained
as having the property of {#aDogamanaM PutkArAdO vA tiryagga-#}
{#manam#}. This theory is then more fully developed in {%Su-%}
{%śruta's Nidānasthāna%} where the {%inhaled vital air%} ‘resides in
the rectum and in time {%draws down%} the excrements, urine,
semen, fœtus and menses’ ({#pakvADAnAlayo'pAnaH kAle#}
{#karzati cApyayam . samIraRaH SakfnmUtraSukragarBArtavAnyaDaH#}), and
‘when obstructed by bile produces burning, heat and a little
blood, when obstructed by phlegm, heaviness in the lower
part of the body’ ({#apAne pittasaMyukte dAhOzRye syAdasfgda-#}
{#ram . aDaHkAye gurutvaM ca tasminneva kaPAvfte#}). Comp. also the
following from the musical work {%Saṅgītadarpaṇa:%} {#prARApA-#}
{#nO taTA vyAnasamAnodAnasaMjYakAH . nAgaM kUrmaM ca kfkalaM devadattaM#}
{#DanaMjayam#} (sic, neuter; comp. these latter words in the {%Vedānta-%}
{%Sāra%} p. 9) {#. tezAM muKyatamaH prARo nABikanDAdaDaH sTitaH .#}
{#SabdoccAraRaniHSvAsocCvAsakAsAdikAraRam . apAnastu gude#}
{#meQre kawIjaNGodare taTA . vyAno'kziSrotragulPezu kawyAM GrARe ca#}
{#tizWati . samAno vyApya niKilaM SarIraM vahninA saha . udAnaH#}
{#pAdayorAste hastayoraNgasaMDizu . tvagAdiDAtUnASritya paYca nA-#}
{#gAdayaH sTitAH#}.--An improvement on Suśruta seems to have
been intended by {%Hemachandra%} who makes the {#apAna#} run
down from the nape of the neck to the {%heels%} ({#apAnapavano#}
{#manyApfzWapfzWAntapArzRigaH;#} comm. {#pfzWAnto gudaH . pArzRI pAdapa-#}
{#ScAdBAgO#}). <sup>2</sup> A fart. <sup>3</sup> The anus. E. {#an#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>5093<pc>186-a<k1>apAnat<k2>apAnat
{#apAnat#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-n-tI-t#}) Inhaling, producing the
function of the vital air {#apAna#} q. v.--In the verse of the
{%Bhāgav. Pur.%} (2. 10. 16.) {#anu prARanti yaM prARAH prARantaM sarva-#}
{#jantuzu . apAnantamapAnanti naradevamivAnugAH,#} it deserves no-
tice that {%Srīdharasvāmin%} takes the word {#apAnat#} in the sense
‘ceasing to perform vital functions’, viz. ‘they (according to
the comm., the senses) cease to exercise their functions when
it (the vital air {#prARa#}) ceases to perform its function’: {#prARA#}
{#indriyARi yaM#} (scil. {#prARaM,#} the word of the preceding verse)
{#prARantaM cezwAM kurvantamanu paScAtprARanti cezwAM kurvanti . apAnantaM#}
{#cezwAM tyajantamanu apAnanti cezwAM tyajanti . rAjAnamanu BftyA iva;#}
but it seems very doubtful whether he is correct in this con-
struction of the verse, as {#prARAH#} might be taken in the
general sense ‘vital airs’, and the sense ‘they perform the
function of exhaling and inhaling according to the function
[Page186-b+ 56]
of life ({#prARa#})’ would be in conformity with the usual mean-
ing of the words in question. E. {#an#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<LEND>

<L>5101<pc>186-b<k1>apAntaratama<k2>apAntaratama

<L>5102<pc>186-b<k1>apAntaratamas<k2>apAntaratamas
{#apAntaratamas#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-mAH#}) The name of an ancient
Ṛṣi, who in a subsequent birth became, according to the
legend, the Vedavyāsa or Kṛṣṇadvaipāyana. ({%Śaṅkara%}
in his comm. on a {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#apAntaratamA nAma vedA-#}
{#cAryaH purARarzirvizRuniyogAtkalidvAparayoH saMDO kfzRadvEpA-#}
{#yanaH saMbaBUveti smaranti#}.) E. {#apa#} and {#antara-tamas,#} lit. ‘free
from interior darkness’.
<LEND>

<L>5103<pc>186-b<k1>apAnnapAt<k2>apAnnapAt
{#apAnnapAt#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-t#}) (ved.) An epithet or name of
Agni (fire) and Savitri (sun).--{%Sāyaṇa%} explains this word
as meaning literally either ‘not protecting ({#na-pAt,#} from
{#pA,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}) or not allowing to fall down ({#na-pAt#}
from the caus. of {#pat,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}) the waters’, fire or
sun drying up the water; or ‘the grandson of the waters’,
water bringing forth plants and trees, and plants and trees
being the cause of fire; the latter explanation, apparently
more congenial with the vaidik poetry than the former, is
also given by {%Yāska.%} Comp. {#ap#} and {#apAnnaptf#}. [The word has
two accents, viz. the udātta on the second and third syllable
and is given by the Padatext of the Ṛgveda as representing
not a compound, but two distinct words; that it may be
analyzed so, is indubitable from passages where it occurs
e. g. in the form {#napAtamapAm#}. On the other hand it must be ob-
served that the double accent belongs also to other and similar
Tatpur. mentioned in the {%Gaṇa%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 2. 140. (comp. e. g.
{#tanUnapAt#}) and that this Gaṇa would comprise more words
than those mentioned in the present edition of Pāṇ. and the
ordinary Gaṇa lists as well as in the Kāśikā, if we may believe
the {%Svaramañjarī%} of {%Nṛsinha,%} which mentions e. g. {#Sukagra-#}
{#nTinO#} (not referring this word to VI. 2. 141.) and concludes
with {#ityAdi;#} it may be observed too, that the {%Nighanṭu%}
mentions {#apAnnapAt#} as {%one%} of the thirty-two {#pada#} enumerated
V. 4., and that {%Sāyaṇa%} in his comm. cannot have looked
upon it otherwise than as a compound when he writes e. g.
{#apAMnapAtsaMjYako'gniH;#} comp. also the remark of {%Patanjali%}
s. v. {#apAnnaptf#}. The genitive {%plur.%} as a former part of a com-
pound, is of rare occurrence, but met with also in other
[Page187-a+ 56]
compounds beginning with {#apAm,#} e. g. {#apAMvatsa, apAnnATa,#}
{#apAmpati#} &c. and in the Tatpur. {#devAnAMpriya#} ({%Pāṇini%} VI. 3. 21.
{%Vārtt.%} 4.). E. {#apAm#} (gen. plur. of {#ap#}) and {#napAt#}.
<LEND>

<L>5104<pc>187-a<k1>apAnnaptf<k2>apAnnaptf
{#apAnnaptf#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ptA#}) The grandson of the Waters, a
vaidik epithet or name of Agni (see the explanation given
s. v. {#apAnnapAt#}); but {%Sāyaṇa%} distinguishes on one occasion
the sacrificial fire from the {#apAnnaptf#} whom he then calls the
Fire of the lightning as being the {%son%} of the rain-waters.
Comp. {#ap#} and {#aponaptf#}. [In the vaidik hymns this word does
not occur as a compound; but that it must have been con-
sidered as such in the ritual literature results from the deri-
vatives {#apAnnaptriya#} and {#apAnnaptrIya#}. {%Patanjali%} in his com-
ment on the latter forms ({%Pāṇ.%} IV. 2. 28.) denies the correct-
ness of a combination {#apAMnaptf#} and assumes that the ending
{#f#} of the latter word merely exists before the affixes in
question, while otherwise the word would be {#apAnnapAt;#}
{%Kaiyyaṭa,%} however, admits of such a combination in the
Vedas. {%Mahābhāṣya%} to {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 2. 28.: {#aTa yadaponaptriya-#}
{#mapAMnaptriyaM vA haviH . kaTaM tasya prEzaH kartavyaH . aponapAte#}
{#'nubrUhi . apAMnapAte'nubrUhi . aponaptrapAMnaptfBAvaH#} (the Ms.
of the E. I. H. No. 330 reads wrongly {#aponaptfpAMnaBAvaH#})
{#kasmAnna Bavati . pratyayasaMniyogena fkArAntatvamucyate . tenA-#}
{#sati pratyaye na Bavitavyam ..;#} but {%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#aTeti . vede kva-#}
{#cidaponaptre svAheti fkArAntaH prayogo dfSayate . kvacidapo-#}
{#napAditi takArAntaH prayoga iti praSnaH . pratyayasaMniyogeneti .#}
{#vede tu cCAndasatvAtkvacidfkArAntayogaH#} (the Ms.: {#CAndasatvA-#}
{#tkaccidfkArAntayogaH#}).] E. {#apAm#} (gen. plur. of {#ap#}) and {#naptf#}.
<LEND>

<L>5115<pc>187-b<k1>apAmArga<k2>apAmArga
{#apAmArga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rgaH#}) The name of a plant (Achyranthes
aspera) which is employed for sacrificial purposes, it being
supposed to have the power of removing sins, and also as
a medicament; it has three varieties: the white, the red and
the water-Apāmārga. The white variety is described as ‘a
little pungent, hot, bitterish, astringent or constipating,
emetic, pungent (sic), increasing the digestion, or stomachic,
and applied against diseases from phlegm, the itch, piles,
diseases of the stomach, of the blood, of serous secretions,
of the vital airs, against cutaneous eruptions, leprosy, in-
dolent tumors and nausea’--; the red variety is ‘a little
pungent, cold, constipating, emetic, obstructing the circu-
lation of the vital air, and rough; it is employed against
diseases from phlegm and of the vital airs, against ulcers,
itch, and poison; its seed or fruit is cold, sweet, indiges-
tive whether raw or cooked, constipating, causing flatulency,
rough, emetic and good for cough and hemorrhages from
the mouth, nose, rectum and cuticle’; the water-variety is
‘pungent and used against pulmonary consumption, swell-
ings, diseases from phlegm and of the vital airs, and against
cough’.--The ashes of the plant are used in cleaning linen.
E. {#mfj#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY,#} the final vowel of the prefix
being lengthened; (or according to {%Bhānud.%} on the {%Amarak.,%}
a Bahuvr. {#apa#} and {#A-mArga; ‘apamArjantyanena…, apa-#}
{#kfzwa AsamantAnmArgo'syeti vA’;#} but according to {%Rāyam.%}
only the former: {#‘apamfjanti vastrAdikamanena’;#} and equally
so the {%Siddhāntak.%} {#‘apamfjyate'nena vyADAdiH’,#} and the {%Kā-%}
{%śikā%} which quotes {#apAmArga,#} besides {#vImArga#} as an instance
to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 3. 122.).
<LEND>

<L>5116<pc>187-b<k1>apAmArjana<k2>apAmArjana
{#apAmArjana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Cleansing, wiping off; figur.
removing, as diseases &c.; {#apAmArjanastotra#} is the name of

{#mfj#} with {#A#} and {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>5117<pc>187-b<k1>apAmpati<k2>apAmpati
{#apAmpati#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> The ocean. <sup>2</sup> A name of Va-
ruṇa, the regent of the waters. <sup>3</sup> (In Astronomy.) The
twenty-fifth of the Nakshatra or lunar mansions; compare
also {#SataBizA#}. <sup>4</sup> (In Astronomy.) The thirteenth of the
sixty degrees into which each of the twelve signs of the
zodiac is subdivided.--Comp. also {#appati#}. E. {#apAm#} (gen.
plur. of {#ap#}) and {#pati#}.
<LEND>

<L>5119<pc>187-b<k1>apAya<k2>apAya
{#apAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Going away, passing away; e. g.
in the {%Mīm. Sūtra:%} {#anapAyaSca kAlasya lakzaRaM hi puroqASe;#} or
in the {%Sāṅkhya S.%} {#pUrvApAya uttarAyogAt#} (comm. {#pUrvasya kA-#}
{#raRasyApAyakAla uttarasya kAryasyotpattyanOcityAt#}); comp. also
the instance which follows meaning 3. <sup>2</sup> Separation, disunion;
e. g. in the {%Bhaṭṭik.%} {#sarvatra dayitADInaM suvyaktaM rAmaRIyakam . yena#}
{#jAtaM priyApAye kadvadaM haMsakokilam;#} comp. also the following
instance. <sup>3</sup> Absence, disappearance; e. g. in the {%Nalodaya:%}
{#tadvAsaH svApAyAM nItiriyaM ceti vipadi sasvApAyAm . ni-#}
{#javAsaHsvApAyAnnikftya tAmamuYcadiha sasvApAyAm#} ‘(Nalus)
thinking he acted rightly in his misery, abandoned her there
[Page188-a+ 56]
(in the forest) when she was asleep, deprived of her own [in-
stance to meaning 2.], her (good luck) having departed from
her [instance to meaning 1.], after having torn (her garment)
in the absence of garment or property of his own (comm.:
{#nijaM svakIyaM yadvAsaH svaM ca DanaM tadapAyAt tadapagamAt#}); or
{#saMniyogaSizwAnAmanyatarApAya uBayorapyapAyaH#} (in which {%Pa-%}
{%ribh.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 4. 153. the E. I. H. Ms. No. 326. of the {%Ma-%}
{%hābhāṣya%} reads however both times {#aBAva#} instead of {#a-#}
{#pAya#}); or {%Mahābhāṣya%} (introd.): {#apAyo lopaH . Gnanti Gnantu#}
{#aGnan . varRApAyo nArTApAyaH#}. <sup>4</sup> Loss; e. g. in the {%Hitop.%}
{#yatrApAyaH saMBavati tatropAyo'pyasti#}. <sup>5</sup> Destruction, cessa-
tion; e. g. in the {%Nyāya S.%} {#duHKajanmapravfttidozamiTyAjYAnA-#}
{#nAmuttarottarApAye tadanantarApAyAdapavargaH#}. <sup>6</sup> Death; e. g. in
the {%Bhaṭṭik.%} {#banDUnaSaNkizwa samAkulatvAdAseduzaH snehavaSAdapA-#}
{#yam#}. <sup>7</sup> Misfortune, calamity, evil; e. g. in the {%Nalod.%} {#aTa#}
{#tuNgopAyasya SravaRena nalasya sAnugo'pAyasya…svamano BI-#}
{#maSciraM jugopa;#} (comm. {#nalasya apAyasyApakramaRasya duHKasya vA#}
{#SravaRena#}). E. {#i (iR)#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>5120<pc>188-a<k1>apAyin<k2>apAyin
{#apAyin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yI-yinI-yi#}) <sup>1</sup> Going away, de-
parting. <sup>2</sup> Perishing, transitory; e. g. in the {%Sāṅkhya S.%}

<L>5121<pc>188-a<k1>apAra<k2>apAra
{#apAra#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-ram#}) 1. The opposite bank of a river;
the same as {#pAra;#} comp. also {#avAra#}. E. See s. v. {#pAra#}.
<div n="P">2. (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) <sup>1</sup> A technical term to
denote that kind of mental acquiescence or indifference which
arises from the reflection that sensual objects perish in con-
sequence of enjoyment and that there is a feeling of pain
or trouble when they perish; some call this kind of ac-
quiescence {#sunetra,#} and others {#pArapAra#} (the latter word writ-
ten thus in the Calc. ed. of the comm. of the {%Sāṅkhya-%}
{%pravachana%} and in the E. I. H. Ms. 2668; in {%Wilson'%}s ed.
of the {%Sāṅkhya-Kārikā%} {#pArApAra#}); it is among the nine
kinds of acquiescence or {#tuzwi#} (q. v.) one of the five called
{#vAhya#} or acquiescences relating to exterior objects. [{%Wilson%}
in his comment on the Kārikā (page 155) renders the literal
meaning of this word ‘shoreless’, taking it therefore as a
Bahuvr.; but it seems to me that the compound terms of
this category, enumerated s. v. {#anuttamAmBas,#} are all Tat-
pur., the simile inhering to these terms being taken from
the notion of ‘water’ or ‘opposite shore’, and the dif-
ferent mode in which the former is expressed ({#amBas, sa-#}
{#lila, oGa, vfzwi#}) as well as the qualification conveyed by
the former part of the compound terms ({#supAra, uttamAmBas#}
&c.) being intended to express the higher or lower degree
of the various acquiescences, none of which is conducive
to final emancipation; the literal meaning of {#apAra#} would
therefore be, in my opinion, ‘a bad or undesirable opposite
shore’. In the list of {%Gaurapāda%} which differs from that of
the other comm., the correctness of the term {#sunetra#} seems
to me, for the reasons given, doubtful, unless {#netra#} is to be
connected there with the sense of {#netrI#} ‘river’.] <sup>2</sup> The re-
verse of the technical Sāṅkhya term {#pAra,#} i. e. <sup>a.</sup> non-ac-
quiescence or not being indifferent through not reflecting
that pain or trouble arises from the {%preservation%} of sensual
objects when they have been acquired; or <sup>b.</sup> non-acquiescence
[Page188-b+ 56]
through not reflecting that {%acquiring%} sensual objects causes
trouble or pain; (the term {#pAra#} being used by {%Gaurapāda%}
in the former, by {%Vāchaspati, Vijnānāchārya%} &c. in the
latter sense); it is amongst the seventeen {#budDibaDa#} or ob-
structions of intellect one of the nine which are the converse
of the {#tuzwi#} or acquiescences. E. {#a#} 1. deter., 2. neg. and {#pAra#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Shoreless, unbounded,
boundless, illimitable. E. {#a#} priv. and {#pAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>5122<pc>188-b<k1>apAraka<k2>apAraka
{#apAraka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rakaH-rikA-rakam#}) Incompetent,
incapable; comp. {#apArayat#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pAraka#}.
<LEND>

<L>5123<pc>188-b<k1>apArapAra<k2>apArapAra
{#apArapAra#}¦ Tatpur. I. n. ({#-ram#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.)
The reverse of {#pArapAra#} (see the remark s. v. {#apAra#} I. 2.),
a technical term to denote the non-acquiescence or non-in-
difference through not reflecting that since a sensual object
perishes in consequence of enjoyment, pain or trouble arises
from its cessation; it is amongst the seventeen {#budDibaDa#} (q. v.)
or obstructions of intellect one of the nine which are the
converse of the {#tuzwi#} or acquiescences. According to others the
term would be {#anapAra#} or {#asunetra#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pArapAra#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-raH#}) The farthest bound of that which is illimi-
table, an epithet of Viṣṇu; e. g. {#pAraM paraM vizRurapArapAraH#}
{#paraM pareByaH paramArTarUpI . sa brahmapAraH parapAraBUtaH paraH parA-#}
{#RAmapi pArapAraH ..#}. (See the explanation of this verse by
{%Wilson%} in his {%Viṣṇup.%} p. 113, note 3.) E. {#apAra#} II. and {#pAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>5130<pc>188-b<k1>apArTa<k2>apArTa
{#apArTa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rTaH-rTA-rTam#}) <sup>1</sup> Purposeless, useless;

deed). <sup>2</sup> Meaningless; e. g. {#apArTavAc#}. Comp. the following.

<L>5131<pc>188-b<k1>apArTaka<k2>apArTaka
{#apArTaka#}¦ Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-rTakaH-rTikA-rTakam#}) The same as
{#apArTa;#} <sup>1</sup> Purposeless, useless. <sup>2</sup> Disinterested, without a
selfish motive; e. g. in the {%Sāṅkhyakār.%} {#nAnAviDErupAyEru-#}
{#pakAriRyanupakAriRaH puMsaH . guRavatyaguRasya satastasyArTamapArTakaM#}
{#carati#} (scil. {#prakftiH#}). <sup>3</sup> Meaningless; e. g. in the {%Kāśikā%} on
{%Pāṇ.%} VII. 2. 58. {#tataH parasmEpadezviti niyamArTaH . sa ca niyamo#}
{#yadyaviSezeRa syAtpUrvo yogo'pArTakaH syAt#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-kam#}) (In the Nyāya philos.) One of the twenty-
[Page189-a+ 56]
two {#nigrahasTAna#} or failures in argument which lead to defeat
in controversy; viz. speech which is incoherent from want
of a causal nexus between what precedes and follows, al-
though the single sentences or words, may give a sense,
if taken individually; (it is different therefore from the {#ni-#}
{#grahasTAna#} which is called {#nirarTaka#} q. v.); {#‘pOrvAparyAyogAda-#}
{#pratisaMbadDArTamapArTakam’#}. E. {#apa#} and {#arTa,#} samās. aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>5132<pc>189-a<k1>apArTavAc<k2>apArTavAc
{#apArTavAc#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-k#}) Unmeaning speech, nonsensical
discourse. E. {#apArTa#} and {#vAc#}.
<LEND>

<L>5133<pc>189-a<k1>apAla<k2>apAla
{#apAla#}¦ Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-laH-lA-lam#}) Unprotected; e. g.

<L>5134<pc>189-a<k1>apAlaNka<k2>apAlaNka
{#apAlaNka#}¦ Tatpur. (?) m. ({#-NkaH#}) A plant (Cassia fistula).--
The word is udātta on the last syllable. E.? (The {%Sid-%}
{%dhāntakaum.%} in its chapter, the {#PiwsUtra,#} gives the word
only in its crude form, whence the masc. gender could not
be established; in the E. I. H. Ms. No. 98 of these Sūtras
the comm. writes once {#apAlaNkA#} and another time {#apAlaNkaH,#}
the latter being probably the correct form, to judge from the
synonymes and the form {#pAlaNka#} which seems kindred to it.)
<LEND>

<L>5135<pc>189-a<k1>apAlana<k2>apAlana

the {%Prātisākhya%} of the {%Ṛgveda.%}

<L>5143<pc>189-a<k1>apAvfta<k2>apAvfta

kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

kṛt aff. {#kta,#} the final vowel of the prefix being lengthened
(according to the Pada text of the {%Ṛgveda%}).
[Page189-b+ 56]
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Independent, self-
willed, unrestrained. E. {#apa#} and {#Avfta#} ({%Rāyamuk.%} on the
{%Amarak.:%} {#apagatamAvftamasvatantratvamasya;#} {%Bhanūd.%} on the same:
{#apagatamAvftamAvaraRamasya#}).

<L>5148<pc>189-b<k1>apASraya<k2>apASraya
{#apASraya#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A support, a recipient, the
person on which another reposes, as it were, by whom he
is protected; e. g. {#brAhmaRApASrayo nityamutkfzwAM jAtimaSnute#}
(scil. {#SUdraH#}) ‘a Śūdra who is supported by a Brahmaṇa
obtains always a superior birth’; (speculation has been rife
on this passage of {%Manu%} 9. 335.: both Calc. editions read
{#brAhmaRAyASrayo#}--which is meaningless--, another reading
is {#brAhmaRopASrayo,#} and the correctness of the word {#apASraya#}
in this verse has been even doubted; but it occurs and is
commented upon in the same sense ‘recipient, support’ e. g.
in the {%Bhāgavata Pur.%} VI. 19. 12. where Viṣṇu is contrasted
with Śrī:) {#tvaM hi sarvaSarIryAtmA SrIH SarIrendriyASayAH . nA-#}
{#marUpe BagavatI pratyayastvamapASrayaH#} (comm. {#pratyayo nAmarUpayoH#}
{#prakASaH . apASrayaH . tayorADAraH#}); i. e. ‘…thou
makest them manifest and thou art their recipient or sup-
port’.--Comp. also {#apASrita#}. <sup>2</sup> That which rests upon; (used
in this sense {%Daśakumārach.%} ed. {%Wilson%} p. 90, 1. 13, where the
word implies the meaning ‘head’ as resting on the hand).
<sup>3</sup> An awning spread over a court or yard. E. {#Sri#} with {#A#}
and {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Unsupported, helpless.
E. {#apa#} and {#ASraya#}.
<LEND>

{%rasw.%} {#apASritaH pfzWato'vazwabDaH#}). <sup>2</sup> Having recourse to, ap-

<L>5156<pc>190-a<k1>apAsarat<k2>apAsarat
{#apAsarat#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-n-ntI-t#}) Going away; e. g.
with the intention of defrauding, absconding: {#miTyAvadanpa-#}
{#rImARaM SulkasTAnAdapAsaran . dApyastvazwaguRaM yaSca savyAjakraya-#}
{#vikrayI,#} (in which verse of {%Yājnav.,%} 2. 262., the Calc. 8<sup>vo</sup> ed.
of the {%Vyavahāra%} section of the {%Mitākṣara%} has omitted to
correct the misprint {#apAsarat#} although it is corrected in
the 4<sup>to</sup> edition; the {%Vivādachint.%} (p. 81, 1. 18), however, reads
in this verse {#apAkraman#} instead of {#apAsaran,#} which word
would correspond in its strangeness with the quotation of
the same work (p. 81, 1. 21) from {%Viṣṇu:%} {#SulkasTAnamanA-#}
{#kraman;#} but as the Calc. edition of {%Viṣṇu'%}s {%Sanhitā%} (fol. 3 {%a,%}
1. 6) reads {#SulkasTAnamapakrAman,#} it is more likely that {#apA-#}
{#kraman;#} and {#anAkraman#} are blunders of the editor than ar-
chaisms of Yājnavalkya and Viṣṇu. The E. I. H. Mss. of
the {%Mit.%} read {#apAsaran#}). E. {#sf#} with {#apa,#} the final vowel
of the prefix being lengthened, or perhaps {#sf#} with {#A#} and
{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<LEND>

<L>5158<pc>190-a<k1>apAsita<k2>apAsita
{#apAsita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Thrown about, scat-

{#lApAsitayA veRyA BEmI yutA lalApAsitayA . nfpa sakalApA-#}
{#sitayA hatvArInbAnDavAnkilApAsi tayA,#} the comm. has
subjected the first compound to the following torture: it
may mean according to him as an attribute of {#veRI#} ‘braided
hair’: <sup>a.</sup> scattered about through the force of running (= {#DA-#}
{#vanabalena vistftayA#}); or <sup>b.</sup> having lost its resting-place through
the force of running (when {#apAsita#} is a Bahuvr. of {#apa#}
and {#AsitA,#} the latter being {#Asin,#} taddh. aff. {#tal;#}
{#= apagatA AsitA upaveSanatvaM yasyAH sA#}); or <sup>c</sup> having lost
its existence through the force of running (when {#apAsita#}
is a Bahuvr. of {#apa#} and {#asitA;#} the latter coming from
{#asin,#} taddh. aff. {#tal; = apagatA vidyamAnatA yasyAH sA#});
or not as an attribute of {#veRI#} and coming from {#vega-bala-#}
{#Apa-asi,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} ‘through the effect of having a
sword which possesses speed and power’; the second com-
pound in this verse, viz. {#sakalApAsitayA#} is explained by
[Page190-b+ 56]
him as the instrum. of {#sakala-apAsitA,#} the latter being
{#apAsi#} q. v., taddh. aff. {#tal:#} ‘through all (scil. enemies)
having lost their sword’.] E. {#as#} (cl. 4.) in the caus., with
{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
