<L>5953<pc>239-b<k1>aBicakzaRa<k2>aBicakzaRa
{#aBicakzaRa#}¦ Tatpur. I. n. ({#-Ram#}) (ved.) (Probably.) A magic
power, a magic remedy; (comp. {#saj#} with {#aBi, aBizakta,#}
{#aBizaNga, Bizakti, Bizaj#}); {%Atharvav.:%} {#yO te balAsa tizWataH#}
{#kakze muzkAvapaSritO . vedAhaM tasya BezajaM SIpudruraBicakzaRam#}.
E. {#cakz#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-RaH-RA-Ram#}) (ved.) (Probably.) Indicating,
pointing out, making clear; {%Atharvav.:%} {#yAvatIrdiSaH pradiSo#}
{#vizUcIryAvatIrASA aBicakzaRA divaH#} &c. E. {#cakz#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#yuc#}. (This would be the E. according to
{%Pāṇ.%} III. 2. 149., when the word must form a fem. in {#A,#}
and be udātta on the last syllable; but if the present ed.
of the {%Atharv.%} is correct, there is an irregularity in the ac-
centuation, for the word is udātta on the third syllable,
i. e. it is accentuated like the neuter, formed with {#lyuw,#}
although the fem. is not in {#I;#} but perhaps the aff. is {#lyu#}.)
<LEND>

<L>5954<pc>239-b<k1>aBicakzya<k2>aBicakzya

where, to be praised, praiseworthy; e. g. {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Sāmav.:%}

<L>5955<pc>239-b<k1>aBicara<k2>aBicara

aff. {#ac;#} ({#cara#} being {#wit,#} the femin. would be {#aBicarI#}).
<LEND>

<L>5957<pc>239-b<k1>aBicaraRIya<k2>aBicaraRIya

<L>5959<pc>239-b<k1>aBicaritavE<k2>aBicaritavE

on the second and on the last syllable.) E. {#car#} with {#aBi,#}

<L>5960<pc>240-a<k1>aBicaritos<k2>aBicaritos

lent purpose (= {#aBicaritum#}); e. g. {%Kāśikā:%} {#ISvaro'Bi-#}

genitive of an obsolete base {#aBicaritu#} with the udātta on
the second syllable; comp. the preceding).
<LEND>

<L>5961<pc>240-a<k1>aBicAra<k2>aBicAra
{#aBicAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) Incantation, employment of charms
or spells for a malevolent purpose.--The {%Shaḍvinśa-Brā-%}
{%hmaṇa%} names as such purposes: killing an enemy and de-
priving him of his cattle or property; it gives an account
of four sacrifices which are performed for the attainment
of these objects, (see {#Syena, trivfdagnizwoma, saMdaMSa#} and {#vajra#})
and describes the manner in which the mantras are to be
recited at these sacrifices; (see {#vizwuti#}).--The {%Tantrasāra%}
(as quoted by {%Rādhākāntad.%}) names six purposes of incan-
tation, viz. causing death ({#mAraRa#}), mental aberration ({#mo-#}
{#hana#}), stoppage of the bodily functions ({#stamBana#}), hatred ({#vi-#}
{#dvezaRa#}), ruin ({#uccAwana#}) and submission ({#vaSIkaraRa#}). [Comp.
e. g. also the following passage from the {%Skanda-Purāṇa:%}
{#kuSErvA dUrvayA devi Asane SuBrakambale . upaviSya tato devi#}
{#japedekAgramAnasaH#} (scil. {#gurugItAm#}) {#. SuklAsane vE SAntyarTe#}
{#'vaSye raktAsanaM priye . aBicAre kfzRavarRaM pItavarRaM DanAgame .#}
{#uttare SAntijApyasyAvaSye pUrvamuKoditam . dakziRe mAraRaM#}
{#proktaM stamBane paScime muKam . mohanaM sarvaBUtAnAM banDamokzakaraM#}
{#param . devaBUpapriyakaraM rAjAnaM vaSamAnayet#} &c.]--{%Suśruta%}
speaks of a variety of fever caused by incantation (see {#a-#}
{#BicArajvara#} and comp. {#aBizaNgajvara#}), the symptoms of
which are, according to the {%Nighaṇṭa Prakāśa,%} thirst,
mental aberration, abscesses, delirium, fainting, anguish,
excessive heat &c.--{%Manu%} (likewise Viṣṇu &c.) when
speaking of incantations (9. 290.) makes a distinction between
{#aBicAra, mUlakarman#} and various {#kftyA;#} the former com-
prises, according to {%Medhātithi%} and {%Kullūka%} as well incan-
tations founded on vaidik writings ({#vEdika#} or {#SAstrIya,#}
such as the Śyena &c.), as those founded on vulgar super-
stition ({#lOkika,#} such as taking the dust of the feet, digging
in needles--{#sUcIniKanana#} in the E. I. H. Mss. of {%Medh.%} being
apparently a better reading than {#mUlaniKanana#} in the present edd.
of {%Kull.%}--&c.) for the purpose of {%causing death;%} {#mUlakarman#} is,
according to both comm., {%subduing%} a person by means of
mantras, drugs &c. ({%Kull.:%} {#mantrOzaDAdinA;#} {%Medh.:%} {#mantrA-#}
{#dikriyayA#}); the {#kftyA#} are, according to {%Kullūka,%} incantations
for the sake of {%causing ruin, making sick%} &c., according to
{%Medh.,%} for the sake of {%causing ruin, animosity between friends%}
{%or relatives, working wonders%} &c. ({#uccAwanasuhfdbanDukalahavici-#}
{#trIkaraRAdihetavaH#}).--{%Manu%} fines a person who employs
charms two hundred Paṇas (9. 290.), classes in another pas-
sage {#aBicAra#} and {#mUlakarman#} amongst the Upapātaka (11. 63.)
and makes the expiation of an {#aBicAra#} depend on the per-
formance, thrice repeated, of the penance called Kṛchchhra
(11. 197.). But as these clauses would jar apparently with
the vaidik texts which impliedly sanction the employment
of charms by regulating the sacrifices Śyena &c. performed
for incantatory purposes, {%Kullūka%} qualifies the definition of
Manu 11. 63. by commenting that {#aBicAra#} is an {#upapAtaka,#} if
it causes the death of an {%innocent%} or {%unoffending%} person ({#SyenA-#}
{#diyajYenAnaparADasya mAraRam#}), while {%Medhātithi%} seems merely
[Page240-b+ 56]
to lay stress on the fact of {%death%} itself (although the death
be that of an enemy) and perhaps too on the condition of
death being caused by a {%vaidik%} kind of incantation ({%Medh.%}
to 11. 63.: {#aBicAro vEdikena SApAdinA mantraprayogeRa Sye-#}
{#nAdiyAgena vA SatrumAraRam,#} or to 11. 197.: {#vEdikena japaho-#}
{#mAdinA SatrormAraRamaBicAraH#}); for the same reason, pro-
bably, both comm. agree in giving to the penalty clause
(9. 290) the additional sense: ‘if the incantation does {%not%}
{%cause death%}’, and qualify, in the clause 11. 197., the incan-
tation as one ‘directed against a person who ought not to have
been brought under the spell (i. e. an innocent or unoffending
person)’; some however, as results from {%Medh.'%}s discussion
on the latter verse, give it a different bearing, for they supply
the preceding word {#yAjana#} at {#aBicAra#} and subject thus to the
penance Kṛchchhra, not the {#yajamAna#} or the person who
institutes an incantatory sacrifice, but the {#ftvij#} or the
priest who performs for him such a sacrifice. But in spite
of these efforts of the commentators to establish a harmony
between Manu and the Veda, it will seem that another
possibility alluded to by {%Medhātithi%} is more plausible, viz.
that Manu did not attach any scriptural authority to such
voluntary rites, as the incantatory sacrifices, and, there-
fore, did not consider himself at variance with the Veda,
when he interdicted incantations in an unqualified manner;
({%Medhātithi:%} {#nanu ca kAmyAnyapi nizidDAni . kAmAtmatA na praSa-#}
{#steti . yattasya vizayaH . sa tatrEva vyAKyAtaH#}). E. {#car#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>5962<pc>240-b<k1>aBicAraka<k2>aBicAraka
{#aBicAraka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rakaH-rikA-rakam#}) Enchanting,
conjuring. E. {#car#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul#}.
<LEND>

{#ramantra eva prati yuvateraBiDAnamaNganAnAm#}. E. {#aBicAra#} and {#mantra#}.

<L>5967<pc>240-b<k1>aBicArayajYa<k2>aBicArayajYa
{#aBicArayajYa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jYaH#}) A sacrifice for the purpose
of incantations, a sacrifice with magic powers, viz. either
of the sacrifices called {#Syena, trivfdagnizwoma, saMdaMSa, vajra#}
qq. vv. See {#aBicAra#}. E. {#aBicAra#} and {#yajYa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5968<pc>240-b<k1>aBicArahoma<k2>aBicArahoma
{#aBicArahoma#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) The same as the preceding.

<LEND>

<L>5969<pc>240-b<k1>aBicArita<k2>aBicArita

<LEND>

<L>5970<pc>240-b<k1>aBicArin<k2>aBicArin

gician, a conjurer. E. {#car#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GinuR#} (ac-
cording to the Dhātupār.).
<LEND>

<L>5971<pc>240-b<k1>aBicArya<k2>aBicArya

<H>{@DICTIONARY,@}
{@SANSKRIT AND ENGLISH,@}
EXTENDED AND IMPROVED FROM THE SECOND EDITION OF THE DICTIONARY
OF
PROFESSOR H. H. WILSON,
WITH HIS SANCTION AND CONCURRENCE;
TOGETHER WITH
A SUPPLEMENT, GRAMMATICAL APPENDICES AND AN INDEX,
SERVING AS
AN ENGLISH-SANSKRIT VOCABULARY.
BY
THEODOR GOLDSTÜCKER,
PH. D., PROFESSOR OF THE SANSKRIT LANGUAGE AND LITERATURE IN
UNIVERSITY COLLEGE, LONDON.
VOL. I. PART 4.
{#aBija--aByAhita#}
BERLIN:
A. ASHER AND CO.,
(ALBERT COHN AND DANIEL COLLIN)
LONDON:
DAVID NUTT.
MDCCCLX.
(MAY.)
[Page241-a+ 56]

<L>5973<pc>241-a<k1>aBija<k2>aBija
{#aBija#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Grown round or every-
where; comp. {#aBijAta;#} e. g. {#aBijAH keSAH#}. E. {#jan#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#qa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5974<pc>241-a<k1>aBijagmivas<k2>aBijagmivas
{#aBijagmivas#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-gmivAn-gmuzI-gmivat#}) Hav-
ing arrived. E. {#gam#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvasu#}.
<LEND>

<L>5975<pc>241-a<k1>aBijana<k2>aBijana
{#aBijana#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) <sup>1</sup> Native country; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%}
{#tataH pragaditA vAkyaM miTilABijanA nfpam#}. <sup>2</sup> The country
of the ancestors; (this is the sense given to the word by
{%Patanjali%} to {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 3. 90. in distinction from {#nivAsa,#} IV.
3. 89., which would mean according to him the country where
one lives oneself: {#aTa nivAsABijanayoH ko viSezaH . ni-#}
{#vAso nAma yatra saMpratyuzyate . aBijano nAma yatra pUrvEruzitam#}).
<sup>3</sup> The ancestors; (according to {%Kaiyyaṭa%}--hence {%Kāśikā%}
and {%Vardhamāna%}--on the preceding quotation: {#aBijana-#}
{#Sabdena pUrve bAnDavA ucyante#} &c.). <sup>4</sup> Race, family in general;
e. g. {%Lāṭyāyana:%} {#ya ezAmaDyayane'BikrAntitamaH syAdaBijanena#}
{#vA#} ({%Agnisvāmin:%} {#aBijanaH kulam#}). <sup>5</sup> The head or ornament
of a family. <sup>6</sup> Fame, notoriety. E. {#jan#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#GaY#} (according to the commentators of the {%Amarak.;%}
kṛt aff. {#ac,#} according to {%Bharatas.%} on the {%Bhaṭṭik.%}).
<LEND>

<L>5976<pc>241-a<k1>aBijanavat<k2>aBijanavat
{#aBijanavat#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) Of family, of a noble
family. (In the verse of the {%Rāmāy.%} {#tacCutvA Barato vAkyaM#}
{#DarmABijanavAYCuciH . papAta#} &c. the word {#DarmABijanavAn#}
is not to be rendered as equivalent to {#DarmavAnaBijanavAMSca,#}
‘virtuous and of noble family’, but ‘of a virtuous family’;
{%Maheśvaratīrtha:%} = {#Darmayukto'Bijano'nvayo yasyAstIti#}
{#taTA;#} {%another:%} = {#DarmayuktavaMSavAn#}.) E. {#aBijana,#} taddh. aff. {#matup#}.
<LEND>

<L>5977<pc>241-a<k1>aBijanitos<k2>aBijanitos

<L>5979<pc>241-a<k1>aBijAta<k2>aBijAta
{#aBijAta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Born, produced,
grown round or everywhere; comp. {#aBija#} ({%Ajayapāla:%} =
{#samantAjjAta#}). <sup>2</sup> Noble, well born. <sup>3</sup> Fortunate, well fated,
wealthy ({%Ajayapāla:%} = {#Danya#}). <sup>4</sup> Fit, proper. <sup>5</sup> Learned,
wise. <sup>6</sup> Handsome ({%Viśva:%} = {#prAptarUpa#}). <sup>7</sup> Pure, faultless;
e. g. in the {%Yoga Sūtra:%} {#kzIRavftteraBijAtasyeva maRergrahItf-#}
{#grahaRagrAhyezu tatsTatadaYjanatApattiH#} ({%Bhojadeva:%} {#aBijAtasya#}
{#nirmalasya#}). The {%Gaṇaratnamah.%} mentions the word in the
{%Gaṇa%} {#brAhmaRAdi#} to {%Pāṇ.%} V. 1. 124.; see {#ABijAtya#}. [In the
verses {%Bhagavadg.%} 16. 3. 4.: {#tejaH kzamA DftiH SOcamadroho#}
{#nAtimAnitA . Bavanti saMpadaM dEvImaBi jAtasya BArata . da-#}
{#mBo darpo'BimAnaSca kroDaH pAruzyameva ca . ajYAnaM cABi#}
{#jAtasya pArTa saMpadamAsurIm,#} it seems more correct to take
{#aBi#} as the separable preposition than as compounded with
{#jAta#} i. e. ‘born in consequence of divine or demoniac fate’:
{%Arjunam.:%} {#devayogyAM sAtvikIMsaMpadamaBilakzya tadABimuKyena#}
{#jAtasya…AsurImaBilakzya jAtasya#} &c.; in a similar
manner {%Śrīdharasvāmin, Madhusūdana,%} the {%Vivaraṇa, Sa-%}
{%dānanda;%} e. g. the latter in his metrical gloss: {#SudDasattvamayI#}
{#dEvI saMpattAmaBilakzya hi . puMso jAtasya vAkpuRyErete DarmA Ba-#}
{#vantyapi .…rajastamomayI duzwavAsanA saMtatirmalEH . Sa-#}
{#rIrAramBakAle'BivyaktA tAmaBilakzya ca . puMso jAtasya damBA-#}
{#dyA dozA ete Bavanti vE#}.] E. {#aBi#} and {#jAta#}.
<LEND>
[Page241-b+ 56]

<L>5980<pc>241-b<k1>aBijAtatA<k2>aBijAtatA
{#aBijAtatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) <sup>1</sup> Noble birth, nobility. <sup>2</sup> Beauty; e. g.
{%Hitop.%} (where the word may have either sense): {#prasAdaH#}
{#kurute patyuH saMpattiM nABijAtatA . kAlimA kAlakUwasya nApEtI-#}
{#SvarasaMgamAt#} (ed. {%Johnson;%} {#nABijAtyatAm#} ed. {%Schlegel-Lassen;%}
{#nABivAYCati#} ed. Seramp.). E. {#aBijAta,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#}.
<LEND>

<L>5981<pc>241-b<k1>aBijAti<k2>aBijAti

<LEND>

<L>5982<pc>241-b<k1>aBijiGraRa<k2>aBijiGraRa
{#aBijiGraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Smelling or rather touching the
head with the nose, as a sign of affection; (not: kissing);
e. g. {%Gobhila'%}s {%Gṛhya S.:%} {#striyAstUzRIM mUrDanyaBijiGraRam#}.

<LEND>

<L>5983<pc>241-b<k1>aBijit<k2>aBijit
{#aBijit#}¦ I. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-t-t-t#}) Everywhere vic-
torious, a vaidik epithet, or, as a neuter, a name of food;
{%Vājas.:%} {#aBijitA tejasA tejo jinva#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} {#aBi sarvato#}
{#jIyate yenetyaBijitsarvajayaheturannaM tena#}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-t#}) <sup>1</sup> The proper name of a Yādava prince, ac-
cording to the {%Viṣṇu P.%} the father, acc. to the {%Harivanśa,%}
the son, of Punarvasu. <sup>2</sup> The name of a sacrifice, forming
part of the {#gavAmayana#} q. v.; comp. also {#ekAha;#} e. g. {#aTEtasyA-#}
{#zwarAtrasya viSvajidaBijitAvekAhAvaBita uBayato jyotirmaDye#}
{#zaqahaH paSukAmo hyetena yajeta#}. <sup>3</sup> (scil. {#yoga#}) The Yoga-or lead-
ing star of the asterism {#aBijit#} (3. 1), the same as {%a%} Lyrae
({%Kālasaṅkalita%} p. 353); its place is 60° or 62° N., the longi-
tude of its circle of declination, according to different authori-
ties, is 265°, 266° 40’, or 268° ({%Colebr. Ess.%} II. p. 341).
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-t#}) <sup>1</sup> (scil. {#nakzatra#}) The name of the twenty-
second Nakshatra or asterism, consisting of three stars
figured as a triangle; it does not occupy an equal portion
of the ecliptic with the other twenty-six Nakshatras, but
is carved out of the contiguous divisions (comp. {%Col. Ess.%}
II. p. 341); viz. it is inserted sometimes between the twenty-
first ({%Pūrvāṣāḍhā%}) and twenty-third asterism ({%Śravaṇā%}),
in which case it takes 3°20' from the former and 1° 40’
from the latter, thus consisting of 5°; it is chiefly used for
astrological purposes ({%Kālasaṅkalita%} p. 353 &c.); to be born
under it is auspicious ({%Koṣṭīpradīpa,%} as quoted by {%Rādhāk.:%}
{#atisulalitakAntiH saMmataH sajjanAnAM nanu Bavati vinItaScA-#}
{#rukIrtiH suveSaH . dvijavarasuraBakto vyaktavANmAnavaH (°NmAnasaH ?)#}
{#syAdaBijiti yadi sUtirBUpatiH svavaMSe#}); it is sacred to Vidhi
or (the masc.) Brahman. <sup>2</sup> The eighth Muhūrta, the period
comprising 24 minutes before and 24 after midday; see
{#kutapa;#} e. g. {%Matsya Pur.%} (as quoted by {%Rādhāk.%}): {#aparAhle#}
{#tu saMprApte aBijidrOhiRodaye . yadatra dIyate jantostadakzayamu-#}
{#dAhftam;#} comp. also {#aBijita#}. E. {#aBi#} and {#jit#}.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-t-t-t#}) Born under the constellation of the
asterism Abhijit. E. {#aBijit#} with luk of the taddh. aff. {#aR#}.
<LEND>

<L>5984<pc>241-b<k1>aBijita<k2>aBijita
{#aBijita#}¦ 1. m. ({#-taH#}) The Yoga-or leading star of the
asterism Abhijit (see {#aBijit#} I. 2. 3.); {#aBijite yoge,#}
used like {#aBijite muhUrte#} ‘in the eighth Muhūrta’ (see
{#aBijit#} I. 3. 2.); e. g. {%Harivanśa:%} {#ahaM tvaBijite yoge ni-#}
{#SAyA yOvane sTite . arDarAtre karizyAmi garBamokzaM yaTAsuKam#}
({%Rāmānanda:%} {#aBijite yoge niSAyA azwame muhUrte#}).
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-tam#}) The eighth Muhūrta; see the preceding.
E. {#aBi#} and {#jita#}.
<LEND>

<L>5985<pc>241-b<k1>aBijiti<k2>aBijiti
{#aBijiti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) (ved.) Complete victory, con-
quest; (the word is udātta on the {%second%} syllable). E. {#ji#}
with {#aBi,#} kṛt. aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>
[Page242-a+ 56]

<L>5986<pc>242-a<k1>aBijinmuhUrta<k2>aBijinmuhUrta
{#aBijinmuhUrta#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-tam#}) See {#aBijit#} I. 3. 2. E.
{#aBijit#} and {#muhUrta#}.
<LEND>

<L>5987<pc>242-a<k1>aBijYa<k2>aBijYa
{#aBijYa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-jYaH-jYA-jYam#}) Knowing, under-
standing, conversant with, skilled in; e. g. {%Sāṅkhyat. Kaum.:%}
{#izwApUrtena dAkziRaH puruzatatvAnaBijYo hIzwApUrtakArI kAmopa-#}
{#hatamanA vaDyate;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#indrajidvikramABijYo manvAno#}
{#vAnaraM jitam…agAt#} &c.; when not compounded with
a preceding noun, the object of knowledge stands in the
genit. or locat.; thus the comm. of the {%Bhaṭṭik.%} explain
{#viyogaduHKAnuBAvAnaBijYEH, viyogaduHKasya yo'nuBavaH .#}
{#anuBavanam . tasyAnaBijYEH#} or {#tatrAnaBijYEH#}. E. {#jYA#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#ka#}.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-jYA#}) <sup>1</sup> Remembrance, recollection ({%Kāśikā:%} =
{#smftiH#}); e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#nABijYA te mahArAja jezyAvaH Sakra-#}
{#pAlitam…nABijYA te sayakzendraM BakzyAvo yadyamaM balAt;#}
or {%Lalitav.:%} {#DyAnapAramitADarmAlokamuKaM sarvajYAnABijYotpA-#}
{#dAya vikziptacittasattvaparipAcanatAyE saMvartate#}. <sup>2</sup> (In Buddhistic
doctrine.) Supernatural knowledge, a supernatural faculty
attached to the Arhatship; there are five, or according to
some six, such faculties viz. 1. the faculty of divine sight,
i. e. the faculty of seeing, without obstacle, all beings and
bodies, of whatever kind, in the totality of the worlds;
2. that of divine hearing, i. e. the faculty of understanding
all words of joy or grief uttered by the beings, and all
sounds of whatever kind uttered in all the worlds (or ‘the
power to hear all sounds whether distant or near, whether
made by devas or men’: {%Spence Hardy'%}s {%Eastern Monachism%});
3. that of knowing the thoughts of other beings; 4. that
of knowing former existences or what births have been
got in former ages; 5. magic power or the power to
assume any shape, to pass without obstacle over seas and
mountains, and to disappear from one world for the sake
of reappearing in another; to these some add: 6. {%āśra-%}
{%vakshaya,%} (which according to {%Burnouf%} probably means)
the power of destroying defects or vices. (See {%Burnouf'%}s
{%Lotus de la bonne loi%} p. 820 seqq.; there is a difference be-
tween this enumeration and that of {%Hardy%} in his {%Eastern%}
{%Monachism%} (p. 284): he has but five {%abhijnās,%} identifies the
magic power and the {%āśravakṣaya%} without defining how-
ever either term, omits the first (the faculty of divine
sight) and has an {%abhijnā%} not named by {%Burnouf:%} the
power of knowing what births will be received in fu-
ture ages). Compare {#zaqaBijYa#}. E. {#jYA#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#aN;#} (but meaning 2. is probably better analyzed
{#aBi#} and {#jYA#}).
<LEND>

<L>5988<pc>242-a<k1>aBijYAna<k2>aBijYAna
{#aBijYAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Recollection, remembrance.
<sup>2</sup> Recognition. <sup>3</sup> A sign or token of recognition; e. g. in
the {%Anukram.%} of the {%Rāmāyaṇa:%} {#saMBAzaRaM ca mETilyA aBi-#}
{#jYAnasya cArpaRam;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#aBijYAnaM gfhItvA te#} (scil.
{#vAnarAH#}) {#samutpeturnaBastalam;#} or {#ayaM mETilyaBijYAnaM kAkutsTa-#}
{#syANgurIyakaH#}. <sup>4</sup> The dark portion in the moon's disk. [A
nom. plur. masc. {#aBijYAnAH#} is mentioned by {%Langlois%} in
his transl. of the {%Harivanśa%} as a v. 1. of {#aBiglAna#} q. v.]
E. {#jYA#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>5989<pc>242-a<k1>aBijYAnaSakuntala<k2>aBijYAnaSakuntala

[Page242-b+ 56]
cognized by the token i. e. by the ring). E. {#aBijYAna#} (scil.
{#smfta#}) and {#SakuntalA,#} scil. {#nAwaka#}.

<L>5993<pc>242-b<k1>aBitas<k2>aBitas
{#aBitas#}¦ ind. (used absolutely or with a noun in the accusa-
tive) <sup>1</sup> Before, in the presence of, towards; e. g. {%Kirātārj.:%}
{#vyaktoditasmitamayUKaviBAsitozWastizWanmuneraBimuKaM sa vikIrRa-#}
{#DAmnaH . tanvantamidDamaBito gurumaMSujAlaM lakzmImuvAha sakalasya#}
{#SaSANkamUrteH#} ({%Mallin.:%} {#aBito'BimuKaM tizWata iti SezaH#}).
<sup>2</sup> Near; e. g. {%Sāvitrī:%} {#aBitaScAgataM premRA pratyAKyAtuM na mArha-#}
{#si#}. <sup>3</sup> On both sides; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#nirAkarizRavo BAnuM#}
{#divaM vartizRavo'BitaH . alaMkarizRavo BAntastaqitvantaScari-#}
{#zRavaH#} ({%Jayam.:%} {#divamaBito vartizRavaH…pUrvapaScimayorvarta-#}
{#nahetutvAt#}); or {#parijanamaBito vilokya dAhaM daSavadanaH pra-#}
{#dideSa vAnarasya#} ({%Jayam.:%} = {#uBayapArSvasTitAn#}); comp. also
the quotation s. v. {#aBijit#} I. 2. 2. where {%Mādhava%} explains
{#viSvajidaBijitAvekAhAvaBitaH#} thus: {#AdO viSvajit . ante#}
{#'BijidityarTaH;#} i. e. in the beginning--at the end; comp.
also {#aBitoBAva#}. <sup>4</sup> On all sides, every-where; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
{#samatra gAvo'Bito'navanteheha#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBitaH = sarvataH#});
or {%Vājas.:%} {#apAM pfzWamasi yoniragneH samudramaBitaH pinvamAnam#}
({%Mahīdh.:%} {#samudramaBitaH . udakasya paritaH#}). <sup>5</sup> Completely,
throughout; e. g. {%Svāmin%} on the {%Amarak.:%} {#ApnotyaBito rajaH;#}
or {%Bharata%} on the same: {#aBito vanadAhaH#}. <sup>6</sup> Quick; e. g. {%Bha-%}
{%rata%} on the {%Amarak.:%} {#gacCABitaH#}. E. {#aBi,#} taddh. aff. {#tasil#}.
<LEND>

<L>6007<pc>243-a<k1>aBidarSana<k2>aBidarSana

<L>6013<pc>243-a<k1>aBidyu<k2>aBidyu

ards heaven, tending heavenward; e. g. the Maruts ({%Sā-%}
{%yaṇa:%} = {#dyulokamaBigatAH#} or = {#aBigatA dyOryEste#}). <sup>2</sup> Radiant,
splendid, shining around; e. g. the Viśvadevas, the Maruts,
sacrificers, a horse &c. ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#aBigatadIptayaH#} or =
{#aBigatA dyOrdIptiryezAm#} or = {#aBito dIpyamAnAH#}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-dyuH#}) (ved.) A half month; in the {%Ṛgv.%} verse:
{#pra vo vAjA aBidyavo havizmanto GftAcyA . devAYjigAti#}
{#sumnayuH,#} where {%Sāyaṇa%} explains, according to the gloss of
the {%Taittirīyabr.%} ({#pra vo vAjA ityanvAha mAsA vE vAjA arDa-#}
{#mAsA aBidyavaH#} &c.), {#aBidyavaH = aBito dyavo divasA#}
{#yezu;#} and similarly in his comm. on {%Śatap.%} I. 4. 1. 8. (E. I. H.
Mss. 657. 1509): {#vastoH . dyuH .#} ({#BAnuH#} is omitted) {#. vAsara-#}
{#mityaharnAmasu pAWAt . dyuSabdo dinavacanaH . dyUnaBi divasA-#}
{#naBi gatA iti vyutptattyA aBidyava ityanenArDamAsA ucyante#}.
E. {#aBi#} and {#dyu#}.
<LEND>

<L>6018<pc>243-a<k1>aBidroha<k2>aBidroha
{#aBidroha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) <sup>1</sup> Offence, injury, oppression;
(in the {%Ṛgv.%} verse {#yatkiM cedaM varuRa dEvye jane'BidrohaM ma-#}
{#nuzyA3ScarAmasi,#} {%Sāyaṇa%} explains {#aBidroham#} as if it were
an adj. in the acc. of the neuter, referring to {#yadidam,#} viz.
[Page243-b+ 56]
{#yadidaM kiMcanABidrohamapakArajAtam;#} but it is more probable
that it is an apposition to {#yadidam#} and that the combina-
tion is a poetical liberty). <sup>2</sup> Abuse, curse; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#nA-#}
{#majAtigrahaM tvezAmaBidroheRa kurvataH . niHkzepyo'yomayaH Sa-#}
{#NkurjvalannAsye daSANgulaH#} ({%Kullūka:%} {#aBidroha AkroSaH#}). E.
{#druh#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6019<pc>243-b<k1>aBiDarma<k2>aBiDarma
{#aBiDarma#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rmaH#}) (In Buddhistic doctrine.) The mani-
fested or revealed truth; ({%Abhidharmakośa,%} as quoted in
{%Burnouf'%}s {%Introd.%} p. 40: = {#aBimuKo DarmaH;#} therefore not to be
rendered: the ‘supreme law’; {#Darma#} has been translated here
‘truth’, instead of ‘law’, in conformity with the judicious
remark of {%Spence Hardy, East. Mon.%} p. 167); i. e. the Bud-
dhistic dogmas and metaphysics, as laid down in the {#a-#}
{#BiDarmapiwaka#} q. v.--The first redaction of the Abhidharma
is ascribed to {%Kāśyapa%} or {%Mahā-Kaśyapa,%} the principal
disciple of {%Śākya Muni;%} but the redaction of the whole col-
lection of works on this subject seems to belong to different
periods the last of which precedes the third Buddhistic
synod; (see {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alt.%} vol. II. p. 458). {%Hodgson%} re-
lates of four great {%Nepalese%} schools divided on account of
their views on the Abhidharma: the {%Svābhāvika, Aiśvarika,%}
{%Kārmika%} and {%Yātnika%} (see {%Burnouf'%}s {%Introd.%} p. 441 and the
quotation given there); {%Csoma de Körös%} speaks of four
other {%Tibetian%} schools which are divided and subdivided
into various sects: 1. the {%Vaibhāṣikās%} which comprise four
sects: {%a.%} one founded by {%Rāhula,%} the son of Śākya, and
subdivided at the period of the third synod into seven sects:
the Mūla-sarvāsti-vādās, Kāśyapīyās, Mahīśāsakās, Dhar-
maguptās, Bahuśrutīyās, Tāmraśātīyās and Vibhādyavā-
dinas; {%b.%} one founded by {%Kāśyapa,%} a Brāhmaṇa, and sub-
divided into six sects, five of which, bearing the collective
name of Mahāsaṅghikās, were known at the time of the
third synod: the Pūrvaśailās, Avaraśailās, Haimavatās,
Lokottaravādinas and Prajnaptivādinas; {%c.%} one founded by
{%Upāli,%} a Śūdra, and having the surname Sammatās, sub-
divided into three sects: the Kaurmakullakās (?), Āvan-
tikās and Vātsīputrīyās; {%d.%} one founded by {%Kātyāyana,%} a
Śūdra, and subdivided also into three sects: the Mahāvi-
hāravāsinas, Jyetavanīyās and Abhayagirivāsinas; 2. the
{%Sautrāntikās%} with two sects; 3. the {%Yogāchārās,%} founded by
{%Āryasaṅgha%} and divided into nine sects; 4. the {%Mādhyami-%}
{%kās%} owing their origin to {%Nāgārjuna%} who lived about 400
years after the Buddha, divided into two sects the founders
of which are probably {%Āryadeva%} and {%Buddhapālita.%} (For
these sects and the doctrine itself see {%Burnouf'%}s {%Introd.%}
p. 437 ff., {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alt.%} II. p. 456 ff.; also {%Spence Hardy'%}s
{%East. Mon.%} where a legend, related p. 197, conveys an idea
of the great merit supposed to be acquired by the study of
the Abhidharma.) E. {#aBi#} and {#Darma#}.
<LEND>

<L>6020<pc>243-b<k1>aBiDarmakoSa<k2>aBiDarmakoSa
{#aBiDarmakoSa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SaH#}) The name of a Buddhistic
work on the Abhidharma (see the preceding and the fol-
lowing), by Vasubandhu; with a commentary called {#aBi-#}
{#DarmakoSavyAKyA#}. E. {#aBiDarma#} and {#koSa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6021<pc>243-b<k1>aBiDarmapiwaka<k2>aBiDarmapiwaka
{#aBiDarmapiwaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) ‘The basket of the revealed
truth’: the name of one of the three collections which com-
prise the sacred books of the Buddhists; (for the two others
[Page244-a+ 56]
see {#sUtrapiwaka#} and {#vinayapiwaka#}); the instructions contained
in it were addressed by the Buddha to the Devas and
Brahmas of the celestial worlds (while those in the {%Sūtra-%}
{%piṭaka%} were addressed to the laity and those in the {%Vinayap.%}
to the priests); its redaction however is not ascribed to
Sākya Muni, but to his principal disciple {%Kāśyapa,%} the
chief of the first Buddhistic synod. It contains seven sections,
the text with 96, 250 stanzas, the commentaries with 30,000,
consisting, therefore, in the whole of 126,250 stanzas; its
best representative is the work called {%Prajnāpāramitā;%}
(comp. {%Spence Hardy'%}s {%East. Mon.%} p. 170 with the quot.
given there, and those s. v. {#aBiDarma#}). E. {#aBiDarma#} and {#piwaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>6022<pc>244-a<k1>aBiDarzaRa<k2>aBiDarzaRa
{#aBiDarzaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Possession by evil spirits. E.
{#aBi#} and {#DarzaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6023<pc>244-a<k1>aBiDA<k2>aBiDA
{#aBiDA#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. f. ({#-DAH-DAH#}) (ved.) Invoked, praised;
{%Vājas.:%} {#aBiDA asi Buvanamasi#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} {#he aSva yastvama-#}
{#BiDA asi . aBiDIyate stUyata ityaBiDAH#}). E. {#DA#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. f. ({#-DA#}) <sup>1</sup> A name, an appellation; e. g. {#iti SrI-#}
{#kAlidAsaviracitaM meGadUtABiDaM mahAkAvyaM saMpUrRam;#} or {%Rāja-%}
{%tar.:%} {#kAvyadevyaBiDA SUravaDUH;#} or {#kasyAnyasyABiDADvaMsi yaTA#}
{#SaNkaravarmaRaH#} ‘whose name else has been made to disappear
({#aBiDA-aDvaMsi#}) like that of Śaṅkaravarman ?’. <sup>2</sup> The literal
or original signification of a word; defined by the rhetorical
works as the power of a word to express that sense which it
has by common consent, or conventionally, whether the word
imply the notion of class ({#jAti,#} as cow &c.) or of quality
({#guRa,#} as white &c.) or of action ({#kriyA,#} as cooking &c.), or
whether it be the name of an individual ({#dravya#} i. e. a proper
name or {#saMjYA,#} as Hari &c.); the term {%‘conventional sense’%}
is not restricted in this definition to the sense of such words
as instanced before, but applies also e. g. to such meanings
as the meaning ‘bee’ of {#maDukara,#} since this word has the
latter sense occasionally, or to the explanations of com-
mentators, although the word commented upon may have
the given sense only in a particular passage; the term does
not extend, however, to the elliptical and constructive or
contingent bearing of a word, these latter being considered
as the two other powers which a word may possess; (see
{#lakzaRA#} and {#vyaYjanA#}); {%Sāhityad.:%} {#vAcyo'rTo'BiDayA boDyo#}
{#lakzyo lakzaRayA mataH . vyaNgyo vyaYjanayA tAH syustisraH Sabdasya#}
{#SaktayaH .. tatra saMketitArTasya boDanAdagrimABiDA . saMketo gf-#}
{#hyate jAtO guRadravyakriyAsu ca;#} {%Kāvyaprak.:%} {#sAkzAtsaMketitaM#}
{#yo'rTamaBiDatte sa vAcakaH . saMketitaScaturBedo jAtyAdirjAti-#}
{#reva vA . sa muKyo'rTastatra muKyo vyApAro'syABiDocyate;#}
or {%the same:%} {#ata evABiDApucCaBUtA setyAhuH#} ({#sA#} i. e. {#la-#}
{#kzaRA#}). <sup>3</sup> A sound; {%Śabdaratn.:%} {#SabdanirGozanirhrAdanisvAna-#}
{#svAnanisvanAH…virAvanAdahrAsAH syuraBiDA cA-#}
{#BiDAnakam . taTA kuhuritaM ceti SabdaparyAya IritaH#}. Comp.
{#aBiDAna#}. E. {#DA#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#aN#}.
<LEND>

<L>6024<pc>244-a<k1>aBiDAtavya<k2>aBiDAtavya
{#aBiDAtavya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-vyaH-vyA-vyam#}) To be named,
to be expressed; comp. {#aBiDAnIya#} and {#aBiDeya#}. E. {#DA#}
with {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#tavya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6025<pc>244-a<k1>aBiDAna<k2>aBiDAna
{#aBiDAna#}¦ Tatpur. 1. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Naming, telling, expressing;
e. g. in the {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#kzubDaM manTABiDAna iti vaktavyam;#}
or {#svAntaM mano'BiDAna iti vaktavyam;#} or {#DvAntaM mano'Bi-#}
[Page244-b+ 56]
{#DAna iti vaktavyam;#} or {#avAtABiDAna iti vaktavyam;#} or {%Pa-%}
{%tanj.%} to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#kaH punarvIpsArTaH . anavayavABiDAnaM vIpsArTaH .#}
{#anavayavena dravyARAmaBiDAnameza vIpsArTaH;#} or in the {%Nyāya%}
{%S.:%} {#arTAdApannasya svaSabdena punaraBiDAnam;#} or in the {%Mī-%}
{%mānsā S.:%} {#guRABiDAnAtsarvArTamaBiDAnam;#} or {%Sāhityad.:%}
{#(nAndI) pUrvaraNgasya raNgadvArABiDAnamaNgamityucyate#}.--In writ-
ings on the {%Mīmānsā philosophy%} {#aBiDAna#} or {#aBiDAyakatva#}
are used sometimes in opposition to {#viDAyakatva,#} when the
former imply such expressions or passages in the Vedas
as do not contain a {#viDi#} or injunction, but merely a
description or explanation; the word becomes in such cases
a synonyme of {#anuvAda#} q. v.; e. g. {%Mīmānsā S.:%} {#viDi-#}
{#mantrayorEkArTyamEkaSabdyAt . api vA prayogasAmarTyAnmantro#}
{#'BiDAnavAcI syAt;#} {%Jaiminīyanyāyam.:%} {#devAMSca yABiryajata#}
{#ityAKyAtaM tu mantragam . viDAyakaM na vAnyena samatvAttadviDA-#}
{#yakam . yacCabdAdeH kzIRaSaktirna viDistriviDaM tataH . A-#}
{#KyAtamaBiDAnaM ca praDAnaguRakarmaRI#} ({%comm.:%} {#ayaM mantra A-#}
{#mnAyate . devAMSca yABiryajate dadAti ca jyogittABiH sacate#}
{#gopatiH saheti .…tatra yaTA brAhmaRagatamAKyAtapadaM pra-#}
{#DAnaguRakarmaRoranyatarasya viDAyakam . taTA mantragatamapIti#}
{#cet .. mEvam . yacCabdAdinA viDiSakteH kzIRatvAt . sati hi#}
{#yacCabde tasya vAkyasyAnuvAdakatvaM pratIyate . na tu viDAyaka-#}
{#tvam .…tasmAdAKyAtasya praDAnakarmaviDAyakatvaM guRakarma-#}
{#viDAyakatvaM cetyevaM dvAveva prakArO na BavataH . kiMtvaBiDAyaka-#}
{#tvamityapyasti tftIyaH prakAraH . tato na mantragatAKyAtasya vi-#}
{#DAyakatvam#}).--Comp. also {#bahvaBiDAna#} (in the sense of {#ba-#}
{#huvacana#}). <sup>2</sup> A proposition, a rule, an axiom; (this seems
to be the sense of the word in the {%comm.%} on the {%Vājas.%}
{%Prātiś.%} 4. 141., where {#aBiDAna#} would imply the axiom or
law taught by the Sūtra; comp. the preceding words {#tasyE-#}
{#taducyate#}). <sup>3</sup> The same as {#aBiDA#} II. 2.; e. g. {%Kāvyapr.:%} {#lakza-#}
{#RAtmakameva Dvananam . tadanugamena tasya darSanAt . na ca tadanu-#}
{#gatameva . aBiDAnAvalambanenApi tasya BAvAnna coBayAnusAryeva#}.
<sup>4</sup> The being named, the being expressed; e. g. in the {%Nyāya%}
{%S.:%} {#kAraRadravyasya pradeSaSabdenABiDAnAt;#} or in the {%Vedānta%}
{%S.:%} {#jyotiScaraRABiDAnAt;#} or {#Cando'BiDAnAnneti cenna#} &c.;
or {#suKaviSizwABiDAnAdeva ca;#} or {%Jayamangala%} in the comm.
on the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#samaSabdenopamAyA aBiDAnAt#} &c.; or
{%Bharatas.%} in his comm. on the same: {#vfdDikriyayostulyakA-#}
{#layorvavfDa ityanenABiDAnAt#}. <sup>5</sup> Speech, discourse. <sup>6</sup> A vo-
cabulary; e. g. {%Vopad.:%} {#kfttadDitasamAsAnAmaBiDAnaM niyA-#}
{#makam;#} comp. also {%Colebr. Ess.%} II. p. 52.
<div n="P">2. m. n. ({#-naH-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> A name, an appellation; e. g. {%Ki-%}
{%rātārj.:%} {#tavABiDAnAdvyaTate natAnanaH#} ({%Mallin.:%} {#tavABiDAnA-#}
{#nnAmaDeyAnnAmaDeyasmaraRAt#}); or {%Śiśupālab.:%} {#jagati sumanasa-#}
{#stadAdi nUnaM daDati parisPuwamarTato'BiDAnam;#} or {%Jaimini%}
{%Sūtra:%} {#uktaM kriyABiDAnaM syAttadaBAve prasidDaM syAt;#} comp.
also the instance s. v. {#aBicAramantra#}. <sup>2</sup> A word; e. g. the
{%Ṭīkā%} on the {%Sāhityad.:%} {#anvitABiDAnavAdino#} (i. e. those
who argue that the words of a sentence are logically con-
nected) {#mImAMsakaguravastu kriyAkArakayoH praTamata evAnvaya-#}
{#boDo jAyate tataH SaktigrahaH;#} or {%Kāvyapr.:%} {#himapayaHSaNkA-#}
{#dyASrayezu paramArTato Binnezu SuklAdizu yadvaSena SuklaH Sukla i-#}
{#tyAdyaBinnABiDAnapratyayotpattiH;#} or {%Suśruta:%} {#vyaktABiDAnama-#}
{#Kilena viDiM niboDa#} &c.; or {%Manu:%} {#strIRAM…ASIrvA-#}
{#dABiDAnavat#} (scil. {#nAmaDeyam#}). <sup>3</sup> A sound (?); comp. {#aBiDA#}
[Page245-a+ 56]
II. 3. and the following article. [The double gender of the word
is mentioned by the {%Siddhāntak.,%} but apparently restricted
to the meanings given under 2., for the {%Gaṇaratnam.%} which
mentions the word in the Gaṇa {#arDarcAdi#}--{%Pāṇ.%} II. 4. 31.
--explains it {#aBiDAnaM#} or {#aBiDAno nAma SabdaSca#}.]
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-nI#}) (ved.) A rope, a halter; (thus explained by
{%Kaiyyaṭa%} when speaking of the meanings of {#DA#} with {#aBi,#}
viz. {#aBipUrvastAvaddaDAtirbanDanoccAraRapratipAdanezu vartate . a-#}
{#SvABiDAnImAdatta ityatra banDanavfttiH#} &c.). E. {#DA#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6026<pc>245-a<k1>aBiDAnaka<k2>aBiDAnaka
{#aBiDAnaka#}¦ n. ({#-kam#}) A sound; see the quotation from the
{%Śabdaratnāvalī%} s. v. {#aBiDA#} II. 3. E. {#aBiDAna,#} taddh.
aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>6027<pc>245-a<k1>aBiDAnacintAmaRi<k2>aBiDAnacintAmaRi
{#aBiDAnacintAmaRi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-RiH#}) ‘The gem that yields
every word desired’; the name of the first part of {%Hema-%}
{%chandra'%}s vocabulary or of the portion containing the syn-
onymes; the work is commented upon by {%Hemachandra%}
himself and by {%Vallabhagaṇi.%} (The latter portion of Hema-
chandra's vocabulary bears the title {%Anekārthasaṅgraha%} or
{%Nānārthasaṅgraha%} and is similar to, but not identical with,
{%Maheśvara'%}s {%Viśvaprakāśa;%} there must have existed or may
still exist an extensive commentary on it, probably by He-
machandra himself, as may be concluded from a single Ms.
leaf which is happily preserved of it in the British Museum.)
E. {#aBiDAna#} and {#cintAmaRi#}.
<LEND>

<L>6028<pc>245-a<k1>aBiDAnatva<k2>aBiDAnatva
{#aBiDAnatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The being an expression or explana-
tion of; see the remark s. v. {#aBiDAna#} 1.; e. g. {%Jaimini%}
{%Sūtra:%} {#BAgitvAttu niyamyeta guRAnAmaBiDAnatvAtsaMbanDAdaBi-#}
{#DAnavadyaTA DenuH kiSoreRa#}. E. {#aBiDAna,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6029<pc>245-a<k1>aBiDAnamAlA<k2>aBiDAnamAlA

<L>6034<pc>245-a<k1>aBiDABAvanA<k2>aBiDABAvanA
{#aBiDABAvanA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-nA#}) (In the Mīmānsā philosophy.)
That notion inhering in a verb, which conveys in a {%literal%}
or {%explicit%} manner the unseen power {#apUrva;#} it is considered
as residing in, or as being imparted by, the affixes of the po-
tential, leṭ, imperative and participles of the passive future;
also called {#SabdaBAvanA#} and distinguished from the {#arTaBA-#}
{#vanA#}. See {#apUrva#} I. 1. 2. 1. p. 199{%b,%} 1. 12 ff. E. {#aBiDA#} and
{#BAvanA#}.
<LEND>

<L>6050<pc>246-a<k1>aBiDyA<k2>aBiDyA
{#aBiDyA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-DyA#}) <sup>1</sup> Desire, wish; e. g. (of Brahman)

{#tmanaH kartftvaprakftitve gamayati so'kAmayata bahu syAM prajAye-#}
{#yeti tadEkzateti ca . tatrABiDyAnapUrvikAyAH svAtantpyapravftteH#}
{#karteti gamyate . bahu syAmiti pratyagAtmavizayatvAt . bahuBava-#}
{#nABiDyAnasya prakftirityapi gamyate;#} {%Anūpanār.:%} {#so'kAmayata#}
{#bahu syAmiti svasya bahutvasaMkalpo'BiDyA#} &c.). See {#aBi-#}
{#DyAna#}. <sup>2</sup> Coveting another's property (in employing charms
or in scheming, or by means of a robbery). <sup>3</sup> Desire of
taking, in general. [Several comm. on the {%Amarak.%} give
merely the meaning: coveting another's property: {#paraDana-#}
{#spfhA#} or {#paradravye vizayaspfhA;#} but {%Svāmin:%} {#cintApUrvaM parasva-#}
{#lipsA;#} {%Rāyamukuṭa:%} {#aBicAre'BiDyAnamaBiDyA .…#}
{#parasvavizaye vizayitayA spfhA vizayispfhABiDyocyate . viza-#}
{#yaspfheti pAWe vizayena cOryAdinA spfhetyarTaH;#} similarly {%Bha-%}
{%ratamalla;%} the {%Kaumudī:%} {#jiGfkzAmAtre'pyaBiDyA;#} {%Vallabha-%}
{%gaṇi%} on {%Hemach.:%} {#parasvehA dravyavizayavAYCA . parasve vizaya-#}
{#spfhetyeko dozaH . cintApUrvaM paradravyavAYCetyarTaH . yatkAtyaH .#}

<L>6055<pc>246-a<k1>aBinanda<k2>aBinanda

<div n="P">2. f. ({#-ndA#}) <sup>1</sup> A sensation of pleasure, a sensation of

{#dantaH karoti te'NgArA aBinandA vizPuliNgAH#} ({%Bṛh.:%} {#vi-#}
{#sPuliNgAH#}); {%Dwivedaganga%} or {%Śaṅkara:%} {#aBinandAH = su-#}
{#KalavAH#}. <sup>2</sup> Wish, desire; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#dAhaprapAkO SiSi-#}

might be possible to look in these instances upon the word
as upon a plural of a {%masc.%} {#aBinanda;#} but in the quoted
passage from Suśruta it is more natural to take it as the
singul. of a femin., as has been done by a modern Paṇdit

<L>6063<pc>246-b<k1>aBinaya<k2>aBinaya
{#aBinaya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-yaH#}) Action and postures expressive
of sentiment, especially when exhibited in a dramatic per-
formance; dramatic representation; it is fourfold: {#ANgika#}
or conveyed by bodily action, as by attitude, gesture &c.,
{#vAcika#} by speech, {#AhArya#} by dress, decorations &c. and
{#sAttvika#} by the spontaneous manifestation of feelings, as
by perspiration, horripilation, inarticulate speech &c.; e. g.
{%Vikramorv.:%} {#lalitABinayaM tamadya BartA marutAM drazwumanAH sa-#}
{#lokapAlaH;#} or a quotation by the {%Sāhityad.:%} {#yasmAdaBinayo#}
{#hyatra prATamyAdavatAryate . raNgadvAramato jYeyaM vAgaNgABinayA-#}
{#tmakam#}. The term {#aBinaya#} as applying merely to the {%means%}
of a dramatic representation is therefore distinct from the
term {#rUpaka#} (and its subdivisions) q. v. which belongs to the
{%contents%} of the representation or to the drama itself, both
being the categories which distinguish the ‘poem to be
seen’ from the ‘poem to be heard’; {%Sāhityad.:%} {#dfSyaSravya-#}
{#tvaBedena punaH kAvyaM dviDA matam . dfSyaM tatrABineyaM tadrUpAro-#}
[Page247-a+ 56]
{#pAttu rUpakam . BavedaBinayo'vasTAnukAraH sa caturviDaH . A-#}
{#Ngiko vAcikaScEvamAhAryaH sAttvikastaTA;#} (the {%Amarak.%} dis-
tinguishes the {#aBinaya#} only as {#ANgika#} and {#sAttvika;#} {%He-%}
{%mach.%} has the same definition as the {%Sāhityad.%}).
<div n="P">[2. n. ({#-yam#}) See the remark s. v. {#aBibala#}.] E. {#nI#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ac;#} {%Saṅgītadarpaṇa:%} {#aBipUrvastu RIYDAtu-#}
{#rABimuKyArTanirRaye . asmAtprayogaM nayati tasmAdaBinayaH smftaH#}.
<LEND>

<L>6064<pc>247-a<k1>aBinava<k2>aBinava
{#aBinava#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-vaH-vA-vam#}) <sup>1</sup> New; e. g. {%Mi-%}
{%tākṣara:%} {#aBinavAni tu vastrARi viBAjyAnyeva#}. <sup>2</sup> Recent,
fresh, young; e. g. {%Amarak.:%} {#aNkuro'BinavodBidi;#} or
{%Hemach.:%} {#aNkuro…'Binavodgame;#} or {%the same:%} {#pravAlo…#}
{#'Binavapallave;#} or {%Jayam.%} (in the comm. on the {%Bhaṭṭik.%}):
{#aBinavAM PalaSriyaM…vitatAna;#} or {%Bharatas.%} (in the same):
{#aBinavAnAM maDUkapuzpARAM saMBavaH#}. Comp. {#aBinavaSAkawA-#}
{#yana#}. <sup>3</sup> Unexperienced, a beginner; e. g. {%Kāśikā%} (explaining
the instance {#praTamavEyAkaraRaH#}) {#aBinavavEyAkaraRaH . saMprati#}
{#vyAkaraRamaDyetuM pravftta ityarTaH#}. [<sup>4</sup> Strange, surprising, mar-
vellous ({%Molesworth%}).]
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-vaH#}) The proper name of two soldiers mentioned
in the {%Rājataraṅgiṇī;%} {#koSADikArI trElokyarAjanAmA hato#}
{#raRe . kappAmattakaDAtreyo vIro'pyaBinavABiDaH;#} and: {#Sa-#}
{#mAlA qAmaraM GnantaM prAsEraBinavABiDam . SAlAsTale vyaDAt#}.
E. {#aBi#} and {#nava#}.
<LEND>

<L>6065<pc>247-a<k1>aBinavacandrArGaviDi<k2>aBinavacandrArGaviDi
{#aBinavacandrArGaviDi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-DiH#}) The ceremony of
presenting the idols of the new moon and of his wife Ro-
hiṇī, placed on the ground in a circle of cowdung, with
flowers, sandal, perfumes, a lamp, fried grain, water,
young Dūrvā grass ornamented with jewels, curdled milk
and white cloth, while reciting the prayer: ‘thou art ever
new at the end of the month, born again and again; in-
crease for my benefit; hail! hail to thee, Lord of the Soma!’;
the time of the ceremony is the evening twilight of the
second day of the light half of every month (i. e. of the
second day of the fifteen days of the moon's increase),
when the sun stands in the west with twelve degrees of its
circumference. The rite is performed by a Kshatriya with
his house chaplain, and great boons are promised to him
in this and the future world for the regular fulfillment of
this act of piety; (according to the {%Bhavishyottara-Purāṇa,%}
where the principal passage runs thus: {#raverdvAdaSaBirBAgErvA-#}
{#ruRyAM dfSyate yadi . pradozasamaye pArTa#} (Kṛṣṇa speaks to
Arjuna) {#arGaM dadyAttadA viBo .. dvitIyAyAM site pakze saMDyA-#}
{#kAle hyupasTite . saMsTApyABinavaM candraM BUmyAM gomayamaRqale ..#}
{#rohiRyA sahitaM devaM candanena suSoBanam . puzpacandanaDUpESca#}
{#dIpAkzatajalEH SuBEH .. dUrvANkurE ratnaDarErdaDnA#} ({%v. l.%} {#ratnaGanErdaDnA#})
{#vastrESca pARqurEH#} ({%v. l.%} {#pARqavEH#}) {#. mantreRAnena rAjendraH kzatriyaH#}
{#sapurohitaH#} (Mss. {#°tam#}) {#.. navo navo'si mAsAnte jAyamAnaH#}
{#punaH punaH . ApyAyasva ca me'pyevaM somarAja namo namaH .. a-#}
{#nena viDinA cArGaM sarvakAmapradaM SuBam . yaH prayacCati kOnteya#}
{#mAsi mAsi samAhitaH .. sa kIrtyA yaSasA yuktaH kAntyA ca Buvi#}
{#mAnavaH . putrapOtraparivfto goDAnyaDanasaMkulaH .. sTitvA varzaSataM#}
{#martye tataH somapuraM vrajet#} &c.). E. {#aBinava-candra-arGa#} and {#viDi#}.
<LEND>

<L>6075<pc>247-b<k1>aBiniDAna<k2>aBiniDAna
{#aBiniDAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Placing over, putting over;
e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrautas.:%} {#AyurasItyuttarayAjyasTAlIM saMspfSya pu-#}
{#rUravA ityaBiniDAnaM tayA;#} ({%comm.%} {#uttarAraRyA aDarAraRe-#}
{#rupari niDAnaM karoti#}). <sup>2</sup> (In the {%Prātiśakhyas%}) Suppression
or weakening of a sound with regard to, or on account
of, scil. the influence of a preceding or following sound
[the qualification {%‘with regard to’%} or {%‘on account of’%} seems
to be implied by the prefix {#aBi#}], viz. <sup>a.</sup> the suppression
of the vowel {#a#} through the influence of a {%preceding%} {#o#} or
{#e#} (comp. {#aBinihita#}); e. g. in {#gAhamAno'dayaH#} of the word
{#adayaH,#} or in {#vAle'vata#} of the word {#avata;#} <sup>b.</sup> the sup-
pression or weakening of the sound or of the vibration of
the voice which naturally follows the pronunciation of a
consonant, if such a consonant is {%followed%} by, and has made
{%sandhi%} with, another consonant; according to the {%Ṛgv.%}
{%Prātiś.,%} such a sound or the vibration of the voice is {%sup-%}
{%pressed,%} if the consonant is surd ({#ka, ca#} &c.); it is {%weakened,%}
if the consonant is sonant ({#ga, ja#} &c.) and the sound which
{%remains,%} after such weakening is called {#Druva#} (q. v.). This
suppression or weakening of the vibration of the voice,
however, takes place only under the following restrictions:
1. in the pronunciation of a {#sparSa#} or {#antaHsTA#} (except {#r#}),
[Page248-a+ 56]
if it is followed by a {#sparSa;#} e. g. in {#arvAgdevaH#} or in {#ulkAm;#}
2. of a {#sparSa,#} if it stands in a pause; e. g. in {#vAk;#} 3. of an
{#antaHsTA,#} if it is followed by another similar {#antaHsTA;#}
e. g. in {#tavvaM~H;#} 4 of {#l,#} if it is followed by an {#Uzman;#} e. g.
in {#SatavalSaH;#} 5. of {#k#} in {#akKyat;#} 6. of {#p#} in {#virapsI;#} 7. of
a {#sparSa#} except {#m#} (i. e. {#k#} till {#B#}), if it is followed by {#y,#}
{#r, v#} or an {#Uzman;#} e. g. in {#yadyat, tadrAsaBaH, yAnvaH, arvA-#}
{#kSaPO;#} (the latter cases 4-7. only in the theory of the {%Śā-%}
{%kalas%}). These general rules are subject to exceptions and
restrictions, and even as such they are not universally re-
cognized; {%Śaunaka,%} for instance, says, that {%Vyāĺi%} does not
recognize the {#aBiniDAna,#} {%in general,%} and admits of it only
when the following consonant is doubled or if a vowel or
{#r#} precede.--The {%Vājas. Prātiś.%} uses instead of the term
{#aBiniDAna#} the explanation {#sTAnakaraRavimokzaH#} ‘giving up
the characteristics of a consonant, viz. the organic dis-
tinction and the distinction with regard to the effort of pro-
nunciation’; (comp. the list in {%Pāṇ.%} I. 1. 9. where {#karaRa#}
answers the {#prayatna;#} and see {%Weber'%}s ed. of this {%Prātiś. Ind.%}
{%Stud.%} IV. p. 127), but applies it merely to the {#sparSa#} at the
end of a word, if it is followed by another word, and in
a pause.--The {%Atharvav. Prātiś.%} (quoted by {%Weber 1. c.,%}
where the {%masc.%} {#aBiniDAnaH#} seems to be an error of the
Berlin Ms.) admits the {#aBiniDAna#} only 1. of a {#sparSa,#} if it
is followed by a {#sparSa,#} 2. of a {#sparSa#} at the end of a word or
at an {#avagraha,#} 3. of {#l#} before an {#Uzman,#} 4 of {#N, Ra, na,#}
before {#h#}. {%Śākalya,%} in the cases 4-7. mentioned above, and
the {%Atharvav. Prātiś.%} in its enumeration do not consider
two consonants, the first of which suffers the {%abhinidhāna,%}
as {#saMyukta#} or combined consonants ({%Śaunaka:%} {#asaMyuktaM SA-#}
{#kalam;#} {%Atharvav. Pr.:%} {#ato'nyatsaMyuktam ‘saMyukta#} is a com-
bination of consonants other than that in the preceding
cases’); i. e. they assume such a stoppage of the voice as
to prevent two consonants to sound together; but {%Śaunaka%}
does not seem to go so far, for he quotes {%Śākalya%} apparently
for the sake of recording his dissent from the opinion of
the latter. The distinction is probably owing to the dif-
ference in the observation, by the different grammarians,
of the phenomena of pronunciation; the supposition of {%Mr.%}
{%Regnier%} ({%Journ. Asiat.%} 1857, p. 230), that there is a twofold
{%abhinidhāna,%} the one applying to the consonantic groups
which are the {%natural%} effect of the sandhi, the other to such
groups as are produced by the {%krama,%} is very ingenious,
but does not necessarily follow from the text of this {%Prātiś.%}
(I. 1. 6. and 7.); for similar differences of opinion in the theory
on the pronunciation of consonantic groups, arising ob-
viously from different observations, may be gathered also
from the Sūtras of Pāṇini. [In the preceding explanation
the term {#sparSa#} comprises the 25 consonants {#ka-Na, ca-Ya,#}
{#wa-Ra, ta-na#} and {#pa-ma;#} the term {#Uzman#} (q. v.) the sibi-
lants {#ha, Sa, za, sa;#} and the semivowels {#ya, ra, la, va#} are
termed {#antaHsTA,#} because their position in the system of
the vaidik gramm. is between the {#sparSa#} and {#Uzman;#} (s. v.
{#antaHsTA#} p. 117{%a,%} 1. 49 the words ‘vowels and consonants’
are a mistake for ‘{#sparSa#} and {#Uzman#}’).] E. {#DA#} with {#ni#} and
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>
[Page248-b+ 56]

<L>6079<pc>248-b<k1>aBinirmukta<k2>aBinirmukta
{#aBinirmukta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) <sup>1</sup> Left, quitted.
<sup>2</sup> One asleep at sunset. [The last meaning, given by the
{%Amarak.%} and {%Hemach.,%} owes its origin probably to {%Manu%}
2. 221. or a similar passage, where the word is to be joined
with the word {#sUryeRa,#} both words meaning literally ‘one
left by the sun’, scil. while asleep (this ellipsis resulting
from the preceding verse 2. 220.); the same remark applies
to the meaning {%‘one asleep at sunrise’,%} given by the Koshas
to {#aByudita,#} for in {%Manu%} 2. 221. the latter word is also to
be coupled with {#sUryeRa,#} when both these words mean liter-
ally: ‘one {%towards%} whom the sun has risen’ (scil. while
asleep), the meaning {%towards%} of {#aBi#} in {#aByudita#} resulting
from the beginning of verse 220., where {#aBi#} is {%karmaprav.%}
or the separable preposition, not the verbal prefix; {%Manu%}
2. 220. 221.: {#taM cedaByudiyAtsUryaH SayAnaM kAmacArataH#} ({%v. l.%} {#kA-#}
{#makArataH#}) {#. nimlocedvApyavijYAnAjjapannupavaseddinam .. sUryeRa#}
{#hyaBinirmuktaH SayAno'ByuditaSca yaH . prAyaScittamakurvARo yu-#}
{#ktaH syAnmahatEnasA;#} and comp. {%Gotama,%} as quoted by {%Kullūka:%}
{#sUryAByudito brahmacArI tizWedaharaBuYjAno'ByastamitaSca rAtriM#}
{#japansAvitrIm#}. The comm. on the {%Amarak.,%} however, ap-
pear to have lost sight of this origin of the meanings ‘asleep
at sunset’ and ‘at sunrise’ of the named words, for {%Rā-%}
{%yamuk.%} e. g. gives the etymological meaning of {#aBi-#}
{#nirmukta#} ‘completely free from feeling, evening work or de-
sign, i. e. completely insensible or disengaged’: {#aBi sarva-#}
{#to BAvena sAyantanena karmaRA niScayena muktaH;#} and he explains
{#aByudita#} as a deriv. of {#aByudita#} with taddh. aff. {#ac,#} re-
ferring it to the {%Gaṇa%} to {%Pāṇ.%} V. 2. 127., when its literal
meaning would be ‘having a sunrise’: {#aByuditamaByudayaH sU-#}
{#ryasya tadyogAdarSaAdyac . BuktA brAhmaRA itivat#} (comp. {%Siddh.%}
{%Kaum.%} fol. 186{%a,%} 1. 11).] E. {#muc#} with {#nir#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6087<pc>249-a<k1>aBiniveSa<k2>aBiniveSa
{#aBiniveSa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Application of thought, lean-
ing towards, attachment; e. g. {%Yājnav.:%} {#evaMvftto'vinItA-#}
{#tmA vitaTABiniveSavAn#} ({%Mit.:%} {#vita° = asatkAryABinive-#}
{#SavAn;#} comp. {#aBiniveSin#}); or {%Manu:%} {#paradravyezvaBiDyAnaM#}
{#manasAnizwacintanam . vitaTABiniveSaSca triviDaM karma mAnasam#}
({%Kullūka:%} {#vita° nAsti paralokaH . deha evAtmeti;#} {%Medhā-%}
{%tithi:%} {#pUrvapakzasya sidDAntatvena grahaRam,#} i. e. adhering to false
doctrines); or {%Śakunt.:%} {#baliaMkKu me ahiRiveso#} (i. e. {#ba-#}
{#lIyAnKalu me'BiniveSaH#}); {%comm.%} {#ahi° = aBilAzaH,#} i. e.
my attachment is indeed very strong; or {%Kāśikā:%} {#kalyARe#}
{#'BiniveSaH,#} or {#pApe'BiniveSaH#}. <sup>2</sup> Intentness, determination
of purpose, determined resolution, tenacity; e. g. {%Kumāra-%}
{%sambh.:%} {#aTAnurUpABiniveSatoziRA kftAByujYA guruRA garI-#}
{#yasA…jagAma gOrI SiKaraM SiKaRqivat#} (quoted also by
{%Vyāḍi%} on {%Hemach.%} 6. 136. or v. 1500.; {%Mallin.:%} {#aBi° = A-#}
{#graha#}); or {%Śisupālab.:%} {#apetayudDABiniveSasOmyo harirhariprasTa-#}
{#maTa pratasTe#} ({%Mallin.:%} = {#apeto yudDe'BiniveSa Agraho yasya#}
{#sa SAntakroDa ityarTaH#}); or {%Raghuv.:%} {#…janakAtmajAyAM ni-#}
{#tAntarUkzABiniveSamISam . na kaScana BrAtfzu tezu Sakto nize-#}
{#dDumAsIt;#} or {%Prabodhach.:%} {#tato devyA#} (scil. {#vizRuBaktyA#})
{#samupajAtABiniveSamuktam#} ({%comm.:%} = {#utpannaH…aBimA-#}
{#no yatra yasyAM kriyAyAM yaTA syAttaTA,#} i. e. after having
taking a proper resolution). <sup>3</sup> (In the {%Yoga%} philosophy.)
The instinctive (but unjustifiable) clinging to life and bodily
enjoyment, (‘which is alike in the unthinking worm as in
the wise man’); it is one of the five {#kleSAH#} ({%Yoga Sūtra:%}
{#avidyAsmitArAgadvezABiniveSAH paYca kleSAH#}) or afflictions
of mind which impede the apprehension of true knowledge;
comp. {#viparyaya#}. ({%Yoga Sūtra:%} {#svarasavAhI viduzo'pi taTA#}
{#rUQo#}--{%v. l.%} but apparently less correct: {#viduzo'pi tanva-#}
[Page249-b+ 56]
{#nubanDo--'BiniveSaH;#} a comm.: {#sarvasya prARina iyamAtmA-#}
{#SIrnityA Bavati . mA na BUvaM BUyAsamiti . na cAnanuBUtamara-#}
{#RaDarmakasyEzA BavatyAtmASIH . etayA ca pUrvajanmAnuBavaH pratI-#}
{#yate . sa cAyamaBiniveSaH kleSaH svarasavAhI kfmerapi jAtamA-#}
{#trasya pratyakzAnumAnAgamErasaMBAvito maraRatrAsa ucCedadfzwyAtmakaH#}
{#pUrvajanmAnuBUtaM maraRaduHKamanumApayati . yaTA cAyamatyantarUQezu#}
{#dfSyate kleSastaTA viduzo'pi vijYAtapUrvAparAntasya rUQaH#} &c.;
{%Bhojadeva:%} {#svasya rasena saMskAreREva vahatIti svarasavAhI . pUrva-#}
{#janmAnuBUtamaraRaduHKAnuBavavAsanAbalAdBayarUpaH samupajAyamAnaH#}
{#SarIravizayAdiBirmama viyogo mA BUdityanvahamanubanDarUpaH#}
{#sarvasyEvA kfmerbrahmaparyantaM#} (from the worm up to Brahmā) {#ni-#}
{#mittaM vinA pravartamAno'BiniveSAKyaH kleSaH;#} {%Mallinātha%} is
therefore wrong in his philosophical explanation on {%Sīsupāl.%}
4. 55., when he renders in the quoted Yoga S. {#aBiniveSaH#}
{#= kAryAkAryezvAgrahaH#}.) E. {#viS#} with {#ni#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6088<pc>249-b<k1>aBiniveSana<k2>aBiniveSana

{#niveSa#} 3.; {%Lalitavist.:%} {#anAtmapratyavekzADarmAloKamuKamAtmAna-#}
{#BiniveSanatAyE saMvartate#} ‘…to the condition of not clinging
to one's own self, i. e. to being indifferent of one's own
life’. E. {#viS#} with {#ni#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>6091<pc>249-b<k1>aBinizkramaRa<k2>aBinizkramaRa
{#aBinizkramaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Going out or forth, leaving,
quitting; e. g. {%Lalitav.:%} {#aBizekaBUmiDarmAlokamuKamavakramaRa-#}
{#janmABinizkramaRa°°°° saMdarSanatAyE saMvartate#}. In Buddhistic
writings it implies moreover the leaving of the house or the
renouncing of the world for the sake of becoming an an-
chorite. (Comp. {%Burnouf'%}s {%Lotus de la bonne loi%} p. 333. 334.)
E. {#kram#} with {#nir#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6092<pc>249-b<k1>aBinizkrAnta<k2>aBinizkrAnta

the preceding and {%Burnouf'%}s {%Lotus%} &c. p. 333. E. {#kram#} with

<L>6093<pc>249-b<k1>aBinizwAna<k2>aBinizwAna
{#aBinizwAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) <sup>1</sup> A sound (esp. a vowel) of the
alphabet in general; e. g. {%Gobhila-Gṛhya S.:%} {#GozavadAdyantara-#}
{#ntasTaM dIrGABinizwAnAntaM kftaM nAma daDyAdetadatadDitamayugdAntaM#}
{#strIRAm;#} (comp. {%Manu%} 2. 33.). <sup>2</sup> The {%Visarga;%} e. g. {%Āsvalāy.%}
{%Gṛhya S.:%} {#nAma cAsmE dadyurGozavadAdyantarantasTamaBinizwAnAntaM#}
{#dvyakzaraM caturakzaraM vA dvyakzaraM pratizWAkAmaScaturakzaraM brahmavarcasakAmaH#}
{#yugmAni tvevaM puMsAmayujAni strIRAm;#} ({%Nārāyaṇa%} explains:
{#aBinizwAno visarjanIyaH . so'nte yasya tattaToktam#} &c., and
exemplifies this injunction by the male names: {#rudradevaH, nA-#}
{#gadevaH, BadradattaH, devadattaH, SivadattaH, devasvAmI, vasuSarmA, ja-#}
{#nArdanaH, devaGozaH, purandaraH, vizRuSarmA,#} and by the female
names: {#suBadrA, sAvitrI, satyadA, vasudA;#} comp. s. v. {#nAmaka-#}
[Page250-a+ 56]
{#raRa#}).--[The reading {#aBinizWAna#} which occurs in Mss., is
incorrect.--The Pandits who have published {%Pāṇini,%} supply
in their comm. on VIII. 3. 86. the word {#anyatarasyAm (= vA)#}
from the preceding Sūtra, and construe thus, besides {#aBi-#}
{#nizwAna,#} an optional form {#aBinistAna;#} {%Patanjali%} and his
comm. have no gloss on this Sūtra, but neither the {%Kāśikā%}
nor the {%Siddhāntak.%} admit of an option in the Sūtra 86., nor
is a form {#aBinistAna#} given by these works or in the {%Dhātu-%}
comm. of {%Mādhava, Maitreya%} &c., or in the {%Dhātupārāyaṇa%} of
{%Hemach.%} s. r. {#stan#}.] E. {#stan#} with {#nis#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6100<pc>250-a<k1>aBinihita<k2>aBinihita
{#aBinihita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Suppressed.--{#a-#}
{#Binihita#} is called <sup>a.</sup> in the {%Ṛgv.-Prātiś.%} the {#sanDi#} (q. v.)
which is produced when the vowel {#a#} in the beginning of
a word is suppressed after a final {#o#} or {#e;#} <sup>b.</sup> in the {%Ṛgv.-,%}
{%Vājas.-%} and {%Atharv.-Prātiśākhyas%} the {#svarita#} (q. v.) which
is produced in consequence of an {%anudātta%} {#a#} (in the be-
ginning of a word) being suppressed after a final {%udātta%} {#o#}
or {#e#}. The {%Taittir.-Prāt.%} calls the latter {#aBinihata#} (acc. to
{%Weber, Ind. Stud.%} IV. p. 135). E. {#DA#} with {#ni#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6101<pc>250-a<k1>aBinihnava<k2>aBinihnava

{#hnava (nihnavABinihnavO)#} are the ritual names of the verses
of the {%Araṇyagāna%} V. 2. 21. and 22. (not met with in the
{%Sāmaveda;%} acc. to {%Benfey'%}s careful compilation in {%Weber'%}s
{%Ind. Stud.%} III. p. 222). E. {#aBi#} and {#nihnava#} or {#hnu#} with {#ni#}
and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>

<L>6102<pc>250-a<k1>aBinIta<k2>aBinIta
{#aBinIta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Brought near or
towards; e. g. (fig., to the understanding, intelligible) in a
quotation of {%Jayam.%} on the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#BAvikatvamiti prAhuH#}
{#prabanDavizayaM guRam . pratyakzA iva dfSyante yatrArTA BUtaBAvinaH .#}
{#citrodAttAdButArTatvaM kaTAyA svaBinItatA#} ({%its easy under-%}
{%standing%}) {# . SabdAnukulatA ceti tasya hetuM pracakzate#}. <sup>2</sup> Performed
(as a drama). <sup>3</sup> Fit, proper, suitable; e. g. {%Mah. Śāntip.:%}
{#asminneva prakaraRe DanaMjayamudAraDIH . aBinItataraM vAkyami-#}
{#tyuvAca yuDizWiraH#}. <sup>4</sup> Highly ornamented or finished. <sup>5</sup> Even-
minded, placid, patient. <sup>6</sup> Impatient. [The two latter
meanings arise from the different manner in which the
verse of the {%Amarak.:%} {#yukte'tisaMskfte marziRyaBinIto#} &c.
may be read, viz. either {#°te marziRi#} or {#te'marziRi;#} hence
{%Bharata, Subhūti, Ramānātha%} &c. = {#akroDana#} (or {#akroDa#})
or = {#akzamAvat;#} {%Bhanūd.,%} however, only = {#kzantf#} (i. e.
[Page250-b+ 56]
{#marzin#}); other Koshas have only the meaning ‘impatient’;
e. g. {%Medinī, Śabdaratnāv.:%} = {#amarzin,#} {%Ajayapāla:%} = {#a-#}
{#marzavat,#} probably also {%Jaṭādhara:%} {#aBinItastrizu nyAyye#}
{#saMskfte'marzavatyapi;#} and {%Hemachandra'%}s {#aBinItastu nyAyye ma-#}
{#rziRi saMskfte#} is probably also to be read {#nyAyye'ma°,#}
for the {%Viśvaprak.%} explains: {#aBinIto BavennyAyye saMskftA-#}
{#marziRorapi#}. The meaning ‘placid’ seems more congenial
with the other meanings of the word; and the meaning
‘impatient’ refers perhaps to an E. {#a#} neg. and {#BinIta#}--
compare {#vinIta#} and the Pref. on the particle {#aBi#}--.]
<sup>7</sup> Friendly, kind ({%Wilson%}). E. {#nI#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<sup>2</sup> Gesture, expressive articulation ({%Wilson%}). Comp. {#aBinaya#}.
E. {#nI#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6108<pc>250-b<k1>aBinna<k2>aBinna
{#aBinna#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-nnaH-nnA-nnam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not cut, not
rent, not broken; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#virugnodagraDArAgraH kuli-#}
{#So mama#} (i. e. of Rāvaṇa) {#vakzasi . aBinnaM SataDAtmAnaM manyate#}
{#balinaM balI;#} or {#jalaniDimagaman…salilasamudayErmahAtara-#}
{#NgErBuvanaBarakzamamapyaBinnavelam;#} or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#indro…BUyoBUyo#}
{#rayimidasya varDayannaBinne Kilye ni daDAti devayum#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%}
{#aBinne SatruBiraBedye Kilye…anyErgantumaSakye sTale,#} i. e.
impenetrable). <sup>2</sup> Undivided, one; e. g. (Brahman) {%Śaṅkara%}
in the comm. on the {%Taittir.-Up.:%} {#asO yo'yamekamaBinna-#}
{#mAtmatattvaM na paSyati#} &c.; or (the Soul in) a quotation from
the Buddhists by {%Vijnānāch.%} on the {%Sāṅkhya-Prav.:%} {#aBi-#}
{#nno'pi budDyAtmA viparyAsanidarSanEH . grAhyagrAhakasaMvittiBeda-#}
{#vAniva lakzyate#}. <sup>3</sup> Not different, same, identical; e. g. {%Pra-%}
{%bodhach.:%} {#paSyAmi yogAYjanaSudDadarSano jaganmiTo BinnamaBinna-#}
{#mISvarAt;#} or {%Bharatas.%} on the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#SlizwamizwamanekArTa-#}
{#mekarUpAnvitaM vacaH . tadaBinnapadaM BinnapadaM BinnapadaprAyamiti dviDA#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-nnaH#}) (In Arithmetic.) An integer, a whole number.
E. {#a#} neg. and {#Binna#}.
<LEND>

<L>6109<pc>250-b<k1>aBinnaka<k2>aBinnaka

quite entire. <sup>2</sup> Not quite identical ({%Siddhāntak.%}). E. {#aBinna,#}
taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

taddh. aff. {#tarap#}.
<LEND>

<L>6111<pc>250-b<k1>aBinnataraka<k2>aBinnataraka
{#aBinnataraka#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-rakaH-rikA-rakam#}) The same as the
preceding; e. g. in a quotation by the {%Gaṇaratnam.:%} {#aBi-#}

<L>6112<pc>251-a<k1>aBinnatA<k2>aBinnatA
{#aBinnatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) <sup>1</sup> Unbrokenness, wholeness. <sup>2</sup> Oneness,
undividedness. <sup>3</sup> Sameness, identity. E. {#aBinna,#} taddh.

<LEND>

<L>6113<pc>251-a<k1>aBinnapadaSlizwa<k2>aBinnapadaSlizwa
{#aBinnapadaSlizwa#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-zwam#}) (In Rhetoric.) A species
of paronomasia, considered as an {#alaNkAra#} (q. v.) or elegant
mode of expression, viz. a connexion of words which ad-
mit of a double interpretation, the sentence consisting chiefly
of {%such%} words (and not of words which would admit but
of one sense); an instance is the following verse of the
{%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#BuvanaBarasahAnalaNGyaDAmnaH pururuciratnaBfto gurUrude-#}
{#hAn . SramaviDuravilInakUrmanakrAndaDatamudUQaBuvo girInahIMSca#}
(scil. {#jalaniDimagaman#}), where all the compounds are at-
tributes as well of {#girIn#} as of {#ahIn,#} according to the
double sense in which they may be taken. See {#Slizwa#} or
{#Sleza#}. E. {#aBinna-pada#} and {#Slizwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6114<pc>251-a<k1>aBinnaparikarmAzwaka<k2>aBinnaparikarmAzwaka
{#aBinnaparikarmAzwaka#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-kam#}) (In Algebra.) The eight
elementary operations (of addition, subtraction, multipli-
cation, division, square, square-root, cube and cube-root)
as applicable to whole numbers; comp. {#BinnaparikarmAzwaka#}
(these operations applied to fractions). E. {#aBinna-pari-#}
{#karman#} and {#azwaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>6115<pc>251-a<k1>aBinyAsa<k2>aBinyAsa
{#aBinyAsa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-saH#}) (Literally: Combination, mix-
ture; esp. in Medicine.) A variety of fever, viz. a mixed
remittent or synochus fever, supposed to be produced by
the morbid state of the three temperamental elements, air,
bile and phlegm collectively; the patient is described by
{%Suśruta%} as ‘being neither too warm nor too cold, not quite
conscious, wandering in his mind, hoarse, with a sharp
taste, dry throat, void of perspiration and not having the
natural excretions, hiccupping, without appetite, dull, pant-
ing (or sighing), lying prostrate, impeded in speech, drowsy
and with contracted limbs’; the cure of this fever is believed
either very difficult or impossible. It is also called {#hatOjas,#}
as the patient looses his strength by this fever, or from the
‘combination’ of the causes which produce it, {#sannipAtajvara,#}
{#sarvAtmakajvara, sarvadozasamutTajvara, sarvajajvara, sarvajvara#}. E.
{#as#} (cl. 4.) with {#ni#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY;#} scil. {#jvara#}.
<LEND>

<L>6116<pc>251-a<k1>aBinyAsajvara<k2>aBinyAsajvara
{#aBinyAsajvara#}¦ Karmadh. or Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) The same as
the preceding. E. {#aBinyAsa#} and {#jvara#}.
<LEND>

<L>6123<pc>251-b<k1>aBipadma<k2>aBipadma
{#aBipadma#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-dmaH-dmA-dmam#}) <sup>1</sup> Every where beau-

adorned with a lotus flower; comp. {#padmalAYCana#}. [Both in-
terpretations of this word are given by the comm. on the
{%Ādip.%} of the {%Mahābh.%} v. 7013: {#dfzwvA tu tAnmattagajendrarUpAmpa-#}
{#YcABipadmAniva vAraRendrAn;#} {%Nīlak.:%} {#aBitaH padmA lakzmIryezAM#}
{#tAn . sarvANgasundarAnityarTaH;#} {%Arjunam.:%} = {#padmavinduyutAn;#}
both comm. mention moreover, instead of {#aBipadmAn,#} a
{%v. l.%} {#atipadmAn#} which {%Nīlak.%} interprets in the same sense:
{#atipadmAniti pAWe sa evArTaH,#} but {%Arjunam.:%} {#padmaH puRqarI-#}
{#kanAmA diggajaH . tasmAdatiSayAnityarTaH,#} i. e. ‘surpassing the
elephant-atlas Padma (= Puṇḍarīka)’; {%Nīlak.%} mentions, be-
sides, a bad {%v. l.%} {#atimattAn#}.] E. 1. {#aBi#} and {#padmA,#} 2. {#aBi#}
and {#padma#}.
<LEND>

<L>6124<pc>251-b<k1>aBipanna<k2>aBipanna
{#aBipanna#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-nnaH-nnA-nnam#}) <sup>1</sup> Come near, run
towards; ({%Viśvapr., Śabdaratn., Ajayap., Bhūripray.:%} = {#a-#}
{#Bidruta#}). <sup>2</sup> Seeking refuge ({%Med., Hemach., Trikāṇḍ.:%} = {#Sa-#}
{#raRArTin#}). <sup>3</sup> Approached by (with a friendly purpose),
protected, saved; e. g. {%Ādip.%} of the {%Mahābh.:%} {#yatra rAjA#}
{#kuruSrezWaH parIkzinnAma vE#} ({%v. l.%} {#sa#}) {#dvija . takzakeRa BujaNgena Da-#}
{#kzyate kila so'dya vE#} ({%v. l.%} {#kila tatra vE#}) {#. gacCAmyahaM#} (i. e.
Kāśyapa) {#taM tvaritaH sadyaH kartumapajvaram . mayABipannaM#} ({%Nīlak.:%}
= {#trAtaM#}) {#taM cApi na sarpo Darzayizyati;#} or {%Suśruta:%} {#tadidaM ba-#}
{#hugUQArTaM cikitsAvIjamIritam . kuSalenABipannaM#} (i. e. culti-
vated by a clever physician) {#tadvahuDABiprarohati#}. <sup>3</sup> Obtained,
appropriated; ({%Ajayap.:%} = {#svIkfta,#} {%Śabdamuktām.:%} = {#a-#}
{#NgIkfta#}). <sup>4</sup> Overcome, afflicted; ({%Amarak., Med., Ajayap.:%}
= {#aBigrasta;#} {%Viśvapr., Śabdaratn., Bhūripr.:%} = {#grasta#}); e. g.
{%Suśruta:%} {#vAtABipanne nayane,#} or {#pittABipanne nayane,#} or {#kaPA-#}
{#Bipanne nayane,#} or {#dfzwirdozABipannA,#} or {#PenaM ca prasfjati tatsa-#}
{#KABipannaH#} (i. e. one possessed by the Skandāpasmāra).
<sup>5</sup> Unfortunate, calamitous ({%Amarak., Med.:%} = {#Apadgata,#} {%Vi-%}
{%śvapr., Śabdaratn., Bhūripr.:%} = {#vipadgata#}). <sup>6</sup> Guilty ({%Ama-%}
{%rak., Med.%} &c. = {#aparAdDa#}). <sup>7</sup> Far, remote ({%Ajayap.:%} = {#vi-#}
{#prakfzwa,#} {%Śabdamuktām.:%} = {#dUra#}). <sup>8</sup> Dead, deceased (i. e. gone
forth; comp. {#preta#}); e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#svaBAvahInErmfgapakziGozEH#}
{#krandanti BartAramivABipannam#} ({%Jayam., Bharatas.%} &c.: {#aBipannaM#}
{#= mftam#}). E. {#pad#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>6127<pc>252-a<k1>aBipitva<k2>aBipitva

({%Yāska:%} = {#kvABiprAptiM kuruTaH#}); or {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Atharv.:%} {#tasmA#}
{#idanDaH suzumA sudakzamihABipitvaM karate gfRAnaH#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%}
= {#asmadaBimataprAptiM karotu#}). <sup>2</sup> Approach (of the day), day-
break, dawn; e. g. {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Sāmav.:%} {#divABipitve'vasA-#}
{#gamizWA#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#divasasyABipatane prAtaHkAle#}). <sup>3</sup> An oc-
casion to be approached or observed, a solemnity, a sacri-
fice; e. g. {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Atharv.:%} {#indro'Bipitvezu raRyati#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%}
{#tasya pUrvoktasya sarvasyABipitvezvaBiprAptizvindro raRyati . ra-#}
{#mate . yadvA pUrvoktAnAM barhirAdInAmaBiprAptizu#} &c.); or {%Ṛgv.:%}
{#uta na IM tvazwA gantvacCA smatsUriBiraBipitve sajozAH#} ({%Sā-%}
{%yaṇa:%} {#aBipitve'Bigantavye yajYe#}); or {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Vājas.:%} {#api#}
{#yaTA yuvAno matsaTA no viSvaM jagadaBipitve manIzA#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%}
{#aBipitve'BipatanIye'smadyajYe;#} {%Mahīdh.%} however gives to
the word in this verse the meaning 1., viz. = {#aBipatane#}

near time, a proximate occasion; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#sanatkakzIvAM~#}
{#aBipitve ahnAm#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#divasAnAM maDye'Bipitve saMni-#}
{#hite'hani sanat…aBipitvaSabda AsannakAlavAcI prapi-#}
{#tvaSabda itivat#}). <sup>6</sup> Any thing obtained (e. g. wealth); e. g.
{%Ṛgv.:%} {#vfkzAScinme aBipitve arAraRuH#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#me mayABi-#}
{#pitve pUrvokte Dane'BiprApte sati#} &c.). <sup>7</sup> Departure, decline
of the day; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#A vaH pItayo'Bipitve'hnAmimA#}
{#astaM navasvaH iva gman#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#ahnAmaBipitve'Bipatane sa-#}
{#mAptO#}); or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#yo vaH sunotyaBipitve ahnAm#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%}
{#ahnAmaBipitve'Bipatane tftIyasavana ityarTaH#}). E. {#Ap#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#tvan;#} but see the E. of {#apapitva#}.

<L>6154<pc>253-a<k1>aBiprAya<k2>aBiprAya
{#aBiprAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Intention, purpose, design; e. g.
{%Rāmāy.:%} {#nABiprAyamaBijYAya mamEvaM vaktumarhasi;#} or {%Nyāya S.:%}
{#aviSezABihite'rTe vakturaBiprAyAdarTAntarakalpanA vAkCalam;#}
or {%Vijnānabh.:%} {#yacCAstrezu SarIradvayameva SrUyate talliNgaSarI-#}
{#rADizWAnaSarIrayoranyonyaniyatatvena sUkzmatvena cEkatABiprAyA-#}
{#diti#} ‘because their oneness is meant to be conveyed by
&c.’; or {%Daṇḍin%} (as quoted by {%Jayam.%}): {#taM BAvikamiti#}
{#prAhuH prabanDavizayaM guRam . BAvaH kaveraBiprAyaH kAvyezvAsIdvya-#}
{#vasTitaH;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#yadyakalpsyadaBiprAyo yodDuM rakzaHpateH sva-#}
{#yam#} &c. <sup>2</sup> ‘Goal’: a name or epithet of Viṣṇu; the 871st of
his thousand names in the {%Anuśāsanap.%} of the {%Mahābh.;%} be-
cause he is the goal of the world which is finally merged
in him: {%Mahābh.:%} {#aBiprAyo priyArho'rhaH#} &c. ({%Gaṅgādhara:%}
{#puruzArTecCuBirnityamaBipreyata ityasO . ABimuKyenAtra jagatprEti#}
{#kAle'Ta lIyate#}). <sup>3</sup> Opinion, belief, meaning; e. g. {%Sāhityad.:%}
{#kecittu karmaRi kuSala iti rUQAvudAharanti . tezAmayamaBi-#}
{#prAyaH . kuSaM lAti . iti vyutpattilaByaH kuSagrAhirUpo muKyo#}
{#'rTaH…dakzarUpamarTaM boDayati;#} or {%Bharatas.%} on the
{%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#BfNgaH…tAM dadaMSa . yataH karaM dfzwvA raktapadmami-#}
{#tyaBisaMDiraBiprAyo yasya#} &c.; or {%Manu:%} {#tezAM svaM svamaBi-#}
{#prAyamupalaBya pfTakpfTak . samastAnAM ca kAryezu vidaDyAdDita-#}
{#mAtmanaH#}. <sup>4</sup> Motive, reason, consideration; e. g. {%Jaiminīya-%}
{%nyāyam.:%} {#pUjyAnAM pratyakzanAmagrahaRamayuktamityaBiprAyeRa#} (from
this reason) {#hUtaSabdasTAne hotfSabdaH paWyate;#} or {%Jayam.%} on
the {%Bhaṭṭik.%} {#(aboDi duHsTaM trElokyam): trElokyaM nihanmi#}
{#yasminhanyamAne'pi sItAdruho'pi naSyanti . ityaBiprAyeRa#}
(from this reason) {#duHsTamaboDi;#} or {%Ved. Sāra:%} {#idamajYAnaM#}
{#samazwivyazwyaBiprAyeRa#} ({%through the consideration of its being%}
{%taken collectively or separately%}) {#ekamanekamiti ca vyavahriyate .#}
{#taTA hi yaTA vfkzARAM samazwyaBiprAyeRa vanamityekatvavyapadeSaH#}
&c. <sup>5</sup> Implied sense, bearing of a word, of a sentence &c.
(used in the same way as {#BAva,#} and in distinction from
{#arTa,#} the obvious or literal sense of a word &c.); e. g. {%Dā-%}
{%yabh.:%} {#vizRuvacane ca banDupadaM mAtulAdyABiprAyam;#} or {%Sāyaṇa%}
(in the comm. on the {%Ṛgv.%}): {#gAmaSvamitijAtyaBiprAyameka-#}
{#vacanam;#} or {%Bharatas.%} on the {%Bhaṭṭik.%} (1. 6.): {#viSvakarmaRA#}
{#nedfSI SoBanA purI nirmitA . ata imAM vilokyedfkpurI-#}
{#nirmARe cezwA jAtetyaBiprAyaH#}. <sup>6</sup> Reference, relation; e. g.
{%Pāṇini:%} {#svaritaYitaH kartraBiprAye kriyAPale#} ({%Kāśikā:%} {#kartAraM#}
{#cetkriyAPalamaBiprEti#}). <sup>7</sup> Any thing meant or intended, but
[Page253-b+ 56]
not real, a semblance; e. g. {%Ṛgv. Prātiś.:%} {#vivfttyaBiprAyezu#}
{#ca pIvo annAM~ rayivfDaH#} ‘amongst the semblances of hiatus’
(i. e. amongst sandhis of final vowels and beginning semi-
vowels, which are not real hiatus, but may be considered
as such); or {#…aBiprAyAMSca paripAdayanti#}. E. {#i#} with
{#pra#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6157<pc>253-b<k1>aBipreta<k2>aBipreta
{#aBipreta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Intended, designed;

{#haviraBipretaM syAt#} &c.; or {%Hitopad.:%} {#yaTABipretamanuzWIyatAm#}.

{#pretAKyAne kfYaH ktvARamulO;#} or {%Kāśikā:%} {#dravyamayaM mARavakaH .#}
{#aBipretArTAnAM pAtraBUta ityarTaH;#} or {#kUjanamanaBipretaM kurvannasO#}
{#pratilomaH;#} or {%Rāmāy.:%} {#pUrvErayamaBipreto gato mArgo'nugamyate;#}
or {#na te kiMcidaBipretaM na kartumahamutsahe . Atmano jIvitenApi#}
{#karizye te priyaM priye;#} or {%Bhāgav. Pur.:%} {#paracCandamaviduzA#}
{#puzyamARo janena saH . anaBipretamApannaH pratyAKyAtumanISvaraH#}.
<sup>3</sup> Meant, implied; e. g. {%Jaimini S.:%} {#sahatvaM cEkakarmye syAttade-#}
{#katvAttvaco'naBipretaM prakftitvAt#} &c.; or {%Mitākṣ.:%} {#…pra-#}
{#yogAntarakaraRe dvEguRyAtikramo'BipretaH;#} or the same on a
penance entailed by the theft of gold: {#suvarRaparimARAdarvA-#}
{#gapItyaBipretam#}. <sup>4</sup> Believed, assumed; e. g. {%Vijnānāch.%} on the
{%Sāṅkhya Prav.:%} {#idAnIM nAstikABipretA api banDahetavo ni-#}
{#rAkartavyAH#}. E. {#i#} with {#pra#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>6161<pc>253-b<k1>aBiplava<k2>aBiplava
{#aBiplava#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) A religious act, forming part of
the sacrifice {#gavAmayana#} (q. v.) and consisting of ceremonies
which last six days; the ceremony of the first and sixth of
these days is called {#jyotis,#} of the second and fourth {#go,#}
of the third and fifth {#Ayus#} ({%Kalpavyākhyā:%} {#jyotirgOrA-#}
{#yurgOrAyurjyotiriti zaqaho'Biplava ityucyate#}); the {#aBiplava#}
recurs several times at the various stages of the Gavā-
mayana and bears its name, according to a legend of the
{%Śatapatha-Br.,%} because the Ādityās, rivalling with the Angi-
rasas in the precedence of getting into the paradise, {%jumped%}
into it by means of the hymns which occur in this ceremony
{#‘aTAdityASca ha vA aNgirasaSca . uBaye prAjApatyA asparDanta#}
{#vayaM pUrve svargaM lokamezyAmo vayaM pUrva iti . ta AdityAH . ca-#}
{#turBi stomEScaturBiH pfzWErlaGuBiH sAmaBiH svargaM lokamaByaplavanta#}
{#yadaByaplavanta tasmAdaBiplavAH’#}. E. {#plu#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>

<L>6162<pc>253-b<k1>aBipluta<k2>aBipluta
{#aBipluta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Overflowed, overrun;
[Page254-a+ 56]
esp. {%figur.%} overwhelmed, strongly affected by, labouring
under; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#rajasABiplutAM nArIM narasya hyupagacCataH#}
&c.; or {%Yājnav.:%} {#pitari prozite prete vyasanABiplute'pi vA#}
&c.; or {%Hitop.:%} {#janmamftyujarAvyADivedanABiraBiplutam . saM-#}
{#sAram#} &c. E. {#plu#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6163<pc>254-a<k1>aBibala<k2>aBibala
{#aBibala#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-lam#}) (In Rhetoric.) An appointment
or rendezvous by ruse or disguise; ({%Sāhityad.:%} {#aBibalama-#}
{#BisaMDiSCalena yaH#}); one of the twelve incidents of that
part of a drama which is called {#garBa#} q. v.; an instance,
alleged by the {%Sāhityad.,%} is the meeting of Kāñchanamālā
with Vasantaka disguised, in the third act of the {%Ratnā-%}
{%valī.%} (The first Calc. ed. of the {%Sāhityad.%} p. 161 and {%Bal-%}
{%lantyne'%}s ed. v. 365 read this word {#aDibala,#} {%Ball'%}s ed.
v. 375 {#aBibala#} and the first ed. p. 163 {#aBinaya#} {%n.;%} but the
latter can be scarcely correct.) E. {#aBi#} and {#bala#}.
<LEND>

viz. ear, skin, eye, tongue and nose; more usually called
{#budDIndriya#} or {#jYAnendriya#} qq. vv. E. {#buD#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#ktin#}.

<L>6168<pc>254-a<k1>aBiBava<k2>aBiBava
{#aBiBava#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The being overpowered or op-
pressed, defeat, discomfiture; e. g. {%Hitopad.:%} {#balavAnapi#}
{#nistejAH kasya nABiBavAspadam;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#baDena saMKye pi-#}
{#SitASanAnAM kzatrAntakasyABiBavena cEva . AQyaMBavizRuH#} &c.;
or {#tvayAdya laNkABiBave'tiharzAdduzwo…'ntarAtmAH#} or {%figu-%}
{%ratively: Śakunt.:%} {#sparSAnukUlA iva sUryakAntAstadanyatejo'Bi-#}
{#BavAdvamanti#} ‘like as the sun-stones, agreeable to the
touch (if left undisturbed in their position) emit fire
when they are overpowered by other (i. e. by the sun's)
fire’, ({%not:%} ‘when other fire comes to them’, as has been
proposed to render this passage); or {%Atharv.:%} {#aBIvarto#}
{#'BiBavaH sapatnakzayaRo maRiH,#} ‘the magic jewel which is
…defeat’, i. e. by which defeat is worked. <sup>2</sup> Becoming
latent, ceasing apparently to exist; in this sense esp. in
{%philosophical%} writings; e. g. {%Nyāya S.:%} {#aBivyaktO cABiBa-#}
{#vAt;#} or {%Yoga S.:%} {#vyutTAnaniroDasaMskArayoraBiBavaprAdurBA-#}
{#vO niroDalakzaRacittAnvayo niroDapariRAmaH;#} or {%Ved. Sū-%}
{%tra:%} {#anaBiBavaM ca darSayati#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#“…eza hyAtmA na#}
{#naSyati yaM brahmacaryeRAnuvindate”…#}); or {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%} {#sO-#}
{#kzmyAdvyavaDAnAdaBiBavAt…#} [{%Iswarak.:%} (scil. {#satAmapyarTA-#}
{#nAmanupalabDiH#}) {#yaTA sUryatejasABiBUtA grahanakzatratArakAdayo#}
{#nopalaByante#}]. <sup>3</sup> Humiliation, abatement of pride, (comp.
[Page254-b+ 56]
{#aBiBUta#} 4.); e. g. {%Bhartṛh.:%} {#niraBiBavasArAH parakaTAH#}. E.
{#BU#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>

<L>6173<pc>254-b<k1>aBiBA<k2>aBiBA
{#aBiBA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-BA#}) <sup>1</sup> The being overpowered or op-
pressed, discomfiture, calamity; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#sumaNgalaSca Sa-#}
{#kune BavAsi mA tvA kAcidaBiBA viSvyA vidat#} ‘be ominous,
bird, and may no calamity befall thee from any quarter’
({%Wilson%}); ({%Yāska:%} = {#aBiBUti;#} {%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#aBiBava#}); or
{%Atharv.:%} {#mA no vidadaBiBA#} &c.; or {#amIvAH sarvaScAtayannA-#}
{#SayadaBiBA itaH#}. <sup>2</sup> Overpowering, mastering (?); see the
following. Comp. {#aBiBava, aBiBavana, aBiBUti#}. E. {#BA#}
({%‘to be’;%} for this meaning of the rad. comp. {%Jayam.%} on
{%Bhaṭṭik.%} 10. 19.), with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#aN#}.
<LEND>

<L>6174<pc>254-b<k1>aBiBAyatana<k2>aBiBAyatana
{#aBiBAyatana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) (In Buddhistic doctrine.) ‘The
basis of mastership or superiority’; {#aBiBAyatanAni#} or the
(eight) bases of superiority are the (eight) mental accom-
plishments or superior powers of a man who by having
internally the {%idea of form,%} perceives externally <sup>1</sup> {%limited%} or
<sup>2</sup> {%illimited forms,%} either {%with agreeable%} or {%disagreeable colours,%}
by having internally the {%idea of absence of form%} perceives
externally <sup>3</sup> {%limited%} or <sup>4</sup> {%illimited forms,%} either, too, {%with%}
{%agreeable%} or {%disagreeable colours,%} and by having internally
the {%idea of absence of form%} perceives externally <sup>5</sup> {%dark-blue%}
{%forms with dark-blue colours, aspect or appearance, <sup>6</sup> yellow%}
{%forms with yellow colours, aspect or appearance, <sup>7</sup> red forms%}
{%with red colours, aspect or appearance,%} and <sup>8</sup> {%white forms%}
{%with white colours, aspect or appearance.%} See {%Burnouf's Lo-%}
{%tus de la bonne loi;%} append. XV. E. {#aBiBA#} 2. and {#Ayatana;#}
({%Burnouf 1. c.%} considers the word as a {%Pāli%} form represent-
ing the Sanskṛt {#aBiBvAyatana,#} i. e. {#aBiBu#} or {#aBiBU#} and
{#Ayatana,#} and renders it accordingly ‘the place or region
of the {%conqueror%}’; but as {#aBiBA = aBiBUti#} or {#aBiBava#}
may also have the active meaning, it seems better to adopt
the given E. and to take the word as a pure Sanskṛt
compound, meaning ‘that on which victory rests’, and
similar in formation to the Buddh. {#rUpAyatana#} or {#AkASA-#}
{#nantyAyatana#}).
<LEND>

<L>6175<pc>254-b<k1>aBiBAra<k2>aBiBAra
{#aBiBAra#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Overburdened, very
heavy; e. g. {%Śatapath.:%} {#sa vA azwAveva kftvo juhvAM gfhRAti .#}
{#caturupaBfti tadvajramaBiBAraM karoti#} (thus in {%Weber'%}s ed. III.
4. 4. 8.; but the E. I. H. Ms. 657 reads in the comm. of {%Sā-%}
{%yaṇa%} {#tadvajramatiBAraM karoti,#} as mentioned also in the {%various%}
{%readings%} of that ed.). E. {#aBi#} and {#BAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>6188<pc>255-a<k1>aBiBU<k2>aBiBU
{#aBiBU#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-BUH#}) I. <sup>1</sup> The same as the preceding;

{%Sāmav.%} or {%Atharv.:%} {#viSvAH pftanA aBiBUtaraM#} (the great con-
queror) {#naraH sajUstatakzurindram#}. <sup>2</sup> The name or epithet of
one of the divinities invoked in the ceremony {#annahoma#} (q. v.)
of the Aśvamedha sacrifice. E. {#BU#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<div n="P">II. Being everywhere; e. g. {%Vājas.:%} {#aBiBUrasyetAste paYca#}
{#diSaH kalpantAm#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} {#he akza yadvA he yajamAna tvamaBi-#}
{#BUrasi . aBiBavitA . aBito vyAptAsi#}). E. {#aBi#} and {#BU#}.
<LEND>

<L>6189<pc>255-a<k1>aBiBUta<k2>aBiBUta

{#magnasya dorBirBuvanasya BAram#}. <sup>2</sup> Overcome with, aggrieved
by; e. g. {%Mahābh. Vanap.:%} {#hfcCayenABiBUtAtmA BImasenamakA-#}
{#mayat;#} or {%Suśruta:%} {#tamo'BiBUte tasmiMstu nidrA viSati de-#}
{#hinAm;#} or {#pittABiBUte srehe#} &c.; or {#pitfgrahABiBUtaH#}.
<sup>3</sup> Made latent; (compare {#aBiBava#} 2.); e. g. {%Gauḍapāda%}
on the {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%} {#yadA sattvena rajastamasI aBiBUte tadA#}
&c.; or {#tamasABiBUte sattvarajasI#} &c. <sup>4</sup> Humiliated, humbled,
surpassed; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#tapovanaM prADyayanABiBUtasamuccara-#}
{#ccArupatatriSiYjam#}. <sup>5</sup> Confused, bewildered, perplexed; {%Ja-%}
[Page255-b+ 56]
{%tādhara%} (E. I. H. 217): {#itikartavyatAmUQe vihastavyAkulAvuBO .#}
{#aBiBUto'BimAyaSca vikrUro#} (? {%Rādhāk.:%} {#viklavo#}) {#vihvalo#}
{#'pi ca#}. E. {#BU#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
