<L>6190<pc>255-b<k1>aBiBUti<k2>aBiBUti
{#aBiBUti#}¦ Tatpur. 1. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> The being overpowered, de-
feat, discomfiture; e. g. {%Kiratārj.:%} {#aBiBUtiBayAdasUnataH su-#}
{#KamujJanti na DAma mAninaH#}. <sup>2</sup> Overpowering, defeating,
victory; in the Veda also used as epithet of a masc., e. g.
{%Ṛgv.:%} {#yuvaM SvetaM pedave…adattamaSvam . johutramaryo aBi-#}
{#BUtim#} ‘the horse which is victory (i. e. victorious) over
the enemy’; or {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Atharv.:%} {#ataH saMgfByABiBUta A Bara#}
‘(Indra) who is victory i. e. victorious (over the enemies)’.
Comp. the use of {#aBikzadA;#} but it is possible, too, to refer
the latter instances to {#aBiBUti#} 2. <sup>3</sup> Disrespect, humiliation.
<div n="P">2. m. f. n. ({#-tiH-tiH-ti#}) (ved.) Overpowering, defeat-
ing, victorious; e. g. {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Vājas.:%} {#A yAtvindro'vasa#}
{#upa…dyOrna kzatramaBiBUti puzyAt#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiBUti para-#}
{#kIyaM balamaBiBAvukaM kzatraM svakIyaM balaM tejo vA puzyAt;#} {%Ma-%}
{%hīdh.:%} {#kIdfSaM kzatram . aBiBUti . aBiBavanaSIlaM SUram;#} or
{#yo no durevo vfkatirdaBItistasminmATAmaBiBUtyojaH#} (where
{#aBiBUti#} and {#ojaH#} are not to be mistaken for a com-
pound; {%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiBUtyaBiBAvukamIjo balam#}). See also
the instances s. 1. 2. E. {#BU#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6191<pc>255-b<k1>aBiBUtyojas<k2>aBiBUtyojas

power of those who overcome or oppress, having the power
of enemies; being equal to them; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#tvazwA…tatakza#}

dered like in the foregoing instances). E. {#aBiBUti#} and {#ojas#}.

<L>6194<pc>255-b<k1>aBimata<k2>aBimata

{#taDyAnAdvA#}. E. {#man#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>6200<pc>256-a<k1>aBimantos<k2>aBimantos
{#aBimantos#}¦ Tatpur. ind. (ved.) (Probably.) To hurt, to in-
jure, to destroy, (comp. {%Nīlak.%} s. v. {#man#} with {#aBi#}); e. g.
{%Śatapath.:%} {#aTa hEka ulmukyena dahanti . tadu taTA na kuryAdeza#}
{#vE rudriyo'gniH sa hEnamISvaraH saputraM sapaSumaBimantoH#} ‘for it
is capable to injure (or to destroy) him with his sons and
cattle’; (for the construction of {#ISvara#} comp. {%Pāṇ.%} III. 4. 13.).
E. {#man#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#tosun#} (i. e. the genitive of
an obsolete base {#aBimantu,#} in the sense of the infinitive,
which in the classical dialect would be {#aBimantum;#} but with
the udātta on the second syllable, which accent the word
would not have, if it were the sixth case of a regular word
{#aBimantu;#} comp. {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 2. 50.).
<LEND>

<L>6206<pc>256-b<k1>aBimanyamAna<k2>aBimanyamAna

<L>6207<pc>256-b<k1>aBimanyu<k2>aBimanyu
{#aBimanyu#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-nyuH#}) A proper name of: <sup>a.</sup> A son of
the Manu Chākṣuṣa by Navalā; <sup>b.</sup> A son of Arjuna by
Subhadrā; <sup>c.</sup> A king of Orissa, who reigned after Vichi-
travīrya (comp. {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alt.%} II. p. 31); <sup>d.</sup> A king of
Kashmir, who reigned after Nāgārjuna (comp. {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind.%}
{%Alt.%} II. p. 413); <sup>e.</sup> Another king of Kashmir, who reigned
after Kshemagupta. E. {#aBi#} and {#manyu#}.
<LEND>

<L>6208<pc>256-b<k1>aBimanyupura<k2>aBimanyupura
{#aBimanyupura#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ram#}) The name of two towns in
Kashmir: the first founded by Abhimanyu, the successor
of Nāgārjuna, the second by the wife of Kshemagupta, in
commemoration of the reign of his successor Abhimanyu.
E. {#aBimanyu#} and {#pura#}.
<LEND>

<L>6209<pc>256-b<k1>aBimanyusvAmin<k2>aBimanyusvAmin
{#aBimanyusvAmin#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-mI#}) The name of a sanctuary
built by the wife of Kshemagupta in commemoration of the
reign of his successor Abhimanyu. E. {#aBimanyu#} and {#svAmin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6210<pc>256-b<k1>aBimara<k2>aBimara
{#aBimara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Killing, slaughter. <sup>2</sup> War, combat.
<sup>3</sup> Danger from one's own army, treachery. <sup>4</sup> A binding, a
tie or fetter; (the three first meanings in several Koshas,
the last in {%Jaṭādhara:%} {#aBimaro vaDabanDayoH#}). E. {#mf#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ap,#} or {#aBi#} and {#mara#}.
<LEND>

<L>6211<pc>256-b<k1>aBimarda<k2>aBimarda
{#aBimarda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rdaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Rubbing, friction. <sup>2</sup> Devastation
of a country &c. by an enemy, invasion. <sup>3</sup> War, battle.
<sup>4</sup> Spirituous liquor (? {%Hemach.:%} {#madya#}). E. {#mfd#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#ac#} or {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

See also {#aBimarza#}. E. {#mfS#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6218<pc>257-a<k1>aBimarza<k2>aBimarza

however, the more correct form; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#paradArABi-#}
{#marzezu pravfttAnnFnmahIpatiH…pravAsayet;#} or {%Śāntip. Mahābh.:%}
{#loBasya vaSamApannAH sarve Baratasattama . aprAptasyABimarzaM tu kurva-#}
{#nto manujAstataH . kAmo nAmAparastatra pratyapadyata vE praBo#}. E.
{#mfz (= mfS)#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6220<pc>257-a<k1>aBimarzaRa<k2>aBimarzaRa
{#aBimarzaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) <sup>1</sup> The same as {#aBimarSana,#} which
is, however, the more correct reading; e. g. {%Nārada:%} {#manu-#}
{#zya mAraRaM steyaM paradArABimarzaRam . pAruzyamanftaM cEva sAhasaM#}
{#paYcaDA smftam;#} or {%Kumārila%} on a {%Mānava S.:%} {#cAturmAsyAdA-#}
{#vutkarzAdaBimarzaRam#}. <sup>2</sup> Licking the lips as an indication of guilt
or prevarication. E. {#mfz (= mfS)#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6221<pc>257-a<k1>aBimAti<k2>aBimAti
{#aBimAti#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-tiH-tiH-ti#}) (ved.) Doing
injury, hurting, offensive, inimical; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#sa hi zmA#}
{#viSvacarzaRiraBimAti saho daDe#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBimAti SatrURAM#}
{#hiMsakam#}). E. {#man#} (cl. 4) with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. or Bahuvr. f. m. ({#-tiH-tiH#}) (ved.) A wicked
man, a foe, an enemy; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#na yaM dipsanti dipsavo#}
{#na druhvARo janAnAm . na devamaBimAtayaH#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBimA-#}
{#tayaH pApmAnaH . pApmA vA aBimAtiriti SrutyantarAt#}); or
{%Ṛgv.%} or {%Vājas.:%} {#agne sahasva pftanA aBimAtIrapAsya#} ({%Sā-%}
{%yaṇa:%} {#aBimAtIrarAtIn…aBito mAnaM yezAM ta iti#}
{#bahuvrIhO pUrvapadaprakftisvaratvam#}--cf. {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 2. 1.--; {%Ma-%}
{%hīdh.:%} {#strItvamArzam . aBimatIYCatrUn#}); or {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Sāmav.:%}
{#mA na staraBimAtaye#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBimanyata ityaBimAtiH SatruH#}).
Comp. {#aBimAtin#}. E. {#man#} (cl. 4), with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff.
{#ktin,#} or ({%Bahuvr.%}) {#aBi#} and {#mAti#} ({#mA,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#});
the latter Etym., according to {%Sāyaṇa,%} but less probable
than the former alluded to equally by this comm., since the
accent of the word--udātta on the second syllable--would
follow not less from {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 2. 2. than from VI. 2. 50.; the use of
the word in the femin. is considered by {%Mahīdh.,%} in the given
quotation, as a vaidik archaism, but it is probably more cor-
rect to assume that the word was originally a {%fem.,%} meaning
{%injury, hostility,%} and became as such afterwards personified as
a masc. in the sense {%enemy;%} comp. {#aBikzadA, aBiBUti#} &c.
<LEND>

<L>6230<pc>257-b<k1>aBimAna<k2>aBimAna
{#aBimAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Philosophy.) Conceiving
objects with the notion that they refer to one's own self:
the mental process which is the essential characteristic of
{#ahaNkAra#} (of the conception of ‘I’ or of the notion of per-
sonality) q. v.; e. g. {%Sāṅkhya Sūtra:%} {#aBimAno'haMkAraH#}
({%Vijnānāch.:%} {#ahaM karotItyahaMkAraH kumBakAravat . antaHkara-#}
{#RadravyaM sa ca DarmaDarmyaBedAdaBimAna ityuktaH#}); or {%Vedānta Sāra:%}
{#aBimAnAtmikAntaHkaraRavfttirahaMkAraH;#} and therefore in {%cor-%}
{%rect writing%} not identical with the philosophical term {#ahaM-#}
{#kAra#} itself, although some authors use both words some-
times apparently as synonymes: {%Vijnānāch.:%} {#ahaMkAraScABi-#}
{#mAnavfttikamantaHkaraRadravyaM na tvaBimAnamAtraM dravyasyEva loke#}
{#dravyopAdAnatvadarSanAt#}. Yet as the notion of personality
in the orthodox philosophical systems is not our notion
of self-consciousness, but the notion based on that con-
dition of the mind which identifies the {%bodily personality%}
or {%individual existence%} with the Absolute, and as this
mental condition is held to lead to an erroneous concep-
tion of the absolute Truth, the terms {#ahaMkAra#} and {#a-#}
{#BimAna#} have generally a {%negative%} bearing, the latter imply-
ing: ‘conceiving the {%wrong%} or {%erroneous idea%} that the ob-
jects of the world refer absolutely to one's own {%bodily%} or
{%individual%} self’; e. g. {%Viśvan.%} (on the {%Nyāya S.%} {#dozanimi-#}
{#ttAnAM tatvajYAnAdahaMkAranivfttiH#}): {#ahaMkAro'hamityaBimAnaH#}
{#sa ca SarIrAdivizayako miTyAjYAnamucyate#} (comp. the {%Sid-%}
{%dhāntamuktāv.:%} {#ahaMkAro'hamiti pratyayaH . tasyASrayo vizaya#}
{#Atmani SarIrAdiriti#}); or {%Sāṅkhyatattvak.:%} {#yatKalvAlo-#}
{#citaM mataM ca tatrAhamaDikftaH . SaktaH Kalvahamatra . madarTA evA-#}
{#mI vizayAH . matto nAnyo'trADikftaH kaScidastyato'hamasmI-#}
{#ti yo'BimAnaH so'sADAraRavyApAratvAdahaMkAraH#}. <sup>2</sup> Con-
ception in general, but (like the preceding meaning) usually
with an implied {%negative%} bearing: erroneous conception or
belief, imagination, fancy; e. g. {%Nyāya Sūtras:%} {#sPawikAnya-#}
{#tvABimAnavattadanyatvABimAnaH#} ‘as crystal is {%fancied%} to be-
come different (from the proximity with objects it comes
in contact with) so the mental activity is {%fancied%} to vary’;
or {#svapnavizayABimAnavadayaM pramARaprameyABimAnaH#} ‘like the
{%conceit%} of things in a dream, is the {%conceit%} of means of
proof and objects of proof’; or {#miTyopalabDivinASastattva-#}
{#jYAnAtsvapnavizayABimAnapraRASavatpratiboDe#} ‘false conception
ceases through the knowledge of the Truth as the {%imagin-%}
{%ation%} of objects in a dream vanishes on awaking’; or {%Bho-%}
{%jadeva%} (on the {%Yoga S.%} {#vivekaKyAti°°#}): {#pratipakzaBAvanAba-#}
{#lAdavidyApravilaye nivfttakartftvajYAtftvABimAnAyA rajastamo-#}
{#malAnaBiBUtAyA budDerantarmuKAyA yA cicCAyAsaMkrAntiH sA#}
{#vivekaKyAtirityucyate#} ‘…of the intellect in which the con-
[Page258-a+ 56]
ceit of being agent or knower has ceased…’; or {%Sā-%}
{%hityad.:%} {#utsAhAdisamudboDaH sADAraRyABimAnataH . nfRAmapi#}
{#samudrAdilaNGanAdO na duzyati#} ‘…from {%imagining%} that the
hero of a poem possesses universal powers’. Comp. also
the inst. s. v. {#aBimanyamAna#}. (This use of the word recon-
ciles its rendering {#jYAna#} by the {%Amarak., Hem., Bhūripr.%} &c.,
and {#ajYAna#} by the {%Medinī.%}) <sup>3</sup> Arrogance, self-conceit, pride
(of family, wealth, superior qualities &c.; {%Ramānātha%} on the
{%Amarak.:%} {#AdinA kulapaSuguRAdigrahaH#}); comp. {#ahaNkAra;#}
e. g. {%Śṛṅgāratil.:%} {#prAyo mUrKaH pariBavaviDO nABimAnaM piDatte;#}
or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#parAmfSantaH praTitABimAnAH procuH prahastapramuKA#}
{#daSAsyam#}. <sup>4</sup> Affection, ({%Amarak.%} &c. = {#praRayaH;#} {%Mukuṭa:%}
= {#prItiH#}). <sup>5</sup> Affectionate solicitation; ({%Ramānātha:%} = {#premRA#}
{#prArTanam#}). <sup>6</sup> Solicitation in general, wish, desire; ({%Svāmin,%}
{%Nīlak.:%} = {#prArTanA#}); e. g. {%Vijnānāch.:%} {#mayAnenendriyeRedaM rU-#}
{#pAdikaM Boktavyamidameva suKasADanamityAdyaBimAnAdevAdisarge-#}
{#zvindriyatadvizayotpattyAhaMkAra indriyAdihetuH#}. <sup>7</sup> Injury, hurt-
ing, killing, desire of doing injury &c. ({%Amarak.:%} = {#hiMsA,#}
{%Bharata:%} = {#hanana;#} {%Sāyaṇa%} on the {%Śatap.:%} = {#hiMsecCA#}). E.
{#man#} (cl. 4) with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY;#} or in the meanings
1-3, perhaps {#mA#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw;#} for the affinity
of both radicals see s. vv.
<LEND>

<L>6231<pc>258-a<k1>aBimAnatA<k2>aBimAnatA
{#aBimAnatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) Pride, arrogance. E. {#aBimAna,#} taddh.
aff. {#tal#}.
<LEND>

<L>6232<pc>258-a<k1>aBimAnavat<k2>aBimAnavat
{#aBimAnavat#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Philosophy.)
Possessing the {#aBimAna#} 1. q. v., consisting of it, (as {#a-#}
{#haMkAra#}); e. g. {%Vijnānāch.%} (on the {%Sāṅkhya Sūtra:%} {#vAhyABya-#}
{#ntarAByAM tEScAhaMkArasya#}): {#tanmAtrendriyARyaBimAnavaddravyopAdA-#}
{#nakAnyaBimAnakAryadravyatvAt#}. <sup>2</sup> Proud, arrogant; e. g. {%Ki-%}
{%rātārj.:%} {#aBimAnavato manasvinaH priyamuccEH padamArurukzataH#} &c.
(The word may have also the sense: {%affectionate%} &c., see
{#aBimAna#} 2. 4-7., but occurs usually only in the two given
meanings.) E. {#aBimAna,#} taddh. aff. {#matup#}.
<LEND>

<L>6233<pc>258-a<k1>aBimAnavfttika<k2>aBimAnavfttika

{#'haMkAraH#}): {#yaH so haM karotItyahaMkAro'BimAnavfttikaH;#} or
(on the {%Sāṅkhya S.%} {#ahaMkAro kartA na puruzaH#}): {#aBimAnavf-#}
{#ttikamantaHkaraRamahaMkAraH;#} comp. also the quotation s. v. {#a-#}
{#BimAna#} 1. and {#aBimAnAtmaka#}. E. {#aBimAna#} and {#vftti,#} sa-
māsānta aff. {#kap#}.

<L>6234<pc>258-a<k1>aBimAnaSAlin<k2>aBimAnaSAlin

<L>6236<pc>258-a<k1>aBimAnita<k2>aBimAnita

<L>6237<pc>258-a<k1>aBimAnitva<k2>aBimAnitva
{#aBimAnitva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Philosophy.) The condition of
one who conceives objects with the notion that they refer
exclusively to one's own self. <sup>2</sup> Personification, persona-
tion; e. g. {%Jaiminīyanyāy.:%} {#pfTivI hotetyAdiko mantraScaturhI-#}
{#tA . tasminmantre yajYANgAnAM caturRAM SrutatvAt . aTavA tasya ma-#}

{#ntrasyABimAnitvenAtmaBUtaH kaScitpuruzaH prajApatinA caturvAra-#}
{#mAmantritaH pratyuttaramuvAceti sa puruzaScaturhUtaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Pride, ar-
rogance. Also {#aBimAnitA#}. E. {#aBimAnin,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6238<pc>258-b<k1>aBimAnin<k2>aBimAnin
{#aBimAnin#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-nI-ninI-ni#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Philo-
sophy.) Conceiving objects with the notion that they refer
exclusively to one's own self; esp., however, with the im-
plied sense that such conception is erroneous; (comp. {#aBi-#}
{#mAna#} 1.); e. g. (in the {%Vedānta,%} the inferior degrees of the
absolute Spirit, each of which conceives the world as re-
ferring exclusively to itself) {%Ved. Sāra:%} {#etatsamazwyupahitaM cE-#}
{#tanyaM vESvAnaro virAqiti cocyate sarvanarABimAnitvAdviviDaM#}
{#rAjamAnatvAcca#} ‘he is called Vaiśvānara, because he conceives
the whole of mankind as referring to him exclusively &c.’
(where the affix {#tva#} belongs to the whole compound {#sarvanara-#}
{#aBimAnin#}). <sup>2</sup> Conceiving (in general), but esp. with the
implied sense: conceiving erroneously, fancying, imagining;
e. g. {%Udyogap. Mahābh.:%} {#prajYABimAnI pratikUlavAdI tyAjyaH#}
{#sa tAdfktvarayEva BftyaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Personifying, personating; e. g. {%Śan-%}
{%kara%} in his comm. on the {%Chhānd. Up.:%} {#…te sarve'rcizam#}
(i. e.) {#arciraBimAninIM devatAmaBiniviSanti#} (i. e. {#pratipadya-#}
{#nte#}) &c. {#…. te DUmaM#} (i. e.) {#DUmABimAninIM devatAmABimu-#}
{#Kyena saMBavanti#} &c. {#…. nEte karmiRaH prakftAH saMvatsaraM#} (i. e.)
{#saMvatsarABimAninIM devatAmaBiprApnuvanti;#} or {%Mahīdh.%} in the
comm. on the {%Vājas.:%} {#SAKAdInAmacetanatve'pi tadaBimAni-#}
{#nAM devatAnAM sattvAddevatAtvam . aBimAnivyapadeSastviti vyA-#}
{#sasUtrokteH;#} or {#saMvatsarABimAnI prajApatiH stUyate;#} or {%Sāy.:%} {#yadya-#}
{#pi tisra eva devatA ityuktatvAtkzityAdyaBimAninyo devatAstisra#}
{#eva#} &c.; or {%Prabodhach.:%} {#maDumatyA ca BUmimApannaH sTAnABimA-#}
{#ninIBirdevatABirupacCandyate#} ‘…by the deities who personated
the place’, i. e. who created in Purusha's mind the illusion that
it was mount Meru; or {%Vedānta-Sūtra:%} {#aBimAnivyapadeSastu#}
{#viSezAnugatiByAm#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#na Kalu mfdabravIdityevaMjAtIya-#}
{#kayA SrutyA BUtendriyARAM cetanatvamASaNkanIyam . yato'Bi-#}
{#mAnivyapadeSa ezaH . mfdAdyaBimAninyo vAgAdyaBimAninyaSca ce-#}
{#tanAdevatA vadanasaMvadanAdizu cetanocitezu vyavahArezu vyapadi-#}
{#Syante na BUtendriyamAtram#}); or {%Daśakumārach.:%} {#kaScinnarendrA-#}
{#BimAnI mAM nivarRya#} &c. ‘somebody personating a doctor &c.’.
<sup>4</sup> Proud, not bearing a slight, haughty; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#aBi-#}
{#mAninamudBrAntamAtmasaMBAvitaM SaWam .…Gnanti vEriRaH;#} or
{%Gītagov.:%} {#hariraBimAnI rajaniridAnImiyamapi yAti virA-#}
{#mam . kuru mama vacanaM#} &c. (comm. {#laGutvaM na sahate#}). <sup>5</sup> Wishing,
desiring; e. g. {%Vijnānāch.%} on a {%Sāṅkhya S.:%} {#…ahaMkAra#}
{#indriyAdihetuH . loke BogABimAninEva rAgadvArA Bogopaka-#}
{#raRanirmARadarSanAt#} (v. 1. {#BogopakaraRakaraRadarSanAt#}). <sup>6</sup> Do-
ing injury, hostile, an enemy; e. g. {%Sāyaṇa%} (in the comm. on
{#aBimAti#}): {#aBimAtIraBimAninaH karmaviGnakAriRaH SacUn#}.
<div n="P"> 2. m. ({#-nI#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Agni as the eldest born of
Brahman (masc.); according to the {%Viṣṇu Purāṇa.%} <sup>2</sup> The
name of a son of the Manu Bhautya who presides over the
fourteenth Manwantara. (There is probably an allegorical
connexion between the name of these personages and the
Sāṅkhya doctrine which makes {#ahaMkAra#} originate in the prin-
ciple of intellect.) E. {#man#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini;#} 1. 4.
perhaps not a Tatpur., but {#aBimAna,#} taddh. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

ing injury, of killing; e. g. {%Śatapath.:%} {#aBimAnuko ha rudraH#}
[Page259-a+ 56]
{#paSUntsyAt;#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#aBimantuM bADituM SaktaH syAt#}). E.
{#man#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ukaY#}.

<L>6242<pc>259-a<k1>aBimuKa<k2>aBimuKa
{#aBimuKa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. or Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-KaH-KA#} or {#-KI;#}
see {%N. B.;%} {#-Kam#}) <sup>1</sup> With the face directed towards, facing,
fronting; e. g. {%Nalop.:%} {#SArdUlo'BimuKo'Byeti;#} or in the
locat. used adverbially, {%Rāmāy.:%} {#kftAYjaliruvAcedaM SvaSrUma-#}
{#BimuKe sTitAm#}. <sup>2</sup> Near, approaching; e. g. {%Raghuv.:%} {#yu-#}
{#yoja pAkABimuKErBftyAnvijYApanAPalEH;#} comp. also {#aBimu-#}
{#KIkaraRa, aBimuKIBUta#}. <sup>3</sup> Disposed towards, engaged in,
ready for; e. g. {%Raghuv.:%} {#prAtaH prayARABimuKAya…tasmE#}
{#vfzwiM SaSaMsuH;#} or {#svasAramAdAya vidarBarAjaH purapraveSABimu-#}
{#Ko baBUva#}. <sup>4</sup> Kindly disposed, favourable, propitious; e. g.
{%Rāmāy.:%} {#na nAstikenABimuKo buDaH syAt;#} or {%Lalitav.:%} {#ye#}
(scil. {#boDisattvAH#}) {#tuzitavaraBavanasTAH sarve caramaBavABimu-#}
{#KAH#} &c. <sup>5</sup> With the face upwards; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#ABugnI#}
{#'BimuKaH Sete garBI garBASaye striyAH . sa yoniM SirasA yAti#}
{#svaBAvAtprasavaM prati;#} comp. also the {%comm.%} of the {%Nalodaya%}
on the word {#anavAk,#} viz.: {#avAk . aDomuKaH . na avAk .#}
{#anavAk . aBimuKaH#}. [N. B. According to a {%Kārikā%} on
{%Pāṇ.%} IV. 1. 54. the fem. of this word must end in {#I (NIz),#}
if it is applied to a {%living being,%} otherwise in {#A;#} thus e. g.
{%Rāmāy.:%} {#rAjAnamevABimuKI kEkeyI vAkyamabravIt;#} or {#prayAtu#}
{#caturaNgiRI . ayoDyABimuKI senA;#} or {%Śaṅk.%} on {%Chh. Upan.%}
4. 6. 1.: {#tAH SanEScarantya AcAryakulABimuKyaH prasTitAH;#} but {%Kā-%}
{%śikā:%} {#aBimuKA SAlA;#} comp. e. g. {#candramuKI#} and similar
compounds (said of a woman) but {#SlakzRamuKA SAlA#}.]
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-KI#}) One of ten earths stepped upon by Buddha,
in Buddhistic mythology; (in the classical Sanskṛt this fem.
in {#I#} instead of in {#A#} would be doubly wrong; comp. the
foregoing remark and {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 1. 58.).
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-Kam#}) <sup>1</sup> With the face towards, in the
direction towards; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#AsyatAmiti coktaH sannA-#}
{#sItABimuKaM guroH;#} or {%Kirātārj.:%} {#vyaktoditasmitamayUKaviBA-#}
{#sitozWastizWanmuneraBimuKaM sa vikIrRaDAmnaH;#} or {%Ṛtusaṃh.:%} {#cU-#}
{#tavfkzAn . aBimuKamaBivIkzya;#} or in the {%dramas:%} {#nepaTyABi-#}
{#muKamavalokya#}. <sup>2</sup> Near; e. g. {%Hitop.:%} {#svagfhABimuKaM prayAtaH;#}
or {%Śiśupālab.:%} {#aBimuKapatitErguRaprakarzAdavarjitam#} &c.; or {%Me-%}
{%ghad.:%} {#arcistuNgAnaBimuKagatAnprAzya ratnapradIpAn#}. [{#aBimuKa#}
is udātta on the last syllable; this accent follows for the
{%Avyayībh.%} from {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 223., for the {%Tatpur.%} from VI.
2. 185., and for the {%Bahuvr.%} from the same Sūtra, since the
rule VI. 2. 177. (exception to VI. 2. 168.) concerns only such
Bahuvr. ending in {#muKa,#} as express a {%permanent%} condition
of the face (comp. {#pramuKa#}), not a {%transitory%} one like ‘facing’,
and applies moreover only to the {%literal%} meaning of {#muKa,#}
not to the figur. sense it has e. g. in {#aBimuKA#} as epithet
of {#SAlA;#} (but VI. 2. 177. applies probably also to {#aBimuKa#} I.
1. 5.); {%Kāśikā:%} {#bahuvrIhirayam . prAdisamAso vA . avyayI-#}
{#BAve tu samAsAntodAttatvenEva sidDam . upasargAtsvANgamiti#}
{#sidDe vacanamabahuvrIhyarTam . aDruvArTam . asvANgArTaM ca;#} comp.
the quotation from {%Patanj.%} s. v. {#apamuKa#}.] E. {#aBi#} and {#muKa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6253<pc>259-b<k1>aBiyA<k2>aBiyA
{#aBiyA#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-yAH-yAH#}) Coming near, approaching,
esp. with a hostile intention; attacking, assailing; e. g. in
the following {#mahAyamaka#} of the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#aBiyAtA varaM tuNgaM#}
{#BUBftaM ruciraM puraH . karkaSaM praTitaM DAma sasattvaM puzkarekzaRam ..#}
{#aBiyAtAvaraM#} (or {#aBiyAtA varaM#}) {#tuNgaM BUBftaM ruciraM puraH .#}
{#karkaSaM praTitaM DAma sasattvaM puzkare kzaRam;#} where {#aBiyAtA-#}
{#varam#} in the second Śloka is analyzed by the commentators
either {#aBiyA#} (instrum. sing. of {#aBiyA#} or of {#aBI#} ‘fear-
less’, scil. {#hanUmatA#}) and {#atAvaram#} ({#ata#} ‘wind, sun &c.’
and {#Avaram#}) or {#aBiyAtA#} (instrum. sing. of {#aBiyAt#})
and {#varam#}. E. {#yA#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<LEND>

<L>6260<pc>260-a<k1>aBiyAtin<k2>aBiyAtin

<L>6264<pc>260-a<k1>aBiyukta<k2>aBiyukta
{#aBiyukta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) <sup>1</sup> Diligent, intent,
studiously engaged in; e. g. {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%} {#svakarmaRyaBiyukto#}
{#yaH saNgadvezavivarjitaH . pUjitastadviDErnityamApto jYeyaH sa tAdfSaH;#}
also applied to {%religious meditation,%} i. e. engaged in medi-
tation; e. g. {%Bhagavadg.:%} {#ananyAScintayanto mAM ye janAH#}
{#paryupAsate . tezAM nityABiyuktAnAM yogakzemaM vahAmyaham#} ({#ni-#}
{#tyA°:#} {%Arjunam.:%} = {#sarvadA madekanizWAnAm;#} {%Śaṅkara:%} = {#sa-#}
{#tatABiyoginAm;#} {%Sadānanda%} in his metrical gloss: = {#A-#}
{#dareRa sadA DyAne vyApftAnAm#} &c.). <sup>2</sup> Versed in, instructed;
e. g. {%Kumārila's Mīm. Vārtt.:%} {#SAstrArTezvaBiyuktAnAM puruzARAM#}
{#hi sarvadA . stokenApyanyaTAtvena SAstrArTo nizPalo Bavet;#}
also used absolutely in the sense of {%learned, a scholar,%} e. g.
{%Kumārila:%} {#aBiyuktAnaBiyuktajYAnayoScABiyuktajYAnaM balavadi-#}
{#tarasya sulaBApavAdatvAt . ataH SAstrABiyuktatvAdAryAvartani-#}
{#vAsinAm . yA matiH sEva DarmANgaSabdArTatvapramA matA .. ete-#}
{#nAryAvartanivAsimaDye'pi .. aBiyuktatarA ye ye bahuSAstrArTa-#}
{#vedinaH . te te yatra prayuYjIransa so'rTastattvato Bavet;#} or {%Rā-%}
{%matīrtha%} on the {%Vedānta S.:%} {#taduktamaBiyuktEH . muKyaM tu sapta-#}
{#daSakaM praTitaM hi liNgamiti#}. Comp. also {#aBiyoga#}. <sup>3</sup> At-
tacked, assaulted, assailed; e. g. {%Śiśupālab.:%} {#aBiyuktaM tvayE-#}
{#naM te gantArastvAmato'pare#} ({%Mallin.:%} {#aBiyuktam . aBiyAtam#});
or {%Hitop.:%} {#aBiyukto yadA paSyenna kiMcidDitamAtmanaH . yuDya-#}
{#mAnastadA prAjYo mriyate ripuRA saha;#} or {#balIyasABiyuktastu#}
{#nfpo'nanyapratikriyaH . ApannaH saMDimanvicCetkurvARaH kAlayA-#}
{#panam;#} or {%Bharatas.%} on the words {#mfzA te mayi duHsTabudDiH#}
of the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#mayyasmadvizaye duHsTo'yamariBiraBiyukto'ya-#}
{#miti te tava budDirmfzA miTyA#}. <sup>4</sup> Blamed, rebuked ({%Wilson%}).
<sup>5</sup> (In Law.) Charged, prosecuted, defendant; e. g. {%Yājnav.:%}
{#aBiyogamanistIrya nEnaM pratyaBiyojayet . aBiyuktaM ca nAnyena#}
&c.; or {%Nārada:%} {#aBiyuktastaTAnyena rAjakarmodyatastaTA#} (v. 1.
{#rAjakAryo°°#}) {#.…vizamasTASca nAseDyA na cEtAnnAhvaye-#}
{#nnfpaH;#} or {%Vyavahārat.%} on {%Vṛhasp.:%} {#atrABiyuktena SapaTaH karta-#}
{#vya ityutsargaH#}. Comp. {#aBiyoga#}. E. {#yuj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6265<pc>260-a<k1>aBiyugvan<k2>aBiyugvan
{#aBiyugvan#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gvA#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Assailing, attacking,
[Page260-b+ 56]
overpowering; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#sa raTena raTItamo'smAkenABi-#}
{#yugvanA . jezi jizRo hitaM Danam;#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiyugvanABi-#}

<LEND>

<L>6266<pc>260-b<k1>aBiyuj<k2>aBiyuj
{#aBiyuj#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-k-k#}) (ved.) Attacking, assailing,
an enemy, (when used absolutely in the femin., with the
ellipsis of {#prajA#} or {#senA#}); e. g. (masc.) {%Ṛgv.:%} {#uta smAsya#}
{#tanyatoriva dyorfGAyato aBiyujo Bayante;#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBi-#}
{#yujo'BiyoktAro'surAH#}); or {#pravfRvanto aBiyujaH#} &c. ({%Sā-%}
{%yaṇa:%} {#aBiyujo'BiyojayitAraH#}); (fem.) {%Ṛgv.:%} {#ABirvi-#}
{#SvA aBiyujo vizucIrAryAya viSo'va tArIrdAsIH;#} or {%fem.%}
{%absolutely: Ṛgv. Sāmav.:%} {#sAhvAnviSvA aBiyujaH…agniH#}
({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiyujo'BiyoktrIH…senAH#}); or {#vi zu vi-#}
{#SvA aBiyujo vajrinvizvagyaTA vfha#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiyujo'Bi-#}
{#yoktrIH prajAH#}). E. {#yuj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<LEND>

<L>6267<pc>260-b<k1>aBiyujyamAna<k2>aBiyujyamAna

is charged, prosecuted, defendant; e. g. {%Vyavahārat.:%} {#prOQi-#}
{#vAdenABiyujyamAnAt#} &c. Comp. {#yuj#} with {#aBi,#} and the
meanings of {#aBiyukta#}. E. {#yuj#} in the pass., with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#SAnac,#} āgama {#muk#}.
<LEND>

<L>6269<pc>260-b<k1>aBiyoktf<k2>aBiyoktf

<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ktA#}) <sup>1</sup> An assailant, an enemy; e. g. {%Hitop.:%} {#a-#}

{#iti#}. <sup>2</sup> (In Law.) A plaintiff, an accuser; e. g. {%Kātyāyana:%}

<L>6270<pc>260-b<k1>aBiyoga<k2>aBiyoga
{#aBiyoga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Connexion, application; e. g.
{%Chaurapanch.:%} {#adyApi tatkanakakuRqalaGfzwagaRqamAsyaM smarAmi#}
{#viparItaratABiyoge#} ({%Gaṇapati:%} {#aBiyogaH saMbanDaH#}). <sup>2</sup> Ener-
getic effort, exertion; ({%Hemach.%} = {#udyama#}); e. g. {%Jayamang.%}
on the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#kftamAraRABiyogA rAtricarI#}. <sup>3</sup> Instructed-
ness, learning, scholarship; e. g. {%Śabara:%} {#anaBiyogaSca Sa-#}
{#bdArTezvaSizwAnAm . aBiyogaScetarezAm;#} or {%Mīm. Sūtra:%} {#tatra#}
{#tattvamaBiyogaviSezAtsyAt#} ({%Śabara:%} {#kaTaM punastatra tattvaM SakyaM#}
{#vijYAtum . SakyamityAha . arTino hyaBiyuktA Bavanti dfSyate#}
{#cABiyuktAnAM guRavatAmavismaraRamupapannam;#} {%Kumārila:%} {#kaH pu-#}
{#naraBiyogaH ko vA tadviSezaH kaTaM vA tena vAcakatvanirUpaRa-#}
{#miti . taducyate . lakzaRaSravaRAByAsAdaBiyogaH pravartate#} &c.).
<sup>4</sup> Imputing, ascribing; e. g. {%Nyāya S.:%} {#anigrahasTAne nigra-#}
{#hasTAnABiyogo niranuyojyAnuyogaH#}. <sup>5</sup> Attack, onset, battle;
(the same as {#aBigraha#} 1. q. v. and see there the explanation
of {%Rāyam.%} &c.); e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#narABiyogaM nfBfjAM praDAna#}
{#mantronmuKaH kiM nayase gurutvam;#} or {%Kirātārj.:%} {#aBiyoga imA-#}
{#nmahIBujo BavatA tasya kftaH kftAvaDeH praviGAwayitA#}. <sup>6</sup> Chal-
lenge; (the same as {#aBigraha#} <sup>2</sup> q. v. and see there the ex-
planation of {%Nīlak.%} &c.). <sup>7</sup> Defeat, destruction (?); e. g.
{%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#yadA na PeluH kzaRadAcArARAM manoraTA rAmabalA-#}
[Page261-a+ 56]
{#Biyoge#} ({%Bharatas.:%} = {#rAmabalasya hanane#}); see the closing remark.
<sup>8</sup> Curse, reproof (? see the closing remark). <sup>9</sup> (In Law.) An
offence as subject of an accusation, a charge; e. g. {%Mitākṣara%}
on {%Yājnav.:%} {#aBiyujyata ityaBiyogo'parADaH;#} or {#kaTamaBi-#}
{#yogasya nihnave'Biyuktena kfte yadyaBiyoktA sAkzyAdiBirBA-#}
{#vito'BiyuktastadA tatsamaM…dadyAt;#} or {%Nārada:%} {#aBi-#}
{#yukto'Biyogasya yadi kuryAdapahnavam#} &c.; or {%Yājnav.:%} {#tulA-#}
{#gnyApo vizaM kozo divyAnIha viSudDaye . mahABiyogezvetAni#}
{#SIrzakasTe'Biyoktari…kuryAt#} ({%Raghunand.:%} {#mahABiyo-#}
{#gezu mahApAtakAdigurutarABiyogezu#}).--An {#aBiyoga#} is, ac-
cording to {%Nārada,%} either a {#SaNkABiyoga,#} a charge on sus-
picion, or {#tattvABiyoga,#} a charge founded on positive in-
dications of guilt ({#dvyaBiyogastu vijYeyaH#}--scil. {#vyavahAraH--#}
{#SaNkAtattvABiyogataH . SaNkAsatAM tu saMsargAttattvaM hoqABidarSa-#}
{#nAt#}); and the latter may be again, according to {%Vijnāne-%}
{%śvara,%} either of a negative kind ({#pratizeDAtmaka#}), as when a
person is accused not to have restored property received
by him, or of a positive kind ({#viDyAtmaka#}), as when a
person is charged with a robbery. The objects or topics
of a charge are arraigned by {%Manu%} &c. under eighteen
heads, which are subdivided again by {%Nārada%} so as to
comprise 108, and by {%Kātyāyana%} so as to comprise 1008
cases; see {#vyavahArapada#} and for the judicial procedure {#vyava-#}
{#hAra#}. [N. B. The meaning {%‘curse, reproof’%} is given on the
authority of a quotation by {%Mallinātha%} to {%Kirātārj.%} 2. 46.
from the {%Viśvaprak.,%} and this quotation would seem also
to countenance the meaning {%‘destruction’%} given by {%Bharatas.,%}
viz. {#aBiyogastu SapaTe syAdAhavaparABavAviti viSvaH;#} the
Mss. of this Kosha, however, in the library of the E. I. H.
and of the R. S., do not contain an explanation of the word
{#aBiyoga,#} but have the following: {#aBizaNgo'Ta SapaTe syA-#}
{#dAkroSe parABave;#} comp. also {%Hemach.:%} {#…aBizaNgaH parA-#}
{#Bave . AkroSe SapaTe ca,#} the latter omitting equally a com-
ment on {#aBiyoga#}.] E. {#yuj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6286<pc>261-b<k1>aBirAja<k2>aBirAja
{#aBirAja#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) The proper name of a Burmese
king; he is, according to the legend, the founder of one of
the oldest dynasties and belongs to the family of the Śākyas
in Kapilavastu; he emigrated from the latter city after its
destruction by a king of Kośala and, having reached the
banks of the Irawaddy, built the city of Tagoung. E. {#aBi#}
and {#rAjan,#} samās. aff. {#wac;#} literally: reigning everywhere.
<LEND>

<L>6294<pc>262-a<k1>aBiruta<k2>aBiruta

<L>6295<pc>262-a<k1>aBirUpa<k2>aBirUpa
{#aBirUpa#}¦ Bahuvr. or Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-paH-pA-pam#}) <sup>1</sup> Pleas-
ing, agreeable, beautiful; ({%Mathureśa, Bhānudīkṣita%} &c.:
{#aBi lakzyaM rUpamasya;#} {%Vardhamāna:%} {#SoBanaM rUpamasya . rUpama-#}
{#Bigata iti vA#}); e. g. {%Nal.:%} {#aBirUpaM mahAtmAnaM paravyUhavi-#}
{#nASanam . yamanvezasi rAjAnaM nalaM padmaniBekzaRam;#} or {%Patanj.%} on
a {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#caYcA aBirUpaH#} ‘(a man like) a beautiful straw-
puppet’ ({%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#tfRamayaH puruzaScaYcA tatsadfSo manuzyaScaYcA .#}
{#saMjYAyAmiti vihitasya kano lup . manuzya iti lup#}). <sup>2</sup> Re-
sembling, conform; e. g. {%Śatap.:%} {#Endryo'BirUpA dvAdaSa Ba-#}
{#vanti#} &c. <sup>3</sup> Learned, wise; e. g. {%Mahābh. Śāntip.:%} {#aBi-#}
{#rUpEH kule jAtErdakzErBaktErbahuSrutEH . sarvA budDIH parIkzeTAstApasA-#}
{#SramiRAmapi#} ({%Arjunam.:%} {#aBirUpEH paRqitEH#}). [For the ab-
stract noun comp. {#ABirUpaka#} and {#ABirUpya#}.]
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name or epithet of: <sup>a.</sup> Kāma, <sup>b.</sup> Viṣṇu,
<sup>c.</sup> Śiva. <sup>2</sup> The moon. [{%Śabdaratnāv.:%} {#aBirUpo buDe ramye#}
{#kAmenduharavizRuzu;#} but amongst the thousand names of
Viṣṇu in the Mahābhārata this name does not occur, nor
amongst the same amount of names of Śiva in the Padma-
purāṇa.] E. {#aBi#} and {#rUpa#}.
<LEND>
[Page262-b+ 56]

<L>6296<pc>262-b<k1>aBirUpaka<k2>aBirUpaka

f. n.) 1. 1. 3.; e. g. {%Kāśikā%} to {%Pāṇ.%} (VIII. 1. 8., a Sūtra ridi-
culed by {%Patanjali%} on account of its verbosity): {#aBirUpa-#}
{#kA3 aBirUpaka riktaM ta ABirUpyam,#} or {#aBirUpakA3 aBi-#}
{#rUpaka SoBanaH Kalvasi mARavaka#}.--According to a {%Gaṇa%} to
{%Pāṇ.%} it may form a {%Karmadh.%} with a word of the Gaṇa
{#kftAdi#} (II. 1. 59.); it does not occur, however, in the cor-
responding Gaṇa of the {%Gaṇaratnamahodadhi;%} comp. similar
{%Karmadh.%} such as {#aDyApakodita, paRqitAjYAta, kuSalAKyAta,#}
{#nipuRodAhfta#} &c. See also {#kumArABirUpaka#}. E. {#aBirUpa,#}
taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>6307<pc>263-a<k1>aBilApa<k2>aBilApa

({%Anūpanār.:%} {#…na saMskAro na vratAni SUdrasyeti tadaBAvo-#}
{#kteSca na SUdre'DikAraH#}); or {#anyADizWite pUrvavadaBilApAt#}
({%Śaṅkara:%} {#…ko'BilApasya tadvadBAvaH . karmavyApAramantareRa#}
{#saMkIrtanam#}); or {%Prakramādhikaraṇa%} (as quoted by {%Rādhā-%}
{%kāntad.%}): {#kAmyABilApasahitaH kuSatilajalatyAgarUpaH saMkalpaH#}
{#SAstrArTaH#} ‘the intention (of performing a vow) implies the
{%enunciation%} of the voluntary rite (to be performed); it con-
sists in such oblations as those of kuśa, oil and water, and
is founded on the sacred precepts’ (comp. {%Mādh. Jaiminī-%}
{%yanyāyam.:%} {#saMkalpo'trAnuzWeyavratatvena viDIyate#}). See {#aBIlApa#}
and comp. {#aBivyAhAra#}. E. {#lap#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.

<L>6309<pc>263-a<k1>aBilAza<k2>aBilAza
{#aBilAza#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-zaH#}) Desire, craving, covetousness;
e. g. {%Vijnāneśvara%} on {%Manu%} ({#kAmAddaSaguRaM,#} scil. {#daRqyaH#} &c.):
{#kAmaH strIvyatikarABilAzaH;#} or {%Kirātārj.:%} {#yastyaktavAnvaH sa#}
{#vfTA balAdvA mohaM viDatte vizayABilAzaH;#} or {%Nyāya S.:%} {#pre-#}
{#tyAhArAByAsakftAtstanyABilAzAt;#} or {%Sāṅkhya Prav.:%} {#yaTA#}
{#duHKAddUzeH puruzasya na taTA suKAdaBilAzaH;#} or {%Daśakumārach.:%}
{#nftyotTitA ca sA sidDilABaSoDinI kiM vilAsAtkimaBilA-#}
{#zAtkimakasmAdeva na jAne#} &c.; or an {%Aśvaśāstra:%} {#aSvavAha-#}
{#nAdyaBilAzEH SvetASvaH sarvakAmadaH#}.--Amongst the works on
poetry which distinguish in their definition of Love (see
{#SfNgAra#}), Love under difficulties (see {#vipralamBa#}) and Love the
course of which runs smooth (see {#saMBoga#}), the {%Kāvyapra-%}
{%kāsa%} mentions {#aBilAza#} or {%longing%} as one (the first in the
given enumeration) of the {%five%} erotic conditions of the first
kind; the {%Sāhityadarp.%} which subdivides ‘Love under dif-
ficulties’ into four categories, names {%longing%} ({#aBilAzaH#}
{#spfhA#}) as one (the first in the given enumeration) of the {%ten%}
erotic conditions of the {#pUrvarAga#} or ‘affection arising from
hearing or sight before the lovers meet’, which is the first
of those subdivisions; either work quoting as an instance
the verse of the {%Mālatīm.,%} ed. Calc. p. 76, line 4 &c. Similarly
the {%Saṅgītadāmodara. Bharata%} as quoted by {%Śaṅkara%} on the
{%Śākuntala,%} calls ‘longing’ the commencement of love ({#praTame#}
{#tvaBilAzaH syAt,#} and in the same words the {%Saṅgītad.%}) when
{%Śāk.%} v. 22. (ed. {%Boehtlingk%}) or v. 24. (ed. {%Williams%}) would
be an instance. An example, however, of {#aBilAza#} as be-
longing to the other description of the Erotic (the {#saMBoga#}),
is in the verse of the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#AliNgitAyAH sahasA trapA-#}
[Page263-b+ 56]
{#vAMstrAsABilAzAnugato ratAdO viSvAsitAyA ramaRena baDvA#}
{#vimardaramyo madano baBUva#}.--[An objectionable reading is
{#aBilAsa,#} for the word is given in the form {#aBilAza#}
not only in the commentaries on the {%Dhātupāthas%} s. r.
{#laz#} (not s. r. {#las#}), but as an {#antyamUrDanya#} in the chapter
on orthography of the {%Viśvapr.%} and amongst the words
that contain a {#z#} only in a similar treatise by {%Purushottama.%}]
E. {#laz#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6331<pc>264-a<k1>aBivahat<k2>aBivahat

ceding; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#UrDvagAH#} (scil. {#DamanyaH#}) {#SabdasparSarUpa-#}
{#rasaganDapraSvAsocCUsajfmBitakzudDasitakaTitaruditAdInviSezAna-#}
{#BivahantyaH SarIraM DArayanti#}. E. {#vah#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<LEND>

<L>6332<pc>264-a<k1>aBivahana<k2>aBivahana
{#aBivahana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Carrying towards, conveyance,
transmission; e. g. {%Nirukta:%} {#aBivahanastutiM…manyante#} (viz.
the {%Ṛgv.%} verse: {#SaMsAvADvaryo prati me#} &c.; {%Durga:%} {#stoma#}
{#eva hi devAnAM voQA Bavati…. evamiyamaBivahanastuti-#}
{#revametacCastramABimuKyagAmi#}). Comp. the comm. on {#aBi-#}
{#vAhya#}. E. {#vah#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6333<pc>264-a<k1>aBivA<k2>aBivA
{#aBivA#}.¦ See the E. of {#aBivAnyavatsA#}.
<LEND>

<L>6334<pc>264-a<k1>aBivAtam<k2>aBivAtam
{#aBivAtam#}¦ Avyayībh. Windwards. E. {#aBi#} and {#vAta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6335<pc>264-a<k1>aBivAda<k2>aBivAda
{#aBivAda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) <sup>1</sup> The same as {#aBivAdana#}. <sup>2</sup> Op-
probrious or harsh speech. The same as {#ativAda#} of which
it occurs as a v. 1. in the {%Amarakosha.%} E. {#vad#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6336<pc>264-a<k1>aBivAdaka<k2>aBivAdaka
{#aBivAdaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dakaH-dikA-dakam#}) <sup>1</sup> One who
salutes or makes the {#aBivAdana#} q. v.; e. g. {%Kullūka%} on
{%Manu:%} {#aBivAdako viprAdirAyuzmAnBava sOmyeti vAcyaH#}.
[Like other nouns formed with the kṛt aff. {#Rvul#} it may
have the same sense as the infin. of the corresponding verb
(i. e. = {#aBivAditum#}), if it is logically connected with an-
other verb; e. g. {%Nalop.:%} {#Agato'smItyuvAcEnaM BavantamaBi-#}
{#vAdakaH#} ‘…to salute thee’.] <sup>2</sup> One who has the habit of
making salutations, civil, polite ({%comm.%} on the {%Amarak.:%}
= {#aBivAdanaSIla#}). E. {#vad#} (in the caus.) with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#Rvul#}.
<LEND>

<L>6337<pc>264-a<k1>aBivAdana<k2>aBivAdana
{#aBivAdana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Respectful salutation of a superior
or elder, especially of a Guru, by a junior or inferior for the
sake of obtaining his blessing; ({%Vīramitr. Āchāraprak.:%} {#a-#}
{#BivAdananAma vaworAtmAnamaBi gurorASIrvacanAnukUlo vyApA-#}
{#raH#}). It consists of three acts, viz. 1. the {#pratyutTAna#} or rising
from the seat, 2. the {#upasaMgrahaRa#} or {#pAdopasaMgrahaRa,#} the peculiar
[Page264-b+ 56]
mode of Hindu obeisance, and 3. the {#aBivAda#} or the ut-
tering of the formula of salutation.
<div n="P"><sup>a.</sup> The first act is indispensable on the part of the person
whose duty it is to make the salutation, whatever be the
quality of the person saluted ({%Āpastamba:%} {#sarvatra tu pratyutTA-#}
{#yABivAdanam#}); but the two other acts undergo various
modifications according to the rank or quality of the person
saluted and the person saluting.
<div n="P"><sup>b.</sup> With regard to the {#upasaMgrahaRa#} or the obeisance, the
general rule is, according to {%Manu,%} that the saluter should
with crossed hands ({%comm.:%} the right hand being placed
over the left) clasp the feet of his {%Guru,%} touching the left
foot with his left, and the right foot with his right, hand;
({%Manu:%} {#vyastapARinA kAryamupasaMgrahaRaM guroH . savyena savyaH#}
{#sprazwavyo dakziRena ca dakziRaH#}); the same injunction is given
by {%Āśvalāyana%} and {%Baudhāyana%} with the addition that he
should first touch, with composure of mind, his own left
ear with his left and his right ear with his right, hand,
and then make his bow, in the indicated manner, by
touching his Guru from the knees to the feet; ({%Āśvalāy.:%}
{#vAmaM vAmena saMspfSya dakziRena tu dakziRam . hastena karRaM hastAByAM#}
{#gurURAmaBivAdanam . vAmopari karaM kftvA dakziRaM nAma co-#}
{#ccaret . jAnupraBfti pAdAntamAraBya pAdayornamet;#} {%Baudhāy.:%}
{#Srotre saMspfSya manaH samADAyADastAjjAnvorA padByAmityupasaMgra-#}
{#haRam#}); according to some, his hands must be made
hollow, when he touches the feet of the Guru and he
is forbidden, under the threat of loosing the benefit of all
his pious actions, to perform this act only with one hand
({%Paīṭhīnasi:%} {#uttAnAByAM pARiByAM dakziRena dakziRaM savyena savyaM#}
{#pAdamaBivAdayet;#} {%Viṣṇu:%} {#ajAkarRena viduzAM mUrKARAmekapA-#}
{#RinA;#} {%Vīramitr.%} on the latter: {#SrotrasamO karO kftvA punara-#}
{#jAkarRavatsaMpuwitena karadvayenetyarTaH;#} {%Viṣṇu:%} {#janmapraBfti yatkiM-#}
{#ciccetasA DarmamAcaret . sarvaM tannizPalaM yAti ekahastABivA-#}
{#danAt#}); {%Āpastamba%} enjoins, on his part, that a Brāhmaṇa
when saluting should raise his right arm as far as his ears,
a Kshatriya as far as his breast (or according to a v. 1. as
far as his shoulder), a Vaiśya as far as his navel and that
a Sūdra making his obeisance should hold it down ({%Āpast.:%}
{#svaM dakziRaM bAhuM SrotrasamaM prasArya brAhmaRo'BivAdayetoraHsamaM#}
{#rAjanyo maDyasamaM vESyo nIcEH SUdraH prAYjaliH;#} {%Vīram.%} on the
latter: {#aMsasamaM rAjanya ityapi pAWaH . maDyaM nABiH;#} {%Atri,%} how-
ever, seems to reserve this mode of salutation for a learned
Brāhmaṇa in general, while he enjoins the touching of the
feet, if the person saluted is a Guru; {#dakziRaM pARimudDftya#}
{#prakAmamaBivAdayet . Srotriye tvaYjaliH kAryaH pAdopagrahaRaM gu-#}
{#roriti#}). If the person to be saluted is a woman, the
politeness of touching her from the knees to the feet is sub-
ject to some restrictions: if she is the wife of the {%Guru,%}
but not of the same class as her husband, {%Manu%} and other
legislators dispense with it altogether; if she is of the same
class and the student is young, he must pay her that re-
spect only when he returns from a journey, on other oc-
casions he prostrates himself before her at his daily salu-
tation, ({%Vīram.%} on {%Manu%} 2. 217. and {%Gautama:%} {#viprozyeti va-#}
{#canAnna pratyahamiti gamyate#}); but if she is young and the young
man knows already to distinguish right from wrong which
[Page265-a+ 56]
is the case when he has completed his twentieth year (ac-
cording to {%Manu;%} or his sixteenth year, according to the
{%Vīram.%} on {%Gautama%}) he must never touch her feet but al-
ways prostrate himself before her; {%Manu%} enjoins further
that the sister of his mother, the wife of his maternal
uncle, his own wife's mother and the sister of his father
must be treated by him like the wife of his Guru, equally
so the wife of his brother ({%comm.:%} the eldest wife, of the
same class), and that the sister of his father and of his
mother as well as his own elder sister must be saluted in
the same manner as his mother, but that his paternal and
maternal kinswomen are to be greeted by touching their
feet only on his return from a journey. {%Gautama'%}s rule
that the wives of a brother and one's own wife's mother
are never to be touched in this manner is restricted by the
{%Vīramitrodaya%} to the wives of the same class ({%Gaut.:%} {#nopa-#}
{#saMgrahaRaM BrAtfBAryARAM SvaSrvASca;#} {%Viram.:%} {#yannopa°° iti gOta-#}
{#mavAkyaM tadasavarRAvizayam#}), and when the same legislator
enjoins that with the exception of a mother, the wife of a
paternal uncle and a sister, no woman must be touched
by her feet in being greeted except on the return from a
journey, the same commentator infers that this ceremony
is obligatory on the latter occasion ({%Gautama:%} {#nAviprozya#}
{#strIRAmamAtfpitfvyaBAryABAginInAm;#} {%Vīram.:%} {#aviprozyeti#}
{#vacanAdviprozya tu pAdopasaMgrahaRaM kartavyameva#}).
<div n="P"><sup>c.</sup> The formula of salutation consists in general, if the
person greeted is a man, of the word {#aBivAdaye#} ‘I greet’,
followed by the declaration of the saluter's own name and
ending with the reverential word {#BoH#} ({%Manu:%} {#aBivAdAtparaM#}
{#vipro jyAyAMsamaBivAdayan . asO nAmAhamasmIti svaM nAma#}
{#parikIrtayet .…BoHSabdaM kIrtayedante svasya nAmno'Bi-#}
{#vAdane . nAmnAM svarUpaBAvo hi BoBAva fziBiH smftaH#}); e. g.
{#aBivAdaye devadatto'haM BoH,#} or {#aBivAdaya indravarmAhaM BoH,#}
or {#aBivAdaya indrapAlito'haM BoH,#} or (if a woman greets) e. g.
{#aBivAdaye gArgyahaM BoH;#} according to the {%Vīram.,%} some com-
bine with the declaration of the name also that of the family
and the descendants when the word {#aBivAdaye#} is placed
at the end of the salutation, e. g. {#amukapravaro'mukagotro'muka-#}
{#SarmAhaM Bo BivAdaye#} ‘father of such and such a son, descendant
of such and such a family, I, such and such a…sarman,
(e. g. {#kfzRaSarman#}) Sir, greet (thee)’; if husband and wife salute
there is no other restriction ({%Gaut.:%} {#strIpuMyoge'BivAdato#}
{#'niyamameke#}), but the formula becomes shortened in this way:
{#aBivAdaye gArgyahaM gArgaSarmAhaM BoH#}. If the person saluted is a
woman or a Śūdra or a man who either does not understand
the Sanskṛt meaning of the proper name or does not know
the proper manner of protracting the final vowel of the
name in the return of the salutation or is otherwise igno-
rant of the proper manner of returning it (see g.), the formula
of the saluter is simply thus: {#‘aBivAdaye'ham’#} ‘I greet’,
such an address being not considered an {#aBivAdana;#} ({%Vī-%}
{%ram.%} on {%Manu.%} 2. 123. and 126.: {#nAmaDeyasyABivAdanikasyA-#}
{#BivAdamaBivAdanavAkyArTatvaM ye na jAnate tAnstrIM ca pratyaha-#}
{#miti lOkikaM nAma coccaretprAjYo na pUrvoktamaBivAdanavAkyam .#}
{#yadvA nAmaDeyasyABivAdakanAmno'nte'BivAdaM plutAkArArikaM#}
{#na jAnate tAnpratIti dveDA meDAtiTirvyAcaKyO;#} {%Medhātithi%} re-
[Page265-b+ 56]
ferring to the Śūtra and Vārttikas of {%Pāṇini%} VIII. 2. 83.).
[{%Medhātithi%} and {%Govindarāja%} take the word {#nAma#} in the
passage of Manu quoted above in its literal sense and give
the formula; e. g. {%Medhāt.:%} {#aBivAdaye devadattanAmAhaM BoH,#}
but this mode of salutation is not approved of by other
authorities; e. g. {%Kullūka%} in reference to this use of {#nAman:#}
{#meDAtiTigovindarAjayoraBiDAnamapramARam#}.]
<div n="P"><sup>d.</sup> The general rule that prevails at a salutation is that
the person who receives it must be an ‘elder’ or what is
technically termed a {%Guru%} and that the person who pays
it must be a ‘youth’ or an inferior; such a salutation
may be of course occasional, but it is a duty of a youth
to salute his ‘elders’ or ‘Gurus’ every morning after
he has managed the consecrated fire ({%Yājnav.:%} {#agnikAryaM#}
{#tataH kuryAtsaMDyayoruBayorapi .. tato'BivAdayedvfdDAnasAvahami-#}
{#ti bruvan;#} {%Yama:%} {#tato'BivAdayedvfdDAnagnikAryAdanantaram;#}
{%Gautama:%} {#guroH pAdopasaMgrahaRaM prAtaH#}).--For the persons
comprised under the name {#guru#} and their relative superiority
or inferiority see s. v., it may suffice here to give the de-
finition of {%Devala%} who enumerates as male Gurus: the
teacher (see {#upADyAya#}), the father, the eldest brother, the
king, the maternal and paternal uncle, the father-in-law,
an initiated householder, the maternal and paternal grand-
father, and the eldest of the same class; as female Gurus:
the mother, the maternal and paternal grandmother, the
sisters of father and mother, the mother-in-law, and the
old nurse; and to add from the definition of others the
priest (see {#ftvij#}) and the spiritual teacher (see {#AcArya#}).
If there are several persons present who have a claim to a
salutation, the teacher who has given instruction either on
worldly or ritual or spiritual matters, has precedence be-
fore all others, according to {%Manu%} ({#lOkikaM vEdikaM cApi#}
{#taTADyAtmikameva ca . AdadIta yato jYAnaM taM pUrvamaBivAdayet#}),
and, in general, every superior Guru has precedence before
the one next to him in degree. [In the passage of {%Gautama:%}
{#pAdopasaMgrahaRaM gurusamavAye'nvaham . aBigamya tu viprozya mA-#}
{#tfpitftadbanDUnAM#} (i. e. mother, father, maternal uncle and aunt,
paternal uncle and aunt &c.) {#pUrvajAnAM#} (i. e. elder brothers
&c.) {#vidyAgurURAM#} (i. e. the Upādhyāya, Āchārya &c.) {#tatta-#}
{#dgurURAM ca#} (i. e. their maternal or paternal grandfathers &c.)
{#saMnipAte parasya,#} the last word ({#parasya#}) does not imply that
each {%following%} precedes in rank each preceding, but means
each {%superior; Vīram.:%} {#mAtrAdInAM purA yatsaMnipAte samAgame#}
{#parasyotkfzwasya praTamamupasaMgrahaRaM kartavyam#}.] The term ‘youth’
mentioned above is not to be taken in its literal, but in its
metaphorical sense; for {%Manu%} rules that fellow citizens are
equal (as to age) for ten years, dancers and singers for five,
learned theologians for three, but persons related by blood
for a very short time; again, that one must consider a
Brāhmaṇa though but ten years old, as if he were the father
of a Kshatriya though aged a hundred years; therefore a
friend, e. g., is not to be addressed with the words {#BoH#} or
{#Bavat,#} unless he be older than ten years, and a Brāhmaṇa
must never salute first a Kshatriya or a man of a lower
class, however distinguished he be ({%Vīram.:%} {#daSavarzADikakaH#}
{#saKA BoBavacCabdAByAM saMboDyaH;#} {%Śātātapa:%} {#nABivAdyAstu vi-#}
[Page266-a+ 56]
{#preRa kzatriyAdyAH kaTaMcana . jYAnakarmaguRopetA yadyapyete bahuSru-#}
{#tAH#}); for if he does so, he incurs severe spiritual penalties.
<div n="P"><sup>e.</sup> Persons not to be saluted are, according to {%Manu, Gau-%}
{%tama, Baudhāyana:%} a priest ({%Ṛtvij%}), a wife's father, a maternal
and paternal uncle, learned and pious persons, {%if they are%}
{%younger;%} they are merely to be addressed with the words ‘I, so
and so, am here’ {#asAvaham,#} and to be honoured by rising from
the seat; this ceremony does not constitute, therefore, an
{#aBivAdana#}. [In {%Manu%} 2. 130. the word {#gurUn#} is to be taken
in the sense of ‘an elder by learning and piousness’; it
does not occur in the corresponding passages of {%Gautama%}
and {%Baudh.;%} the former: {#ftvikSvaSurapitfvyamAtulAnAM tu ya-#}
{#vIyasAM pratyutTAnamanaBivAdyAH;#} the latter with the same words
except for the last, {#pratyutTAyABiBAzaRam#}.] In law courts, in
houses of penance and palaces where Brāhmaṇas are assem-
bled, the latter are not to be saluted individually, but the words
{#sarveByo namaH#} ‘respect to all’ are to be addressed to the whole
assembly; this mode of address is called the {#namaskAra#} which
is different therefore from the {#aBivAdana;#} ({%Viṣṇu:%} {#saBAsu#}
{#cEva sarvAsu yajYarAjagfhezu ca namaskAraM na kurvIta brAhmaRaM nA-#}
{#BivAdayet;#} {%Vīram.%} on those words: {#sarvAsu DarmavyavahAraprA-#}
{#yaScittAdinirRayasaBAsu namaskAraM na kuryAt . pratyekamiti Se-#}
{#zaH . kiM tu sarveByo nama ityeva vaktavyam;#} {%Vṛhadviṣṇu:%} {#saBAM#}
{#nABivAdayet#}); {%Āpastamba%} forbids to salute a man who
carries fuel, flowers, kuśa grass, fire, water and rice in
his hands and one who performs the Japahoma; {%Kātyāyana:%}
a wicked man, a cripple, a stranger, one who has enemies
after him, a diseased person, a Yogin, one bent upon do-
ing penance and a youngster (similarly {%Vṛhaspati%}); {%Śatā-%}
{%tapa:%} a heretic, an outcaste ({#patita#}), a Vrātya (q. v.), a
person while his head is oiled, while eating, yawning,
cleansing his teeth, performing his natural functions &c.;
the {%Vṛhadnāradīya:%} an atheist, a libertine ({#BinnamaryAda#}), an
impious man, a thief and a cheat, a man fond of litigation,
a drunken man, one who vomits or stands in water, one
who carries rice given to him as alms or one who is in a
lying position, one who performs a Śrāddha, a vow or a
sacrifice; amongst {%women Śātātapa%} forbids to greet: one in
her courses, one recently delivered, one who has killed her
husband and one who has miscarried.
<div n="P"><sup>f.</sup> A man must not salute, according to {%Āpastamba,%} while
he has his shoes on, while his head is covered ({#vezwitaSi-#}
{#rAH#}) and while his hands are stretched out; according to
{%Śaṅkha,%} while he carries water in his hands, while he is
unclean, performs funeral rites or is in a lying position
…, according to {%Baudhāyana,%} while he carries fuel, a
water-jug, flowers or rice.
<div n="P"><sup>g.</sup> The return of the salutation or the {#pratyaBivAdana#} con-
sists, generally, in uttering first the words {#AyuzmAnBava#}
{#sOmya#} ‘long mayst thou live, friend’ or similar words to
the same effect; ({%Manu:%} {#AyuzmAnBava sOmyeti vAcyo vipro#}
{#'BivAdane,#} where the word {#iti#} indicates, according to {%Me-%}
{%dhātithi%} and the {%Vīramitrodaya,%} that the preceding words are
merely an illustration of the phrase to be used; thus the
address may be worded also in this manner: {#AyuzmAneDi#} or
{#dIrGAyurBUyAH#} or {#ciraM jIva#} &c.); these words are followed
[Page266-b+ 56]
by the name of the person who has greeted first and, if
the latter is a Brāhmaṇa, the last vowel of his name, which
at the same time is the last vowel of the whole phrase, be-
comes protracted (according to the general rules on making
vowels {#pluta#} q. v.); some require moreover, that the name
should always receive the addition of the word {#Sarman,#} others,
however, consider this addition unnecessary ({%Manu:%} {#akA-#}
{#raScAsya nAmno'nte vAcyaH pUrvAkzaraH plutaH;#} {%Vīram.:%} {#tatra nAmE-#}
{#veti kecit . SarmAntamityapare#}); the return of the salute to
a Brāhmaṇa would therefore run on the following pattern:
{#AyuzmAnBava sOmya devadattA3,#} or {#AyuzmAnBava sOmya devada-#}
{#ttaSarmA 3 n,#} or {#AyuzmAnBava piRAkapARA 3 i (= piRAka-#}
{#pARe),#} or {#…vizRA 3 u (= vizRo),#} or {#AyuzmAneDi#}
{#…#} &c.; (the omission of the word {#Sarman#} when it originally
belongs to the name, or the omission of the name altogether
are rebuked by {%Kullūka%}). If the person thus addressed is
a Kshatriya or Vaiśya or if the word {#BoH#} is added after
the name (which seems permitted according to {%Kātyāyana%}
on {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 2. 83., although {%Patanjali%} observes that other
authorities do not approve of the combination of the name
{%and%} {#BoH,#} but allow only the enunciation of the one or the
other), the protraction of the vowel is optional; e. g. in
returning the salute to a Kshatriya: {#AyuzmAneDIndravarmA 3 n#}
or {#…°varman,#} to a Vaiśya: {#AyuzmAneDIndrapAlitA 3#} or
{#…°pAlita;#} or with {#BoH, AyuzmAneDi devadatta BoH 3#} or
{#…BoH#} (but the latter phrase should be, according to the
above mentioned observation, either {#AyuzmAneDi BoH 3#} or
{#…devadattA 3#}); if the person addressed is a woman or a
Śūdra or spoken to in contempt or derision, no protraction
of the vowel takes place, e. g. a woman: {#AyuzmatI Bava#}
{#gArgi;#} a Śūdra: {#AyuzmAneDi tuzajaka;#} or in contempt: {#A-#}
{#yuzmAneDi sTAlin#} ({%Patanjali:%} {#asUyakastvamasi jAlma . na tvaM#}
{#pratyaBivAdanamarhasi . Bidyasva vfzala sTAlin;#} {%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#asU-#}
{#yakaH pratyAcazwe . pratyaBivAdavAkyAntasTasya nAmno gotrasya ca#}
{#pluta izyate nAnyasyeti yOgikasya pluto na viDeyaH . tatra pratya-#}
{#BivAdayitrA sTAliSabdaM saMjYAM matvA pluto vihitaH . yadA tU-#}
{#pahAsArTamasUyakastamAkzipati tadAsO pratyaBivAdaM nArhatyASI-#}
{#rvacanaM hi pratyaBivAdo gfhyate . pratisaMBAzaRamAtraM tu pratyaBivAdaM#}
{#matvA vArttikakftAsUyake pratizeDa uktaH;#} in phrases such as
{#devadatta kuSalyasi, devadatta AyuzmAneDi#} which are not word-
ed in the proper manner in which the return of a salutation
should be made, since the name does not stand at the end
of the sentence, the protraction of the vowel is equally
prohibited).--If the person to whom the salutation is to
be returned, has performed the preparatory observances of
a sacrifice, his name should not be enounced but in its
place the reverential word {#BoH;#} and to the wife of another
or to any woman not related by blood the epithet of address
should be {#Bavati#} or {#suBage#} or {#Bagini#} (according to {%Manu%}).
After the person has returned the greeting, he may put
the usual polite questions, after the saluter's health &c.;
(it is not therefore the latter who asks after the health &c.
of the person who returns the salute, for {%Govindarāja%} who
expresses that opinion, is rebuked for it by {%Kullūka%}); the
model, however, laid down by {%Manu%} and {%Āpastamba,%} that
a Brāhmaṇa must be asked whether he prospers, a Ksha-
[Page267-a+ 56]
triya whether he is quite well, a Vaiśya whether he is
happy, and a Śūdra whether he is free from disease ({%Manu:%}
{#brAhmaRaM kuSalaM pfcCetkzatrabanDumanAmayam . vESyaM kzemaM samAgamya#}
{#SUdramArogyameva ca;#} {%Āpastamba:%} {#kuSalamavaravayasaM samAnavayasaM#}
{#vA vipraM pfcCet . anAmayaM kzatriyaM kzemaM vESyamArogyaM SUdram#})
is not to be taken in its literal sense, as the commentators
observe and as may be inferred from instances in the epic
and dramatic literature; thus in the {%Sabhāparvan%} of the {%Ma-%}
{%hābhārata, Nārada%} after having returned the salute of {%Yu-%}
{%dhishthira%} does not content himself with the question whether
the king is quite well, but overwhelms him with an inter-
rogatory of 110 Slokas (v. 151-260) which is perhaps the
completest of its kind, though probably an overdone illus-
tration of this part of a Hindu greeting.
<div n="P"><sup>b.</sup> The object of the {#pratyaBivAdana#} being a blessing ({%Viṣṇu:%}
{#SizyARAmASizaM dadyAtpAdopagrahaRo guruH#} and compare the
commencement of this article), a person who omits to re-
turn the salutation is threatened by {%Yama%} to become guilty
of all the sins of the person he ought to have greeted
({#aBivAde tu yaH pUrvamASizaM na prayacCati . yadduzkftaM Bavettasya#}
{#tasmAdBAgaM prapadyate#}), by {%Angiras%} to fall into hell and by
the {%Bhavishya-Purāṇa%} moreover, if the person thus slighted
is a Brāhmaṇa, to be reborn in a future life as a tree on a
cemetery which will be inhabited by vultures and crows;
({%Bhav.-Pur.:%} {#aBivAde kfte yastu na karotyaBivAdanam . ASizaM#}
{#vA na kurvIta sa yAti narakaM Druvam . aBivAde kfte yastu taM vipraM#}
{#nABivAdayet . SmaSAne jAyate vfkzo gfDrakAkanizevitaH#}).--
<div n="P"><sup>i.</sup> As a reward for performing properly and habitually the
ceremony of a salutation {%Manu%} promises an increase of
life, wisdom, fame and strength ({#aBivAdanaSIlasya nityaM#}
{#vfdDopasevinaH . catvAri saMpravarDanta AyurvidyA yaSo balam#})
and the Buddhistic work {%Dhammapāda%} which has modified
the quoted verse, an increase of life, beauty, happiness and
strength ({#aBivAdanaSIlassa niccaM vadDApacAyino . cattAro#}
{#DammA vaqQanti Ayu vaRRo suKaM balaM#}). Comp. {#aBivandana#}.
E. {#vad#} in the caus., with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6338<pc>267-a<k1>aBivAdanaSIla<k2>aBivAdanaSIla

{#aBivAdanaSIlasya nityaM vfdDopasevinaH . catvAri saMpravarDanta#}
{#AyurvidyA yaSo balam#}. E. {#aBivAdana#} and {#SIla#}.

<L>6347<pc>267-b<k1>aBivAnyA<k2>aBivAnyA
{#aBivAnyA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-nyA#}) (ved.) A cow who (has lost
her own calf and) suckles another; comp. {#aBivAnyavatsA#}).
The word occurs in the {%Mānava Kalpa Sūtras%} where it is
rendered by {%Kumārila%} {#vivatsA,#} and twice in a quotation of
{%Mādhava'%}s {%Jaiminīyanyāyam.%} from a passage referring to
the Mahāpitṛyajna: {#mahApitfyajYa evaM SrUyate . pitfByo'gni-#}
{#zvAtteByo'BivAnyAyE dugDe manTamiti;#} when {%Mādhava%} says
on one occasion: {#atra vatsarahitAyA aBivAnyASabdABiDe-#}
{#yAyA DenvA dugDe#} &c. and on another: {#mftavatsA DenuraBi-#}
{#vAnyA#} &c.; but while all the Mss. of this work within my
reach coincide in reading {#aBi°°,#} the corresponding pas-
sage in {%Weber'%}s ed. of {%Śatap.%} II. 6. 1. 6. runs: {#aTa pitfByo'gni-#}
{#zvAtteByaH . nivAnyAyE dugDe sakfdupamaTita ekaSalAkayA manTo#}
{#Bavati,#} and the E. I. H. Ms. 657 of {%Sāyaṇa'%}s ({%Mādhava'%}s)
comm. of the {%Śatap.%} has also the reading {#nivAnyA#} without
any further remark. It is probable, however, that the
quotation of the {%Jaiminīyanyāyam.%} belongs to a school of
the {%black Yajurveda%} and that {#aBivAnyA#} and the reading of
the {%Śatapathabr.%} {#nivAnyA#} are synonymous terms. Comp.
{#aBivAnyavatsA#}. E. doubtful, perhaps {#aBivA#} and {#anya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6348<pc>267-b<k1>aBivAnyavatsA<k2>aBivAnyavatsA
{#aBivAnyavatsA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-tsA#}) (ved.) A cow who (has
lost her own calf and) suckles another; {%Aitareya Br.:%} {#aBi-#}
{#vAnyavatsAyAH payasA juhuyAdanyadivEtatpayo yadaBivAnyavatsA-#}
{#yA anyadivEtadagnihotraM yatpretasya#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#vA gatiganDayo-#}
{#riti DAtoraBipUrvasyABivA iti rUpam . anyaScAsO vatsaScA-#}
{#nyavatsaH . aBiprApto'nyavatso yasya goH seyamaBivAnyavatsA#}
{#pozaRAdiprakAreRopasTitetyarTaH#}). Comp. {#aBivAnyA#}. A less
correct reading is {#apivAnyavatsA#}. E. doubtful; acc. to {%Sā-%}
{%yaṇa%} as quoted: {#aBivA#} (i. e. obtained) and {#anya-vatsa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6354<pc>268-a<k1>aBiviDi<k2>aBiviDi
{#aBiviDi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-DiH#}) Comprehension, complete per-

as the interpretation of the meaning ‘until ({%inclusively%})’ of

{#ryAdA#} of its meaning ‘until ({%exclusively%})’; thus {%Kaiyy.%} on a
{%Kār.%} to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#AN maryAdABiviDyoriti samAsaviDO Ni-#}
{#nnirdizwaH . vinA teneti maryAdA . saha tenetyaBiviDiH;#} or {%Kāś.%}
on {%Pāṇ.%} III. 2. 134.: {#aBiviDO cAyamAkAraH;#} or on {%Pāṇ.%} V.
1. 19.: {#aBiviDO cAyamaDikAraH#} (i. e. the Sūtra V. 1. 63. {%in-%}
{%clusively%}); or {%Kumārila%} on the words {#A caturTAtkarmaRaH#}
of a {%Mānava-Kalpas.:%} {#aBiviDipakze saMnamanAdeH . maryAdA-#}
{#pakze'numArjanAdeH#} (comp. also s. v. {#aBivAsana#}); or {%Kāś.%} (on
{%Pāṇ.%} {#aBiviDO BAva inuR#}): {#aBiviDiraBivyAptiH . kri-#}
{#yAguRAByAM kArtsnyena saMbanDaH#} (i. e. when completeness of act
and properties are implied); or {%Kāś.%} (on {%Pāṇ.%} {#aBiviDO#}
{#saMpadA ca#}): {#yatrEkadeSenApi sarvA prakftirvikArarUpaM saMpadyate so#}
{#'BiviDiH#} (i. e. when the {%complete%} or {%thorough%} transformation
of the original substance is implied). E. {#aBi#} and {#viDi#}.
<LEND>

<L>6356<pc>268-a<k1>aBivimAna<k2>aBivimAna
{#aBivimAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) The same as {#aBimAna#} 1. q. v.
and therefore used in the {%Chhāndogya Upanishad%} as an epi-
thet of {%Vaiśvānara%} or the worldly form of the Supreme
Soul, since he conceives the whole of mankind as referring
to him exclusively (viz. ‘I am Brahman’); {%Chh. Up.:%} {#yastve-#}
{#tamevaM prAdeSamAtramaBivimAnamAtmAnaM vESvAnaramupAste sa sarvezu#}
{#lokezu sarvezu BUtezu sarvezvAtmasvannamatti#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#pratyagAtmata-#}
{#yABivimIyate'hamiti jYAyata ityaBivimAnaH#} ‘because it is
conceived as Supreme Soul under the notion of I, it is called
Abhivimāna’; and comp. the passage of the {%Vedānta Sāra%}
where Vaiśvānara is defined as the Supreme Soul conceived
[Page268-b+ 56]
as wordly Totatily: {#etatsamazwyupahitaM cEtanyaM vESvAnaro virA-#}
{#qiti cocyate sarvanarABimAnitvAt,#} this passage and esp.
the latter word being founded on the quoted words of the
{%Chh. Upan.;%} as Vaiśvānara is the Supreme Soul in its re-
ference to the world there is a tendency to equivocation in
the Upan., for {#prAdeSa#} which means there ‘space’ in general,
might convey the notion of limitedness--in its sense ‘span’
--and {#aBivimAna#} remind of {#vimAna#} ‘absence of measure’;
or {#aBivimAna#} might be taken in the sense ‘creator’, scil.
of the universe; these possibilities are alluded to by {%Śan-%}
{%kara%} in his commentary on the {%Vedānta Sūtras,%} but the
first explanation is clearly that adopted in preference by
him and the Vedāntists; comp. {%Śaṅk.%} on the {%Vedānta Sūtra%}
(I. 2. 24.): {#vESvAnaraH sADAraRaSabdaviSezAt#} where the given
passage is alleged, and on the {%Ved. Sūtra:%} {#Amananti cEna-#}
{#masmin#} (I. 2. 32.) where he observes: {#aBivimAnaSrutiH pratya-#}
{#gAtmatABiprAyA . pratyagAtmatayA sarvEH prARiBiraBivimIyata#}
{#ityaBivimAnaH#} (i. e. 1. {%as above%}) {#. aBigato vAyaM pratyagAtma-#}
{#tvAdvimAnaSca mAnaviyogAdityaBivimAnaH#} (i. e. 2. {%‘resorted to,%}
{%because he has the nature of the Supreme Soul, and illimited, be-%}
{%cause he is devoid of measure’%}) {#. aBivimimIte vA sarvaM jagatkA-#}
{#raRatvAdityaBivimAnaH#} (i. e. 3. {%‘creator’%}) {#. tasmAtparameSvaro vE-#}
{#SvAnara iti sidDam;#} {%Govindānanda:%} {#ABimuKyenAhaM brahmeti vi-#}
{#mimIyate jYAyata ityaBivimAnaH pratyagAtmA#} (i. e. 1.) {#. aBigata-#}
{#ScAsO vimAnaH sarvasvarUpatve satyAnantyAt . mAnamatra parimARam#}
(i. e. 2.) {#. aBivimimIta iti nirmimIte#} (i. e. 3.) {#. tasmAdvE-#}
{#SvAnaravAkyamupAsye brahmaRi samanvitamiti sidDam#}. E. 1. (and
3.) {#mA#} with {#vi#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw;#} (2. {#aBi#} and {#vimAna#}).
<LEND>

<L>6364<pc>269-a<k1>aBivega<k2>aBivega
{#aBivega#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) Determination, intention; {%Ṛgv.:%}
{#asatsu me jaritaH sABivego yatsunvate yajamAnAya Sikzam#}

{#aBivego'BigamanaM manaso vfttiviSezaH . asat . asti vidyate .#}
{#yat#} &c.; the irregular Sandhi {#saBivegaH#} instead of {#so'Bi-#}

aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6365<pc>269-a<k1>aBivyakta<k2>aBivyakta

manifest, distinct, apparent; e. g. {%Mīm. Sūtra:%} {#tatrotpatti-#}

<L>6366<pc>269-a<k1>aBivyakti<k2>aBivyakti

<L>6370<pc>269-b<k1>aBivyAdAna<k2>aBivyAdAna
{#aBivyAdAna#}¦ Bahuvr. n. ({#-nam#}) (In vaidik Grammar.) A sup-
pressed sound; viz. such a long vowel {#A,#} separated from
a preceding {#A#} by a hiatus, as becomes {%wrongly%} absorbed
by the protracting beyond the legitimate measure of such a
preceding {#A;#} as if in the pronunciation of {#tA ApaH, avasA#}
{#A, yA ApaH, tA A#} (in verses of the Ṛgveda), the
speaker commits the fault of allowing the final {#A#} of {#tA,#}
{#avasA, yA#} to absorb, by unduly protracting it, the be-
ginning {#A#} of {#ApaH#} and {#A#}. [In the {%Ṛk-Prātiś.-Sūtra%}
{#aBivyAdAnaM ca vivfttipUrve kaRWye tA Apo'vasA eti#}
{#dIrGe#} it would seem more natural to look upon {#aBivyAdAna#}
as a Tatpur. and render it ‘absorption’; but as {#vyAdAna#}
means ‘enouncing, pronouncing’ and as a negative value
of {#aBi#} is but seldom admissible in a {%Tatpur.,%} it appears
better to adopt {%Uvaṭa'%}s comment which represents the
word as a {%Bahuvr.%} and supplies {#akzara,#} viz.: {#AdAnamAramBaH .#}
{#viviDaM vipulaM viSAlaM vAdAnamaTavAdAnameva vyAdAnam . kena-#}
{#cidaBivyAptamaBiBUtaM vA vyAdAnaM tasya tadidamaBivyAdAnaM Bava-#}
{#tyakzaram;#} and since the condition of {%this%} defect of pronun-
ciation is the meeting of {%two%} {#A,#} there seems equally no
choice left but to adopt the elliptical interpretation of this
comm., as regards {#vivfttipUrve kaRWye dIrGe,#} which words he
renders as neuters in the dual accus., for in giving them
the apparently more natural value of a locat. sing. the rule
would not necessarily imply the meeting of {%two%} long vowels
{#A#}.] E. {#aBi#} and {#vyAdAna,#} scil. {#akzara#}.
<LEND>

<L>6371<pc>269-b<k1>aBivyADin<k2>aBivyADin

cessively; {%Atharv.:%} {#mA no vidanvivyADino mo aBivyADi-#}
{#no vidan . ArACaravyA asmadvizUcIrindra pAtaya#} (comp.
{%Vājas.:%} {#SUra izavyo'tivyADI#}). E. {#aBi#} and {#vyADin#}.

<L>6390<pc>270-b<k1>aBiSas<k2>aBiSas

<L>6391<pc>270-b<k1>aBiSasta<k2>aBiSasta
{#aBiSasta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-staH-stA-stam#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Insulted, blamed,
accused, whether rightly or wrongly, but esp. wrongly;
hence, calumniated; e. g. {%Baudhāyana:%} {#pAtakABiSaMsane kf-#}
{#cCrastadarDamaBiSastasya;#} or {%Manu:%} {#vatsasya hyaBiSastasya puro#}
{#BrAtrA yavIyasA . nAgnirdadAha romApi satyena jagataH spfSaH;#}
or {%Kātyāy.:%} {#indrasTAne'BiSastAnAM mahApAtakinAM nfRAm .#}
{#nfpadrohe pravfttAnAM rAjadvAre prayojayet;#} or {%Yājnav.:%} {#aBi-#}
{#Sasto mfzA kfcCraM caredAgneyameva vA#} &c.; compare also the
quotation s. v. {#aBiSapta#}.--According to {%Yājnavalkya%}
3. 285 ff. a man exonerates himself from a false accusation
by undergoing the penance Kṛchchhra, or by sacrificing
to Agni the Puroḍāśa, or to Vāyu a sacrificial animal
(compare the legend in {%Manu%} 8. 116. and in the {%Hariv.%}
6428 &c.; {%Vijnāneśvara%} holds that the term {#apANktya,#} when
used by {%Manu%} 11. 200., comprises the {#aBiSasta#}); whoever
makes a false accusation becomes twice as guilty as if he
had divulged the real blemish of a person, and assumes,
moreover, all the other evils that may arise to the slan-
dered person; he undergoes, besides, the penalty of fasting
during a whole month, muttering the Śuddhavatī prayers
and abstaining from sensual enjoyments. The civil liabi-
lities for an insult or slander are regulated according to
the nature of the offence and relative caste, sex &c. of the
[Page271-a+ 56]
parties; comp. {%Manu%} 8. 267-270.; {%Yājnav.%} 2. 204-211. and the
synopsis of the various law authorities as given by the
{%Mitākṣara%} on the named verses of {%Yājnav.,%} by the {%Vīra-%}
{%mitrod.%} p. 148 a ff., the {%Vivādachint.%} p. 69 &c. &c.--<sup>2</sup> Ill-
famed, defamed, of doubtful character; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#pApa-#}
{#rogyaBiSastaSca dAmBiko rasavikrayI#} (scil. {#varjyAH#}) ({%Medhāt.:%}
{#aBiSastaH pAtakayoH karteti loke prasidDaH . asatyakartfkatvani-#}
{#Scaye;#} {%Kull.:%} {#anirRote'pi tasminmahApAtakAdO jAtABi-#}
{#SApaH#}); or {#niyamya prayato vAcamaBiSastAMstu varjayet#} ({%Medh.:%}
{#a° = kftapAtakatve prasidDAnadfzwapAtakAnapi#}); or the {%Mit.%} when
it explains in a verse of {%Kātyāy.%} the word {#saMdigDaH = aBi-#}
{#SastaH#}. Several commentators on the {%Amarak.%} restrict the
sense of the word to the meaning ‘a married man or wo-
man slandered on the score of chastity’, others however
take it in the general sense of the first meaning: {%Rāyam.,%}
{%Bharatam., Padārthak., Nīlak., Bhanūjid,%} &c. {#mETunaM prati#}
{#miTyAdUzitayoH parastrIparapuruzayoH,#} or {#miTyAmETunaparivA-#}
{#dayukte,#} but also: {#parastriyAM parapuruze vA miTyAdUzite mETunaM#}
{#prati AhUta iti kecit . upapannapAtaka iti kecit . miTyA-#}
{#dUzitamAtra iti kecit#} ({%Bharatam.%}); thus {%Sārasund.%} = {#mi-#}
{#TyAvAkyadUzitaH,#} {%Kṣīrasv.%} {#alIkotpannapAtakavyapadeSaH#}. E.
{#SaMs#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<div n="P">II. Hurt, struck, inflicted; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#devi kenABiSa-#}
{#stAsi kena vAsi vimAnitA;#} or {%Manu:%} {#AturAmaBiSastAM#}
{#vA cOravyAGrAdiBirBayEH . patitAM paNkalagnAM vA sarvopAyErvi-#}
{#mocayet#} ({%Kull.:%} = {#vyADitAM cOravyAGrAdiBayahetuBiH;#} but,
besides {#sarvaprARErvimocayet#} instead of the latter words, there
is a {%v. l.%} {#aBizaktAm#} in the place of {#aBiSastAm,#} which is
also adopted by {%Medhātith.:%} {#aBizaktAM = gfhItAm#}); or {%Nā-%}
{%rada:%} {#baDAdfte brAhmaRasya na baDaM brAhmaRo'rhati . Siraso#}
{#muRqanaM daRqastasya nirvAsanaM purAt . lalAwe vABiSastANkaH#} (a
mark of infamy stamped on his forehead) {#prayARaM gardaBeRa#}
{#ca#}. E. {#Sas#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6392<pc>271-a<k1>aBiSastaka<k2>aBiSastaka
{#aBiSastaka#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-stakaH-stikA-stakam#}) The same as the
preceding: I. e. g. {%Yājnav.:%} {#BftakADyApakaH klIvaH kanyAdU-#}
{#zyaBiSastakaH#} (scil. {#ninditAH#}) ({%Mit.:%} {#satAsatA vA brahmahatyA-#}
{#dinABiyukto'BiSastaH#} i. e. one rightly or wrongly accused
of a crime); or {#strIbAlavfdDakitavamattonmattABiSastakAH#} scil.
{#asAkziRaH#} ({%Mit.:%} {#aBiSastaH . aBiyukto brahmahatyAdinA;#}
{%Vīram.:%} = {#mahApAtakABiSastaH#}). II. e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#dEvabala-#}
{#pravfttA ye#} (scil. {#vyADayaH#}) {#devadrohAdaBiSastakAH#} ‘the diseases
which proceed from divine power are those {%inflicted%} through
the wrath of the gods’. E. {#aBiSasta,#} taddh. aff. {#ka (svArTe)#}.
<LEND>

<L>6393<pc>271-a<k1>aBiSasti<k2>aBiSasti
{#aBiSasti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-stiH#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Abuse, calumny, scandal,
defamation ({%Med., Hemach., Viśvapr., Bhūripr., Ajayap.,%}
{%Śabdaratnāv.,%} &c. = {#apavAda#} or {#lokApavAda#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
{#uruzyA Ro aBiSasteH soma#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiSasteraBiSaMsanAda-#}
{#BiSAparUpAnnindanAt#}); or {%Vājas., Atharv.:%} {#amutra BUyAdaDa#}
(v. 1. {#°Di#}) {#yadyamasya bfhaspate'BiSasteramuYcaH#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} {#aBi-#}
{#SasteH . aBiSApAdapi lokApavAdAdapi#}); hence personified:
(ved.) a {%slanderer,%} an {%enemy;%} e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#jahI Bikitvo#}
{#aBiSastimetAm#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#enamaBiSaMsakam#}); or {#tvaM devAM~ aBi-#}
{#SasteramuYcaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBiSaMsakAcCatroH#}); in the verse of the
{%Ṛgv.:%} {#yuvaM sinDUM~raBiSasteravadyAdagnIzomAvamuYcataM gfBItAn#}
it is probably more correct to take {#avadyAt#} as an appo-
sition to {#aBiSasteH#} than to consider {#aBiSasteH#} as a masc.
[Page271-b+ 56]
or as an adject. referring to {#avadyAt#} i. e. ‘you have liberated
the rivers from that crime, the slander’, (but {%Sāy.%} from
‘that notorious crime’: {#aBiSasteraBiSasyamAnAdaBitaH praka-#}
{#witAdavadyAttasmAtpApAdamuYcatam#}). <sup>2</sup> Asking, begging; (ac-
cording to the various Koshas mentioned above; some
comm. of the {%Amarak.%} however restrict its sense to the
‘religious begging’; thus {%Rāyam., Ramān., Nīlak.,%} &c.:
{#BikzAmAtre,#} {%Bharatam.:%} {#vrataBikzAyAm#}). E. {#SaMs#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<div n="P">II. Injury, destruction (ved.); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#naBo na rUpaM#}
{#jarimA minAti purA tasyA aBiSasteraDIhi#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#aBi-#}
{#SasterhiMsAhetoH#}); or {#somyAsaH…titikzante aBiSastiM janA-#}
{#nAm#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#aBiSastiM = hiMsAm;#} but {%Mahīdh.%} takes the
word in the latter instance, when it occurs in the corre-
sponding verse of the {%Vājas.,%} in the sense and etym. of I. 1.
viz. = {#durvacanam#}); or {%Vajas.:%} {#samidasi sUryastvA purastAtpAtu#}
{#kasyAScidaBiSastyE#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#hiMsAyAH#}); also personified
in this sense: {%an enemy;%} when {%Sāyaṇa%} however, and pro-
bably wrongly, analyzes it as a Bahuvr. m.; comp. {#aBi-#}
{#SastipA, aBiSastipAvan#} and the following. E. {#Sas#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6394<pc>271-b<k1>aBiSasticAtana<k2>aBiSasticAtana

<L>6395<pc>271-b<k1>aBiSastipA<k2>aBiSastipA
{#aBiSastipA#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-pAH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Protecting against

butter, {%Vājas.:%} {#anaBiSastyaBiSastipA anaBiSastenyam#} ({%Ma-%}
{%hīdh.:%} {#aBiSastirftvijAM parasparaviroDena nindanaM tasyAH pAti#}
{#rakzatItyaBiSastipAH;#} or protecting against slanderers; e. g.
as an epithet of Soma, {%Ṛgv.:%} {#kimaNga tvA brahmaRaH soma gopAM#}
{#kimaNga tvAhuraBiSastipAM naH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBiSaMsakeByaH pAlayi-#}
{#tAram#}). <sup>2</sup> Protecting against injury or destruction; e. g.
as an epithet of Soma, {%Ṛgv.:%} {#soma…suvIro aBiSasti-#}
{#pAH#} (when {%Sāyaṇa%} analyzes the latter word instead of {#aBi-#}

sary: {#aBito hiMsAto rakzakaH;#} comp. the following word
and its explanation); or protecting against those who inflict
injury, against enemies; e. g. also as an epithet of Soma,

{#parirakzakaH#} (comp. the remark s. v. {#aBiSasti#} II.). Comp.
the following. E. {#aBiSasti#} I. and II., and {#pA#}.

<L>6402<pc>272-a<k1>aBiSApa<k2>aBiSApa
{#aBiSApa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> Charge, accusation; more esp.
a heavy charge, and one from which the accused is able to
exonerate himself; hence a false imputation, a calumny;
e. g. {%Yājnav.:%} {#nfpArTezvaBiSApe ca vaheyuH SucayaH sadA#} ({%Mit.:%}
{#nfpadrohezu mahApAtakABiyoge ca#}); or {#sAhasasteyapAruzyago'Bi-#}
{#SApAtyaye striyAm . vivAdayetsadya eva kAlo'nyatrecCayA#}
{#smftaH#} ({%Mit.:%} {#aBiSApaH pAtakABiyogaH#}); or {%Kātyāy.:%} {#aBi-#}
{#SApe samuttIrRe prAyaScitte kfte buDEH . viSudDipatrakaM deyam#} &c.;
or the same {#uttamezu samastezu aBiSApe samAgate . vfttAnuvAda-#}
{#leKyaM yattajjYeyaM saMDipatrakam;#} or {%Vyāsa:%} {#BAgABiSApasaMdigDe#}
{#yaH samyagvijayI Bavet . tasmE rAjYA pradAtavyaM jayapatraM suni-#}
{#Scitam#}. <sup>2</sup> A curse, an imprecation (esp. uttered by a
Brāhmaṇa, a Guru, an old man and a magician; {%Vijaya-%}
{%rakshita%} as quoted by {%Rādhākaṇtad.:%} = {#brAhmaRaguruvfdDasidDA-#}
{#nAmanizwABiSaMsanam;#} {%Chakrapāṇidatta%} in his comm. {%Bhānu-%}
{%matī%} on {%Suśruta:%} {#aBiSApo guruvfdDasidDAcAryAdiBiraBiSa-#}
{#panam#}); e. g. {%Nalop.:%} {#yasyABiSApAdduHKArto duHKaM vindati#}
{#nEzaDaH . tasya BUtasya no duHKAdduHKamapyaDikaM Bavet#}. According
to the medical superstition, a kind of fever is produced by
the imprecation of a Brāhmaṇa &c. the symptoms of which
are delirium and thirst and otherwise like those of the fever
produced by incantation (comp. {#aBicArajvara#}); e. g. {%Su-%}
{%śruta:%} {#aBicArABiSApAByAM…jvaro pravartate;#} and {#aBi-#}
{#cArABiSApAByAM mohastfzRABijAyate#}.--Also {#aBISApa#}.
E. {#Sap#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#DaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6416<pc>272-b<k1>aBiSrI<k2>aBiSrI
{#aBiSrI#}¦ (ved.) I. Tatpur. m. f. ({#-SrIH-SrIH#}) <sup>1</sup> Approaching,
having recourse to; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#evA ta indro suBvaM supeSasaM#}
{#rasaM tuYjanti praTamA aBiSriyaH#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#praTamA muKyA grA-#}
{#vARo'Dvaryavo vA . aBiSriyaH . aBiSrayantaH santaH#}); or
{#asaScataH . SataDArA aBiSriyo hariM navante'va tA udanyuvaH#}
({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiSrayaH . aBitaH somaM SrayantyaH#}); or {%Ṛgv.,%}
{%Sāmav., Vājas.:%} {#A sute siYcata SriyaM rodasyoraBiSriyam .#}
{#rasA daDIta vfzaBam#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiSriyamaBiSrayantam;#} but
comp. II.). <sup>2</sup> To be had recourse to, to be respected or
venerated everywhere; e. g. {%Ṛgv., Sāmav., Vājas.:%} {#GftavatI#}
{#BuvanAnAmaBiSriyorvI pfTvI maDuduDe supeSasA#} ({%Sāyaṇa%} and
{%Mahīdh.:%} {#aBiSriyA = aBiSrayaRIye#} or {#ASrayaRIye#}); or {%Ṛgv.,%}
{%Vājas.:%} {#vESvAnarasya sumatO syAma rAjA hi kaM BuvanAnAmaBi-#}
{#SrIH#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiSrIraBiSrayaRIya ABimuKyena sevitavyaH;#}
[Page273-a+ 56]
{%Mahīdh.:%} = {#ASrayaRIyaH . aBi samantAt . SrIyate sevyate#}
{#'BiSrIH#}); or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#enI ta ete bfhatI aBiSriyA hiraRyayI#}
{#vakvarI barhirASAte#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#aBitaH sevye;#} but comp. II.).
E. {#SrI#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. ({#-SrIH-SrIH#}) <sup>1</sup> Splendid or shining every-
where; e. g. in the verse {#A sute#} &c. quoted above (p. 272,
col. {%b,%} line 49), where {%Mahīdh.%} explains {#aBiSriyam#} as epi-
thet of {#vfzaBam,#} viz. {#aBi sarvataH SrIH SIBA yasya so'BiSrIH .#}
{#tam#}. <sup>2</sup> Omnipotent, all-powerful; e. g. in the verse {#enI ta#}
{#ete#} quoted above (line 2) where {%Sāyaṇa%} says that the word
might mean also {#prAptESvarye#}. E. {#aBi#} and {#SrI#}.
<LEND>
