Another astrological work, the {%Muhūrtachintāmaṇī,%} lays
down the following rules: ‘the inauguration of a king is
auspicious, if it takes place at the period of the sun's pro-
gress to the north of the equator, when Jupiter, the Moon
and Venus have risen or those powerful planets: Mars, the
Sun, the predominant or the minor planet which rule the
(king's) nativity; but {%not%} on the fourth, ninth or fourteenth
day of the month Chaitra, on a Tuesday, during the night
or in an intercalary month. If it is performed at the
conjunction of ill-omened planets with the first asterism
(reckoned from that under which the king is born) their
influence brings him illness; with the eighth, death; with
the fifth, affliction of his sons; with the twelfth, poverty;
with the tenth, it deprives him of energy; with the seventh
or fourth, it destroys his sovereign power. All is au-
spicious, however, if an auspicious planet enters into the
circle. If Jupiter enters into conjunction with the ninth
or fifth asterism (reckoned from that under which the king
is born) or Mars with the sixth, or Venus with the tenth,
the king will always enjoy royal happiness; if Saturn
enters into conjunction with the third, the Sun with the
eleventh or Jupiter with the tenth or fourth asterism (and
the inauguration then takes place), his empire will remain
firm’; [{#rAjABizekaH SuBa uttarAyaRe gurvinduSukrEruditErbalA-#}
{#nvitEH . BOmArkalagneSadaSeSajanmapErno cEtrariktAraniSAmalimlu-#}
{#cEH .. 9 .. pApEstanO rugniDane mftiH sute putrArttirarTavyayagErda-#}
{#ridratA . syAtKe'laso Brazwapado dyunAmbugEH sarvaM SuBaM kendragatEH#}
{#SuBagrahEH .. 2 .. gururlagnakoRe kujo'rO sitaH Ke sa rAjA#}
{#modate rAjalakzmyA . tftIyAyagO sOrisUryO KabamDvorguruScedDa-#}
{#ritrI sTirA syAnnfpasya .. 3 .. iti rAjABizekaprakaraRam ..;#}
the technical terms are rendered, in the given translation,
according to the comment of the author, {%Daivajnarāma%}].
<div n="P">{%B.%} INAUGURATION OF A MILITARY COMMANDER. This
ceremony, the object of which is to ensure to the chief of
an army victory over his enemies, does not appear to have
been performed before the period of the {%Mahābhārata,%}
where the inauguration of {%Kārtikeya%} as commander of the
divine hosts is mentioned as the type of such a rite; comp.
e. g. the words addressed by {%Duryodhana%} to {%Śalya,%} the king
of Madra, when he chose him for his military chief: {#sEnA-#}
{#patyena varaye tvAmahaM mAtulAtulam . so'smAnpAhi yuDAM SrezWa#}
{#skando devAnihAhave . aBizicyasva rAjendra devAnAmiva pA-#}
{#vakiH . jahi SatrUnraRe vIra mahendro dAnavAniva#}.--The pro-
ceedings at such an inauguration are not fully detailed in
the description given in the {%Śalyaparvan%} of the {%Mahābh.%}
(ch. 46), of the inauguration of {%Kārtikeya;%} but from the
[Page285-b+ 56]
rites which are mentioned, it may be inferred, that they
were substantially the same as those which took place
at the inauguration of a king; (comp. e. g.: {#tato'Bizeka-#}
{#saMBArAnsarvAnsaMBftya SAstrataH . vfhaspatiH samidDe'gnO juhAvAgniM#}
{#yaTAviDi . tato himavatA datte maRiprabaraSoBite . divyara-#}
{#tnAcite puRye nizaRRaM paramAsane . sarvamaNgalasaMBArErviDimantrapura-#}
{#skftam . ABizecanikaM dravyaM gfhItvA devatAgaRAH#} &c. {#….#}
{#bahulatvAcca noktA ye viviDA devatAgaRAH . te kumArABize-#}
{#kArTaM samAjagmustatastataH . jagfhuste tadA rAjansarva eva divO-#}
{#kasaH . ABizecanikaM BARqaM maNgalAni ca sarvaSaH . divyasaMBA-#}
{#rasaMyuktEH kalasEH kAYcanErnfpa . sarasvatIBiH puRyABirdivyatoyA-#}
{#Bireva tu . aByaziYcankumAraM vE saMprahfzwA divOkasaH . senApatiM#}
{#mahAtmAnamasurARAM BayaMkaram . purA yaTA mahArAja varuRaM vE#}
{#jaleSvaram . taTAByaziYcadBagavAnbrahmA lokapitAmahaH#} &c.); the
text (as results from the last quotation) professes at least
that they are analogous to those at the inauguration
of {%Varuṇa%} as king of the waters, and at the latter cere-
mony (mentioned {%Śalyap.%} chap. 48) reference is made to the
inauguration of {%Indra,%} which is the type of a royal inau-
guration; ({#varuRaM devatAH sarvAH sametyedamaTAbruvan . yaTAsmA-#}
{#nsurarAwSakro BayeByaH pAti sarvadA . taTA tvamapi sarvAsAM#}
{#saritAM vE patirBava .…aBiziktastato devErvaruRo'pi#}
{#mahAyaSAH . saritaH sAgarAMScEva nadAMScApi sarAMsi ca . pAla-#}
{#yAmAsa viDinA yaTA devAYCatakratuH .#}). There seems to
have been that difference, however, that the military com-
mander, his installation having been performed, did not
give but receive presents, for the {%Mahābh.%} exhibits a long
list of presents that were offered to {%Kārtikeya%} by the gods
who assisted at his consecration.--The time deemed au-
spicious or inauspicious is the same for the inauguration
of a military chief as for that of a king, except that {%Tuesday%}
is considered also amongst the lucky days of the former,
Mars being himself a military chief; (according to {%Daiva-%}
{%jnarāma%} in his comm. on the quoted first verse of the
{%Muhūrtachintāmaṇi:%} {#kutracidBOmavAro'pyuktaH . sa senApatya-#}
{#Bizekaparo jYeyaH . BOmasya senApatitvAt#}).
<div n="P">2. The water or liquid used at the ceremony of inau-
guration; e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrautas.:%} {#kaRquyanyABizekeRa prali-#}
{#mpate#} ({%Śrīdeva:%} {#aBizekeRa = aBizekodakena#}); or {%Ādip. Ma-%}
{%hābh.:%} {#karRo'BizekArdraSirAH SirasA samavandata#}. 3. The
name of the sacrificial building where the inauguration of
a king takes place; ({%Mānasāra:%} {#sarvAlaMkArasaMyuktamaBizekA-#}
{#KyamaRqapam#} &c.). 4. Bathing, washing; e. g. {%Sāṅkhya Prav.:%}
{#duHKAduHKaM jalABizekavanna jAqyavimokzaH#} ({%Vijnānāch.:%} {#yaTA#}
{#jAqyArttasya jalABizekAdduHKAnivfttireva Bavati na tu jAqya-#}
{#vimokza ityarTaH#}); esp. for religious purposes, ablution; e. g.
{%Śatātapa:%} {#surApaH…SarkarAyAstulA sapta dadyAtpApaviSu-#}
{#dDaye . japitvA tu mahArudraM daSAMSaM juhuyAttilEH . tato'BizekaH#}
{#kartavyo mantrErvaruRadevatEH#} &c.; or {%Vanap. Mahābh.:%} {#plakzA devI#}
{#smftA rAjanpuRyA devI sarasvatI . tatrABizekaM kurvIta valmI-#}
{#kAnniHsfte jale . arcayitvA pitFndevAnaSvameDaPalaM laBet;#} or
{%Anuśāsanap. Mahābh.:%} {#skanda uvAca . mamApyanumato DarmastaM#}
{#SfRuDvaM samAhitAH . nIlazaRqasya SfNgAByAM gfhItvA mfttikAM tu#}
{#yaH . aBizekaM tryahaM kuryAttasya DarmaM niboData#} &c.
<div n="P">5. Washing the image of a divinity, purifying it with
ablutions. This ceremony takes place either at a festival
[Page286-a+ 56]
held in honour of a divinity or at the installation of an
idol as a domestic and tutelary divinity; it consists in
rubbing it over with ointments and washing it with liquids
prepared of different substances under the recital of appro-
priate mantras. (According to the given quotation from
the {%Agni-Pur.,%} the invocations mentioned in the latter, are
the same for the consecration of an idol as for that of a
king.) At the {%Dola%} festival held in honour of the juvenile
{%Kṛṣṇa%} the following materiels are used, according to the
{%Utkalakhaṇḍa%} (as quoted by {%Rādhākāntadeva%}): cold water,
cow-dung, cow's urine, cow's milk, curds, clarified butter
(i. e. the five substances of the Panchagavya), infusions of
Kuśa-grass ({#kuSodakam#}), of Śaṅkha (a perfume, apparently
a dried shell-fish; {#SaNKodakam#}), of sandal ({#candanodakam#}),
of saffron ({#kuNkumodakam#}), of fruits and flowers ({#Paloda-#}
{#kam#} and {#puzpodakam#}), an unguent prepared of the powder
of sandal wood and of emblic myrobalan ({#candanapizwAma-#}
{#lakyudvartanam#}); scented water ({#suganDijalam#}) with which the
idol is washed eight times, milk, clarified butter and honey
being added severally at the second, seventh and eighth
ablution; an infusion of perfumes ({#ganDodakam#}) with which
five ablutions are made; water taken from places of pil-
grimage ({#tIrTajalam#}), Ganges-water, water proceeding from
an ant-hill, infusion of small annuals ({#sarvOzaDijalam#}),
Sahasradhārā-water ({#sahasraDArAjalam#}), various kinds of
water in jars (according to some, in 108 jars).--At the
{%Durgā%} festival, according to the {%Vṛhannandikeśvara-Purāṇa%}
(also quoted by {%Rādhāk.%}) the image of the goddess is rubbed
over before a looking glass ({#darpaRapratibimbe#}) with an oint-
ment prepared of turmeric and powder of emblic myro-
balan and then washed with the following things one after
the other, under the recital of mantras, with: pure water,
an infusion of Śaṅkha, Ganges-water, an infusion of per-
fumes, each article of the Panchagavya (successively, as
mentioned before), an infusion of Kuśa-grass, Pañchāmṛta
(a mixture of milk, curds, sugar, clarified butter and honey),
ice-water, honey, an infusion of flowers, sea-water mixed
with the juice of the sugar-cane ({#ikzurasasAgarodake#}), an
infusion of small and large annuals mixed together ({#sarvO-#}
{#zaDimahOzaDijalam#}), water containing five kinds of extracts
({#paYcakazAyodakam#}), eight sorts of earth ({#azwamfttikAH?#} pro-
bably {#azwO mf°#}), infusion of fruits, hot water, Sahasra-
dhārā-water, various kinds of water in eight jars, viz.
atmospheric water in one jar ({#vyomagaNgAmbupUrRAdyakalasaH#}),
cloud-water in a second ({#meGatoyapUrRa°#}), water of the Sara-
svatī in a third ({#sArasvatatoyapUrRa°#}), sea-water in a fourth
({#sAgarodakapUrRa°#}), water mixed with lotus-pollen ({#padmareRu-#}
{#miSritajalapUrRa°#}) in a fifth, cascade-water in a sixth ({#nirjJa-#}
{#rodakapUrRa°#}), water from various places of pilgrimage in a
seventh ({#sarvatIrTAmbupUrRa°#}) and pure water in an eighth jar
{#SudDajalapUrRAzwamakalasaH#}). Besides these substances, other ri-
tual works mention: river-water, infusions of cocoa-nuts and
of (pounded) pearls, rain-water, infusions of camphor and
of sandal, aloe, gold, silver, {%Gorochanā,%} saffron, {%Śrīphala,%}
corn, Dūb-grass, sugar, lake-water, Ganges-and sea-water
mixed together, an infusion of five kinds of grain ({#paYca-#}
[Page286-b+ 56]
{#Sasyajalam#}), of sesamum, tank-, lotus-pond-, and well-
water, infusions of fruits and roots, Arghya (q. v.) -water,
other kinds of water in four jars, and cold water; sesamum-
oil and fragrant-oil; earth from river-banks, earth stirred
up by the teeth of a boar ({#varAhadantamfttikA#}), earth from
the door of a brothel ({#veSyAdvAramfttikA#}), from the gate of
a palace ({#rAjadvAramfttikA#}), earth stirred up by the horns
of a bull, earth from an ant-hill, from a quadrivium, from
the near and opposite banks of a stream ({#pArAvAramfttikA#}),
from the door of a temple and from the Ganges; and accord-
ing to some, earth stirred up by the teeth of an elephant,
earth from a river, from its two banks, from a town-gate
({#nAgaramfttikA#}), from a cowpen and a trivium; others
name infusions of the five articles of Pañchāmṛta severally,
of the small and the large annuals severally ({#savOzaDi-#}
{#mahOzaDI pfTak#}), of the five kinds of extracts severally, or
infusions only of two articles of the Pañchāmṛta (viz.
honey, butter and milk excepted); again some name an
ointment made of turmeric only, some one prepared of
sesamum-oil and turmeric, and others add an aromatic
powder and one made of five kinds of grain. In the ritual
works founded on the {%Kālī-%} and {%Devī-Purāṇas%} there are men-
tioned, besides, infusions of (pounded) corals, emeralds, ru-
bies, pearls, lapis lazuli, several varieties of lotusses ({#padma,#}
{#kahlAra, kumuda#}), of sugar-cane, lac ({#alaktaka#}), red sandal,
turmeric, flour, rice and white mustard, as well as pool-
water and water from various places of pilgrimage; earth
from five such places; oil made of the Viṣṇu plant, an
ointment made of emblic myrobalan together with sesamum-
oil and turmeric.--The ritual works founded on the
{%Purāṇas%} mention moreover eight melodies which are se-
verally played when the idol is washed with the eight kinds
of water in the eight jars (see above col. {%a,%} line 43), as
well as the instruments with which they are played. At
the washing with the atmospheric water the melody is (acc.
to the ritual of the {%Vṛhannandikeśvara-Pur.%}) {%Mālasī,%} played
with the instrument {%Mangalotsava,%} or (acc. to the ritual of
the {%Devī-Pur.%}) {%Vārāḍī,%} played with the instrument {%Indra-%}
{%vijaya,%} or (acc. to the ritual of the {%Kālī-Pur.%}) {%Mālava,%}
played with the instrument {%Vijaya;%} at the washing with
the cloud-water, the m. is {%Devakīrī,%} p. w. the instr. {%Bhu-%}
{%vanavijaya (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Mālavagauḍa,%} p. w. the instr.
{%Mangalavijaya (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Lalitā,%} played with the large
kettle drum {%Dundubhī (K.-Pur.);%} at the washing with the
water of the Sarasvatī, the m. is {%Vārāḍī,%} p. w. the instr.
{%Vijaya (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Mālava,%} p. w. the instr. {%Devotsava%}
{%(D.-Pur.),%} or {%Vibhāṣā,%} p. w. the drum {%Dundubhi (K.-Pur.);%}
at the washing with the sea-water, the m. is {%Deśāla,%} p. w.
the instr. {%Rājābhiṣeka (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Deśāla,%} p. w. the
instr. {%Ghanatāla (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Bhairavī,%} p. w. the flute
{%Vanśī (K.-Pur.);%} at the washing with the lotus pollen-water,
the m. is {%Dhānuṣī,%} p. the instr. {%Madhurī (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or
{%Mālavī,%} p. w. the instr. {%Madhukara (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Koḍā,%}
p. w. the instr. {%Indrābhiṣeka (K.-Pur.);%} at the washing
with the cascade-water, the m. is {%Bhairavī,%} p. w. the cymbal
{%Karatāla (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Bhairavī;%} p. w. the double drum
[Page287-a+ 56]
{%Ḍhakkā (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Vārāḍī,%} p. w. the conch {%Śaṅkha%}
{%(K.-P.);%} at the washing with the Tīrtha-water, the m. is
{%Gujjarī,%} p. w. the flute {%Vanśī (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Vasanta,%}
p. w. the conch {%Śaṅkha (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Vasanta,%} p. w. the
instr. {%Pañchaśabda (K.-Pur.);%} at the washing with the pure
water the melody is {%Vasanta,%} p. w. the instr. {%Pañchaśabda%}
{%(Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Koḍā,%} p. w. the drum {%Mṛdaṅga (D.-Pur.),%}
or {%Dhānuṣī,%} p. w. the instr. {%Vijaya (K.-Pur.).%} See {%Rādhāk.%}
s. v. {#aBizeka#}.--At the installation of a domestic idol
({#devapratizWA#}) the following articles are recommended for
the ablution by the {%Devapratiṣṭhatattva%} (as quoted by
{%Rādhāk.%}): river-, torrent-, sea-, cascade- and cloud-water,
a mixture of milk, curds, sugar, clarified butter and honey,
{%Panchagavya%} mixed with an infusion of Kuśa-grass; earth
stirred up by the hoofs of a horse and the teeth of an ele-
phant, earth from a mountain, from Kuśa-grass and an
ant-hill, sesamum-oil, clarified butter, an infusion of five
extracts ({#paYcakazAyodakam#}), flowers of the mango-tree, of
the {%Champaka%} (Michelia champaca), of the Acacia suma,
lotusses and Oleander; leaves of holy basil, jasmin and
{%Śṛphala%} (Ægle marmelos.), a cleansing powder prepared
either of the refuse of Sesamum ({#tilakalka#}), or of rice
({#SAlitaRqula#}), or of {%Vilwa%} (Ægle marmelos.) -leaves, or of
emblic myrobalan ({#Amalaka#}); hot water, water from places
of pilgrimage. To prepare the liquid either a hundred and
eight, or fifty four, or twenty jars are required, or one
jar may suffice; the water is taken in the proportion of
a hundred and eight Pala-weight--such is the vaidik (!)
quantity--or, commonly, in the proportion of three
hundred and sixty Tola-weight, and the substances named
are mixed and shaken with it in each jar separately.--
If a person, however, cannot afford to provide all these
articles, he may take merely earth from an ant-hill, new
cowdung, dry cowdung, some water mixed with ashes and
scented water. (Comp. {%Rādhāk., Śabdak.%} s. v.).--E. {#sic#}
with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}. Comp. also {#aBizecanIya#}.

{#aBizekaBUmi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-miH#}) (In Buddhistic doctrine.)
(Perhaps.) The place of ablution or purification, one of
the 108 {#DarmAlokamuKa#} q. v.; {%Lalitav.:%} {#aBizekaBUmiDarmAlo-#}
{#kamuKamavakramaRajanmABinizkramaRaduzkaracaryAboDimaRqalopasaMkra-#}
{#maRamAraDvaMsanaboDiviboDanaDarmacakrapravartanamahAparinirvARasaM-#}
{#darSanatAyE saMvartate#}. E. {#aBizeka#} and {#BUsi#}.

<L>6447<pc>287-a<k1>aBizektf<k2>aBizektf
{#aBizektf#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ktA#}) One who inaugurates or conse-
crates by means of the rite {#aBizeka#} q. v.; e. g. {%Śatapath.:%}
{#kzatriyo vAva kzatriyasyABizektA;#} or {%Aitar. Br.:%} {#so'Bizi-#}
{#kto'Bizektre brAhmaRAya hiraRyaM dadyAtsahasram#}. E. {#sic#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#tfc#}.
<LEND>

<L>6448<pc>287-a<k1>aBizekAha<k2>aBizekAha
{#aBizekAha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) The day of inauguration; e. g.
{%Agni-Pur.:%} {#upavAsyABizekAhe#} &c. (see the quot. s. v. {#aBi-#}
{#veka#} page 282{%b,%} line 8). E. {#aBizeka#} and {#ahan,#} sāmas.
aff. {#wac#}.
<LEND>

<L>6449<pc>287-a<k1>aBizekya<k2>aBizekya

(see {#aBizeka#}). E. {#aBizeka,#} taddh. aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>6450<pc>287-a<k1>aBizecana<k2>aBizecana
{#aBizecana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The same as {#aBizeka#} q. v.;
e. g. {%(bathing for religious purposes), Kaṇāda Sūtr.:%} {#aBi-#}
{#zecanopavAsabrahmacaryagurukulavAsavAnaprasTayajYadAnaprokzaRA diNna-#}
[Page287-b+ 56]
{#kzatrakAlaniyamAScAdfzwAya#} ({%Upaskāra:%} {#aBizecanaM snAnaM gaNgA-#}
{#yAm#}); or {%(inauguration, consecration) Mahābh. Sāntip.:%}
{#rAzwrasyEtatkftyatamaM rAjYa evABizecanam;#} or {%Harivanśa:%} {#na cA-#}
{#DikAro devAnAM rAjendrasyABizecane;#} or {%Rāmāy.:%} {#rAjamArgaH#}
{#kftaH SrImAnpOrE rAmABizecane#}. E. {#sic#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6451<pc>287-b<k1>aBizecanIya<k2>aBizecanIya
{#aBizecanIya#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) To be bathed
or consecrated, worthy of being bathed or consecrated (see
{#aBizeka#}); e. g. {%Śatapathabr.:%} {#ye vA etasyodfcaM gamizyanti rAzwraM#}
{#te Bavizyanti rAjAno BavizyantyaBizecanIyAH…viSo#}
{#'naBizecanIyAH#}. E. {#sic#} with {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#anIyar#}.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Fit for, or serving for,
the ceremony of consecration (see {#aBizecana#} and {#aBizeka#});
e. g. {%Śatapathabr.:%} {#aBizecanIyAni pAtrARi Bavanti yatrEtA#}
{#Apo'BizecanIyA Bavanti#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-yaH#}) The name of a Soma sacrifice: the second
of the seven Soma sacrifices which form part of the {%Rāja-%}
{%sūya%} (q. v.; and see {#pavitra#} or {#aByArohaRIya, daSapeya, keSava-#}
{#panIya, vyuzwidvirAtra#} consisting of two sacrifices, and {#kzatra-#}
{#DftiH;#} {%Sāyaṇa%} in conformity with {%Kātyāyana:%} {#tatra#}--i. e.
in the {%Rājasūya%}--{#pavitrABizecanIyadaSapeyakeSavapanIyavyuzwi-#}
{#dvirAtrakzatraDftisaMjYakAH sapta somayAgAH;#} the {%Vyākhyā%} of the
{%Maśaka Sūtr.:%} {#rAjA rAjasUyena yajeta tasya sapta sutyA aByA-#}
{#rohaRIyaH . aBizecanIyaH . daSapeyaH . keSavapanIyaH . vyuzwi-#}
{#dvirAtraH . kzatrasya Dftiriti#}). It is performed a year after
the {#pavitra#} or {#aByArohaRIya#} has taken place ({%Sāyaṇa%} on the
{%Śatap.:%} {#evaM pavitrAKyAtpraTamasomayAgAdanantaraBAvInyAnuma-#}
{#tAdInIzwidarvihomAtmakAni saMvatsaraparyantamanuzWeyAni karmARya-#}
{#nukrAntAni . aTa dvitIyasyABizecanIyAKyasya somayAgasya pra-#}
{#yogo'BiDAsyate;#} the {%Vyākhyā%} on {%Maśaka:%} {#aByArIhaRI-#}
{#yenezwvA saMvatsarAdUrDvamaBizecanIyena yajeta#}), and commences,
according to {%Harisvāmin,%} on the first day of the second
or dark fortnight; acc. to the {%Sāmaveda-school,%} on the first
day of the first or light fortnight of the month Phālguna
(February-March); it consists of several ceremonies which
last five days, the first or {#dIkzA#} occupying one day, the
{#upasad#} offerings three days and the {#sutyA#} one day. The
officiating priest who performs the initiatory rites and
chants the Sāmav.-hymns specified in {%Maśaka'%}s {%Kalpasūtras,%}
must be a Brāhmaṇa of the family of {%Bhṛgu.%} The principal
ceremonies of this sacrifice (in which seem to have originated
those of the {#aBizeka#} q. v.) are the following: after the
initiatory rites have been performed and the {%Adhwaryu%}
priest has summoned the king who performs the Rājasūya
sacrifice, in proclaiming his name, the name of his father
and mother and that of his kingdom, he takes seventeen
kinds of liquid with vessels made of {%Udumbara%} (Ficus glo-
merata) wood, viz. he takes 1. water of the river Sarasvatī,
which he places in a well screened place; 2. having pro-
vided himself with as much clarified butter as is sufficient
for a full libation and gone into a pond, and having sent
there a man or a beast, he pours into the first wave which
is roused by either of them in an eastern direction, the
clarified butter and then takes the water of that wave; 3. he
repeats the same process with the second wave which is
roused in a western direction; 4. he then takes river-water
[Page288-a+ 56]
in the direction with the stream and 5. against the stream,
6. river-water which has broke out and formed a separate
stream, 7. sea-water, 8. water from a whirlpool, 9. water from
a deep lake, 10. water proceding from rain during sunshine,
before it has fallen down, 11. water from small tanks, 12. well-
water, 13. ice- or dew-water; ({%Śrīdeva%} observes that it must
be collected in places where there is much dry grass,
by throwing a clean garment over it and afterwards by
wringing it out in a cup); 14. honey, 15. water proceeding
from the membranes investing the fœtus of a cow which
has calved, 16. milk, 17. clarified butter; ({%Śrīdeva%} observes
that the water of the Sarasvatī and all water which is not
at hand as well as the water which can only be had con-
ditionally, e. g. that of 10. 13 15., must be first procured and
then the other kinds). He then catches, at it were, sun beams
with the hollow of his hand and joins them with each of the
seventeen liquids while repeating severally the hymns he
has recited before, when collecting each water. Then, he
pours these liquids into one vase made of {%Udumbara-%}
wood, arranges four vases made severally of {%Palāśa%}-(Butea
frondosa), {%Udumbara-,%} the pendant branch of the {%Ficus%}
{%Indica-,%} and {%Aśvattha-%} (Ficus religiosa) wood, spreads
out before them a tiger-skin and distributes the water col-
lected in the one vase, into the four sacrificial vases. Next
follows the toilet of the king who takes off the garments
he wore at the preparation for the sacrifice, and now is
clad by the Adhwaryu in a silk under garment and over
it in a red and white cloak; on his head the priest places
the royal turban ({%uṣṇīṣa%}), fastening both its ends to his
waist; and in his hands the bow, which he strings, and
three arrows. Then he throws copper into the face of a
long-haired eunuch who sits in the midst of the assembly and
represents the various kinds of death. These rites having been
performed, the Adhwaryu invites the king to step on the
tiger-skin, placing under his feet a golden circle and another
golden circle perforated with nine or a hundred holes on his
head; then he lifts up the arms of the king, and while the
latter is thus standing with his face towards the east, either he
or the royal family priest drops the contents of the Palāśa
vase over him; then the king's brother drops over him the
water contained in the Udumbara vase; then a Kshatriya
friend the water in the third vase, and lastly a Vaiśya
the water in the Aśvattha vase. The Hotṛ then having
recited the legend of Śunaḥśepa, the king gives to the
Adhwaryu and to him severally a hundred or a thousand
cows as well as gold, food and cloth; he then rubs the
consecrated water which remains on his body, over himself
with a black-horn-brush, makes three steps on the tiger-
skin at the hand of the Adhwaryu, and having poured the
remainder of the consecrated liquid into the Palāśa vase
hands it to his favourite son. After a libation of clarified
butter the Adhwaryu then proclaims the name of the king
coupling with it, however, this time the name of the son
(by saying e. g. ‘here is Daśaratha, the father of Rāma’).
The subsequent ceremonies refer to the preparation of a
carriage, the putting to it of a team of horses &c., the
[Page288-b+ 56]
giving of cows to the king's brother, the king's mounting
the car, tying on his feet a pair of shoes made of boar's
skin, giving to his bow-bearer the bow with the three ar-
rows and after various other rites, playing a game of shells,
five shells having been handed to him by the Adhwaryu,
with his brother, his charioteer ({%sūta%}) or his architect ({%stha-%}
{%pati%}) and his military chief, the shells being either made
of gold, or the fruits of Beleric myrobalan serving as such
({%Sāyaṇa%} on the {%Śatap.:%} {#akzA nAma kapardakAH suvarRanirmitAH .#}
{#viBItakaPalAni sOvarRA vetyeke#}) and the game representing
the victory of the Kali age over the other ages; the cere-
mony closes with libations in the fire. (The Mīmānsists
do not consider the recital of the legend of Śunaḥśepa and
the game of shells as special parts of the Abhiṣechanīya,
but as rites belonging in general to the whole Rājasūya
sacrifice. For the full detail of the ceremony and the
hymns to be recited at the various rites see {%Śatapathabr.%}
V. 3. 3. 1.--4. 4. 25. and {%Kātyāyana'%}s {%Śrautas.%} book 15,
4-7.). E. {#aBizecana,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#} (II. 2. scil. {#somayAga#});
({%Mādhava,%} however, who uses also the term {#aBizecya#} as
the name of the ceremony, seems to consider the word as
a Tatpur. like {#aBizecanIya#} I.).
<LEND>

<L>6452<pc>288-b<k1>aBizecya<k2>aBizecya
{#aBizecya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-cyaH-cyA-cyam#}) <sup>1</sup> To be bathed.
<sup>2</sup> To be consecrated, to be inaugurated (see {#aBizeka#}); e. g.
{%Rāmāy.:%} {#tatra tvamaBizecyaSca manastvarayatIva mAm . SvastvA-#}
{#hamaBizektAsmi yOvarAjye paraMtapa#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-cyaH#}) The same as {#aBizecanIya#} II. 2.; e. g.
{%Mādhava'%}s {%Jaim. nyāyam.:%} {#rAjasUyakaTaMBAvAnuvftteH sarvaSeza-#}
{#tA . kalpyAkANkzABizecyasya prakriyA prabalA tataH;#} or {#ekasyE-#}
{#vABizecyasya tadaNgaM niKilasya vA . rAjasUyasyApakarzAdAdyaH#}
{#prakriyayottaraH;#} or {#aBizecyaprAkftANgasamAptO devanAdayaH .#}

plained by Mādhava in these instances as synonymous with
the Soma sacrifice {#‘aziBecanIya’#}. E. {#sic#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛtya aff. {#yat#}.

<L>6456<pc>288-b<k1>aBizeRi<k2>aBizeRi
{#aBizeRi#}¦ denom. parasm. ({#-Rayati;#} the mūrdhanya {#z#} remains

if reduplication takes place; e. g. desider. {#aBizizeRayizati,#}
on which form {%Kaiyyaṭa%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 3. 64. observes:
{#avyutpannaH senASabdaH . aTavA sahenena senA . sahasya saH saMjYA-#}
{#yAmiti#}--VI. 3. 78.--{#sAdeSaH . yadA tu kfvfjFzIti#}--
{%Uṇṇādis.%} 3. 10.--{#sinoternapratyaye senASabdo vyutpAdyate tadA-#}

{#aBi,#} and there would be, according to the Hindu theory,
no inflected verb of a base {#aBizeRi#}).

<L>6460<pc>289-a<k1>aBizwi<k2>aBizwi
{#aBizwi#}¦ Tatpur. (ved.) I. 1. f. ({#-zwiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Approaching, moving
towards, access; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBImavanvantsvaBizwimUtayo'nta-#}
{#rikzaprAM tavizIBirAvftam . indram#} &c. ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#SoBanA-#}
{#ByezaRavantaM SoBanABigamanamityarTaH#} i. e. with graceful motion);
or {#sa vetasuM daSamAyaM daSoRiM tUtujimindraH svaBizwisumnaH#} &c.
({%Sāy.:%} = {#suzwvaByezaRIyAnyaBigamyAni sumnAni suKAni yena de-#}
{#yAni#} i. e. who bestows happiness that is easy of access);
comp. also {#aBizwidyumna;#} or {%Ṛgv., Vājas.:%} {#vanemA te aBi-#}
{#zwiBiH#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#mArgEH,#} but comp. II. 1.). <sup>2</sup> Approaching
in order to assist, assistance, help, protection; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
{#(indra) pAhi no dUrAdArAdaBizwiBiH sadA pAhyaBizwiBiH#}
({%Sāy.:%} = {#aByAgamanEH#} or {#aBita ezaREH#}); or {#yABiH kaRvama-#}
{#BizwiBiH prAvataM yuvamaSvinA . tABiH#} &c. ({%Sāy.:%} = {#apekzi-#}
{#tABI rakzABiH#}). <sup>3</sup> The object to be approached or aimed
at, wish, desire; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#UtIryuvoraha citra aBIke#}
{#aBavannaBizwayaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#sarvEH prARiBiraByezaRIyA aBavan#});
or {#SatenA no aBizwiBirniyutvAM~ indrasAraTiH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBita#}
{#ezaRIyEH kAmEH#}); or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#indra sadyaScittamaBizwaye karo#}
{#vaSaSca vAjinam#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBimataprAptaye,#} but see also II. 1.);
or {%Ṛgv., Vājas.:%} {#yo nUnaM mitrAvaruRAvaBizwaya Acakre#} ({%Mahīdh.:%}
= {#aBimatalABAya#}); or {#devaM devaM vo'vase devaM devamaBizwaye#}
({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBilazitaprAptyarTam;#} {%Mahīdh.:%} = {#aBilazitaPalAptaye,#}
the sense of ‘attainment’ in the latter instances being rather
implied by the fourth case than by the base of the word);
or {#SaM no devIraBizwaya ApaH#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#aBIzwAya;#} but
comp. II. 1.); comp. also {#aBizwikft#}.
<div n="P">2. m. f. ({#-zwiH#}) <sup>1</sup> One who goes towards; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
{#A yaM pfRanti divi sadmabarhizaH samudraM na suBvaH svA aBizwayaH#}
({%Sāy.:%} = {#ABimuKyena gamanavatyaH#}). <sup>2</sup> One who approaches with
a hostile purpose, attacking, conquering; an enemy; e. g.
{%Ṛgv., Sāmav., Vājas.:%} {#(indra) mahAM~ aBizwirojasA#} ({%Sāy.:%}
= {#aBigantA#} i. e. {#SatrURAmaBiBavitA,#} but see also II. 2.); or
{%Ṛgv.:%} {#indra svarzA janayannahAni jigAyoSigBiH pftanA aBizwiH#}
({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBigantA#} i. e. {#aBiBAvukaH san#}); comp. also {#aBi-#}
{#zwipA#}. <sup>3</sup> One who approaches for the sake of a desire, desirous
of; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#Urjo napAdaBizwaye#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBIcCate mahyamannaM#}
{#prayacCeti SezaH#}). E. According to {%Sāyaṇa,%} {#iz#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#ktin,#} when {#aBizwi#} would stand in the room of {#aBIzwi,#}
analogously to {#SakanDu, halIzA#} &c. for {#SakAnDu, halezA#} &c.;
a more plausible E., however, seems to be {#sTA#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛt or uṇ. aff. {#ki,#} when {#aBizwi#} would stand instead of
[Page289-b+ 56]
{#aBizWi,#} analogously to {#suzwu, duzwu, pulasti#} (explained by
{%Mahīdh.%} to {%Vāj.%} 16. 43.: {#paro'gre tizWati pulastiH . yasya tatvaM#}
{#CAndasaM rasya latvaM ca#}) &c.; an E. {#as#} ‘to be’ with {#aBi#}.
kṛt aff. {#ktin,#} which is countenanced, too, by another
explanation offered by {%Mahīdhara%} on {#pulasti,#} might apply to
the meaning ‘attacking, conquering’, but would be scarcely
reconcilable with the meanings implying {%‘approach’%} and
{%‘assistance’.%}
<div n="P">II. 1. f. ({#-zwiH#}) Sacrificing towards, in presence of or
completely, a complete sacrifice; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#indra sadyaScitta-#}
{#maBizwaye#} &c. (see above 1. 1. 3.; the word being explained by
{%Sāy.%} also {#ABimuKyena yAgAya#}); or {#vanemA te aBizwiBiH#}
({%Sāy.:%} = {#havirBiH;#} comp. also I. 1. 1. and III. 1.); or {#SaM no#}
{#devIraBizwaya ApaH#} (see above 1. 1. 3.; {%Sāy.:%} = {#yajYAya#}); or
{%Vājas.:%} {#dEvIM DiyaM manAmahe sumfqIkamaBizwaye#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#aBi#}
{#samantAdyajanamaBizwiH…aBimuKatvena prAptasya yajYasya si-#}
{#dDyarTam#}); comp. also {#aBizwikft#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zwiH#}) One to be worshipped by a sacrifice; e. g.
{%Ṛgv.:%} {#mahAM~ aBizwirojasA#} (see above I. 2. 2.; {%Sāy.%} in the cor-
responding {%Sāmaveda-%} verse: = {#ABimuKyena yazwavyaH,#} besides
{#aByezaRaSIlo vA SatrURAm#}); or {%Vājas.:%} {#Iqito devErhari-#}
{#vAM~ 2 .. aBizwirAjuhvAno havizA SarDamAnaH#} (where the word
has the same sense and need not be explained as a Bahuvr., as
{%Mahīdh.%} does: {#aBi samantAdizwiryAgo yasya;#} comp. also III. 2.).
E. {#yaj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin;#} comp. the remark under E. I.
<div n="P">III. 1. f. ({#-zwiH#}) Praise, an encomiastic hymn; e. g.
{%Ṛgv.:%} {#vanemA te aBizwiBiH#} (see 1. 1. 1. and II. 1.; {%Sāyaṇa%}
giving besides the quoted explanation also the sense {#stotrEH#}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zwiH#}) One who is praised; e. g. {%Vājas.:%} {#Iqito#}
{#devErhariSAM~ 2 .. aBizwiH#} (see II. 2.; {%Mahīdh.%} giving besides
the quoted explanation also the following: {#aBizwUyata itya-#}
{#BizwiH#}). E. {#stu#} with {#aBi,#} uṇ. aff. {#qi#} ({%accord. to Mahī-%}
{%dhara%}). [The meanings s. II. and III. and the correspond-
ing EE. do not appear required by the context in the pas-
sages where the word occurs; and the commentators them-
selves either disagree or give the option of the meanings
s. I. The {%Ṛgv. Prātisākhya%} observes that if {#aBizwi#} pre-
cedes as first part of a compound another word beginning
with a {#s,#} this {#s#} does not become {#z;#} e. g. {#svaBizwisumna,#}
not {#svaBizwizumRa#}.]
<LEND>

<L>6461<pc>289-b<k1>aBizwikft<k2>aBizwikft
{#aBizwikft#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-t#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Fulfilling desires; e. g.
{%Ṛgv., Vājas.:%} {#A na indro dUrAdA na AsAdaBizwikfdavase#}
{#yAsadugraH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#yajamAnasaMbanDinAmaBizwInAM kartA;#} {%Ma-%}
{%hidh.:%} {#aBizwimaBilAzaM karotItyaBizwikft . manoraTapradaH#});
or {%Ṛgv., Sāmav.:%} {#aBizwikfdDi carzaRiH#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#aBIzwaPalasya#}
{#kartA#}). <sup>2</sup> Performing a sacrifice; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#tvadvAjI vA-#}
{#jaMBaro vihAyA aBizwikfjjAyate satyaSuzmaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#yajYa-#}
{#kft;#} besides {#aByezaRakft#}). E. {#aBizwi#} (I. and II.) and {#kft#}.
<LEND>

<L>6469<pc>290-a<k1>aBizyat<k2>aBizyat

<L>6470<pc>290-a<k1>aBizyanda<k2>aBizyanda
{#aBizyanda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ndaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Oozing, flowing. <sup>2</sup> Great increase,
excess; e. g. {%Raghuv.:%} {#(maTurA) svargABizyandavamanaM kftvevopa-#}
{#niveSitA#} ‘founded as it were by throwing off the excess
of population in the paradise’. <sup>3</sup> (In Medicine.) {%Ophthalmīa%}
which, if neglected, produces the severe kind called {%Adhi-%}
{%mantha;%} it may be produced, according to {%Suśruta,%} by de-
rangement in the air, bile, phlegm or blood; if the disease
is produced by derangement in the air, the patient ‘has a
sensation of throbbing, rigidity, horripilation, of sand in
the eye and harshness, he suffers from headache, dryness
and his tears are cold’ (comp. {#vAtABizyanda#}); if by de-
rangement in the bile, ‘he suffers from burning pains, discharge
of pus, has a liking for cold applications, a sensation of
smoke in the eye, his tears are warm and his eye is yel-
low’ (see {#pittABizyanda#}); if by derangement in the phlegm,
‘he likes hot applications, the eye feels heavy, is swollen,
itches, is greasy, white, very cold and has a thick discharge’
(see {#kaPABizyanda#}); if by derangement in the blood, ‘his tears
are copper coloured, the eye is red and its small vessels very
red; moreover the symptoms of bile are present’ (see {#raktA-#}
{#Bizyand#}). Comp. {#aBisyanda#}. E. {#syand#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6471<pc>290-a<k1>aBizyandin<k2>aBizyandin
{#aBizyandin#}¦ (In Medicine.) I. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ndI-ndinI#}
{#-ndi#}) 1. Oozing, trickling, fluid; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#daDi tu#}
{#maDuramamlamatyamlamiti…. mahABizyandi maDuraM kaPamedo-#}
{#vivarjanam…. rase pAke ca maDuramatyaBizyandi dozalam#}.
E. {#syand#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.
<div n="P">2. Causing defluxions or serous effusion ({#yadeva dravyaM SarI-#}
{#rAByantare kledaM janayati…. aBizyandidravyARi daDimatsyadu-#}
{#zwodakapraBftIni#}); e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#vidAhiguruvizwamBirukzABi-#}
{#zyandiBojanEH…. hikkA SvAsaSca nfRAM samupajAyate;#} or
{#divA svapnamaBizyandi guru cAnnaM vivarjayet#}. Comp. {#aBisya-#}
{#ndin#}. E. {#syand,#} in the caus. with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.
[Page290-b+ 56]
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-ndI-ndinI-ndi#}) Affected with ophthalmia
(see {#aBizyanda#}) ({%Wilson%}). E. {#aBizyanda,#} taddh. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

<L>6472<pc>290-b<k1>aBizyandiramaRa<k2>aBizyandiramaRa

<LEND>

<L>6473<pc>290-b<k1>aBizvaNga<k2>aBizvaNga
{#aBizvaNga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-NgaH#}) Strong attachment, love, devotion
(‘the feeling happy or unhappy according to whether an-
other is happy or unhappy, the wishing to live or to die,
according to whether another lives or dies’); a stronger
term therefore than {#sakti#} which merely implies the pleasur-
able feeling derived from the connexion with an object, e. g.
{%Bhagavadg.:%} {#asaktiranaBizvaNgaH putradAragfhAdizu…eta-#}
{#jjYAnamiti proktam…#} ‘not deriving pleasure from the
connexion with any object, absence of love for son, wife,
house &c…that is called wisdom’ ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#asaktiH .#}
{#saktiH saNganimittezu vizayezu prItimAtraM tadaBAvo'saktiH .#}
{#anaBizvaNgo'BizvaNgABAvo'BizvaNgo nAma saktiviSeza evA-#}
{#nyAtmaBAvanAlakzaRo yaTAnyasminsuKini duHKini vAhameva suKI#}
{#duHKI ca . jIvati mfte vAhameva jIvAmi marizyAmi ceti;#}
{%Sadānanda:%} {#saktirmamedamityeva prItimAtramudIritA . aBi-#}
{#zvaNgastu putrAdO tAdAtmyADyAsalakzaRaH anyasminputraBAryAdO#}
{#suKaduHKAnvite sati . ahameva suKI duHKItyAdirUpo durA-#}
{#grahaH . varjyO tO saktyaBizvaNgO putradAragfhAdizu#}). Compare
{#aBizaNga#}. E. {#svaYj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

e. g. {%Jaimini Sūtr.:%} {#arTApattestadDarmaH syAnnimittAKyABisaMyo-#}
{#gAt;#} or {#apanayo vA prasidDenABisaMyogAt;#} comp. {#saMyoga#}
and the inst. s. {#aBisambanDa#}. E. {#yuj#} with {#sam#} and {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6479<pc>290-b<k1>aBisaMskAra<k2>aBisaMskAra

{#nAha . evaMrUpASca te Ananda sUtrAntAM pratikzepsyanti prativa-#}
{#kzyanti cAnekaprakArAMScAnyonyaprakArAnaBisaMskArAnaBisaMskari-#}

<L>6494<pc>291-b<k1>aBisanDa<k2>aBisanDa
{#aBisanDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-nDaH#}) A detractor, a calumniator. See
the following. (For the fem. {#aBisanDA#} see s. v.) E. {#DA#}
with {#sam#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ka#}.
<LEND>

<L>6495<pc>291-b<k1>aBisanDaka<k2>aBisanDaka
{#aBisanDaka#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) The same as the preceding; e. g. {%Manu:%}
{#vEqAlavratiko jYeyo hiMsraH sarvABisanDakaH#} ({%Kullūka:%} = {#para-#}
{#guRAsahanatayA sarvAkzepakaH;#} {%Medhāt.:%} = {#AkzepakaH . paraguRAnna#}
{#sahate…. aBisaMDatta ityAtaScopasarga iti#}--{%Pāṇ.%} III. 1.
136.--{#kaH . tataH svArTe kaH . sarvezAmaBisaMDakaH zazWIsamAsaH#}).
Another reading of the word is {#atisanDaka#}. E. {#aBisanDa,#}
taddh. aff. {#ka#}.
<LEND>

<L>6496<pc>291-b<k1>aBisanDA<k2>aBisanDA
{#aBisanDA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-nDA#}) <sup>1</sup> Speech, word, declaration
(with the implied sense of {%deliberateness%}); e. g. {%Chhānd. Up.:%}
{#sa yadi tasya kartA Bavati#} (i. e. if a man has committed a
theft) {#tata evAnftamAtmAnaM kurute#} (and by denying it makes
himself untrue) {#so'nftABisaMDo'nftenAtmAnamantarDAya paraSuM#}
{#taptaM parigfhRAti sa dahyate'Ta hanyate . aTa yadi tasyAkartA#}
{#Bavati tata eva satyamAtmAnaM kurute sa satyABisaMDaH satyenAtmA-#}
{#namantarDAya paraSuM taptaM parigfhRAti sa na dahyate'Ta mucyate#}.
<sup>2</sup> Promise, agreement; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#tena#} (sc. {#daSaraTena#})
{#satyABisaMDena trivargamanutizWatA . pAlitA sA purI SrezWA indre-#}
{#RevAmarAvatI#}. Compare {#aBisaMDAna#} and {#aBisaMDi#}. E. {#DA#}
with {#sam#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#aN#}.
<LEND>

<L>6497<pc>291-b<k1>aBisanDAna<k2>aBisanDAna

{#ca Bartari#}. <sup>3</sup> Aim, intention, purpose, interest in an object;

{#manyakartftvaM ca;#} or {%Sāṅkhya Pravach.:%} {#svaBAvAccezwitamanaBi-#}

<L>6498<pc>292-a<k1>aBisanDi<k2>aBisanDi
{#aBisanDi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-nDiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Speaking, saying, declaring
(with the implied sense of {%deliberateness%}); e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} (on
the passage of the {%Chh. Up.%} quoted s. v. {#aBisanDA#}) {#…sa#}
{#dahyate'Ta hanyate rAjapuruzEH svakftenAnftABisaMDidozeRa….#}
{#yadAtmABisanDyanaBisaMDikfte mokzabanDane#} (liberation or bondage
caused by a--righteous--or by a false declaration)
{#…tatsatyaM sa AtmA#} &c.; or {%Sāhityad.:%} {#aBivalamaBisaMDi-#}
{#SCalena yaH#}. <sup>2</sup> Intent, purpose, aim, interest in an object;
e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} (on the {%Ved. Sūtra:%} {#adfzwAniyamAt#}): {#…aha-#}
{#midaM PalaM prApnavAnIdaM pariharARi . itTaM prayate . itTaM karavA-#}
{#RItyevaMviDA aBisaMDyAdayaH pratyAtmaM pravartamAnA adfzwasyAtmanAM#}
{#ca svasvAmiBAvaM niyaMsyantIti . netyAha ..#} ({%Sūtra:%}) {#aBisaM-#}
{#DyAdizvapi cEvam;#} or {%Ved. Sūtra:%} {#na ca kArye pratipattyaBi-#}
{#saMnDiH#} ({%Anūpanar. Śirom.:%} {#prajApateH saBAM veSma prapadye . iti#}
{#pratipattyaBisaMDiH prAptisaMkalpaH#}); or {%Gautama:%} {#aBisaMDimA-#}
{#trAtputriketyekezAm#} ‘some say that a {#putrikA#} (q. v.) may be
appointed merely by intention’ (another category being the
{#putrikA#} appointed by an express declaration; comp. {%Kul-%}
{%lūka:%} {#aBisaMDimAtrakftA . vAgvyavahAreRa na kftA#}); or {%Śāntip.%}
{%Mahābh.:%} {#yaH karotyanaBisaMDipUrvakaM#} (unintentional) {#tacca nirRu-#}
{#dati yatpurA kftam . nApriyaM taduBayaM kutaH priyaM tasya tajjana-#}
{#yatIha kurvataH;#} or {%Mitākṣ.:%} {#nanu kAmakfte prAyaScittABAvA-#}
{#tkaTaM vyavahAryatvaM tadaBAvaScAnaBisaDikfte'parADe prAyaScitta-#}
{#miti vasizWavacanAt#}. Comp. also the inst. s. v. {#aBisaMhita#}.
<sup>3</sup> Implied sense, bearing (of a sentence &c.); used thus
frequently by commentators, e. g. {%Mītākṣ.%} (on {%Yājnav.%} 2.
27. or 61. or 96.) or the {%Dattakamīm.%} (p. 17. 27. 29. on pas-
sages in law-books): {#ayamaBisanDiH#} ‘such is the sense of
the passage’. <sup>4</sup> Belief, opinion (with the implied sense of
{%erroneousness%}); e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#dadaMSa tAmrAmburuhABisaMDistf-#}
{#zRAturaH pARitale'pi DfzRuH#} ‘the impudent bee parched
with thirst bit her in the palm of her hand, believing it to
be a red lotus’ ({%Jayam.:%} {#raktapadmametadityaBisaMDiraBiprAyo#}
{#yasya BfNgasya sa#}). [<sup>5</sup> Joint junction. <sup>6</sup> Making peace or
alliance. <sup>7</sup> Cheating, deceiving ({%Wilson%}).] E. {#DA#} with {#sam#}
and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ki#}.
<LEND>

<L>6518<pc>293-a<k1>aBisAra<k2>aBisAra
{#aBisAra#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> An assignation, a lover's
appointment; e. g. {%Gītagov.:%} {#ratasuKasAre gatamaBisAre mada-#}
{#namanoharaveSam . na kuru nitambini gamanavilambamanusara taM#}
{#hfdayeSam;#} or in the following verse (which exemplifies an
alliteration called {#mahAcakra#} or {#kulAlacakra#} q. v.): {#rADA SrutA-#}
{#livacanA virasABisArA rAsABisArasamaye vivftApakArA .#}
{#rAkA patAvftaparApyapayAtamArA rAmAtayA paramadurgalitASru-#}
{#DArA;#} or {%Vivādachint.:%} {#striyaM puruzaM vABisAraM prati saMcAra-#}
{#yati yaSca tayoraBisArasTAnaM dadAti tO pAradArikavaddaRqyO#}.
<sup>2</sup> An army. <sup>3</sup> An attack; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#pravfttistErihAKyA-#}
{#tA Svo'BisAraH purasya naH#} ({%Dharaṇik.:%} = {#yudDa;#} battle, war).
<sup>4</sup> A follower. <sup>5</sup> A purificatory ceremony; (viz. lustration
of arms). [In the explanation of the {%Dharaṇik.:%} {#aBisAro#}
{#bale yudDe sahAye sADane'pi ca,#} the meaning {#bala#} and {#sADana#}
are clearly founded on the compound words {#sarvABisAra#}
and {#lohABisAra,#} the former meaning the making a whole
army ready for attack or battle, and the latter a ceremony
observed by princes before opening a campaign; the mean-
ing {#bala#} in the {%Dharaṇik.%} should therefore not be rendered
‘strength’, not the meaning {#sADana#} ‘instrument’.] <sup>6</sup> A
fish; (according to the {%Nighaṇtaprakāśa%}).
<div n="P">2. m. pl. ({#-rAH#}) The name of a country, in the south-
west of Kashmir, the modern {%Hazār;%} usually mentioned
together with the Dārva (e. g. {%Bhīṣmap. Mahābh.:%} {#dArvA-#}
{#BisArA dAradAH puRqrAScEva sahasraSaH;#} or {%Rājatar.:%} {#SIte#}
{#dArvABisArAdO zaRmAsAnpArTivo'vasat#}); the {%Abisares%} of
{%Arrian;%} (comp. {%Wilson'%}s {%Arr. Antiq.%} p. 190; {%Troyer'%}s {%Rājatar.%}
11. cc. s. v.; {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alterth.%} II. pp. 138. 144. 146. 154 ff.
235. 467. 669. 887. &c.).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-rI#}) The name of a town; probably the capital
of the country Abhisāra; {%Sabhāp. Mahābh.:%} {#aBisArIM tato#}
[Page293-b+ 56]
{#ramyAM vijigye kurunandanaH#}. E. {#sf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY;#} the
fem. in {#I#} is irregular. Comp. also the two following articles.
<LEND>

<L>6519<pc>293-b<k1>aBisArasTAna<k2>aBisArasTAna
{#aBisArasTAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) A locality adapted for as-
signations. [The {%Sāhityadarpaṇa%} recommends the following
eight places for lovers to meet: a field, a garden, temple-
ruins, the house of a procuress, a forest, a place of
pilgrimage, a cemetery, the bank of rivers (&c.); but
thinks that occasionally any dark place will do: {#kzetraM vAwI#}
{#BagnadevAlayo dUtIgfhaM vanam . mAlayaM ca SmaSAnaM ca nadyAdInAM#}
{#tawI taTA . evaM kftABisArARAM puMScalInAM vinodane . sTAnA-#}
{#nyazwO taTA DvAntacCannezu kvacidASrayaH#}. The rhetorico-musical
work {%Saṅgītadāmodara%} improves the enumeration in men-
tioning: ‘a bower, a grove, a park, a ditch (without water),
a place where water is distributed, an attic, a hemp-field,
the bank of a river, a thorny spot, a building ground, a
house in the neighbourhood of a town, the ruins of a col-
lege and so on’, these having been the places where the
cowherdesses made their appointments with Kṛṣṇa: {#ni-#}
{#kubjakAnanodyAnanirambupariKAprapAH . awwAlikASaRakzetraDunI-#}
{#roDAH#} (Ms. Paris. B. 155; Ms. E. I. H. 1486: {#awwAlikA#}
{#gavAkzaSca#}--‘a window’--{#DunIroDaH#}) {#sakaRwakAH . vAwI-#}
{#parisarAgArapaScAdBagnamaWAdayaH . ete pradeSAH saMketasTAnAni#}
{#muravidvizaH . yatrA-#} (Ms. E. I. H. {#atrA-#}) {#BisAraM kurvanti devyA#}
{#vallavavallaBAH#}. Compare e. g. the third story of the {%Vetala-%}
{%pañchavinśati.%}--Also called {#saMketasTAna#}.] Comp. also the
following article. E. {#aBisAra#} and {#sTAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>6520<pc>293-b<k1>aBisArikA<k2>aBisArikA
{#aBisArikA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-kA#}) A woman who meets her lover
by assignation ({%Amarak.:%} {#kAntArTinI tu yA yAti saMketaM#}
{#sABisArikA;#} {%Hemach.:%} {#yAti yA priyaM sABisArikA;#} {%Śabda-%}
{%ratnāv.:%} {#kAntamuddiSya saMketaM yAti yA sABisArikA#}); {%Bharata%}
defines this character which is of frequent occurrence in
poetry and affords an insight into the amorous customs
of the ancient Hindus, as ‘a woman who, having lost all
modesty and fear, under the influence of love or passion
invites her paramour to come to her (as quoted by {%He-%}
{%mach.'%}s {%comm.:%} {#hitvA lajjABaye SlizwA madanena madena vA#}--
by {%Vallabhagaṇi:%} {#madena ca--. aBisArayate#}--{%Vallabh.:%}
{#aBisArayedyA--kAntaM sA BavedaBisArikA#}); or as ‘one
who cannot even wait for the arrival of the messenger she
has sent out, but suffers unbearable pains of thirst after
the water of love, desirous as she is to drink the lips of her
absent friend’ ({%Vetalapanch.:%} {#yA dUtikAgamanakAlamapArayantI#}
{#sA duHsahasmarajalArtipipAsiteva . niryAtavallaBajanADarapAnalo-#}
{#BAtsA kaTyate munivarEraBisAriketi#}); similarly the {%Rasi-%}
{%kasarvaswa%} which defines her as ‘one who having lost all
modesty, attracted by her lover's youth and by love invites
him to meet her’ ({#lajjAM hitvA samAkfzwA yOvanena madena ca .#}
{#aBisArayate kAntaM kIrtitA sABisArikA#}); but if we follow
other works on Hindu rhetoric, this definition would only
apply to the second or the last of the three categories of the
{#aBisArikA,#} as mentioned e. g. by the {%Sāhityadarpaṇa%} and the
{%Saṅgītadāmodara;%} the former of which works, after having
prefaced the definition that ‘wise men call {%abhisārikā%} a woman
who under the dominion of love either invites her lover to
come to her or goes herself to him’ ({#aBisArayate kAntaM yA#}
{#manmaTavaSaMvadA . svayaM vABisaratyezA DIrEruktABisArikA#}) dis-
[Page294-a+ 56]
tinguishes between gentle-women who go to meet their lovers,
courtesans and servant girls; ‘the gentle-woman will make
herself on such occasions as small as possible, deafen the
noise of her ornaments and wrap herself up in a veil; the
courtesan will make a display of gay apparel, her ankle-
ornaments will merrily tinkle and her face smile with joy;
if a servant girl goes to meet her lover, her speech will
stammer with delight, her eyes stare wide open with flurry,
and her gait will be awkwardly bewildered’ ({%Sāhityad.:%}
{#saMlInA svezu gAtrezu mUkIkftaviBUzaRA . avaguRWanasaMvItA ku-#}
{#lajABisaredyadi .. vicitrojjvalaveSA tu valannUpuranisvanA .#}
{#pramodasmeravadanA syAdveSyABisaredyadi .. madasKalitasaMlApA vi-#}
{#BramotPullalocanA . AvidDagatisaMcArA syAtprezyABisaredyadi ..#}).
But the rhetorico-musical work {%Saṅgītadāmodara%} is appa-
rently more in keeping with the general division of amorous
ladies (see {#nAyikA#}) into such as are their own mis-
tresses, or such as belong to another (as a married
woman and a maiden) and such as belong to every body
(comp. {#svastrI, anyastrI#} and {#sADAraRastrI#}), when it sub-
stitutes for the servant girl the second category; for its
story runs thus: ‘the gentle-woman goes to the lover's
house wrapped up, afraid, bashful, concealing her emotions,
confused (?), with downcast looks; a married woman will
go to him her speech somewhat stammering, her eye glaring
wide open with flurry, her gait awkwardly bewildered,
with slow steps, and no one will see her; but a courtesan
walks up to her lover in the company of a friend, full
of passion, her eyes trembling, fearless, decorated with
all kind of ornaments, surrounded by people, with tinkling
anklets: (in short) just as she pleases’. This work tells
us besides that some of these ladies prefer assignations
during the light half of a month, i. e. from new to full
moon,--hence called {#SuklABisArikAH#} or dames of the
light fortnight--and others during the dark half, when
the moon is in the wane--hence called {#kfzRABisArikAH#}
or dames of the dark fortnight; the former wear garlands
of Arabian jasmine, are anointed all over with Sandal
preparations and dressed in silk, but do not make their
appearance by moon-light; the latter are anointed with
black aloe unguents, are fond of dark colours, and are
also afraid of the moon-rise; ({#kulajAnyANganA veSyA triDA#}
{#syAdaBisArikA .. kulajA saMvftA trastA savrIqA tadgfhaM vrajet .#}
{#saMlInA svezu BAvezu srastA vikzepitAnanA .. mandasKalitasaMlApA#}
{#viBramotPullalocanA . AvidDagatisaMcArA SanErgamanakAriRI .#}
{#nAyakaM paranArI tu vrajennAnyena vIkzitA .. saKIyuktA madAvizwA#}
{#sPAritAkzI tvaSaNkitA . nAnABaraRacitrAQyA taTA parijanAvf-#}
{#tA . sanUpurA yaTAkAmaM veSyA sarati nAyakam .. Suklapakze kfzRapakze#}
{#dviDA syAdaBisArikA . mallikAmAlyaDAriRyaH sarvANgenArdraca-#}
{#ndanAH#}--Ms. E. I. H.; Ms. Paris. {#sarvANgInArdracandanAH--.#}
{#kzOmavatyo na lakzyante jyotsrAyAmaBisArikAH . kAlAguruvi-#}
{#liptANgI nIlarAgavadaMvadA . candrodayaparitrastA kfzRapakzABi-#}
{#sArikA#}).--[A specimen of the gentle-woman is doubt-
less {%Urvaśī%}--in the drama {%Vikramorv.%} act 2, scene 2--,
when she comes to meet {%Purūravas%} in a purple dress with
pearl ornaments (cf. {%Wilson's Hindu theatre%} I. p. 230 note:
{#aBisArikAveSA;#} {%Bollensen:%} {#kftABisaraRaveSA;#} ‘{%Urvaśi:%}
[Page294-b+ 56]
I feel my strength desert me; bring him quickly--or
quickly lead me to his royal palace’; or {%Rādhā%} in the
{%Gītagov.;%} comp. e. g. the words of her friend, ed. {%Lassen%} V. 19:
{#saBayacakitaM vinyasyantIM dfSO timire paTi . pratitaru muhuH#}
{#sTitvA mandaM padAni vitanvantIm . kaTamapi rahaH prAptAmaNgera-#}
{#naNgataraNgiBiH . sumuKi suBagaH paSyansa tvAmupEtu kftArTatAm#});
a specimen of the married woman may be found in the
daughter of alderman Samudradatta, in the third story of
the {%Vetālapañchavinśati.%} Instances of the courtesan are e. g.
{%Mithyādṛṣṭi%} (Heresy) in the drama {%Prabodhach.%} (comp.
e. g. act 2, scene 9: {#…nIlendIvaradAmadIrGatarayA dfzwyA#}
{#DayantI mano dolAndolanalolakaNkaRaraRatkArottaraM sarpati#});
or {%Amaruśat.%} v. 28 and 69. A servant girl who makes love in
the manner described, is exhibited in the {%Sāhityadarpaṇa:%} her
betel-stained teeth she always displays; with horse laughter
she laughs, but no one knows why; from place to place
she sets, to please, her staggering steps, and dancing high
her hips, she slily stops before young men’.] The best
time for {%abhisārikās%} to meet their lovers is, according to
the {%Saṅgītad.,%} ‘during a dense fog, a winter-night, com-
plete darkness, at noon of a summer-day, while a whirl-
wind rages, during an uproar, at moon-rise, during a re-
volution, when the king is ill, or the town is on fire, during
a great festival, and in the evening’, for it seems ‘that on
such occasions the cowkeeper girls as well as the dames of
the dark as those of the light fortnight had their amatory
sport with Kṛṣṇa’; (but their meeting at moon-rise is
apparently at variance with the preceding definition; {#sPA-#}
{#rikujJawihemantarajanIDvAntasaMcayAH . grIzmamaDyAhgavAtAlI-#}
{#kolAhalaviDUdayAH . rAzwraBaNganfpAtaNkapuradAhamahotsavAH .#}
{#pradozASceti kaTitA dvAdaSAnehasaH kramAt#} (Ms. E. I. H.; Ms.
Paris. {#dvAdaSAnekaSaH kramAt#}) {#. gokulasTAH purEtezu kaMsArA-#}
{#tiriraMsayA . suveSAstarasA yAnti kfzRaSuklABisArikAH#}).
The {%Rasamañjarī%} (as quoted by {%Rādhākāntadeva%}) distin-
guishes in general between {%abhisārikās%} who meet their para-
mours in day-time, by moon-shine and in the dark (see
{#divABisArikA, jyotsnABisArikA, anDakArABisArikA#});
comp. e. g. {%Ṛtusanhāra:%} {#sutIkzRamuccE rasatAM payomucAM GanA-#}
{#nDakArAvftaSarvarIzvapi . taqitpraBAdarSitamArgaBUmayaH prayAnti#}
{#rAgAdaBisArikAH striyaH;#} or {%Kumārasambh.:%} {#yatrOzaDipra-#}
{#kASena naktaM darSitasaMcarAH . anaBijYAstamisrARAM durdinezva-#}
{#BisArikAH#}. For the places of assignation see {#aBisAra-#}
{#sTAna#}. E. {#sf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul,#} fem. aff. {#wAp#}.
<LEND>

<L>6521<pc>294-b<k1>aBisArin<k2>aBisArin
{#aBisArin#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-rI-riRI-ri#}) <sup>1</sup> The same
as {#aBisarat#}. <sup>2</sup> Coming back to its herd, after having
broken away from it; e. g. (a cow) {%Uśanas:%} {#adaRqyA mfta-#}
{#vatsA ca saMjYArogavatI kfSA . adaRqyAH kARakUwASca vfzASca#}
{#kftalakzaRAH#} (v. 1. {#adaRqyO kARakubjO ca ye SaSvatkftalakza-#}
{#RAH#}) {#. adaRqyAgantukA gOSca sUtikA cABisAriRI#} ({%Mitra-%}
{%miśra:%} {#aBisAriRI svayUTAtpracyutA punaH svayUTagAminI#}).
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-riRI#}) The name of a vaidik metre which consists
of two {%pādas%} of the class {%Virāj%} (i. e. of ten syllables) and
of two {%pādas%} of the class {%Jagati%} (i. e. of twelve syllables);
{%Ṛgv. Prātis.:%} {#vErAjajAgatO pAdO yo vAcetyaBisAriRI#} (the
quoted instance being the {%Ṛgv.%}-verse: {#yo vAcA vivAco#}
{#mfDravAcaH purU sahasrASivA jaGAna . tattadidasya pOMsyaM gfRI-#}
[Page295-a+ 56]
{#masi piteva yastavizIM vAvfDe SavaH#} (with a {#vyUha#} q. v. in the
third {%pāda%}). E. {#sf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.
<LEND>

<L>6525<pc>295-a<k1>aBisusUz<k2>aBisusUz
{#aBisusUz#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-sUH-sUH-sUH#}) <sup>1</sup> One who desires to
press out the juice of the Soma plant. <sup>2</sup> One who desires to
sprinkle upon or to bathe. (This word and {#nisusUz#} are the
object of the rule of {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 3. 117., as regards the effect of
the redupl. caused by the affix {#san#} not followed by another
affix on the {#s#} of {#su (zuY),#} for an {%inflected%} form {#susUzati,#} with
the radical {#s#} unchanged, {%without%} a prefix, would follow already
from VIII. 3. 61. and a similar form {%with%} a prefix ending in
{#i#} or {#u,#} e. g. {#aBisusUzati#} or {#°te#} from VIII. 3. 64.; {%Patanj.:%}
{#sani kimudAharaRam . susUzati . nEtadasti prayojanam . stOti-#}
{#syoreva zaRyaByAsAdityetasmAnniyamAnna Bavizyati . idaM tarhi .#}
{#aBisusUzate . etadapi nAsti prayojanam . sTAdizvaByAsena cA-#}
{#ByAsasyetyasmAnniyamAnna Bavizyati . idaM tarhi prayojanam .#}
{#aBisusUzaterapratyayaH . aBisusUH . nisusUH;#} comp. {#aBisozyat#}.)
E. {#su (zuY)#} in the desider., with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<LEND>

<L>6534<pc>295-b<k1>aBisyandin<k2>aBisyandin

<L>6535<pc>295-b<k1>aBisyandiramaRa<k2>aBisyandiramaRa
{#aBisyandiramaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) A suburb, a smaller town
appended to the royal capital; {%Jaṭādh.:%} {#tatrABisyandiramaRaM#}
{#SAKAnagaramapyuBe;#} {%Śabdaratn.:%} {#tadaBisyandinagaraM SAKAnaga-#}
{#rameva ca;#} similarly {%Trikāṇdaśeṣa.%} (The comm. of the {%Ama-%}
{%rak.%} on the synon. {#SAKAnagara#} restrict the term to the
suburb of a {%royal capital;%} e. g. {%Mathureśa:%} {#mUlanagarAttu yada-#}
{#nyatpuraM tacCAKAnagaram . ekaM rAjaDAnIsamIpe nagarAntarasya#}--
i. e. ‘{%one%} term for another town in the neighbourhood of a
royal capital’--{#. aBisyandiramaRaSabdo'pyatra;#} or {%Rāmā-%}
{%śrama:%} {#mUlanagaraM rAjaDAnI tato'nyadyatpuraM tacCAKeva nagaraM#}
{#SAKAnagaram#}. The word implies literally ‘a pleasure ground
where people flock together’ and the writing {#aBizya°#} is
therefore incorrect, since {#syand,#} pref. {#aBi,#} applies in this
compound to {%living beings;%} comp. the preceding; {%Rāyam.%}
(on {#SAKAnagara#}): {#mUlanagare'saMmitajanOGasyAvasTAnArTaM mUla-#}
{#nagarasya saMniDO yadanyatpuraM nagarAntaraM kriyate#} &c.; {%Bharatam.:%}
{#mUlanagare'saMmitasya janOGasya sTAnAya mUlanagarasya samIpe'Nke#}
{#vA yadanyatpuraM nagarAntaraM tacCAKAnagaram#}). A word {#aBi-#}
{#syandIvana#} in the same sense which occurs in a Ms. of the
{%Bhūriprayoga,%} belonging to the E. I. H., is probably a mis-
reading for the given word. E. {#aBisyandin#} and {#ramaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6536<pc>295-b<k1>aBisyandIvana<k2>aBisyandIvana

<L>6537<pc>295-b<k1>aBisvayamAtfRRam<k2>aBisvayamAtfRRam

<L>6538<pc>295-b<k1>aBisvar<k2>aBisvar
{#aBisvar#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-svaH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Praising, a hymn, an
economiastic song; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBisvarA nizadA gA ava-#}
{#syava indre hinvAnA draviRAnyASata#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBisvarA .#}
{#aBitaH svaraH svaraRaM SabdanaM yasya tena stotreRa#}); or {%Sāmav.,%}
{%Ṛgv.:%} {#nemiM namanti cakzasA mezaM viprA aBisvare#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%}
{#aBisvare aBisvaraRAya stotrAya;#} {%Ṛgv. v. l.:%} {#aBisvarA#}).
<sup>2</sup> Invocation, the calling near, the urging to one's presence;
e. g. {%Ṛgv., Sāmav.:%} {#sTAtA raTasya haryoraBisvara indro dfhLA#}
{#cidArujaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#haryoraSvayoraBisvare'smadABimuKyena preraRe#}
{#nimittaBUte sati#} i. e. the calling his horses towards us being
the motive of Indra's mounting his chariot, or ‘he mounts
his chariot for the purpose ({%dative%}) of urging the horses to
our presence’). [The {%Ṛgv. Prātiś.%} notices the unchanged
condition of {#s#} in this compound.] E. {#svf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
[Page296-a+ 56]
aff. {#vic#}. (The first explanation of {%Sāyaṇa%} which appa-
rently represents the word as a {%Bahuvr. n.%} of {#aBi#} and
{#svar#} can be scarcely correct, since {#aBisvar#} is udātta on the
last syllable; his subsequent gloss is therefore preferable;
the dative {#aBisvare#} is udātta on the last syllable according
to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 168. and need not be referred, therefore, to
a base {#aBisvara#} for which there is no authority.)
<LEND>

e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBisvartAro arkaM na suzwuBaH#}. E. {#svf#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#tfc#}.

<L>6540<pc>296-a<k1>aBihata<k2>aBihata

jured; e. g. {%Ādip. Mahābh.:%} {#tAM drOpadIM prekzya tadA sma sarve#}
{#kandarpavARABihatA baBUvuH;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#vajramuzwerviSiSleza mEnde-#}
{#nABihataM SiraH;#} or {%Raghuv.:%} {#kaScitkarAByAmupagUQanAlamAlo-#}
{#lapatrABihatadvirePam . rajoBirantaH parivezabanDi lIlAravindaM#}
{#BramayAMcakAra;#} or {%Amaruśat.:%} {#kzipto hastAvalagnaH prasaBamaBi-#}
{#hato'pyAdadAno'SuMkAntaM gfhRan#} &c.; or {%Pāṇ. Śikṣā%} (ed.
Calc. and {%Weber%} in the {%Ind. Stud.%}): {#sodIrRo mUrDnyaBihato#}

{%S.:%} {#duHKamADyAtmikamADiBOtikamADidEvikaM ca yenABihatAH#}

{#vApi jantorlalAwadeSe'Bihatasya tEstu . nAsA sravetpUyam#} &c.

{%Suśruta:%} {#vyAyAmaBArADvaparikzatena vegAvaroDABihatena cA-#}
{#pi#} &c.; or {#purIzamAsyAdapi vA nireti purIzavege'Bihate#}
{#narasya#}. <sup>4</sup> (In {%Arithmetic.%}) Multiplied; e. g. {%Līlāvatī:%} {#anyo-#}
{#nyahArABihatO harAMSO rASyoH samacCedaviDAnamevam . miTo#}
{#harAByAmapavartitAByAM yadvA harAMSO suDiyAtra guRyO#}. E. {#han#}
with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>6549<pc>296-b<k1>aBihAra<k2>aBihAra
{#aBihAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Seizing or robbing any thing
in the owner's presence ({%Amarak., Jaṭādh.:%} = {#aBigrahaRa;#}
see the following meaning). <sup>2</sup> Robbing or stealing, in ge-
neral; ({%Amarak., Med., Hem., Ajayap., Śabdaratnāv.%} &c.:
= {#cOrya;#} {%Bharata:%} {#aBimuKagrahaRe sarvato grahaRe ca#}); e. g.
{%Śāntip. Mahābh.:%} {#ye guptAScEva durgASca deSAstezu praveSayet .#}
{#Danino balamuKyAMSca sAntvayitvA punaH punaH . sasyABihAraM kuryAcca#}
{#svayameva narADipaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Attack, assault ({%Amarak., Bharata:%}
{%Med.%} &c.: = {#aBiyoga;#} {%Rāmāsr.:%} {#aBigamyAkramaRamaBiyogaH;#}
‘approaching out of desire to do injury’ {#apacikIrzayABiga-#}
{#myAkramaRam#}). <sup>4</sup> Strenuous effort, exertion (;accord. to {%Mathu-%}
{%reśās%} explan. of {#aBiyoga#} in the {%Amarak.:%} = {#udyoga;#} and
{%Hem. nān.:%} = {#udyama;#} for the verse 4. 235. in the latter runs,
according to the best Mss. thus: {#aBihAraH saMnahane cOriko-#}
{#dyamayorapi;#} the last words being in the room of the absurd
lesson of the Calc. ed.: {#…cOryamadyapayorapi,#} according
to which the word would mean instead of ‘exertion’, ‘a
wine-drinker!’). <sup>5</sup> Arming, taking up an armour or arms
in general ({%Amarak.%} &c. &c.: {#saMnahana#} or {#saMnAha;#} {%Bharata:%}
= {#saMnAhagrahaRam . KaqgakavacAdigrahaRamityanye#}). <sup>6</sup> Mingling to-
gether, intermixture; e. g. {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%} (things may be
imperceptible) {#…sOkzmyAdvyavaDAnAdaBiBavAtsamAnABihA-#}
{#rAcca#} ({%Vijnānāch.:%} {#samAnABihAraH sajAtIyasaMvalanam . yaTA#}
{#mAhizagavyamiSraRAnmAhizatvAgrahaRAditi#}). E. {#hf#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6552<pc>296-b<k1>aBihita<k2>aBihita<h>1
I. {#aBihita#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Said, spoken,
declared, called, named; e. g. {%Śāntip. Mahābh.:%} {#BaradvAja#}
{#uvAca . yadetadBavatABihitaM suKAnAM paramA sTitiriti na ta-#}
{#dupagfhRImaH;#} or {%Gauḍap.%} on the {%Sāṅkhyak.:%} {#yamA niyamASca#}
{#pAtaYjale'BihitAH;#} or {%Nyāya S.:%} {#vijYAtasya parizadA tri-#}
{#raBihitasyApyapratyuccAraRamananuBAzaRam;#} or {%Vṛhasp.:%} {#arTinA-#}
[Page297-a+ 56]
{#Bihito yo'rTaH pratyarTo yadi taM taTA . prapadya pAraRaM brUyAtpra-#}
{#tyavaskandanaM hi tat;#} or {%Suśr.:%} {#sirAvyaDaviDO pUrvaM narA ye ca#}
{#vivarjitAH . na tezAM nIlikAM viDyedanyatrABihitAdBizak;#} or
{#iti yatprAgaBihitaM vistarastasya vakzyate;#} or {%spoken to, addressed:%}
e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#vipAko'yaM daSagrIva saMdfzwo'nAgato mayA .#}
{#tvaM tenABihitaH paTyaM kiM kopaM na niyacCasi;#} or {%Daśakum.:%}
{#mayA tu smayamAnenABihitam . sOmya#} &c.; see {%Kaiyyaṭa'%}s ex-
planation at the end of {#aBihita#} II. <sup>2</sup> Determined, con-
veyed, explicit or clear (as the sense); e. g. {%Pāṇini%} inscribes
the chapter treating on the use of the oblique cases: {#anaBi-#}
{#hite#} i. e. when the sense of the case requires an expla-
nation; the sense of the {%base%} is naturally conveyed by the
first case or nominative ({%Patanj.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} II. 3. 1.: {#anaBi-#}
{#hitastu viBaktyarTastasmAdanaBihitavacanam . kaH punarviBaktyarTaH .#}
{#ekatvAdayo viBaktyarTAH . tezvanaBihitezu karmAdayo'BihitA#}
{#viBaktInAmutpattO nimittatvAya mA BUvanniti tasmAdanaBihi-#}
{#tavacanam . tasmAdanaBihitADikAraH kriyate .;#} comp. II. 3. 46.
and {%Vārtt.:%} {#aBihite praTamA#}); or {%Nyāya S.:%} {#aviSezABi-#}
{#hite'rTe vakturaBiprAyAdarTAntarakalpanA vAkcCalam#}. See {%Kaiyy.%}
at the end of II. <sup>3</sup> Placed upon, fastened upon; e. g.
{%Mānava-Kalpa-S.:%} {#aBihitatamaM dakziRaM kuryAt#} (scil. {#pari-#}
{#Dim#}) i. e. placed nearest the Āhavanīya fire; or {#upaBfdDruva-#}
{#yoH sakASAdaBihitatarA#} i. e. the {#juhU#} is placed nearer the
Āhavanīya than the {#upaBft#} and {#DruvA#} ({%Kumārila'%}s {%Bhāṣya:%}
{#upaBftaH sakASAjjuhUrAhavanIyasaMnikfzwatarA#}). See {%Kaiyy.%} at
the end of {#aBihita#} II.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-taH#}) The proper name of a Gotra-or family-
chief; his descendants are called {#aBihitAH#} or {#ABihitayaH;#}
another reading of the word is {#anaBihita#} q. v. ({%Vardha-%}
{%māna,%} the author of the {%Gaṇaratnamahodadhi:%} {#aBipUrvasya#}
{#hinoterdaDAtervA kte naYi ca . anaBihitastasyAnaBihitAH .#}
{#AnaBihitayaH . kecidaBihiteti naYA vinA paWanti . tatrA-#}
{#BihitAH . ABihitayaH#}).
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-tam#}) A word; e. g. {%Kāvyaprak.:%} {#sAmAnyarUpARAM#}
{#padArTAnAmAkANkzAsaMniDiyogyatAvaSAtparasparasaMsargo yatrApa-#}
{#dArTo'pi viSezarUpo vAkyArTastatrABihitAnvayavAde kA vArtA#}
{#vyaNgyasyABiDeyatAyAM ye'pyAhuH#} &c.; or {%Sāhityad.:%} {#tA-#}
{#tparyArTastadboDakaM ca vAkyamityaBihitAnvayavAdinAM matam#} (i. e.
the opinion of those who contend that the purport of a
sentence arises from the logical connexion between the
words of the sentence); or {%comm.%} on the {%Sāh.:%} {#aBihitA-#}
{#nAmaBiDayA lakzaRayA vA padopasTApitAnvayaboDavAdinAM prA-#}
{#cInanEyAyikAnAmityarTaH#} (the latter maintaining that the
‘purport’ of a sentence follows from the original or ellip-
tical sense of the words themselves).
<div n="P">4. f. ({#-tA#}) The name of a plant (Commelina salici-
folia); see {#jalapippalI#} ({%Nigh. Prak.%}). E. {#DA#} with {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#kta#} (2. also referred to II. {#aBihita#}).
<LEND>

<L>6553<pc>297-a<k1>aBihita<k2>aBihita<h>2

{#ityatra banDanavfttiH . aBihitaH Sloka ityuccAraRavfttiH . aBi-#}

<L>6559<pc>297-b<k1>aBihrut<k2>aBihrut

{#Dako'si hi#}); or {%Atharv.:%} {#apa tasya dvezo gamedaBihruto#}

<L>6560<pc>297-b<k1>aBihruti<k2>aBihruti

<L>6561<pc>297-b<k1>aBihvAra<k2>aBihvAra
{#aBihvAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) (ved. Probably.) Evil, misfor-
tune, sin; e. g. {%Atharv.:%} {#yo asya samiDaM veda kzatriyeRa samA-#}
{#hitAm . nABihvAre padaM ni daDAti sa mftyave#} ‘he does
not put his foot into misfortune (or into sin which leads)
to death’. ({%Roth%} and {%Whitney%} in their edition of the
{%Atharv.%} write {#aBihvAra;#} but the former gives in a quotation
of this passage in his Dictionary the form {#aBihvara#} which
seems less correct.) E. {#hvf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6562<pc>297-b<k1>aBI<k2>aBI<h>1

as the first part of several Tatpur. See the following ar-
ticles and the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>6563<pc>297-b<k1>aBI<k2>aBI<h>2
II. {#aBI#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-BIH-BIH-Bi#}) Fearless; e. g.
{%Rāmāy.:%} {#niSvasantaM yaTA nAgaM rAvaRaM vAnarottamaH . sahasA#}
{#paramodvignaH sopAsarpadaBIstataH;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#aBiyAtAvaraM#}
{#tuNgaM BUBftaM ruciraM puraH#} where the comm. analyze {#aBiyA-#}
{#tAvaraM#} either {#aBiyAtA#} (fut.) and {#varam,#} or {#aBiyA#} (instr.
[Page298-a+ 56]
of {#aBiyA#} q. v.) and {#atAvaram (= atasya Avaram#}), or
{#aBiyAtA#} (instr. of {#aBiyAt#}) and {#varam,#} or {#aBiyA#} (instr.
of {#aBI#}) and {#atA#} (instr. of {#at:#} ‘going’) and {#Avaram;#}
see also {#aBIBABiBUBABU#}. Comp. III. {#aBIka#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#BI#}.
<LEND>

<L>6564<pc>298-a<k1>aBIka<k2>aBIka<h>1
I. {#aBIka#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) Lustful, libidinous; e. g.
{%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#dadfSe parRaSAlAyAM rAkzasyABIkayATa saH#} (comm. =
{#kAmukyA#}); the same as {#aBika#}. E. See s. v. {#aBika;#} with
the protraction of the second syllable. [The {%Śabdaratnāvalī%}
which has only the form {#aBIka#} gives the meanings: <sup>1</sup> Lustful
({#kAmuka#}). <sup>2</sup> Anxious ({#utsuka#}); the former perhaps in re-
ference to the E. {#kam#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#qa;#} the latter in
reference to the E. {#aBi,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.]
<LEND>

<L>6565<pc>298-a<k1>aBIka<k2>aBIka<h>2
II. {#aBIka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) (ved.) [occurs especially in the
locative {#aBIke#}] <sup>1</sup> Neighbourhood, vicinity ({#aBIke#} near;
perhaps also in reference to time: {%soon; Nirukta:%} = {#A-#}
{#sanna#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#ko vAM mahaScittyajaso aBIka uruzyantaM#}
{#mADvI dasrA na UtI#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#AsannapradeSe#}); or {#sadyo#}
{#dasyUnpra mfRa kutsyena pra sUraScakraM vfhatAdaBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#samIpe#}
or {#saMgrAme,#} see the following); or {#pari vAmaSvA vapuzaH pataNgA#}
{#vayo vahantvaruzA aBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#gfhasamIpe#}); or {#svarvatIrita#}
{#UtIryuvoraha citrA aBIke aBavannaBizwayaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#samIpe#});
or {%Ṛgv., Vājas.:%} {#A yadize nfpatiM teja AnawSuci reto#}
{#niziktaM dyOraBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#AsannakAle#} {%soon, Māhidh.:%} = {#samIpe,#}
{%Sāy.%} considering {#dyOH#} as an epithet ‘luminous’ of Agni;
{%Mahīdh.%} as a {%genitive%}--not {%ablat.%}--depending on {#aBIke#});
or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#mahaScidagna enaso aBIka UrvAddevAnAmuta martyAnAm#}
({%Sāy.:%} = {#antike,#} with {#devAnAm#} and {#martyAnAm#} depending
on it). <sup>2</sup> Battle, combat ({%Nigh.:%} = {#saMgrAma#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
{#Asno vfkasya vartikAmaBIke yuvaM narA nAsatyAmumuktam#} ({%Sāy.:%}
{#saMgrAme#} i. e. in the battle between the wolf and the quail;
the abl. {#AsnaH#} depending not on {#aBIke,#} but on {#amumu-#}
{#ktam#}); or {#atriM na mahastamaso mumuktaM tUrvataM narA duritAdaBIke#}
({%Sāy.:%} = {#saMgrAme,#} the abl. {#duritAt#} depending on {#tUrvatam,#}
not on {#aBIke#}); or {#tvaM no asyA indra durhaRAyAH pAhi vajri-#}
{#bo duritAdaBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#samIpavartini saMgrAme,#} the abl.
{#duritAt#} depending on {#pAhi,#} not on {#aBIke#}); or {#ahannindro#}
{#adahadagnirindo purA dasyUnmaDyandinAdaBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#saMgrAme#}).
[These two meanings of the word answer perfectly the
sense of all the ved. passages where it occurs; other mean-
ings leant to this word, are neither required nor founded
on authority.] E. {#ac#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ac;#} (the for-
mation being analogous to {#pratIka, samIka, anUka;#} {%Sāyaṇa%}
who gives this E. and assimilates it in this derivation to
the words of the {%Gaṇa%} {#pacAdi,#} on account of the affix,
and to those of the {%Gaṇa%} {#pfzodara,#} on acc. of the irregu-
larity in the composition, proposes also an E. {#i (iR)#}
with {#aBi,#} uṇ. aff. {#kak;#} but the former is preferable; the
literal sense of the word is therefore ‘approaching’; comp.
{#aBigamana, aBiyAna#} and similar compounds.
<LEND>

<L>6567<pc>298-a<k1>aBIkzRam<k2>aBIkzRam
{#aBIkzRam#}¦ Avyayībh. <sup>1</sup> Repeatedly, frequently ({%Amarak.,%}
{%Hemach., Ajayap., Śabdar.%} &c.); e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#mUtre niku-#}
[Page298-b+ 56]
{#mBArDapalaM vipAcya pibedaBIkzRaM kuqavArDamAtram;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%}
{#icCantyaBIkzRaM kzayamAtmano'pi na jYAtayastulyakulasya lakzmIm;#}
or {%Sāhityad.:%} {#vinayati sudfSo dfSoH parAgaM praRayini kOsu-#}
{#mamAnanAnilena . tadahitayuvateraBIkzRamakzRordvayamapi rozara-#}
{#joBirApupUre;#} or {%Kṣīrasv.%} and {%Vardhamāna%} (the author
of the {%Gaṇaratnam.%}): {#aBIkzRamAsPAlayatIva kumBam;#} or
{%Bhāgav. Pur.:%} {#aBIkzRAvagAhakapiSAYjawilAnkuwilAlakAn .#}
{#AtmAnaM cogratapasA biBratI cIriRaM kfSam#}. <sup>2</sup> Constantly,
always ({%Amarak.%} &c.); e. g. {%Kṣīrasv.:%} {#aBIkzRaM vakti#}.
<sup>3</sup> Much, exceedingly, eminently ({%Trik., Med., Śabdar.%} &c.);
e. g. {%Kenopan.:%} {#aTADyAtmaM yadetadgacCatIva ca mano'nena cEta-#}
{#dupasmaratyaBIkzRaM saMkalpaH#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} = {#BfSam#}). <sup>4</sup> Quickly;
({%Hem., Med., Śabdar.%}). [The word is said by some comm.
on the {%Amarak.%} to be used also in the three genders; but
this assertion appears to be founded only on the circum-
stance that it occurs in other {%Koshas%} also amongst the in-
flected words; its form, however, is always there {#aBIkzRam#}
which might apply as well to an adj. as to an indecl.; e. g.
{%Rāmāsrama:%} {#ajayastvaBIkzRaSabdamanavyayamapyAha . anavyayapra-#}
{#karaRapAWAt#}). E. That given by {%Rāmāśr., Bhanūjid.%} &c.:
{#kzRu#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#qam,#} and {#Bi#} being protracted be-
cause the form belongs to the {#pfzodarAdi,#} is not very
plausible; {%Yāska%} explains the word as a contraction of
{#aBikzaRam;#} but as the protraction of the final vowel of
{#aBi#} {%in compounds%} points either to a kṛt deriv. with {#GaY#} or
{#kvip#} or to the loss of a following {#a#} (comp. {#aBIka#} II. and
{#aBIpat#}), the word is better considered as an Avyayībh.
of {#aBi#} and {#akzRa#}. (It belongs to the {%Gaṇas%} {#svarAdi#} {%Pāṇ.%}
I. 1. 37. and {#brAhmaRAdi#} V. 1. 124.)
<LEND>

<L>6583<pc>299-a<k1>aBIBABiBUBABU<k2>aBIBABiBUBABU
{#aBIBABiBUBABU#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-BUH#}) ‘A site of splendour sur-
passing a fearless elephant.’ (This monstrous compound
occurs in the following specimen of alliteration: {#jajOjojA-#}
{#jijijjAjI taM tato'titatAtitut . BABo'BIBABiBUBABU-#}
{#rArArirarirIraraH#} which is rendered by {%Yates:%} ‘the warring
foe overpowering all the sons of courage, distressing the
most brave, glorious, exceeding in terror a fearless ele-
phant, and advancing in his chariot, then attacked him’.
E. {#aBI-iBa-aBiBU-BA#} and {#BU#}.

<L>6584<pc>299-a<k1>aBIma<k2>aBIma

cording to an optional reading of {%Gaṅgādhara%} who inter-

or {#SaraBa#} and {#aBIma,#} and comments upon {#BIma#} and {#aBIma#}
[Page299-b+ 56]
as follows: {#(vikzetyataH sarvajano) Biyo magvikalpaHtaH zuNga#}
(compare {%Uṇṇādi-S.%} 1. 147.) {#taTA ca BImaH . BayaMkaro vApya-#}
{#BayaMkaro hi satAM tvaBImaH…#} (the following words of
this verse and the next verse refer to another name of

<L>6586<pc>299-b<k1>aBImoda<k2>aBImoda
{#aBImoda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) Excessive happiness or joy; e. g.
{%Atharv.:%} {#AnandA modAH pramudo'BImodamudaSca ye . ucCi-#}
{#zwAjjajYire sarve divi devA diviSritaH;#} or {#AnandA modAH#}
{#pramudo'BImodamudaSca ye . haso narizwA nfttAni SarIramanu#}
{#prAviSan#} (where {#aBImodamudaH#} is either Dwandwa ‘ex-
cessive joy and pleasure’ or perhaps an irregular intensitive
formation with the reduplication of the whole radical in-
stead of its first syllable (similar in some degree to the ved.
{#badbaD#} the intens. of {#banD#}); the masc. of the relative, {#ye,#}
being accounted for by the preceding masculines). Comp.
{#aBIlApa#}. E. {#mud#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6587<pc>299-b<k1>aBIra<k2>aBIra
{#aBIra#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-raH#}) A cowherd. ‘According to
Manu (X. 15.) the {%Abhīra%} is of mixed origin, the offspring
of a Brāhmaṇa father and a mother of the Ambashtha or
medical caste; but the {%Abhīras%} were a people, a pastoral
tribe, settled about the beginning of the Christian era, on
or near the lower course of the Indus on a tract known to
classical geographers, as the {%Abiria%} of Ptolemy, lying north
of the Sahyadri mountain and of Syrastrene. The {%Abhīras%}
of Saurāṣtra are mentioned in the Mahābhārata. From
their pastoral habits the name came to be generally applied
to the cowherds of Hindustan. In the spoken dialects of
upper India the word is corrupted to Ahīr, Uheer; in Ben-
gālī and Marāṭhī it is unchanged, occurring as Abhīr.’
({%Wilson'%}s {%Glossary of Indian Terms.%}) See {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alt.%}
vol. 1. pp. 106. 396. 539. 546. 705. 798. 799. 823; II. pp. 385.
547. 553. 592. 792. 855. 953. 956. &c.--The word as a
name of a people occurs in the Purāṇas ‘always conjoined
with the {%Śūdras,%} as if conterminous’ ({%Wilson'%}s {%Viṣṇu-P.%}
p. 195 n. 154).--The {%Sāhityadarpaṇa%} mentions the {%Abhīras%}
as assistants appointed in, or belonging to, the harem
(together with dwarfs, eunuchs, Kirātas or mountaineers,
Mlechchhas or barbarians, the mock-brother-in-law of a
king, i. e. the brother of his concubine, hump-backs, mutes
&c.: {#vAmanazaRqakirAtamlecCABIrAH SakArakubjAdyAH#}). The
same work, in defining the purposes for which Sanskṛt
and the Prākṛt-dialects are used in the dramatic dialogue,
appropriates the dialect of the Abhīras (which therefore is
not considered by the {%Sāh.%} as an Apabhranśa-dialect) to
cowherds and woodcutters; comp. {#ABIrI#} s. v. {#ABIra;#}
{#(ABIrezu taTABIrI…. ABIrI SAvarI cApi kAzWa-#}
{#pattropajIvizu);#} others hold the Abhīra-dialect as belonging
to the Apabhranśa, when it would be excluded from dra-
matic use. See {#apaBraMSa#} and {%Lassen'%}s {%Institutiones Linguae%}
{%Pracriticae.%}--(The word occurs usually in the form
{#ABIra;#} the dialect spoken by the Abhīras is {%always%} called
{#ABIrI,#} not {#aBIrI#}.)
<div n="P">2. n. (? {#-ram#}) The name of a {%Mātrāvṛtta%} or Prākṛt
[Page300-a+ 56]
metre, regulated by quantity; it consists of a stanza of
four lines with eleven {%mātrās%} in each line (the value of a
mātrā being a short syllable, and a long syllable equal to
two short), viz. each line being composed either of seven
mātrās and a Scolius (˘¯˘), or of a Dactylus (¯˘˘),
a Iambus (˘¯) and a Scolius, or of a Scolius, a Tri-
brachys (˘˘˘) and a Scolius. E. {#Ir#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff.
{#ac#} (according to several comm. of the {%Amarak.%}); but the
word is probably not of Sanskṛ4tic origin.
<LEND>

({%Nigh. Prak.%}). E. {#Ir#} with {#ami,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>6590<pc>300-a<k1>aBIrAjI<k2>aBIrAjI
{#aBIrAjI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-jI#}) The name of a poisonous insect;
according to {%Suśruta,%} one of the eighteen varieties, the bite
of which produces diseases of the vital element {%air.%} E.
(perhaps) {#aBIra#} and {#AjI#}.
<LEND>

<L>6591<pc>300-a<k1>aBIru<k2>aBIru
{#aBIru#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-ruH-ruH#} or {#rUH-ru#}) Fearless,
undaunted; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#te vASImanta izmiRo aBIravo#}
{#vidre priyasya mArutasya DAmnaH;#} or {%Manu:%} {#gulmAMSca sTApayedA-#}
{#ptAnkftasaMjYAnsamantataH . sTAne yudDe ca kuSalAnaBIrUnavikA-#}
{#riRaH;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#ahaM svapnakprasAdena tava vandAruBiH saha .#}
{#aBIruravasaM strIBirBAsvarABiriheSvara;#} or in the following
specimen of alliteration: {#BUriBirBAriBirBIrErBUBArEraBire-#}
{#Bire . BerIreBiBiraBrABEraBIruBiriBEriBAH#} ‘elephants con-
tended with elephants that were numerous, heavy, terrible,
immense, roaring, cloud-like and fearless’ ({%Yates, Essay%}
{%on alliteration%}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ruH#}) A (euphemistic) name of Bhairava or
Śiva; e. g. {#aBIrurBEravo BIrurBUtapo yoginIpatiH#} ({%Vaṭuka-%}
{%bhairavastava,%} as quoted by {%Rādhāk.%}).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-ruH#} or {#rUH#}) The name of a plant (Asparagus
racemosus); according to some, a large variety of it. (So
called, because its leaves are firm on account of its nu-
merous roots, or on account of their containing always
juice; {%Bhanūj.:%} {#sTirapatratvAt;#} {%Rāyam.:%} {#dUralambitabahumUla-#}
{#tvAt . sadArasAlayatvena sTirapatratvAditi tu svAmI;#} comp.
{#aBIrupatrI#}); e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#aBIrUmisisinDUtTavatsakoSIra-#}
{#padmakEH…datto vastiH suSItalaH#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#BIru#}.
<LEND>
