<L>6599<pc>300-b<k1>aBIvarta<k2>aBIvarta
{#aBIvarta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rtaH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Being everywhere; e. g.
{%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBi tvA viSvaBUtAnyaBIvarto yaTAsasi#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBitaH#}
{#sarvatra vartamAno Bavasi#}). <sup>2</sup> Approaching, esp. with hostile
intent; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBIvartena havizA yenendro aBivAvfte .#}
{#tenAsmAnbrahmaRaspate'Bi rAzwrAya vartaya#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBIvartena =#}
{#aBigacCatA#}); or {%Atharv.:%} {#aBIvartena maRinA yenendro aBi-#}
{#vAvfDe . tenA°°#}. Hence the word has become the epithet or
name of several vaidik verses or hymns which are recited
for obtaining victory; {%Benfey,%} in his valuable Index to the
{%Sāmaveda,%} mentions the following {%Sāma-verses%} which, in
the Gānas bear this name: 1. 242 (= 1. 3. 1. 5. 10), 2. 25. 26
(= II. 1. 1. 9), or only 2. 25b. 26a (= II. 1. 1. 9. 1b. 2a), 2. 35. 36
(= II. 1. 1. 13), 2. 117 (= II. 1. 2. 20. 1), 2. 161. 162 (= II. 2. 1. 13),
2. 206 (= 2. 2. 9. 1), 2. 214-216 (= II. 2. 2. 12), 2. 272 b. 273 a (= II.
3. 1. 11. 1 b. 2 a), 2. 283. 284 (= II. 3. 1. 15), 2 347 b. 348 a (= II. 3.
2. 12. 1 b. 2 a), 2. 429 a. 430 b (= II. 4. 1. 12. 1b. 2a), 2. 710-713 (= II.
6. 1. 5 and 6), 2. 741-743 (= II. 6. 2. 5), 2. 761. 762 (= II. 6. 2. 12),
2. 771. 772 (= II. 6. 2. 16), 2. 929. 930 (= II. 7. 3. 3), 2. 987. 988
(= II. 8. 1. 8); moreover {#indrasyABIvartaH#} or {#prajApateraBIvartaH#} or
{#aBIvartasyANgirasasya BAgam#} 1. 236 (= 1. 3. 1. 5. 4); {#jamadagnera-#}
{#BIvartaH#} 1. 239 (= I. 3. 1. 5. 7) and 2. 771. 772 (see above);
{#vfzasya jYAnasyABIvartaH#} 1. 523 (= I. 6. 1. 4. 1); e. g. {%Maśaka-%}
{%Kalpa-Sūtr.%} (in the chapter on the {%Abhijit%}): {#pra soma deva-#}
{#vItaya ityaBIvartaH#} (i. e. {%Sāmav.%} 2. 117); or {#punAnaH soma DA-#}
{#rayetyaBIvartaH#} (i. e. 2. 25); also called {%Brahmasāman;%} e. g.
{%Mādh. Jaiminīyany.:%} {#gavAmayane brahmasAma vihitam . aBI-#}
{#varto brahmasAma Bavati#}.--It is the name, too, of {%Ṛgv.%} 10.
174.--In {%Vājas.%} 14. 23. the name is applied to a {%sacrificial%}
{%brick%} ({#izwakA#}), when {%Mahīdhara%} explains {#aBIvarta#} as meaning
literally either ‘repetition’ or ‘approaching’, the former
assuming the sense {%stoma,%} since the Sāmaverses are re-
peated in a hymn of that description, and the latter the
meaning ‘year’, since the year (i. e. time) approaches all created
beings; he holds therefore that the brick is likened in this
passage to a hymn or to a year. (The {%vaidik glossary%} of
{%Someśvara%} explains the word in this manner: {#aBIvarto#}
{#BUtaBedayAtAyAtanirUpaRe . nAnAsaMsftisaMsTAnasvarUpAmnAya-#}
{#varRane . divyezwikAtmanicayacayane'pi prakIrtitaH#}). E. {#vft#}
with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY;#} the second vowel being protracted;
(this protraction is mentioned in the {%Prātiśākhyas%}).
<LEND>
[Page301-a+ 56]

<L>6600<pc>301-a<k1>aBIvft<k2>aBIvft

<L>6601<pc>301-a<k1>aBIvfta<k2>aBIvfta
{#aBIvfta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Surrounded,
accompanied. <sup>2</sup> Covered, obscured.--In the {%Ṛgv.%}-verse
I. 164. 29.: {#ayaM sa SiNkte yena gOraBIvftA mimAti mAyuM Dvasa-#}
{#nAvaDi SritA,#} {%Sāyaṇa%} who supplies to {#ayaM#} the word {#vatsaH#}
and takes the latter as a metaphorical expression for the
world desiring rain, and {%‘the cow’%} as the cloud, renders
the beginning words: {#yena vatsena gOrmAtABIvftA . AgatyA-#}
{#Bito vezwitA Bavati;#} {%Durga%} on {%Yāska%} 2. 9. supplies to
{#ayaM#} the word {#meGa#} and renders {#gOH#} ‘voice, speech’: {#ayaM#}
{#sa meGaH SabdAyate Sabdamiva karoti . na ca tAvadasO SabdaM#}
{#karoti . aTa ca tAvanmADyamikAyAM vAci tatsTAyAM SabdaM#}
{#kurvatyAM tatsAhacaryAdvijYAyate sa eva SabdaM karotIti . yena#}
{#meGena kiM kftamiti . yena gOraBIvftA . yena mADyamikA vA-#}
{#gaBipracCAditA satI mimAti mAyuM nirmimIte nirvartayati#}
{#mAyuM SabdaM karotItyarTaH;#} in {%Roth'%}s ed. of the {%Nirukta%} (2. 9.)
{#aBipravfttA#} must therefore be corrected to {#aBipravftA,#}
the former being contrary to the sense and unsupported by
the gloss of {%Durga.%} E. {#vf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta,#} with
the second syllable protracted (as noticed by the {%Ṛgv.%}
{%Prātiś.%}).

<L>6603<pc>301-a<k1>aBISu<k2>aBISu
{#aBISu#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SuH#}) <sup>1</sup> (ved.) Finger ({%Nighantu:%} = {#aNgu-#}
{#li#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#sTirA vaH santu nemayo raTA aSvAsa#}
{#ezAm . susaMskftA aBISavaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aNgulayaH#}); or {#daSA-#}
{#BISuByo arcatajareByo daSa Duro daSa yuktA vahadByaH#} ({%Durga%} to
{%Yāska:%} {#‘aByaSnuvate karmARi’, aBISavo'pyaNgulaya eva tA#}
{#aByaSnuvate karmARi vyApnuvantItyarTaH . anekErnAmaBiraNgulaya evo-#}
{#ktAH#}). <sup>2</sup> (ved.) Arm ({%Nigh.:%} = {#bAhu#}). <sup>3</sup> (ved.) A ray of
light ({%Nigh.:%} = {#raSmi#}); see {%Durga%} at the end. <sup>4</sup> A rein
({%Nigh.:%} = {#raSmi#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv., Vājas.:%} {#raTe tizWannayati vA-#}
{#jinaH puro yatrayatra kAmayate suzAraTiH . aBISUnAM mahimAnaM#}
{#panAyata manaH paScAdanu yacCanti raSmayaH#} ({%Sāy., Mahīdh.:%} =
{#raSmInAm#}); or {%Vājas.:%} {#suzAraTiraSvAniva yanmanuzyAnnenI-#}
{#yate'BISuBirvAjina iva#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#pragrahEH#}); or {%Ṛgv.:%}
{#anaSvo jAto anaBISurarvA#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#AlambanADArapragraha-#}
{#sTAnIyaraSmirahitaH#}). Comp. {#aBIzu#}. E. ({%Yāska, Sāyaṇa,%}
&c.) {#aS#} with {#aBi,#} uṇ. aff. {#uR,#} with an irregular con-
traction in the second syllable (compare e. g. {#aBIkzRa#});
‘finger’ and ‘arm’ because they perform work; or perhaps
because they move quickly, ‘finger’ being derived in several
synonymes from radicals implying motion, comp. {#aNguli,#}
{#agrU, aTari#} &c.; ‘rays of light’ metaph. as fingers of the
sun; or perhaps because they ‘pervade; ‘rein’ esp. of the
horses of the sun, metaph. as the rays; but acc. to {%Durga%}
the two latter meanings would seem to refer to another E.,
viz. a rad. implying checking, restraining, ‘for the rays
check the water and the reins horses’; perhaps {#IS#} with
{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#u;#} {%Durga%} to {%Yāska%} on {%Nigh.%} 1. 5. {#(raSmirya-#}
{#manAttezAmAditaH sADAraRAni paYcASvaraSmiBiH): Aditya-#}
[Page301-b+ 56]
{#saMbanDenEva raSminAmAnyuttarARi paYcadaSa . raSmiryamanAduda-#}
{#kasya . aSvAnAM vA#}.
<LEND>

<L>6606<pc>301-b<k1>aBIzu<k2>aBIzu
{#aBIzu#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-zuH#}) <sup>1</sup> A ray of light. <sup>2</sup> A rein. <sup>3</sup> Desire.
<sup>4</sup> Attachment, love. (The two first meanings in {%Amarak.,%}
{%Hem., Viśvapr.,%} &c. for the two latter comp. {%Śabdaratnāv.:%}
{#aBIzu pragrahe raSmO puMsi kAmAnurAgayoH#}. {%Bharata%} and
{%Mathureśa%} on the {%Amarak.%} admit the form {#aBISu#} only for
the meaning ‘ray’ (in the classical dialect); {%Mallin.%} on the
{%Śiśupālab.%} 16. 51. however observes that all the words which
are given by the Koshas as ending in {#z,#} occur in the vaidic
and in the classical language with a final {#S: viSvaprakA-#}
{#SAdayaH sarve'pyaBiDAnikA mUrDanyAntezu ye lokavedayostAla-#}
{#vyAntA dfSyante#}. Comp. {#aBISu#}.) E. see {#aBISu,#} with {#z#} for
{#S;#} but the comm. on the {%Amarak.%} derive the word from
{#iz#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#u;#} or {#aBi (= aBigata)#} and {#izu;#}
this E. is without any probability.
<LEND>

<L>6607<pc>301-b<k1>aBIzumat<k2>aBIzumat

e. g. {%Śiśupālab.:%} {#tava sarvagatasya saMprati kzitipaH kzipnuraBIzu-#}
{#mAniva#} ({%Mall.:%} = {#aMSumAn#}). <sup>2</sup> Enamoured, amourous

<LEND>

<L>6608<pc>301-b<k1>aBIzwa<k2>aBIzwa
{#aBIzwa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> Longed for, dear,
beloved; ({%Rāyam.%} on the {%Amarak.:%} {#aBi punaH . punarizwama-#}
{#BIzwam#}); e. g. {%Hitop.:%} {#prARA yaTAtmano'BIzwA BUtAnAmapi#}
{#te taTA . AtmOpamyena BUtezu dayAM kurvanti sADavaH;#} or {%Pancha-%}
{%tantra:%} {#Aha ca . Bo mitra tvaM vaDAya mayA samAnIto BAryA-#}
{#vAkyena viSvAsya . tatsmaryatAmaBIzwadevatA#}. <sup>2</sup> Wished, desired
(in general); e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#samAranta mamABIzwAH saMkalpA-#}
{#stvayyupAgate;#} or {#utkArezu ca DAnyAnAmanaBIzwaparigrahAH#} (scil.
{#yUyaM yAta#}). <sup>3</sup> Optional, arbitrary, any one or any one
thing of several; e. g. {%Lilāvatī:%} {#[dviDA BavedrUpaviBAga evaM]#}
{#sTAnEH pfTagvA guRitaH sametaH . izwonayuktena guRena niGno'BI-#}
{#zwaGnaguRyAnvitavarjito vA#} ({%Colebrooke:%} [These (the preceding)
are two methods of subdivision by form.] Or multiply se-
parately by the places of figures and add the products to-
gether. Or multiply by the multiplicator diminished or
increased by a quantity {%arbitrarily%} assumed; adding or
subtracting the product of the multiplicand taken into the
assumed quantity); or {%Vījagaṇita:%} {#fRAtmikA cetkaraRI#}
{#kftO syAdDanAtmikAM tAM parikalpya sADye . mUle karaRyAvanayora-#}
{#BIzwA kzayAtmikEkA suDiyAvagamyA#} ({%Colebrooke:%} if there be a
negative surd-root in the square, treating that irrational
quantity as an affirmative one, let the two surds in the
root be found, and one of them, as selected by the intel-
ligent calculator, must be deemed negative).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zwaH#}) A beloved person, a sweetheart; said
esp. of a man; e. g. {%Śiśupālab.:%} {#aBIzwamAsAdya cirAya kAle#}
[Page302-a+ 56]
{#samudDftASaM kamanI cakASe . yozinmanojanmasuKodayezu samudDftA-#}
{#SaNkamanIcakASe;#} or (superl.) {%Sāhityad.:%} {#smitaSuzkaruditaha-#}
{#sitatrAsakroDaSramAdInAm . sANkaryaM kilakiYcitamaBIzwatamasaMga-#}
{#mAdijAdDarzAt;#} but also used in a general sense of {%either%}
{%sex;%} e. g. {%Sāhityad.:%} {#tatra tu ratiH prakfzwA nABIzwamupEti vi-#}
{#pralamBo'sO#} ({%comm.:%} {#aBIzwaM nAyakaM nAyikAM vA#}).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-zwA#}) <sup>1</sup> A beloved woman, a mistress. <sup>2</sup> Betel
(Piper betel); see {#tAmbUlI#}. [{%Wilson'%}s {%first ed.%} and {%Rādhāk.'%}s
{%Śabdakalpadr.%} give the meaning {%‘perfume’%} and refer for
its being a synonyme of {#reRukA#} to the authority of the
{%Śabdachandrikā;%} but this reference contains an error, caused
perhaps by an omission of a copyist of the {%Śabdachandrikā.%}
The latter vocabulary has been composed by {%Chakrapāṇi-%}
{%datta%} with a view of being a supplement to the {%Amarak.;%}
it does not contain as much matter as this vocabulary nor
does it follow {%throughout%} its order; but in certain portions it
{%has%} the same order and it gives always literally the text of
the {%Amarak.,%} wherever additional synonymes have been
intended by the author, these synonymes being either im-
mediately annexed by him to the words of the {%Amarak.%}
in a subsequent verse or pointed out through the repetition
of the word to be enlarged upon, which then is put in the
locative. The end of the enumeration is marked by the
repetition of the word synonymized, between two full stops.
Thus the Śloka of the {%Amarak.%} II. 4. 4. 8. which contains,
up to {#nAgavallI,#} synonymes of ‘piper betel’, and afterwards
those of the perfume {#reRukA#} (viz. {#tAmbUlavallI tAmbUlI nAga-#}
{#vallyapyaTa dvijA . hareRU reRukA kOntI kapilA BasmaganDinI#})
runs thus in the {%Bodleian%} copy of the {%Śabdach.,%} of Professor
{%Wilson'%}s collection: {#tAmbUlavallI tAmbUlI nAgavallyapyaTA dvijA .#}
{#hareRU reRukA kOntI kapilA BasmaganDinI . tAmbUlyAM kawukABIzwA#}
{#devABIzwA gfhASayA#} (these four words mean therefore {%Betel%}) {#.#}
{#reRukAyAM BavejjyotsnI kftAntA KaranAdinI . varAvaramuKI#}
{#pucCArSoGnI SyAmA varatkarI#} (and these eight words the per-
fume {%Reṇukā%}) {#.. reRukAKye ganDadravye ..#}. The mentioned Ms.
omits, as may be observed, (contrary to its practice, and
merely from carelessness of the copyist,) the ending word,
{#.. tAmbUlI ..,#} before {#reRukAyAM,#} and as it has served both,
Professor {%Wilson%} and {%Rādhākaṇtadeva,%} the oversight be-
comes thus explainable.]
<div n="P">4. n. ({#-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> A desired object, desire; e. g. {%Sāhityad.:%}
{#jYAnABIzwAgamAdyEstu saMpUrRaspfhatA DftiH;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#kva ca#}
{#KyAto raGorvaMSaH kva tvaM paragfhozitA . anyasmE hfdayaM dehi#}
{#nAnaBIzwe GawAmahe#} ({%Jayam.:%} = {#anaBimate vizaye;#} {%Bharatas.:%}
= {#anucite vastuni#}). <sup>2</sup> The name of a plant; see {#tilaka;#}
(according to the {%Nigh. Prak.;%} but as the gender is not
given in this work, it is doubtful whether the word is in
this sense a {%m.%} or a {%n.%}). E. {#iz#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta;#}
in the first meaning perhaps better {#aBi#} and {#izwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6609<pc>302-a<k1>aBIzwatA<k2>aBIzwatA
{#aBIzwatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) Desirableness, the being wished for; e. g.
{%Bharatas.%} on the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#atrApi#} (i. e. 11. 6.) {#kAntiguRo#}
{#dIptarasatvAt . preyo'pyasti . preyastvarTezvaBIzwatA . aBIzwasya#}
{#kAmasya pratipAdanAt#} (see {#kAnti#} and {#preyas#}). E. {#aBIzwa,#}
taddh. aff. {#tal#}.
<LEND>

<L>6618<pc>302-b<k1>aBU<k2>aBU
{#aBU#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-BUH#}) Unborn; a name or epithet of Viṣṇu,
the 437<sup>th</sup> among the thousand names which occur in the
{%Anuśasanap.%} of the {%Mahābh.;%} (according to {%Gaṅgādhara%}
who admits in the verse {#anirvirRRaH sTavizWo BUrDarmayUpo#}
{#mahAmaKaH#} the option between the reading {#sTavizWo BUH#} and
{#sTavizWo'BUH,#} and interprets accordingly: {#BUrhi satAM Bava-#}
{#tyato BUrna ca BUrajanmA . BAve'TavA kartari DAtutaH kvip ..#}
{#oM Buve'Buve vA namaH#}). E. {#a#} neg. and {#BU#}.
<LEND>

<L>6619<pc>302-b<k1>aBUta<k2>aBUta
{#aBUta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Non-existent, what is
not or has not been; e. g. {%Kaṇāda Sūtras:%} {#viroDyaBUtamaBU-#}
{#tasya ..#} ({%Śaṅk. Upask.:%} {#aBUtaM varzaM BUtasya vAyvaBrasaMyogasya#}
{#liNgam . evaM sPowAderviroDI mantrapAWaH . taTA cABUtamanutpannaM#}
{#sPowAdiBUtasya mantrapAWasya liNgam . viroDiliNgasyodAhara-#}
{#RAntaramAha#}) {#.. BUtamaBUtasya ..#} ({%Śaṅk. Upask.:%} {#BUtaM sPowAdi-#}
{#kamaBUtasya mantrapAWasya liNgam . evaM BUto vAyvaBrasaMyogo'BU-#}
{#tasya varzasya liNgam . evaM BUto dAho'BUtasya manyAdisamava-#}
{#DAnasya liNgam#} &c.); or {%Yāska:%} {#kastadveda yadaBUtamidamapItara-#}
{#dadButam#}. Comp. the following articles. E. {#a#} neg. and {#BUta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6620<pc>302-b<k1>aBUtatadBAva<k2>aBUtatadBAva
{#aBUtatadBAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) The becoming of, the being
transformed or changed of a substance to, what it has not
been before; {%Kaiyyaṭa:%} on {%Patanj.%} on the {%Vārtt.%} {#aBUtatadBAva#}
{#iti vaktavyam#} to {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 50.: {#yena rUpeRa prAgaBUtaM kAraRaM#}
{#tena rUpeRa tasya BAvo'BUtatadBAvaH;#} {%Kāśikā%} on the same
{%Vārtt.:%} {#kAraRasya vikArarUpeRABUtasya tadAtmanA BAvo'BUta-#}
{#tadBAvaH;#} or {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} III. 1. 12.: {#BfSAdizvaBUtatadBAva-#}
{#grahaRaM kartavyam#}. [The notion implied by this term is ex-
pressed by the affixes called in {%Pāṇini'%}s system {#cvi#} and
{#sAti,#} and in some denominatives by the affix {#kyaN;#} see
the Sūtras quoted, and V. 4. 51-55.--The Calcutta Paṇḍits
who have compiled a comm. on {%Pāṇ.%} have misapplied this
[Page303-a+ 56]
word in using it in the sense of ‘the {%being%} or taking place
of what has not been before’, when they comment on the
word {#AScarya#} ‘wonderful’, VI. 1. 174.; neither {%Patanjali%} and
his comm., nor the {%Kāś.%} or the {%Siddhk.%} make use of the
word at this occasion.] E. {#aBUta#} and {#tadBAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6621<pc>303-a<k1>aBUtapUrva<k2>aBUtapUrva
{#aBUtapUrva#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rvaH-rvA-rvam#}) Not having existed
before, unprecedented; e. g. {%Rāmāy. Yuddhak.:%} {#aBUtapUrvo#}
{#rAmeRa seturbadDaSca sAgare#}. E. {#aBUta#} and {#pUrva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6622<pc>303-a<k1>aBUtaprAdurBAva<k2>aBUtaprAdurBAva
{#aBUtaprAdurBAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) Manifestation of what has
not existed before; e. g. {%Kāś.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} {#(‘itTaMBUtena kftamiti#}
{#ca’) kftamiti kriyAsAmAnye karotirvartate . nABUtaprAdurBAva eva#}
‘the verb ‘to do’ of which ‘done’ is the past part. means
in this Sūtra action in general, not (that special action
which implies) manifestation of what has not existed be-
fore’ i. e. {#kftam#} is there not to be taken literally, but as
the general notion of verbal action. E. {#aBUta#} and {#prAdurBAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6623<pc>303-a<k1>aBUtarajas<k2>aBUtarajas

{#tarajasastaTA prakftayo'pare#} &c.; or {%Brāhma Pur.:%} {#devAScABU-#}
{#tarajasastaTA prakftayaH smftAH;#} comp. {%Wilson'%}s {%Viṣṇup.%} p. 262.
n. 15. E. {#aBUta#} and {#rajas#} lit. ‘in whom the condition of
of Rajas or passionateness is non-existent’.
<LEND>

<L>6624<pc>303-a<k1>aBUtAharaRa<k2>aBUtAharaRa
{#aBUtAharaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) A covert or metaphorical ex-
pression; {%Sāhityad.:%} {#…vyAjASrayaM vAkyamaBUtAharaRaM matam;#}
as in the following instance where the death of Aśvatthā-
man is reported under the metaphor of a prostrate elephant:
{#aSvatTAmA hata iti pfTAsUnunA spazwamuktvA svEraM Seze gaja iti#}
{#kila vyAhftaM satyavAcA#}. E. {#aBUta#} and {#AharaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6625<pc>303-a<k1>aBUti<k2>aBUti
{#aBUti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Non-existence, non-entity; e. g.
{%Vājas.:%} {#aBUtyE svapanam#} (in the Purushamedha the priest
consecrates a drowsy man as a symbol of Sleep to Non-
existence). <sup>2</sup> The not being, the not becoming of; e. g.
{%Śatap.%} or {%Bṛhadār.:%} {#tadDEtatpaSyannfzirvAmadevaH pratipede . ahaM#}
{#manuraBavaM sUryaSceti tadidamapyetarhi ya evaM vedAhaM brahmAsmIti sa#}
{#idaM sarvaM Bavati tasya ha na devAScanABUtyA ISata#} ({%Śaṅk.:%} {#devA#}
{#mahAvIryASca na api aBUtyE aBavanAya brahmasarvaBAvasya neSate#}
{#na paryAptAH;#} {%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBUtyE sarvAtmakabrahmaBAvasyABavanAya na#}
{#paryAptAH#} ‘they are not able to prevent him to become
Brahma’). E. {#a#} neg. and {#BUti#}.
<LEND>

<L>6626<pc>303-a<k1>aBUmi<k2>aBUmi
{#aBUmi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-miH#}) <sup>1</sup> Anything but earth, anything but
a solid ground; e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrautas.:%} {#SUlaM cABUmO#} ({%Yā-%}
{%jnikad.:%} {#aDvaryustadDfdayaSUlaM na pfTivyAM nApsu nikzipet,#} he is
not to put it down anywhere, i. e. he is to hold it up).
<sup>2</sup> No object for; e. g. {%Śākunt.:%} {#sa Kalu manoraTAnAmaBUmirvi-#}
{#sarjanAvasarasatkAraH#} (comm. {#aBUmiH = avizayaH#}) ‘the honour
(Indra conferred on me) at the occasion of dismissing me,
was indeed no object for (i. e. beyond) my wishes’; or
{%Śiśupālabadha:%} {#aBUdaBUmiH pratipakzajanmanAM BiyAm#} (comm.
{#aBUmiravizayaH#}) ‘he was no object for fear from enemies’,
i. e. he was fearless. [<sup>3</sup> A bad or unsuitable ground.] E.
{#a#} neg. or deter. and {#BUmi#}.
<LEND>

<L>6627<pc>303-a<k1>aBUmija<k2>aBUmija
{#aBUmija#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Not grown in (arable)
lands, grown in marsh-lands; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#anArtavaM vyA-#}
{#DihatamaparyAgatameva ca . aBUmijaM navaM cApi na DAnyaM guRava-#}
{#tsmftam . navaM DAnyamaBisyandi laGu saMvatsarozitam#} &c. [For
the culture of rice in India in dry arable lands and in
[Page303-b+ 56]
marsh-lands (the flooded rice) comp. {%Crawfurd'%}s {%Indian%}
{%Archip.%} I. p. 357 ff.; and for the medicinal effect of either,
{%Ainslie'%}s {%Materia Indica%} I. 341. ‘the produce of the {%caar%}
crop (the flooded rice) which is reapt in October, he (Aga-
stya) considers as of a different quality; this he says {%“will%}
{%bring on indigestion, flatulency, eruptions on the skin, and%}
{%other evils;”%} he finishes by saying, that {%“a person had%}
{%better beg his bread, than eat the rice of the caar crop”.%}] E.
{#a#} neg. and {#BUmija,#} or {#aBUmi -ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>6630<pc>303-b<k1>aBUza<k2>aBUza

<L>6632<pc>303-b<k1>aBfta<k2>aBfta

vant); e. g. {%Manu:%} {#gopaH kzIraBfto yastu sa duhyAddaSato#}

{#(aBfte =) BaktAdirahite;#} {%Vīram.:%} {#sEzA BftiH pUrvaM dravyAntare-#}
{#RABfte jYeyA . yastu dravyAntareRa BftaH . tatra tadeva BftirityarTaH#}].
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-taH#}) The name of a Gotra-chief (according to
a Ms. of the {%Kāśikāvr.,%} where the word occurs in the {%Gaṇa%}
{#naqAdi#} to {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 1. 99.). E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bfta#}.

<L>6633<pc>303-b<k1>aBftrima<k2>aBftrima

hired, not paid; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#asaMskftrimasaMvyAnAvanuptri-#}
{#maPalASinO . aBftrimaparivArO paryaBUtAM taTApi mAm#}
({%Jayam.:%} {#mfgARAmamunazyatvAdaBftrimaH parIvAro'nujIvilo-#}
{#ko yayostO mfgaparIvArO#} i. e. ‘having an unpaid retinue,
viz. the deers of the forest’). E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bftrima#}.
<LEND>

<L>6634<pc>303-b<k1>aBfSa<k2>aBfSa
{#aBfSa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-SaH-SA-Sam#}) Not much, little; e. g.

{#BfSAyate#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#BfSa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6635<pc>303-b<k1>aBeda<k2>aBeda
{#aBeda#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) <sup>1</sup> Undividedness, close union; e. g.
{%Hitop.:%} {#aBedena ca yuDyeyU rakzeyuSca parasparam;#} or {%Bhartṛh.%}
{%Śriṅgāraś.:%} {#adarSane darSanamAtrakAmA dfzwA parizvaNgarasEkalo-#}
{#lA . AliNgitAyAM punarAyatAkzyAmASAsmahe vigrahayoraBedam#}.
<sup>2</sup> Sameness, identity; e. g. {%Kaiyy.%} (on {%Patanj.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} I.
1. 9.): {#spfzwatAdyaBedAdvivArAdiBede'pi yaTA Bavati taTA spf-#}
{#zwatAdiBede'pi vivArAdyaBedAtprApnotIti praSnaH;#} or {%Bharatas.%}
on {%Bhaṭṭik.%} 1. 21.: {#kzatriyatvaM brAhmaRatvaM cAnyonyaprayojanakaM jA-#}
{#tivyaktyoraBedopacArAt#}.--The term is of frequent occur-
rence in {%philosophical%} works; e. g. {%Viśvan.%} on a {%Nyāya S.:%}
[Page304-a+ 56]
{#guRaguRinoraBedo na;#} or {%Sāṅkhya Prav.:%} {#AYjasyAdaBedato#}
{#vA guRasAmAnyAdestatsidDiH praDAnavyapadeSAdvA;#} or {%Sāṅkhya%}
{%Tattwak.:%} {#aDyavasAyo budDiH . kriyAkriyAvatoraBedavivakza-#}
{#yA…budDeH yo'DyavasAyo budDerasADAraRavyApArastadaBedA#}
{#budDiH#}. In the {%Vedānta%} {#aBeda#} is especially applied to {%the%}
{%identity of the universal and individual soul%} or of the {%Deity%}
and the {%world;%} e. g. {%Vedāntasāra:%} {#anayorvyazwisamazwyorvanavfkza-#}
{#yoriva jalASayajalayoriva cABedaH . etadupahitayorISvara-#}
{#prAjYayorapi vanavfkzAvacCinnAkASayoriva jalASayajalagataprati-#}
{#bimbAkASayoriva cABedaH#}. This view of identity is refuted
by the {%Nyāya-Vaiś.;%} e. g. in this passage of the {%Siddhānta-%}
{%mukt.:%} {#satyaM jYAnamiti brahmaparaM jIvezu nopayujyate jYAnAjYA-#}
{#nasuKitvaduHKitvAdiBirjIvAnAM BedasidDO sutarAmISvaraBedaH#}
(ed. Calc. 1827; the reading {#°SvarABedaH#} in Dr. {%Röer'%}s ed.
seems a misprint) {#. anyaTA banDamokzAnupapatteH . yo'pISva-#}
{#raBedaboDako vedaH so'pi tadaBedena tadIyatvaM pratipAdayanstO-#}
{#ti . aBedaBAvane ca yatitavyamiti vadati . ata eva sarva eva#}
{#Atmani samarpitAH SrUyante . mokzadaSAyAmajYAnanivfttAvaBedo#}
{#jAyata ityapi na . Bedasya nityatvena nASAyogAt . BedanASe#}
{#'pi vyaktidvayaM sTAsyatyeva#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Beda#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dA-dam#}) <sup>1</sup> Undivided, closely
joined; e. g. {%Siddhāntamukt.:%} {#karmaDArayasTale tu nIlotpalami-#}
{#tyAdAvaBedasaMbanDena nIlapadArTa utpalapadArTe prakAraH . na ca#}
{#tatra lakzaRA#}. [<sup>2</sup> Identical.] E. {#a#} priv. and {#Beda#}.
<LEND>

<L>6636<pc>304-a<k1>aBedaka<k2>aBedaka
{#aBedaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dakaH-dikA-dakam#}) Not dividing,
not separating, not producing a difference; e. g. {%Patanjali%}
on the {%Kātyāy. Vārtt.%} {#BedakatvAdguRasyeti vaktavyam#} (to {%Pāṇ.%} I.
1. 1.): {#uBayamidaM guRezUktam . BedakA aBedakA iti . kiM puna-#}
{#ratra nyAyyam . aBedakA guRA ityeva nyAyyam . kuta etat .#}
{#yadayamasTidaDisakTyakzRAmanaNNudAtta#} (VII. 1. 75.) {#ityudAttagrahaRaM#}
{#karoti tajjYApayatyAcAryo'BedakA guRA iti;#} or {%Patanj.%}
on {%Pāṇ.%} I. 1. 9.: {#udAttAdInAM tarhi savarRasaMjYA na prApnoti .#}
{#aBedakA udAttAdayaH#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bedaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>6637<pc>304-a<k1>aBedya<k2>aBedya
{#aBedya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-dyaH-dyA-dyam#}) Infrangible, in-
destructible; e. g. {%Devīmāh.:%} {#viSvakarmA dadO tasyE paraSuM cA-#}
{#tinirmalam . astrARyanekarUpARi taTABedyaM ca daMSanam;#} im-
penetrable; e. g. {%Sāyaṇa%} on {%Ṛgv.%} (VI. 28. 2.): {#aBinne =#}
{#SatruBiraBedye (sTale) nidaDAti;#} also in a moral sense: {%in-%}
{%corruptible, indestructible;%} e. g. {%Kull.%} on {%Manu%} (7. 64.):
({#SuciH#} i. e.) {#arTastrISOcayuktaH . tena DanastrIdAnAdinABedyaH,#}
or {%Lalitav.:%} {#SradDA mArzADarmAlokamuKamaBedyASayatAyE saMvartate;#}
and in the philosophical sense explained s. v. {#aBeda,#} i. e.
{%not to be differenced,%} e. g. {%Mahābh.:%} {#mAnaso nAma pUrvo'pi#}
{#viSruto vE maharziBiH . anAdiniDano devastaTABedyo'jarAmaraH#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-dyam#}) A diamond ({%Rājanigh.%} = {#vajra#}). E. {#a#} neg.
and {#Bedya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6638<pc>304-a<k1>aBEdika<k2>aBEdika

<L>6639<pc>304-a<k1>aBoktf<k2>aBoktf
{#aBoktf#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktA-ktrI-ktf#}) Not enjoying, not using,
(not keeping; comp. {#aBuj#}). Comp. the following. E. {#a#}
neg. and {#Boktf#}.
<LEND>

<L>6640<pc>304-a<k1>aBoktftva<k2>aBoktftva
{#aBoktftva#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tvam#}) The condition of one who does
not enjoy; in the {%Sāṅkhya phil.%} the condition of {%Prakṛti%}
or Matter in contradistinction from that of {%Purusha%} or Soul,
for whose benefit or enjoyment the former is created; e. g.
[Page304-b+ 56]
{%Sāṅkhya Prav.:%} {#praDAnasfzwiH parArTaM svato'pyaBoktftvAduzwra-#}
{#kuNkumavahanavat#} ‘Matter is created on account of some one
other; for though its creation is spontaneous, it cannot
enjoy (being unintelligent), like as a camel carries saffron
(for some one else, i. e. for its master)’. E. {#a#} neg. and
{#Boktftva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6641<pc>304-b<k1>aBogin<k2>aBogin
{#aBogin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-gI-ginI-gi#}) Not enjoying,
abstemious; e. g. {%Bhāgav. Pur.:%} {#aBogino'yaM tava vipra#}
{#dehaH pIvA yatastadvada naH kzamaM cet#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bogin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6642<pc>304-b<k1>aBogGan<k2>aBogGan
{#aBogGan#}¦ Tatpur. m. pl. ({#-GanaH#}) (ved.) Destroying those
who do not sacrifice, killing the impious; an epithet of the
Maruts; {%Ṛgv.:%} {#yuvAno rudrA ajarA aBogGano vavakzuraDri-#}
{#gAvaH parvatA iva#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#ye devAnhavirBirna Bojayanti tezAM#}
{#hantAraH#}). E. {#aBoj#} and {#han#}.
<LEND>

<L>6643<pc>304-b<k1>aBogya<k2>aBogya
{#aBogya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-gyaH-gyA-gyam#}) What cannot be
enjoyed or used; e. g. {%Meghad.:%} {#snehA nAhuH kimapi viraha-#}
{#vyApadaste hyaBogyA dfzwe vastunyupacitarasAH premarASIBavanti#}
({%Wilson:%} ‘true love, no time nor distance can destroy; and
independent of all present joy, it grows in absence, as re-
newed delight, some dear memorials, some loved lines ex-
cite’). Comp. the difference between this word and {#aBojya#}.
E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bogya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6644<pc>304-b<k1>aBoj<k2>aBoj
{#aBoj#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-k#}) (ved.) Not giving (the gods) the
enjoyment (of a sacrifice), impious; {%Sāy.%} (in his gloss. on
{#aBogGan#} q. v.); {#BojayantIti BojaH . na Bojo'BojaH#}. E.
{#a#} neg. and {#Boj#}.
<LEND>

<L>6645<pc>304-b<k1>aBojana<k2>aBojana
{#aBojana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not eating, as {%a symptom of%}
{%disease,%} caused by want of appetite &c.); e. g. {%Shādvinśabr.:%}
{#aTa yadAsya prajayA paSuzu SarIre vArizwAni prAdurBavanti vyA-#}
{#Dayo vA anekaviDA atisvapnamasvapnamatiBojanamaBojanamAlasyaM#}
{#vraRamajIrRanidrARyevamAdIni tAnyetAni sarvARi yamadevatyAnya-#}
{#dButAni prAyaScittAni Bavanti .#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBIjanamarucyA-#}
{#dinA#}). <sup>2</sup> Abstinence, fasting, as {%a religious act;%} e. g.
{%Kātyāy. Śrautas.:%} {#aBojanaM tasyocCvAsAt;#} or as {%a penance%}
(see {#prAyaScitta#}) for the expiation of sin; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#vedo-#}
{#ditAnAM nityAnAM karmaRAM samatikrame . snAtakavratalope ca prAya-#}
{#ScittamaBojanam;#} or {%Bharadvāja:%} {#nirAcArasya viprasya ni-#}
{#zidDAcaraRasya ca . annaM BuktvA dvijaH kuryAddinamekamaBojanam;#}
(for the various modes of fasting, as practised in under-
going the penances {#prAjApatya, sAntapana, mahAsAntapana, ati-#}
{#sAntapana, kfcCraM, atikfcCra, taptakfcCra, pAdakfcCra, parAka,#}
{#cAndrAyaRa#} &c. see s. vv. and s. v. {#prAyaScitta#}). In the verse
of {%Manu%} 8. 49. which describes the five different means by
which a creditor may obtain payment of a debt ({#DarmeRa#}
{#vyavahAreRa cCalenAcaritena ca . prayuktaM sADayedarTaM paYcamena balena#}
{#ca#}) {%Kullūka%} interprets the term {#Acarita#} ({%Sir W. Jones%} and
and {%Colebr. Dig.%} I. 339. ‘distress’) according to {%Vrihaspati:%}
{#dAraputrapaSUnhftvA kftvA dvAropaveSanam . yatrArTI dApyate'rTaM#}
{#svaM tadAcaritamucyate;#} {%Medhātithi%} however qualifies the ‘sitting
at the debtor's door’ by adding {#aBojana#} (viz. {#aBojanagfhI-#}
{#tadvAropaveSanam#}) and {%Vijnāneśvara%} when quoting this verse
of {%Manu%} in the {%Mit.%} on {%Yājnav.%} (2. 40.) renders {#Acaritena#}
(misprinted in the 4<sup>to</sup> ed. {#acaritena#}) simply with {#aBojanena#}.
(For this practice of fasting at the door of debtors which
is familiar under the name of ‘sitting in Dherna’; comp.
{%As. Res.%} IV. p. 332.) E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bojana#}.
<LEND>
[Page305-a+ 56]

<L>6648<pc>305-a<k1>aBojya<k2>aBojya
{#aBojya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jyaH-jyA-jyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not to be con-
sumed by eating or drinking, unfit for food, prohibited
as food; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#aBojyamannaM nAttavyamAtmanaH SudDimicCa-#}
{#tA;#} or {%Mahābh. Śāntip.:%} {#cikitsakasya yaccAnnamaBojyaM rakzi-#}
{#RastaTA . gaRagrAmABiSastAnAM raNgastrIjIvinAM taTA;#} (unfit
for {%drinking%} e. g.) {%Vṛhat-Śātātapa:%} {#pItaSezaM tu yatkiMci-#}
{#dBojane muKaniHsftam . aBojyaM taddvijasyAhurBuktvA cAndrAyaRaM#}
{#caret;#} sometimes {%contrasted%} with ‘what is unfit to be {%drunk%}’
and then used in the same sense as {#aBakzya;#} e. g. {%Śāntip.:%}
{#pretAnnaM sUtikAnnaM ca yacca kiMcidanirdaSam . aBojyaM cApyapeyaM#}
{#ca DenordugDamanirdaSam;#} but in general (though not always)
the use of {#aBakzya#} is restricted to solid food while {#aBojya#}
is said of eating and drinking; (comp. also the criticism of
{%Kātyāy.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} VII. 3. 69. where the latter renders {#Bojya#}
with {#Bakzya#} while he ought to have rendered it, according to
{%Kātyāy.,%} {#aByavahArya#} q. v.; for {#BojyaH sUpaH#} and {#BojyA yavAgUH#}
are, as {%Patanjali%} instances, as good expressions as others
where {#Bojya#} is combined with articles of solid food; {%Patan-%}
{%jali,%} it is true, defends at the same time {%Pāṇini%} by ob-
serving that the derivatives of {#Bakz#} are sometimes used,
too, in connexion with liquids or food in general, e. g. in
{#abBakza#} or {#vAyuBakza;#} but {%in general%} the distinction, pointed
out in the {%Vārttika%} of {%Kātyāy.%} is correct; {%Patanj.:%} {#kiM punaH#}
{#kAraRaM na siDyati . BakzirayaM KaraviSade vartate . tena drave na#}
{#prApnoti . nAvaSyaM BakziH KaraviSade vartate . kiM tarhi . anya-#}
{#trApi vartate . tadyaTA . abBakzo vAyuBakza iti#}). For prohi-
bited articles of food and the penances on eating such
food see the quotation s. v. {#aBakzya#}. <sup>2</sup> One whose food
must not be eaten; see the following; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#aBo-#}
{#jyAnAM tu BuktvAnnaM strISUdrocCizwameva ca . jagDvA mAMsamaBakzyaM#}
{#ca saptarAtraM yavAnpibet#} ({%Kull.:%} {#a° = aBojyAnnAnAm;#} {%Me-%}
{%dhāt.:%} {#yezAmannaM na Bujyate te'BojyAH puruzAH#}). E. {#a#} neg.
and {#Bojya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6649<pc>305-a<k1>aBojyAnna<k2>aBojyAnna
{#aBojyAnna#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-nnaH-nnA-nnam#}) One whose food
must not be eaten (because eating it makes impure or brings
misfortune); e. g. {%Manu:%} {#ya ete#} (those mentioned in the
preceding verses) {#'nye tvaBojyAnnAH kramaSaH parikIrtitAH .#}
{#tezAM tvagasTiromARi vadantyannaM manIziRaH#} ‘…their food, the
wise say, is (like) skin, bones and hair’. Such persons
are, for instance, an insane man, a wrathful person, a
thief, a public singer, a carpenter, a eunuch, a woman in
her courses or in childbed, a backbiter, a tailor, a black-
smith, a physician, a libidinous woman, a usurer &c.; see
{%Manu%} 4. 205-221.; {%Yājnav.%} 1. 160-168.--One who has un-
knowingly eaten the food of such persons must fast during
three days; but, having eaten it knowingly he must per-
form the penance called {%Kṛṣchhra,%} as if he had tasted
seminal impurity, ordure or urine; according to {%Manu%} 4. 222.
In another verse, however, {%Manu%} (11. 152.) is satisfied, if
such a sinner drinks barley gruel for seven days and nights
[Page305-b+ 56]
(see the quot. s. v. {#aBojya#}). Comp. {%Raghunand.%} I. p. 317 ff.
E. {#aBojya#} and {#anna#}.
<LEND>

<L>6650<pc>305-b<k1>aBOtika<k2>aBOtika
{#aBOtika#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kI-kam#}) Not produced by
the coarse or visible elements, intellectual.--In the
{%Sāṅkhya philosophy%} {#aBOtikasarga#} is one of the creations or
evolutions of {%Prakṛti%} or Matter, comprising the evolutions
called {#liNgasarga#} ‘evolution of mind’ and {#BAvasarga#} ‘evolution
of mental affections’, the other evolution of {%Prakṛti%} being
{#BOtikasarga#} or {#BUtasarga,#} produced by the coarse elements and
comprising eight classes of celestial beings (see {#brAhma, prA-#}
{#jApatya, sOmya, Endra, gAnDarva, yAkza, rAkzasa, pESAca#})--in
whom prevails the quality {#sattva#}--, five species of brute
creation (tame animals, wild animals, birds, reptiles and
immovable substances)--in whom prevails the quality
{#tamas#}--, and the species man, with the predominant quality
{#rajas;#} ‘both, the {#aBOtika#}--and the {#BOtika#}--evolutions,
comprise therefore sixteen evolutions of Matter’. [This is, in
my opinion, the bearing of {%Gaudapāda'%}s concluding remark
on the {%Sāṅkhya-Kār.%} v. 54: {#evamaBOtikaH sargo liNgasargo BA-#}
{#vasargo#}--cfr. v. 52--{#BUtasargo dEvamAnuzatEryagyona#}--cfr. v. 53--
{#ityeza praDAnakftaH zoqaSasargaH#}]. E. {#a#} neg. and {#BOtika#}.
<LEND>

<L>6651<pc>305-b<k1>aByakta<k2>aByakta
{#aByakta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) I. Oiled, anointed,
greased; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#nAYjayantIM svake netre na cAByaktAmanA-#}
{#vftAm . na paSyetprasavantIM ca tejaskAmo dvijottamaH;#} or {%Yājnav.:%}
{#aputrA gurvanujYAto devaraH putrakAmyayA . sapiRqo vA sagotro#}
{#vA GftAByakta ftAviyAt;#} or {%Kātyāy.:%} {#aByaktaSirasaM cEva#}
{#nABivAdyetkaTaMcana;#} or {%Suśruta:%} {#snehAByakte yaTA tvakze cakraM#}
{#sADu pravartate . saMDayaH sADu vartante saMSlizwAH SlezmaRA taTA;#} or
{#GftAByaktAgranetraM (vastiM) GftAktagudAya prayacCet;#} in the {%Atharv.%}
verse (10. 1. 25.)--{#aByaktAktA svaraMkftA sarvaM BarantI duritaM#}
{#parehi#}--the first word {#aByakta#} seems to represent the {%neuter%}
in the sense of {#Gfta, aByaktAktA#} then being equivalent to
{#GftAktA#}. E. {#aYj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<div n="P">II. Approached, arrived, near; used by {%Yāska%} to ex-
plain etymologically the word {#aBIka (aBIke'Byakte)#} and
similarly by {%Sāyaṇa%} e. g. to {%Ṛgv.%} I. 71. 8.: {#aBIke'Byakte#}
{#'Bigate'BiprApte#}. E. {#ac#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6652<pc>305-b<k1>aByagni<k2>aByagni

<L>6653<pc>305-b<k1>aByagra<k2>aByagra

{#sOmitre rAkzasAvAratAM Druvam . idaM SoRitamaByagraM saMprahAre'cyu-#}
{#tattayoH#} ({%Bharatas.:%} {#saMprahAre yudDe . idamaByagramaBinavaM SoRitama-#}

<L>6654<pc>305-b<k1>aByaNka<k2>aByaNka

<L>6655<pc>306-a<k1>aByaNga<k2>aByaNga
{#aByaNga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-NgaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Anointing, in general; e. g. {%Jai-%}
{%minīyanyāyam.:%} {#jyotizwome SrUyate dIkzArTAByaNge…. tatra#}
{#barhizi samUlacCedasyAByaNge navanItasya puroqASe yaTocitapA-#}
{#kasya ca viDeyatayA sarvamavaSizwaM stAvakam#}. See also {#aByaYjana#}.
<sup>2</sup> Rubbing the body with unctuous substances, smearing
the body with oil, inunction; e. g. {%Suśr.:%} {#snAnAByaNgadivA-#}
{#svapnaSItavyAyAmayozitaH . na Bajeta svarotsfzwo yAvanno balavA-#}
{#nBavet#}.--{%Raghunandana%} quotes in the {%Śuddhitattva%} (II.
p. 132) the following definition ({#AyurvedoktapAriBAzikaM#}) of
the word: {#mUrDni dattaM yadA tElaM BavetsarvANgasaMgatam . sroto-#}
{#BistarpayedbAhU aByaNgaH sa udAhftaH . tElamalpaM yadaNgezu na ca#}
{#syAdvAhutarpaRam . sA mArzwiH pfTagaByaNgo mastakAdO prakIrtitaH#}
‘when oil is applied to the head, goes over the whole
body and delights with its flood the arms, this is called
{%Abhyanga;%} but when little oil comes on the body and the
arms are not much wetted, such partial inunction of the
head &c. is called {%Mārṣṭi%}’. The medicinal effect of this
practice is thus briefly described in the {%Rājanigh.:%} {#aByaNgo#}
{#mArdavakaraH kaPavAtavinASanaH . DAtUnAM puzwijananaH sutvamvarRa-#}
{#valapradaH . pAdAByaNgo'Ta nidrAkfccakzuzaH pAdarogahA . cakzuzi#}
{#pratibadDe dve Sire pAdagate nfRAm . ataScakzuHprasAdArTaM pAdA-#}
{#ByaNgaM samAcaret#} (comp. also {%Wise, Hindu syst. of Med.%} p. 93).
A religious student, an anchorite and a widow are for-
bidden to anoint themselves; {%Manu:%} {#(brahmacArI varjayet)#}
{#aByaNgamaYjanaM cAkzRorupAnacCatraDAraRam#}); {%Prachetas%} (as quoted
by {%Raghunand.%}): {#tAmbUlAByaYjanaM cEva kAMsyapAtre ca Bojanam .#}
{#yatiSca brahmacArI ca viDavA ca vivarjayet#}). <sup>3</sup> Unguent, lini-
ment; e. g. {%Suśr.:%} {#sPowajanmarujAsrAvatvakpAkaH svedanaM jvaraH .#}
{#daraRaM cApi mAMsAnAmaByaNge vizasaMyute#}. [<sup>4</sup> Applying colly-
rium to the eyes. <sup>5</sup> Sediment of oil, oil cake ({%Wilson%})].
See the following. E. {#aYj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6656<pc>306-a<k1>aByaYjana<k2>aByaYjana
{#aByaYjana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Anointing, greasing, in general;
e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrauta S.:%} {#aByaYjanapraBfti karoti#} (scil. {#yUpA-#}
{#nAm#}); or {%Hitop.:%} {#durjanaH prakftiM yAti sevyamAno'pi ni-#}
{#tyaSaH . svedanAByaYjanopAyEH SvapucCamiva nAmitam#}. <sup>2</sup> Making
clear or bright, manifesting; (see the meaning 4.). <sup>3</sup> The
same as {#aByaNga#} 2.; e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrauta S.:%} {#evaM pratiprasTAtA#}
{#patnImaByaYjanAdi tUzRIm;#} or {%Manu:%} {#BojanAByaYjanAddAnAdya-#}
{#danyatkurute tilEH . kfmiBUtaH SvavizWAyAM pitfBiH saha majjati#}.
Sometimes used together and contrasted with a word
meaning a partial inunction of the body such as appli-
cation of collyrium to the eyes; e. g. {%Bhāgav. Pur.:%} {#aYja-#}
{#nAByaYjanonmardastryavaleKAmizaM maDu . sragganDalepAlaMkArAMstyaje-#}
{#yurye DftavratAH#}.--One of the great sacrifices (see {#sattra#}) which
lasts 49 days, is called, on account of the daily anointments
which form part of its ceremonial,--according to {%Śabara%}
on the {%Jaiminīsūtras%} and some Mss. of the {%Jaim. nyāyamālāv.%}
--{#aYjanAByaYjana#} (e. g. {%Śab.:%} {#astyaYjanAByaYjananAmakonapaYcA-#}
{#SadrAtraH#} &c.; {%Jaim.nyāy.:%} {#astyaYjanAByaYjanasaMjYaka ekonapaYcA-#}
{#SadrAtraH sattraviSezaH . tatra SrUyate . gOggulavena prAtaHsavane#}
{#'ByaYjanaM pEludAraveRa mADyandine savane sOganDikena tftIyasavana#}
{#iti#}), according to the {%Āśvalāyana-%} and {%Kātyāy. Śrauta S.%}
{#AYjanAByaYjanIya#} q. v.; e. g. {%Kātyāy.:%} {#AYjanAByaYjanIye#}
{#'BiplavAHzaw ..…yaTAsavanaM tEH#} (i. e. with butter pre-
pared with {#guggulu, suganDitejana#} and {#pIludAru#}) {#savanezvAYja-#}
{#nAByaYjane kurvIrannAgnIDre'harahaH;#} {%Yājnikad.:%} {#AYjanamakzRoH#}
[Page306-b+ 56]
(Ms. E. I. H. 1362. on book 24. 3. 13.: {#aYjanamakzRoH#}) {#. aBya-#}
{#YjanaM SarIrasyeti karkaH;#} on another occasion ({%Kātyāy.%} 21. 4. 26.)
the term {#aByaYjana#} is, in the same combination with {#AYjana,#}
said by the {%Saṅkṣiptasāra%} (as ‘extracted’ by {%Weber%}) to de-
note merely the {%‘anointment of the feet’:%} {#AYjanamakzRoraYjanaM#}
{#kajjalAdinA . aByaYjanaM ca pAdayostElAYjanam#}. <sup>4</sup> An unctuous
substance, esp. oil or butter; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#AtmA pitusta-#}
{#nUrvAsa ojodA aByaYjanam#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#aByaYjanamaByaYjanasADanaM Gf-#}
{#tatElAdikam;#} but he proposes also to take {#aBya°#} as an
accus., with an adv. sense, determining {#ojodA,#} viz. {#aBi-#}
{#vyaktaM yaTA Bavati taTojodA,#} i. e. ‘imparting strength mani-
festly’); or {%Śatap.:%} {#teBya AgateBya AYjanAByaYjane prayacCanti;#}
or {%Mānava Kalpa S.:%} {#hastenAYjanAByaYjanalepaM nimArzwi#} ({%Kumā-%}
{%rila:%} {#aByaYjanaM tElam;#} on a subsequent {%Sūtra:%} {#aYjanAByaYjana-#}
{#pAtre tarhi drazwavye#}); or {%Suśr.:%} {#(cikitset…mftyuvaSaprayAtaM)#}
{#tIkzRAYjanAByaYjanaDUmayogEH#} &c.; or {#tElamaByaYjane#} (in the butter)
{#kAryaM kuzWe sarjarase'pi vA#} (at the treatment of the children-
disease {#revatI#}); or {#nasyAByaYjanasekezu vidaDyAdyogatattvavit .#}
{#KarASvASvatarolUkakaraBaSvaSfgAlajam#}. <sup>5</sup> A collyrium or appli-
cation to the eye-lashes; see {#aYjana;#} e. g. {%Ṛgv., Atharv.:%}
{#cittirA upabarhaRaM cakzurA aByaYjanam . dyOrBUmiH koSa AsI-#}
{#dyadayAtsUryA patim;#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#cakzurevAYjanamAsIt#}). This last
sense of the word is probably restricted to the vaidik pe-
riod. E. {#aYj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6657<pc>306-b<k1>aByaDika<k2>aByaDika
{#aByaDika#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Preeminent, ex-
cellent, excessive, very much; e. g. {%Mahābh. Anuśās.:%} {#stri-#}
{#yAstvaByaDikaH sneho na taTA puruzasya vE;#} or {%Bharata:%} {#alaM-#}
{#kArasvaBAvajYErjYeyA BAvarasASrayAH . yOvane'ByaDikAH strIRAM#}
{#vikArA vaktragAtrajAH;#} or {%Daśakumārach.:%} {#aByaDikabalena#}
{#vidvizA mahati saMparAye BinnamarmA siMhavarmA balAdagfhyata;#} or
{%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#mAtrAtimAtraM SuBayEva budDyA ciraM suDIraByaDikaM#}
(adverb.) {#samADAt#}. <sup>2</sup> Exceeding (a given quantity &c.),
going beyond (a certain limit); e. g. {%Kumārila%} on a {%Mānava%}
{%Kalpa S.:%} {#katipayatfREraByaDikaM muzwiM lunAti;#} or {%Mādh.%}
{%Jaim.nyāy.:%} {#caturviMSatiparamAH sattramAsIranniti vacanAdaBya-#}
{#DikAnAM na tatrADikAraH#} &c.; or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#kftvA karma yaTA-#}
{#dizwaM pUrvakAryAviroDi yaH . karotyaByaDikaM kftyaM#} (a business
besides) {#tamAhurdUtamuttamam#}. <sup>3</sup> Superior than, more excel-
lent, mightier than, greater than, more than (either with

added in the fifth case); e. g. {%Manu:%} {#sarvopAyEstaTA kuryAnnI-#}
{#tijYaH pfTivIpatiH . yaTAsyAByaDikA na syurmitrodAsInaSa-#}

{#mahe drOpadi pARqaputrAn#} (where the {%ablative%} {#za° gu°#} is not
the object of comparison, but expresses the reason; {%Nīlak.%}
(who reads {#'pyaDikAH#}): {#zaqByo guReByaH lyablope paYcamI#}
{#zaqguRAnprApya pARqaveByo'pyaDikAH;#} {%Chaturbhujam.:%} {#ata eva#}
{#vayamapyaDikAH . zaqByo guReByaH saMDivigrahayAnAsanadvEDasaMSraye-#}
{#Byo hetuByaH#}); or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#rAme tu rAjanviparItametatpaSyAmi#}
{#tenAByaDikaM vipakzam;#} with a noun in the {%abl.:%} e. g. {%Yājnav.:%}
{#Agamo'ByaDiko BogAdvinA pUrvakramAgatAt;#} or {%Sūryasiddh.:%}
{#vfze saptadaSe BAge yasya yAmyo'SaMkadvayAt . vikzepo'ByaDiko#}
{#BindyAdrohiRyAH SakawaM tu saH;#} or {#sUryAdaByaDikAH paScAdastaM#}
{#jIvakujArkajAH . UnAH prAgudayaM yAnti SakrajYO vakriRO taTA#}.

<L>6664<pc>307-a<k1>aByantara<k2>aByantara
{#aByantara#}¦ I. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) The reverse of
{#vAhya#} and comp. {#antara#}. <sup>1</sup> Interior, being in the middle or
between, included in; e. g. {%Manu:%} (the following are not to be
invited at a Śrāddha) {#…brahmaviwparivittiSca gaRAByantara eva#}
{#ca#} (one being in, i. e. belonging to, a college &c.); or
{%Rāmāy.:%} {#UcustadAgataM rAmamidamaByantarAH striyaH#} (the women
who lived in the town); or {%Sāṅkhya Pravach.:%} {#na vAhyA-#}
{#ByantarayoruparaYjyoparaYjakaBAvo'pi deSavyavaDAnAtsruGnapAwa-#}
[Page307-b+ 56]
{#liputrasTayoriva;#} or a {%Kār.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} (IV. 1. 78.): {#SabdAntara-#}
{#midaM vidyAdfzwamaByantaraM trizu#} ({%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#tripraBftizu yadaByanta-#}
{#ram#}); or {%Patanj.%} in the introd. on {%Pāṇ.:%} {#aByantaraSca samudAye#}
{#'vayavaH;#} or {%the same:%} {#nanu BavAnapyaByantaro loke . aByantaro#}
{#'haM loke na tvahaM lokaH;#} or the same on {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 135. v. 8:
{#yastvasO DAtUpasargayoraBisaMbanDaH . tamaByantaraM kftvA DAtuH#}
{#sADanena yujyate;#} or {%Śaṅkara%} (on the {%Ved. Sūtra:%} {#antara#}
{#upapatteH#}): {#parameSvara evAkzaRyaByantaraH puruza;#} or {%the same%}
(on the {%Sūtra%} {#adfzwAniyamAt#}): {#bahuzvAtmasu sarvagatezu prati-#}
{#SarIraM vAhyAByantarAviSezeRa saMnihitezu manovAkkAyErDarmADarma-#}
{#lakzaRamadfzwamupArjyate#}.--‘The {%Sautrāntika%} and {%Vaibhāṣika%}
sects (of the Buddhists) admitting external ({#vAhya#}) and in-
ternal ({#aByantara#}) objects, distinguish, under the first head,
elements ({#BUta#}) and that which appertains thereto ({#BOtika#}),
namely organs and sensible qualities; and under the second
head, intelligence ({#citta#}) and that which unto it belongs
({#cetta#})’. {%Colebroke'%}s {%Ess.%} I. p. 392; comp. {%Burnouf Introd.%} I.
p. 448 ff.; {%Kœppen, Die Religion des Buddha%} I. p. 600 and
the references given there. <sup>2</sup> Initiated in, familiar with,
interested in; with a noun in the locative; e. g. {%Kātyāy.%}
(on the admissibility of witnesses): {#aByantarastu niHkzepe sA-#}
{#kzyameko'pi dApayet#} (v. 1. in the {%Vīramitr.:%} {#vAcayet#}) {#.#}
{#arTinA prahitaH sAkzI Bavedeko'pi yAcite;#} or {%Raghunand.:%}
{#kAryezvaByantaro yaH syAdarTinA prahitaSca yaH . kulyAkulavivAdezu#}
{#Baveyuste'pi sAkziRaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Near, intimate; e. g. {%Panchat.:%}
{#tyaktAScAByantarA yena vAhyAByantarIkftAH . sa eva mftyumApnoti#}
{#yaTA rAjA kakudrumaH#}. [It is doubtful, however, whether
the correct form of the word is not in the {%latter sense%} {#A-#}
{#Byantara,#} when, by its taddhita-derivation, it would cor-
respond in value with the compound {#aByantarIkfta;#} comp.
e. g. the following verse of the {%Mahābh. Śāntip.%} 4787: {#A-#}
{#Byantare prakupite vAhye copanipIqite . kzIRe koze Srute mantre#}
{#kiM kAryamavaSizyate#}. See also the remark s. v. {#aByantarakaraRa#}.]
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-ram#}) Interior, middle, the space within, lit. and
fig.; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#yaH SyAvadantOzWanaKo'lpasaMjYaSCardyardito#}
{#'ByantarayAtanetraH#} &c.; or {#sirABiraBisaMprApya viguRo'Byantare#}
{#BfSam#} &c.; or {%Yājnav.:%} {#kfcCrAtikfcCro'sfkpAte kfcCro#}
{#'ByantaraSoRite#} ‘…the penance Kṛchchhrātikṛchchhra
(is the penalty) when the blood (of a Brahman) is {%shed,%} the
penance Kṛ. when his blood still remains in his body (i. e.
when he is beaten black and blue)’; or {%Ratnāvalī:%} {#devi#}
{#taduttizWAvaH . AvAsAByantarameva praviSAvaH;#} or {%Meghad.:%}
{#…nirvinDyAyAH paTi Bava rasAByantaraM saMnipatya strIRAmAdyaM#}
{#praRayavacanaM viBramo hi priyezu;#} or {%Hitop.:%} {#ato'haM zaRmA-#}
{#sAByantare#} (within six months) {#tava putrAnnItiSAstrABijYAnka-#}
{#rizyAmi#}. E. {#aBi#} and {#antara#} ({%Rāyam., Bhānud.%} &c. =
{#aBigatamantaram#}).
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-ram#}) Towards the interior, inwards;
see the quotation s. v. {#aByantarAyAma#}. E. {#aBi#} and {#antara#}.
<LEND>

<L>6665<pc>307-b<k1>aByantarakaraRa<k2>aByantarakaraRa
{#aByantarakaraRa#}¦ Karmadh. ({#-Ram#}) The same as {#antaHkaraRam;#}
and the reverse of {#vAhyakaraRa#}. This form of the word oc-
curs in some Mss., but the more correct form is {#AByantara-#}
{#karaRa#} q. v.; and the compound {#vAhyAByantarakaraRa#} which is
of frequent occurrence in {%Vedānta-, Sāṅkhya-%} and {%Yoga%}
writings, is to be analyzed therefore: {#vAhya-ABya°-ka°#}.
E. see {#AByantarakaraRa#}.
<LEND>
[Page308-a+ 56]

<L>6666<pc>308-a<k1>aByantarakalA<k2>aByantarakalA
{#aByantarakalA#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-lA#}) Literally, interior art, i. e.
art of wantonness. (It is mentioned in the second chapter
of the {%Daśakumārach.%} as one in a long list of arts, a mother
is to afford her daughter instruction in, if she wants to
bring her up as a courtezan; this fine description of mater-
nal duties is termed there {#gaRikAmAturaDikAraH,#} and com-
prises amongst others:) {#sajIvanirjIvAsu ca dyUtakalAsvaByanta-#}
{#rIkaraRaM#} (initiation in the art of gambling with live and
dumb objects) {#aByantarakalAsu vESvAsikajanAtprayatnena prayoga-#}
{#grahaRam#} ‘making her learn from confidential friends how to
become an arrant coquette’ &c. E. {#aByantara#} and {#kalA#}.
<LEND>

<L>6667<pc>308-a<k1>aByantaratas<k2>aByantaratas
{#aByantaratas#}¦ ind. In the interior, inwards; e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} (on
the {%Bṛhadār.:%} {#asTInyantarato dArURi#}) {#puruzasya snAvno'Byanta-#}
{#rato'sTIni Bavanti . taTA kinAwasyAByantarato dArURi#}
{#kAzWAni;#} or {%Suśr.:%} {#dfzwirvirUpA SvasanopasfzwA saMkucyate'Byanta-#}
{#rataSca yAti#}. [In a word like {#vAhyAByantaratas,#} e. g. {%Sāhi-%}
{%tyad.:%} {#tanmayaM tatprakASo hi vAhyAByantaratastaTA,#} the analysis
is {#vAhyAByantara-tas#}.] E. {#aByantara,#} taddh. aff. {#tasi#}.

<L>6668<pc>308-a<k1>aByantarAyAma<k2>aByantarAyAma
{#aByantarAyAma#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) (In Medicine.) A curvature
of the spine, considered as one of the diseases produced
by the derangement of the temperamental element {%air%} (see
{#vAtavyADi#}) and thus described by {%Suśruta:%} {#aNgulIgulPaja-#}
{#WarahfdvakzogalasaMSritaH . snAyupratAnamanilo yadi kzipati vega-#}
{#vAn . vizwabDAkzaH stabDahanurBagnapArSvaH kaPaM vaman . aByantaraM#}
{#Danuriva yadi namati mAnavaH . tadA so'ByantarAyAmaM kurute#}
{#mAruto balI ..#} ‘When deranged {%air%} pervading fingers,
ankles, belly, heart, chest and neck, contracts the muscles
(of these parts), when the eyes and jaws of the patient
become fixed and his sides (at it were) broken, when he
vomits phlegm and his body is {%bent inwards%} (i. e. for-
wards), such deranged {%air%} produces the disease {%Abhyantarā-%}
{%yāma%}’. Comp. {#vAhyAyAma#}. E. {#aByantara#} (Avyayībh.) and {#AyAma#}.
<LEND>

<L>6669<pc>308-a<k1>aByantarIkaraRa<k2>aByantarIkaraRa
{#aByantarIkaraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Initiating in, making
familiar with; see the inst. s. v. {#aByantarakalA#}. [<sup>2</sup> Making
a near friend (of a person); comp. the following.] E.
{#aByantara,#} taddh. aff. {#cvi,#} and {#karaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6670<pc>308-a<k1>aByantarIkfta<k2>aByantarIkfta

{#prAgalByAdvaktumicCanti hi mantrezvaByantarIkftAH#}. <sup>3</sup> Made near
or intimate; comp. the inst. s. v. {#aByantara#} I. 1. 3. E. {#aBya-#}
{#ntara,#} taddh. aff. {#cvi,#} and {#kfta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6671<pc>308-a<k1>aByamana<k2>aByamana
{#aByamana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Disease; {%Yāska%} (on the word
{#amIvahA#} {%Ṛgv.%} VII. 55. 1.): {#aByamanahA#} ‘destroyer of dis-
eases’ ({%Sāy.:%} = {#rogARAM nASakaH#}). Comp. the following.
<sup>2</sup> Attacking; see s. v. {#aByamin#}. E. {#am#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6672<pc>308-a<k1>aByamanavat<k2>aByamanavat
{#aByamanavat#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) With diseases; {%Yāska%}
(on the word {#amavAn#} of {%Ṛgv.%} 4. 4. 1.: {#kfRuzva pAjaH prasitiM#}
{#na pfTvIM yAhi rAjevAmavAM~iBena#}): {#yAhi rAjevAmAtyavAna-#}
{#ByamanavAnsvavAnvA#} &c. ‘come like a king’, {#amavAn#} i. e.
‘with ministers’ (viz. to obtain victory) or ‘with diseases’
(to terrify thy enemies) or ‘with riches’ (viz. with a well
supported army, and therefore to obtain victory); {%Durga%}
on {%Yāska:%} {#yAhi rAjeva yaTA rAjA yAyAdamAtyavAnAvi-#}
[Page308-b+ 56]
{#yukto (?) vijayAya taTA tvaM yAhi . aTavA yaTAByamanavAn .#}
{#rogaBUtaH pareByo BayadAtA yAyAttaTA yAhi . aTavA yaTA#}
{#svavAn . vittavAn . suBftasEnyo yAyAdvijayAya taTA yAhi#}
(comp. also {%Sāy.%} on the same verse). E. {#aByamana,#} taddh.
aff. {#matup#}.
<LEND>

<L>6673<pc>308-b<k1>aByamita<k2>aByamita
{#aByamita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Also {#aByAnta#} q. v.
<sup>1</sup> Sick, diseased. <sup>2</sup> Arrived, come, taken place; e. g.
{%Bhaṭtik.:%} {#tezAM nihanyamAnAnAM saMGuzwEH karRaBediBiH . aBUdaBya-#}
{#mitatrAsamAsvAntASezadigjagat#} ({%Jayam.:%} {#aBya° = aBigata-#}
{#trAsam;#} {%Bhar.:%} = {#prAptaBayam#}). <sup>3</sup> Uninjured; {%Durga%} (on
{%Yāska'%}s explanation of {#amatra#} 6. 23.: {#amatro'mAtro mahAnBa-#}
{#vati . aByamito vA#}): {#aByamito vA syAt . anaBihiMsitaH#}
{#kenacit#}--[The first meaning, for which no corroborative
passage in the literature has come under my observation,
rests on the authority of the {%Koshas%} of {%Amara, Hemach.,%}
the {%Rājanigh.%} and the comm.--{%Kāśikā%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VII. 2. 28.
gives the instances {#aByamita#} and {#aByAnta#} (while the {%Siddhk.%}
only has the simple forms {#amita#} and {#Anta,#} and {%Kātyāy.%}
and {%Patanjali%} offer no remark at all), but without stating
their meaning. {%Mādhava%} quotes in the {%Dhātuvṛ.%} the alleged
{%Sūtra%} and the simple forms {#amita#} and {#Anta,#} but under
{#am#} ‘to go, to honour, to sound’, not under {#am#} ‘to be
sick’; and, what is more remarkable, {%Hemach.,%} too, quotes
in the {%Dhātūparāyaṇa%} {#aByamita#} and {#aByAnta#} under {#am#} ‘to
sound, to honour’ to which he refers {#am#} ‘to go’, but
not under {#am#} ‘to be sick’. It will seem therefore, that
the meaning ‘diseased’ of these participles is a doubtful
one.--Unless {%Durga'%}s meaning ‘uninjured’ is merely con-
structive or explanatory of a (possible) meaning ‘attacking’
(viz. successfully attacking), the E. he has derived it from,
is unknown to me.] E. {#am#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#} and
āgama {#iw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6689<pc>309-a<k1>aByarTanA<k2>aByarTanA

{#mama . nAnayAByarTanAyuktamuktapUrvaM smarAmyaham;#} or (a quotation
in {%Rādhākāntad.'%}s {%Śabdak.%} s. v. {#alaMkAra#}): {#dozasyAByarTanA-#}
{#nujYA tatrEvaguRadarSanAt;#} or {%Kumārasambh.%} (and quoted also
by {%Vijnānabh.%} on {%Sāṅkhyapr.%} 6. 6.): {#aByarTanABaNgaBayena sA-#}
{#DurmADyasTyamizwe'pyavalambate'rTe#}.--The neuter form {#aByarTana#}
{#(-m)#} is objectionable (comp. {#arTanA, prArTanA#} and {%Pāṇ.%} III.
3. 107.), although it occurs e. g. in a verse of the {%Śāntis.%} of
{%Hœberlin'%}s {%Chr.,%} where the necessity of metre seems to have
[Page309-b+ 56]
led to the grammatical inaccuracy: {#DanEryAcYAlabDErna na pari-#}
{#Bavo'ByarTanaPalaM…nikAro'gre paScAdDanamahaha BostadDi#}
{#niDanam#}. E. {#arT#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#yuc#}.

<L>6690<pc>309-b<k1>aByarTanIya<k2>aByarTanIya

<L>6691<pc>309-b<k1>aByarTayamAna<k2>aByarTayamAna
{#aByarTayamAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) One who requests
or solicits; e. g. {%Mitākṣ.%} (on {%Āpastamba%}): {#tatrApravfttasya#}
{#pravartakaH prayojakaH . sa ca triprakAraH . AjYApayitAByarTayamAna#}
{#upadezweti ca .…aByarTayamAnastu yaH svayamasamarTaH prArTanA-#}
{#dinA macCatruM vyApAdayeti samarTaM pravartayati so'BiDIyate…#}
In a {%legal%} sense the {#aBya°#} is therefore the instigator of a
crime, who has not the power of doing the criminal act
himself but {%requests%} another who has the power, to do it
for him; while the {#AjYApayitf#} is the person who {%orders%} his
subordinate to accomplish the criminal act, and the {#upadezwf#}
the person who {%instructs%} others how to do it; all three be-
longing to the category {#prayojaka#}. E. {#arT#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#SAnac#} and āgama {#muk#}.
<LEND>

<L>6697<pc>309-b<k1>aByarDayajvan<k2>aByarDayajvan

{#yanyajati,#} explained by {%Durga:%} {#aByarDayannaBivarDayanyAjayati#}

{#nkurvan . yo yajati Danena pUjayati#}). E. {#aByarDa#} and {#yajvan#}.

<L>6700<pc>310-a<k1>aByarhat<k2>aByarhat

<L>6701<pc>310-a<k1>aByarhita<k2>aByarhita
{#aByarhita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Respected, much

{#tvAdaByarhitaM pUrvamiti nyAyenAByarhitatvAttadvyAKyAnamAdO yu-#}
{#ktam;#} or {%Śaṅk.%} (on the {%Chhānd. Up.%} {#sa eza koSo vasuDAnaH#}

{#vAraByate#}. <sup>2</sup> Fit, proper, suitable; e. g. {%Kirātārj.:%} {#aByarhitA#}
{#banDuzu tulyarUpA vfttirviSezeRa tapoDanAnAm#} ({%Mallin.:%} {#aByarhi-#}
{#tA ucitA#}); or {%Dāyabh.:%} {#duhitfto'ByarhitAyAH patnyA#}
{#eva…aDikAraH#}. E. {#arh#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6702<pc>310-a<k1>aByarhitatva<k2>aByarhitatva
{#aByarhitatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> The being much or more respected
or honoured; the being superior or preferable; e. g. {%Kaiyy.%}
on {%Patanj.%} to the first {%Vārtt.%} quoted s. v. {#aByarhita#} 1.: {#SradDAmeDe#}
{#iti . satyAM SradDAyAmarTakriyAkAriRI meDeti SradDAyA aByarhi-#}
{#tatvam#} ‘…therefore Śraddhā is more respected (i. e. oc-
cupies a higher rank than Medhā)’; or {%Jaiminīyanyāy.:%}
{#taTApi parapratyakzAtsvapratyakzasyAByarhitatvena sparSa evAtrAnuzWeyo#}
{#na sarvavezwanam#} ‘because that which is before one's own eyes
is preferable to (i. e. more to be relied upon than) that
which is before other's eyes’, &c.; or {%Jayam.%} (on the po-
sition of {#sOmitri#} in the compound {#sOmitrisItA#} {%Bhaṭṭik.%}
3. 9.): {#sahacaratvenAByarhitatvAtpUrvanipAtaH;#} or (on that of {#puro-#}
{#hita#} in {#purohitAmAtya#} {%Bhaṭṭik.%} 3. 29.): {#purohitasyAByarhitatvA-#}
{#tpUrvanipAtaH#}. <sup>2</sup> Fitness, suitableness. E. {#aByarhita,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

{#aByAhitapaSu#} q. v. in a Ms. of the {%Kāśikā.%} E. {#aByarhita#} (in
the sense of a locat.) and {#paSu#}.
<LEND>

<L>6705<pc>310-a<k1>aByavakASa<k2>aByavakASa
{#aByavakASa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SaH#}) An open space. [The {%Gaṇa-%}

{%Pāṇ.%} IV. 4. 73.--as a various reading given by {%Sākaṭāyana%}
instead of {#aBrAvakASa#}. See {#AByavakASika#}.] E. {#kAS,#} with

<L>6706<pc>310-a<k1>aByavadAnya<k2>aByavadAnya
{#aByavadAnya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-nyaH-nyA-nyam#}) (ved.) Not liberal,
mean, miserly; {%Śatap. (= Bṛhadār.):%} {#mA no BavAnbaho-#}
{#ranantasyAparyantasyAByavadAnyo'BUditi#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#mA BUnno#}
{#'smAnaBi asmAneva kevalAnprati BavAnsarvatra vadAnyo BUtvA#}
{#avadAnyo mA BUtkadaryo mA BUdityarTaH;#} {%Anandag.:%} {#vadAnyo#}
{#dAnaSIlo viBave satyadAtA kadarya iti BedaH;#} {%Dwivedag.:%}
{#anyasminnarTijane vadAnyo dAnaSIlo BUtvA no'smAnevABi#}
{#aBilakzyAsmAnprati avadAnyaH kadaryo viBave satyadAtA mA#}
{#BUdBavAn#}). E. According to the quoted commentators it
would seem as if they looked upon {#aByavadAnya#} not as a
compound but as representing two distinct words {#aBi#} and
[Page310-b+ 56]
{#a#} (neg.)--{#vadAnya,#} since the negative {#a#} could otherwise
not have been recognized by them, in conformity with
grammar, between {#aBi#} and {#vadAnya#}. Whether this division
of the word has taken place in the {%Bṛhadār.,%} it is pro-
bably not possible to say; in the {%Śatap.,%} however, the ac-
cent shows that {#aByavadAnya#} is {%one%} compound base. But as
{#aBi#} imparts sometimes a negative sense (‘away’) to the
latter part of a compound of which it is a former part
(comp. {#aByaya, aBiharaRa#} &c.), it is more plausible per-
haps to take {#avadAnya#} as another form of, and equivalent
in meaning to the shorter and probably older {#vadAnya#} (from
{#vadAna = avadAna#}), and to analyze therefore: {#aBi#} and
{#avadAnya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6707<pc>310-b<k1>aByavaskanda<k2>aByavaskanda

q. v. ({%Hemach.%}). E. {#skand#} with {#ava#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6708<pc>310-b<k1>aByavaskandana<k2>aByavaskandana

{#niHSaktikaraRAya SatruBiryaH prahAro dIyate#}. 2. {%Bhanud.:%} {#prahA-#}

<L>6709<pc>310-b<k1>aByavaharaRa<k2>aByavaharaRa
{#aByavaharaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Throwing down or away (as
ashes into the water; in this sense probably restricted to
the vaidik liter.); e. g. {%Śatapath.:%} {#aTa yadvanIvAhanaM ca Basma-#}
{#naScAByavaharaRaM tO darSapUrRamAsO#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#Basma° = apsUKyaBa-#}
{#smAvapanam#}); or {%Kātyāy. Śr. S.:%} {#Svo'ByavaharaRAdi prAyaSci-#}
{#ttyantaM#} &c. ({%Yājnik. = Sāy.%}). <sup>2</sup> (Literally: taking down, scil.
the throat i. e.) Taking food, eating or drinking; comp. the
following; e. g. {%Mitākṣ.%} (on {%Manu%} 11. 92.): {#tattAlumAtrasaM-#}
{#yoge surAyA abudDipUrve drazwavyam . nanu ca dravaddravyasyAByavaharaRaM#}
{#pAnamityucyate . aByavaharaRaM ca kaRWAdaDonayanam#}. E. {#hf#} with
{#ava#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6710<pc>310-b<k1>aByavahAra<k2>aByavahAra
{#aByavahAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Taking food, eating or drinking;
comp. the preceding; ({%Hemach.%} = {#aSana;#} {%Bhūripr., Rājanigh.%}
= {#Bojana#}) e. g. {%Manu:%} {#alpAnnAByavahAreRa rahaHsTAnAsanena#}
{#ca . hriyamARAni vizayErindriyARi nivartayet;#} or {%Patanj.%}
(in his {%introd.%} to {%Pāṇ.%}): {#vede Kalvapi payovrato brAhmaRaH .#}
{#yavAgUvrato rAjanyaH . AmikzAvrato vESya ityucyate . vrataM ca#}
{#nAmAByavahArArTamupAdIyate#}. The {%Kāśikā%} explains the meaning
of {#Buj#} and the words {#nigaraRa#} and {#pratyavasAna#} with {#aByava-#}
{#hAra#}. <sup>2</sup> Food; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#so'hamaByavahArArTI tO dfzwvA#}
{#kftaniScayaH#} &c.; or {%Kāśikā%} (on {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 125.): {#jamBaSabdo#}
{#'ByavahAravAcI dantaviSezavAcI vA . SoBano jamBo'sya su-#}
{#jamBo devadattaH . SoBanAByavahAraH SoBanadanto vA;#} comp.
{%Siddhk.:%} {#jamBo Bakzye dante ca#}). E. {#hf#} with {#ava#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6711<pc>310-b<k1>aByavahArya<k2>aByavahArya
{#aByavahArya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-ryaH-ryA-ryam#}) Fit to be taken
as food (solid or liquid); e. g. {%Vārtt.%} 1. to {%Pāṇ.%} VII. 3. 69.:
{#BojyamaByavahAryamiti vaktavyam,#} with which words {%Kātyāyana%}
criticizes {%Pāṇini%} for having either restricted the sense of
{#Bojya#} to that of {#Bakzya#} (‘fit to serve as solid food’) or used
{#Bakzya#} in the general acceptation of {#aByavahArya#}. {%Patanjali,%} it
[Page311-a+ 56]
is true, defends {%Pāṇini%} (as he frequently sides with {%Pāṇini%}
against the hypercriticisms of {%Kātyāyana%}) also on this oc-
casion by alleging {#abBakza#} and {#vAyuBakza#} in evidence that {#Bakz#}
(and, impliedly, that {#Bakzya#}) are used in a general sense;
but on another occasion when he shows that there are
words the bearing of which in the classical language can
merely be established from the context in which they occur
in the vaidik literature, and not be made out otherwise (see
{#ekapada#}), he gives these very instances as a proof of his
latter assertion, and admitting therefore that they belong to
this exceptional category, corroborates thus involuntarily
the view of {%Kātyāy.%} that {#Bakz#} cannot be applied to the word
{#ap#} in a {%general sense,%} and much less to any other word
having the sense of a liquid substance ({%Patanj. Introd.:%}
{#aTavA santyekapadAnyapyavaDAraRAni tadyaTA . abBakzo vAyuBakza#}
{#iti . apa eva Bakzayati vAyumeva BakzayatIti gamyate . evami-#}
{#hApi sidDa eva na sADya iti;#} {%Kaiyy.:%} {#evaSabdaprayoge dvipada-#}
{#mavaDAraRam . dyotakatvena evaSabdasyApekzaRAt . yadA tu dyota-#}
{#kamantareRa sAmarTyAdavaDAraRaM gamyate tadA tadekapadamityucyate#}
{#tatra sarva evApo BakzayantItyabBakzaSrutiH sAmarTyAnniyamamavagama-#}
{#yati . apa eveti . ihApi nityAnityavyatirekeRa rASyantarA-#}
{#BAvAtsidDaSabdopAdAnAnniyamo'vagamyate#}). But as {#Bakz#} {%is%}
applied to {#ap,#} in the vaidik language, and as it seems
strange that {%Pāṇini%} should have erred in the use of so
common words as {#Bojya#} or {#Bakzya,#} it is possible also to ob-
tain another result from this discussion of {%Patanjali,%} which
would reconcile the observations he makes in his Introd.,
with those he has appended to the quoted Sūtra, a result
supported by many {%Sūtras%} of {%Pāṇini,%} viz. that {%Kātyāyana,%}
far from being a contemporary of {%Pāṇini,%} as is stated in
one of the ghost stories of the {%Kathāsaritsāgara,%} has lived,
on the contrary, at another period, and that many {%Vārttikas%}
of his must not be looked upon {%by us%} as impugning the ac-
curacy of {%Pāṇini'%}s rules at the time when this grammarian
wrote, but as commenting upon, extending and restricting
the validity of these rules at a probably much later period
of the Sanskṛt literature. See my Preface to the {%Mānava-%}
{%Kalpa-Sūtras.%}
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-ryam#}) Food (in general); e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#SucI-#}
{#nyaByavahAryARi mUlAni ca PalAni ca;#} or {%Kāśikā:%} {#satfRamaBya-#}
{#vaharati . na kiMcidaByavahAryaM tyajatItyarTaH;#} or {#KaraviSadamaBya-#}
{#vahAryaM BakzaSabdenocyate#}. E. {#hf#} with {#ava#} and {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#Ryat#}.
<LEND>

<L>6712<pc>311-a<k1>aByavahAryatva<k2>aByavahAryatva
{#aByavahAryatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The condition of food; e. g. {%Nago-%}
{%jibh.%} (on {%Kaiyy.:%} {#paya eva vratayati#}): {#vratayatIti . aByavahArya-#}
{#tvenopAdatta ityarTaH#}. E. {#aByavahArya,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6718<pc>311-b<k1>aByasana<k2>aByasana

({%Śaṅk.:%} {#…yaTA SAnto Bava vatsa svADyAyaM yogaM cAnutizWa#}
{#taTA te Sreyo BavizyatIti;#} {%Sadānanda:%} {#…yaTA Bo vatsa#}
{#SAntastvaM Bava svADyAyamAcara . yogaM taTAnutizWa tvaM niHSreyaste#}

{%nam.:%} {#svA° = vedAByAsa;#} (comp. {#vyasana#} in the same sense,
e. g. in this verse of the {%Hitop.:%} {#vipadi DEryamaTAByudaye kzamA#}

cile to thee the cow by being constantly after her like

<L>6721<pc>311-b<k1>aByasUyaka<k2>aByasUyaka
{#aByasUyaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yakaH-yikA-yakam#}) <sup>1</sup> In the habit

{#…kzipAmyajasramaSuBAnAsurIzveva yonizu#} ({%Arjunam.:%} =
{#sanmArgavartinAM guRezu dozAropakAH;#} {%Sadānanda:%} {#nanu gurvAdayaH#}
{#SizwAH kaTaM tAnnAnuSAsati . ityatrAhAByasUyante (°yAM te?)#}
{#kurvantaH sajjanezvapi . vedamArge sTitAnAM te kAruRyAdiguRezva-#}
{#pi . pratAraRAdidozARAmAropaRasvaBAvakAH#} ‘…intimating
that their kindness &c. is merely deceit &c.’). <sup>2</sup> Envious,
spiteful; ({%Śaṅk.%} on the word {#aBya°#} in the quoted verse:
{#sanmArgasTAnAM guRezvasahamAnAH#})--Comp. {#asUyaka#} and the
following.--E. {#asU (N)#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#vuY#} (im-
plying here habit or disposition).
<LEND>

<L>6722<pc>311-b<k1>aByasUyA<k2>aByasUyA
{#aByasUyA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-yA#}) <sup>1</sup> Detraction, calumny; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%}
{#anirvftaM BUtizu gUQavEraM satkArakAle'pi kftAByasUyam . vi-#}
{#BinnakarmASayavAkkule no mA jYAticelaM Buvi kasyacidBUt#} ({%Bha-%}
{%ratam.:%} {#kftAByasUyaM kftAmarzaM guRe'pi dozAvizkaraRamasUyA#}).
<sup>2</sup> Envy, spite; e. g. {%Raghuv.:%} {#jagmuH… . BojyAM prati vyarTa-#}
{#manoraTatvAdrUpezu veSezu ca sAByasUyAH#} ({%comm.:%} {#IrzyAsahitAH#});
[Page312-a+ 56]
or {#…dilIpaH . atizWadekonaSatakratutve SakrAByasUyAvini-#}
{#vfttaye yaH#} ({%comm.:%} {#indrasyerzyAnirAkaraRArTam#}). [The learned
Paṇḍits who partly complied and partly composed the
comm. on the present edition of {%Pāṇini%} seem to have
employed {#aByasUyA#} in the sense of ‘abuse, reproof’, or:
‘derision’, when they observe on {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 2. 94.: {#adya#}
{#amAvasyA#} (the opinion of the person which, as the inter-
locutor has shown, is wrong) {#ityevaM vAdI yuktyA svamatAtpra-#}
{#cyAvya sAByasUyamanuyoktrEvamanuyujyate,#} for there is neither {%ca-%}
{%lumny%} nor {%envy%} in what the {%anuyoktṛ%} says, but only {%reproof%}
or perhaps {%derision;%} on what authority they have used the
word in this sense is unknown to me, for there is no com-
ment on the Sūtra by {%Kāty.%} and {%Patanj.%} &c., and the {%Kāś.%}
and {%Siddhk.%} write: {#adyAmAvAsyetyevaM vAdinaM yuktyA pracyAvya#}
{#svamatAdevamanuyujyate#}.]--The same as {#asUyA;#} {%Śabdārnava:%}
{#asUyA tvaByasUyA ca;#} as quoted also by {%Bhānud.,%} &c. on the
{%Amarak.;%} the latter work, however, and its comment., as
well as other {%old%} authorities do not allow {#asUyA#} to be a
synonyme of {#Irzya#} ‘envy’, but restrict its sense to the first
meaning. See s. v. {#asUyA#}.--E. {#asU (N)#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#a#}.
<LEND>

<L>6723<pc>312-a<k1>aByasta<k2>aByasta
{#aByasta#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-staH-stA-stam#}) <sup>1</sup> Accumulated by
repeated practice; e. g. {%Suśr.%} (of {%food%}): {#viSuzkamannamaByastaM#}
{#na pAkaM sADu gacCati;#} or {%the same%} (of {%qualities which are re-%}
{%born in a future life%}): {#karmaRA codito yena tadApnoti punarBave .#}
{#aByastAH pUrvadehe ye tAneva Bajate guRAn#}. <sup>2</sup> Repeatedly done,
repeated, frequently practised; e. g. {%Mitākṣ.:%} {#yadA tvetadeva#}
{#vimiSritaM paYcagavyaM trirAtramaByasyate tadA yatisAntapanasaMjYA#}
{#laBate . etadeva tryahAByastaM yatisAntapanaM smftam;#} or {%Amaruśat.:%}
{#BrUBedo racitaSciraM nayanayoraByastamAmIlanam#} &c.; or {%Mṛchchh.:%}
{#kAlasyAlpatayA ca cIvarakftaH skanDe na jAtaH kiRaH . nAByastA ca#}
{#kazAyavastraracanA#} &c. Comp. also s. v. {#AkUpAra#}. <sup>3</sup> Mentally re-
peated, learnt by heart, studied; e. g. {%Bhartṛh.:%} {#nAByastA Buvi#}
{#vAdivfndadamanI vidyA vinItocitA…SUnyAlaye dIpavat;#} or
{%Nagojibh.%} (in the introd. on {%Patanj.%}): {#bahUnAmapi samAnapfzWoda-#}
{#rapARipAdAnAmaDyayanamaDIyAnAnAmekaH kaScitpaSyannapi svaBya-#}
{#stADyayano'pi tIkzRabudDirapi sanna paSyati . arTAnaBijYatvAt;#}
or {%Mallin.%} (on {%Kiratārj.:%} {#sukftaH pariSudDa AgamaH kurute dIpa#}
{#ivArTadarSanam#}) {#sukftaH svaByastaH#}. <sup>4</sup> (In {%Arithmetic.%}) Multi-
plied; e. g. {%Yāska:%} {#viMSatidvidaSataH SataM daSadaSataH sahasraM#}
{#sahasvadayutaM niyutaM prayutaM tattadaByastam#} &c. ({%Durga:%} {#sahasraM daSa-#}
{#kftvo'ByastamayutaM…ayutamapi daSakftvo'ByastaM niyutami-#}
{#tyucyate#} &c.); or {%Sūryasiddh.:%} {#trijyAByastaM BujaPalaM calakarRavi-#}
{#BAjitam;#} or {#…tena#} (scil. {#BUpariDinA#}) {#deSAntarAByastA#}
{#grahaBuktirviBAjitA#}. [In pure-arithmetical works this term
is of less frequent occurrence than {#guRita, saMguRita, hata,#}
{#Ahata, nihata#}.] <sup>5</sup> (In {%Grammar.%}) Reduplicated (but see
{#aByasta#} {%neuter%}); e. g. {%Yāska:%} {#erira itIrtirupasfzwo'ByastaH;#}
or {#rarivAn . rAtiraByastaH#}.--{%Yāska%} in using {#aByasta#} as a
{%masc.%} and therefore, with the ellipsis of {#DAtu#} (q. v.) differs
from {%Pāṇini%} who uses the word merely as a {%neuter;%} and
in applying it to a radical like {#Ir,#} differs from {%Kātyāyana%}
and {%Patanjali,%} probably also from {%Pāṇini;%} see the following.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-stam#}) (In {%Pāṇini%}); scil. {#aNga#} q. v. The {%redupli-%}
{%cated base%} of a radical, in general, in the preterite ({#liw#}),
the aorist ({#caN#}), the desider. ({#san#}) and the intens. ({#yaN#})
[Page312-b+ 56]
--comp. VI. 1. 8. 9. 11.--, moreover the reduplicated base
of a radical of the third class ({#hu#} &c. VI. 1. 10.) and the
{%base%} (being in reality a reduplicated one) of {#jakz, jAgf,#}
{#daridrA, cakAs, dIDI, vevI#} and {#SAs#} (to which {%Kātyāy.%}
adds, though not with the consent of {%Patanj.%} and {%Kaiyy.:%}
{#sas#} and {#vaS#} VI. 1. 6 and vv.), before a {#sArvaDAtuka,#} as well
as the {%reduplicated base%} of a radical of the named categories
in the participles (included in the foregoing terms) and in
such derivatives as {#baBru, yayu, cakra, ciklida#} &c. (VI. 1. 12 vv).
The term {#aByasta#} {%n.%} comprises therefore, in {%Pāṇini,%} the
radical syllable {%and%} the syllable of reduplication (which
latter is called by him {#aByAsa;#} VI. 1. 5.: {#uBe aByastam;#}
VI. 1. 4.: {#pUrvo'ByAsaH#}); e. g. {#dadA#}--, and {#nenij#}--of
{#dadAti#} and {#nenijati#} are {#aByastam#} ({#da#}--and {#ne#}--being
in these words the {#aByAsa#}). {%Kātyāyana%} and {%Patanjali%} con-
clude from this definition of {%Pāṇini%} that the term can only
be used where there are {%two%} syllables representing the re-
duplication and that it is not applicable to the first syllable
in instances like {#Irtsanti#} (the desid. of {#fD#}) or {#Ipsanti#}
(the desid. of {#Ap#}) ({%Kāty.:%} {#uBegrahaRaM saMjYinirdeSArTam;#}
{%Pat.:%} {#antareRApyuBegrahaRaM prakftaH saMjYinirdeSaH . kaTaM dve iti#}
{#vartate . idaM tarhi prayojanam;#} {%Kāty.:%} {#yatroBe SabdasvarUpe SrUyete#}
{#tatrAByastasaMjYA yaTA syAt;#} {%Pat.:%} {#iha mA BUt . Irtsanti Ipsa-#}
{#ntIti . Irtsan . Ipsan . Ertsan . Epsan#}). [The learned
Paṇḍits who partly complied and partly composed the
comm. of the present ed. of {%Pāṇ.%} have been mistaken, con-
sequently, when they supply at the term {#aByasta#} the word
{#DAtu,#} instead of {#aNga,#} in their gloss on VI. 1. 189. (‘{#aByasta-#}
{#saMjYakAnAM DAtUnAm#} &c.’ instead of {#…aNgAnAm#}); for
such an ellipsis would unduly restrict the bearing of the
rule and be at variance not merely with the process of re-
duplication as conceived by {%Pāṇini%} (I. 1. 59.), but with the
neuter gender of the term. {%Pāṇini,%} it is true, calls the
seven quoted radicals {#jakz#} &c. {#‘aByasta’#} (whence {%Patanjali%}
speaks of {#sapta jakzityAdayo'ByastasaMjYakAH#}--scil. {#DAtavaH#}--,
and the {%Kāś.%} comments {#jakza ityayaM DAturityAdayaScAnye zaq#}
{#DAtavo'ByastasaMjYakA Bavanti,#} which is a much clearer para-
phrase of the {%Vārtt.%} and {%Bhāṣya,%} than the modern gloss
which renders {#zaz#} of the Sūtra simply with {#saptan#}), but,
not to speak of the exceptional nature of these radicals
which are not of a primitive kind, is is obvious that {%Pā-%}
{%ṇini,%} in connecting the {%neuter%} {#aByastam#} (of the preceding
Sūtra) with the word {#jakzityAdayaH#} (of the following), did
not mean the {#DAtu,#} but the {#aNga#} of these radicals, espe-
cially as he treats of the rules concerning the {#aByasta,#} in
the chapter on {#aNga#} (VI. 4. 1. to the end of the seventh
book). The same inaccuracy of supplying the word {#DAtu,#}
instead of {#aNga,#} has been frequently committed by the same
Paṇḍits in the last named chapter (e. g. VII. 4. 69. 73. 84. 85.
86. 87. 88. 89. 90. 91. 92. 96. 97. &c. &c. where the {%Kāśikā%} either
omits the word supplied or has {#aNga#}), but even {%Jayāditya%}
himself has nodded, though rarely.--{%One%} Sūtra may, in-
deed, lead to the assumption that {%Pāṇini,%} too, speaks of
a {#DAtu#} which is {#aByasta,#} but merely apparently; VI. 1. 32. he
rules {#hvaH saMprasAraRam#} ‘there is {%samprasāraṇa%} of the radical
{#hve#}’; and VI. 1. 33. he adds {#‘aByastasya’;#} this latter word,
[Page313-a+ 56]
however, does not mean ‘when {#hve#} is {#aByasta#}’, but, acc. to
{%Kāty.%} and {%Pat.,%} when there is a reason for making ‘a re-
duplicated base’ of {#hve#} (viz. in the desid., intens. &c.); for
it is not this base (of two syllables) that suffers {%sampra-%}
{%sāraṇa,%} but the radical when it is {%not yet%} a reduplicated
base; properly speaking {#aByastanimitte#} would have been
therefore a better Sūtra than {#aByastasya;#} and, continues
{%Kātyāy.,%} if {%Pāṇini%} meant to rule that a reduplicated base
({#aByasta#}) suffers {%sampr.,%} a prohibition was at least required
for the syllable of reduplication ({#aByAsa#}) &c.: {%Patanj.:%} {#hvo#}
{#'Byastasyetyucyate . na cEtad hvo'Byastam . kasya tarhi hvAyayateH .#}
{#hva etadaByastam . kaTam . ekAco dve praTamasyeti#} (VI. 1. 1.) {#.#}
{#evaM tarhi hvayateraByastasyetyucyate . na cAtra hvayatiraByastam .#}
{#kastarhi . hvAyayatiH . hvayatirevAtrAByastam . kaTam . ekAco#}
{#dve praTamasyetyevamapi; ..#} {%K. Vārtt.:%} {#aByastanimitte'naByastasaMpra-#}
{#sAraRArTam ..;#} {%Pat.:%} {#aByastanimitta iti vaktavyam . kiM prayoja-#}
{#nam . anaByastasya saMprasAraRArTam . anaByastasya saMprasAraRaM yaTA#}
{#syAt . juhUzati . johUyate ..;#} {%K. Vārtt.:%} {#aByastasya prasAraRe#}
{#hyaByAsaprasAraRAprAptiH ..;#} {%Pat.:%} {#aByastaprasAraRe hi aByAsa-#}
{#prasAraRasyAprAptiH syAt#} &c.--In the {%Vārtt.%} 1. to VI. 1.
186. {#aByastasic#} is a Dwandwa, before it becomes com-
pounded with the following {#arTa#}. E. {#as#} (cl. 4) with {#aBi,#}
kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6724<pc>313-a<k1>aByastamaya<k2>aByastamaya
{#aByastamaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) (ved.) The setting of the sun
with regard to (some act, i. e. while some act is taking
place); e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śr. S.:%} {#anudDftAByastamaye#} (q. v.) {#kuSabadDe#}
{#hiraRye paScAdDriyamARa iDmenodDaredArzeyo brAhmaRaH;#} or {%Yājni-%}
{%kad.%} (on {%Kāty. Śr.-S.:%} {#AdityAByaye'hutAyAmapi#}): {#vapA-#}
{#homAtpUrvamAdityAByastamaye#} &c. Comp. the following. E. {#aBi#}
and {#astamaya#} (not {#aByastam#} and {#aya#}).
<LEND>

<L>6725<pc>313-a<k1>aByastamita<k2>aByastamita
{#aByastamita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) One towards whom
the sun has set (scil. while he is asleep), asleep at sunset;
e. g. {%Gotama:%} {#sUryAByudito brahmacArI tizWedaharaBuYjano'Bya-#}
{#stamitaSca rAtriM japansAvitrIm#} (where the ellipsis ‘when
asleep’ follows from the word {#svapna#} in the preceeding pas-
sage: {#retaskandane Baye roge svapne'gnInDanaBEkzacaraRAni sapta-#}
{#rAtraM kftvAjyahomaH sABisanDervA retasyAByAm#}).--This is the
reading acc. to both Calc. edd. of {%Kullūka%} to {%Manu%} 2. 220;
the Calc. ed. of {%Gotama'%}s {%Sanh.%} (made by {%Bhavanīcharana-%}
{%vandya,%} as he says, {#bahuprayatnataH#}) has, however, {#sUryAByudite#}
{#…(a)Byastamite ca…,#} when it would be necessary to
take {#sU°#} as equivalent to {#sUryAByudaya#} and {#aBya°#} as expressing
the sense of {#aByastamaya,#} both words being then locatives
of a neuter {#°tam#}. But {%Kullūka'%}s reading seems better as
being countenanced by analogous expressions in {%Manu%} 2. 221.
Comp. {#aBinirmukta#} and {#aByudita#}. E. {#aBi#} and {#astamita#} (not
{#aByastam#} and {#ita,#} for {#aBi#} refers to the person or act con-
cerned by the sunset; similarly in ved. passages which
contain the combination {#aByastamagAt#} or {#aByastamiyAt,#} the
rad. {#gA#} or {#i#} are combined first with {#astam#} and then with
{#aBi,#} not with {#aByastam#}); see also the preceding.
<LEND>

<L>6726<pc>313-a<k1>aByastasvara<k2>aByastasvara

a {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 188.: {#svapAdInAM vA vacanAdastasvaro#}
{#vipratizeDena;#} or {%Pat.%} on a {%Vārtt.%} to VI. 1. 192.: {#aByastasvaro#}
{#'tra bADako Bavizyati#}. E. {#aByasta#} and {#svara#}.
<LEND>
[Page313-b+ 56]

<L>6732<pc>313-b<k1>aByAKyAna<k2>aByAKyAna
