<L>6733<pc>313-b<k1>aByAgata<k2>aByAgata
{#aByAgata#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Come, arrived; e. g.
{%Rāmāy.:%} {#aTa te mantrinaH sUtaM sumantraM sapurohitAH . Ucura-#}
{#ByAgatAnasmAmrAjYe tvAvedayeti vE;#} frequently with the im-
plied sense, ‘as a {%visitor%}’ and then also used absolutely as
a {%masc. ‘visitor’;%} e. g. {%Hitop.:%} {#vAlo vA yadi vA vfdDo yuvA#}
{#vA gfhamAgataH . tasya pUjA viDAtavyA sarvatrAByAgato guruH;#} or
{#gururagnirdvijAtInAM varRAnAM brAhmaRo guruH . patireko guruH#}
{#strIRAM sarvasyAByAgato guruH;#} or {%Mahābh. Udyogap.:%} {#ye cA-#}
{#pyanye saMSritA DArtarAzwrAnnAnAdigByo'ByAgatAH sUtaputra . dfzwvA#}
{#tAMScEvArhataScApi sarvAnsaMpfcCeTAH kuSalaM cAvyayaM ca . evaM sarvA-#}
{#nAgatAByAgatAMSca rAjYo dUtAnsarvadigByo'ByupetAn . pfzwvA#}
{#sarvAnkuSalaM tAMSca sUta paScAdahaM kuSalI tezu vAcyaH#} (comp. s. v.
{#aBivAdana#}), in which passage {#AgatAByAgata#} might seem
to be merely a poetical redundance to denote the great
number of the arrived envoys, but the comm. of {%Chaturbhu-%}
{%jam.%} is probably correct in distinguishing between the {#Agata#}
or the {%guest%} (who makes a stay) and the {#aByAgata#} or the
[Page314-a+ 56]
{%visitor%} (who soon leaves): {#AgatAn . tatrevAgatya sTitAn .#}
{#aByAgatAn AgatAgatAnapi gamizyataH;#} for a similar dis-
tinction is made between {#atiTi#} and {#aByAgata#} e. g. in this
verse of the {%Bhāg.-Pur.:%} {#yastviha vA atiTInaByAgatAnvA#}
{#gfhapatirasakfdupagatamanyurdiDakzuriva pApena cakzuzA nirIkzate#}
{#tasya#} &c.; {%Hemach.,%} however, treats {#atiTi#} and {#aByAgata#}
as convertible terms, the distinction being probably dropped
in common language. <sup>2</sup> (In {%Law.%}) Come down by inheri-
tance (as property); e. g. {%Yājnav.:%} {#kramAdaByAgataM dravyaM hfta-#}
{#maByudDarettu yaH . dAyAdeByo na taddadyAdvidyayA labDameva ca;#} or
{%Nārada:%} {#kramAdaByAgataM prAptaM putrEryannarRamudDftam . dadyuH pEtAmahaM#}
{#pOtrAstaccaturTAnnivartate#}. E. {#gam#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6734<pc>314-a<k1>aByAgama<k2>aByAgama
{#aByAgama#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) <sup>1</sup> Arrival (with friendly intent),
visit ({%Hemach., Viśvapr., Bhūripr., Med., Śabdar.:%} = {#aByu-#}
{#dgama#}). <sup>2</sup> Neighbourhood ({%Hem.%} &c.: = {#antika;#} or {#nikawa#}).
<sup>3</sup> Hostile encounter, war, battle ({%Amarak., Hem., Bhūripr.,%}
{%Śabdar., Viśvapr.:%} = {#yudDa, samara, Aji#} &c.). <sup>4</sup> Enmity,
hostility ({%Hem.:%} = {#roDa;#} {%Med., Viśvapr., Bhūripr., Trik.:%}
= {#viroDa;#} {%Śabdar.:%} = {#vEra#}). <sup>5</sup> Striking, hurting ({%Med.:%} =
{#aBiGAta;#} {%Hem., Viśvapr., Śabdar.:%} = {#GAta#}). <sup>6</sup> Result,
fruition, enjoyment; e. g. {%Nyāya Sūtra:%} {#yaToktahetutvAtpAra-#}
{#tantryAtsvakftAByAgamAcca na manasaH#} ‘(desire &c.) are not qua-
lities of {%Manas,%} because they are caused by what has been
explained before, because they depend on other (existences),
and because enjoyment arises only from one's own doings’
({%Viśvan.:%} {#aByAgamo BogaH . sa manaso yatnAdisattve na syAt#}
&c.). [{%Rādhāk.%} quotes s. v. a meaning {#aByutTAna#} ‘rising
from a seat at the arrival of a guest’ as founded on the
{%Viśvapr.,%} but none of the {%Mss.%} of this Kosha at my dis-
posal give this explanation; they read: {#aByAgamo'ntike#}
{#GAte viroDAByudgamAjizu#}.] E. {#gam#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>

<L>6735<pc>314-a<k1>aByAgamana<k2>aByAgamana

<L>6736<pc>314-a<k1>aByAgArika<k2>aByAgArika
{#aByAgArika#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) One who takes care of his family, a
householder, a pater-familias ({%Amarak., Hemach.:%} = {#kuwu-#}
{#mbavyApfta;#} {%Rāyam., Padārthak.:%} = {#kuwumbaH putradArAdiH . tezAM#}
{#pozaRe saMsaktaH;#} similarly, {%Bharatam., Nīlak%} &c.; {%Ramān.%} =
{#kuwumbin#}). E. {#aBi-AgAra#} ({%Avyayībh.%} ‘concerning the
house’), taddh. aff. {#Wan#}. Another etym. proposed by
{%Rāyam.%} and optionally by {%Bhānud.%} {#aBi (= aDika)#} and
{#AgArika#} is less plausible. A various reading {#AyyAgA-#}
{#rika#} is objectionable; comp. {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 4. 70.--

<L>6738<pc>314-a<k1>aByAGAtin<k2>aByAGAtin
{#aByAGAtin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-tI-tinI-ti#}) In the habit of
assaulting, quarrelsome, pugnacious; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#kurvanti#}
{#parisAriRyo vidyutaH paridevinam#} (scil. {#mAm#}) {#. aByAGAti-#}
{#BirAmiSrAScAtakEH parirAwiBiH#} ({%Jayam. Bhar.:%} {#aByA° =#}
{#aBihananaSIlEH#}); {%Hem. Dhātup.%} s. v. {#han = aByAhanataSIla#}.
E. {#han#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GinuR#}.
<LEND>
[Page314-b+ 56]

<L>6754<pc>315-a<k1>aByAroha<k2>aByAroha
{#aByAroha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) <sup>1</sup> (ved.?) Ascending, mounting;
e. g. {%Śatap.%} (III. 3. 4. 9.): {#udDate prOgye Palake BavataH . tada-#}
{#ntareRa tizWantsubrahmaRyaH prAjati SreyAnvA ezo'ByArohAdBavati#}
({%Sāy. Ms. E. I. H.:%} {#prayugasaMDiPalake udDate prayugAdapyunnate#}
{#cuvukapramARe BavataH . ata eva sUtrakArastasminneva pradeSe Palaka-#}
{#yorOdDatyaM sUtrayAmAsa prayugAccodDate ca Palake Bavata iti .#}

{#praSastatvaM lokasidDam . atastadaByArohAtsomaH SreyAnBavati .#}
{#atastadaDizWitaSca kawamAroQumarhati#} (Ms. {#°marhamiti#}) {#. BUyizWa#}

e. g. {%Śatapath.:%} {#aTa vA ato'hnAmaByArohaH . prAyaRIyenA-#}
{#tirAtreRodayanIyamatirAtramaByArohanti caturviMSena mahAvratama-#}
{#Biplavena paramaBiplavaM pfzWyena paraM pfzWyamaBijitA viSvajitaM svara-#}
{#sAmaBiH parAntsvarasAmno'TEtadaharanaByArUQaM yadvEzuvatamaBi ha#}
{#vE SreyAMsaM rohati nEnaM pApIyAnaByArohanti ya evametadveda ..#}
{#aTa vA ato'hnAM nivAhaH . prAyaRIyo'tirAtraScaturviMSA-#}
{#yAhne nivahati caturviMSamaharaBiplavAyABiplavaH pfzWyAya pfzWyo#}
{#'Bijite'BijitsvarasAmaByaH svarasAmAno vizuvate vizuvA-#}
{#ntsvarasAmaByaH svarasAmAno viSvajite viSvatitpfzWyAya pfzWyo#}
{#'BiplavAyABiplavo go'AyurByAM go'AyuzI daSarAtrAya daSa-#}
{#rAtro mahAvratAya mahAvratamudayanIyAyAtirAtrAyodayanIyo#}
{#'tirAtraH svargAya lokAya pratizWAyA annAdyAya#}. <sup>3</sup> (ved.)

by muttering prayers’; then, the act of praying itself);

<L>6755<pc>315-b<k1>aByArohaRa<k2>aByArohaRa

<LEND>

<L>6756<pc>315-b<k1>aByArohaRIya<k2>aByArohaRIya
{#aByArohaRIya#}¦ m. ({#-yaH#}) The name of a Soma sacrifice:
the first of the seven Soma sacrifices of the {%Rājasūya%}
which is performed by a king (see {#rAjasUya#} and the quo-
tations s. v. {#aBizecanIya#}); it is called so in the {%Śrauta%}
{%Sūtras%} of {%Āśvalāyana%} and of the {%Sāmaveda-schools,%} but for
shortness sake {#pavitra#} in the {%Śrauta S.%} of {%Kātyāyana;%} ({%Āśval.:%}
{#aTa rAjasUyaH . purastAtPAlgunyAH pOrRamAsyAH pavitreRAgni-#}
{#zwomenAByArohaRIyena yajeta pOrRamAsyAM cAturmAsyAni prayuNkte#}
{#nityAni parvARi cakrAByAM tu parvAntarezu carantyaharviparyayaM pakza-#}
{#viparyayaM vA;#} {%Yājnikadeva%}--Ms. E. I. H. 1362--on {%Kāty.%}
{%Śr. S.%} XV. 1. 4. and 5.: {#SAKAntare'sya#} (i. e. {#pavitrasya#}) {#aByA-#}
{#rohaRIya iti saMjYA . PAlgunIpakzasya praTamAyAM dIkzetAByA-#}
{#rohaRIyA yajYasyEkA dIkzA dvAdaSaM SataM dakziRA iti cCando-#}
{#gasUtre . ASvalAyano'pi purastA°°° prayuNkta iti#} [--the first
quotation being taken from {%Lātyāy. Śr. S.%} IX. 1. where,
however, the Ms. E. I. H. 1652 and the Ms. R. L. Berlin
Chamb. 89 (p. 64 {%a%}) and {%Agnisw.%} comm. Chamb. 436 (p. 244{%b%})
have the more correct reading {#°ByArohaRIyAya jyotizwo-#}
{#mAya tasyEkA dI°°--#}] {#. pavitra iti saMjYAsaMvyavahArArTA#}).
Neither {%Āśval.,%} nor {%Lāṭyāy.,%} nor {%Maśaka%} give a detailed
description of this sacrifice, since it shares chiefly in the rites
of the {%Agniṣṭoma,%} and {%Kātyāyana,%} too, who founds his rules
({%Śr. Sūtr.%} XV. 1. 4.--3. 46.) on the text of the {%Śatapathabr.%}
(V. 2. 3. 1.--3. 2. 8.) and, among the Sūtra-authors, gives
the fullest information, only mentions what is peculiar to
this sacrifice and not what it has in common with the Agni-
ṣṭoma; {%Maśaka%} Ms. Chamb. Berl. 100 (p. 42 {%b%}): {#kxpto'ByA-#}
{#rohaRIyaH;#} {%Vyākhyā%} E. I. H.: {#kx° iti . jyotizwoma ityanu-#}
{#vartate sa cAgnizwomasaMsTaH . agnizwomamaByAharatIti SruteH;#}
{%Yājnik.%} on {%Kāty.:%} {#avacane'gnizwoma iti vakzyamARatvAt#});
the {%Śatap.%} itself, however, begins its description only with
the proceedings connected with but following the {%Abhyāroh.,%}
viz. with the {%Pūrṇāhuti%} &c.; ({%Sāy.:%} {#tatra#}--i. e. {#rAjasUye--#}
{#pavitranAmake praTamasomayAge pravfttisamAnatvena vaktavyABAvAttaM#}
{#parityajya tadavasAne kartavyaM tatra pUrRAhutipraBfti vESezikamuttara-#}
{#tantramaBiDIyate#}).--The {%Abhyārohanīya%} (or {%Pavitra%}) com-
mences on the first day of the first or light fortnight of the
month Phālguna (February-March) and lasts eight days, the
{%four%} first of which are occupied by the {%Dīkṣā%} or initiatory
rites, the {%three%} following by the {%Upasad%}-offerings (q. v.)
and the {%eighth%} by the {%Sutyā%} (q. v.; {%Yājnik. Paddh.:%} {#caturdI-#}
{#kzastryupasatka ekasutyaH pavitrasaMjYakaH somayAgo'gnizwomasaMsTaH#});
the presents given to the priests are a thousand cows; in the
choice of the priests, the buying of the Soma &c. it con-
forms itself, as is said before, to the rules of the Agni-
ṣṭoma.--The rites connected with this sacrifice and
following it, are: on the {%ninth%} day the {%Pūrṇāhuti%} or a liba-
tion of a ladle-full of butter, in the house of the sacrificer,
if he wishes it;--the present he makes on this occasion,
being left to his own liberality. ({%Harisvāmin%} adds the
following details, which may serve as an instance: the
Adhwaryu takes first the Āhavanīya fire out; four seats
are prepared; the choice of the Brahman is made silently;
[Page316-a+ 56]
the Adhw. sits silently down at the right side of the Brahman
and the sacrificer, prepares the clarified butter, cleans the
ladles {%Sruch%} and {%Sruva%} and takes with the {%Sruva%} as much
butter as is necessary to fill the {%Sruch;%} then he proceeds
with fuel and the {%Sruch%} to the fire, sits down, puts the
fuel on and in saying svāhā! sacrifices the butter with the
words: ‘this to Agni, this to Prajāpati’; then the sacri-
ficer gives the present to the Adhwaryu.) The principal
ceremonies after this libation are: on the following or {%tenth%}
day the burnt sacrifice of a Puroḍāśa fried in eight bowls,
under the recital of {%Vājas.%} 9. 35., to Anumati (q. v.), when
the present to the priest is a garment; on the {%eleventh%} day
the sacrifice of a Puroḍāśa fried in eleven bowls, to Agni
and Viṣṇu, the present being gold; on the {%twelfth%} day, of
a Puroḍāśa, also fried in eleven bowls, to Agni and Soma,
the present: a cow which has been several times liberated,
(liberation being the object to be effectuated by this gift);
on the {%thirteenth%} day, of a Puroḍāśa fried in twelve bowls,
when the priest receives a bull; on the {%fourteenth%} day, an
{%Āgrayaṇeṣṭi%} (q. v.) accompanied with the gift of a cow.--
The next four sacrifices are those which constitute the
{%Chāturmāsya%} ceremonies, viz. the {%Vaiśvadeva, Varuṇapra-%}
{%ghāsa, Sākamedha%} and {%Śunasīrya%} (qq. vv.); they are per-
formed during four successive months but so that the com-
mencement of the {%Śunasīrya%} falls on the same day on which
the Dīkṣā of the Abhyārohanīya had begun in the pre-
ceding year. The rite on the {%first%} day of the Śunasīrya is
the {%Pañchavatīya%} (q. v.), viz. a libation of butter under
special injunctions and accompanied by the muttering of
the verses {%Vāj.%} 9. 35. and 37., (performed esp. when the king
suffers from a painful disease, since it will give him relief);
the present is a cart with three horses. There follows on the
{%second%} day the {%Indraturīya%} which consists of four libations,
viz. a libation of {%Havis%} fried in eight bowls, to Agni,--
of {%Charu%} made of barley, to Varuṇa,--of Charu made
of gavedhuka-rice, to Rudra,--of curds proceeding from
the milk of a cart-cow, to Indra; and this cow is then
offered to the priest as a present. The sacrifice on the
then following, or {%third,%} day is the {%Apāmārgahoma,%} which
serves also to break the spell of incantatory rites performed
by an enemy and to turn them against himself, and the
peculiarities of which are therefore described with some
detail by {%Kāty.%} and the commentator; it seems to be barren
for the Adhwaryu, for no present is mentioned. The next
in order are the {%Trishamyukta%}-libations in three divisions:
first, Puroḍāśa fried in eleven bowls, to Agni and Viṣṇu,
Charu to Indra and Viṣṇu, and Charu or Puroḍāśa fried
in three bowls to Viṣṇu;--the present is a short bull or
cow; secondly on the following day, Puroḍāśa fried in
eleven bowls, to Agni and Pūṣan, Charu to Indra and
Pūṣan, and Charu to Pūṣan, the present: a black bull
or cow; thirdly on the following day, Puroḍāśa fried in
eleven bowls, to Agni and Soma, Charu to Indra and
Soma, and Charu to Soma, the present: a tawny bull or
cow; on the next day Puroḍāśa fried in twelve bowls is
offered to Viśvānara, and Charu made of barley to Va-
[Page316-b+ 56]
ruṇa, or the latter libation is spared for a separate, the
following day; in such a case the present given to the
priest for the libation to Viśvānara is a bull, and for that
to Varuṇa, a black garment, or if such a garment cannot
be had, one that is not black. [The Śunasīrya and the
other ceremonies would therefore comprise seven, or if the
two last are performed on one day, six days; and the cere-
mony to be mentioned presently, the {%Ratnahavis,%} would be-
gin on the eighth or seventh day after the Śunasīrya. Such
is the rule of the {%Kāṇva%} school, but {%Harisvāmin%} despatches
the {%Indraturīya, Apāmārgahoma%} and the three {%Trishamyukta%}
on the day after the Śunasīrya, and puts the Viśvānara-
and Varuṇa-libations on the third, or the Viśvānara-lib.
on the third and the Varuṇa-lib. on the fourth day, with
the further remark that, according to the option in the per-
forming of the latter rites, the beginning of the next fol-
lowing, the {%Ratnahavis,%} would come to fall either on the
third or on the fourth day. This difference between the
two schools, as regards the time of the performance of these
rites, continues therefore in what follows.] The rites next
in order are twelve libations called {%Ratnahavis%} (q. v.) which
are performed on twelve successive days in twelve different
houses, whereto the sacrificer repairs for this purpose on
each following day, with the {%Gārhapatya%} and {%Āhavanīya%}
fire placed on the two {%Araṇis;%} viz. a libation of 1. Puroḍāśa
fried in eight bowls, to Agni Anīkavat, in the house of
the {%Senānī%} or commander in chief; 2. Charu to Bṛhaspati,
in the house of the {%Purohita%} or family priest; 3. Puroḍāśa
fried in eleven bowls to Indra, in the house of the {%Yaja-%}
{%māna%} or the king for whom all these proceedings take
place; 4. Charu to Aditi, in the h. of the {%Mahiṣī%} or his
first and principal wife; 5. Charu (made of barley) to Va-
ruṇa in the h. of the {%Sūta%} or the master of the horse
({%Yājnik.:%} = {#aSvasAraTiH;#} {%Hariśv.:%} = {#aSvapozaka#}); 6. Puro-
ḍāśa fried in eight bowls, to the Maruts, in the h. of the
{%Grāmaṇī%} or mayor ({%Yājnik.:%} = {#grAmanetA vESyAnAM mahattaraH#});
7. Puroḍāśa fried in twelve or eight bowls, to Savitṛ, in
the h. of the {%Kṣattṛ%} or goldstick-in-waiting (at the same
time the overseer of the harem and confidential messenger;
({%Sāy.:%} {#kzattA nAma yazwihasto'ntaHpurADyakzaH sarvezAM niyantA#}
{#pratihArAparaparyAyaH#}); 8. Puroḍāśa fried in two bowls, to
the Aśvins, in the h. of the {%Saṅgrahītṛ%} or the driver (who
stands on the left side of the king in his carriage); 9. Charu
to {%Pūṣan,%} in the h. of the {%Bhāgadugha%} or minister of the
revenue ({%Sāy.:%} {#rAjYaH prAptaM zazWaM BAgaM prajAByo gfhItvA rAjYe#}
{#dogDi prayacCatIti BAgaduGaH#}); 10. Charu made of Gave-
dhukas which have been fetched from the houses of the
overseer of the gambling halls ({%akṣavāpa%}) and of the {%govi-%}
{%kartṛ%} or (master of the) huntsmen (or acc. to others of a
ploughman), to Rudra, in the h. of the {%Yajamāna%} or sacri-
ficer; 11. Ājya or clarified butter taken four times, to Road
(personified as a divinity), in addressing it with the words
‘may Road liking the clarified butter partake of it ({%Śatap.%}
V. 3. 1. 11.)’, in the h. of the {%Dūta%} or messenger; 12. a
Darvihoma of Charu made of black rice which has been
unhusked with the finger-nails, under the recital of the
[Page317-a+ 56]
words {#eza--svAhA#} ({%Vājas.%} 9. 35.), or a simple Charu pre-
pared in the same manner under the recital of the same
words and a {%Vaṣaṭkāra,%} to Nirṛti, in the h. of a wife of
the king who has been left by him for want of having
borne him a son. The presents to the priests in the pre-
ceding twelve acts are severally (and in the given order):
1. gold, 2. a cow with a black back (or acc. to others with
a white back; see {#SitipfzWa#}), 3. a bull, 4. a milch-cow, 5. a
horse, 6. a spotted cow, 7. a red (or acc. to others, a white;
see {#Syeta#}) cart-ox, 8. two twin-cows or, if they cannot be
had, two cows, which are born one after the other, 9. a
cow with white and black hairs, 10. three presents (for the
lib. to Rudra), viz. a. either a cow with white thighs (acc.
to some, with black thighs) or one with a white tail (acc.
to some, with a black tail; see {#SitibAhu#} and {#Siti-#}
{#vAla#}), b. a dagger-sword, sharp and its point unbent,
(without a sheath), c. a vessel where gambling-dice are
thrown in, tied round with a cord made of hairs; 11. three
presents (for the lib. to Road), viz. a. a bow covered with
{%pyukṣṇas%} [which word is rendered by {%Sāy.:%} tendon, by
{%Yājnik.%} in reference to others: tail of a peacock, or skin
of a boa constrictor; the E. I. H. Ms. of the comm. to
{%Śatap.%} V. 3. 1. 11. and {%Weber'%}s ed. read {#ukzRa°#} for {#pyukzRa#}
which seems doubtful, though {#ukzRa#} is explained {#ukzavikAra#}],
b. a leather quiver with arrows, and c. a red turban; 12. a
black, old diseased cow.--Then the king tells his bar-
ren wife to go forth and out of his power, and she re-
pairs to the house of a Brāhmaṇa where the king has no
more any control over her.--After the {%Ratnahavis%} have
been completed, the (royal) sacrificer goes to his palace
and makes (apparently on the day of the twelfth Ratna-
havis) a libation of Charu which has been prepared in the
milk of a white cow which has had a white calf, to Soma
and Rudra; and the present he makes to the priest, is this
white cow; (this rite is performed esp. if the king suffers
from scabs or vitiligo). On the following day he makes a
libation of Charu to Mitra and Bṛhaspati, and makes to
the priest the gift of a cow. This libation which is also
the subject of special injunctions, closes the rites which are
connected with the Abhyārohaṇīya and are immediately
followed by those of the {%Abhiṣechanīya.%} [The {%Sāmaveda%}
school must have rejected the performance of the Śunāsīrya
and of all the following rites, since they place with distinct
words the beginning of the {%Abhiṣechanīya (v. s. v.)%} on the
same day of the following year on which, in the previous
year, the initiatory rite of the Abhyār. commenced, viz. on
the first day of the light fortnight of the month Phālguna,
i. e. on the same day when acc. to the {%Yajurveda%} school,
the Śunāsīrya would have to begin (e. g. {%Lātyāy. Śr. S.:%}
{#saMvatsarAdUrDvamaBizecanIyena yajeta tasminneva kAle;#} {%Agnisw.:%}
{#izwvAByArohaRIyena saMvatsaramAsitvA tato'BizecanIyena yajeta .#}
{#aBizecanIya iti saMjYA . tasminneva kAle . yasminkAle'ByA-#}
{#rohaRIyenezwam . PAlgunIpakzasya praTamAyAmiti#}); {%Harisvāmin%}
who seems to assign only a fortnight to the performance
of the rites from the Śunāsīrya to the last Charu-libation,
puts the Abhish. (as mentioned s. v.) on the first day of
[Page317-b+ 56]
the {%dark%} fortnight of the month Phālguna ({%Harisw.:%} {#PAlguna-#}
{#kfzRapratipadyaBizecanIyasya dIkzeta#}) in reading the {%Śrauta S.%}
XV. 3. 49. of {%Kātyāy.:%} {#PAlgunIyajanIye dIkzate;#} but the
{%Kāṇva%} school which is followed by {%Yājnikadeva,%} the com-
mentator of {%Kātyāy.,%} assigns a much longer duration to
these rites and places therefore the beginning of the {%Abhish.%}
(which circumstance I omitted to mention under {#aBizeca-#}
{#nIya#}) on the first day of the light fortnight of the month
Chaitra (March-April), in reading the named Sūtra {#PAlgu-#}
{#nIpakzayajanIye'BizecanIyaM dIkzate#} and supplying at {#PAlgu-#}
{#nIpakza#} the word {#atIta;#} they forbid moreover altogether
any religious act to be performed during the dark fortnight
of Phālguna ({%Yājnik.:%} {#PAlgunyAM nityaM SunAsIrIyaM prAtarnityaM#}
{#vESvadevaM parva . PAlgunakfzRapakze kimapi karma na Bavati#})]. E.
{#aByArohaRa,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#} (or perhaps a Tatpur., {#ruh#} with
{#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#anIyar;#} comp. the E. of {#aBize-#}
{#canIya#}); scil. {#somayAga#}.
<LEND>

<L>6757<pc>317-b<k1>aByArohya<k2>aByArohya

to be reached; e. g. {%Śatapathabr.:%} {#yajYena vE devAH . imAM#}
{#jitiM jigyuryEzAmiyaM jitiste hocuH kaTaM na idaM manuzyErana-#}
{#ByArohyaM syAditi#}. E. {#ruh#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛtya

<LEND>

<L>6758<pc>317-b<k1>aByAvartam<k2>aByAvartam
{#aByAvartam#}¦ Tatpur. ind. By repeatedly coming; by being re-
peated; e. g. {%Śatap.:%} {#tena retasA siktenemAH prajAH punaraByA-#}
{#vartaM prajAyante#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aByAvftyAByAvftya#}); or (said of the
verses in a {#stotra#}) {%Śatap.:%} {#yadUrDvA stomA anuyanti . yajYama-#}
{#ByAvartaM sAmaBiH kalpamAnAH;#} or {#upAvartaDvamiti vA anyAni#}
{#stotrARi . aByAvartaM DuryE stuvata imA vE prajA etAni sto-#}
{#trARyaByupAvfttAstasmAdimAH prajAH punaraByAvartaM prajAyante;#} or
{#caturviMSAH pavamAnAH . trivfdaByAvartaM catuScatvAriMSAH pavamAnA#}
{#ekaviMSamaByAvartam#} &c. (where {#aByAvartam#} is not to be taken
as a neuter in the sense of {#Avfttistotra;#} for in the gloss
of {%Harisvāmin%}--Ms. E. I. H.--: {#‘paYcaBiretABiH kalpAntaraM#}
{#prapaYcyate . tatra praTame yAvadahani trayo'pi pavamAnA yASca-#}
{#turviMSAyAnu (?) aByAvartayanti . aByAvartaM DuryE stuvate tattrivft#}
(Ms. {#natfvft#} sic) {#. pavamAnavyatiriktAnyAvfttistotrARi tri-#}
{#vfnti BavantItyarTaH#}’, the word {#Avfttistotra#} explains the
{%‘sense’%} but not the grammatical quality of {#aByAvartam#}. It
should be observed that in this and similar passages {#trivft,#}
{#ekaviMSa, trayastriMSa, ekaviMSa#} &c. are names of {%Stomas%} which
qualify the {%Stotra:%} the former expressing how often the
verses of a Stotra are to be repeated, while the {%Viṣṭuti%}
explains the {%order%} in which such a repetition takes place;
comp. e. g. {%Mādh. Jaiminīyany.:%} {#tezu trizu tfcezUrDvagAnena tri-#}
{#vftstomo Bavati . na tvatra paYcadaSasaptadaSastomAdInAmivAvftta-#}
{#gAnamasti;#} or {#atra#} (I. 4. 3.) {#trizvapi vAkyezu trivftpaYcadaSasapta-#}
{#daSaSabdA guRaviDAyakatvena saMmatAH .…tasmAdvahizpavamA-#}
{#nAdiSabdAH stotranAmaDeyAni .--tErnAmaBiH karmARyanUdya tri-#}
{#vfdAdiguRA viDIyante#}). E. {#vft#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#Ramul#} (with the udātta on the penultimate, which ac-
cent the word would not have, if it were a regular accus.
of a deriv. with {#GaY#}).
<LEND>

<L>6762<pc>318-a<k1>aByASa<k2>aByASa
{#aByASa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-SaH-SA-Sam#}) Near, proximate;
e. g. {%Kumāras.:%} {#tayA vyAhftasaMdeSA sA baBO niBftA priye .#}
{#cUtayazwirivAByASe maDO#} (in the approaching spring) {#paraBf-#}
{#tonmuKI;#} or {%Patanj.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 50 v. 3: {#samIpIBavati .#}
{#aByASIBavati . antikIBavati#} &c.; comp. {#samaByASIkaraRa;#}
a noun depending on it stands in the gen. or abl.; e. g.
{%Kāś.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} II. 3. 34.: {#aByASaM grAmasya#} or {#grAmAt#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-Sam#}) Neighbourhood, vicinity; e. g. {%Mahābh.%}
{%Draupadīhar.:%} {#Danuzo'ByASamAgatya tasTO giririvAcalaH;#}
or {%Nalop.:%} {#sahasAByAgatAM BEmImaByASaparivartinIm . jagrAhA-#}
{#jagaraH#} &c.--It retains its abl. ending when compounded
with a past partic. in {#kta;#} e. g. {%Kāś.:%} {#aByASAdAgataH#}. [The
{%Amarak.%} and {%Hem.%} give the word as having three genders;
the {%Med.%} and {%Trikāṇḍaś.%} have the form {#aByAsa#} as a masc.
in the sense of {%vicinity;%} on the latter form see the remark
at the end. A masc. nom. {#aByASaH#} in the sense ‘neigh-
bourhood’, has not come under my observation; the cases
{#°Sasya, °Sam#} &c. are better referred to a neuter.]
<div n="P">3. m. ({#-SaH#}) Result, consequence; e. g. {%Chhānd. Up.:%}
{#sa ya etadevaM vidvAnsADu sAmetyupAste'ByASo ha yadenaM sADavo#}
{#DarmA A ca gacCeyurupa ca nameyuH#} ({%Śaṅk.:%} {#sADuguRavadvidvAMsta-#}
{#syEtatPalamaByASaH#} &c.); or {#tadya iha ramaRIyacaraRA aByASo#}
{#ha yatte ramaRIyAM yonimApadyeran#} ({%Śaṅk.:%} {#tenAnuSayena puRyena#}
{#karmaRA candramaRqale BuktaSezeRAByASo ha#} &c. (In other pas-
sages of {%Dr. Röer'%}s ed. of the {%Chh. Up.%} the word is written,
when implying the same sense, {#aByAsa,#} e. g. {#kAmaM DyAya-#}
{#nnapramatto'ByAso ha yadasmE sa kAmaH samfDyeta;#} or {#sa ya etamevaM#}
{#vidvAnAdityaM brahmetyupAste'ByAso ha yadenaM sADavo GozA A#}
{#ca gacCeyuH#} &c.) E. {#aS#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}. [The
comm. to the {%Amarak.%} who give only the sense ‘near’,
allow the word to be written {#aByASa#} or {#aByAsa,#} equally
so {%Vallabhag.%} on {%Hem.--Rāyamukuṭa%} is even at hand
with an E. {#sad#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#qa,#} which he
founds on the {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} III. 2. 101.; or {#as#} (cl. 4)
with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}. But though the confusion be-
tween the two forms is undeniable, it is certain that the
best Mss., and among them the grammatical ones, write
always {#aByASa#} in the sense of ‘near’; and it seems to me,
too, that the meaning ‘result’ is better referred to {#aByASa,#}
than to {#aByAsa,#} because it follows more naturally, like
that of ‘near’, from a radical expressing quickness, per-
vasion, than from the radical {#as,#} ‘to throw’. An ana-
logy for both meanings is afforded by {#aByAgama#} q. v.]
<LEND>

<L>6766<pc>318-b<k1>aByAsa<k2>aByAsa
{#aByAsa#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-saH#}) <sup>1</sup> Repetition, repeated occurence;
e. g. {%Manu:%} {#te'ByAsAtkarmaRAM tezAM pApAnAmalpabudDayaH . saM-#}
{#prApnuvanti duHKAni#} &c.; or {%Kātyāy. Śr. S.:%} {#aBiplavAByAse-#}
{#nABipUraRam;#} or {%Kumārila%} on a {%Mānava-Kalpa-S.:%} {#triri-#}
{#tyaByAso'nuvAdaH;#} or the {%Mit.%} on {%Yājnav.%} (2. 81.): {#etacca#}
{#…anaByAse ca drazwavyam . loBAdikAraRaviSezaparijYAne#}
{#'ByAse ca manunoktam;#} or the {%same%} on {%Yājn.%} (3. 255.): {#ajYA-#}
{#nato'ByAse tu vasizWenoktam .…jYAnato'ByAse tu SaNKo-#}
{#ktam .…atyantAByAse harItoktam;#} or {%Raghun. Prāya-%}
{%śchittat.%} (a quotation): {#goGnavadvihitaH kalpaScAndrAyaRamaTApi#}
{#vA . aByAse tu tayorBUyastataH SudDimavApnuyAt;#} or {%Jaimini-%}
{%Sūtras:%} {#AgneyastUktahetutvAdaByAsena pratIyeta;#} or {#yAvajjIviko#}
{#'ByAsaH karmaDarmaH;#} or {#aByAso vA vikArAtsyAt . paSustvevaM#}
{#praDAnaM syAdaByAsasya tannimittatvAtsamAsaSabdaH syAt;#} or {#arTa-#}
{#vAMstu nEkatvAdaByAsaH syAt…;#} or {#vediprokzaRe mantrAByAsaH#}
{#karmaRaH punaHprayogAt#} &c. &c.; or {%Ved. Sūtr.:%} {#Anandamayo#}
{#'ByAsAt;#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#paramAtmAnandamayo Bavitumarhati . kutaH .#}
{#aByAsAt . parasminneva hyAtmanyAnandaSabdo bahukftvo'Byasyate#});
or {%Nyāya-S.:%} {#nAnuvAdapunaruktayorviSezaH SabdAByAsopapatteH ..#}
{#SIGrataragamanopadeSavadaByAsAdviSezaH;#} or {#aByAsAt#} (sound
is permanent on account of its frequent occurrence) {#.. anyatve#}
{#'pyaByAsasyopacArAt;#} or {%Mādh. Jaiminīyany.:%} {#…sUktaM tri-#}
{#rAvartanIyam . tatra praTamAvfttO praTamAyA fcastriraByAsaH;#} or
{#aByAsAdanyakarmatvaM darSezwO dviH prayujyatAm#} &c. &.; or {%Mādh.%}
{%Sarvadarś. (Pāṇinid.):%} {#yaTA svADyAyaH sakftpaWyamAno nAva-#}
{#DAryate . aByAsena tu sPuwAvasAyaH#} &c.; or {%Mādhāva%} observes
in his comm. on the {%Aitareyabr.%} at the end of several chap-
ters, that the last word is to be repeated to indicate the
close of the chapter, e. g. the word {#Bavati#} at the end of
the first Adhyāya is to be repeated: {#BavatiSabdasyAByAso#}
{#'DyAyasamAptyarTaH;#} or at the end of the fifth Adhy. or the
first Pañchikā: {#aByAso'DyAyasamAptyarTaH,#} similarly at the
end of the seventh, ninth, tenth &c. &c. Adhyāyas. See
also s. v. {#AkUpAra#}. <sup>2</sup> Repeated practice, repeated use of
a thing, habit; e. g. {%Pāṇini:%} {#miTyopapadAtkfYo'ByAse;#} or
{%Yājnav.:%} {#tatrAtmA hi svayaM kiMcitkarma kiMcitsvaBAvataH .#}
{#karoti kiMcidaByAsAdDarmADarmoBayAtmakam;#} or {%Mit.%} on {%Yājn.%}
(3. 253.): {#aByAse tu surAyA iti vAsizWe#} &c.; or {%Medhāt.%} on
{%Manu:%} {#(vyasanasya ca mftyoSca vyasanaM kazwamucyate) vyasanaSabdenA-#}
{#tyantAByAsaH . etadvargavizaya ucyate#} (i. e. in the sense of ‘bad
habit, vice’); or {%Nyāya-S.%} (soul is eternal): {#pretyAhArAByA-#}
{#sakftAtstanyABilAzAt;#} or (knowledge of the absolute truth
increases) {#samADiviSezAByAsAt ..…araRyaguhApulinA-#}
{#dizu yogAByAsopadeSAt;#} or {%Suśruta:%} {#ASayyAByAsayogena#}
{#karotyASayasaMBavam;#} or {%Rājatar.:%} {#darSanAByAsasaMvfdDacacUrAgaH#}
{#kzamApatiH#} (comp. also the inst. s. v. {#anvaya#} p. 151{%b,%} 1. 45);
[Page319-a+ 56]
or {%Sāhityad.%} (v. 49): {#SikzAByAsAdimAtreRa rAGavAdeH svarU-#}
{#patAm . darSayannartako nEva rasasyAsvAdako Bavet#} (where {#Si-#}
{#kzAByAsa#} seems rather to be a Tatpur., than a Dwandwa).
<sup>3</sup> Repeated mental practise, study; e. g. {%Viśvan.%} on a {%Nyāya-%}
{%S.%} (3. 113. where it is mentioned as one of the twenty-
seven means to awaken memory): {#aByAsaH saMskArabAhulyam#}
({%abhyāsa%} means the multiplicity of mental impressions) {#.#}
{#etasya yadyapi nodboDakatvaM taTApi tAdfSe SIGramudvoDakasamava-#}
{#DAnaM syAdityASayena tadupanyAsaH . aByAso dfQatarasaMskAraH#}
(i. e. it means a mental impression which has become very
strong); or {%Sāṅkhya-Prav.:%} {#tattvAByAsAnneti netIti tyAgA-#}
{#dvivekasidDiH#} ‘discriminative knowledge becomes accom-
plished through the study of the twenty-five principles and
the avoiding of what is negatived in scriptural texts with
the words: “it is not…it is not…”’; or {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%}
{#evaM tattvAByAsAnnAsti na me nAhamityapariSezam . aviparyayA-#}
{#dviSudDaM kevalamutpadyate jYAnam;#} or {%Manu:%} {#vedAByAso hi viprasya#}
{#tapaH paramihocyate;#} or {%Yājnav.:%} {#yaTA viDAnena paWansAmagA-#}
{#yamavicyutam . sAvaDAnastadaByAsAtparaM brahmADigacCati;#} or
{%Bhartṛh. Vākyapadīya:%} {#aByAsapratiBAhetuH sarvaH SabdaH parEH#}
{#smftaH .…anAgamaSca so'ByAsaH samayaH kEScidizyate#}.
<sup>4</sup> Reading; e. g. {%Ṛgv. Prātiś.:%} {#aByAsArTe drutAM vfttiM prayo-#}
{#gArTe tu maDyamAm . SizyARAmupadeSArTe kuryAdvfttiM vilambitAm#}
‘let the quick way (i. e. quick time) be used at the reading
(of sacred texts), the middle in common discourse, the
slow in instructing pupils’. <sup>5</sup> Constant veneration; e. g.
{%Mahābh. Anuśāsanap.:%} {#aByAse nityaM devAnAM saptarzIRAM Druvasya#}
{#ca . mokzaRaM sarvakfcCrARAM mocayatyaSuBAtsadA#}. <sup>6</sup> (In {%Philo-%}
{%sophy%} and such passages of non-philosophical works as
refer to the philosophical doctrines, this word has been used
in the following manner: in the {%Mīmānsā%} and {%Nyāya%} it is
used only in the three first meanings as illustrated by some
instances from their Sūtras; in the {%Vedānta Sūtras%} equally
so, but in the {%later Vedānta%} it assumes also the sense)
<sup>a.</sup> {%inculcation of a truth conveyed in sacred writings by means%}
{%of repeating the same word or the same passage;%} it is one of
the six characteristics of the {#SravaRa#} or ascertaining the pur-
port of the Vedānta (see the enumeration of the other terms
s. v. {#apUrvatA#}): {%Ved. Sāra:%} {#prakaraRapratipAdyasya vastunastanmaDye#}
{#pOnaHpunyena pratipAdanamaByAsaH;#} by such repetitions are meant,
according to the {%Ved. Sāra,%} e. g. that of the words {#tattvamasi#}
which occur nine times in the sixth Prapāth. of the {%Chhānd.%}
{%Upan.;%} or, acc. to {%Rāmakṛṣṇat.%} that of {#sa eza neti neti#}
of the {%Bṛhadār.,%} or of the passage {#sa yaScAyam#} in the
{%Taitt. Up.,%} or of the passages {#yenAkzaraM puruzaM veda satyam,#}
{#tadetadakzaraM brahma, tamevEkaM vijAnITa AtmAnam#} (?) in the
{%Muṇḍaka Up.,%} &c. (In the {%Sāṅkhya Prav.%} it has also the
sense as illustrated before by instances from these Sūtras,
but in the {%Sūtra%} 6. 29. and the {%Yoga%} it means) <sup>b.</sup> {%the effort%}
{%of the mind to remain in its unmodified condition of purity%}
{%(sattwa) or that condition which is free from the affections of%}
{%passion (rajas) and sin (tamas): Yoga S.%} 1. 13.: {#tatra sTitO#}
{#yatno'ByAsaH#} ({%Patanjali'%}s {%comm.:%} {#cittasyAvfttikasya praSAnta-#}
{#vAhitA sTitiH#}--comp. 3. 10.--{#tadarTaprayatnI vIryamutsAhaH .#}
{#tatsaMpipAdayizayA tatsADanAnuzWAnamaByAsaH;#} {%Vāchaspatim.%} on
these words: {#cittasyAvfttikasya rAjasatAmasavfttirahitasya#}
[Page319-b+ 56]
{#praSAntavAhitA vimalatA sAttvikavfttivAhitEkAgratA sTitiH#}
&c.; {%Bhojad. Rājamārt.:%} {#vfttirahitasya cittasya svarUpanizWA-#}
{#pariRAmaH sTitiH#}); {%this effort becomes consolidated or firm if%}
{%it is persevered in during a long time, unremittingly and%}
{%through the accomplishments (of penance, chastity, wisdom and%}
{%faith): Yoga S.%} 1. 14.: {#sa tu dIrGakAlanErantaryasatkArAsevito#}
{#dfQaBUmiH#} ({%Patanj.'%}s {%comm.:%} {#dIrGakAlAsevitaH . nirantarAse-#}
{#vitaH . tapasA brahmacaryeRa vidyayA SradDayA ca saMpAditaH satkA-#}
{#ravAndfQaBUmirBavati . vyutTAnasaMskAreRa drAgityevAnaBiBUtavi-#}
{#zaya ityarTaH;#} according to the {%Rājamārtaṇḍa ‘through the%}
{%accomplishment of great respect’:%} {#bahukAlaM nErantaryeRAdarA-#}
{#tiSayena ca sevyamAno dfQaBUmiH sTiro Bavati dArQyAya pra-#}
{#BavatItyarTaH#}); it is together with {#vErAgya#} (q. v.) the means
to hinder the modifications of the mind which are called
{#pramARa, viparyaya, vikalpa, nidrA#} and {#smfti#} qq. vv.; {%Yoga S.%}
1. 12.: {#aByAsavErAgyAByAM tanniroDaH;#} (comp. also the {%Sūtra%}
1. 18.: {#virAmapratyayAByAsapUrvasaMskAraSezo'nyaH#}); the word is
used in the stated sense in the {%S. Prav. Sūtra:%} {#DyAnaDAra-#}
{#RAByAsavErAgyAdiBistanniroDaH#} ({%Vijnānabh.:%} {#samADidvArA#}
{#DyAnaM yogasya kAraRaM DyAnasya ca kAraRaM DAraRA tasyASca kA-#}
{#raRamaByAsaScittasTEryasADanAnuzWAnamaByAsasyApi kAraRaM vizaya-#}
{#vErAgyam#} &c.); {#aByAsa#} has this {%technical%} Yoga-sense also,
for instance, in these verses: {%Bhagavadgītā%} (6. 35.): {#asaMSayaM#}
{#mahAbAho mano durnirgrahaM calam . aByAsena tu kOnteya vErA-#}
{#gyeRa ca gfhyate#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#aByAso nAma cittaBUmO kasyAMci-#}
{#tsamAnapratyayA vfttiH…gfhyate niruDyata ityarTaH;#} {%Sadānanda:%}
{#aByAsena viSudDena vErAgyeRa nigfhyate . aByAso nAma kasyAM-#}
{#ciccittaBUmO nirantaram . samAnapratyayA vfttiScittasyADiviyo-#}
{#ginaH#}); or (12. 9.) {#aTa cittaM samADAtuM na Saknozi mayi sTiram .#}
{#aByAsayogena tato mAmicCAptuM DanaYjaya ..#} ({%Śaṅk.:%} {#cittasyE-#}
{#kasminnAlambane sarvataH samAhftya punaH punaH sTApanamaByAsaH .#}
{#tatpUrvako yogaH samADAnalakzaRastenAByAsayogena#} &c.; {%Sadān.:%}
{#cetasaH sTApanaM BUyo BUyo'ByAsaH sa ucyate . tatpUrvakasamA-#}
{#Diryastena mAM prAptumISvaram#}) {#aByAse'pyasamarTo'si matkarmapara-#}
{#mo Bava .…Sreyo hi jYAnamaByAsAjjYAnAdDyAnaM viSizyate .#}
{#DyAnAtkarmaPalatyAgastyAgAcCAntiranantaram;#} or {%Mahābh. Śān-%}
{%tip.:%} {#taTEtadantaraM vidyAtsattvakzetrajYayorbuDaH . aByAsAtsa taTA#}
{#yukto na gacCetprakftiM punaH#} ({%Arjunam.:%} {#taTA nErmalyena yukto#}
{#yadi tadA na prakftisaNgaM gacCet#} which explanation {#‘nErmalyena’#}
will become intelligible when compared with the definition
of the term, as applying to the condition of {#sattva#}); comp.
also {%Mādhava'%}s {%Sarvadarś.:%} {#tatra maDumatI nAmAByAsavErAgyA-#}
{#divaSAdapAstarajastamoleSasuKaprakASamayasattvaBAvanayAnavadyavE-#}
{#SAradyavidyotanarUpa ftamBaraprajYAKyA samADisidDiH#}. <sup>7</sup> (In
{%Grammar.%}) <sup>a.</sup> Reduplication (in general); e. g. {%Nirukta%} (on
the word {#babDAm#}): {#AdinAByAsenopahitenopaDAmAdatte baBa-#}
{#stirattakarmA#}. <sup>b.</sup> (In {%Pāṇini.%}) The first syllable of the re-
duplicated base; {%Pāṇ.:%} {#pUrvo'ByAsaH#}. See the explanation
s. v. {#aByasta#} 2. (In this sense, and not in the general sense
{%reduplication,%} the term is also understood in the {%Vārttikas%}
and the other commentaries on {%Pāṇ.;%} e. g. VI. 1. 12. v. 9;
16. v. 3; 17. v. 1; 30. v. 1; 135. v. 5; VII. 4. 58. v. 1; 67. v. 1;
82. v. 3; VIII. 2. 3. v. 7; 6. v. 11;--or I. 1. 65. paribh. 1;
VII. 4. 83. paribh. 1. 2.)--<sup>8</sup> (In {%Poetry.%}) The repetition
of a word or verse in a stanza, or of the stanza itself;
e. g. {%Lāṭyāy. Śr. Sūtr.:%} {#aByAso gUrdasya#} (the stanza {%Sāmav.%}
[Page320-a+ 56]
2. 457-459.) {#. aByAsAdiruttarezAM trayARAm#} ({%Agnisvāmin:%} {#dvi-#}
{#tIyapAde yanmaDyamaM caturakzaramaByasyate sa pratihAraH#} &c.).--
In the late artificial poetry there are four kinds of such
repetitions which bear the name {#aByAsa,#} viz. {#pAdAByAsa,#}
{#arDAByAsa, sarvAByAsa#} and {#SlokAByAsa#} qq. vv.; the general
name, however, for repetitions of syllables, words or verses
is {#yamaka#} q. v. (where all the names of the subdivisions will
be found). <sup>9</sup> (In {%Arithmetic.%}) <sup>a.</sup> Multiplication; (more
usual terms, however, are {#aBihati, Ahati, guRana#}). <sup>b.</sup> Pro-
duct of multiplication; e. g. (for both meanings) {%Vījagaṇ.:%}
{#vajrAByAsO jyezWalaGvostadEkyaM hrasvaM laGvorAhatiSca prakftyA . kzuRRA#}
{#jyezWAByAsayugjyezWamUlaM tatrAByAsaH kzepayoH kzepakaH syAt;#} ‘the
greatest and least roots are to be reciprocally multiplied
crosswise; and the sum of the products to be taken for a
least root. The product of the two (original) ‘least’ roots
being multiplied by the given coefficient and the product
of the ‘greatest’ roots being added thereto, the sum is the
corresponding greatest root; and the product of the addi-
tives will be the (new) additive’; {%Colebrooke'%}s {%Alg.%} p. 171.
<sup>10</sup> (In {%military terminology.%}) Archery; (as such the word is
named in several {%Koshas: Hem., Trik., Bhūripr.;%} while
{%Hemach.%} e. g. sometimes adds the word for {%bow%} or {%arrow%}
which is supplied; thus, {%nānārth.%} 3. 730.: {#AkarzaH pASake#}
{#DanvAByAsANge dyUta indriye;#} or 4. 163.: {#upAsanamAsane . SuSrU-#}
{#zAyAM SarAByAse#} &c.; elsewhere it has, with this sense and
without the addition of {#Sara#} or {#Danu,#} not come under my ob-
servation, except, where its elliptical sense may be easily
supplied, in the) {%Dhanurveda:%} {#…kumBakena sTiraM kftvA huMkA-#}
{#reRa visarjayet . ityaByAsakriyA kAryA DanvinA sidDimicCatA#}.
<div n="P">[II. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-saH-sA-sam#}) The same as
{#aByASa#} which is the more correct form.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-saH#}) <sup>1</sup> Result, consequence; e. g. {%Chhānd. Up.:%}
{#sa ya etamevaM vidvAnAdityaM brahmetyupAste'ByAso ha yadenaM sADa-#}
{#vo GozA A ca gacCeyurupa ca nimreqerannimreqeran#} (ed. {%Röer%}
p. 232); or {#AtmAnamantata upasftya stuvIta kAmaM DyAyannapramatto#}
{#'ByAso ha yadasmE sa kAmaH samfDyeta#} &c. (ed. {%Röer%} p. 49).--
See {#aByASa#} 3. <sup>2</sup> Neighbourhood, vicinity; e. g. {%Mahābh.%}
{%Ādip.:%} {#rorUyamARasyAByAse BfSaM viprasya pARqavaH#} &c.; or
{%Vanap.:%} {#tatrAByAsasTo'pi kaScinnApaSyat;#} or {%Rāmāy.:%} {#aByetya#}
{#tvaramARaSca raTAByAsaM manIziRaH#} &c.; or {%Daśakum.:%} {#adarSaM#}
{#ca mArgAByAsavartinaH kasyApi kzapaRavihArasya#} &c.--In both
meanings the writing {#aByASa#} which occurs, too, in some
Mss. of the passages quoted, is more correct. See the
remark under the latter word, also as regards the masc.
gender of the second meaning.] E. {#as#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6767<pc>320-a<k1>aByAsanimitta<k2>aByAsanimitta
{#aByAsanimitta#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ttam#}) (In comm. on {%Pāṇini.%}) The
cause of the reduplication-syllable; e. g. a {%Vārtt.%} in the
{%Kāś.%} (not in the {%Bhāṣya%}) to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#svAperRyantasyAByAsanimi-#}
{#ttena pratyayenAnantarye sati saMprasAraRamizyate#}. E. {#aByAsa#} and
{#nimitta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6768<pc>320-a<k1>aByAsayoga<k2>aByAsayoga
{#aByAsayoga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) Deep meditation preceded by
the effort to keep the mind in its unmodified condition or
in that of goodness. See {#aByAsa#} 6. b. and the instance
p. 319{%b,%} 1. 30. Comp. {#aDyAsayoga#}. E. {#aByAsa#} and {#yoga#}.
<LEND>

[Page320-b+ 56]
of the reduplication-syllable; e. g. in {#dehi, Dehi#} &c.: a
{%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#GvasoredDAvaByAsalopaSca;#} (comp. {%Pāṇ.:%} {#atra#}
{#lopo'ByAsasya#}). E. {#aByAsa#} and {#lopa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6770<pc>320-b<k1>aByAsavikAra<k2>aByAsavikAra

change (esp. of the vowel) in the syllable of reduplication;

of the intens. verbs: {#cecIyate, lolUyate, pApacyate, yAya-#}
{#jIti#}); e. g. a {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#na vAByAsavikArezvapavAda-#}
{#syotsargabADakatvAt;#} or a {%Paribhāṣā:%} {#aByAsavikArezvapa-#}
{#vAdA utsargAnviDInna bADante#}. E. {#aByAsa#} and {#vikAra#}.
<LEND>

{#s#} to {#z#} and the latter) {%Pat.%} on a {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#(tadvyavAye#}
